Rickety. For at least the past 40 years, that’s been the default modifier for the Orange Bowl Stadium, a Miami landmark since 1937. Electric is more fitting. Start with the shock upon arrival when the guy told you, “treinta” -- $30 -- to park on his lawn. When the stands shook and swayed, it registered on the Richter Scale. A big-play roar for the home team was like Niagara Falls from the Maid of the Mist. Homefield advantage? Huge. The Dolphins played there from 1966 to 1988, went unbeaten in 1972, and made it to four Super Bowls. None since. The University of Miami has won five National Championships since 1985, the most in college football. Now the Hurricanes are turning out the lights at the Orange Bowl for the last time after their game against Virginia on Saturday and will move to Dolphins Stadium in North Miami in 2008. Less rickety, less electricity.

DAVID BINNEY BIG BAND The alto saxophonist David Binney has blazed an impressive trail through the New York jazz landscape over the years, almost exclusively on his own terms. Mr. Binney, above, can often be heard setting off depth charges in cozy settings like the 55 Bar, where his intensely cohesive groups enjoy a presiding eminence, for good reason. (See the ''gig download'' section of davidbinney.com.) Outside the New York nexus Mr. Binney's reputation is strong but a bit distorted; last year's Downbeat Critics Poll patronizingly designated him a ''rising star'' on his instrument, even though he's in his mid-40s, having lighted upon New York from Southern California more than 25 years ago. That honor would have been appropriate in the 1990s, when Mr. Binney was still establishing both his style and his footing. He started Mythology Records about a decade ago, and since then he has averaged an album a year, some on other independent labels. Last year he released not only ''Out of Airplanes'' (Mythology), featuring the guitarist Bill Frisell, but also ''Cities and Desire'' (Criss Cross) with the tenor saxophonist Mark Turner. His only 2007 title is ''Océanos'' (Criss Cross), a collaboration with the pianist Edward Simon that's as notable for its compositions -- Mr. Binney contributed half of them -- as for its high standard of improvisation.

FOR CHILDREN 'A DOLPHIN UP A TREE!' (Tomorrow and Sunday) The only dolphins around New York can be found in the water, typically in the aquarium on Coney Island. But these days at least one member of the species occupies a far more unusual position: up a tree in Manhattan. The title character in this show by Kimberly Foster (book and lyrics) and John Fleming (music and lyrics) is actually a little girl under a spell. A headline yesterday with an article about discussions between Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and South Korea's minister of national defense, Kim Jang-soo, misattributed a comment about North Korea in some copies. It was Mr. Kim who said that North Korea remains a military threat -- not Mr. Gates, who said that much work remained to make certain that North Korea had surrendered its nuclear weapons and its weapons development programs.

A sports article yesterday about Bode Miller's effort to race independently in Alpine skiing referred imprecisely to his goal in World Cup competition. Although he is trying to surpass Phil Mahre in victories, doing so would make him the most successful American man to compete on the World Cup circuit -- not the most successful racer in history, a distinction held by Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden, with 86 wins. (Miller has 25 career World Cup victories; Mahre had 27.)

Wolfgang Wagner, below, the embattled 88-year-old chief of the Wagner Festival in Bayreuth, Germany, was a no-show at a meeting on Tuesday dominated by the politicians and businessmen who are members of the Bayreuth Foundation, which supervises the festival, The Times of London reported. At the gathering, they called upon all contenders to succeed Mr. Wagner to prepare plans for the future of the annual event, devoted to the works of his grandfather Richard Wagner. Amid mounting pressure to step aside, Mr. Wagner, who has run the festival since 1966, was represented by his lawyer in what The Times called ''an often passionate and irritable debate'' over leadership of the festival, which has always been held by a member of the Wagner clan. Mr. Wagner, who has his job for life unless it can be established that he has lost his faculties, wants leadership to pass to Katharina Wagner, 29, his daughter from his second marriage. The other main contenders are relatives in their 60s: Eva Wagner-Pasquier, a daughter from his first marriage; and Nike Wagner, his niece and the daughter of Wieland Wagner, his brother, who died in 1966.

The 41st Annual Country Music Association Awards show attracted 16 million viewers on Wednesday, matching its performance a year ago, according to Nielsen's estimates. The large audience put ABC on top of the ratings during every hour of prime time. CBS ranked second, easily securing the runner-up spot at 9 p.m. and 10 with ''Criminal Minds'' (14.5 million), followed by ''CSI: NY'' (12.9 million). The race for second place at 8 p.m., however, remained competitive. The CW's ''America's Next Top Model'' (5.1 million) was No. 2 among adults 18 to 49, while CBS's ''Kid Nation'' delivered the second-most total viewers in the hour (7.2 million). At 9, NBC's ''Bionic Woman'' (6.4 million) shared third place in its time slot with Fox's ''Kitchen Nightmares'' (6.4 million), although the NBC show slipped to fourth place in the 18-to-49 set. For the night, NBC tied Fox in third.

HOT springs north of San Francisco are open year round, though inland from the coast, summer can be brutally hot. The springs are delightful in winter, as steam rises from the pools, and the cold plunges grow frigid. At Harbin Hot Springs (18424 Harbin Springs Road, Middletown; 707-987-2477; www.harbin.org) a one-hour session of Watsu, a massage in warm water that is a Harbin specialty, is $70 (the expected tip for body work at these resorts is about 20 percent). Accommodations range from camping for $25 a night to cottages for $260. Clothing is optional in tubs and pools. Guests can use the kitchen or buy meals; a big plate of tofu and steamed vegetables with peanut sauce, green salad and a drink runs about $20. Alcohol is not allowed.

La Scala in Milan canceled tonight's long-awaited performance of Verdi's ''Requiem,'' the capstone of a year of events commemorating the 50th anniversary of the death of Arturo Toscanini, The Associated Press reported. The concert, which was to have been conducted by Daniel Barenboim, the house's principal guest conductor, was called off in response to a strike by 800 employees.

(Discovery) BEAR'S MISSION EVEREST Bear Grylls, above, the adventurer and sort-of survivalist who was criticized recently for having a little assistance from his crew during his wilderness stints, travels to the Himalayas to fulfill a dream of flying a powered paraglider higher than Mount Everest in this hourlong special. (In 1998, at 23, Mr. Grylls became the youngest British climber to complete a summit and descent of that mountain.) At 9 he begins a new season of ''Man vs. Wild,'' focusing on three geographic areas for two weeks each, offering tips culled from experts on enduring extreme climates. First: the heat of the barren Sahara. 8 P.M. (ABC) MEN IN TREES Wolves descend on Elmo, leaving Marin (Anne Heche) and Jack (James Tupper) foaming at the mouth in this two-part episode. HILL--Janet E. (Schwartz), death came to Janet near midnight as November 5th, 2007 came to a close. Until the end, after battling death valiantly for 19 years, Janet's spark of life finally gave way when her weary struggling spirit surrendered to the inevitable. She leaves behind grieving parents, Marvin and Gloria Schwartz, her devoted son, Joshua, two beloved brothers, Robert M. Schwartz, Esq. and Dr. John J. Schwartz, John's dear wife, Lynda Harbold Schwartz, niece, Laura, nephew, Jack, and loving aunt, Arline Feigen. Two days after NBC acknowledged that it was talking to Rosie O'Donnellabout a possible show on MSNBC, those conversations have stalled, with no immediate prospect of being revived, an executive of the network said Wednesday night. Ms. O'Donnell said as much in a posting to her Web site, rosie.com, earlier in the evening. The NBC executive, who would describe the negotiations only on condition of anonymity, said a principal hurdle had been the length of a potential contract. To preserve her options, Ms. O'Donnell would commit only to a year, the executive said. But the network wanted a deal for at least two years. A publicist for Ms. O'Donnell, Cindi Berger, did not dispute the NBC executive's assessment. ''Things do happen for a reason,'' she said yesterday. ''No harm, no foul. It didn't work out now. We leave the door open for other opportunities.''

ELLEN FISHER After less than an hour's sampling of a rehearsal for Ellen Fisher's forthcoming solo, ''Time's Up ... ... Scenes 1-12,'' you stumble out into the Manhattan streets feeling as if you've been through multiple worlds and mental states. Who knows what will take place tomorrow when Ms. Fisher presents her entire three-hour dance installation at the Roulette gallery? The piece is built around a dozen 15-minute music segments, which Ms. Fisher requested from various artists, including the composer-choreographer Meredith Monk. (Ms. Fisher is in Ms. Monk's vocal ensemble.) Some, like the singer-songwriter Rachel Loshak, and the visual artists Don Voisine and Mark Dagley, responded with original compositions, which will have their premieres at the performance. Others, like the fashion designer Gary Graham, chose a selection of songs. (He threw in some costume changes as well.) Ms. Fisher took what each person submitted without editing the songs or their order.

The longstanding question of financing the reconstruction of Berlin's old city palace has finally been resolved. The German parliament will support the project with $645 million. The budget commission limited the cost to $810 million, and a private association and the state of Berlin will make up the difference. Built in the Middle Ages, the city palace became the principal residence of the kings of Prussia in 1701. It was severely damaged by Allied bombs in 1945 and demolished in 1950 by the East German Communist authorities, who viewed it as a reminder of the imperial past and erected the Palace of the Republic in its place in the 1970s.

'BEYOND THE WALL: KIDS WITH CAMERAS -- JERUSALEM' In Israel, Jewish and Muslim children rarely see the world through one another's eyes. But not long ago, some did -- with the help of a camera's lens. The results are at the JCC in Manhattan, where ''Beyond the Wall'' illustrates the efforts of Jason Eskenazi, a New York photojournalist, to teach photography to children who were neighbors but seemed hopelessly divided by religion and politics. Mr. Eskenazi, with a grant from the nonprofit group Kids With Cameras, traveled to Jerusalem in 2004 with 24 point-and-shoot cameras. By distributing leaflets in the Muslim quarter, he recruited a dozen Muslims, all 8 to 12; a Jewish center helped find an equal number of Jews the same ages. Mr. Eskenazi met with each group separately. ''The goal was to make a portrait of Jerusalem,'' he said. But he also had a more difficult, and at first hidden, objective: someday to show each group the other's work.

WAELSCH--Salome G., Ph.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the loss of our Distinguished University Professor Emerita of Molecular Genetics. World renowned for her contributions to the field of developmental genetics, and one of the pioneering woman scientists of the 20th century, Dr. Waelsch was a founding member of the Einstein faculty, joining the medical school when it opened in 1955. She was the leading force in the creation of our Department of Genetics, which she chaired from 1963 to 1976. Until she reached her mid-90s, she graced this campus with her presence, her scientific brilliance, and her lively interactions with faculty colleagues and students. Among her many accolades, she was awarded the National Medal of Science, the nation's highest scientific honor, in 1993, and was elected to membership in the National Academy of Sciences in 1979. She was the recipient of the Thomas Hunt Morgan Medal of the Genetics Society of America and received the first Lifetime Achievement Award presented by the American Cancer Society. She was an Honorary Life Member of The New York Academy of Sciences, a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and a foreign member of the Royal Society of London. Dr. Waelsch's personal history has a special resonance for this College of Medicine, the first medical school established in the United States under Jewish auspices. She escaped from Nazi Germany in 1933. When invited back to her alma mater, the University of Freiburg, nearly 50 years later to receive an honorary degree for her scientific accomplishments, she refused to attend. Her refusal, she said in a letter to the University, was in honor of all of those who suffered under the Nazi regime, among them the man whose name our medical school carries with the greatest pride. We at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine are proud to have had Dr. Waelsch among us for nearly half a century. Her legacy of scientific accomplishment and moral imperative continues to inspire us, and she will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to her daughter, Naomi Kerest, her son, Peter, and her three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

TODOROVICH--Branka Opacic. Born on June 23, 1927 in Pristina, Jugoslavia, Branka was raised in Belgrade, graduating from its Academy of Fine Arts. She married Professor Miroslav Todorovich on February 18, 1951. They emigrated to NYC in the mid 1950s. Branka attended the Music Department of the Columbia School of General Studies. Branka was the office manager at a doctor's office on the Upper West Side. She achieved a third degree karate black belt. Branka was the beloved mother of Mark (Amy), Mira (Kirk) Kanzelberger, and grandmother of Leo, Sophia, Petar, George, and Thomas Kanzelberger. Branka is fondly remembered for her kindness to all who had the privilege to know her, her practical wisdom and her culinary gifts. Branka passed away on November 5, 2007 after a long illness. Funeral services will be held at 12 Noon on Saturday November 10th at the Cathedral of Saint Sava, 25th between Broadway and 6th Ave, with a brief visitation to be held at 11:30 in the Cathedral. For further information, contact Krtil Funeral Home, 212744-3084.

Claudio Abbado, left, is back on the podium. Two months after he canceled all appearances for the near future -- including a much-awaited visit to Carnegie Hall with the Lucerne Festival Orchestra in early October -- Mr. Abbado led performances on Tuesday and Wednesday in Bologna, Italy, with members of the Orchestra Mozart, which he directs. Mr. Abbado, who suffered from stomach cancer, had cited poor health and the advice of doctors but did not disclose what was wrong. A spokesman for Orchestra Mozart, Diego Ravetti, said Mr. Abbado, 74, had undergone a small surgical procedure unrelated to his past illness and been ordered to rest as a precaution. ''He's in good form,'' Mr. Ravetti said. ''He came back to life. He suffers away from the podium.''

GOLDFLUSS--Hon. Howard E., 83, passed away in New York City on November 7, 2007. Beloved husband of Laura Yarvin for 58 years. Devoted father of Ellen Kaden and Lisa Goldfluss Bestor. Cherished grandfather of David and Rebecca Kaden. In the course of his wonderful, wide-ranging career, Howard was a trial lawyer, Judge of the Criminal Court of the City of New York, Justice of the Supreme Court of the State of New York, successful novelist and author, talk show host and news commentator on radio stations WMCA, WOR and WVOX, commentator for Fox 5 TV News, newspaper columnist, Adjunct Professor of Criminology at Fordham University, and member of the New York State Commission on Child Abuse and Neglect. A proud member of the greatest generation, Howard served his country with devotion in the Second World War. The loves of his life were his family, the law, and his friends at the Friars Club. Services will be held at 11:15am on Sunday, November 11 at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York.

'FOLKERT DE JONG: LES SALTIMBANQUES' Folkert de Jong is a young Dutch sculptor, though looking at his debut New York solo show at the James Cohan Gallery in Chelsea you would swear he was from Los Angeles. He makes life-size sculptural tableaus that bring to mind the grotesque masked figures inhabiting the Los Angeles stalwart Paul McCarthy's video performances, not to mention his use of icky, viscous industrial insulation materials like Styrofoam and polyurethane. Then there is the palette -- sky blue, bubble-gum pink, burning reds and a toxic green -- making the figures look like elaborately costumed visitors at a Halloween party, or melted department-store mannequins. His aesthetic roots also reach back into Modern European art, specifically Picasso's paintings of the Harlequin, an archetypal itinerant circus performer and lonely adventurer. For the youthful Picasso the Harlequin was a kind of alter ego, reflecting the alienation of an aspiring artist and foreigner living alone in Paris. Mr. de Jong's interest in the Harlequin feels more complicated than this, with him arranging groups of Harlequin figures in acrobatic formations (above, ''The Tower 'Violin Player''') or huddled about a fire in an oil drum. They are real people, if a little coldblooded. And they are also metaphors of a sort, pointing up the condition of the contemporary artist: a beggared fool performing for the wealthy. (Through Nov. 24, James Cohan Gallery, 533 West 26th Street, Chelsea, 212-714 9500, jamescohan.com.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

A federal judge has ruled in favor of Penguin Putnam, a unit of Penguin Group, in a case in which it was accused of copyright infringement when it published ''Dorothy Parker, Complete Poems.'' In the case, Stuart Y. Silverstein, a Los Angeles lawyer who researched and assembled 122 previously uncollected poems and verses in the book ''Not Much Fun: The Lost Poems of Dorothy Parker,'' said Penguin had used his book as source material without crediting him. He argued that he was entitled to ''compilation copyright'' for the creativity he had showed by including or recategorizing some poems that other scholars had said were not proper poems, and by excluding others that scholars had said were Parker's work. Judge John F. Keenan, of Federal District Court in Manhattan, who signed the most recent decision, ruled in 2003 that Penguin had infringed Mr. Silverstein's copyright and ordered the publisher to recall its books. Penguin appealed, and in May 2004 a federal appeals court concluded that Mr. Silverstein's copyright interest was slight and ordered the case to return to Federal District Court for a further ruling. On Wednesday Judge Keenan dismissed Mr. Silverstein's complaint, ruling that he did not demonstrate any creativity in selecting the poems that appeared in ''Not Much Fun.''

'BEATIFIC SOUL: JACK KEROUAC ON THE ROAD' The celebration of the 50th anniversary of the publication of Jack Kerouac's ''On the Road'' continues this week, as the New York Public Library opens this new exhibition of Kerouac's diaries, manuscripts, photographs and other personal items, including his collections of fantasy baseball and horse racing materials, his harmonicas and his Buddhist bells. At the center of the exhibition, opening today, is the original 120-foot scroll on which Kerouac wrote ''On the Road.'' Viking, the original publisher of the novel in its edited form, released a book version of the scroll in September.

NEW YORK COMEDY FESTIVAL Charlie Murphy's pursuit of a career in stand-up seems like the set-up for a joke his brother Eddie would have used in ''Raw'' -- one that would have begun with a description of a brother riding his coattails and ended in a perfectly timed, expletive-heavy punch line. Fortunately, Charlie Murphy, above, is well aware of the comedic possibilities of having a famous sibling. If his past shows are any indication, when he takes the stage at Caroline's during the final weekend of the New York Comedy Festival, his best bits will be self-deprecating ones in which names are dropped liberally. (In addition to his brother, he can always draw easy applause by mentioning ''Chappelle's Show,'' on which he also mined life in his brother's entourage for material.) And while his delivery doesn't have the punch of, say, a Chris Rock, his humor is serviceable enough to draw more than a few guilty laughs. Another festival performer for whom comedy is a family enterprise is Damon Wayans, who has shared a stage or a television show or a movie with several of his relatives. Mr. Wayans has gone from controversial on ''In Living Color'' to wholesome on ABC's ''My Wife and Kids,'' and back again. Which Mr. Wayans will show up at the Beacon Theater? Probably not the one who dutifully appeared in an ABC sitcom predictable enough to require a laugh track.

Thanks to a tip from Stanford Athletic Director Bob Bowlsby, I found this list of the most expensive and least expensive college towns in the United States to live in. Bowlsby knows this, of course, because Palo Alto is the most expensive, with the average price of a 4-bedroom, 2,200 square-foot house being $1.67 million. This led to Stanford beginning an innovative new program where they actually buy houses for their football team coordinators to live in and give the assistant coaches a $3,000 per month housing stipend. That would buy a mansion in Muncie, Ind., the home of Ball State and the least expensive university town. A 4-bedroom house there costs an average of $150,000. The list was compiled by Coldwell Banker and is available to see here. Definitely some surprising numbers scattered throughout.

Need a sign that things are different this season at Stanford? Look no further than the tin of Skoal tobacco on the desk of Coach Jim Harbuagh. Harbaugh is the Cardinal's fiery first-year coach and a longtime N.F.L. quarterback. He replaced the bookish Walt Harris. (Harris always made it a point to say that he bought The New York Times on Tuesdays to read the Science Times section.) Harbaugh often tells his players to "approach this day with an enthusiasm unknown to mankind." He won them over, in part, by running wind sprints with them and jumping in to quarterback some two-minute drills in practice. He won over the country by beating top-ranked U.S.C. as a 41-point underdog. Now can he win over recruits? Here's the always free-spirited Harbaugh talking about growing up in a football family, Stanford's limited recruiting pool and why his coordinators get free houses.

HARTMANN--Thomas Buchan, of Montgomery Township, NJ, died peacefully on November 7th. He was 85 years old. He entered Princeton University in 1941 and was one of the first Princeton undergraduates to volunteer to serve in World War II. As a dive bomber pilot in the Marine Corps, he flew 89 combat missions in the Pacific and received the Distinguished Flying Cross. Tom began his teaching career at the Hun School in Princeton and later became professor of Journalism and Mass Media at Rutgers University. He was well known for his unselfish personal service to public institutions and leaders at the municipal, state and national levels. He worked closely with Senator Bill Bradley in his campaigns and was a founding member and trustee of Outward Bound, USA. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Martha, three daughters and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held December 1st at 1:00pm at the Unitarian Church in Princeton.

SCHOENFELD--Gertrude P., 98, died quietly on November 7, 2007. Formerly of New York City and Ft. Lee, NJ, for two years she was tenderly cared for at the Regent Care Center, Hackensack, NJ. Graduate of Hunter College, 1931. Devoted wife of the late Arthur K. Schoenfeld with whom she founded their business, Arthur Kermit Associates, Englewood, NJ. Beloved mother of Susan Teltser Schwarz and mother-inlaw of the late Richard L. Teltser and Arthur L. Schwarz. Dear sister of Florence Dickstein and the late Rosalind Deimel. ''Gram'' to Julie T. Meyer and Peggy Galant and her husband John Galant, ''Great-Gram'' to Ryan and Riesling Meyer and Pamela Jordan Galant. Interment private. A memorial service will be held at the Harvard Club of New York City on Saturday, November 17, at 1:30pm.

LEVINSON--Steven Jay. A magnificent man! Bede's besheirt. Adored father of Matthew and (Nicole), Ethan and (Jamie), Rachel and (Ryan Bailine). Beloved Zaydie of Jacob, Max and Henry. A valiant warrior to the end. A man who never forgot where he came from and always knew where he was going. All those who were blessed to have known his grace, his style, his wisdom, his generosity and his humor will miss him and carry him in their hearts forever. Memorial contributions can be made to: Trustees of Columbia University; Dr. Abby Siegel Research Fund #

GOLDFLUSS--Howard. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Howard Goldfluss. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Services will be held on Sunday, November 11th, at Riverside Memorial, 180 West 76th Street, at 11:15 am. Jerry Lewis, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Michael Gyure, Executive Director GOLDFLUSS--Hon. Howard E./d, 83, passed away in New York City on November 7, 2007. Beloved husband of Laura Yarvin for 58 years. Devoted father of Ellen Kaden and Lisa Goldfluss Bestor. Loving father-in-law of Lewis Kaden and Geoffrey Bestor. Cherished grandfather of David and Rebecca Kaden. In the course of his wonderful, wide-ranging career, Howard was a trial lawyer, Judge of the Criminal Court of the City of New York, Justice of the Supreme Court of the State of New York, successful novelist and author, talk show host and news commentator on radio stations WMCA, WOR and WVOX, commentator for Fox 5 TV News, newspaper columnist, Adjunct Professor of Criminology at Fordham University, and member of the New York State Commission on Child Abuse and Neglect. A proud member of the greatest generation, Howard served his country with devotion in the Second World War. The loves of his life were his family, the law, and his friends at the Friars Club. Services will be held at 11:15am on Sunday, November 11 at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York.

REFINERY FIRE The Valero Energy Corporation, the biggest United States refiner, said its refinery in Port Arthur, Tex., was processing 185,000 barrels of oil a day, about 57 percent of capacity, after a fire early yesterday. Output is expected to increase over the next few days as the company begins to bring the refinery back into operation, Bill Day, a company spokesman, said in an e-mail message. The fire in the refinery's diesel hydrotreater followed a power disruption, Mr. Day said. The refinery, Valero's largest, is capable of processing 325,000 barrels of oil a day, the company said. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

HILLMAN--Rita K. Founding Trustee, Honorary Chairman, and generous benefactor of the International Center of Photography, Rita was much admired and loved by her fellow trustees and the ICP staff. We were honored to have had her friendship, counsel, and support since the earliest days of this institution, which she helped establish and whose educational work with young people gave her particular satisfaction. Our affection for her was accompanied by gratitude for her generosity and encouragement, unfailing wisdom, delightful sense of humor, and keen intelligence. She was a true New Yorker, a gracious presence and an indomitable spirit. Our profound condolences to the entire Hillman Family, the Hillman Foundation, and to the many who were touched by her. Gayle Greenhill, Chairman Jeffrey A. Rosen, President Cornell Capa, Founding Director Emeritus Willis E. Hartshorn, Ehrenkranz Director International Center of Photography

10 P.M. (Cinemax) THE LAST KING OF SCOTLAND (2006) The dictator Idi Amin fled Uganda in 1979 after the fall of a regime estimated to have killed half a million people. This drama, based on the novel by Giles Foden and directed by Kevin Macdonald, imagines Amin -- played by Forest Whitaker, above, who won the best-actor Oscar for the role -- within his palace walls, being tended to by a young Scotsman. That European, played by James McAvoy, has become his personal physician. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called both men's performances ''excellent'' and said that the movie ''delivers shocks worthy of the horror film it becomes.'' 8 P.M. TODOROVICH--Branka Opacic. Born on June 23, 1927 in Pristina, Jugoslavia, Branka was raised in Belgrade, graduating from its Academy of Fine Arts. She married Professor Miroslav Todorovich on February 18, 1951. They emigrated to NYC in the mid 1950s. Branka attended the Music Department of the Columbia School of General Studies. Branka was the office manager at a doctor's office on the Upper West Side. She achieved a third degree karate black belt. Branka was the beloved mother of Mark (Amy), Mira (Kirk) Kanzelberger, and grandmother of Leo, Sophia, Petar, George, and Thomas Kanzelberger. Branka is fondly remembered for her kindness to all who had the privilege to know her, her practical wisdom and her culinary gifts. Branka passed away on November 5, 2007 after a long illness. Funeral services will be held at 12 Noon on Saturday November 10th at the Cathedral of Saint Sava, 25th between Broadway and 6th Ave, with a brief visitation to be held at 11:30 in the Cathedral. For further information, contact Krtil Funeral Home, 212744-3084.

An odd event took place in Moscow on Nov. 8 and 9: A "U.S.S.R." team played a 10-board match against a team from "Yugoslavia." Of course, neither of these countries exists anymore, having split up after the end of the cold war. But the match was held to commemorate an annual series of "friends and rivals" matches between the two countries from the 1950's through the 1980's. In keeping with the spirit of the idea, the participants in the current match were players who had competed in those earlier encounters. The official Web site, which is in Russian and English, has all the games as well as pictures of the event.

Formula One: Ross Brawn, who was Ferrari's technical director during Michael Schumacher's spectacular run, was named team principal for Honda. Brawn, who has never been a team principal, had also been courted by his former team. DNA samples taken from the body of the former Pakistan coach Bob Woolmer will be retested, extending the inquest into his death into a fourth week. Woolmer was found unconscious March 18 in his hotel room in Jamaica, a day after his Pakistan team lost to Ireland in the Cricket World Cup. Woolmer was pronounced dead at a local hospital, but an autopsy ruled that he had been murdered, sparking a manhunt by the Jamaican police until a review reversed the findings.

The DealBook column last Sunday, about chief executives who seek merger deals for their companies, misstated the status of a buyout that Richard D. Kinder, the chairman of Kinder Morgan Inc., led to acquire that company. It was completed in May; it is not pending.

An article on Sept. 23 about the performance of Hertz, the rental car company, since its buyout by private equity firms in 2005 referred imprecisely to some of its past practices. At times, Hertz indeed used outside printers and other outsourcing for some work and used financial yardsticks like Ebitda and cash flow; those practices did not start after the buyout, though they have been expanded broadly. And before 2000, Hertz’s chief executive reported directly to senior managers such as the chief financial officer and vice chairman of Ford, a previous owner of Hertz; the chief executive did not report to lower-level managers. A letter dated Oct. 2 from Frank A. Olson, chief executive of Hertz from 1977 to 1999, clarifying certain past practices, was misdirected within The Times. This correction was further delayed for research.

It took a German to capture on film the seduction of American space, and how it would look to vanish into it. I first saw Wim Wenders’s “Paris, Texas” in 1994, 10 years after it was made. Not long before I drove through the American desert for the first time. I exercised the freedom it offered by driving at very high speeds. When I stopped the car on the side of the road and got out, especially at night, the idea of my own disappearance into such enormousness terrified me. I grew up on Long Island, and whenever my family traveled, we went east, across the Atlantic, back toward the crowded cities of Europe from which we’d come. When I left for college, the farthest west I’d been was New Jersey.

CLAVIN--Joseph P., ''Uncle Joe'' on November 9, 2007 at the age of 85 with a classic personality. Graduate of Our Lady of Angels Grammar School. Poly Prep Country Day School and Norwich University. World War II Veteran of the United States Marine Corps. After his tour of duty he attended the American Academy McAllister Institute of Funeral Service. Upon graduating his faith led him to monastery life as a Trappist Monk. He later went on to serve as a Licensed Funeral Director working with his family until the early 1980's. Upon retirement he traveled extensively throughout the world, settling in Gulfport, Mississippi for several years. Illness brought him back to his roots in Bay Ridge days before Hurricane Katrina devastated the Gulfport region. He leaves behind two sisters, Mary I. Shanahan and Peggy Brown. He now joins his three brothers, Maj. Michael E. Clavin (killed in action in Germany), James R. Clavin and Thomas A. Clavin, all veterans of the U.S. Armed Forces. He was a proud uncle of many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Visiting will take place at his family's home, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Ave, Brooklyn on Monday, Veterans Day, 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 9:30am at Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to his beloved Our Lady of Angels Church, 7320 Fourth Ave, Brooklyn, New York 11209. Semper Fi
Theater Jesse Green

HILLMAN--Rita K., the noted philanthropist and art collector, died Thursday night, November 8th, at Lenox Hill Hospital, on the Upper East Side. She was 95 years old. She was born Rita Jean Kanarek on May 16, 1912, in New York City and attended New York University from 1929 to 1932, where she studied psychology. In 1932, she married the publisher Alex Lester Hillman, and together they began collecting art, focussing mainly on French Impressionism and Post-Impressionist art. Over the years, the Hillmans amassed a remarkable collection of nineteenthand twentieth-century European paintings, drawings, and sculptures. Among the artists represented in the Hillman Collection are Picasso, Matisse, Braque, Miro, Manet, Toulouse-Lautrec, Renoir, Bonnard, Degas, Cezanne, Seurat, Soutine and Modigliani. In 1966, their son Richard died tragically in a road accident at the age of 28. Rita's husband, Alex, died in 1968. After his death, Rita became the President of the Alex Hillman Family Foundation, and, under her leadership, the foundation began to play a major role in supporting the arts in New York City. In 1974, she became a founding trustee of the International Center of Photography, and, over the course of more than three decades of involvement with ICP, she served as chairman of the Board and then honorary chairman. She also served as vice chairman of the Board of the Brooklyn Academy of Music from 1982 to 1997 and was a member of the executive committee for more than thirty years. She was on the executive committee of the American Friends of the Israel Museum since its founding. In the late nineteeneighties, the city-and countrywide nursing shortage inspired her to shift the focus of the foundation to support nursing in New York City, with a special emphasis on bedside care, and to assist nursing students who couldn't afford tuition. In 1989, she established the Hillman/Penn Nursing Scholars Program at the University of Pennsylvania, which provides scholarships and postgraduate clinical mentoring opportunities to students committed to work for one year at a new York City hospital upon completion of their studies. In 1990, she partnered with Lenox Hill Hospital to found the Hillman Partners in Practice Program, and, in 1991, she established additional Hillman Scholar programs at the New York University Division of Nursing and the Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing. Since their inception, Hillman Nursing Scholar programs and scholarships have helped more than 1200 registered nurses. In 2004, Rita received the American Journal of Nursing - Beatrice Renfield Caring for the Caregiver Award. Rita is survived by her son, Alex HIllman, as well as her grandson, Ahrin Mishan, the son of the late Richard Hillman, as well as by her grandchildren Eva, Rebecca, Janice, and Richard. A funeral service will be held at 10:30am on Monday, November 12th at Frank E. Campbell's, Madison Avenue and 81st Street. Burial will be at the Kensico Cemetery, in Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowersc ontributions in her memory can be made to the charity of your choice. HILLMAN--Rita K/d. Founding Trustee, Honorary Chairman, and generous benefactor of the International Center of Photography, Rita was much admired and loved by her fellow trustees and the ICP staff. We were honored to have had her friendship, counsel, and support since the earliest days of this institution, which she helped establish and whose educational work with young people gave her particular satisfaction. Our affection for her was accompanied by gratitude for her generosity and encouragement, unfailing wisdom, delightful sense of humor, and keen intelligence. She was a true New Yorker, a gracious presence and an indomitable spirit. Our profound condolences to the entire Hillman Family, the Hillman Foundation, and to the many who were touched by her. Gayle Greenhill, Chairman Jeffrey A. Rosen, President Cornell Capa, Founding Director Emeritus Willis E. Hartshorn, Ehrenkranz Director International Center of Photography HILLMAN--Rita/d. The Trustees Committee, faculty, students and staff of Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing join the entire Beth Israel Medical Center in acknowledging the passing of Rita Hillman, whose genuine interest and unwavering support enabled 253 men and women to pursue careers in nursing. The Hillman Scholars Program has helped the school to attract and educate the most qualified, motivated and caring students. Her love and passion for nursing and her indomitable spirit touched the life of each of her scholars. By helping them to become nurses, she has also had a tremendous impact on healthcare in New York City. We will be forever grateful for her dedication and generosity, and extend our heartfelt condolences to her wonderful family, kind assistant at the Foundation, and friends. Janet Green Co-Chair, Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing Ruth Nerken Co-Chair, Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing Janet Mackin, RN, EdD Dean, Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing Marilyn Parker, RN, EdD Associate Dean, Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing Bernice Pass-Stern Assistant Dean, Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing HILLMAN--Rita/d. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished and longtime member Rita Hillman. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, President Robert A. Calinoff, Secretary HILLMAN--Rita/d, BAM mourns the loss of our longtime friend, supporter and enthusiastic Board member for over 30 years. Rita was spirited, gracious and loyal. Sincere condolences to Alex, Ahrin, Ligaya, Dorie and her legions of friends and fans. HILLMAN--Rita/d. With profound sorrow, the entire Beth Israel Medical Center family mourns the passing of Rita Hillman, who dedicated herself to improving the quality of nursing care. Through the Hillman Family Foundation, Mrs. Hillman was a staunch supporter of Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing for 17 years. She funded numerous projects at the nursing school, most notably the Hillman Scholars Program, which offers full-tuition scholarships to the ''best and brightest'' individuals who demonstrate academic excellence and a commitment to compassionate nursing care. Mrs. Hillman knew many of her more than 253 scholarship recipients personally and took great pleasure in following their progress. She will be remembered fondly for her generosity, warmth, spirit and encouragement. We extend our deepest sympathies to all of her family and friends. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman, Board of Trustees David J. Shulkin, MD President and CEO

SACKETT--Gloria Schwartz, November 3rd at 83. Mom passed away comfortably surrounded by her large and loving family. She is survived by her three sons and her daughters-in-law with her late husband Donald Schwartz: Jack-(and Margo), Harvey (and Jan) and Larry (and Shelley) and her seven grandchildren -Robert, Daniel, David, Amy, Rebecca, Mira and Eric. She will also be missed by her eight greatgrandchildren. She was also married to the late Dr. Sidney Sackett and is survived by her brother Herbert Harris. To have known her was to have felt her optimism -to have loved her was to have felt embraced by her warmth. AT THE SUNDAY NIGHT DRUM CIRCLE, SIESTA BEACH, SIESTA KEY, AUG. 26, 2007 Christine Jugueta, 33, an interfaith minister from Boston, with her friend David Azoulay. ''I was in Sarasota doing a 10-day retreat related to universal worship and interfaith ministry. We heard there was this drum circle every Sunday, and a few of us were really excited because we knew there would be some attractive men there. I mean, possibly. When you arrive at the parking lot, you can hear the drumming in the distance, this thing that's calling you, beckoning you to come. It seemed like this strange kind of tribal activity. After I had really danced hard, I decided to go for a swim and ended up meeting a guy who was standing by my sarong when I came out. We hung out. Funny, because I went out there to study for my ministry training, and I end up feeling like Daryl Hannah, emerging out of the water and there's a guy standing by my sarong.'' As told to Seth Kugel

LEO--Ernest J., former Professor of German at Brooklyn College passed away on November 8, 2007 in Manhattan. He was born in Brooklyn in 1929 to Mary Harre Leo and Ernest M. Leo. He graduated Columbia College, Phi Beta Kappa and received a Masters from Northwestern. He taught and studied for a Ph.D. at Harvard. He served in the Army CounterIntelligence Corps until his honorable discharge in 1954. Ernest taught German at University of Pittsburgh, Columbia, City College and then at Brooklyn College for over 20 years until his retirement in 1992. An avid historian of the Napoleonic era. He is survived by four nephews and their spouses, two grandnieces and two grandnephews. Services at Gannon Funeral Home at 152 E. 28th St. 6-8pm on Monday November 12, and on Tuesday morning between 9-10am. Burial will be at Greenwood Cemeter Tuesday, November 13. In lieu of flowers, donations may be given in Ernest's memory to their favorite charity.
Pop Kelefa Sanneh

8 P.M. (2) THE CHEETAH ORPHANS The cheetah cubs Toki, left, and Sambu were orphaned at 4 weeks when a lion killed their mother. Not long after, Simon King, a wildlife filmmaker, assumed nurturing responsibilities -- from bottle-feeding the brothers to teaching them how to hunt -- at the 50,000-acre Lewa Wildlife Conservancy in northern Kenya. This ''Nature'' episode follows the cheetahs' upbringing as they learn to hunt on their own and try, through both triumph and tragedy, to re-enter the wild.

THE NEWS The dollar sank to a new low against the euro and to its lowest level in decades against the Canadian dollar and British pound. BEHIND THE NEWS The drop followed reports midweek that China might reduce the percentage of its $1.4 trillion in foreign currency reserves held in dollars and put it into other currencies to get a better return. Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, didn't help matters when he warned that the economy would slow noticeably. But the dollar could have fallen even more if he had signaled that the Fed might lower interest rates again, since such cuts have helped to weaken the dollar, which tends to fall when interest rates decline.

I found the Ethicist's response to ''Milkshake Misdeed?'' (Oct. 21) somewhat guilt-inducing. My siblings and I were faced with a similar dilemma just last year in the case of our ailing, elderly mother. Like the writer's father, our mother had been denied anything by mouth to prevent aspiration and pneumonia. For six months she begged for food, for water -- for anything -- while we stood by conflicted and heartbroken trying to act in her best interests. Friends who had recently lost a parent steered us to a hospice. A palliative-care physician helped us realize that allowing our mother to eat and drink was the more compassionate course, no matter the possible consequences. Our mother lived six months more and enjoyed watermelon, pears, peaches, water -- and milkshakes. Did our decision hasten her death? Probably. But the comfort and pleasure she received by eating and drinking at will for those six months far outweighed anything else. In retrospect, we feel we made the right -- the compassionate -- decision.

Imagine a courtroom scene, maybe something out of ''Law & Order.'' Then ask yourself which official earns the least of all those important people sitting in front of the jury. If you guessed the judge, chances are you're right. Certainly the defense lawyer, if a private attorney, makes far more in hourly fees than the person with the gavel. Some district attorneys, in New York City at least, earn more than not only the trial judge but also the chief judge. There are even nonjudicial employees in the state judiciary system who can earn as much or more than the person who is up there making the most important decisions in the entire courthouse.
Jones Inlet, Oct. 30.

GOLDFLUSS--Hon. Howard E., 83, passed away in New York City on November 7, 2007. Beloved husband of Laura Yarvin for 58 years. Devoted father of Ellen Kaden and Lisa Goldfluss Bestor. Loving father-in-law of Lewis Kaden and Geoffrey Bestor. Cherished grandfather of David and Rebecca Kaden. In the course of his wonderful, wide-ranging career, Howard was a trial lawyer, Judge of the Criminal Court of the City of New York, Justice of the Supreme Court of the State of New York, successful novelist and author, talk show host and news commentator on radio stations WMCA, WOR and WVOX, commentator for Fox 5 TV News, newspaper columnist, Adjunct Professor of Criminology at Fordham University, and member of the New York State Commission on Child Abuse and Neglect. A proud member of the greatest generation, Howard served his country with devotion in the Second World War. The loves of his life were his family, the law, and his friends at the Friars Club. As a professor of American history at the University of Colorado at Boulder and the chairwoman of the school's Center of the American West, what do you make of the flurry of new films that revisit Jesse James and the town of Yuma and the empty space of the desert landscape? Just as we had an upsurge in difficult westerns when we were struggling with Vietnam, now we're struggling with Iraq, and so we are having the same upsurge. Right. Westerns are useful in wartime because they bolster myths about American virility and strength. Do you think westerns make men feel more competent? Whenever American men of power experience anxiety, they want to go see a western, and they want to see a western where the man peacocks and parades around and everyone says, ''Isn't he something?''

The argument that low-income prekindergartners would thrive on a regimen of academics and ''direct instruction'' does not take into account that these children, even more than middle-class youngsters, need a rich preliteracy experience with the hands-on interactions that all children relish (Ann Hulbert, Oct. 28). That is precisely the way all children learn at 4 and 5 years old. Sooner is not better for the decoding of symbols, which is the basis of reading and mathematical notation, no matter how much easier it makes testing and measuring skills. Most young children are simply not neurologically ready for these tasks. They are more likely to zoom ahead when they hit age 6, ready to take on academics with confidence. And to assume that a ''developmentally sensitive'' prekindergarten does not demand that children ''listen up and follow routines'' is erroneous. A thoughtful pre-K program teaches students to be respectful, take turns, raise hands and learn from each other. The bottom line is that our government does not want to pay for the well-educated teachers, in good facilities, that our least-privileged children need and deserve.

For American children in the '50s, westerns were the default entertainment option. If it wasn't Roy Rogers then it was Hopalong Cassidy or the Lone Ranger. In the evening, with the parents, ''Have Gun -- Will Travel.'' Every kid had a fringed vest, a pair of toy six-shooters and a cowboy hat. We played cowboys and Indians and, if we were girls, imagined ourselves in bonnets and long dresses, with names like Miss Kitty. It was numbing. In years of gunfights, cattle drives, galloping horses and saloons, only one movie ever galvanized me, one I saw on TV, in black and white: ''Broken Arrow,'' with Jeff Chandler as Cochise, James Stewart as Tom Jeffords and Debra Paget as the Apache girl Stewart is allowed to marry. Stewart was a real movie star, and I must have noticed him, but what sticks in my mind is the very thing that made the movie startling when it came out in 1950 -- the fact that it is sympathetic to the Native American point of view, as represented by Chandler, strikingly handsome and dignified as Cochise, and Jay Silverheels, rough-voiced and dynamic, as Geronimo.

WEININGER--Eva (nee Fernbach), died in San Antonio, Texas on October 21, 2007 at the age of 104. Her long, full life was marked by artistic talent, integrity and an independent spirit. Eva was born in Bunzlau, Germany on July 21, 1903, the eldest of three sisters. She was one of the first female students to attend Berlin's trade school for cabinetmakers. Her keen interest in functional, innovative design led her to join the Bauhaus in Dessau in 1927. There she met Andor Weininger, a talented artist, musician, performer and Bauhaus Band leader. They were married in 1931 in Berlin where they worked together creating modernist furniture and interior design. In 1938, Eva, Andor and their infant daughter fled Hitler's Germany. They lived in Holland for 13 years, then six years in Canada, finally settling in New York City in 1958. After Andor's death in 1986, Eva catalogued his work and welcomed a steady stream of art scholars to her Manhattan apartment. She founded the Weininger Foundation to ensure that future generations could learn from her vast collection of artworks, and made numerous donations to museums and universities around the world. Throughout her life, Eva's ability to confront hardship and challenges with curiosity, energy and humor were admirable. Eva's daughter, Cornelia, died in 1996. She is survived by her youngest sister, Renate Fuchs; her nieces Anita Younes, Gudula Khan and Linda Miller and her eight grandnieces and nephews.

A screenwriter friend and I duck into Video Free Brooklyn to rent Altman's ''McCabe and Mrs. Miller.'' ''Great death scene!'' my friend exclaims. I instantly agree, but it turns out we mean two different things. He's thinking of McCabe -- Warren Beatty, that is -- succumbing from his bullet wounds after going to ground in a snowstorm, then being enveloped by swirling flakes and the elegiac tones of Leonard Cohen's ''Winter Lady.'' Yes, this is one of the western's great death scenes. It completes one of the slowest and most heart-rending descents in all cinema; the shattering of McCabe's dreams comes to stand for a farewell to both the western tradition and to the sublimely fragile idealisms of the glamorous hippies both Beatty and McCabe really were beneath gruff western garb.

TAGGART--William John, 71, abstract painter, printmaker, and sculptor, died at his home in Salisbury, CT, on October 17. Born in Buffalo, NY, in 1936, he received a BFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago on a Ford Foundation Fellowship and an MFA from the University of New Mexico. After he moved to New York his work was shown at the Betty Parsons Gallery from 1970 until Parsons' death in 1982. His work was featured in group shows and one-man exhibitions throughout the U.S. and is held in many private and public collections, including the American embassies in Bonn, Mexico City, and New Delhi; the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago; the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo; IBM; the Prudential Insurance Company and the Port Authority of NY and NJ. Taggart is survived by his wife Sarah Cooke Taggart and three sons from his first marriage, Sean Michael, Caleb Samuel and Joshua Barney Taggart, as well as a grandson, two brothers, and two sisters. Interment will be on November 24 in Doswell, VA. A memorial service will be held in New York at a date to be determined.

Something look different? Today we add an extra page and a dash of color to the Sunday editorial report of The Times. The Times's forum for debate has just grown a little larger, both online and in the newspaper. We invite you to join in the discussion.

AT the epicenter of the mortgage earthquake was a lineup of exotic loans with newfangled payment terms. These were frequently offered to borrowers with poor credit who failed to understand the loans' terms and often could not keep up with the payments. While these types of loans have largely disappeared from the landscape, some industry leaders expect them to return soon enough. ''We do this all the time,'' said Stephen Habetz, the chief executive of Threshold Mortgage, a brokerage in Westport, Conn. ''You can go back 10, 12 years and see the same headlines, where we roll out these products when the market heats up. And it'll happen again.''

The illustrations on these pages have been taken from the Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 2007. Every year since 1952, the Book Review has asked a panel of judges to make a selection from among the several thousand children's books published that year. The judges this year were David Wiesner, who has been awarded the Caldecott Medal three times, for ''Flotsam'' in 2007, ''The Three Pigs'' in 2002 and ''Tuesday'' in 1992, and is the United States nominee for the 2008 Hans Christian Andersen Award; Steven Heller, a co-chairman of the M.F.A. Designer as Author department of the School of Visual Arts and a former art director of the Book Review; and Ellen Loughran, a visiting associate professor at the Pratt School of Information and Library Sciences. As a matter of note, Peter Sis has won six times before; Guy Billout has won four times before; and Brian Selznick has won once before. The Editors 600 BLACK SPOTS: Written and illustrated by David A. Carter. Little Simon/Simon & Schuster Children's Publishing. $19.99. (Ages 3 and up)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Oct. 27, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Perennial sellers are not actively tracked. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

CORRIGAN--Dorothy B. (nee Bria) of Rye, formerly of Bronxville and White Plains, New York, died on November 10, 2007. Daughter of the late Jenny Imbrogno and Emil P. Bria of Waterbury, Connecticut. Wife of the late Captain Richard Donald Corrigan of New Rochelle, New York. Mother of Patton Richard Corrigan of Connecticut. Sister of the late Elvira Bria Cacaci, Judith Bria, and Olga Bria. Grandmother of four and great-grandmother of seven. Mrs. Corrigan attended the college of New Rochelle, and was awarded a BA Degree by Good Counsel College, White Plains, and MA Degree in English by Manhattan College, Riverdale, New York. Mrs. Corrigan was assistant to the Publicity Director at the College of New Rochelle; staff newspaper reporter of Bronxville Review Press and Westchester Newspapers. Inc. and Associate editor of Jewelers Pre-Views, New York City, before becoming a teacher. At Harrison High School, she taught junior and senior English, Journalism, Creative Writing, and Drama. She also taught Journalism to the gifted and talented of Harrison High School and Rye Neck High School. During World War II, Mrs. Corrigan served in Civilian Defense as an Air Raid Warden and Civilian Military Intelligence for several years. The family will receive friends on Sunday from 37pm at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road Rye, NY. A mass of Christian Burial will be held on Monday, 10am, at Resurrection Church in Rye, NY. Interment will be at Arlington National Cemetery beside the late Captain Richard Donald Corrigan, her husband.

BERENSON--Clare, z'l, 94, born in 1913 in Hunter, NY youngest of six children of Sarah Rubin and Beinish Averick; lived most of her life in Hillside, NJ and Rye, NY died peacefully of a stroke with family and friends at her side on November 8. She was predeceased by her husband of 36 years, Samuel James Berenson M.D. Loving mother to Betty and David Menashi, David and Robert. A wonderful grandmother to Steven James and Diana Beth Menashi. She attended Hunter College, a Piano and French major. She managed her husband's medical practice and volunteered at St. Elizabeth's Hospital. We will miss your laughter, and in your honor, Mom, we will cut the Seder short. Graveside funeral on Sunday in Woodbridge, NJ. May we all ''be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.''

FISCHMAN--Jerome, 79, retired Adelphi and Lehigh University professor died November 3rd at his home, in Huntington, NY surrounded by loving family and friends. He leaves behind Myra, his wife of 55 years, children Deborah and Michael, granddaughters Aria and Eliana, son - in - law Perry, Helen, Joseph, sister Rita Brettschneider, niece Jane, nephew Joe, and a wealth of cherished relatives and friends. Jerry was a force of knowledge, compassion and love. His death leaves a void in our lives that can never be filled.

HILL--Janet E. (Schwartz), death came to Janet near midnight as November 5th, 2007 came to a close. Until the end, after battling death valiantly for 19 years, Janet's spark of life finally gave way when her weary struggling spirit surrendered to the inevitable. She leaves behind grieving parents, Marvin and Gloria Schwartz, her devoted son, Joshua, two beloved brothers, Robert M. Schwartz, Esq. and Dr. John J. Schwartz, John's dear wife, Lynda Harbold Schwartz, niece, Laura, nephew, Jack, and loving aunt, Arline Feigen. In their grief, they and the many others touched by her in her time, tearfully bid her farewell. As long as recollections have been meant to endure, Janet will be remembered by her family and others with love and a sigh for the emptiness left by her passing. A graveside service will be conducted at the interment at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. Shiva at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin L. Schwartz in Larchmont, New York will be observed from the 13th to the 15th of November, 2007.

Today is Day 3 of the stagehands’ strike on Broadway, and anxieties are mounting, as reflected in accusations leveled on both sides, lost restaurant and hotel revenue and worry among workers all along the Great White Way. Campbell Robertson reports that the two sides — the producers’ league and the stagehands’ union — do not appear to be near a settlement.

When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg gave the jazz musician Fats Domino the key to the city last week, it got us wondering: What is the key made of, what does it represent and who has received this honor? In researching the answers to these questions, we received a list of recipients since 1978. The mayor’s press office, which furnished the list, cautioned that it would be incomplete before the 1990s, when record keeping was computerized. Additionally, some older names and titles on the list were misspelled or rendered incorrectly, some beyond recognition. Where there was a question that we at City Room could not resolve, we omitted the name, so this roster is not comprehensive.

Following is a fourth and final set of answers from Benjamin Weiser and Leslie Kaufman of The Times, who, along with a panel of experts, answered readers’ questions about The Times’s series on foster care [“A History of Neglect,” Part 1 | Part 2 | Part 3] during the past week. Previous sets of questions and answers were posted last week.

A tidbit from Charles McGrath’s lengthy obituary of Norman Mailer, who died on Saturday, intrigued us: Mailer’s role in helping to win parole for Jack Henry Abbott, a felon, in 1981. Mailer championed Mr. Abbott’s release, citing the quality of the prisoner’s writings, and he agreed to hire Mr. Abbott as a research assistant. But Mr. Abbott went on to commit another murder within weeks of his parole.

Updated, 2:12 p.m. | Pope Benedict XVI will make his first visit to the United States as pontiff over six days in April, and he plans to visit ground zero, address the United Nations and celebrate Masses at National Stadium in Washington and St. Patrick’s Cathedral and Yankee Stadium in New York, officials at the Vatican and the Archdiocese of New York announced today.

A few weeks ago, City Room wrote about a casting call for a zombie yoga video in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, which drew about 75 participants who wanted to take the corpse post literally. Now the products of that quick-and-dirty shoot against the New York City skyline has been released at ZenofZombie.com. It’s a promotion for a book by Scott Kenemore, “The Zen of Zombie: Better Living Through the Undead,” a parody of a self-help book. (Boing Boing TV offers a behind-the-scenes look at the making of the video.)

Rumors about an avian serial killer on the loose in Brooklyn raise an age-old question: How to get rid of pesky pigeons? Well, one can kill them (not advisable on grounds of ethics or taste), starve them (well, not really starve them, but stop feeding them) or scare them away. At least those are the methods that most have tried in the past.

Evening news programs on the three major networks have devoted significantly more time to the 2008 presidential campaign so far this year than any of the pre-election years since 1991, according to Andrew Tyndall, a television news analyst. NBC spent the most time covering the campaign with 228 minutes, followed by CBS with 191 minutes and ABC with 180 minutes. Individual candidates and the horse race were covered the most; only 18 minutes has been spent on issues on the trail.

I'm here at the World Energy Congress in Rome, a conference of leaders in the energy field that occurs once every five years. I just heard Rex Tillerson, chairman of ExxonMobil say that: "The world has plenty of oil resources ... Twice the total of oil consumed in human history is still available." OK, so why is oil hitting $100 a barrel? Mr. Tillerson seemed to place much of the blame on oil-rich countries that were not giving oil companies like his adequate access to their riches, nationalizing their oil resources.

After I wrote my post examining what makes it worthwhile for a current generation to work to limit future risks, I sent an e-mail to a few contacts exploring risks and responses, inviting them to weigh in. A note came back from the Apollo 9 astronaut Rusty Schweickart, who has lately been pressing for the United States to intensify efforts to limit a danger both far more concretely understood than global warming and far less in vogue as a serious threat -- the reality that a very large rock will inevitably head on a collision course for Earth.

NYMEX Holdings has entered into an agreement to buy a 15.1 percent stake in Norwegian sea freight derivatives exchange Imarex.
Sears chieftain and well known hedge fund investor Edward Lampert has been buying up shares in automotive retailer AutoNation.
The auction of Wendy's International may be in jeopardy because of continued turmoil in the credit markets, potentially forcing the company to delay its sale, The New York Times reported.
Rexel, the world's largest distributor of electrical equipment, agreed to buy Hagemeyer with a sweetened offer of 3.1 billion euros ($4.5 billion) to expand in Europe as its American market slows.

Justine Henin finished her record-breaking season undefeated after Wimbledon. She won the Sony Ericsson Championships yesterday in Madrid, rallying past Maria Sharapova, 5-7, 7-5, 6-3. The top-ranked Henin won her 10th title of 2007 and earned $1 million at the season-ending event, becoming the first woman to surpass $5 million for a year. She has won 25 matches in a row.

Nand-ranked Rafael Nadal looked susceptible to an upset by Richard Gasquet before rallying to win, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, in Gold Group play at the Masters Cup in Shanghai. Then sixth-ranked David Ferrer came out hot, breaking No. 3 Novak Djokovic’s powerful serve in the first game and never letting up during a 6-4, 6-4 triumph.
Adam Vinatieri missed a 29-yard field-goal attempt with 1 minute 31 seconds left, as the Colts comeback fell short on a night that Peyton Manning delivered one of his worst performances.

Alessio Di Mauro says his nine-month ban for betting on tennis is too severe and he is a scapegoat for the match-fixing scandals surrounding the sport. “I made a silly mistake and I’m being punished excessively,” Di Mauro said in Gazzetta dello Sport. Di Mauro, ranked 124th, became the first player sanctioned under the ATP’s new anticorruption rules Saturday. He was also fined $60,000 after it was determined he made 120 bets with an online bookmaker from Nov. 2, 2006, through June 12, 2007. The investigation found none of the bets were on his matches and said no results were affected.
The Rutgers women’s basketball team was hoping for a victory, a fresh start and some good news as it opened its season Sunday night. It got none of the above, losing 60-58 to No. 7 Stanford.

A chart in Business Day last Monday with an article about collateralized debt obligations, a complex investment instrument backed by assets like mortgages, described incorectly a ranking of investment banks. The N.H.L.’s rookie scoring leader, Patrick Kane, had a power-play goal and an assist to help the Blackhawks beat Detroit, 3-2, last night in Chicago, ending the Red Wings’ record-tying winning streak at nine games. Also last night, Paul Stastny had two goals and an assist to help the host Colorado Avalanche beat the Minnesota Wild, 4-2.

With heavy snow hampering visibility, Marc Gini of Switzerland won a slalom in Reiteralm, Austria, for his first World Cup victory. Bode Miller of the United States, competing independently, was 26th. Miller, who hit his chin on a gate in the first run, came to a near standstill and almost missed a gate in his final run. The top American was Jimmy Cochran, who was 14th.

Phil Mickelson blew a three-shot lead with seven holes to play but still won the HSBC Champions in Shanghai, beating the Englishmen Ross Fisher and Lee Westwood with a 6-foot birdie putt on the second playoff hole. It was Mickelson’s first win outside the United States in 14 years. Mickelson had a three-stroke lead after 11 holes, but dropped four shots on 12, 13 and 15.

Paula Creamer ran away with the Tournament of Champions, winning by eight strokes over Birdie Kim in Mobile, Ala. Creamer, 21, closed with a four-under-par 68 to finish at 20-under 268 — a stroke off the tournament record set last year by Lorena Ochoa.

An Italian police officer accidentally shot and killed a soccer fan while trying to break up a fight between supporters of rival teams near a highway restaurant in Arezzo, the authorities said. Enraged, hundreds of fans later rioted in Rome, attacking a police station. Gabriele Sandri, a 26-year-old Lazio fan, was hit in the neck by a bullet while in a car at a rest area about 125 miles north of Rome.

The N.F.L. players union is appealing Commissioner Roger Goodell’s decision not to reduce the season-long suspension of Titans cornerback Pacman Jones. The union said it appealed Goodell’s decision in a letter dated Nov. 8 — two days after Goodell notified Jones that he must serve out the suspension handed down in April.

Brazil won its second consecutive FIFA Beach World Cup, beating Mexico, 8-2, in the final in Rio de Janeiro. André and Bruno each scored two goals, giving Brazil its 11th world title in beach soccer since the event began in 1995.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 11 (AP) — One week after Adrian Peterson set an N.F.L. record with a 296-yard performance against San Diego, the Green Bay Packers held him to 45 yards on 11 carries Sunday before knocking him out of the game with a knee injury in the third quarter of a 34-0 rout of the Minnesota Vikings.

A man was killed by a New Jersey Transit train about 12:30 a.m. yesterday after jumping or falling onto the tracks at the New Brunswick station. Dan Stessel, a spokesman for New Jersey Transit, told The Star-Ledger of Newark that witnesses said the man refused bystanders’ offers of help to get back to the platform. At the last minute, he tried to get off the tracks, but it was too late, the witnesses said. The man’s name was not released yesterday.

A parked garbage truck weakened a sidewalk grate that later gave way under a woman who walked on it in May, Con Edison said yesterday. When the grate collapsed, the woman, Jessica Hinksmon, fell into a 10-foot-deep transformer vault beneath the sidewalk on 51st Street between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue. Ms. Hinksmon suffered minor injuries. A spokesman for Con Edison, Michael Clendenin, said a videotape showed that the truck was on the grate for at least 10 minutes, and that it was not the only time a heavy vehicle stopped on the grate. “The cumulative effect of the stress created by these repeated heavy loads contributed to the grating’s failure,” he said. After the May 17 accident, the utility inspected 19,722 similar grates and repaired 325 of them, Mr. Clendenin said.

A 66-year-old man was killed late Saturday night when the car he was driving was struck by an out-of-control Honda Accord, the police said. The driver of the Accord, Christopher Rivera, 25, of Howard Beach, was arrested and charged with driving while intoxicated and vehicular manslaughter. The collision occurred shortly after 10:45 p.m. on Woodhaven Boulevard near 101st Avenue in Woodhaven, when Mr. Rivera’s car crossed the median into northbound traffic, striking the victim’s 1999 Nissan Maxima, the police said. The Maxima then struck a third vehicle, a 2006 BMW. The driver of the Maxima, whose name was not released yesterday, was pronounced dead at the scene. His passenger, a 60-year-old woman, was in stable condition at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. Mr. Rivera and his passenger were also in stable condition, as were the two occupants of the BMW, the police said.

Former United States Representative John E. Sweeney was charged with driving while intoxicated yesterday after an early morning traffic stop, the State Police said. Mr. Sweeney was pulled over by a state trooper on the Northway in Saratoga County at 1:20 a.m., the police said. The State Police said his blood-alcohol level was measured at 0.18; in New York the legal limit is 0.08. The Times Union of Albany reported that E. Stewart Jones, Mr. Sweeney’s lawyer, confirmed the arrest. “He is a private citizen,” Mr. Jones said. “This is a private matter.” Mr. Sweeney was released; he is scheduled to appear in Town Court on Wednesday. Mr. Sweeney, a Republican, lost his House seat last year to Kirsten Gillibrand, a Democrat.
The Army has yet to decide whether to replace or repair the Tomb of the Unknowns, which is marred by cracks.

A Brooklyn woman was arrested yesterday on accusations that she fatally stabbed a man during a domestic dispute on Saturday evening, the police said. The woman, Shenequa DeFreitas, 27, of Ocean Avenue, was charged with manslaughter, the police said. Ms. DeFreitas stabbed the man, Thomas Adonis, 25, of East 57th Street, in the torso during a dispute in her home about 6:20 p.m., the police said. Mr. Adonis was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead.

A changing of the guard was predicted in the N.F.C. West. But San Francisco and Arizona have not put up much of a fight, even though Seattle, the three-time defending champion, has left the door wide open. With Shaun Alexander injured and ineffective, Seahawks Coach Mike Holmgren has renewed focus on the passing game, which is ranked 10th in the league. The 49ers, losers of six in a row, wish they had only one facet of their 32nd-ranked offense to be concerned about. The Seahawks, who won in San Francisco in Week 4, are hungry for payback after a season sweep by the 49ers last year. San Francisco Coach Mike Nolan’s father, Dick Nolan, a former Giants player and 49ers coach, died yesterday, but Mike Nolan is expected to be with his team tonight. NAILA-JEAN MEYERS.

PETERSEN--Nis-Adolph, 84, of New York, NY, well-known and highly regarded Professor at New Jersey City College, died on October 26th, 2007 after a long illness. Beloved son of Erma Claussen and George Frederick Petersen, brother of the late Heinke Elise Petersen Lanigan. Nis is survived by his sister, Lie Ruff and his beloved nieces and nephew, Sonia, Lorna and Michael. Memorial service to be held at St. Thomas Episcopal Church located at 53rd Street and Fifth Avenue, New York, NY on December 1st at 12:00pm.

THE life of the celebrity-award-show dress is always short and frenzied. Conceived through a series of pleas by designers, fittings, rejections and more pleas, given birth to on the red carpet -- generally without a single dollar changing hands -- the dress dies in a garment bag in the back of a closet. Its existence is often memorialized only by People magazine.

THE United States has plenty of affluent do-gooders who are taken with the idea that with their experience and creativity they could harness expertise and money to better the lives of people in the developing world. You need to have a lot of passion, energy and wits, but so must the people overseas who are helping you.

FOX--Clara, passed away November 9, sleeping peacefully. She was 90 years old. She was the Co-Chair of The New York Housing Conference, a life-time member of the National Housing Conference and Director Emeritus of Settlement Housing Fund. The Boards and Staffs of these organizations mourn her loss deeply. Clara originated the idea of combining low and moderate income housing with social programs, and she ran the first leadership training programs for new owners of middle income cooperative housing. She began her career in the field of early childhood education. She held numerous positions in government and non - profit organizations, wrote extensively and lectured frequently. Until the very end of her life, she was an active housing advocate, especially concerned about the lack of middle income housing in New York City. She had little patience with leaders who did not work hard enough to achieve effective housing programs. She was generous with her time and mentored her successors. We will especially miss her way with words and her wit. We offer our condolences to her daughter, Roberta Fox. Her funeral will take place Wednesday, November 14, at 12:45pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel. A memorial is tentatively planned for December 11 at 10am at a place to be determined. Carol Lamberg, Susan Cole, Charles Warren, John Kelly

Loving mother of Margaret Baron (Richard), Mary Hayes (Rich Contay), John Hayes (Clare), Anne Allison (William), Elizabeth Reilly (Michael), Mark Hayes (Gabriele), Jude Hayes (Moira) and the Late Loretta. TURITZ--Bertha, formerly of Teaneck and Englewood, NJ, died at age 88 on Friday, November 9. She was a beloved sister, mother, grandmother and great - grandmother. Bertha was the wife of the late Bill Turitz, and is survived by her children Lynn Rappaport, Stanley Turitz and Barbra Horner, her seven grandchildren and 16 great-grandchildren.

ECONOMIC INDICATORS Inflation will be the big economic news this week, with reports on the producer price index (Wednesday) and the consumer price index (Thursday). Other reports will include retail sales for October and business inventories for September (Wednesday) and industrial production and capacity use for October (Friday).

BRUNELL--Albert L., died on Saturday, November 10th, 2007 at the age of 73 years after a protracted illness. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Susanne, his children Leslie and Thomas and their spouses Joseph Corrado and Joanne, and his four grandchildren, Emma, Sallie, Sebastian and Seth. He graduated from Stuyvesant High School, received his Bachelors Degree from Hobart and a Law Degree from NYU Law School. He spent much of his career as a National Trust Examiner and as Director of Fiduciary Services for the Comptroller of the Currency. For the past 43 years he lived in Demarest, NJ. He served on the boards of the Demarest Public Library, Swim Club and Zoning Board. A lifetime St. Louis Cardinals fan, he followed his favorite team for over six decades. He delighted in attending a home game in St. Louis as an honored guest during their extraordinary 2004-2005 season. He will be remembered as a kind, generous and wise father and a devoted family member. He always stressed the importance of family, and often offered witty and sagacious comments at family functions and events. He will be dearly missed by his wife, children, and grandchildren, as well as his cousins Peter, Emily and Claude Samton, Annette and Paul Marcus and Peter Schrag. Funeral services 2 pm Tuesday, November 13th at Rober Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt 4, East Paramus, NJ 07652. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations should be made to the Brunell Fund for New Arrivals at the JCC on the Palisades, 411 East Clinton Ave, Tenafly, NJ 07670.
