THEY call it the Map of Africa. It is a cute name for an acute problem: the stains that African girls often endure when they are menstruating and the rags or camel's skin they use for protection fail. ''Girls who can't manage their period stay home, and that is affecting their education,'' said Michelle J. Vaeth, communications director for FemCare, the Procter & Gamble unit that makes Always pads and Tampax tampons.

HOBERMAN--C. Debbie, 61, of pancreatic cancer on November 10, 2007. Funeral services will be held at Hannemann Funeral Home, Inc. 88 South Broadway, Nyack, NY. Donations may be sent to Abbott House, 100 North Broadway, Irvington, NY 10533.

DiBERNARDO--Eleonora M., 69, passed away on November 9, 2007. A woman of great strength with a positive spirit who lived each day to the fullest. She believed that no act of kindness was ever too small. Passionately devoted to her family and loyal friend to many. Dedicated to the cause of Madison Square Boys and Girls Club, where she worked for 52 years. Greatly appreciative of Dr. Clifford Hudis and his staff at Memorial Sloan Kettering who enabled her to persevere in her courageous battle against incurable breast cancer over the past 8 years. She is survived by Franco, her husband of 44 years, daughters Nancy DiBernardo-Conroy and Jane Yohe, son-inlaws John P. Conroy, Jr. and David Yohe; grandchildren Katherine Grace Yohe, John, Daniel and James Conroy and her beloved Ellie and Oliver. Also survived by her siblings Louise DeBernardo, Walter Minigutti and their families. Her family will miss her more than words can ever express. To honor her memory, donations can be made in her name to Memorial Sloan Kettering Breast Cancer Medicine Research and Madison Square Boys and Girls Club Scholarship Fund.

An article in The Arts on Oct. 31 about the challenges facing female architects misspelled the surname of an architect who designed and furnished a 1929 house whose décor was later altered by the architect Le Corbusier. She was Eileen Gray, not Grey.

An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday misstated the closing date for ''Mel Kendrick: Red Block,'' at the David Noland Gallery Inc. It is Nov. 21; the exhibition did not close on Saturday.

DONORS should get a much clearer picture of how secular charities handle their money, and which charities are legitimate, thanks to new rules imposed by Congress. Even the tiniest nonprofit, like garden clubs with a few hundred dollars of income a year, must file simple disclosure statements online with the Internal Revenue Service or lose their tax exemptions. The rules took effect on Jan. 1, and introduce a category of Form 990 filing called the 990-N, which applies to organizations with revenues from $1 to $25,000. The first annual reports under the new law are due May 15, 2008.

IN the world of animal rights' charities, a certain phrase has been fund-raising gold lately -- ''Michael Vick's dogs.'' When Mr. Vick, the star quarterback for the Atlanta Falcons, pleaded guilty to planning an interstate dogfighting ring, he was singled out for protests and was shunned by the National Football League. But for charities like the Humane Society of the United States, People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals and the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, Mr. Vick's long-suffering pit bulls, freed from gladiator duty, became the faces to show the public for fund-raising.

One challenge that foundations face in giving away large amounts of money is finding organizations that are equipped to handle it. The GAVI Alliance -- formerly the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunization -- has received a commitment of $1.5 billion over 15 years from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. Here is a look at how the money flows.

Evening news programs on the three major networks have devoted significantly more time to the 2008 presidential campaign so far this year than any of the pre-election years since 1991, according to Andrew Tyndall, a television news analyst. NBC spent the most time covering the campaign with 228 minutes, followed by CBS with 191 minutes and ABC with 180 minutes. Individual candidates and the horse race were covered the most; only 18 minutes has been spent on issues on the trail.

GOLTZER--Albert, retired Associate Principal oboist of the New York Philharmonic, died Saturday in a Connecticut hospital of pneumonia. He was 89. Mr. Goltzer retired from the Philharmonic in 1984 after a long and distinguished orchestral career. Born in Brooklyn, New York on July 25, 1918, he did not begin to study music until he was thirteen, while at Brooklyn's Tilden High School. Young Albert was a natural. In 1938, just nineteen years old, he was invited to join the New York Philharmonic by then music director Sir John Barbirolli, who heard him play chamber music at a party. Just before that, he had won a scholarship to Julliard as well as the Gabrilowitch Memorial Scholarship of the National Orchestral Association. He studied with Philharmonic musicians Engelbert Brenner, Bruno Labate and Michael Nazzi. Mr. Goltzer was so young he lied about his age so he could sign his contract with the orchestra. Mr. Goltzer took a leave of absence to serve in the military during World War II. In 1946, he assumed the position of solo oboist with the St. Louis Symphony. After his stay in St. Louis, he was solo oboe with the CBS Symphony and the WOR Orchestra, and a member of the New York Woodwind Quintet. In 1955, Mr. Goltzer was invited back to the New York Philharmonic by Dimitri Metropolis, where he played until 1984 as associate principal. Albert Goltzer made numerous recordings and was on the faculties of the Julliard, Mannes and Manhattan Schools of Music. He is survived by his beloved wife, Doris, an accomplished orchestral musician currently with the New York City Opera, son George and George's wife, Barbara Gertel Goltzer, son Seth, brother-in-law Alvin Delman, and grandchildren Andrew, Jill, Samantha and Adam. His late brother, Harold Goltzer, played beside him for many years as associate Principal bassoonist of the New York Philharmonic. Services Monday, 11:15am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

A memorial event will be held at a later date. THE microfinance industry -- bankers to the poor -- faces a paradox of scale, growing large in some ways but remaining small in others. There are more than 3,100 microfinance institutions worldwide, serving 113 million poor people. But even thriving microfinanciers are tiny by banking business standards. They typically make loans of $100 or so to entrepreneurs living on a dollar or two a day.

She is survived by her loving husband of 31 years, Saul, her adoring sister Iris, brother-in-law Larry, nephew Adam, her brother Jerry and her devoted niece Rochelle, nephew Bruce and grandnieces Sara and Hannah. Trudy was an accomplished and caring social worker and had completed all course work for her Ph.D. in Social Work at NYU when she first became ill. She practiced at Mount Sinai Medical Center for over 20 years and held the position of Associate Director of Social Work Services for Ambulatory Care. SCHWARTZ--Bernard, M.D., Ph.D., glaucoma specialist, founding chairman of the Department of Ophthalmology at the Tufts-New England Medical Center, and Editorin-Chief of two ophthalmology journals, died on November 10, 2007 at age 79, of a recently diagnosed cancer. Dr. Schwartz was born in Toronto, Ontario, Canada in 1927. He received his medical degree from the University of Toronto in 1951, then undertook postgraduate training at the University of Iowa, where he completed his ophthalmology residency in 1955 and then earned his Ph.D. in physiology in 1959. From 1960 to 1968, he conducted research and clinical practice in the New York area. In 1968, he joined the faculty and staff of the Tufts-New England Medical Center where he established and chaired the Department of Ophthalmology until 1990. Active in many ophthalmological organizations, he received the Presidential Award from the American Glaucoma Society in March 2007. Beloved husband of Marcia (Struhl) of Boston, MA. Devoted father of Ariane Schwartz of Boston, MA, Jennifer Schwartz of San Francisco, CA, Karen Schwartz of Los Angeles, CA, and Lawrence Schwartz of Connecticut. Loving brother of Dr. Harvey Schwartz and his wife Fran of Toronto, Canada. Services will be held at Stanetsky Memorial Chapel, 1668 Beacon St., Brookline, MA, Tuesday, November 13 at 12:00pm. Interment service will be at New Cedar Park Cemetery, 735 Forest Ave., Paramus, NJ on Wednesday, November 14 at 12:30pm. Memorial observance will be at Bernard's late residence Thursday through Friday evening ending at sundown. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Bernard may be made to Research to Prevent Blindness, 645 Madison Ave., Floor 21, NY, NY 10022-1010 or to another similar sight charity of ones choice. Stanetsky Memorial Chapel, 617.232.9300 www.stanetsky.com

A police shooting of an unarmed young man drew an angry crowd in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, on Monday night and focused attention anew on the use of force by the police. Khiel Coppin, 18, died in a hail of 20 bullets fired by five police officers who had responded to his mother’s 911 call for help in a domestic dispute. The police said officers believed Mr. Coppin had a gun, but it turned out that he had been holding a hairbrush.

Student researchers at Hunter College spent much of October observing 3,120 New York City drivers at 50 intersections and, according to their study, 1 in 3 were using cellphones, smoking, eating, drinking or grooming while operating their vehicles.The study, overseen by Peter S. Tuckel, a professor of sociology, found that more than 1 in 5 of the drivers were observed talking on their cellphones — half of them on hand-held phones, which has been illegal in New York State since 2001. In addition, about 1 in 10 drivers were engaged in other distractions like eating hamburgers and French fries, drinking coffee or soda, applying makeup, and smoking cigarettes.

The city will build a 950-seat elementary and middle school in Battery Park City, a recognition of the unanticipated surge in population in Lower Manhattan since 9/11, officials announced this morning.

Don't tell your child, the class cut-up, about the lead story of today's paper:
Fred Thompson picks up a major endorsement today, in the form of support from the National Right to Life Committee, whose backing Mitt Romney and Mike Huckabee had also sought.

E*Trade Financial lost more than half its market value Monday, after an analyst suggested that the company might have to seek bankruptcy protection if panicked customers withdraw deposits because of its faltering mortgage investments.

Cisco Systems said Monday that it will launch a program to make venture capital investments in technology companies in Central and Eastern Europe, a first step into a region where the networking giant hopes to fund startups and potentially make acquisitions.

The books that tend to catch people's attention are those at the edges of the span of thought on an issue of the day, whether it is the existence of God, the way out of Iraq or the best way to avoid global warming.
Properties on the market in Florida, Montana and Washington.

Macquarie Group, Australia's biggest securities firm, said a rally in equity markets may falter in the second half, making it harder to repeat its record 45 percent profit growth of the first six months.

Investment firm Sun Capital Partners is threatening to take its $544 million buyout offer for Kellwood to the company's shareholders unless the apparel maker's board reconsiders its rejection of the bid, the Wall Street Journal reported Tuesday in its online edition.

The Vodafone Group , the world's biggest provider of mobile-phone services, said it may sell shares in Vodacom Group in an initial public offering as part of Vodafone's plan to raise its 50 percent stake in South Africa's largest wireless provider.

When I decided to become a lawyer 20 years ago, it was a decision laden with shoulds, mostly from my father, who was projecting his wishes onto me. (His "Marci should be a lawyer" became "I should please my father and become a lawyer.") If I had listened better to my own vision for a career, I might have found a career that fit me better the first time around.
CDM Resource Partners, a company that provides natural gas contract compression services, aims to raise as much as $140 million in an initial public offering.
Early-stage venture capital firm Accel Partners announced the final closing of its 10th investment fund with $520 million on Monday.

Lewis Hamilton, the 22-year old Formula One racing sensation who came within inches of winning the Grand Prix championship in his debut season, is now reportedly mulling another bold maneuver -- listing himself on the London stock market.

Twelve Wall Street firms that had started competing platforms for trading unregistered securities known as 144a issues have agreed to cooperate on a single platform operated by the Nasdaq Stock Market, the exchange said Monday.
A smoked fish spot in TriBeCa cultivates a last-century vibe, two pumpkin pie tricks and helpful new utensils with vintage style.
A look at Villa San Giorgio, a renovated two-story farmhouse in Italy.

It's been a busy month for Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia. After helping to push Charles O. Prince III out of the top job at Citigroup, the bank's largest shareholder is now claiming bragging rights to the world's largest private jet.

British investor Guy Hands' Terra Firma, on the hunt for additional equity investors in EMI, is telling prospective partners they can nearly quadruple their money in the struggling major label and cash out within five years, The New York Post reported.

What's really killing investors' confidence in Wall Street firms is the uncertainty and unpredictability of the recent write-downs, David Weidner wrote in a commentary on MarketWatch. The solution may be for more firms to take a tough line on marking to market.

The hedge fund at the center of Overstock.com's controversial short-selling lawsuit has filed a counterclaim against the online retailer, arguing it is trying to cover up questionable accounting and poor business decisions.
The hedge fund controlled by Edward S. Lampert, the value-oriented billionaire investor, may be out $4.47 billion in the third quarter, according to press reports' back-of-the-envelope calculations.

There is a new Web site today, which I'll get to in a moment. But first you should check out the site it is parodying, from the Community Financial Services Association of America -- otherwise known as the Payday Lenders.

Private equity dealmaking may be slowing in the United States, but according to The Washington Post, some of the biggest and most powerful dealmakers here have found a way to keep the buyout boom going: by aggressively pushing into China.

Countrywide Financial, the mortgage lender, said Monday that its ability to raise money and increase deposits in its banking subsidiary could be hampered if its credit ratings were reduced below investment grade.

While Al Gore's new role as partner in the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers will give the Nobel laureate an opportunity to use his expertise in environmental causes to identify investments, it is the former vice-president's political ties that may come in even handier in nurturing green businesses.
Gazprom, Russia's state-owned energy company, is considering taking equity stakes in two London-listed oil companies that had hitherto faced problems with Russian regulators.

Sweden's financial regulator has given Gulf-based Borse Dubai approval to own OMX, the Nordic stock market operator, bringing Nasdaq's joint $4.9 billion bid to acquire OMX with Borse Dubai a significant step closer.

BHP Billiton, whose $153 billion takeover offer for a rival mining company, Rio Tinto, was rejected by the target's board, took its case to shareholders Monday, detailing what it said would eventually be $3.7 billion in annual savings and holding out the promise of $30 billion in payouts if the deal goes ahead.

A widening corruption scandal at the Korean electronics giant Samsung engulfed the government of South Korea on Monday when President Roh Moo-hyun's next chief prosecutor and his top anticorruption agent faced accusations of accepting bribes from the conglomerate.

Constellation Brands, the winemaker, said Monday that it planned to buy the American wine business of a rival, Fortune Brands, for $885 million, in a move to expand its portfolio of higher-end California wines.
In Science Times, Natalie Anger lays into Hollywood cartoons, in which the overwhelming majority of animal characters are male, despite nature's preferred sex ratio of roughly 50-50:
Accounts.
The online brokerage is the latest financial company to struggle as a result of a large stake in complex bonds tied to the American housing market.

Despite government crackdowns, the use of so-called "black money" is still rife in Spain and could be skewing officially reported prices by as much as 30 percent, says Martin Dell of Kyero.com, the property portal.
Adrian Peterson's torn knee ligament was the injury news of the day, but the status of several other top players is up in the air.
The television folks who brought you tmz.com are back online again, this time not with the inside dope on celebrity misbehavior but with a community Web site for mothers.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer is abandoning his plan to issue driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants, saying that opposition is just too overwhelming to move forward.
Twin New York Times/CBS News polls suggest that the outcome for the presidential nominating battle is far from settled in either Iowa or New Hampshire.
The C.I.A. officer pleaded guilty today to charges that she illegally sought classified information from government computers about the radical Islamic group Hezbollah.
In a lawsuit, Judith Regan says that an executive with the company encouraged her to mislead investigators about her relationship with Bernard B. Kerik.
The Dow rose 2.5 percent as investors cheered upbeat news on consumer spending and the credit market.
Death rates for 13 diseases that can be prevented by childhood vaccinations are at all-time lows in the United States, according to a study.
European competition authorities refused to approve Google’s purchase of DoubleClick, and ordered an in-depth review amid opposition from rivals, publishers and consumer groups.
The patients in Chicago were the first known cases of the virus being spread by organ transplants in 22 years.
The president said that the bill contained money for too many of the special projects known as earmarks.
An attempt by the European Union to impose caps on aircraft emissions received a lift when legislators voted to raise the costs on airlines and to include international flights sooner than expected.
The price of crude oil extended its slide today after a prominent energy group lowered its estimate for worldwide oil demand, saying high prices were hurting consumption.
Economic unease, from the credit markets to the gas pump, has proven a boon to the nation’s largest discount retailer, but a bust for the biggest home improvement chain.
New York City Police Commissioner Raymond Kelly said that the shooting of an unarmed 18-year-old Brooklyn man was justified.
Police blocked the road to Benazir Bhutto’s home and arrested hundreds from her party. In a phone interview with CNN, Ms. Bhutto called for General Pervez Musharraf to resign.
Allen Iverson scored 37 points and J. R. Smith added 29 to help the Denver Nuggets beat the visiting Cleveland Cavaliers, 122-100, last night.

EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn., Nov. 12 (AP) — Vikings running back Adrian Peterson will miss Sunday’s game against the Oakland Raiders with a torn ligament in his right knee. Coach Brad Childress said Monday that Peterson tore his lateral collateral ligament in Minnesota’s 34-0 loss to Green Bay. Peterson will not require surgery, Childress said.
Five officers shot a man after responding to his mother’s 911 call for help in a domestic dispute, an official said.

Monday’s auction was so singular that it could not really serve as an indicator of how the art market is responding to the plunge in stock market prices and disappointing results at Sotheby’s sale of Impressionist works.
Chris Paul, who led the Hornets with 27 points, scored on a driving layup with 2.6 seconds left to break a tie with the Nets, who did not fare too well without Vince Carter.

A highly contagious virus that causes stomach flu sickened about 220 passengers aboard a Norwegian Cruise Lines ship that returned to Honolulu after its weekly seven-day cruise around the islands, officials said. Laboratory tests found that a norovirus, which causes nausea, vomiting and diarrhea, was on the ship, Pride of Hawaii, said Janice Okubo, spokeswoman for the Hawaii Department of Health. The virus infected about 9 percent of the 2,500 passengers. Passengers who felt sick, as well as their cabinmates, were asked to remain in their rooms for 24 hours. Norwegian said it was giving those passengers a $200 on-ship credit. Surfaces in the ship were cleaned to eliminate lingering viruses, it said.
Jorge Posada has agreed to terms of a four-year deal that would make him the highest-paid catcher in the majors.
China’s consumer prices rose sharply in October, the government reported on Tuesday, adding to pressure for measures to cool a surge in food prices.

Patrik Elias ended a streak of 11 games without a goal at exactly the right time last night, scoring with 5 minutes 23 seconds left in the third period for the Devils in a 3-2 victory over the host Pittsburgh Penguins.
The freshman Eric Gordon scored 33 points last night in his first college game, and D. J. White added 17 points to help No. 8 Indiana defeat visiting Chattanooga, 99-79.

An obituary on Sunday about the writer Norman Mailer misspelled, in some copies, the surname of the secretary of state whom Mr. Mailer invited to a literary conference, an invitation that prompted criticism of Mr. Mailer from leftists. He is George P. Shultz, not Schultz.
The Atlantic Sun, a little-known league spread over five Southeastern states, surely had its best week ever, defeating three major programs in a four-day period.

Top-ranked Roger Federer has lost consecutive matches for the first time in four and a half years, falling yesterday to Fernando González, 4-6, 7-6 (1), 7-5, at the season-ending Masters Cup in Shanghai.The loss ended Federer’s 15-match winning streak in round-robin play at this tournament, which features the top eight men’s singles players and doubles teams. Earlier yesterday, Andy Roddick overcame a lapse in the second set to defeat Nikolay Davydenko, 6-3, 4-6, 6-2. Federer will probably have to beat Roddick and Davydenko to reach the semifinals.Federer, who won three Grand Slam titles this year, has already clinched the No. 1 ranking for the fourth straight year. But in the last month, he lost twice to David Nalbandian. Each defeat came in a Masters Series event, first in the final at Madrid, then in the third round at Paris.

Oklahoma State linebacker Chris Collins was permanently dismissed from the team yesterday, six days after he pleaded guilty to felony aggravated sexual assault of a 12-year-old girl in Texas. Collins had been suspended for the remainder of the season Thursday, after entering his plea last week on a charge resulting from an assault in May 2004, when Collins was a junior in high school.Collins, one of four men charged in the assault, will be formally sentenced Dec. 10. He will be permitted to keep his scholarship.

Hartwick College’s 72-70 victory over Utica College on Saturday broke the all-division N.C.A.A. scoring record for the second time in less than a month. On Oct. 27, Weber State beat Portland State, 73-68, to break a 38-year-old record.The Utica-Hartwick game included 20 touchdowns, 1,042 yards of total offense and 52 first downs.

Curtis Strange and Hubert Green, each winners of 2 majors and 17 tournaments on the PGA Tour, were among six golfers inducted into the World Golf Hall of Fame last night.Se Ri Pak of South Korea was inducted based on the L.P.G.A. Tour’s points system, which she surpassed three years ago, combined with 10 years on the women’s Tour.Strange, elected on the PGA Tour ballot with 70 percent of the vote, was the last golfer to win consecutive United States Opens, in 1988-89. Green, 60, captured the 1977 United States Open and the 1985 P.G.A. Championship. Joe Carr, the first Irishman to be inducted; Kel Nagle of Australia, who won the 1960 British Open; and Charles Blair Macdonald, who designed the National Golf Links in Southampton, N.Y., were the other inductees.

Wyoming Coach Joe Glenn apologized yesterday for making an obscene gesture to Utah players on Saturday in Salt Lake City after the Utes tried an onside kick while ahead by 43 points in a 50-0 victory.“Football is an emotional game, and I let my emotions get the best of me,” Glenn said in a statement.Glenn was reprimanded by the Mountain West Conference.
Britain’s prime minister said he will push for a worldwide ban on foreign investment in Iran’s oil and gas industry and other financial sanctions.
About 500 unionized writers for CBS News are expected to vote Thursday to authorize a strike, potentially joining their creative colleagues on the picket line.
A magnetic resonance imaging exam Monday revealed that Vince Carter sustained a Grade 1 sprain Saturday night against the Boston Celtics.

A visit to the back right corner of the Knicks’ locker room usually provides a glimpse into the team’s state of affairs. Quentin Richardson resides there, dispensing brutal honesty when it is needed most.

A front-page article on Oct. 29 about the lobbyist Robert D. Blackwill, a former White House aide who works on behalf of the former Iraqi prime minister Ayad Allawi for the Washington firm of Barbour Griffith & Rogers, misstated, in two references, the surname of another former aide who met with one or more of the firm’s lobbyists to discuss Iraq, according to disclosure reports. She is Meghan O’Sullivan, not Sullivan.
The Congolese militia leader Thomas Lubanga, accused of using child soldiers, is to go on trial in March as the first person to be tried by the International Criminal Court in The Hague.
A French soldier with the United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon was killed and another wounded in a shooting accident, a force spokeswoman said.
As France braced for a fresh wave of transportation strikes, a union leader said walkouts set to start tonight were about more than retirement benefits of about public sector workers.

NATO forces in Afghanistan may be breaching their own operating rules by handing detainees to Afghan security services despite reports that they torture their prisoners, the human rights group Amnesty International said.
The Libyan government denied entry to tourists without an Arabic translation of their passports, forcing several planeloads of foreigners to turn back on arrival.
The United Nations envoy to Myanmar, Paulo Sérgio Pinheiro, visited Yangon’s notorious Insein prison and other sites where protesters were held after soldiers crushed anti-junta marches in September.
Two studies could change the way teachers and parents understand children who are disruptive or withdrawn.

A tiny hole in a pipe at a nuclear power plant led to a large investigation over sabotage fears, but the authorities have closed the case as an unsolved act of vandalism, the F.B.I. said. “No one is being charged unless more evidence becomes available,” said Judy Orihuela, a bureau spokeswoman. An 1/8-inch hole was discovered in March 2006 in a cooling system pipe at the Turkey Point power plant, operated by Florida Power and Light. The F.B.I. sent 50 agents to interview more than 700 workers. An out-of-state contractor hired to do routine maintenance is suspected of drilling the hole, Ms. Orihuela said.

A shooting at a house on a suburban San Diego cul-de-sac left five people dead in what the authorities said could be a murder-suicide. Police officers responding to a report of shots fired on Sunday found two men and two women dead at the house in Temecula, said Sgt. Dennis Gutierrez of the Riverside County sheriff’s department. A fifth victim, a woman, died at a hospital, he said. Sergeant Gutierrez said neighbors told investigators that all five people lived at the house. The victims’ identities were not released, but all were thought to be related, he said.

A teenager who plotted an attack on a suburban Philadelphia high school discussed the 1999 Columbine massacre with the Finnish student who killed eight people and then himself at a school near Helsinki last week, the teenager’s lawyer said. The American, who is 14 years old, contacted the Finnish youth, Pekka-Eric Auvinen, 18, online last summer, and they exchanged views about Web sites and videos, including one that glorified the Columbine attack, said the American’s lawyer, J. David Farrell. Although that video was among “common interests” the two boys discussed, there was no talk of any plan that Mr. Auvinen had to attack the Finnish school, Mr. Farrell said, adding that his client was “shocked” by the attack in Finland.

A federal judge ordered the White House to preserve copies of all its e-mail messages, a move that Bush administration lawyers had argued strongly against. The order, from Judge Henry H. Kennedy Jr. of Federal District Court, came in response to two lawsuits trying to determine whether the White House destroyed e-mail messages in violation of federal law. Two private groups that filed suit, Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington and the National Security Archive, say 5 million messages have disappeared. Judge Kennedy’s order is directed at maintaining backup tapes that contain copies of messages.

Two teenagers stabbed an adult acquaintance, took a blowtorch to his corpse and threw his severed head into a river, prosecutors said. The teenagers, Jean Pierre Orlewicz, 17, and Alexander James Letkemann, 18, ambushed 26-year-old Daniel Sorenson last Wednesday in a garage owned by Mr. Orlewicz’s grandfather, said Kym Worthy, the Wayne County prosecutor. “They prepared a space to kill him,” Ms. Worthy said at a news conference. Mr. Sorenson’s head was found Saturday in the Rouge River on the border of Detroit and Dearborn Heights, about 15 miles from where his torso was found. Not guilty pleas were entered on the teenagers’ behalf, and both were ordered held without bail.
A pathologist hired by the family of Carol A. Gotbaum concurred with an official finding that Ms. Gotbaum had accidentally strangled herself while in police custody.
The position at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers will provide former Vice President Al Gore with an opportunity to nurture green businesses.
The nation’s largest private employer is offering better coverage to a greater number of workers.
Ronald Reagan may have been blessed with a Hollywood smile, but he was elbow deep in the same old race-baiting Southern strategy of Goldwater and Nixon.
The M.T.A. is wrong to try to solve its problems primarily on the backs of financially burdened riders.
The story of the 1930s public works programs is timely again, because much of America is falling apart.
Every penny you donate to The Times’s Neediest Cases Fund goes to seven local charities.
With the price of crude flirting with $100 a barrel, lawmakers may finally be preparing to pass a series of energy-saving measures.
The recent crash of an Air Force F-15 fighter jet is the latest reminder of the tough military budget choices this country will face for the foreseeable future.
Scott Stevens pondered his future Monday night as he, Mark Messier, Ron Francis, Al MacInnis and Jim Gregory were inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame.
Coaches in the National Football League may rank among the most paranoid people on the planet, along with counterintelligence agents and U.F.O. conspiracy theorists.
Colleagues often describe the U.S. attorney in Minneapolis as representative of what went wrong at the department.
Colts Coach Tony Dungy apologized to his team after Sunday’s game for wasting a timeout to argue a call, but the loss may linger long after the frustration over its unusual conclusion wears off.
A surveillance camera captured the scene as a gunman opened fire on three boys shortly before midnight in Elizabeth, N.J.
Bryant Gumbel, a skilled sports and morning news anchor, seemed not to know the game as well as he should have in his first season as the play-by-play announcer for the NFL Network.
Darren Dopp could face perjury charges over his denial that he ordered surveillance of  Senator Joseph L. Bruno’s travels, according to a person who has been briefed on the investigation.
For now, the Mets are only monitoring Alex Rodriguez and are preparing to forge ahead on the more pressing issues of identifying a catcher and a second baseman.
The move comes as many analysts anticipate that the business intelligence software market is about to enter a period of significant demand.
Dustin Pedroia, the Boston Red Sox’ second baseman, was an easy pick for American League rookie of the year, while Ryan Braun barely edged Troy Tulowitzki for the National League honor yesterday.
The Blackstone Group reported third-quarter earnings that were lower than in the period a year earlier, as troubles in the credit market shook up its real estate business.
New regulations in Hollis, N.H., threaten the social scene that has emerged at the town dump.
The drama of Italian soccer, the success and the squalor, the skill and the sleaze, has again been laid bare for the world to see.
Mr. Mann, a director from the heyday of live television, won an Oscar for his first big-screen effort, “Marty,” in 1955.
The Bloomberg administration wants to try to convince thousands of low-achieving students that succeeding in school is actually, well, cool.

Twelve Wall Street firms that had started competing platforms for trading unregistered securities known as 144a issues have agreed to cooperate on a single platform operated by the Nasdaq stock market, the exchange said yesterday.
Ms. Day appeared in almost two dozen MGM movies during Hollywood’s Golden Age, notably as the nurse Mary Lamont in a series of Dr. Kildare movies.
The biotechnology company disclosed that it recently received two federal subpoenas seeking documents related to its products.
The wind died down and the driving rains stayed away last night in Seattle, so the Seahawks poured it on the San Francisco 49ers instead.

The police arrested about a dozen students and adults — including parents — during a fight at Lakewood High School yesterday that involved up to 150 students at its peak, officials said. The fight started about 10:45 a.m. between two nonstudents in the parking lot, and soon spread to the nearby lunchroom, Deputy Police Chief Charles Smith said during an afternoon news conference. About 75 officers from Lakewood and surrounding towns were needed to break up the brawl, Chief Smith said. The most serious injury was suffered by a student who needed stitches for facial injuries, the police said.

An Albertson woman who is the daughter of a renowned Kentucky Derby-winning jockey has been charged with vehicular manslaughter and driving while intoxicated after a crash Sunday morning in which one person was killed and four people were injured, the Nassau County police said yesterday. The accused woman, Sophia Santos, 20, the daughter of the jockey José Santos, was in Nassau University Medical Center yesterday, the police said. They said that Nancy Tumminello of Elmont was turning left onto Hempstead Turnpike from Wantagh Avenue about 2:30 a.m. on Sunday when her car was hit by Ms. Santos’s, which was westbound on Hempstead Turnpike. One passenger in Ms. Tumminello’s car, Virginia Casazza Urgo, 62, of Valley Stream, who was out celebrating her birthday with the group, was pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. Two other passengers were taken to the hospital in critical condition, while Ms. Tumminello and a fourth passenger were treated and released, the police said.

At a ceremony commemorating the 265 people who died six years ago in the crash of American Airlines Flight 587, which was bound for the Dominican Republic, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg noted that some elected officials could not attend because they were in that country helping out after a tropical storm. The Airbus A300-600, carrying many Dominican-born New York residents, crashed in the quiet neighborhood of Belle Harbor on Nov. 12, 2001, after taking off from Kennedy International Airport. All 260 aboard the plane were killed, as well as five people on the ground. Earlier this month, Tropical Storm Noel claimed the lives of 84 people in the Dominican Republic.

The head of the Police Department’s detective bureau is under investigation on allegations of sexual misconduct with a minor, the Norwalk police chief has confirmed. The chief, Harry Rilling, told The Hour newspaper that the official, Lt. Thomas Cummings, had been removed from active duty while the complaint was being investigated by state prosecutors. Lieutenant Cummings, 46, has not been charged with any crime. Chief Rilling said he asked the state’s attorney’s office to investigate, although he said the complaint did not claim that Lieutenant Cummings’s official position was involved.

Constellation Brands, the winemaker, said yesterday that it planned to buy the American wine business of a rival, Fortune Brands Inc., for $885 million, in a move to expand its portfolio of higher-end California wines.
Salesforce.com wants to become a platform like Microsoft’s Windows operating system, a product so popular that it is the foundation for a veritable ecosystem of software developers.

Secretary of the State Susan Bysiewicz ordered a second recount of ballots in East Haven’s mayoral election yesterday after discrepancies turned up in the first recount. April Capone-Almon, a Democrat, defeated Mayor Joseph Maturo, a Republican, by 21 votes in last week’s election, according to Election Day counts. Local officials who counted the paper ballots on Sunday found that Ms. Capone-Almon had an even bigger lead. Lori Jaffe, an election moderator, declined to reveal the exact discrepancy, but said the victory margin was now about 50 to 60 votes.

A sophomore at New York University committed suicide in a dormitory room on Friday, university officials said yesterday. The university declined to identify the student or to provide other details, citing requests for privacy from the student’s family. The suicide was the second at N.Y.U. this semester; a freshman from California jumped from a dormitory roof in September. In 2003 and 2004, five students jumped to their deaths.

A city councilman has proposed a ban on feeding pigeons as a way to control the number of them in New York. Noting that pigeons produce an average of 25 pounds of droppings each year, Councilman Simcha Felder, a Brooklyn Democrat, proposed that the city impose a $1,000 fine for feeding pigeons. “We have pigeons doing whatever they do all over the city without anyone trying to stop it,” he said. Efforts to chase pigeons have had mixed results. Electrifying roosting areas near elevated subways has had some success, but an effort to use hawks to lower the pigeon population in Bryant Park was scrapped after a hawk attacked a Chihuahua.
Japan’s economy grew more than expected in the third quarter, quieting some concerns about the economy.
The era in which a new ethanol distillery in agricultural America was greeted with delight seems to be ending.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and senior members of his administration continued to reach out privately to the producers and stagehands.
Less than a month after its sales forecast fell short of analysts’ estimates, the maker of security software said Monday that it would cut jobs in some business units.
A Roman Catholic nun pleaded no contest on Monday to two counts of indecent behavior with a child in connection with accusations from when she worked at a school in Milwaukee.
Staten Island will soon bring a little bit of Tuscany to New York, in the form of a vineyard being developed at the Staten Island Botanical Garden.
Yet BHP Billiton, whose $153 billion takeover offer for rival Rio Tinto was rejected by the target’s board, stopped short of making a hostile bid for Rio.
If the Supreme Court agrees to hear a case on the District of Columbia’s strict gun-control law it is likely to find itself back on the front lines of the culture wars.

The move by the United States attorney’s office signals that criminal charges may be filed against the crew of the vessel that lost 58,000 gallons of fuel after hitting the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge.
The Jets are more secretive than most about injuries. So it was startling Monday when the Jets disclosed which injured knee had ended the season of Jonathan Vilma.
Reebok will segue next month from shoe business to show business, teaming with the IFC cable network for a celebrity interview series that is being produced by a new entertainment arm of Reebok.
Many Californians are discovering that they do not have enough insurance to rebuild their fire-damaged homes.

The authorities charged 18 men from four states in what they described Monday as a new twist on the old sport of fox hunting: releasing trapped animals into fenced pens so they can be chased down by dogs.
The Giants could be the third-best team in the N.F.C. after Dallas and Green Bay, but are 0-3 against them and unlikely to improve their playoff position in the next seven weeks.

MGM Mirage and Pansy Ho, daughter of the billionaire Stanley Ho, will open their joint venture’s first casino in Macao on Sunday. The casino, the MGM Grand Macau, will have 600 rooms, suites and villas and 375 gambling tables and cost about $1.25 billion, said MGM, the gambling company based in Las Vegas.

Nymex Holdings, parent of the New York Mercantile Exchange, will buy a 15.1 percent stake in a Norwegian financial derivatives exchange, Imarex, for about $52 million, the companies announced. Imarex, based in Oslo, specializes in markets for bulk and tanker shipping, electrical power, oil, carbon dioxide emissions, and seafood. It has operations in major Norwegian cities, as well as in Singapore, London, Houston and Zurich.

Two electrical equipment and distribution companies, Hagemeyer of the Netherlands and Rexel of France, are in exclusive talks about a $4.6 billion buyout, the companies said. Rexel would pay 4.85 euros ($7.13) a share, or around 3.13 billion euros. Rexel has not yet made a formal offer, and Hagemeyer said the bid would meet “high-level due diligence” this week.

China will get a stake in a 2,000-ton-a-year uranium mine in Kazakhstan in exchange for its share in a uranium-processing business, the state-owned company Kazatomprom said. The company’s president, Moukhtar Dzhakishev, said in Almaty that the company would gain access to Chinese assets, without elaborating. Kazatomprom said on Oct. 12 it signed agreements in Beijing with the China Guangdong Nuclear Power Group and the China National Nuclear Corporation, China’s largest producers of atomic energy.

Isuzu Motors, Japan’s biggest maker of light trucks, had a 26 percent drop in second-quarter operating profit after rising overseas vehicle sales failed to make up for a slump in domestic demand. Operating profit, or sales minus the cost of goods sold and selling, general and administrative expenses, fell to 25 billion yen ($227 million) in the three months that ended Sept. 30, from 33.7 billion yen a year earlier. Sales rose 10 percent, to 472.4 billion yen.
The killing of a British student has baffled and intrigued Perugia, Italy, a scenic university city that attracts thousands of students from other countries every year.

European finance ministers meeting in Brussels urged China to let its currency strengthen so Europe’s economy no longer bears the brunt of the slide in the United States dollar. The officials are stepping up complaints two weeks before a delegation led by Luxembourg’s finance minister, Jean-Claude Juncker, and the European Central Bank president, Jean-Claude Trichet, arrives in Beijing to make the case for exchange-rate revaluation.

WestLB, the German state-owned bank based in Düsseldorf, said it would report a full-year loss of more than 100 million euros ($145 million) because of “persistently difficult market developments.” The lender will post a pretax “low three-digit million euro loss,” in contrast to an original forecast of a profit, according to a statement. The company, which is scheduled to publish nine-month earnings on Dec. 6, blamed “the substantial price losses of structured securities in the past weeks.”.
The luxury sports car maker said it earned 4.24 billion euros ($6.18 billion) for the year, up from 1.39 billion euros a year earlier.
The National Right to Life Committee, courted by a number of Republican candidates, has decided to endorse Fred D. Thompson.
Like drugs and gangs and poverty, a four-story wall of rusty shipping containers that blocks the daylight has simply become another unavoidable part of life at the Millard E. Terrell Homes.
Ms. Martinez, a stand-up comic, was known for sassy humor with the Original Latin Divas of Comedy and other Latina troupes.
Analysts said investors had few reasons to sustain a rally, even with many stocks available at enticingly low prices.
Adobe’s Chief executive Bruce R. Chizen, said Monday that he would step down and be succeeded by the company’s president and chief operating officer, Shantanu Narayen, on Dec. 1.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,848 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans last week:.

BUSINESS-CLASS SALES The trans-Atlantic business-class fare war for holiday travel that Continental started recently is escalating as American, Lufthansa and eight other carriers have joined in. Round-trip business-class fares on trans-Atlantic routes, which can cost $10,000 at regular walk-up prices, are being offered at $1,200 and less by some carriers for limited periods over the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays. Matthew Bennett, publisher of the online premium air travel newsletter Flightbliss.com, suggests that the discounts are a good way for elite-status frequent fliers to take holiday trips in comfort while padding their year-end totals of miles needed to requalify for elite status next year. Business-class fares, he points out, often yield extra qualifying mileage credit.

LESSING--Helen. The Board of Directors, officers and staff of American Friends of Tel Aviv University mourn the loss of our cherished friend, Helen Lessing. Helen and her husband, Fred, were long-serving members of the Board of American Friends and of the Board of Governors of Tel Aviv University. They were widely esteemed for their generous support of higher education, as well as an unwavering commitment to the Jewish community. The Fred and Helen Lessing Professor of Ancient History chair at Tel Aviv University is a testament to their dedication to the study of the past as a guide to our future. We extend our deepest sympathies to daughter Joan, and the entire family. William F. Cohen, Chairman Roni Krinsky, President LESSING--Helen D. The Board and staff of the American Friends of the Israel Museum and of the Israel Museum mourn the death of Helen D. Lessing, mother of our long time Executive Committee member, Joan C. Lessing. We offer heartfelt condolences to Joan and the entire family. Stephen S. Lash, President, AFIM James S. Snyder, Anne & Jerome Fisher Dir., IM Monique Birenbaum, Executive Director, AFIM

PEPE--Charles W., 80, died November 7, 2007 in Atlanta, Georgia after a prolonged illness. Born May 21, 1927 in Brooklyn, New York, Mr. Pepe received a Bachelor of Science from Tufts University and later a Master of Arts in teaching from Emory University. From New York, at Mr. Richard Rich's invitation, Mr. Pepe moved south and worked in the executive offices of Rich's Department Store. Mr. Pepe began his teaching career in the City of Atlanta at the Margaret Mitchell School. He then became the principal of John B. Gordon School, and later worked as the principal of Sarah Smith School, where he remained until he retired. Mr. Pepe served on the board of trustees of the Savannah College of Art and Design. Pepe Hall, the art history and architectural history building on the college's Savannah campus, is named for him and his wife, Marie. A life-long educator and passionate advocate of organ donation, Charlie Pepe has donated his body for scientific inquiry to Emory University. In lieu of cards or flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Charlie and Marie Pepe Scholarship Fund, c/ o SCAD Institutional Advancement, Post Office Box 3146, Savannah, Georgia 31402. Charles Pepe is survived by his wife, Marie Huper Pepe, and a sister, Mrs. Virginia Gathy, of Manhasset, Long Island, New York and Boynton Beach, Florida.

Democratic Party elites say Rudolph W. Giuliani would be the toughest competitor for their party's presidential nominee to face next November, according to a survey of superdelegates, which include members of the Democratic National Committee and elected officials. Many of the superdelegates did not offer an opinion of which candidate would be the most daunting opponent for the Democratic presidential candidate, according to the survey, which was conducted by The New York Times and CBS News. However, while a majority did not offer a candidate name, 22 percent ranked Mr. Giuliani as the toughest rival, and 11 percent said Mitt Romney would be.

So bad, apparently, that in an interview last week he twice refused to say whether he would endorse her should she win the Democratic presidential nomination.

WETTREICH--Inge. The Kaplen JCC on the Palisades mourns the passing of Inge Wettreich, a beloved member of the Board of Trustees. A woman of many passions and an involved leader of many communal organizations, Inge served selflessly to advocate for those less fortunate, including senior adults, the frail elderly, and children and adults with special needs. In her dedication to the JCC, Inge served as the first and longest chairperson for internal fundraising, chair of the Senior Adult Advisory Committee, was an active supporter of Cultural Arts, and a valued member of the House Committee. As the JCC horticulturist - in - res idence, she was personally responsible for much of the landscaping that beautifies the JCC grounds. To recognize her talents and generosity of heart, the JCC dedicated a garden at the JCC in her honor. She and her husband, Dolph, were formally acknowledged for their ''passionate and compassionate'' leadership at a JCC gala benefit in 2004. Our heartfelt condolences to her husband Dolph, her daughter Karen and son Jeffrey, grandchildren Dana, David and Alexa, and her sister Ellen. May her memory be for a blessing. Robin Miller, President Avi A. Lewinson, Exec. Dir. WETTREICH--Inge. The Officers and members of the board of Governors of the Jewish Home Family note with profound sorrow the passing of our longtime supporter, and very dear friend, Inge Wettreich. Inge was a special person who exhibited a deep commitment to many humanitarian, medical, social and Jewish causes. She demonstrated a profound dedication to helping the elderly and less fortunate as seen in her commitment to the entire Jewish community. Inge was a very special person to all who were privileged to know her. She will be missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved husband, Dolph, her son Jeffrey, her daughter Karen, and her grandchildren Dana, David and Alexa. May her name be for a blessing. Ary Freilich, Pres. Jewish Home at Rockleigh Carl Epstein, Pres. Jewish Home Foundation Maggie Kaplen, Pres. Jewish Home Assisted Living William Lippman, Pres. Jewish Home & Rehab Ctr Charles P. Berkowitz, Executive Vice President WETTREICH--Inge, of Englewood, NJ, died November 11 at the age of 79. Beloved wife of Dolph Wettreich, and the late Herbert Schwarz. Devoted mother of Karen Schlansky and Jeffrey Schwarz. Loving sister to Ellen Miano. Cherished grandmother to Dana and David Schlansky and Alexa Schwarz. Inge Wettreich was a landscape architect and prominent leader in many local and national organizations. She was a long time leader of UJF/UJC of Englewood and surrounding communities. She was involved in the leadership campaign, secretary of the UJC board and chair of the older adults committee. She was on the board of Directors and Trustee of the JCC on the Palisades, Tenafly, NJ. She served seven years as chairperson for internal fundraising and eight years as chair of the Senior adult Department. She was one of the original founders of the JCC Thurnauer School of Music, Cultural Arts Committee and was the JCC Horticulturalist in Residence. Inge was the campaign chair and president of the Women's Division of the United Jewish Fund. She was on the Board of Temple Emanuel in Englewood and was a long term board member of Englewood Hospital and Medical Center. She was an activist for the Israel Cancer Research Center, and established the Partners in Research Program for cancer research. She received the Humanitarian award for her efforts in cancer research. Inge was president of the UJA-Association for Developmentally Disabled Adults, providing group homes for handicapped adults. She was on the board of JHRC, Jewish Home and Rehabilitation Center in Rockleigh, NJ, as well as many other needy local and national agencies. In each organization beautification was a side benefit; she created lovely gardens for many of these organizations. The funeral will be 10am, Tuesday November 13, at the JCC on the Palisades, 411 East Clinton Ave, Tenafly, NJ.

GOLTZER--Albert. The New York Philharmonic mourns the passing, on November 10 at age 89, of its former oboist, a member beginning in 1938. He left for military service in World War II, and later played with the St. Louis and CBS Symphony Orchestras. He returned to the Philharmonic in 1955, serving until 1984 as Associate Principal Oboe alongside his brother, the late Associate Principal Bassoon Harold Goltzer. We extend our condolences to his wife, Doris, sons George and Seth, and family. Lorin Maazel, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Zarin Mehta, Pres./Exec.Dir. Members of the Staff

A state supreme court judge in Sydney dismissed a case against a terrorism suspect, Izhar ul-Haque. Mr. Haque had been accused of attending a terrorist training camp run in Pakistan in early 2003. But the judge said he had been detained and threatened by security officers in a manner ''reminiscent of Kafka.'' The decision was another blow for the security forces, which are still reeling from the fiasco surrounding the arrest of an Indian doctor, Mohammed Haneef, during the summer. He was ultimately deported but never charged.

8 P.M. (22, 26) JUDGMENT DAY: INTELLIGENT DESIGN ON TRIAL In 2004 the Dover, Pa., school board ordered science teachers to read a statement to their high school biology students that suggested intelligent design as an alternative to Darwin's theory of evolution. The teachers refused to read the statement, and parents filed a lawsuit in federal court accusing the school board of violating the separation of church and state. This ''Nova'' episode talks to townspeople, scientists and lawyers who participated in the historic and emotion-riddled six-week trial that followed. 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES After the decayed corpse of a high school student is found in a time capsule, the team investigates his former classmates, now in their 30s.

A pathologist hired by the family of Carol A. Gotbaum, who died in police custody at a Phoenix airport, said yesterday that he concurred with an official finding that Ms. Gotbaum had accidentally strangled herself. But he also blamed the police for her death. The pathologist, Dr. Cyril H. Wecht, who conducted a separate autopsy, said he agreed that Ms. Gotbaum, while intoxicated, accidentally strangled herself on her shackles at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport on Sept. 28. But Dr. Wecht also said that officers roughed up Ms. Gotbaum, 45, a New York resident who was flying to an alcohol treatment center in Tucson, and said they should have watched her as she sat in the holding room alone, screaming. Sgt. Andy Hill, a Phoenix police spokesman, said officers followed proper procedures when they arrested Ms. Gotbaum, the stepdaughter-in-law of Betsy Gotbaum, the New York City public advocate.

The ''What's Online'' column in Business Day on Saturday, about a report on credit cards published by the National Consumer Law Center, misstated the organization's Web address. The correct address is consumerlaw.org, not consumerlaw.com.

An article on Thursday about Barack Obama's late arrival at a rally in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, after his plane landed in Des Moines misstated the name of the college where the rally was held. It is Kirkwood Community College, not Kirkland.

PFEFFER--Marjorie. The Board of Directors of the Arnold Pfeffer Center for Neuropsychoanalysis deeply mourns the loss of their fellow director, dear friend, and chief benefactor. When her husband Arnold, the founder of our scientific organization, died in 2002, Marjorie stepped into his position and successfully helped guide its growth from local, to national, then international prominence. In her quiet unassuming way, she was a strong leader, always generous, and thoughtful of others. Building bridges between psychoanalysis and the neurosciences in a way that benefited both fields was her focus, and in this effort her dedication and drive inspired all who came to know her. She will be greatly missed. Our heartfelt condolences go out to her family and to her many friends. Mark Solms, Ph.D. , Director David Milrod, M.D., Chair

BRUNELL--Albert L., on November 10th, 2007, age 73. Loving husband of Susanne, father of Leslie and Thomas, grandfather of Sebastian and Seth, Emma and Sallie Corrado. He gave us his love, his kindness, his humor. We will miss him greatly. Marcus and Samton families. Funeral Services 2pm Today, Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, NJ. Donations to Jewish Home at Rockleigh, NJ 07647.

GRANGER--Lee. The American Academy of Dramatic Arts mourns the loss of one of its most devoted and longserving former trustees, Lee M. Granger. Her tireless efforts on behalf of the Academy and its students live on in our shared and enduring legacy. On behalf of our Officers, Board of Trustees, faculties and staff, we express our sincere condolences to her sons Thomas M. Clyde and D. Mason Granger, and to her extended family. Samuel Davis, Chairman Roger Croucher, President and CEO James Warwick, President, LA Division GRANGER--Lee M., 93, a lifelong resident of New York City, died on November 9, 2007. Widow of the late David Granger. She is survived by two sons, Thomas M. Clyde of Boston and D. Mason Granger of New York City and New Orleans, a brother, Jonathan Mason of West Palm Beach, FL, three grandchildren, Alexandra Clyde Meskan of Wayzata, MN, Thomas M. Clyde of Atlanta, GA, and William C. Clyde of Durham, NH, and six greatgrandchildren. Over the years she helped to support the work of, and served on the boards of, a variety of organizations benefitting the community, including The Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, The Boys Club of New York, The American Academy of Dramatic Arts, American Friends of Blerancourt, French Institute Alliance Francaise, and Grosvenor Neighborhood House. A memorial event will be held at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to The Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY 10065, or The Boys Club of New York, 287 East 10th St., New York, NY 10009, or The American Academy of Dramatic Arts, 120 Madison Ave., New York, NY 10016.

SHALOWITZ--Sidney, 79, of Highland Park, IL, November 10, 2007. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Father of Karen (Jim Price), Richard (Fredi Schwebel) and Deborah (Bruce Cowans). Grandfather of Samantha Shalowitz, Deena, Aaron and Naomi Cowans.
The ''Short Cuts'' column in Business Day on Saturday, about replacing the batteries in smoke alarms, misstated the recent change regarding daylight saving time. It ended on Nov. 4; it did not begin.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s decision to abandon his plan to issue driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants comes after a tumultuous public debate that brought into focus national anxieties over immigration and even presidential politics. Judging from the scores of comments on a blog post published yesterday, the issue will probably remain emotional and raw for some time.

Updated, 11:23 a.m. | Chastened and contrite, Gov. Eliot Spitzer acknowledged this morning that he had misjudged public sentiment in proposing to grant driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants, but he vowed to press Washington for comprehensive immigration legislation and said his critics had stoked partisan and irresponsible fears of immigrants. (The full text of the governor’s remarks is below.)

At Thursday’s monthly board meeting, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to propose raising tolls on its Hudson River crossings, as well as its three bridges in Staten Island and PATH trains.

Today, Con Edison will end 125 years of direct current electricity service that began when Thomas Edison opened his Pearl Street power station on Sept. 4, 1882. Con Ed will now only provide alternating current, in a final, vestigial triumph by Nikola Tesla and George Westinghouse, Mr. Edison’s rivals who were the main proponents of alternating current in the AC/DC debates of the turn of the 20th century.

Another reminder of the resourcefulness of man — and that it takes all kinds in New York City — was Leung Chi Kee, 60, of Bayside, Queens, who on Tuesday was pedaling his homemade bottle cart up Francis Lewis Boulevard.It was trash day in the neighborhood, and as is his habit, Mr. Leung was pedaling his cart up the boulevard and peering into each trash can at the curb for empty bottles to redeem.
Following is the script of the weekly “Only in New York” audio podcast. Listen at left or download the mp3 to a portable player. Browse a list of other Times podcasts here.

On Tuesday evening –- in fact, at the very moment Gov. Eliot Spitzer was abandoning his plan to grant driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants –- a panel of experts on immigration gathered at the Center for Jewish History on West 16th Street for a wide-ranging discussion about immigration to New York City, past and present.

People at the corner of 39th Street and Fourth Avenue in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, got something of a surprise on Tuesday night when, according to the police, the driver of the B35 bus stopped his vehicle and suddenly stormed off.

One of the police officers involved in Monday’s fatal shooting of a troubled 18-year-old man in Brooklyn is a vocalist in a punk-rock band called EDP — which, in police parlance, is an acronym for an emotionally disturbed person.The officer, Sgt. Carl Carrara, was one of five officers who fired a total of 20 shots at Khiel Coppin on a dark sidewalk outside Mr. Coppin’s home on Monday night after Mr. Coppin pulled a hairbrush from beneath his sweatshirt and pointed it at the officers as if it were a gun. Sergeant Carrara, 32, fired five bullets from his semiautomatic gun.

There seems to be mixed messages on the future of Real ID in New York. In an interview from London, Michael Chertoff, the secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, said that he had spoken to Gov. Eliot Spitzer this morning and had been given no indication that New York would back off from a plan announced three weeks ago to offer new federally recognized licenses known as Real ID by next year.

A phalanx of Chinese restaurant workers called for a boycott of Ollie’s Noodle Shop and Grill today. They claimed that the president of the popular restaurant chain was leading a retaliation and blacklisting effort against restaurant workers across the city who were organizing.
After shelving its proposed driver’s license policy this morning, Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s administration just said it would also drop a plan to start charging sales tax on Internet purchases.

When Agata Slota’s bicycle disappeared from a spot near Union Square one day in September, the odds were that she would never see it again. About 60,000 bikes are stolen in New York City each year, and only 2 percent of them are recovered by their owners. Because the bike was distinctive –- her brother had built it himself –- Ms. Slota, 27, posted an ad and photograph on Craigslist in the hopes that someone would notice it.

From the outside, the landmark Metro Theater on Broadway, an Art Deco jewel box between 99th and 100th Streets, looks almost as exquisite as it must have in the 1930s, when movies were still known as “photoplays,” though no photo has played there for two years.
The panel has gathered yet again to answer the vexing annual question of what wine to serve with the bird.

Asa Hoffman, a World Chess Federation master and New York City resident, is being featured in a commercial and print advertising campaign for HIP, the health insurance company. Hoffman, a fixture on the New York City chess scene for decades, said that he got the job through his wife, Eva Veronica Hoffman, an actress. The print ad appeared most recently in Tuesday's New York Post on page 19, although Hoffman is identified as "Mooney, Jim" in the ad.

Kurt Campbell is an expert on Asia and security issues who is now chief executive of the Center for a New American Security. He served in the Pentagon in the Clinton administration, in charge of Asia/Pacific issues, and earlier taught at Harvard. Kurt has written widely, for popular and academic audiences, about everything from Japan to nuclear policy.
Seth Kugel samples an array of delicacies on a traditionally Middle Eastern street near downtown Brooklyn.

LOS ANGELES -- The L.A. Auto Show offers more to gawk at than just shiny metal. Some of the display space is given over to accessories and components, like this Super E-Spec tire from Yokohama Tire Corporation. The company says it can reduce the proportion of petroleum products used in car tires by combining citrus oil with natural rubber, producing a compound it calls Super Nano Power Rubber.

It was fun yesterday, but today, frankly, Michael Schumacher risks reminding us all of how monotonous it is when the same M. Schumacher tops the times, wins all the races, wins all the titles, dominates everything. Today the seven-time world champion even sent Felipe Massa more than two seconds behind him.** (Checkmate +?!) We had a great season with competition this year - but were they really the best drivers in the world?

Termini, Rome's main train station, has come a long way since it was inaugurated for the 1950 Jubilee Holy Year. Most people barely cast a passing glance at the station either becasue they're either running to catch a train, or eager to hit Rome's streets.

Senator Hillary Clinton has come out firmly against giving driver's licenses to illegal immigrants, one day before a debate against her fellow Democrats, who have put her on the defensive on the issue.

The blog I posted yesterday on payday lending has provoked a heap of responses, from people who see a clear economic need for such loans and from people who view the lenders as being little more than crooks.

Giuliani who had some of the most pointed words, saying that Mitt Romney "probably has the worst record on illegal immigration. Last week, the Rand Corporation, a non-profit think tank based in Santa Monica, Calif., released a study analyzing the societal and private benefits of diesel, hybrid, and E85 vehicles. The study found that diesels provided the most benefits, followed closely by hybrids. E85, a fuel blend of 85 percent ethanol from corn and 15 percent gasoline, was determined to provide no net societal benefits, primarily due to its high cost of production.

The Valentinos, as I like to abbreviate one of the last great fashion entourages, are in town. Diane Von Furstenberg and her husband, Barry Diller, had a dinner last night for Valentino and Giancarlo Giammetti at DVF's place on 14th Street. A very fun, casual night. The crowd included Liam Neeson, Natasha Richardson, Daphne Guinness (in a great array of rings and rhinestone bracelets, by Lacroix, that almost looked like gloves), Lynn Wyatt, Stephen and Christine Schwarzman, lots of editors, and Fran Lebowitz. I love talking to Fran, though I always feel like I'm the responsible party in a tippy canoe. So great is my laughter at her lightly and liberally dispensed comments.

A small band of students at Harvard's Institute of Politics is spending a lot of their time in New Hampshire in the leadup to that state's primary, as part of their academic project. In articles and videos on their Web site, CampusVoices.org, they've been following candidates, interviewing voters and campaign staff members. Take a look at some of their videos on the site; they're all student-produced and offer a sometimes grainy, uncut view that you won't necessarily see on television -- especially because they are shot through the eyes of young potential voters.

While "House" lifted Fox to another win in the ratings on Tuesday, NBC earned a solid second-place finish thanks to a two-hour edition of "The Biggest Loser." The weight loss competition matched its highest ratings of the season among adults 18 to 49, according to Nielsen's estimates.

LOS ANGELES -- The 2007 L.A. Auto Show opened to the press Wednesday morning at the Los Angeles Convention Center. Notwithstanding recent industry news about labor shifts, drops in profitability and pledges to restore the greatness of American manufacturers, the L.A. show offers a flurry of press conferences and gives the automakers a chance to promote their shiniest new products.

Texas Tech's Mike Leach did not seem fazed by the record $10,000 fine he was hit with by the Big 12 for criticizing the officials in the Red Raiders' loss to Texas on Saturday. An earthquake measuring 7.7 on the Richter scale caused panic, power outages, damage to airport tarmacs and road closures.
Here are excerpts from reader responses to David Leonhardt’s Nov. 14 Economic Scene column:.
Voters’ anxiety about the cost of health care is strikingly high — higher, in fact, than other economic worries.
The write-down was less than expected and the firm’s remaining $884 million exposure to C.D.O.s gave comfort to investors that the worst of Bear’s write-downs were over.
Pardus Capital Management has sent a letter to management of Delta Air Lines asking it to seek a stock-for-stock merger with UAL.
United Automobile Workers members at Ford Motor approved the new four-year contract by the widest margin of any auto company, the union said today.
New York Gov. Eliot Spitzer conceded that his efforts to sell his proposal to issue driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants had failed.
Prices were restrained at the producer level last month while consumer spending cooled amid speculation that economic growth is slowing, the government reported.
Losses in the housing market are spreading, but revenue growth elsewhere should offset the losses, the bank said.
In their first meeting in 15 years, the prime ministers of North and South Korea discussed economic initiatives today.
The opposition politician Imran Khan was seized by students and turned over to the police, witnesses said.
Labor unions and President Nicolas Sarkozy faced off in a confrontation over his plans to curb the early retirement benefits of a small group of public sector workers.

Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic lost matches yesterday in the round-robin phase of the season-ending Masters Cup in Shanghai. Djokovic lost to Richard Gasquet of France, 6-4, 6-2, and was eliminated from contention for the semifinals with one match left in the Gold Group. Nadal lost to David Ferrer, 4-6, 6-4, 6-3.Top-ranked Roger Federer and No. 4 Nikolay Daydenko, who lost their first matches Monday, will play each other today, followed by Andy Roddick against Fernando González.
A 16-year-old boy running from attackers in Newark yesterday afternoon was fatally shot in the back just as he was climbing over a fence, the police said.
The police charged a man with manslaughter yesterday in the stabbing death of a man in Brooklyn.
McDonald’s said yesterday it would sell up to 21 percent of its company-owned restaurants to franchisees over the next three years.

A film review in Weekend on Friday about “No Country for Old Men,” in which Tommy Lee Jones is one of the stars, misidentified the role Mr. Jones played in “The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada” in comparing his part in the new film to two previous roles. He played a ranch hand — not the sheriff, a role played by Dwight Yoakam.
An Agence France-Presse report in the “Arts, Briefly” column yesterday about French literary awards misspelled the surname of the winner of the Prix Femina. He is Eric Fottorino, not Fittorino.

An article on Nov. 4 about the state of the presidential campaign a year before the election misstated, in some editions, the surname of a former chairman of the Democratic National Committee who said the Democrats’ desire to win had eased some of their traditional internal divisions. He is Joe Andrew, not Andrews.
Paul Pierce scored 31 points, and the Boston Celtics beat the Pacers, 101-86, Tuesday night in Indianapolis to remain unbeaten.

Richard Roberts, the embattled president of Oral Roberts University who is facing accusations he misspent university money to support a lavish lifestyle, has received a vote of no confidence by the tenured faculty.
The freshman guard Jonny Flynn hit a 3-pointer from the top of the key with 5.3 seconds left to break a 68-68 tie, and Syracuse defeated visiting Saint Joseph.
City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn announced a new case-tracking tool yesterday, similar to the city’s 311 system, to help manage and resolve constituent complaints.
The parents of a Long Island teenager involved in a hit-and-run crash that killed a freshman at the University of Connecticut were charged yesterday with helping him cover up the crime.
A lawyer for a Staten Island woman charged with importing meat without proper licenses and mislabeling a shipment argued yesterday that the charges impinge on her right to freedom of religion.
Prosecutors opened their murder case yesterday against two men accused of hiring assassins to kill an associate of the Genovese crime family in 1994.

The New York Civil Liberties Union yesterday filed suit to have the police make public a database of information that officers have recorded on more than 800,000 stops of civilians since the beginning of 2006.
The United States Supreme Court declined yesterday to review a lawsuit filed by a former poet laureate of New Jersey challenging the elimination of his post.
A Bronx man has been charged with murder and robbery in the holdup of a crowded Manhattan poker club, the police said yesterday.

Nike is recalling about 235,000 helmet chin straps after the company received 18 reports of the chin straps breaking, including some that resulted in concussions and facial lacerations, a government safety group announced. Nike has received two reports of concussions, two reports of facial lacerations requiring stitches, and a report of a broken nose. The chin straps, made in China, were sold at sporting-goods stores nationwide and on Nike’s Web site from April 2006 through October 2007.

Virginia Tech cornerback Victor Harris said yesterday that he believed shots fired into his apartment over the weekend were random. “I don’t have any enemies or nothing like that,” said Harris, a junior. “The shootings were very random, and the police are looking into it.” Three Tech students were in the off-campus apartment just before 4 a.m. Sunday when it was hit with at least two gunshots. The police said no one was injured. No one has been arrested.

The University of South Carolina announced it would not hold its traditional “Tigerburn” pep rally before its game with its archrival Clemson because of a beach fire in Ocean Isle Beach, N.C., that killed seven of the universities’ students last month. The rally, at which students burn a massive papier-mâché Clemson Tiger, has been a tradition at South Carolina for four decades.
Seattle will join Major League Soccer beginning in 2009. The yet-to-be named team will play at Qwest Field, home of the Seattle Seahawks. The expansion will make Seattle the league’s 15th club.

The Swiss yacht club that won the last two America’s Cup is asking an American rival to withdraw its lawsuit by Friday to ensure the 2009 competition will be raced on schedule. The Societe Nautique de Geneve, the home of the Cup champion Alinghi, is being sued by the United States syndicate BMW Oracle Racing’s Golden Gate Yacht Club because it says the Spanish boat Desafío Español — which helped establish the 33rd edition’s format — is an “invalid challenger.” If Golden Gate continues with its lawsuit in New York state and wins, it would be able to renegotiate the race format with Alinghi, probably pushing the event into 2010.

Chris Armas, the Chicago Fire captain, retired after a 12-year career in M.L.S., including the last 10 in Chicago. Armas, a 35-year-old midfielder, played in 264 regular-season games and had two goals in 66 appearances with the United States national team.

Texas Tech Coach Mike Leach was fined a record $10,000 by the Big 12 Conference yesterday for his criticism of game officials after last week’s 59-43 loss to No. 12 Texas. The fine doubled the previous high by the league. Leach and Texas Tech declined to comment.
Most trains in France stopped running as rail unions walked out in a strike that was expected to last until at least Friday.
Russia said it had formally ended its military presence in Georgia after more than two centuries.
Hamas security forces arrested supporters of the rival Fatah movement in the Gaza Strip, a day after a mass rally ended with six dead and more than a hundred wounded.
Khieu Samphan, the former Khmer Rouge head of state whose arrest by a genocide tribunal has been widely anticipated, suffered a stroke, his daughter and a neighbor said.
President Roh Moo-hyun called for a meeting of the leaders of the United States, China and the two Koreas to speed up North Korea’s denuclearization and reach a peace treaty on the Korean Peninsula.
Secretary General Ban Ki-moon has nominated the Belgian criminologist Serge Brammertz as chief prosecutor at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague.
Students, parents, teachers and law enforcement officers spent Tuesday trying to figure out what led to a near-riot at a high school in New Jersey and, more important, what it meant.
Jonathan Vilma, inside linebacker and defensive captain, finally spoke Tuesday about the mysterious knee injury that ended his season. But he did not tell much.

The Dow Jones industrials surged on sunnier forecasts from Wal-Mart and two major banks, but many analysts doubted the high spirits would last.
