Sydney Johnson understands he has to a lot more to do than win basketball games. He is in charge of bringing the mystique back to Princeton.
The Yankees’ latest offer to Mariano Rivera — three years for $45 million — would make him by far the highest-paid closer ever.
The N.H.L. fined the Rangers and the Maple Leafs as a result of an incident before their game Saturday night. Sean Avery was accused of making derogatory comments about Leafs forward Jason Blake.

Lululemon Athletica, the maker of popular yoga clothing, says one of its lines is made with seaweed. But some of the company’s claims about the fabric are now being called into question.
Rudolph W. Giuliani will begin advertising in New Hampshire with a commercial that presents him as the man who tamed New York.
The Mets have zeroed in on catcher Yorvit Torrealba, who played for the N.L. champion Colorado Rockies, and should offer him a multiyear deal worth perhaps as much as $5 million annually.
Death rates for 13 diseases that can be prevented by childhood vaccinations are at all-time lows in the United States, according to a study released Tuesday.
Lee C. Bollinger, the president of Columbia University, was confronted Tuesday by discontented professors who gathered more than 100 faculty signatures for a document criticizing his leadership.

Gov. Deval Patrick signed a bill establishing a 35-foot zone around abortion clinics that protesters cannot enter. Supporters of the law say it is meant to shield women entering the clinics from harassment and unwanted attention. Opponents say the law violates free speech. Previous state law, enacted in 2000, said protesters could not go within six feet of a person if they were within an 18-foot zone outside a clinic.

Sandra Day O’Connor’s husband has struck up a romance with a fellow Alzheimer’s patient since moving into an assisted-living center, and under the circumstances, she is just glad he is comfortable, said their son, Scott. Ms. O’Connor, the first woman to serve on the Supreme Court, cited her husband’s illness and her need to take care of him when she retired in 2005. Scott O’Connor told KPNX in Phoenix that the romance had changed the outlook of his father, John, about being in the center. “Mom was thrilled that Dad was relaxed and happy and comfortable living here and wasn’t complaining,” Scott O’Connor said.

A Mexican man who was trying to cross the border illegally died Sunday of burns suffered in last month’s Southern California wildfires, the authorities said. The man, Alejandro Martinez Flores, 20, is the 10th person killed by the wildfires. Seven other deaths involving evacuees have been indirectly linked to the blazes. Meanwhile, Los Angeles County prosecutors said they would not charge a 10-year-old boy who admitted to starting a fire last month that burned 38,000 acres and destroyed 21 houses. The boy accidentally ignited brush while playing with matches, they said.

The drug manufacturer Merck and academic researchers said they would “unblind” the study of an experimental AIDS vaccine that may have actually raised the risk of infection, telling thousands of people who volunteered whether they got the actual shot or a dummy injection. Two international trials of the vaccine were stopped in September after it became clear it did not work.

Cardinal Francis George of Chicago, left, a defender of Roman Catholic orthodoxy with extensive experience at the Vatican, was elected president of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops at the group’s fall meeting in Baltimore. He had served as vice president for the last three years, and the prelate holding that job is customarily elected to the top post. Cardinal George succeeds Bishop William Skylstad of Spokane, Wash. Meanwhile, Bishop Skylstad released a statement calling conditions in Iraq “unacceptable” and calling for a bipartisan, “responsible transition” out of the country.
The suspended Titans cornerback Pacman Jones is expected to accept a plea deal that will get him probation in return for his testimony about a triple shooting at a Las Vegas strip club.

Rupert Murdoch says he plans to abolish subscription fees at The Wall Street Journal’s Web site, according to news accounts from Australia.

This season, Brett Favre has set the N.F.L. career records for victories (topping John Elway’s 148 on Sept. 16) and touchdowns (topping Dan Marino’s 420 on Sept. 23), and is closing in on Marino’s mark for passing yards. All this has happened in a season in which the Packers (8-1) are looking like a playoff team for the first time since 2004.
Jurors heard opening arguments on Tuesday in the trial of a bird-watching enthusiast who fatally shot a cat that he said was stalking endangered shorebirds.
With one writers’ strike already under way, CBS will face the prospect of a second one when news writers, producers, editors and artists take a strike authorization vote on Wednesday and Friday.

European regulators refused Tuesday to approve Google’s $3.1 billion purchase of the Internet advertising company DoubleClick.  Instead they ordered a review of the deal.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 (AP) — The Countrywide Financial Corporation said Tuesday that the number of mortgages it originated fell by nearly half in October compared with the month a year ago, while the percentage of delinquent loans rose.

The families of two firefighters killed this summer fighting a blaze at the former Deutsche Bank building near ground zero have filed legal papers contending that “dangerous conditions” and a failure to inspect for them turned the site into “a veritable tinderbox.”.

A first edition of the Emily Brontë novel “Wuthering Heights,” published in 1847 under the pseudonym Ellis Bell because the author feared she faced prejudice as a female writer, sold at an auction in London yesterday for $236,000.

Since September, recipes from the archives of The New York Times have been available online at no charge. The editors of the Dining section have chosen some of the best Thanksgiving recipes and articles and brought them together on a single topic page. Some highlights include tips on the easiest ways to cook a turkey (don't bother rinsing or brining; or, cook only the breast) as well as links to dozens of recipes, including appetizers, vegetarian choices and side dishes that tweak tradition, like hashed brussels sprouts with lemon zest or wilted chard with pickled red onions. All of this, along with a slideshow of prepared dishes with their recipes, can be found at nytimes.com/thanksgiving.

LOVELAND--Genevra Kay, known as Kay to her family and friends, died of cancer 25 August in Seattle, Washington. She was 66. She is survived by her mother, Sydney Cook, her sister Dana Baker, her brother Kyle Rosene, and their children and grandchildren. She had an honorary brother and sister as well, Bruce and Carole Stock. She was preceded in death by her beloved partner of thirty-one years, Stelyani Sandris. Kay received her law degree with honors from the University of Texas and had a distinguished career in the law, spending the last thirteen years before her 2007 retirement at the Federal Judicial Center in Washington, D.C., where she was in charge of production of many highly admired educational programs for the federal courts and was noted for her graceful and forceful writing on legal topics. While at the National Center for State Courts in 1989-1992, she also co-authored a book, Managing Notorious Cases, a well-known handbook. In partnership with Ms. Sandris she produced two award-winning films: Farenthold, on the second campaign of Frances ''Sissy'' Farenthold for the governorship of Texas, 1977, and More Than The Music, 1984, about a concert by pianist Mona Golabeck at a California women's prison. She wrote a book, Stella's Story; Fight For Life Against A Malignant Brain Tumor, and edited her partner's memoirs Greek Soul, Memories Of A Detroit Childhood. Kay was deeply interested in political matters and worked in various capacities for state and federal politicians and for a number of legal causes and issues. Her wide-ranging interests in these and in women's issues led her to make many friends and colleagues in Washington and California. She was a role model and mentor for a number of young women, as an example of what one woman could make of her life. Her love of travel made her many friends internationally. Few of those who met her will ever forget her. A memorial service will be held for Kay at the Spiritual Center, American University, 17 November at 10:30am. A luncheon will follow. Anyone wishing to speak at the service or to attend the luncheon should contact Lisa Fuentes at LisaFuentes@gmail.com or by phone at 202-222-6387. In lieu of flowers, her friends ask that any contributions be made in her name to the Freedom From Hunger Foundation or the Astraea Foundation of New York. In addition, she asked that her friends remember her whenever they are dancing.

As cluttered as my gadget drawer may be, I could not resist a couple of items in a new line of utensils from Sur La Table called ''Things Cooks Love.'' Highest on the list is the granny turning fork, with its polished, elegant-feeling wooden handle. The three-prong fork, designed after one that was used in Civil War mess kits and made by a company that has been in business for 170 years, is 10 inches long, enough to reach into the roasting pan and move around the onions as they sizzle in the drippings, to turn the potatoes in their baking dish, to spear some soup ingredients out of the pot. It's narrow enough to extract pickles from a tall jar.

Stephon Marbury was not the Knicks' starting point guard Tuesday, and it was not clear when, or if, he would be again. That his future was even in question was a startling sign of how badly his once-promising career has eroded. Nearly four years ago, Isiah Thomas, the Knicks' president, acquired Marbury to reinvigorate the franchise. Now the coach, Thomas will no longer tie his fate to Marbury, which is why Marbury went missing Tuesday.

The musical was one of Stephen Sondheim's -- ''Passion'' -- and a scene in the script called for beef and gravy. But actors can't eat beef and gravy eight times a week. The stagehand thought it over. ''I ended up cutting up cantaloupe and covering it with balsamic vinegar to make it look like beef with gravy on it,'' said Tom, a veteran Broadway stagehand in the prop department. ''They kind of liked it, actually. I think it's an acquired taste.''

For four weeks, The New York Times editorial board, MSNBC and techPresident.com have been collaborating on a new kind of presidential campaign forum, in which citizens post video questions directed at the candidates and then vote for the questions they would most like to see answered. After the top 10 questions have been determined, candidates will be able to post their answers, on video, and the public will again be invited to vote, this time on whether the candidates really answered the questions.

With its white tiles, vintage detailing and tenement-green bagel case, Zucker's Bagels and Smoked Fish, which just opened in TriBeCa, has a properly dated look to suggest it has been around almost as long as such New York icons as Russ & Daughters (since 1914) and Barney Greengrass (since 1908). The architect, Glen Coben, has even hung a weathered carved sturgeon on the sign outside. The menu of smoked fish, salads and delicatessen meats sold here does not stray from the tried and true, and is much the same as at Murray's Bagels in Chelsea, which like Zucker's is owned by Matt Pomerantz. But here he offers smoked wild Pacific Coho salmon in addition to sockeye and king, and serves a few more egg dishes for brunch. There is a counter for a quick bite and several simple wood tables in the dining area.

T O the brave gladiators of the Mashed Potato Wrestling Federation, it does not matter whether the potatoes are peeled beforehand or if the cooking water is correctly salted. ''You just want to make sure you don't breathe it into your lungs,'' said Steve Barone, a video producer in Minneapolis and the reigning champion of the sport, which takes place in a pit of squishy mashed potatoes. ''That stuff is like concrete,'' said Mr. Barone, whose pit name is Steve-O Gratin.

Pumpkins used for jack-o'-lanterns are not the type best suited for pie; they are too watery and stringy. Many pie bakers, especially those who do not shop at farmer's markets, opt for the convenience of canned pumpkin. An alternative has just been introduced in a line of food products made by Heritage Family Specialty Foods, a Texas maker of private label foods. A hefty jar holds a rich, deep orange mixture of pumpkin, spices and sweeteners. The addition of three eggs and a cup of milk is all it takes to produce a pie filling that is mellow, fragrant and deliciously custardy, with an almost honey color. I was not too happy about the preservatives among the ingredients, which are at odds with the notions of heritage and home baking, but the result trumped this concern. The filling, called Classic Pumpkin Pie in a Jar, was made for Country Living Magazine, and is $12.99 from hfsfoods.com and macys.com.

It was a familiar exchange of pleasantries. Denise Owens would wheel her cart into the C-Town Supermarket across the street from her grim apartment complex on Gates Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant. Alan Dorsette, 15, a cashier at the store who lived down the hall from her, would ask, ''How's your son?'' Sometimes Ms. Owens would say ''He's O.K.'' More often, Alan said, it would be, ''He's crazy, he's not taking his medicine, he's sick.''

TREADWELL--Karen, of Westport, Connecticut, loving wife and best friend of Alan H. Eugley, beloved mother of Elizabeth, age 18 and Seth, age 11, died November 11, 2007 after four year battle with breast cancer. She was 48. Ms. Treadwell grew up in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and was a Westport resident for the past 13 years. She graduated from Colgate University in 1981 where she received a BA in History. While at Colgate she was a member of the University's first China Study Group as well as study groups in Geneva, Switzerland, London, England and Washington, DC. She continued as an avid traveler throughout her life and took great pleasure sharing those experiences with her husband Alan and son, Seth. Karen Treadwell enjoyed a fulfilling 21 year career with the Rockefeller Group in New York City where she most recently served as Vice President and Treasurer. In this position she was responsible for the Company's Treasury Department including all debt and investment activity. Ms. Treadwell also served as a member of the Rockefeller Group's Investment and Development Committees evaluating major new real estate projects. She was a member of the Executive Committee and past Chairman of the National Association of Corporate Treasurers. Ms. Treadwell was also a member of the board of directors of the Old Merchants House Museum in Greenwich Village, NY. In 2000, she was appointed to the Academy of Women Achievers of the YWCA of the City of New York. In addition to her husband and two children, survivors include her parents, Kenneth and Sally Treadwell of Pittsburgh, PA. Friends are invited to attend a Celebration of the Life of Karen Treadwell Monday, November 19 at 1:00pm at The Unitarian Church in Westport, 10 Lyons Plains Road, Westport, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Camp Horizons, PO Box 323, South Windham, CT 06266, or to The Merchant's House Museum, 24 East Fourth Street, New York, NY 10003.

New York City's new A-to-F report cards for public schools, unveiled last week, had many surprises. For example, the grades upended a common perception -- that high-performing schools have more students from wealthy families, while low-performing schools are packed with students who qualify for free lunch, a measure of poverty. The new grading system considers a high-performing school one that raises its students' achievement from one year to the next. And so schools got more credit for student progress, regardless of where they started. The result: Schools with high marks were not only in well-heeled areas, and F schools were everywhere.

AMERICA'S potato farmers spent decades narrowing their crop to a few breeds best suited to frozen French fries and dehydrated mashed potatoes. Now, even large-scale growers are expanding their horizons, following the lead of small farmers with paradigm-changing yellow potatoes like Yellow Finn, Bintje, Butterball, Gold Rush, Carola and Désirée. The rush for Yukon Golds, a cultivar bred in Canada and the first yellow potato to take hold in the United States, opened growers' eyes to the opportunities for branding. Green Giant has recently spent years developing the Klondike Rose, a yellow-fleshed, red-skinned potato.

An article on Nov. 4 about the state of the presidential campaign a year before the election misstated, in some editions, the surname of a former chairman of the Democratic National Committee who said the Democrats' desire to win had eased some of their traditional internal divisions. He is Joe Andrew, not Andrews.

Judith Regan, the former book publisher, says in a lawsuit filed yesterday protesting her dismissal by the News Corporation, the media conglomerate, that a senior executive there encouraged her to lie to federal investigators about her past affair with Bernard B. Kerik after he had been nominated to become homeland security secretary in late 2004. The lawsuit asserts that the News Corporation executive wanted to protect the presidential aspirations of Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Kerik's mentor, who had appointed him New York City police commissioner and had recommended him for the federal post.

The Abroad column in The Arts yesterday, about efforts to revive opera in Italy, misspelled the surname of an Italian actress who performed at Teatro Flaiano, where a streamlined version of ''Tosca'' is being presented in an effort to attract younger audiences. She was Anna Magnani, not Mignani.

An article in the Arts & Leisure section on Sunday about a dance performance set to Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring'' misidentified the program and misstated the name of the organization co-producing it this Saturday and Sunday. It is ''The Rite of Spring Project'' -- not ''The Stravinsky Project,'' the title of programs being performed in London and at Stanford University. The show in New York is being produced by Weill Music Institute, not the Weill Institute for Music. The article and a picture caption also misstated the given name of the choreographer working with public school students who are performing this weekend. He is Royston Maldoom, not Royce.

The Tyco duo, L. Dennis Kozlowski and Mark H. Swartz, lost their appeal today. Reading the appeals court decision makes it sound like the two men have little hope of overturning their convictions in further appeals.

Uniter or Divider | 10:10 p.m. Mrs. Clinton is asked if she is too polarizing to unite the country. She said she heard the same complaint when she ran for the Senate from New York but managed to get elected by reaching out to everyone. She talked about how she worked with Republican colleagues in the Senate and promised as president to "spend a lot of my time working not with just Republicans but people who aren't in public life."

LAS VEGAS - On a busy intersection with a view of this city's legendary downtown Strip, hundreds of supporters and staff members of the Democratic nominees filled the sidewalks at the site of tonight's debate, waving placards and chanting slogans at passing cars to crank up support for their candidates.
LOS ANGELES -- With all the hoopla the Los Angeles Auto Show has received during the past two years, due simply to a calendar adjustment, you'd think it was in its infancy.

This is a very good point from Dean Baker. We're told that we mustn't regulate subprime lending, despite the vast wave of foreclosures it has produced, because to do so would prevent minorities and other disadvantaged Americans from achieving the dream of homeownership. Yet homeownership is already back down to about what it was before the big wave of subprime lending began. All that the wonders of the financial market achieved, it seemed, was to give a lot of people a brief taste of homeownership, followed by a nasty foreclosure.

Clarification | 8:01 p.m. The vote was a straw poll of U.A.W. Region 4 local unions, which includes Illinois. While Mr. Edwards received more support from Iowa members and retirees, the strength of support from Illinois members pushed Mr. Obama over the edge. Technically, what happened today was not a formal endorsement, rather a recommendation to endorse, which Mr. Obama will likely receive before the Iowa caucusesDES MOINES - Senator Barack Obama collected an endorsement here today from the United Auto Workers, an organization of 30,000 members and retirees across Iowa.
Emerging markets are not known for their transparent business practices. How American and European investment banks navigate such risky waters is the topic of a recent story on The Deal.com.
Which is worse? A voter using the word "bitch" in referring to Hillary Clinton? Or John McCain's attempt to cash in on it?
With the Heisman campaign seemingly narrowing down to a two-horse race between Oregon's Dennis Dixon and Florida's Tim Tebow, the spin is on.
When Carl C. Icahn purchased 1-percent stakes in two well-established biotech companies, MedImmune and Biogen Idec, the moves drew little attention.
Yesterday, Newsweek hired Daily Kos founder Markos Moulitsas as a campaign contributor, and the reaction on the Web was nearly tepid.

Many interesting comments and questions but I can't resist getting back to the castration of Victoria Woodhull. During her action-packed career as a 19th-century reformer, free love advocate and presidential candidate, she ran into an extremely tough period involving indictments, bankruptcy and family disorder, and was taken to a doctor with symptoms of a nervous breakdown. He concluded that she suffered from a "female ailment" that could be cured by removal of her ovaries. That sort of thing happened quite a bit back then, but happily Victoria managed to recover with all her parts intact.
Melena Ryzik of The Times hobnobs at the intellectual center of the world, the 2007 National Book Awards.
UPDATE: Luciano Emilio, in his first M.L.S. season, was awarded the Most Valuable Player award.
In Oregon, scientists work to harness the waves as a new source of renewable energy.

The Mets are on the verge of signing Yorvit Torrealba, their top catching target, to a three-year contract, according to a team official who did not want his name used because he was not authorized to speak publicly about a deal that was not finalized.

Corporations outside the United States that use international accounting standards will no longer be required to adjust their financial statements to comply with American accounting rules, the Securities and Exchange Commission decided Thursday.
In a new 30-second spot to begin airing tomorrow in New Hampshire, Senator Barack Obama talks education and gets tough with parents.
Cravath, Swaine & Moore, the white-shoe law firm, named three partners from its associate ranks, effective Jan. 1.
At his Senate confirmation hearings, Attorney General Michael Mukasey repeatedly refused to answer some of the most important questions because he said he had not yet received top-secret briefings.

If nothing else, a new residential tower going up in Dallas is in esteemed architectural company. The Museum Tower, a 42-story condominium project, is part of the city's rapidly growing Arts District, which includes the work of four Pritzker Prize-winning architects: the Renzo Piano-designed Nasher Sculpture Center; the Meyerson Symphony Center designed by I.M. Pei, the Winspear Opera House planned by Sir Norman Foster and Rem Koolhaas' Wyly Theater.

Before he became chief executive of Ford, Alan Mulally thought the company made a big mistake by killing off one of its most recognizable model names, the Taurus. But did Ford make another mistake by resurrecting the Taurus name this spring and slapping it on a slow-selling full-size sedan?
It was a national news story recently when a University of Florida student was tasered by police at an appearance by John Kerry -- and uttered his now-famous phrase, "Don't tase me bro."

With its best ratings of the season, "Criminal Minds" lifted CBS into first place on Wednesday. The 9 p.m. crime show delivered 15.7 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, while eking out a victory as the night's top rated show among adults 18 to 49.
A. O. Scott reviews "Redacted," a film exploring the difficulty of cutting through the fog of war.
A. O. Scott reviews "Margot At The Wedding," starring Nicole Kidman and Jennifer Jason Leigh.
The CPI report today shows the overall cost of food is up 4.4 percent over the most recent 12 months.

What we know today is that Alex Rodriguez will soon return to the Yankees with a contract that will guarantee him upwards of $275 million. The new wrinkle is that Rodriguez could actually make at least $300 million if he sets the career home run record in pinstripes.

Off and on for more than a year, I've been in a running debate with Dave Roberts, an environmental blogger for Grist, over the shape of the climate problem and the prospects of various efforts to tackle it. We held an e-chat Wednesday night to fine tune where we differ and where we agree. (You can see Dave in this Outside Magazine story on Grist.) He's cross-posting this today as well.
The Washington Post reports today that Alberto Gonzales' supporters have set up a fund to pay his legal expenses.
I'm planning a trip to Buenos Aires in December and wondered if you could recommend some great restaurants.

In winning Dow Jones, Rupert Murdoch has taken over the paper he has long dreamed of owning, The Wall Street Journal. But the mogul dropped word earlier this week that he had considered bidding for another storied newspaper: DealBook's parent, The New York Times.

LOS ANGELES -- Not everything on display at the Los Angeles Auto Show is right off the assembly line. The main purpose here, of course, is to showcase new (or newish) models, and the manufacturers trumpet each feature and shade of paint as if they'd developed a rounder version of the wheel. But the shows also offer enthusiasts and car buffs the chance to get close to a few pieces of classic rolling sculpture.
Toyota is reaching out to a market you might have thought was already well-served: buyers interested in full-size S.U.V.’s that use only gasoline and have seating for up to eight.

LOS ANGELES -- Why are there only 14 world premieres at the 2007 L.A. Auto Show? Has the show lost the momentum it seemed to have gained last year by moving its date from early January to late November? The 2006 Los Angeles show boasted 21 new world debuts.

Elizabeth Barrett Browning's "Sonnets from the Portuguese" gets its title, of course, from the fact that Robert Browning's pet name for her was Portuguese, and because they wanted to disguise these intimate poems as translations.
Harry Shearer wears many hats, among them comedic writer, voice actor for "The Simpsons," radio host, and Huffington Post blogger.
In today's New York Times, Bill Carter explains why some struggling television shows are getting a second chance at life because of the writers' strike.
Students from Harvard's Institute of Politics attended a Hillary Rodham Clinton event in New Hampshire.

The keepers of bioethics are even more alarmed than usual now that scientists have reported cloning a monkey embryo and extracting stem cells. In her article about the monkey research, my colleague Gina Kolata quotes the reaction of the Rev. Tadeusz Pacholczyk, director of education at the National Catholic Bioethics Center:

"There's nothing more humiliating in sports than a doomed college football coach playing out the string. It's like watching someone poke a wounded animal on its last breath," Bryan Curtis writes in this week's PLAY newsletter. "This year's walking dead include Nebraska's Bill Callahan, Texas A&M's Dennis Franchione, and possibly even Tennessee's Phillip Fulmer, who won the national championship in 1998 but hasn't done much since. While a coach's final days have never been a happy affair (ask every Notre Dame coach since Lou Holtz), the Internet has made them even more torturous."

Last week Don Shula, the legendary coach whose 1972 Miami Dolphins were the last team to finish a season undefeated, suggested that if the New England Patriots finish the season unbeaten, the feat would be tainted because the team videotaped the signals of an opposing team. Do you agree with the Hall of Fame coach?

The International Atomic Energy Agency, the United Nations agency responsible for monitoring nuclear activities around the world, is just out with a new report on Iran, focusing on whether the country is living up to its agreements and complying with Security Council resolutions.

It has been more than a year since Amaranth Advisors went down in a blaze of losses, marking one of the largest hedge-fund failures in history. While the cause of its death is generally seen as Amaranth's ill-fated energy trades, Amaranth is proposing a controversial new theory. The defunct fund, which once oversaw more than $9 billion, argues that improper meddling by J.P. Morgan Chase was the real reason that it didn't pull through the crisis.

Stephon Marbury sparked what seemed like a major Knicks crisis on Tuesday, when he deserted his team during a West coast swing. On Wednesday, he boarded a cross-country flight back, playing in the team's fourth straight loss, this time to the Los Angeles Clippers.

UPDATE & APOLOGY 11/16: I erred in describing EA folks as the designers of SimCity Societies. It's the crew at Tilted Mill Entertainment, outside Boston. The lead designer and company president, Chris Beatrice, helped clarify this for me (I admit freely that my sons are the gaming experts in my house, not me), and pointed out the importance of distinguishing between the creators of a game and the company that publishes it (which is Electronic Arts).
Sure, it's easy to laugh at another great addition to the Oddly Enough archive at Reuters: Sect holes up in cave to await end of world.

LOS ANGELES -- At the 2007 Los Angeles Auto Show, fuel-cell vehicles made quite a showing. Oh, we're still on that technology? True, it's not as trendy or accessible to the general consumer as hybrid, diesel, or even flex-fuel. But it is by no means a has-been -- or even an also-ran. For example, Honda has been serious about hydrogen fuel cells since the first-generation FCX in 2002, fine-tuning the technology with a sleeker model in 2005, and pushing the envelope even further with the new FCX Clarity.

This Thursday the crazy CSTV.com duo of Matt Meyers and Mike Ogle have plenty of new adventures to share. If you're a Giants fan, you'll be especially interested. That's because they caught up with Ron Dayne and Tyrone Wheatley, both great college running backs and former Giants. They also checked in with the linebacking corp at Grand Valley State and learned what it's like to have a cool drink of Barry Alvarez. Gas up the tanks. It's time to hit the road.
John Thain isn't just moving to a new company. He's moving to a whole new pay scale.
Denis Johnson, reporting a story in Iraq, wasn't available last night to pick up his National Book Award for "Tree of Smoke."
Walter Cronkite, the former anchor of the "CBS Evening News," will contribute weekly editorials to the start-up channel Retirement Living TV.
LOS ANGELES -- If the Los Angeles Auto Show were a race among auto executives to deliver the pithiest phrase for journalists' consumption, it would be on.
Tonight, after the Democratic presidential hopefuls leave the stage at their debate in Las Vegas, they have another destination on their evening itinerary: Paris.

We're starting a new feature today, called the Open Caucus -- a roundtable of people from different parts of the country who will join us now and then in online conversations about the 2008 presidential campaign, the candidates and the issues.

The folks at the Government Accountability Office may be better known for their regular updates on progress in Iraq and other hardcore analysis, but they apparently go undercover as well. Over the past year, investigators have been testing airport security checkpoints for vulnerabilities, and have found some disturbing ones.

If you ever get the chance to have a meal with the Penn State offensive line, make sure to count your fingers when you're done. According to Jeff McLane of the Philadelphia Inquirer, the linemen throw down food as if they were Kobayashi in Coney Island. Teammates estimate that tackle Dennis Landolt eats 7 to 10 peanut butter and jelly sandwiches a night. No word on whether he cuts the crusts off or not.

Galleon Group, a $7 billion hedge fund known for its technology investments, is making a big bet on A.M.D.. Citing an unnamed trader involved in the trade, The New York Post said the fund has purchased "several million shares" of the chipmaker, which is struggling to keep pace with larger rival Intel.
"Why don't we have a stronger Democratic female candidate?" asks 90's feminist bête noire Camille Paglia in Salon.
More submissions from readers to tide us over during the TV writers' strike (send yours via the comment link below):
Following is a transcript of the Democratic Presidential debate in Las Vegas, as provided by the Federal News Service.

Iberia Lineas Aereas de Espana, Spain's largest airline, received a takeover approach valued at as much as 3.7 billion euros ($5.4 billion) from a group of investors including Spanish billionaire Alicia Koplowitz.

Ralcorp said on Thursday that it would acquire Kraft Foods' Post cereals business in a deal valued at about $1.65 billion. Including about $950 million in debt, the deal is worth $2.6 billion, said Ralcorp, a maker of private-label and frozen bakery foods.

3M said Thursday that it will acquire Aearo Technologies, a maker of personal protection like hearing and eye protectors, from British buyout firm Permira for $1.2 billion in cash. The deal will be financed by a combination of cash on hand and debt.

Las Vegas, that city of dreams and heartbreak, takes center stage tonight as it hosts the Democratic presidential candidates at a debate on the University of Nevada-Las Vegas campus. Hillary Rodham Clinton may be seeking redemption after poor reviews of her performance at the last debate, and her top rivals John Edwards and Barack Obama likely will continue to direct their most pointed attacks toward her.

John A. Thain won plaudits as Wall Street's Mr. Fix-It by revitalizing the embattled New York Stock Exchange. Now, he faces what could be a more formidable challenge: turning around Merrill Lynch, the once-proud Wall Street firm battered by losses from the mortgage debacle.

RWE, Germany's second-largest power company, on Wednesday postponed the initial public offering of its American Water business due to market turmoil in the United States, forcing it to abandon plans for a share buyback and significant increase in its dividend.
Fatdoor, a social network for neighbors, on Wednesday said it picked up $5.5 million in a first round of funding and former Yahoo veteran Jennifer Dulski as its chief executive.

Long-simmering talk of an inevitable round of airline industry mergers heated up again Wednesday. But by the end of the day, after a spike in their share prices, the central players in any merger talks, dismissed the rumors as just that.

Much of the attention surrounding reports that John A. Thain is poised to take the top job at Merrill Lynch has been lavished on the head of NYSE Euronext and the challenges he faces as the investment's bank's new chief.

Last week, the smart money seemed to be on Laurence D. Fink as the next chief of Merrill Lynch. The founder and chief executive of BlackRock, the large investment firm partly owned by Merrill, was being widely touted as the front-runner for the position left by E. Stanley O'Neal, who resigned in the wake of a multibillion write-down at the investment bank.

If you want to fill a huge auditorium, set up a panel with the words "changing landscape" and the name of an industry or profession, then spread the word to members of the industry, who pride themselves on keeping up with trends.
Hewlett-Packard agreed to buy EYP Mission Critical Facilities, a data center engineering firm, for an undisclosed sum in a deal that will provide an exit for TA Associates.
A few months ago, the comedian Harry Shearer dug up an old Dan Rather video to poke fun at the CBS anchorman's vanity ...
TPG Capital, the private equity firm formerly known as Texas Pacific Group, is one of the likely bidders for a stake in Japan Airlines's $900 million credit card unit, according to Reuters.
Oracle Chief Executive Larry Ellison seems to be enjoying the catbird seat.

As DealBook noted Wednesday, it seems that no echelon of the financial world remains untouched by the long arm of Goldman Sachs. As former Goldman Sachs alumnus John A. Thain, for example, prepares to take the reins of Merrill Lynch, he is only the latest example of a tradition borne out across Wall Street, in Washington and around the world.

Carlsberg and Heineken raised their bid for Scottish & Newcastle to 7.3 billion pounds ($14.9 billion), aiming to force talks with management after Britain's largest brewer rejected their first approach.

Healthcare specialist Skyline Ventures raised $350 million in its fifth investment vehicle, bulking up from a $200 million fund closed in July 2005 to allow the firm to make bigger commitments to portfolio companies.
Barack Obama announced several new technology policy initiatives Wednesday during a visit to Silicon Valley, including a proposal for a "chief technology officer."
United Rentals, the rental equipment company, said Wednesday that Cerberus Capital Management had backed out of its planned $4 billion purchase of the company.

Walter Butler, head of French buyout shop Butler Capital Partners, said Wednesday that he is negotiating to buy roughly a 75 percent stake in retailer Virgin France Group from defense and media conglomerate Lagardère.

Morgan Stanley will become an equity investor in hedge fund firm Traxis Partners, which was founded by a team of its own bankers. Morgan Stanley will have a less than 20 percent stake in the $1.5 billion global macro fund firm, according to HedgeFund.Net.

Biogen Idec, the biotechnology company that is reportedly attempting to sell itself to a major pharmaceuticals company before the end of the year, may be having trouble finding a buyer. Biogen Idec shares have fallen sharply over the last month on concern the Cambridge company won't fetch much of a premium - if it sells at all.

Barclays, Britain's third-biggest bank, said its investment bank unit made a 1.3 billion pound ($2.7 billion) write-down due to its exposure to credit market problems in the four months to the end of October.
McCormick agreed Wednesday to buy the Lawry's business from Unilever Group for $605 million in cash, adding wet marinades to its selection of dry spices.

Shares of the $30 billion hedge fund Och-Ziff Capital Management Group fell 4.2 percent Wednesday during its first day as a public company. Och-Ziff, which raised $1.15 billion with its initial public offering of stock late on Tuesday, ended the day down $1.35 a share, closing at $30.65.

Warren E. Buffett urged Congress Wednesday to maintain the estate tax, saying that plans to repeal the tax would benefit a handful of the richest American families and widen income disparity in the United States.
American International Group, the giant insurance company, said Wednesday that it had approved the repurchase of an additional $8 billion in stock.

For the new chairman of Lazard's global energy practice, Bruce Bilger, the energy industry remains far removed from the slowdown that has gripped deal activity since mid-summer. Indeed, he told DealBook this week that he expects mergers and acquisitions to remain strong across all sectors.
Question: Is it fake or is it Craigslist?

“Quarterlife” unfolds in eight-minute episodes that go up on Myspacetv.com every Sunday and Thursday night. Central to the mood of the series is the notion that the emergence of new media has made it harder to be young than it once was.

So the Dolphins (0-9) finally gave up on Cleo Lemon and replaced him with the rookie John Beck. Hallelujah! says the Miami Herald's Greg Cote. But are you really surprised? Lemon started five games for the Dolphins in the past two seasons and lost them all. He had more touchdowns rushing (four) than passing (three) this season, and the longest completion of his career went for 38 yards. In a city where many still worship Dan Marino, that won't do.
No fuel cell, no lithium-ion cells, no tree-hugging -- just an all-out sports car from Hyundai.

Audi says it’s introducing a new vehicle segment with the Cross Cabriolet quattro. Could that happen? In a word, No.

This marks the third up! design study that Volkswagen has introduced this year as part of its New Small Family, priming the bite-size theme for public consumption.

The rookie Devin Setoguchi and Patrick Marleau connected in the shootout after scoring regulation goals, and the San Jose Sharks beat host Dallas, 4-3, in the Stars’ first game since a major front office shake-up.Tom Hicks, the Stars’ owner, made several management changes Tuesday and yesterday, hoping to jump-start his struggling team. Dallas rallied from a two-goal third-period deficit to send the game into overtime before losing its fourth in a row at home.Hicks fired General Manager Doug Armstrong on Tuesday, replacing him with the former star Brett Hull and the assistant general manager Les Jackson as co-interim general managers. Hicks moved Jim Lites, the team president, into a full-time role in his sports marketing firm yesterday, giving the team president’s job to Jeff Cogen, who had filled the same position for Hicks’s baseball franchise, the Texas Rangers.
The Performa 07 festival took a break from live programming this week, presenting two evenings of early-postmodern dance recordings at Anthology Film Archives.
A federal appeals court today said that new fuel-economy standards for light trucks, including S.U.V.’s, didn’t thoroughly assess environmental impact.
Barry Bonds was indicted today on four counts of perjury in connection with his testimony about his use of performance-enhancing drugs, his lawyer said.
The ruling was the fifth time in two months that the nation’s highest court has issued or upheld a stay of execution.
Hundreds of thousands of passengers were stranded, in what has become the largest work stoppage in the history of the German state railway system.
The toll and fare increases will be used to help finance bonds for the construction of a second passenger rail tunnel under the Hudson River to Pennsylvania Station.
Researchers using robotic roaches were able to convince real cockroaches to do things that their instincts told them were not the best idea.
The S.E.C. decided that companies outside the United States will no longer need to adjust their financial statements to comply with U.S. accounting rules.
Airlines will make fuller use of military airspace during Thanksgiving under a plan  announced today by President Bush.
After a  damaging child-labor scandal in India, Gap announced measures aimed at eradicating the exploitation of children in the manufacture of its goods.
David Pogue posted to his blog the latest collection of answers to Pogue’s Imponderables, and threw out a few more tech mysteries for readers to consider.
Researchers report today that the dinosaur, named Nigersaurus taqueti, probably lived on ferns, horsetails and other ground vegetation.
The automaker said it would offer more buyouts to unionized workers and that it had canceled plans to build a low-cost assembly plant in North America.
French labor unions met today on whether to prolong a transport strike that crippled services for a second day.
A plan by the Lose Angeles Police Department to map out Muslim communities, a proposal that civil rights groups sharply criticized as racial and religious profiling, has been shelved.

Former United States Representative John E. Sweeney pleaded guilty last night to a charge of driving while intoxicated related to a weekend traffic stop on the Northway in Saratoga County. Mr. Sweeney, speaking to reporters outside Clifton Park Town Court after entering his plea, offered several apologies: “One, to the court for burdening it with this matter; two, to the general public for creating a rift that I should not have created; and finally, and maybe just as important, to my family for the pain I’ve caused them through this.” Mr. Sweeney, 52, was pulled over by a state trooper at 1:20 a.m. on Sunday. The State Police said he registered a 0.18 percent blood alcohol level. In New York the legal blood-alcohol limit is .08 percent. Mr. Sweeney’s license was suspended for six months. In addition, he was fined $1,000 and was ordered to attend a meeting of a victim’s impact panel and classes for those convicted of D.W.I.

A three-pound rock smashed through the windshield of a moving automobile here yesterday morning and killed an elderly passenger, the police said. the Old Brookville Police and Nassau County Police began an investigation. The driver, Marie Waters of Bayville, was traveling north on Route 107, through wooded areas near Glen Head and Chicken Valley Roads, when the rock struck the car about 10:15 a.m., the police said. The rock crashed through the windshield and struck Ms. Waters’s mother, Ria Oill, 75, also of Bayville. She was taken to North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, where she was pronounced dead.
Government investigators learned on the Internet how to make an improvised incendiary device and bought the parts for less than $150 at local stores.

Vincent Lecavalier had three goals and two assists to set a team record with his sixth consecutive multipoint game, leading the Tampa Bay Lightning to a 6-1 victory at home over the Carolina Hurricanes.
Wayne Ellington scored 20 points and made key plays late to help No. 1 North Carolina avoid a major upset and beat Davidson, 72-68, Wednesday night in Charlotte, N.C.
Playing six freshmen, the Red Storm struggled for most of the night before edging St. Francis of Brooklyn, 72-64, in its season opener at Carnesecca Arena.

An article in Business Day on Nov. 6 about the comparison of electricity prices between states where they are set by the market and states where they are set by regulators misstated a measure of electricity for nuclear power plants, which in unregulated states have at times charged for power they had offered to give away during low-demand hours. The price is per megawatt-hour, not kilowatt-hour.

An article in Business Day yesterday about a plan in Europe to impose quotas on the emission of carbon dioxide by airlines misstated at one point the entity that gave the plan preliminary approval. It was the European Parliament, not the European Union.

An article on Saturday about the results of recent DNA testing on the remains of the Notre Dame football legend George Gipp, which showed he did not father a child with an 18-year-old high school student in 1920, contained several incorrect references.

An article in The Arts on Oct. 31 about a new work by the choreographer John Jasperse, “Misuse liable to prosecution,” misstated the daily cost of the war in Iraq, using a figure given by Mr. Jasperse when he recites a list of numbers in the work. It is about $330 million, according to an estimate by the Congressional Research Service, not $720 million. (That figure is an estimate by the American Friends Service Committee, and includes long-term health care for veterans and debt interest, among other factors.).

An article in Business Day on Nov. 6 about the comparison of electricity prices between states where they are set by the market and states where they are set by regulators misstated a measure of electricity for nuclear power plants, which in unregulated states have at times charged for power they had offered to give away during low-demand hours. The price is per megawatt-hour, not kilowatt-hour.

Because of an editing error, the About New York column on Saturday, about Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner, referred incorrectly in some editions to the judge who presided over Mr. Kerik’s arraignment on federal tax fraud charges in Federal District Court in White Plains. It was Magistrate Judge George A. Yanthis — not Judge Stephen C. Robinson, the trial judge assigned to the case.

A front-page article on Saturday about President Bush’s meetings with families who have lost relatives in the war in Iraq referred incorrectly to a meeting between Cindy Sheehan, an opponent of the war, and the president. The meeting took place in 2004, not 2005, and Ms. Sheehan complained later — not immediately after the meeting — that President Bush had been dismissive of her.
By the third period, the pockets of empty seats at the Devils’ new Prudential Center had swelled to gaping voids as the Rangers kept the Devils from feeling at home in their still-new building.
Efforts to reunite the Roman Catholic and Orthodox churches took a cautious step forward as a joint commission agreed that the pope has primacy over bishops of both churches.
The health minister apologized for a surgical mix-up that resulted in a knee patient’s undergoing a complex brain operation. The brain patient had knee surgery.
The group is accused of firing mortars and machine guns without “any simultaneous, direct threat,” a military prosecutor said.
A powerful magnitude 7.7 earthquake struck in the copper-producing north, killing at least two people, and injuring more than 100.
A bomb went off in the capital, Dushanbe, outside the presidential palace and a conference hall where Prime Minister Oqil Oqilov was due to speak.
The World Health Organization said that 329 human cases of Rift Valley fever, including 96 deaths, had been reported in Sudan.
A 26-ounce white truffle from Italy’s Piedmont region was sold at a charity auction over the weekend to three Hong Kong property developers for a record $208,000.

The producer of some early-season tournaments announced it would start a 16-team postseason event that will augment the N.C.A.A. and the National Invitation tournaments. The College Basketball Invitational will be staged in March by The Gazelle Group, based in Princeton, N.J. The organization runs the 2K Sports College Hoop Classic and the O’Reilly Auto Parts CBE Classic. The new event intends to compete with the N.I.T. for teams that do not make the N.C.A.A.’s field of 65.

A local investor group trying to buy the Nashville Predators canceled a news conference after city officials denied they had reached an agreement on changes to the team’s arena lease. Earlier in the day, the group said it was set to make an announcement after weeks of negotiations with city officials about changes the potential buyers said were necessary to complete the $193 million deal and keep the team in Nashville.

Rick Nash, Sergei Fedorov and Jason Chimera each had a goal and an assist, and the host Columbus Blue Jackets beat the Chicago Blackhawks, 4-2, to snap a four-game skid. Dan Fritsche also scored for Columbus.

The former major league pitcher Rick Rhoden had a hole-in-one yesterday to take a two-stroke lead after the second round of the Champions Tour’s national qualifying tournament. Rhoden, the winner of 50 celebrity golf titles, aced the 186-yard 17th hole with a five-iron and finished with a two-under-par 70 for a six-under 138 total at TPC Eagle Trace in Coral Springs, Fla. It was his ninth career hole-in-one and fourth in competition. He also made one at the 2006 United States Senior Open.

Rutgers Coach C. Vivian Stringer has landed one of the nation’s best-regarded recruiting classes. The sixth-ranked Scarlet Knights announced they have received five letters of intent from players for the 2008-9 season. The list was led by forward April Sykes of Crawford, Miss. Also committing to Rutgers were guard-forward Jasmine Dixon of Long Beach, Calif.; forward Chelsey Lee of Miami; forward Brooklyn Pope of Fort Worth; and guard Nikki Speed of Pasadena, Calif.

The New England Revolution is offering fans free round-trip bus rides to Washington for the M.L.S. Cup between the Revolution and the Houston Dynamo. The buses will leave from Gillette Stadium on Saturday morning. The M.L.S. Cup is Sunday afternoon at R.F.K. Stadium.

Patrick Valenzuela is set to ride again in Southern California for the first time in nearly a year Saturday at Hollywood Park. Valenzuela, 45, has not ridden in Southern California since Nov. 26, 2006, when he broke his ribs after being kicked by his mount at Hollywood Park. He had knee surgery and received clearance from his doctor last month to resume riding.
Students who faced possible expulsion for participating in an antiwar protest at their suburban Chicago high school will be allowed to return to class.
Canada’s attorney general has ended the prosecution of an American refugee aid worker, Janet Hinshaw-Thomas, who had been accused of immigrant trafficking.
Adam Habib, a South African Muslim academic, has been told by the State Department that he was barred from entering the United States because of engaging in terrorist activities.
Congress passed and sent to President Bush a five-year Head Start bill that opens up the preschool program to more children.
O. J. Simpson and two other men were ordered to stand trial on a dozen charges, including armed robbery and kidnapping, related to a confrontation in a Las Vegas hotel room in September.
President Hugo Chávez warned Spain on Wednesday that he would review diplomatic and business ties with it, escalating a dispute that erupted when Spain’s king told Mr. Chávez in public to “shut up.”
Amaranth has sued JPMorgan Chase for at least $1 billion, accusing the bank of fraudulently taking advantage of the firm during its crisis in September 2006.

Boston routed the visiting Nets, 91-69, Wednesday night, turning up the defense and the tempo while Kevin Garnett was on the bench with three fouls.

A soldier who left his post at Fort Drum in Watertown, N.Y., without leave more than a year ago to seek treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder was arrested yesterday at a cafe eight miles from the base as he was preparing to surrender, his lawyer said.

A former curator at the Historical Society of Rockland County who stole an antique atlas worth $65,000 was sentenced last week to five years’ probation and 24 weekends of community service. The curator, Rebecca Streeter-Chen, 50, of Highland Park, N.J., pleaded guilty to grand larceny in Rockland County Court in August after being caught trying to sell the 1823 New American Atlas.

A personal assistant accused of killing her boss, Linda S. Stein, a prominent real estate agent who once managed the punk rock group the Ramones, was indicted yesterday on murder charges. Prosecutors said the assistant, Natavia S. Lowery, 26, of Brooklyn, was scheduled for arraignment on Nov. 27. The police have charged that Ms. Lowery beat Ms. Stein to death with a piece of exercise equipment on Oct. 30, and afterward told the police that her boss had mistreated her. She is being held without bail. As Ms. Lowery was led from State Supreme Court yesterday, relatives and supporters rose and shouted encouragement.

A justice in State Supreme Court rescheduled the trial of the three detectives charged in the shooting of Sean Bell from Jan. 7 to Feb. 4 yesterday after lawyers for the detectives requested an extra month to prepare for the case, said Michael J. Palladino, president of the Detectives’ Endowment Association. The rescheduling came during a brief hearing yesterday that the detectives, Michael Oliver, Gescard F. Isnora and Marc Cooper, watched in silence. Mr. Bell, 23, died in a volley of 50 gunshots from the police as he and two friends were leaving his bachelor party in Jamaica on Nov. 25, 2006, unaware that they were being followed by Detective Isnora, who was under cover. He has said he believed that the men were armed; no gun was found. Detectives Oliver and Isnora face manslaughter charges, while Detective Cooper faces two misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment.

A dispute between Martha Stewart and some of her neighbors here over her bid to trademark the hamlet’s name has been resolved with a compromise. Ms. Stewart’s company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, has agreed to seek a Katonah trademark only for furniture, mirrors, pillows and chair cushions. Opponents of the trademark have agreed not to challenge that application. Yesterday, in a joint statement with the Katonah Village Improvement Society and two local stores, Ms. Stewart’s company agreed to drop trademark applications for products “such as hardware, paint, lighting and home textiles.”.

Workers called for a boycott of Ollie’s Noodle Shop restaurants yesterday, claiming that the president of the popular restaurant chain was leading a retaliation and blacklisting effort against restaurant workers who are trying to organize. The workers claimed that the president of Ollie’s, Tsu Yue Wang, had threatened employees, telling them they would not be able to find work. “The old boss would call the new boss and say, ‘These guys are causing problems,’ ” said Jerry Weng, 28, an immigrant who said he had worked for wages as low as $2 an hour at an Ollie’s. In May, the chain closed its West 44th Street location, where a number of the main organizers of a labor lawsuit had worked. Mr. Wang’s lawyer, Richard Ian Greenberg, did not respond to calls yesterday.
A homeowner in Marietta, Ga., used 14,700 gallons a day in September on landscaping and his pool, prompting an outcry from other homeowners trying to conserve water.

A masked man who claimed that he was armed and had planted four bombs in a casino held police officers at bay from a shuttle bus for nearly six hours, demanding $3 million, before surrendering early yesterday, the state police said. The man, David B. Kilkeary, 37, of Crofton, Md., served more than three years in prison for twice robbing a bank in Maryland, legal records show. During the standoff, Mr. Kilkeary blamed the Showboat Casino-Hotel for the suicide of his brother, who he said was a former employee, a law enforcement official said. But a spokeswoman for the Showboat’s parent company said a search of personnel records turned up no one with the bother’s name. No gun was found, said Capt. Al Della Fave of the state police. The F.B.I. charged Mr. Kilkeary with threatening to kill people and damage property, and with obstructing interstate commerce by extortion. Compiled by John Sullivan.

More than a decade after the skeletal remains of a 4-year-old girl were found in a wooded area of Long Island, a jury in Suffolk County Court yesterday convicted the girl’s mother of murder. The mother, Khairual Abdul, 43, was found guilty after a six-week trial. Her estranged husband, Parmjit Singh, 48, has also been charged in the death of the child, Jennifer Shafiq, and will be tried later, said a spokesman for District Attorney Thomas J. Spota. Each spouse has blamed the other for Jennifer’s death. The couple, then living in Queens, beat her to death in 1990, the authorities say, and buried her in a shallow grave in Manorville, in Suffolk County. Her remains were found in 1996. The parents were arrested in 2006 after Mr. Singh, arrested on a domestic violence charge, implicated Ms. Abdul in the girl’s death, the authorities said. Compiled by John Sullivan.
Dallas is a victory from the best start in franchise history, and has a two-game lead over the Giants in the National Football Conference East.

The shares of the hedge fund Och-Ziff Capital Management Group fell 4.2 percent during its first day as a public company.

GINDI--Isaac M. The entire Magen David Yeshivah family is deeply saddened by the loss of one of our highly respected founders and past President Isaac M. Gindi. He was a cherished friend who will be remembered for his leadership, perseverance and tireless efforts on behalf of Magen David Yeshivah. Our heartfelt condolences to his children Joyce and Joe, Morris and Jill, Eddy and Viviane, his grandchildren and the entire family. We all grieve with you. Eddie J. Esses , President

FRANKLIN--Harriet Quaker, on November 13, 2007. Beloved wife of Harry. Mother of Robert Quaker and Jan Halsbond. Stepmother of Susan Alexander of Naples, FL, and Michael Franklin of Pittsfield, MA. Grandmother of David and Amber Quaker and Emily and Douglas Halsbond. Services Friday November 16, 12:30pm at ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial'', 76th Road and Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY.

BING--John W., 88, born in Hamburg, Germany, died November 11, 2007, after a long battle with cancer. After immigrating to New York from Nazi Germany, he served in the US Army, European theater during World War II. Partner of the re-insurance brokerage firm Bleichroeder, Bing & Co., Inc., he continued to work for more than 20 years for each acquisition. He recently retired after a 70 year career. In addition to his work, he enjoyed photography and won several amateur competitions. He was known for his annual photographic holiday card. He is survived by his son Andrew Bing of Seattle, WA, his son George Bing and wife Karen of Tolland, CT, and his daughter Monica (Bing) Luke and partner David Jacobs of Bedford, MA; as well as grandchildren, MaryBeth (Bing) and Jason Lipman, Lisa (Bing) and John Sizer, Kristen (Bing) and Roger Clarke, Jessica Bing, Neil Luke and Lisa Luke and great-grandchildren, Ben and Emma Lipman, Grace and Johnny Sizer. A memorial service will be held December 9, 2007, 2pm, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St, New York. Donations to Storm King Art Center, Mountainville , NY (www.stormking.org)

A headline in some editions yesterday with a sports article about National Hockey League fines against the Rangers, the Maple Leafs and two players misstated the reason one player, Sean Avery of the Rangers, was fined. It was for his role in a pregame altercation less than a week after being involved in another pregame incident; he was not fined for derogatory comments he was accused of making about another player.

TREADWELL--Karen A. The Board of Directors, staff, and volunteers of the Merchant's House Museum are profoundly saddened by the untimely loss of our beloved Board member, Karen Treadwell. For the past 17 years, Karen worked creatively and tirelessly to help strengthen and preserve the Merchant's House. She will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Karen's husband, Alan Eugley, her children, Elizabeth and Seth, and her parents, Kenneth and Sally Treadwell. Margaret Halsey Gardiner, Executive Director Nicholas B. A. Nicholson, Chair Deborah Spaeder McWilliams, Vice Chair Merchant's House Museum 29 East 4th St, NY, NY 10003

RUSSELL--Alicia Zintl, 61, of the Watch Hill section of Westerly, RI, died Monday at the University of Massachusetts Memorial Medical Center after she and her daughter were struck by a car while crossing a street Sunday night in Putnam, CT. Her daughter, Amanda Fortune Russell, a student at the Hyde School in Woodstock, CT, was treated at Day Kimball Hospital in Putnam and released. Mrs. Russell was the wife of Edwin Larson Russell, chief executive officer of Horizon Investments, which is based in Westerly. A native of Philadelphia, she was one of five children born to Robert Trainor Zintl and Rosemary Zintl McCune. Upon receiving a bachelor of arts degree in history in 1967 from Newton College of the Sacred Heart in Chestnut Hill, MA, Mrs. Russell worked as a research assistant to Oscar Handlin, the Pulitzer Prizewinning historian and Carl M. Loeb University Professor, Emeritus, Harvard University. She and Mr. Russell married in 1972 and they lived in Manhattan where she worked in the textile fibers division of DuPont. She and her family also lived in Chicago; Brussels, Belgium; Essex, CT; Rumson, NJ; and Duluth, MN, before settling in Westerly. Mrs. Russell made many friends and contributions to the communities where she and her family resided. In Westerly, RI, she worked as an elementary reading specialist and English as a Second Language instructor. She was also a literacy volunteer, a member of the board of trustees for the Westerly Public Library and a volunteer at the Hyde School. Her many joys included painting, gardening, yoga and the company of family and friends -also, of her beloved dog, Schatzie. In addition to her husband and daughter, Mrs. Russell is survived by a son, Robert Larson Russell, of Westerly; a brother, Paul Andrew Zintl and his wife, Lisa Frost Zintl of Brookline, MA, and their two sons, Sam and Bob; a sister, Amy Zintl Koch and her husband, William, of Norwell, MA, and their son, Thomas. Also her stepfather, LeRoy K. McCune of Greenville, DE, and several nieces: Colby Zintl of San Francisco and her children, Joe, India and Jack Marcus; Anna Zintl of New York City; and Elizabeth Cole Wilson and Sarah Wilson, both of Los Angeles. Mrs. Russell was predeceased by a brother, Robert T. Zintl Jr., and sister, Anne Elizabeth Zintl. A memorial service for Mrs. Russell will be held Saturday, 11am, at Watch Hill Chapel, 5 Bluff Ave., Westerly. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be made in Mrs. Russell's memory to the Warm Shelter, 56 Spruce St., Westerly, RI, 02891.

FOR fitness buffs seeking to add a splash of green to their daily routines, ditching bottled water for B.Y.O.B. (bringing your own bottle) has become the way to go. Refillable containers keep unnecessary waste out of landfills, environmental advocates say, and save the oil used in producing plastic and transporting bottles. Once the domain of the outdoor set, reusable containers are gaining widespread popularity.

Bill Bragin, director of Joe's Pub at the Public Theater and an influential concert promoter, has been hired as director of public programming at Lincoln Center, it was announced yesterday. He will begin in January in the new position, and will program the Midsummer Night Swing and the Out of Doors summer series and work on events for Lincoln Center's 50th anniversary, coming in 2009. ... Two more seasons of the drama series ''Damages,'' starring Glenn Close, have been ordered by FX, Fox's general entertainment basic cable network. Each season will consist of 13 episodes.

The captain and crewmen of a Chinese ship responsible for an oil spill on Nov. 7 after hitting the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge have refused to speak to federal investigators, a spokesman for the National Transportation Safety Board said. But the local pilot who was guiding the ship told investigators that its radar had malfunctioned shortly before the accident. The safety board said, however, that a check of the radar showed it was functioning normally.

CHANDELIERS made out of plumbing pipe? What would Louis XIV have thought? Actually, given their playful and original contrast of dripping crystals and muscular pipes, he might have been gone for them in a big way. And the prices, from the brand-new one-man company of Michael McHale Designs, are kingly: the Banqueting Chandelier, above right, sells for $9,750. A former entertainment lawyer who grew up in Detroit and got his graduate degree at Oxford, Mr. McHale, 41, above, got into design by happenstance: shopping for a chandelier for his Brooklyn Heights apartment, he could find nothing he liked. ''The materials just sort of struck me as, you're not getting very much,'' he said. ''Molded plastic and Mylar in kind of an interesting shape, a light bulb and a bit of electrical cord for $900. I remember being disgusted and thinking I could make it more interesting and it would be cheaper.'' (It is necessary here to make an editorial clarification: Cheaper for Mr. McHale.)

The Manhattan district attorney's office yesterday quietly dropped its prosecution of a street performer accused of harassing police officers by reciting the First Amendment at a rally in Union Square Park. Prosecutors said they deliberately allowed the case to be dismissed by failing to meet a court-ordered deadline to file papers explaining why the arrest of the performer, who is known as Reverend Billy and whose real name is William Talen, was justified. ''Sometimes not making a decision is a good decision,'' one prosecutor said. Mr. Talen, above, who is the head of what he calls the Church of Stop Shopping, was arrested in June after he repeatedly recited the 45 words of the First Amendment through an unamplified megaphone during a rally in support of bicyclists. The police said he refused to stop when they asked him to, and followed them around. The amendment deals with ''the right of the people peaceably to assemble.''

In conjunction with the Museum of Modern Art's retrospective of works by the sculptor Martin Puryear, MoMA stores are offering reproductions of two objects Mr. Puryear made for his own use. The teakettle, left and right, is an adaptation of one with an unwieldy hinged handle; he substituted a fixed handle with a wooden grip. The pan scraper, center, grew out of his penchant for removing encrusted food from dishes with a nylon disc; he created one with a swiveling handle. Mr. Puryear said he often modifies objects to make them more functional or pleasing, going so far as to replace the metal legs on a Saarinen womb chair with wooden ones. ''It's sacrilegious, I know,'' he said. The pan scraper ($12) goes on sale this week; the kettle ($195), which has a Bakelite handle, will be available in December. Information: momastore.org. JULIE SCELFO

A front-page article on Monday about the current medical thinking on the safety of drug-coated heart stents misstated the relationship between Columbia University and the Cardiovascular Research Foundation, an organization that runs the largest annual meeting for doctors who use stents. The foundation was founded and is led by physicians employed by Columbia University, but it is not part of the university.

Steven Buckwald, below left, the owner of Surroundings Flowers on the Upper West Side, is opening a shop today at the Apthorp -- the first, he said, of 25 such stores planned for Manhattan in the next five years. There he will sell the same flowers that he puts into arrangements for clients like the Metropolitan Opera, for about a third of the price, or a 40 percent markup from cost. On Nov. 30 he will open a Harlem shop. Both shops will sell bouquets like the one with coral peonies and pink roses ($40), below right, as well as flowers priced by the stem. (If he pays 50 cents for a Gerbera daisy, he said, it will sell for 70 cents.) The Apthorp is at 2207 Broadway (78th Street); the Harlem shop is at 1351 Amsterdam Avenue (125th Street); (212) 580-8982. ELAINE LOUIE

Over the past 20 years, Jim Oliveira, a Manhattan artist, has developed a technique for creating paintings he calls ''color piles.'' He mixes clear acrylic with inks and pigments, and pours it onto plastic-lined worktables, as if it were pancake batter, forming circles of varying sizes and thicknesses. Once they have dried, the disks are stacked into clusters and attached to a Belgian linen canvas. Now he is using the same technique to make ottomans, which are covered in a ''fabric'' of acrylic disks over a reinforced plywood frame that sits on glides. They come in 12- and 18-inch sizes ($8,500 to $12,500), and in multicolored compositions, below, as well as black, metallic gold and a bright blue inspired by the painters Yves Klein and Lucio Fontana. Information: (212) 343-2524 or jimoliveirastudio.com.

Are universities gobbling up New York City? Town-gown disputes have flared recently at such diverse schools as Columbia University (where hunger-striking students are protesting a campus expansion in Harlem), New York University (which is steadily developing more and more of Greenwich Village) and even Queens College (which is building its first dormitory).

Kevin Mooney, proprietor of Mooney’s Pub on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, has encountered his fair share of Mooneys who weren’t related to him in his 72 years. I think I was the latest – I stopped in on Wednesday to interview him about the bar, which apparently is going to be closing soon.I had always seen the place and wondered about it, whether there was some distant family relationship. If there is, it is distant enough that neither Kevin Mooney nor I know about it; he was born in County Galway, in Ireland, whereas my grandfather’s family came to New York from Scotland in the early part of the 20th century. It’s definitely an Irish name, though, so it seems as my family’s Mooneys did some bouncing from island to island long ago. So you never know -– I read once that, mathematically speaking, we can all claim descent from Nefertiti and Confucius anyway.

New York City’s eighth graders have made no significant progress in reading and math since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took control of the city schools, in contrast with the largely steady gains that have been recorded on state tests, according to the National Assessment of Educational Progress. As Jennifer Medina reports in a front-page article, the results paint a generally stagnant picture for the city, although there are gains in fourth-grade math. On measure after measure, the scores showed “no significant change” between 2005, when the test was previously administered, and 2007.
After humbling reversals on immigration and sales taxes in the last week, and more troubles on the Troopergate front, how does Gov. Eliot Spitzer unwind?

Serendipity 3, a popular restaurant on East 60th Street, was in the news last week for a publicity stunt boasting about the world’s most expensive dessert: a $25,000 Frrrozen Haute Chocolate. It was back in the headlines today, after the city shut it down for failing a second health inspection.

A lawyer for the family of Khiel Coppin, an 18-year-old mentally ill man who was fatally shot by police officers in Brooklyn on Monday, asserted today that the police had used excessive force against an unarmed man. The lawyer, Paul Wooten, repeated his call for an independent investigation into the shooting, which the police commissioner has said appeared to be within departmental guidelines.In a news conference at Brighter Way Baptist Church, in Bedford-Stuvyesant, elected officials and community leaders called the shooting senseless and urged improvements in police training, particularly with respect to the mentally ill. Several of those who spoke angrily stated that young black men like Mr. Coppin were automatically considered to be armed and dangerous. Mr. Coppin was holding a hairbrush when he was shot, but there had been conflicting information as to whether he was armed.

At a time when transportation hubs are being reshaped by security measures, it might be logical to infer that the enormous structural outriggers added last weekend to the Port Authority Bus Terminal were intended to protect the structure in an explosion. Or deter pigeons, perhaps. In fact, their primary purpose is to reinforce the terminal against a different kind of trauma: earthquakes.

Landlord-tenant hostility is nothing new in New York City, but investigators said today that a Brooklyn landlord, Oludola Johnson, took things to a new and illegal level.

Do people walking down the street have a right of privacy against having their picture taken, without permission, for a gallery show? The Court of Appeals, the state’s highest court, skirted that issue on Thursday when it cited procedural grounds to dismiss a lawsuit by an ultra-Orthodox Jewish man who had sued a photographer on religious grounds. The court did not address the privacy issues at the heart of the case.From 1999 to 2001, the artist and photographer Philip-Lorca diCorcia took images of individuals walking through Times Square. None of them knew they were being photographed. In the fall of 2001, Mr. diCorcia exhibited some of the photos at the Pace/MacGill gallery, which published and sold a catalog of images from the exhibition. Ten limited-edition prints of each photo were created for sale to the public.

From the blitzkrieg beginning to the atomic end, the course of the conflict was shaped profoundly by which side had the technological upper hand, so both sides kept up a furious pace of wartime R & D that wound up besotting the world with gadgetry and science.
