For the second consecutive week, CBS edged past ABC on Thursday to lead the night's ratings in both total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. Although "Grey's Anatomy" remained No. 1 in that demographic, giving ABC a strong second place finish overall, CBS proved more consistent throughout the night.

It seems surprising that the return of Ricky Williams has not produced more news media coverage. A player talented enough to rush for 1,853 yards and 16 touchdowns in a season, who then had his career torpedoed by positive drug tests and a bizarre trip around the world, he should be the talk of the town. Instead, he is being mostly ignored. Jeff Darlington of The Miami Herald took a look at his return with the Dolphins, but most other media outlets have gone with this Associated Press story as the only mention of him. On second thought, a player who can't stay clean, who plays for a team that is 0-9, probably shouldn't expect much more.
Most observers feel that Hillary Clinton aced the "diamonds or pearls" question at last night's Las Vegas debate, and many feel that the question was "frivolous," "trivial," and "sexist."

When Hurricane Katrina hit, poor people in Louisiana and Mississippi bore the brunt of it -- they lived in the most vulnerable areas and structures, and they were in the worst position to escape the storm and deal with the aftermath.

It doesn't take much to rekindle speculation about a tie-up between Microsoft and Yahoo. Analysts, investors and bloggers have long discussed the pros and cons of this as yet strictly hypothetical pairing. So when a Microsoft executive went on the record Thursday about wanting to triple the size of his company's Internet search business, it was more than enough to get the rumor mill creaking back into action.

The madness has already begun this week, with Arizona knocking off No. 2 Oregon last night. Will the weekend bring more upsets? Or will this be a weekend when the results go to form? And what team will emerge as the king of the Ivy League? Our fearless prognosticators will attempt to answer these questions with their weekly predictions.

The game of the week this week is clearly Harvard-Yale. Seriously. Michigan and Ohio State both lost last week to make their game not quite as big as it could have been. Still it's for the Big Ten and that still counts for something, right? The other intriguing matchups of the weekend are Georgia-Kentucky, with the new Mark Richt shaking things up in Athens and Boston College looking to stop its free fall and still grab the A.C.C. title. Clemson-Boston College is for the Atlantic Division and that makes it worth watching. Unlike Notre Dame-Duke, which is worth watching like a train wreck. Anyway, not much more college football out there this year so take advantage and watch some games this weekend.
There are very few political analysts more closely associated with the Clintons than James Carville, who was a key adviser to Mr. Clinton in the 1992 campaign.

With Citigroup's search for a new chief executive entering its third week, columnists Michael Lewis of Bloomberg News and Rob Cox of Breakingviews are offering the gigantic bank their unsolicited -- and sharply ironic -- advice on the situation.

Check out this video clip, posted by Russia Today and linked by Wired's Danger Room security blog, showing scenes from the police crackdown on demonstrators last week in Tbilisi, the capital of the Republic of Georgia, where a state of emergency is being lifted today. About halfway through the two-and-a-half-minute clip, you'll see what appear to be LRADs -- long-range acoustic devices, a sort of sound cannon -- in action on the back of two police pickup trucks.
How serious is North Korea about getting rid of its nuclear weapons and forging more normal ties with the United States?

In September Randy Pausch, a computer science professor at Carnegie Mellon University, gave his last lecture, telling the audience that he would soon die of pancreatic cancer. But those may not be his last public words after all.

How times have changed for the Yankees: as important as Joe Torre was to the success of the major league team, he was not involved in the larger aspects of the organization. New manager Joe Girardi, meanwhile, has spent the week at the team's academy in the Dominican Republic.

In his column today, Carl Hulse writes about how Republicans and Democrats are digging into the results from local elections held earlier this month to discern trends for 2008. "It is hard to overstate how carefully lawmakers and their political advisers have been combing through the data from municipal, county and state elections to see what it means for them."
To gain Merrill Beth Winner's heart, Cory Bronson first had to make it past her doorman.

With the opening of the Red Cat in 1999, Jimmy Bradley moved to the forefront of New York City chefs, establishing his talent for putting together --- and executing --- menus that could please both demanding, sophisticated eaters and those just looking to pass the time with comforting, satisfying food.
Irving Brecher, who wrote ''Meet Me in St. Louis'' and ''Bye Bye Birdie,'' weighs in on the writers' strike. He's 93. His agent died. He's seeking representation. He's mad. Here he is:

LAS VEGAS - It was a long night for the Democratic candidates. After the two-hour debate last night, they went over to the ballroom at the Paris Las Vegas Hotel on the Strip to make their cases to 2,300 Democrats in fancy evening wear at a gala dinner.

Many people in baseball are privately delighted that the agent Scott Boras will get less than he wanted for Alex Rodriguez. The Yankees will soon make official a 10-year contract with Rodriguez for about $275 million, with the chance to make at least $300 million. Boras had contended that Rodriguez deserved more than $32 million per season.
From the Borowitz Report:

We asked the Open Caucus, our newly formed virtual roundtable of voters from across the country, for their views on last night's debate among the Democratic presidential candidates. A few commented as the evening's forum unfolded in Las Vegas; others have posted their observations overnight.

Well, it didn't take long for the craziness to start in college football this week. Oregon became the fifth No. 2 team to lose this season when the Ducks were defeated, 34-24, by Arizona on Thursday night. Mike Tokito of the Oregonian writes that Oregon must now adjust in order to salvage something from this season. Stewart Mandel of SI.com writes that the loss showed just how valuable quarterback Dennis Dixon is to the Ducks. The B.C.S. Guru tells us what it all means for the, well, B.C.S.

A few months ago, in my TBR: Inside the List column, printed weekly on dead trees, I wrote about a galley copy of a Michael Ondaatje novel, "Anil's Ghost," that was for sale on the used book Web site abebooks.com. What was special about this galley - and the reason it was offered at $1,250 - is that John Updike had filled it with comments while preparing a review for The New Yorker.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Taxes on hedge funds and private equity funds made a prominent appearance in the latest Republican debate, but that subject -- a hot-button issue for the high-finance crowd -- was notably absent from Thursday night's Democratic one.
Wednesday the writers guild's claims about residuals were rebuffed by ABC Studios. Thursday the studio's claims about residuals were rejected by the writers. And the picketers walk 'round and 'round.

An interesting casualty of the writers' strike: On Thursday "TV Guide magazine said it would cancel a ceremony and a broadcast of its first Online Video Awards," Stuart Elliott notes in Friday's New York Times.

Seven days ago, nonwriting staff members on "The Tonight Show with Jay Leno" were informed that they would be laid off at the end of this week. But the plan has changed and the staffers "will be paid for at least another two weeks," Broadcasting & Cable reports.
News from Down Under:

"Reflecting the deep divisions within Congress over granting legal immunity to telephone companies for cooperating with the Bush administration's program of wiretapping without warrants, the Senate Judiciary Committee approved a new domestic surveillance law on Thursday that sidestepped the issue," reports The Times's James Risen:
Garmin on Friday withdrew its 2.3 billion euro ($3.4 billion) bid for Tele Atlas, clearing the road for TomTom to acquired the digital map maker.
Just asking, but have we really thought through the physical implications of what we're repeatedly asking Pakistan's President to do?

[UPDATE, 2/13: I wrote a story on a federal court ruling that could open the way for more mountaintop coal mining. Environmental groups say the ruling adds urgency to their calls for President Obama to erase some rules favorable to those seeking to expand such mining that were written by the outgoing Bush administration.]
Goldman Sachs is a perennial leader in the mergers and acquisitions league tables, with strength in nearly every category. Apparently, now it's reaching into deal making in the sports arena.
Of the seven Democratic candidates onstage at last night's Las Vegas debate, Hillary Rodham Clinton's aggressive performance seemed to put her back on her feet after last month's debate.
It's time again for Friday's week in reading:
A series of Fanta soft-drink commercials from Japan:
BEA Systems has been hoping to prove it is worth more than the $6.7 billion that Oracle offered to pay for it last month.
CSX's board on Friday publicly backed management and rebutted criticisms by a hedge fund that the railroad operator has overspent and failed to improve its stock's performance.
Cerberus Capital Management, the private equity firm, has offered to negotiate new terms with United Rentals after abandoning a $4 billion buyout this week, according to regulatory documents.
Two months after Northern Rock was put up for sale to fix Britain's largest victim of the subprime crisis, the mortgage lender is still causing headaches.

Merrill Lynch's new chief executive, John A. Thain, said price drops in the mortgage- securities market may create "great opportunities" and plans to hire senior managers to bolster the trading division.

Investment banks, hammered by massive write-downs and trading losses since the summer, are radically shifting business plans of their mortgage-backed securities departments - and it's leaving hedge funds out in the cold, according to The New York Post.
Cathleen Schine's most recent novel is "The New Yorkers."

Gideon Yu, the former chief financial officer of YouTube and current chief financial officer of Facebook, is one of the most notable new executives in Silicon Valley. But while Mr. Yu operated in high-tech's highest circles over the last two years, an impersonator was quietly using his name and credit card number to make fraudulent purchases.

Two high-ranking Democratic lawmakers asked the Federal Communications Commission not to rush changes in the longstanding rule that had barred a company from owning both a newspaper and a radio or television station in the same city.

London investor 3i Group added new meaning to the term "private equity" with an agreement announced Thursday to acquire luxury lingerie retailer Agent Provocateur. The price was not disclosed but, according to The Deal.com, the deal valued the company at about 60 million pounds ($124.3 million).

Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog each week. In his latest post, Altidore discusses his trip to South Africa as a first-time member of the United States senior national team.
Shares in BHP Billiton rose as much as 2.4 percent on Friday, bucking the trend in a broadly falling stock market, following a report that Rio Tinto was considering a counterbid for its BHP.

When the Shaw Group, an industrial engineering company, became mired in a contract dispute over its construction work on an electricity plant in Texas, it filed a lawsuit against its client, the AES Corporation.
Lawmakers in two hearings on Thursday proposed ways to force nursing homes to provide more details about ownership and to hold those owners more accountable when problems emerge.
Years ago, Japan rose to economic prominence by taking apart American products like cars and television sets to learn how to make them better.
Acquisitions of asset management firms have surpassed even last year's record levels as financial institutions like Morgan Stanley seek stable revenues amid volatile markets.
More submissions from readers to tide us over during the TV writers' strike (send yours via the comment link below). Look for more posts like this in the days ahead:

The Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board formally launched a 1.8 billion New Zealand dollar ($1.4 billion) bid for a stake in New Zealand's Auckland International Airport on Friday, prompting the airport to seek rival offers.

Pfizer, the world's biggest drug company, flopped miserably with a seemingly can't-miss idea. But Alfred E. Mann is so certain he can succeed that he is betting nearly $1 billion of his own money on the effort.
Buyout shop Lindsay Goldberg is partially cashing out of EnergySolutions through a $690 million initial public offering of the nuclear services provider.

TPG Capital will push ahead with its offer for Spain's No. 1 airline Iberia Lineas Aereas de España despite seeing its indicative 3.4 billion euro ($5 billion) offer trumped by a rival Spanish syndicate, The Deal.com reported.
If Cisco wants to make a big splash in the managed security arena, it may need to do some more shopping. The 451 Group looks at some of the takeover targets that the company might pursue.
General Motors, Ford Motor, Chrysler and the United Auto Workers have created a $54.4 billion plum for Wall Street.
Initiate Systems, a master data management company, filed this week to raise up to $75 million in an initial public offering. But, The 451 Group asks, could an M&A event still be in its future?
A day after a report surfaced that New York hedge fund Galleon Group has purchased "several million shares" of Advanced Micro Devices, the U.S. chipmaker looks set to get another large investor.

Several leaders of Washington's technology community are creating an investment firm to back local entrepreneurs as they start up companies, The Washington Post reported, the latest in a series of local organizations helping to turn promising innovations into businesses.
Goldman Sachs' top economist said losses from slumping credit markets may reduce lending by $2 trillion.

Talks continued Thursday between British insurance firm Resolution and its suitor Pearl Group to hammer out a deal that will probably not significantly exceed the 4.9 billion pound ($10.2 billion), or 720 pence per share, offer already on the table.

Live Nation, the world's largest live-concert promoter, said Thursday that it had reached a deal to acquire Signatures Network, a major manufacturer of concert T-shirts and other music merchandise, for about $79 million in cash, stock and debt.
China will introduce a program allowing individuals to invest directly in Hong Kong equities in the second quarter of next year, HSBC Holdings said.
The cyclone that swept across the edges of southern Bangladesh downed trees and swept away homes.
In South Korea, the Jump Up Internet Rescue School aims to help young Koreans overcome the growing problem of Internet addiction.
Oregon is the latest top-five team to fall this season, losing on the road to Arizona, 34-24, Thursday night.
“The Life of Reilly” is built around “Save It for the Stage,” a one-man stage show by Charles Nelson Reilly, a showbiz gadfly and Tony Award-winning theater director.
Brian De Palma’s “Redacted” traffics in, and clearly means to provoke, strong, unbalanced emotions.
Suicide, infidelity, spousal abuse and arrested development are the building blocks of “Park,” a wearisome comedy.
When it comes to emotional violence, “Margot at the Wedding” is hard to beat.
If the concept of “Mr. Magorium’s Wonder Emporium” is ingenious, its execution is erratic.
A jaunty mix of chanting, baking and spiritual uplift, “How to Cook Your Life” introduces us to the cooking classes of Edward Espe Brown, a twinkling Zen priest.
“Love in the Time of Cholera” is faithful to the outline of the novel but emotionally and spiritually anemic.
At the very least, the documentary “What Would Jesus Buy?” might make a viewer think twice about that next purchase at the Gap.
You don’t need to wait for Angelina Jolie to rise from the vaporous depths naked to know that this “Beowulf” isn’t your high school teacher’s Old English epic poem.
Alan Saret at the Drawing Center, “Modernism” at Seventh Regiment Armory, Anthony Caro at Mitchell-Innes & Nash and more.
Robert Farquhar’s play is an all-out assault on pretentious theater directors and the idiot actors who follow their commands in the interest of realism.
The decision means, among other changes, that the company will seek a new agency to handle its media planning and buying assignment.
Merrill Lynch said today that it would award its incoming chairman and chief executive, John Thain, a cash bonus of $15 million for 2007.
The crew of the International Space Station are performing a nonstop series of tasks inside and outside the station.
The complex federal appeals court ruling signaled trouble for civil rights groups trying to show that an eavesdropping program was unconstitutional.
As leaders of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries meet in Saudi Arabia, there are signs that high oil prices are a mixed blessing for producers.
A Federal Reserve governor warned today that another interest rate cut would probably offer few benefits to the economy.
Senate Republicans blocked an effort by Democrats to act on a war spending bill that would have required troop withdrawals. A Republican measure also failed.
It is hard to overstate how carefully lawmakers and their political advisers have been combing through the data from municipal, county and state elections to see what it means for them.
Joe Nuxhall, who spent more than half a century with the Reds as a pitcher and broadcaster, died Thursday at 79.
An Icelandic company said on Friday that it is launching a service that will assess a person’s genome for disease risk.
Oregon’s quarterback, Heisman trophy front-runner Dennis Dixon, was injured as the team lost to Arizona, marking the fifth time a second-ranked team has lost this season.
A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with 17 armed robberies in Lower Manhattan in the past nine weeks, the police said.
Josh Howard fueled first-half spurts that let the Mavericks build a huge lead that they turned into an easy victory over the San Antonio Spurs on Thursday night.

Police internal affairs officers and the Essex County prosecutor’s office are investigating a shooting that left a 21-year-old man dead on a Newark street early yesterday. Though the police initially reported that the man, Jihaad Sumler, aimed a gun at a police officer, the prosecutor, Paula Dow, later said that events were still unclear — including whether Mr. Sumler had been armed and whether he had been running from the police when he was shot at least twice. Late yesterday, the Newark police said that Mr. Sumler was being pursued and had drawn a weapon, but there was no mention of it being pointed at an officer. A police spokesman, Detective Todd McClendon, did not return calls seeking comment. The shooting occurred about 1 a.m. yesterday.
The health care products maker Johnson & Johnson, faced with lagging sales of some products, said Thursday that it would create three units to increase prospects.
Cerberus Capital Management, the private equity firm, has offered to negotiate new terms with United Rentals after abandoning a $4 billion buyout this week.
Kevin Boss, a rookie who spent the first eight games of the season blending into the background, emerged from obscurity by making a critical mistake.
The Runnin’ Bulldogs were in over their heads at Madison Square Garden Thursday, losing to Connecticut.
The Rangers were drawn into a goal-scoring contest with a Flyers team that is far more accustomed to playing such games. Still, they won an exciting game, 4-3, in a shootout.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the selection of John A. Thain, the chief executive of NYSE Euronext, to lead the brokerage firm Merrill Lynch, misstated Thursday’s closing price for NYSE shares in some copies. It was $86.74, not $78.69.

The Antiques column in Weekend on Nov. 2, about an exhibition related to Napoleon at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and a table Napoleon commissioned that Sotheby’s was offering for sale, omitted an organizer of the exhibition, “Symbols of Power: Napoleon and the Art of the Empire Style: 1800-1815.” While curators at the Museum of Decorative Arts in Paris chose the objects for the show, the American Federation of Arts also helped organize it.

An article on Tuesday about warnings of an environmental disaster in southern Russia after at least 11 ships, including a small oil tanker, sank or broke apart in a fierce storm in the Black Sea included an incorrect conversion to gallons for the amount of fuel oil spilled from the tanker. It was about 360,000 gallons (1,300 metric tons). The figure in the article, 562,000, was the conversion from 2,000 metric tons, the earlier estimate for the spill.

A picture caption yesterday with a theater column about the Shakespeare Theater Company’s new Sidney Harman Hall in Washington, and its productions there and at its nearby Lansburgh Theater, misidentified the theater where the company is performing Christopher Marlowe’s “Edward II.” It is Sidney Harman Hall, not the Lansburgh Theater.

Because of an editing error, a report in the baseball roundup yesterday about support by Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida for public funding of a ballpark for Tampa Bay misstated the team’s nickname in some editions. It is the Rays — not the Devil Rays, a name that the club abandoned earlier this month.

An article yesterday about the ceremonial swearing-in of Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey included incorrect information about a meeting the same day with lawyers for Puerto Rico’s governor, Aníbal Acevedo-Vilá, about a pending corruption inquiry. Mr. Mukasey was not at the meeting, which was attended by other Justice Department officials.

An article on Tuesday about warnings of an environmental disaster in southern Russia after at least 11 ships, including a small oil tanker, sank or broke apart in a fierce storm in the Black Sea included an incorrect conversion to gallons for the amount of fuel oil spilled from the tanker. It was about 360,000 gallons (1,300 metric tons). The figure in the article, 562,000, was the conversion from 2,000 metric tons, the earlier estimate for the spill.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about big investment firms that propped up their money market mutual funds misstated the exposure of one such fund to debt issued by complex securities called structured investment vehicles. While Wachovia booked a $40 million loss on securities it bought from its Evergreen fund, which greatly reduced investor exposure, it has not eliminated all risk to SIV debt.

An article yesterday about the approval of principles by American Roman Catholic bishops to guide voters misstated what the principles said about “intrinsic evils,” notably abortion. The document defines them as actions that must be opposed; it does not “defend” them that way.

An article on Wednesday about transplant recipients who contracted H.I.V. and hepatitis C from donated organs misstated the organization that first reported the news. It was Fox News Chicago, a television station, not The Chicago Tribune.

Sidney Crosby and Evgeni Malkin extended point streaks and Georges Laraque scored for the first time in 40 games to help the Pittsburgh Penguins defeat the Islanders, 3-2, to end a four-game losing streak.
Prime Minister Vojislav Kostunica angrily rejected allegations that children and adults with mental disabilities were systematically abused in the country’s institutions.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 15 — With more specifics and more urgency than usual, Gov. Jon S. Corzine said on Thursday that he would reveal the details of his controversial and long-percolating plan to reduce the state’s $32 billion debt by half by refinancing the state’s toll roads in his State of the State speech on Jan. 8.
The government said it had reached an agreement with the country’s main Islamic separatist group on carving out boundaries for a Muslim homeland in the southern Mindanao region.
About 30 members of an eccentric Christian sect have retreated to a cave on a snowy hillside outside Nikolskoye in central Russia, where they have been in a standoff with the police.
A prosecutor said he was preparing to bring a murder charge against a policeman who fatally shot a 26-year-old Roman man over the weekend.
Abu Hamza al-Masri, Britain’s most prominent radical Muslim cleric, can be extradited to the United States to face trial on charges of supporting terrorism.
The Senate narrowly approved the 2008 budget, pulling the government of Prime Minister Romano Prodi back from the brink of collapse.
The definitive history of New York night life may one day make note of Stephen Sakai in a short chapter called Downtown Bouncer Violence.

Christian Fittipaldi will drive for Andretti Green Racing in the American Le Mans sports car series next season. Fittipaldi, a 36-year-old Brazilian and nephew of the two-time Formula One champion and Indianapolis 500 winner Emerson Fittipaldi, is a former CART teammate of Michael Andretti, a co-owner of A.G.R.

South Carolina will hold a reworked pep rally to replace the traditional Tiger Burn in the aftermath of a beach-house fire that killed seven students last month.The ceremony will be Nov. 23, a day before the Gamecocks play Clemson. South Carolina students voted to cancel the original rally, where a likeness of a Clemson Tiger is burned, in memory of the students who died. Six were from the University of South Carolina. One was from Clemson.
Live Nation, the world’s largest live-concert promoter, said that it had reached a deal to acquire a major manufacturer of concert T-shirts and other music merchandise.

The Big Ten Conference fined Illinois and Ohio State $10,000 each and reprimanded their head coaches for a shoving match involving players after last Saturday’s game. Players from both teams shoved one another and at least a couple threw punches as they met at midfield of Ohio Stadium after the 28-21 Illini victory.

The former major league pitcher Rick Rhoden double-bogeyed the final hole to drop into a three-way tie for the lead after the third round of the Champions Tour’s national qualifying tournament. Rhoden shot a par 72 to match Jack Ferenz (69) and Scott Masingill (70) at six-under 210 on the TPC Eagle Trace in Coral Springs, Fla. After the fourth round today, the low 30 players and ties will earn spots into open qualifiers at all co-sponsored events on the 2008 Champions Tour.

Max Jones, the longtime general manager of Roush Fenway Racing, has moved to Yates Racing as a co-owner and general manager, with the veteran crew chief Robbie Reiser stepping into his former job.Jones became general manager for Jack Roush’s team in 1992. During his tenure, the team won the 2003 Nascar Nextel Cup title, as well as championships in the Craftsman Truck Series, road racing and, this year, the Busch Series title.

Eastern High School’s nine-year dynasty in New Jersey field hockey is over. The Vikings’ 208-game unbeaten streak against state rivals ended Wednesday night in a 3-2 overtime loss to Oak Knoll of Summit in the semifinals of the state tournament of champions. Eastern, in Voorhees, won nine consecutive state Group 4 titles and posted a 204-0-4 mark against New Jersey schools in a run that began at the start of the 1999 season. The school’s last loss was a 2-1 decision to Shawnee on Nov. 13, 1998, in the South Jersey Group 4 title game.

Elected officials and housing advocates called on the city yesterday to provide free legal representation in New York City housing court to low-income elderly residents, who they said often had trouble navigating the system and protecting themselves from eviction.
Not a minivan-driving suburban parent, she's a soccer-playing mom: one of the top college players in the Northeast and the mother of a 14-month-old.
With typically tough defense and a balanced offense, the No. 5 Hoyas raced out to a big lead last night and were never challenged in a 74-52 victory against the visiting Wolverines.
A federal appeals court said that new fuel-economy standards for light trucks, including S.U.V.’s, didn’t thoroughly assess the impact of greenhouse gases.
Militants in Pakistan’s tribal areas have captured more territory inside settled areas despite an emergency decree.
The state is the only one for which the White House has waived the rule that 50 percent of its federal grants be spent on low-income programs.
State Department officials said that they were not abandoning a policy to order diplomats to Iraq if there was a need in the future.
Iran has been denied purchases of nuclear-related materials at least 75 times over the past nine years because of suspicions the purchases could have been used for building bombs.
Inflation remains contained despite high oil prices and a record low dollar, a government report showed on Thursday.

Serendipity 3, a popular East Side restaurant, has been closed after failing its second health inspection in a month. Health department officials said that they closed the restaurant, known for its extravagant and expensive desserts, on Wednesday night. “Both inspections revealed rodent and fly infestation and conditions conducive to pest infestation, including stagnant water in the basement,” the department said in a statement. An inspector spotted a live mouse and mouse droppings, flies and more than 100 live cockroaches, the department said.

A Staten Island man has been charged with raping a 62-year-old homeless woman under the boardwalk on South Beach in July of last year, prosecutors announced yesterday. The man, Jason Gonzalez, 27, pleaded not guilty at his arraignment yesterday, Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Staten Island district attorney, said in a statement. Mr. Gonzalez is serving two to four years in a state prison for grand larceny, prosecutors said.

A jeweler was convicted yesterday of falsely reporting that five men were plotting to bomb the subways, in a scheme apparently meant to cause trouble for the men, his former business associates. The jeweler, Rimon Alkatri, 35, was convicted in State Supreme Court of falsely reporting an incident and faces up to seven years in prison. The report resulted in a police investigation of the former business associates, and the police searched their homes. Nothing suspicious was found. Mr. Alkatri’s lawyer, Michael L. Soshnick, said his client admitted making the call but denied that the information was deliberately false.

Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, called for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his schools chancellor to apologize to the city’s 80,000 teachers yesterday, a day after the chancellor sent principals an e-mail message announcing the formation of teams of lawyers and consultants meant to help principals remove poorly performing tenured teachers. Ms. Weingarten said that the message seemed timed to the release yesterday of national reading and math test scores showing little progress among New York City students. “The first speck of bad news, all of the sudden they go after teachers,” Ms. Weingarten said. The mayor said yesterday that removing tenured teachers was “a last alternative.”.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday proposed eliminating discounts for drivers who use the cashless E-ZPass toll collection system during peak hours on its crossings between New Jersey and Manhattan and Staten Island. Under the proposal, which is subject to public hearings, all drivers would pay $8 to use the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels, the George Washington Bridge and bridges to Staten Island. Drivers with an E-ZPass tag crossing at peak hours now pay $5, while those with cash pay $6. To ease traffic during the most congested hours of the day, the authority also proposes that drivers with E-ZPass pay $6 during off-peak hours. The increases would be the first since 2001.

Robert E. Chambers Jr., known as the “preppy killer,” blamed drug abuse yesterday for his latest arrest, on charges of selling cocaine from the Upper East Side apartment he shared with a companion, Shawn Kovell. Mr. Chambers’s lawyer, Valerie Van Leer-Greenberg, told a justice in State Supreme Court that she was considering a psychiatric defense, among others, for her client, arguing “diminished capacity predicated upon polysubstance abuse.” The next hearing is on Dec. 18. Mr. Chambers, who was arrested on Oct. 22, has pleaded not guilty.

Senator Charles E. Schumer announced yesterday that he had recommended two women to the White House to fill vacant posts on the federal bench in Brooklyn and Manhattan. Mr. Schumer recommended Kiyo Ann Matsumoto, a United States magistrate judge in the Eastern District of New York, for the opening on United States District Court in Brooklyn. If nominated and confirmed, Judge Matsumoto would become the first Asian-American judge in that court. He also recommended Cathy Seibel, the deputy United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, for the district court posting in Manhattan.

A fire that ravaged an upper floor of a skyscraper in Lower Manhattan early yesterday morning was caused by an electrical problem, the Fire Department said, though the exact malfunction had yet to be identified. Firefighters were called to 80 Pine Street at 12:21 a.m. The fire, which started on the 29th floor, was brought under control just over an hour later, the department said. The department said 138 firefighters responded and 8 sustained minor injuries.

Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo joined five other state attorneys general in criticizing the Nuclear Regulatory Commission’s review of applications to extend the operating life of nuclear plants. The group said the N.R.C.’s consideration of the potential effect of earthquakes and terrorist attacks was insufficient. The owner of the two reactors at Indian Point, in Westchester County, has applied to extend its license by 20 years. Diane Screnci, a spokeswoman for the commission, said the agency conducted “rigorous examinations” to determine safety.
With no end in sight to the writers strike, several hosts of late-night shows have begun taking steps to ensure that their nonwriting staffs receive some portion of their pay.
Off-Track Betting parlors could become a thing of the past in the city by next June, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Thursday.
Republican voters are often captivated by Senator John McCain’s discussion of the issue of torture, even though many don’t agree with him.
Starbucks, the world’s largest chain of coffee shops, lowered its profit and sales forecasts after reporting its first decline in customer visits.
A recent pattern in which China issues regulations aimed at favoring Chinese industries over foreign competitors has raised concerns among U.S. officials.
CBS said that Dan Rather’s allegations were “far-fetched” and denied that the network has ever been “out to get Dan Rather.”
By a 10 to 9 vote, the Senate Judiciary Committee approved an overhaul of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act that dropped a key provision.

GEGERIAS--Mary, of Brookline, MA. With courage and dignity, Dr. Mary Gegerias of Chestnut Hill, Emeritus Professor of French at Pine Manor College, esteemed cultural ambassador, passed away November 13, 2007. Dr. Gegerias was the daughter of the late Panagiota Collias Gegerias and John Gegerias. A sister, Anna Gegerias Kapelos, predeceased her. She is survived by her sister, Helen Gegerias, her nephews George Kapelos and John Kapelos, her niece, Pamela Kapelos Fitzgerald, and her family, her godson Edouard Henri Grace Dejoux, and many beloved cousins, colleagues, and friends. A viewing will take place between 5 and 8 pm on Friday, November 16, 2007 at the Cathedral Chapel, 162 Goddard Avenue, Brookline, MA. Funeral services will be held Saturday, November 17, 2007 at 1 pm at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of New England, Parker and Ruggles Streets, The Fenway, Boston, MA. Interment at Forest Hills Cemetery, Boston, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Dr. Gegerias may be made to the Mary Gegerias Fund, Pine Manor College, 400 Heath Street, Chestnut Hill, MA, 02467.

The Pioneer Valley is about 150 miles north of New York City, a drive of just under three hours. Key towns of literary note include Northampton, one mile west of the Route 9 exit of Interstate 91, and Amherst, six miles east of the same exit. Amherst and Northampton can be reached by Peter Pan Bus lines, and Amtrak trains run to Amherst. Literary events are listed in local newspapers, including The Daily Hampshire Gazette (www.gazettenet.com) and The Valley Advocate (www.valleyadvocate.com), and are posted on Web sites of local bookstores, museums, colleges and libraries.

CHEREN--Melvin. (January 21, 1933-December 7, 2007) Affectionately known as ''The Godfather of Disco'' for his championing of DJs, dance music and club culture from the early days of the Disco Movement, Mel began his five decade career in the music business at ABC/Paramount, where he eventually became Head of Production. He held the same position when he moved to Scepter Records. During his tenure at Scepter he was responsible for many innovations such as the first 12 inch record for DJs and the first instrumental mix on the B-side, earning Scepter the ''Trendsetter of the Year'' Award from Billboard in 1974. With a former Scepter colleague he formed his own company, West End Records in 1976, which has been associated for over 30 years with enduring dance classics like ''Hot Shot'' and ''Heartbeat''. In recent years West End released popular compilation CD's of remixes and live performances by legendary Paradise Garage DJ Larry Levan. Mel was the financial backer of the landmark club created by his former life-partner Michael Brody. This history is well documented in Cheren's autobiography, My Life and the Paradise Garage: Keep on Dancin' published in 2000 and in a recent documentary, The Godfather of Disco. In 2005 Mel was inducted into the Dance Music Hall of Fame with their Lifetime Achievement Award, an honor which meant a great deal to him. For all of his accomplishments in the music industry, Mel was most proud of his work in support of various causes and charities and in particular his efforts in support of the LGBT Community and the fight against AIDS. He was part of the vanguard of gay men who first responded to the AIDS crisis in New York in the early Eighties and gave GMHC their first home in his Chelsea brownstone which he later operated for over 20 years as a successful bed-and-breakfast, the Colonial House Inn. He was the founder of 24 Hours For Life, an AIDS charity that was the fiscal sponsor for LIFEbeat, on whose Board he served as a Charter Director. Mel was also quietly a friend to many friends and strangers in need as well as an accomplished painter. A large number of Mel's works of art memorialize friends lost to AIDS. It is a sad irony that he is a fatality of the same health crisis that he fought so long to eradicate. Even in his last days he took a stand for AIDS prevention in a cautionary interview aired on the LOGO channel throughout the week of World AIDS Day. Mel Cheren is survived and will be greatly missed by many family members, prominent among them being Illya Dekhtyar, Mark Cheren and Barry Cherin, as well as a large extended family of close friends, colleagues and fellow activists. An announcement will soon be made about a memorial service/celebration and various memorial benefit parties taking place over the third weekend in January which would have marked his 75th birthday. Donations in Mel's honor can be made to GMHC, 119 West 24th Street, New York, New York 10011; The LGBT Community Center at 208 West 13th Street, New York, New York 10011; or LIFEbeat, 630 9th Avenue Suite 1010 New York, New York 10036.

THE ARISTOPHANIC LABORATORY The illustrious playwrights of ancient Greece gave us the tortured Oedipus, the grief-stricken Electra and the jealous and murderous Medea, among other dark and passionate characters, but every play coming out of Athens at that time was not necessarily tragic. Though we see the work of Aristophanes less frequently nowadays, he was toiling away too, writing bawdy, irreverent comedies with overtly political themes. This master of the Greek Old Comedy period is the only parodist from his era whose work survives today -- he wrote about 40 plays during his lifetime (around 450 to 388 B.C.), though fewer than a dozen are still extant. The Target Margin Theater, which spent last season breathing new life into Greek tragedy and philosophy, including adaptations of Plato's ''Symposium'' and Aristotle's ''Poetics,'' is lightening up things by devoting its 2007-8 season to Aristophanes. This is the last weekend of the Aristophanic Laboratory, a festival of adaptations and interpretations of the existing plays and fragments. The final offerings are ''The Name Means Public Spirited. Or, All Those Other Things,'' above, by Mallery Avidon, which is loosely adapted from ''Ecclesiazusae'' (say that 10 times fast -- it's eck-lee-zee-AH-zoo-sigh and kind of fun to say out loud), and takeoffs on ''Lysistrata'' and ''Peace,'' two of Aristophanes' most overt and imaginative pleas for peace. The plays may be old, but the themes, well, not so much. Most of Aristophanes' life was defined by the long and brutal Peloponnesian War between Athens and Sparta, and his plays are filled with appeals for an end to the fighting.

'THE WHOLE SHOOTIN' MATCH' One of the finest films to play in New York this year was made on a shoestring budget in and around Austin, Tex., almost three decades ago. ''The Whole Shootin' Match'' was written, directed, photographed and edited by a grievously undersung independent talent named Eagle Pennell, who died in 2002 at 49, mostly forgotten after years of swimming and all but drowning in booze. Mr. Pennell was just 25 and a film school dropout when he made ''Shootin' Match'' in 1978 for an estimated $20,000. Shot in black-and-white 16 millimeter in a quasi-documentary visual style, with sensitive framing and attentively hand-held camerawork, the film follows the tragic-comic though more often than not comic-tragic adventures of two bosom buddies, Lloyd and Frank, wonderfully played by Lou Perryman (above, left, in a scene from the film) and Sonny Davis. Chronically just a few dollars away from broke, Lloyd and Frank spend their days dreaming and scheming, and occasionally working, angling for a way to get a leg up on fate, on luck and their aimless, rootless lives. Nights are reserved for boozing, philosophizing and nuzzling available women, as well as periodic barroom fisticuffs. Filled with hilarious observations and digressions, both verbal and visual, and characterized by a deeply felt and lived-in sense of place, ''The Whole Shootin' Match'' is an exemplar of American regional filmmaking or what Roger Ebert, in his glowing review, nicely called ''Wood-Burning Cinema.'' The film had other champions: It was shown at the 1979 New Directors/ New Films festival, where it received over-the-moon praise from Vincent Canby in this paper. It also apparently helped inspire Robert Redford to found the Sundance Film Festival. None of this seemed to have done much good for Mr. Pennell, who, after a ritualistic and predictably disappointing Hollywood stopover, faded from view. In 1999 Steve McVicker wrote a lengthy and terribly sad account of Mr. Pennell's rise and fall for the Houston Press, which you can still read online at houstonpress.com. Newly preserved, ''The Whole Shootin' Match'' will hit DVD soon, but catch it now in its big-screen glory. (Through Wednesday, Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, 212-496-3809, filmlinc.org; $11.) MANOHLA DARGIS

'MILTON ROGOVIN: BUFFALO' The case of the Jewish optometrist Milton Rogovin is a sobering reminder of the adage that what goes around comes around. Persecuted in the 1950s because of his activities in the Communist Party, he is now celebrated as one of the great American documentary photographers of the postwar period. In 1999 the United States government, which had hauled him before the House Un-American Activities Committee, embraced him as a social and civil rights pioneer when the Library of Congress acquired more than 1,100 of his master prints, along with negatives and contact sheets. And now comes this 97-year-old artist's first large-scale gallery exhibition in Chelsea at Danziger Projects, focusing on his three-decade-long series of portraits of residents of the Lower West Side of Buffalo. A committed social-documentary artist, he shows little in the way of compositional tricks or technical frills. Nor was he interested in staging scenes or capturing decisive, dramatic moments. Mr. Rogovin wanted to show everyday people in their everyday lives -- young men in a bar; a girl on her way to school (above, from the series ''Lower West Side, 1969-1973''); a young boy lifting weights. His pictures are nonjudgmental, depicting his poor, frequently (but not exclusively) black subjects gently and lovingly. His photographs may not be great art, but they show America as it really was. (Through Nov. 24, Danziger Projects, 521 West 26th Street, Chelsea, 212-629-6778, danzigerprojects.com.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

The National Theater in Prague, one of the city's most imposing cultural landmarks and a symbol of Czech culture and nationhood, is to undergo three years of repairs intended to restore its original splendor, Agence France-Press reported yesterday, citing managers. The work, to be carried out without closing the theater, will focus on the facade of the late-Italian-Renaissance-style structure, its massive cupola and the paintings and artwork in the foyers. At the top of the building, two six-ton statues representing Victory in a horse-drawn chariot will be stabilized to allay fears about pubic safety. The cornerstone of the structure was laid in May 1868, but the building was nearly destroyed by fire just before its official opening in 1881. It was restored within two years.

With its best ratings this season, ''Criminal Minds'' lifted CBS into first place in the ratings on Wednesday. The 9 p.m. crime show delivered 15.7 million viewers, Nielsen estimated, while eking out the night's top ratings among adults 18 to 49 and finishing just ahead of its time slot competitor, ABC's ''Private Practice'' (11.5 million). ABC ranked second for the night, leading the 8 o'clock hour with ''Pushing Daisies'' (8.9 million), but finishing second at 10 with ''Dirty Sexy Money'' (8.1 million). Fox was third over all, with above-average ratings for its comedies at 8, ''Back to You'' (7.3 million) and '' 'Til Death'' (7.4 million). At 9 Fox's ''Kitchen Nightmares'' (7 million) improved to third place ahead of NBC's ''Bionic Woman'' (6.3 million), which saw its lowest ratings to date. NBC was fourth for the night.

Donations in his memory may be made to The Anti-Defamation League or the charity of your choice.

Are the Beatles ready to go online? Paul McCartney, left, says the band's catalog will probably turn up on the Internet next year, Reuters reported, citing Billboard.com. The Beatles have been among the most famous holdouts in the march to the Internet, but the recent settlement of a prolonged trademark dispute may have finally cleared the way. ''It's all happening soon,'' Mr. McCartney said. ''Most of us are all sort of ready. The whole thing is primed, ready to go. There's just maybe one little sticking point left, and I think it's being cleared up as we speak, so it shouldn't be too long.'' The solo catalogs of all four Beatles have been available digitally since October.

VOLPE--Dr. Edmond L. First President of the College of Staten Island, died Friday, December 14th, at Richmond University Medical Center on Staten Island. He was 85. Along with creating the College of Staten Island in 1976, Dr. Volpe was also a prominent literary critic specializing in modern American literature, especially the work of William Faulkner. Prior to becoming president of Richmond College in 1974, he was Chairman of The City College of New York, Department of English. In 1976, he was appointed first President of the College of Staten Island. For funeral service details, contact Casey Funeral Home, Staten Island, 718-447-4242

LIVEZEY--Lowell W. New York Theological Seminary announces with great sadness the passing on December 9, 2007, of Dr. Lowell W. Livezey, Professor of Urban and Religious Studies and Director of the Ecologies of Learning Project at the Seminary. Dr. Livezey directed large studies of urban congregations, using ethnographic data assembled in collaboration with colleagues and students in Chicago, Boston, and New York. He argued that the ''religion factor'' is more salient than often recognized in the economic, demographic, and spatial restructuring of modern industrial cities. Dr. Livezey received the B.A. from Swarthmore College and the M. Th. and D. Min. degrees from the University of Chicago School of Divinity. He spent two decades in the peace movement before beginning his second career in studying communities, meanings, culture, and social change. In 2005, Dr. Livezey became the founding Director of the Ecologies of Learning Project (EOL) at NYTS, funded through a major grant from Lilly Endowment Inc. Lowell Livezey was a person of immense insight, wisdom and compassion, of great integrity and depth, and an outstanding colleague. He embodied the values of teaching, learning and research that lie at the heart of the scholarly endeavor. He also was a friend, a caring human being, someone around whom community was easily formed. In the language that is familiar to the people of faith, Lowell simply was a blessing to NYTS. Lowell helped us all understand the life and work of the churches and especially the intellectual task of preparation for ministry more clearly. Dr. Craig Dykstra, Senior Vice President, Religion of Lilly Endowment Inc., stated that ''Lowell Livezey's work on religion and urban culture is path-breaking -a permanent contribution. His patient, generous and imaginative work with pastors and other religious leaders in Chicago, Boston and New York, as well as with scholars, will bear great fruit for many years to come.'' Dr. Livezey is survived by his wife, Dr. Lois Gehr Livezey, Director of the Globalization Project of the Center for World Christianity at NYTS. Contributions in Dr. Livezey's memory may be made to the Lowell W. Livezey Fund, Ecologies of Learning, New York Theological Seminary, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 500, New York, NY 10115. A memorial will be held on January 26, 2008, 10:00 am, at The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York City. Dr. Dale T. Irvin, President Dr. Diane T. Ashley, Chair of the Board of Trustees

MIXER Not to be outdone by other cultural-turned-party institutions around town, Eyebeam gallery, devoted to high-tech projects and research, is now starting its own art-and-fun series, Mixer. The inaugural event begins tomorrow with a live multimedia performance by the video artist Benton-C Bainbridge. In ''Brother Islands (Places to Lose People),'' above, Mr. Bainbridge, who was a recent Eyebeam teaching fellow, documents the history of two abandoned East River islands; using video, photos, music and actors playing ghosts, he hopes to explore the idea and mechanics of quarantine. The setup will help: the work will literally surround the audience, who sit in the middle of six 10-foot-tall screens, said Paul Amitai, Eyebeam's program and events coordinator. (Each Mixer event is organized around a theme; tomorrow's is ''place.'') After the video opera, Eyebeam's 8,000-square-foot warehouse space will be transformed into a dance party, with laptop electro by the D.J. Jesse Stiles 3000 and live video mixing by Vade and the 1970s synthesizer pioneer Bill Etra, . It's also an opportunity for the audience to interact with the technology.

After a series of killings and other violence in prison, a federal magistrate approved an agreement yesterday that requires Mississippi officials to improve conditions for 1,000 inmates locked in the super-maximum-security unit of the state penitentiary for 23 hours a day. The agreement, in the form of a consent decree, is the result of a lawsuit filed in 2005 by the American Civil Liberties Union.

SIMKIN--Edward R., 96, of Lenox, MA and Nyack, NY died peacefully December 10th, 2007. Loving and devoted husband of 67 years to Selma Simkin, father of Mark, Linda and Diana Simkin, father-in-law to David Kritchman, grandfather to Ian Salsberg. A dear friend to many. He graduated from Brooklyn College in 1936, then founded Simkin's in Haverstraw in 1944 selling toys and music. He then pursued a career in finance, becoming Vice President at the Dreskin, Advest, and Gruntal companies. He worked as a financial advisor well into his 90s. In ''retirement'', he was a enthusiastic follower of international emerging markets. His keen intelligence, lively sense of humor, love of music and generous heart enriched our lives. He will be deeply missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to charities that filled the world with music and grace.

KRASNER--Leonard. Passed away from heart attack on November 28, 2007 in Reno, NV at age 82. Leonard Krasner received his Ph.D. in psychology from Columbia University. In a career that spanned more than 50 years, he did much to advance the cause of behavioral therapy and was widely regarded as the intellectual founder of behavior modification. He started the first U.S. clinical psychology training program focused on behavior therapy at Stony Brook in the 1960s. In partnership with many other colleagues, he authored major textbooks on clinical psychology from a behavioral perspective. Born in NYC to Helen and Samuel Krasner on December 17th, 1924, he was a beloved husband, father, grandfather, professor, author and friend. Married to Miriam Krasner (who died in 2002) for almost 55 years, they were role models of a loving, lifelong partnership. Leonard's survivors include his four children Wendy , David, Charlie and Stefanie, five grandchildren Robin, Michelle, Zachary, Henry and Harry, and scores of loving friends. A Leonard Krasner Memorial Award has been arranged through the Association for Behavioral and Cognitive Therapies, formerly known as the Association for Advancement of Behavior Therapy. Donations to this award fund should be made out to ABCT and sent to The Leonard Krasner Memorial Award, ABCT, 305 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10001.

KOCZY--Rosemarie Inge 68, of Croton-on-Hudson, NY, internationally renowned artist, succumbed on December 12, 2007 to inflammatory breast cancer. Born March 5, 1939 in Reckling-hausen, Germany to Jewish parents, she was deported in 1942 and survived two concentration camps. In 1959 she left Germany for Geneva to study art at the Ecole des Arts Decoratifs. Graduating with distinction in 1965, she soon gained recognition throughout Europe as a tapestry maker. A chance encounter with Peggy Guggenheim in Venice in 1973 led to an abiding friendship (and the commissioning of a tapestry) and contact with then Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum director Thomas Messer. By the mid-1970's the unexpressed trauma of her early years forced a change of direction in her work toward an open acknowledgment of the Holocaust. By the time Koczy accepted a fellowship to the MacDowell Colony in 1980 at Messer's invitation, she had already begun to create the signature pen and ink drawings memorializing the victims of the Shoah reverenced today throughout the world. In addition to hundreds of paintings, wood sculptures and other works, they alone numbered over 12,000 at the time of her death. Of them she wrote: ''The drawings I make every day are titled 'I Weave You A Shroud.' They are burials to those I saw die in camps.'' Esteemed in both mainstream and outsider art worlds but in the moral dimension apart from both, Koczy's work renowned in the Guggenheim, the Collection de l'Art Brut in Lausanne and Jerusalem's Yad Vashem, to give partial sense of its reach. Rosemarie Koczy's first marriage (which brought her Swiss citizenship) ended in divorce. She wed composer Louis Pelosi in 1984 and became an American citizen in 1989. She is survived by her husband, a sister Gisela and a half-brother Walter, both of Germany. She was interred at Bethel Cemetery, Croton on December 14. Her gravestone will read: ''I weave you a shroud...of love.''

OHLY--Nicholas, 68, of New Haven died suddenly November 12, 2007 in Yale New Haven Hospital. He is the husband of Sara Huntington Ohly. Mr. Ohly was born in Brooklyn, NY November 29, 1938, a son of the late John Hallowell and Elizabeth Congleton Ohly. He worked as an architect at Roche-Dinkeloo & Associates from 1968 until the time of his death. Projects he worked on include the Central Park Zoo, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the NYU Student Center. He was one of three jurors on the Building Committee of the Josef and Anni Albers Foundation and an active founding member of the American Friends of Le Kinkeliba, an organization that supports medical centers and education in rural Senegal. Nick was an accomplished sculptor and photographer who also drew, painted, and designed furniture and lighting fixtures. He loved the woods and mountains of Vermont, his neighborhood of Wooster Square, and his active life of hiking, skiing, skating, kayaking, dancing, traveling, and riding his bicycle. He was passionate about music. He is the father of Derek W. and Jack H. Ohly, brother of Frederick C. Ohly and the late John H. Ohly, and grandfather of Miles G. Ohly. Family and friends may call Friday from 4-7pm at the Iovanne Funeral Home, Inc., 11 Wooster Pl., New Haven, CT and are invited to attend services Saturday morning at 11am in St. Paul and St. James Episcopal Church, 87 Olive St, New Haven, CT. Burial will be private. Contributions can be made to New Haven Urban Design League 129 Church St, Suite 419 New Haven, CT 06510 or The Nick Ohly Kindergarten in Senegal c/o The American Friends of Le Kinkeliba, 88 Beacon Rd, Bethany, CT 06525. Sign Nick's online memorial at www.iovanne.com.

BERLIN--Edwin Paul. May 12, 1930-December 7, 2007. Edwin Paul Berlin, 77, of Rancho Bernardo in San Diego, CA, died peacefully at his home on December 7, 2007 with his loving wife and son by his side. Born in New York City, he received B.S. and MBA degrees from New York University. A resident of Huntington, L.I., New York for over 18 years, he was a selfemployed advertising/copy consultant and humor writer until he retired and moved to California. Prior to that, he was vice president and copy chief at Dunwoodie Associates, and held advertising manager positions at Sperry Rand Semiconductor Div. (now Unisys) and General Instrument Corp. He served with the U.S. Army in Japan during the Korean War. His humorous articles were published by a number of leading magazines and newspapers and many of his Letters-ToThe-Editor were published in the N.Y. Times. Survivors include his wife of 44 years, Faith Frances Berlin; son, Edwin Berlin, Jr. of Oakland, CA; stepson, Michael Harmon of Laurel, MD; and brother, Martin Berlin of Melville, NY. No funeral or memorial services are scheduled. Gifts honoring his memory and his long struggle with metastatic cancer can be sent to Elizabeth Hospice, Escondido, CA.

PAYSON--Benjamin A., M.D., decorated for heroism at Omaha Beach, Normandy, France, on D-Day, Dr. Benjamin A. Payson died on December 15th, 2007 in Boca Raton, FL. His professional career as attending surgeon at Beth Israel Medical Center and Beekman Downtown Hospital in New York City spanned over 40 years. He touched the lives of thousands of patients, doctors and nurses who remember Ben as a compassionate healer, gifted teacher and kind human being. Ben lived every day to its fullest. His passions were his family, his professional life, classical music and golf. He will be forever in the hearts and memories of his loving family: his wife Anita, his late wife Selma, his children Renee Panoff, Arthur Payson and Paula PaysonWolosky, his daughter-in-law Janice, his son-in-law Mark, his late son-in-law Gary, and grandchildren: Jesse, Max, Spencer, Sophie, Samuel and Ross. Services Monday, December 17th, at Frank E. Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue, please call for time, 212-288-3500. Interment will be at Temple Israel Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

OPPENHEIM--David J. Mary Schmidt Campbell and the entire Tisch School of the Arts community deeply mourn the death of David J. Oppenheim -gifted musician, producer, director, writer who was dean of the Tisch School of the Arts from 1969 to 1991. His many professional accomplishments include playing with some of the 20th century's greatest conductors as a former concert clarinetist; the director of the classical music division at Columbia Records; a film and television producer, director, and writer with numerous credits to his name; and serving as the executive producer of cultural programming at the Public Broadcast Laboratory. During his more than two decades as dean, he transformed the School of the Arts from a little known collection of classrooms and offices scattered throughout the Village into an internationally celebrated training ground for the individual artist and scholar of the arts. We shall miss his unique blend of energy, creativity, professionalism, and scholarship. We extend our profound sympathy to his family. Mary Schmidt Campbell, Dean, NYU's Tisch School of the Arts OPPENHEIM--David J. The NYU Community mourns the death of our distinguished and cherished friend David Oppenheim. The Dean of the Tisch School of the Arts for over 20 years, his leadership laid the groundwork that enabled the school to achieve the position of international renown it now enjoys in the cinematic and performing arts. He possessed great personal charm, powerful strategic vision, extraordinary creativity, enormous artistic passion, and an unwavering belief in the promise of the Tisch School. Great Dean, great man, great friend -David Oppenheim's loss will be keenly felt on our campus and in the world of the arts. On behalf of the NYU community, we convey our deepest sympathies to his family and loved ones. Martin Lipton, Chair NYU Board of Trustees John Sexton, President, NYU

FUEL STANDARDS STRUCK DOWN A federal appeals court rejected the Bush administration's year-old fuel economy standards for light trucks and sport utility vehicles. The three-judge panel told the government to produce new rules taking into account the value of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. NEW TRADE BATTLE WITH CHINA The Bush administration is crying foul over a Chinese directive that requires burdensome new safety inspections for foreign-made medical devices -- but not for those made in China. The rule seems part of a recent pattern in which Chinese officials issue new regulations aimed at favoring Chinese industries. [C1.]

The membership and the Board of Governors of the Boca Rio Golf Club, Boca Raton, FL announce with deep regret and sorrow the passing of our dear friend and esteemed member, Anita Newman, and extend our sincerest condolences to her husband William and their family. Robert Merson, President Boca Rio Golf Club, Inc. NEWMAN--Anita (nee Eagle), died in White Plains, New York on November 14, 2007. Beloved wife of William, they would have celebrated their 59th anniversary on December 12th. She is survived by her daughter, Debbie, her son-in-law Dean Bernstein and her grandchildren Samantha, Matthew and Lauren. Two other children, Steven and Sharon predeceased her. She is also survived by her brothers Robert (Marilyn) Eagle and Sidney (Anita) Eagle. Anita was a beautiful woman who filled her life with beauty. She was an avid collector of all kinds of antiques and art-from Fiestaware to oil paintings. She was a life-long fan of Frank Sinatra from the time she was a teenager waiting outside the Paramount Theatre in order to catch a glimpse of him. Anita was an enthusiastic golfer and enjoyed her days with her friends at Boca Rio Golf Club in Florida and Brae Burn in Purchase, New York, playing mah-jong and canasta and going out to wonderful dinners. She loved to travel, and together with Bill, they visited Europe, The Far East, Africa and Russia. They were among the first American tourists to visit China in 1978. Anita participated with her husband in major philanthropic endeavors. Foremost among them were the United Jewish Appeal and Baruch College, whose main campus building and library bear their names. Anita will be sorely missed by her family and friends. Funeral services will be held at 10am on Friday, November 16, at Temple B'nai Israel in Armonk, NY. The family will be sitting Shiva at the home of Debra and Dean Bernstein following services on Friday and Saturday 12-8pm.

The sentences -- but not the issue of guilt -- sending three men to prison for the 2004 theft of the Edvard Munch masterwork ''The Scream'' will be reconsidered by the Supreme Court of Norway, Agence France-Press reported. The hearing was sought by the defense and the prosecution after an appeals court in April imposed prison terms of five and a half to nine and a half years. The men were also ordered to pay a total of $287,000 in fines to the city of Oslo, site of the Munch Museum, where the daylight armed theft of ''The Scream'' and another Munch work, ''Madonna,'' took place. Svein Tore Andersen, a spokesman for the Supreme Court, said it would consider only their sentences. No date for the hearing was set. The stolen paintings were recovered in August 2006.

His many close friends and family know we will not see his like again, and we will all miss him profoundly, and cherish his memory. Memorial Service to be held at St. Bartholomew's Church, 50th Street and Park Avenue, on Tuesday, January 15th, at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, F/ B/O Colorectal Cancer Research, in memory of C. Sims Farr.

HARRIS--George De Lancey, of New York, NY, and Port Royal, Nova Scotia, died in New York at age 83 on December 7, 2007. He is survived by his wife of 49 years, Joanna Cochrane Harris, their son, James Harris, and his brother, Thomas L. Harris. Del (as he was widely known) Harris was born in New York City and grew up in Scarsdale and Nova Scotia. He and Mrs. Harris lived in Port Royal, Nova Scotia, five months of the year in a home he decorated and cherished. A veteran of WWII, Del, with his brother Thomas, owned D. P. Harris Hardware and Manufacturing Company. The company, founded by his grandfather, produced Rollfast bicycles. He traveled internationally for many years representing his company. Del, much loved by everyone who knew him, possessed a generous and loving spirit. Predeceased by his daughter, Charlotte, he will be interred, like her, in the Harris family plot in the Annapolis Royal Cemetery, Nova Scotia. A memorial gathering will be held on December 16th.

When it comes to scoring tickets for hot concerts, nothing is too much. Just ask Jody Powell and Kenneth Donnell. Mr. Powell, 35, hung onto a 12-foot statue of Hannah Montana for the better part of six days to win four tickets to a sold-out concert by Miley Cyrus, star of the Disney Channel show ''Hannah Montana,'' The Associated Press reported. ''I'm ecstatic,'' he said. ''It's like a dream come true.'' He was one of 20 contestants who began the competition on Nov. 8 by placing a hand on the 400-pound statue on the parking lot of the radio station WFLZ-FM in Tampa, Fla., where the concert will be held next week. Participants, who were furnished with catered meals, got 12-minute breaks every three hours. Mr. Donnell, of Glasgow, paid $170,000 for a pair of tickets to see Led Zeppelin rehearse and perform at a reunion concert on Dec. 10 in London, the BBC reported. The tickets were sold as part of an auction for the charity Children in Need.

'THREE GENERATIONS OF JAZZ TRUMPET' Jazz lore and custom have largely pegged the trumpet as a young man's instrument. There is powerful precedent, from Buddy Bolden onward, for the earnest or brazen prodigy who blazes onto the scene. But however punishing the physical demands of the trumpet (or in the case of Bolden and others, the cornet), it also clearly rewards experience. For every bold arrival, it seems, there's a well-traveled elder with lessons to impart. ''Three Generations of Jazz Trumpet,'' one of several concerts organized at Symphony Space by the former Dizzy Gillespie protégé Jon Faddis, advances this guildlike notion. (It doesn't do anything to show that women are strong stewards of the horn; that point demands its own concert.) Naturally, the evening's anchor is Mr. Faddis, a smarter trumpeter at 55 then he was at 25, if not a more dazzling one. His latest release, ''Teranga'' (Koch), showcases his composure with the same rhythm section that supports him here: David Hazeltine on piano, Kiyoshi Kitagawa on bass and Dion Parson on drums.
MASSIMO--Gene, died peacefully December 2, 2007 at his home. He is survived by his mother Ida, sister Terry DeMartini and partner Bob Tessmer.

After turning up late and stumbling about the stage of the National Indoor Arena in Birmingham, England, the trouble-prone British soul singer Amy Winehouse, 24, left, listened to boos, heard jeers and saw members of the audience walking out on Wednesday night, Agence France-Presse reported. ''Let me tell you something,'' she said as she began a 17-date British tour. ''First of all, if you're booing, you're a mug for buying a ticket. Second, to all those booing, just wait till my husband gets out of incarceration -- and I mean that.'' The reference was to her spouse, Blake Fielder-Civil, who is being held in Pentonville Prison in London, accused of perverting justice and assaulting the landlord of a pub. The concert's closing number, ''Valerie,'' ended when Ms. Winehouse stopping singing, dropped the microphone and walked off the stage. Andy Coleman, the music critic of The Birmingham Mail, said the concert was ''one of the saddest nights of my life.'' ''I saw a supremely talented artist reduced to tears,'' he continued, ''stumbling around the stage and, unforgivably, swearing at the audience.''

SIDEL--Nancy Jarmon, born December 6, 1939 in New York City. Survived by her loving sons John and Henry, their wives Eva-Lotta Hedman and Beth Levison, and her adoring grandchildren, Matilda, Ben and Gabe. Also survived by her dear companion of many years Patrick McCormick. She amazed her family, friends and doctors with her resilience, optimism and determination in the face of cancer. Ultimately she passed in peace. Her professional life included teaching English literature at the Lycee Francais, heading up the Bank of New York's new business for private banking and serving as Director of Development at the Hudson River Museum. She was passionate about reading, classical music, travel, swimming, walking, her family and her bridge game. Even throughout her illness she played consistently and became a Lifetime Silver Grandmaster. Her energy and spark will be missed forever. Memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell at 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., 3:30pm on Sunday, December 16th. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in memory of Nancy J. Sidel to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center at P.O. Box 27106, NY, NY 10087-7106 or the New York Society Library at 53 East 79th St., NY, NY 10021

WANG--Kenneth, died peacefully in his home, in Cove Neck, on December 14th, surrounded by his family. He was born in China in 1914. He was the beloved husband of Mary, and cherished father of Anthony, Charles and Francis and their wives, Lulu, Nancy and Laura. He was much beloved by his seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He was also the much loved brother of Hsiang-Ming Hsia. He graduated from Soochow University School of Law in 1938. He practiced law in Shanghai until 1945 when he was recruited to be a judge of the Court of Appeals for Shanghai. In 1947 he was awarded a fellowship by Harvard University School of Law where he earned an LLM degree. He returned to China in 1948 to resume his law practice and to teach at Soochow University Law School. In 1949 he became President of Aurora College for Women. In 1952 Professor Wang and his family moved to the U.S. and he joined the faculty of St. John's University School of Law in New York City. He was invited to serve as Visiting Professor of Law at Michigan University Law School in 1963. In 1964 he was invited by President Lyndon B. Johnson to participate in the White House Conference on International Law and International Cooperation. In addition to his professorship at St. John's, he was also on the panel of Arbitrators of The American Arbitration Association. By the time he retired as Professor of Law at St. John's in 1984, he had taught and inspired generations of young lawyers and future leaders in business and government. After his retirement from St. John's, Professor Wang became the senior partner of Wang and Wang in Taipei, a law firm specializing in transnational law. St. John's honored him in 1984 with the President's Medal, in 1987 with an honorary Doctor of Laws degree, and in 1992 with the Medal of Honor. In 2003, Soochow University honored him with the naming of the Kenneth Wang School of Law. He will always be honored in the hearts of his family, friends and students. Services were private. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be sent to St. John's University School of Law, in support of the Kenneth Wang International Fellowship, at 8000 Utopia Parkway, Queens, NY 11439.

'THE THREE SILLIES' Along with acne, voice changes and growth spurts, intense embarrassment over your parents is an undeniable symptom of puberty. Usually poor Mom and Dad don't have to be guilty of more than existing, but Sammy, heroine of ''The Three Sillies'' at the Looking Glass Theater, finds her family's behavior especially cringe-inducing. Her father, with his bird calls and tickle attacks, makes you think of Robin Williams on amphetamines; her mother, whose voice is as loud as her outfits, is his perfect mate. And Sammy's younger sister, Sally, shows no signs of outgrowing her own silliness. Directed and written by Aliza Shane, ''The Three Sillies'' unfolds on Sammy's birthday, when she finds herself seriously in need of seriousness. After discovering that her old talking teddy bear (Mark DeFrancis, above right) is capable of original speech, Sammy (Ayelet Blumberg, center) is surprised that he agrees to run away with her. But he does make her promise that she will return home if they can find three bigger sillies than her folks.

O. J. Simpson, below, still dealing with the legal fallout from murder charges and charges that he took part in an armed robbery, has been accused of plagiarism. In a lawsuit filed in federal court in Los Angeles, Amir Pourtemour contends that his book was plagiarized by Mr. Simpson in the writing of ''If I Did It: Confessions of the Killer,'' a hypothetical account of how he would have killed his ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ron Goldman, Bloomberg News reported. Mr. Pourtemour's suit says large parts of his 1995 book, ''The Perfect Alibi: O. J. Simpson's Strategy for Murder,'' were copied. Yale Galanter, a lawyer for Mr. Simpson, could not be reached for immediate comment.

It's all about a struggling Japanese artist and the mysterious cat that seems to change his fortunes. At noon, 55 Mercer Street, SoHo, (212) 352-3101, cultureproject.org; $20.

In the wake of the news that Oregon quarterback Dennis Dixon will miss the rest of the season with an injured left knee, John Hunt of the Oregonian reports that Dixon actually tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his knee against Arizona State two weeks ago. After discussing the situation with his family and the Ducks coaching staff, he decided to continue to play despite the injury.

There's a very good Economic Letter from the Dallas Fed about the housing crisis, which explains a lot about how the mess happened. In short: lenders began making lots of dubious loans in large part because they were able to slice and dice the loans and sell them off to investors who didn't know what they were buying. My only fault with the letter is that it doesn't emphasize the extent to which borrowers were also suckered in.

Eugene Perelshteyn, a grandmaster from Massachusetts, won the Spice Cup, a tournament at Texas Tech University in Lubbock, Tex. He led from start to finish, scoring 6.5 out of 9. Gilberto Hernandez, a grandmaster from Mexico, finished second, a half point back. The games from the tournament can be replayed at Monroi.com. The tournament, which was a memorial to Samuel Reshevsky, the Polish-born American grandmaster, was organized by Susan Polgar, chairwoman of the United States Chess Federation, and Paul Truong, Polgar's husband.

Jenny Wolf of Germany beat her own world record yesterday in winning the women’s 500 meters at a World Cup race in Calgary, Alberta. Wolf’s time of 37.02 seconds lowered the 37.04 she skated March 10 in Salt Lake City. Her 10.13 for the first 100 meters was also a record. Jeremy Wotherspoon of Canada won the men’s 500.
