Billy Gillispie has still not signed a formal contract, more than seven months after agreeing to become Kentucky’s men’s coach.Gillispie is employed under a two-page memorandum of understanding, which details his compensation package, Athletic Director Mitch Barnhart said yesterday. Barnhart did not say what had delayed negotiations. Gillispie, who has a seven-year agreement that pays him $2.3 million a year in base salary, does not have an agent and has declined to discuss the matter during preseason news conferences.

The America’s Cup champion Alinghi rejected an offer to settle a lawsuit brought by an American syndicate, and asked its rival to drop legal proceedings.The United States syndicate, Golden Gate Yacht Club, home of BMW Oracle Racing, made a last-ditch offer yesterday for a joint settlement. BMW Oracle Racing was contending that Desafio Español’s status as official challenger, which allowed it to negotiate the format of the next America’s Cup, was illegal.BMW Oracle wanted the right to replace Desafio Español and draw up new rules for the next regatta with Alinghi. But Alinghi’s club, Société Nautique de Genève, rejected the move shortly after it was presented.Golden Gate said that the offer was endorsed by fellow challengers Emirates Team New Zealand, Team Origin and Team Shosholoza.

Jimmie Johnson, the reigning Nextel Cup champion and the current points leader, won his fourth pole of the season and the 13th of his career yesterday at Homestead-Miami Speedway. Johnson holds an 86-point lead over his Hendrick Motorsports teammate Jeff Gordon heading into the season-ending Ford 400 tomorrow. Johnson qualified at 176.788 miles an hour on the 1.5-mile oval, ahead of Ryan Newman (176.569) and Kasey Kahne (176.350).The pole virtually assured Johnson of earning the 5-point bonus for leading at least one race lap tomorrow. If he does lead a lap, Johnson needs to finish only 19th or better to win the Chase title, regardless of what Gordon does. Gordon will be starting 11th. Even without leading a lap, Johnson can wrap up his second championship by finishing 18th or better.

An article in some editions on Nov. 1 about the death of Linda S. Stein, a Manhattan real estate agent and a pioneer of the punk music scene during her marriage to Seymour Stein, the founder of Sire Records, attributed an erroneous distinction to him. Although several publications say Mr. Stein was the creator of the Billboard Top 100 music charts, now known as the Hot 100, they were in fact created by Tom Noonan, Mr. Stein’s boss at the time. The caption for a picture in some editions showing Ms. Stein and some of her music industry associates in 1979 misstated the surname of the wife of the musician Dee Dee Ramone. She is Vera Ramone, not March.

LIEBOWITZ--Elsie, on November 14, 2007, age 99 (and a half). Loving wife of the late Judge Simon J. Liebowitz. Beloved mother of Gloria Herman, Burt Liebowitz and the late Sonia Brodsky. Cherished and popular grandmother of Steven, Esther, Ruth, Judith, Suzanne, Ellen, Eileen, the late Mindy and 11 great-grandchildren. Her personality and lifestyle set an example for family and friends. Services Sunday 11:30am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

DEVERIN--Daniele, died in New York on Friday, November 9, 2007, of congestive heart failure, aged 84 years. A longtime resident of New York and avid weekend gardener in Brookfield, CT, she was born in Saint Romain de Colbosc, France, and studied medicine at the University of Paris. Following her emigration to the U.S. after WWII, she worked for many years in Manhattan, primarily as an agent for commercial illustrators. She is survived by her son, Christopher Smeall, her daughter-in-law, Ann Fabian, and her two grandchildren, Andrew Smeall and Isabelle Smeall, of New York and Salisbury, CT; her sisters Michele Pellot of Paris, Claude Goodrich of Pacific Palisades, CA, and Magdeleine Flach of Chambery, France; her brother-in-law Daniel Flach of Chambery; numerous nieces, nephews and cousins; and many friends. She will be remembered by them all for her intelligence, independent spirit and love of life.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about sleep bruxism, or teeth grinding, misstated its prevalence. Although sleep bruxism is a common sleep disorder, it is not the third most common one behind sleep-talking and snoring. In a 2001 study, those were the top three parasomnias, one class of sleep disorders.

An exhibition review in Weekend on Nov. 2 about ''Water: H20=Life,'' at the American Museum of Natural History, misstated the number of gallons of water used daily per capita in Britain and Ethiopia, according to a display in the exhibition. It is 31 in Britain and 3 in Ethiopia, not 118 and 10. (Those are the numbers of liters used daily per capita in those countries, according to the display, which rounds off the figures when they are converted to gallons.)

FIRESTONE--Nathaniel, 81, of Fort Lee, NJ, on November 16, 2007. He is survived by his wife of fifty-six years, Marina, daughter Louise, son John, their spouses Joseph Pizzurro and Sandra Miller, and grandchildren Katie, Claire, Andrew and Gregory. Known as ''Nat'' to colleagues, ''Nuti'' to friends and family, ''Nonno'' to his grandchildren, he was born in Czernowitz, Romania, escaped to Italy in 1945 and graduated from the University of Torino and Yale School of Architecture. He worked as an architect in New York and Houston and supervised Peace Corps volunteers in Tunisia from 1964-1966. He was proud of his professional and volunteer work for the University of Texas Health Science Center and his 35year-long loving restoration of the family cottage, ''The Ark.'' A memorial service is being planned. In lieu of flowers, please consider a gift to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center, Holy Name Hospice, Teaneck, NJ, or the charity of your choice.

YU--Harvey (Hsing Min). Born Beijing, China on March 26, 1918, died October 28, 2007 in Gwynedd, PA. Survived by his devoted wife Margaret of 56 years, brother Yu Xingzhi of Shanghai and Second and Fourth Sisters Yu Junmin and Yu Xiaomin of Beijing, China. Predeceased by Elder Sister and artist Yu Feng, and Third Sister Yu Yimin, both of Beijing. Beloved father of Lesley, Lloyd and Warren and adored grandfather of eight grandchildren. Graduate of Beijing's Qing Hua University 1939, University of Michigan 1941 and Harvard Business School 1949. Captain US Marine Corps, stationed Tianjin, China 1945-1947. Employed by IBM Corp. 1960-1990 in East Fishkill, NY. Contributions in his name may be made to the Poughkeepsie Public Library District, 93 Market St., Poughkeepsie NY 12601 or to the American Red Cross of Dutchess County, 103 Hooker Ave., Poughkeepsie NY 12601.

cisco increases buyback Cisco Systems, the world's biggest maker of networking equipment, increased its stock buyback by as much as $10 billion after a disappointing sales forecast this month. The amount would allow Cisco to repurchase about 6 percent of its shares outstanding, based on yesterday's closing price. Cisco stock has slumped 8.6 percent since Nov. 7, the day its chief executive, John Chambers, above, said declining orders from automobile and financial companies are curbing growth.(BLOOMBERG NEWS) ANNTAYLOR REDUCES INVENTORY AnnTaylor Stores, the clothing retailer, said third-quarter profit exceeded analysts' estimates as the company reduced inventory to counter slowing sales. Net income rose 3.8 percent to $40.8 million, or 66 cents a share, beating analysts' estimates by 5 cents. The retailer reduced its full-year forecast by 10 cents to as much as $2.15 a share, exceeding the $2.09 average estimate of analysts. AnnTaylor climbed $1.08, to $32.47. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

(HBO) PU-239 (2006) A devoted family man (Paddy Considine) working in a deteriorating Russian nuclear plant is exposed to a lethal dose of radiation while trying to prevent a disaster, after which he is turned into a scapegoat and suspended without pay. Desperate to provide for his wife (Radha Mitchell, above with Mr. Considine) and son before his death, he steals a small amount of weapons-grade plutonium, Pu-239, and heads to Moscow, where he turns to a would-be gangster (Oscar Isaac) in a bid to sell it on the black market -- and unwittingly puts the world in jeopardy. Scott Z. Burns wrote and directed this cautionary tale, based on the short story by Ken Kalfus. Steven Soderberg, George Clooney and Peter Berg are among the executive producers. 8 P.M. (Food Network) EMERIL'S ULTIMATE THANKSGIVING Emeril Lagasse concocts a feast of herb-roasted turkey with a chestnut and sage stuffing, twice-baked potatoes and cranberry and orange sauce, as well as sweet potato and pecan pie.

RUBINSTEIN--Jack, 90, of Roslyn and Boca Raton, died November 13, 2007. Beloved husband of Norma (Rubin) and the late Betty. Loving father of Helen and Michael (Audrey). Dear stepfather of Ronni Rubin Bolger and Alisse Rothenberg (Eric). Devoted grandfather of Rachel, Betsy and Mark. Caring stepgrandfather of Adam Rothenberg, Jaclyn Greenberg (Leo) and Elizabeth Bolger. Survived by brother Irving. Founder of Academy -Broadway Corp. A man of untold generosity in the world of charity and philanthropic endeavors. He leaves a rich legacy of love and devotion to his family and many friends. We will cherish his memory always. Services will be held on Sunday, November 18, 11am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck (opposite LIRR Station). Donations in his memory may be made to The Anti-Defamation League or the charity of your choice.

Twenty-five years ago I was on the staff of the Council of Economic Advisers (yes, it was the Reagan administration -- but I had a technocratic, non-political position, and was one of a number of Democrats working there, including a guy by the name of Larry Summers). And one of my jobs was to go to international meetings, where I helped draw up communiques. These communiques were, by design, bland and uninformative -- because consensus, not insight, was the goal, so anything controversial was fuzzed over.

Since so many of you have commented about the first-woman-candidate thing, let me suggest a subject that's obviously trivial, but one I've always found interesting. When Hillary Clinton first ran for the U.S. Senate in New York, she wore the same thing virtually every day--a black pantsuit and a pink blouse. She was doing exactly what men do, which is to adopt a kind of uniform.

What has long been reported and speculated became official Sunday, as Baylor announced that it was firing Coach Guy Morriss. This is somewhat old news at it had been leaked out weeks ago, but it will be interesting to see who takes over this most difficult of jobs.

Almost eleven years ago, I stood in the orphanage in Hoa Binh, Vietnam, waiting to meet my adoptive parents for the first time. I was just six years old. This past spring, we journeyed back to Vietnam for my first visit since my adoption. We visited my orphanage and many other wonderful places in Vietnam. My visit to the orphanage triggered so many memories of my time there and of that first meeting with my new parents. The poem I wrote reflects some of those memories and instances. There were so many but that first meeting was what stood out most in my remembrances. Time changes many things but our memories somehow survive. I look back now and don't have any regrets or fears about changing my life. This experience has enabled me to revisit the past with a new outlook.

For Suphala, home is where the rhythm is. "Once I'm onstage, I feel complete," says this New York-based tabla player, who was the first female musician to perform in post-Taliban Kabul. A Minneapolis native, she studied tabla - a traditional North Indian drum - with the master Alla Rakha and has collaborated with the hip-hop producer Timbaland. She takes her blend of electronic and classical Indian music everywhere, from Brooklyn (where she recorded her most recent album, "Blueprint") to a royal palace in Jodhpur, India ("the acoustics are amazing"), but Suphala finds some of her most attentive audiences at the airport. "It's a given that my tabla gets lots of looks at security," she says. "The case does look like something out of 'Star Wars."'

A 21-year-old woman died yesterday after her horse stumbled during a cross-country jumping event and crushed her. Eleanor Brennan, of Esmont, Va., was competing in the 2007 Horse Trials in Ocala, Fla., and was riding an 11-year-old male named Mister Barnabus. The horse struck a gate during the event, tumbled onto his neck and landed on Brennan, a statement from the Marion County Sheriff’s Office said.

The police are investigating an incident at Homestead-Miami Speedway involving the Nascar driver Kasey Kahne and a security guard. A spokesman for Kahne said he was rushing to his motor home when he was stopped by the guard, who refused to let him through an entrance to a secure lot without a credential. Kahne, still in his driving uniform, tried to walk past the guard and, according to the spokesman, the two bumped. When Kahne turned around, the guard was on the ground. The police were called and Kahne spent several minutes in handcuffs before being released.

Marleen Veldhuis of the Netherlands and Stefan Nystrand of Sweden broke world records at the short course Arena World Cup in Berlin. Veldhuis clocked 23.58 seconds to lower the women’s 50-meter freestyle record by 0.01. Nystrand finished in 45.83 in the men’s 100 freestyle to break the 46.25 mark.

The former European 1,500-meter champion Sureyya Ayhan has tested positive for doping and faces a lifetime ban. Ayhan was suspended for two years for breaking drug-testing rules in 2004.

An article last Sunday about county animal shelters being inundated with pregnant cats and kittens misstated the role of Dr. Michael Woltz at the Central Animal Hospital in Scarsdale. He is the owner, not the co-owner.

Because of an editing error, the National Perspectives article last Sunday about developers learning to build environmentally friendly houses and condominiums referred imprecisely to the development of the Withers Preserve, a housing project in Myrtle Beach, S.C. The developers are building around the wetlands, not “on” them.

The “In the Region” article in New Jersey copies last Sunday about foreign and out-of-state buyers and renters seeking pieds-à-terre near the Hudson River in New Jersey misstated the name of a Midtown Manhattan brokerage firm active in the area. It is Marketing Directors, not Market Directors.

The “In the Region” article in some copies last Sunday about “virtual villages,” in which older people stay in their own homes with help from a grass-roots support network, included an incorrect time frame provided by Staying Put, a virtual village in New Canaan, for its goal to recruit 150 household memberships. The group aims to achieve this total by the end of 2008, not the end of this year.

The Streetscapes column on Oct. 21, about the first B. Altman department store, at 19th Street and Sixth Avenue, misstated the given name of the founder of Greenhut & Company, which opened at the site after Altman moved. He was Joseph B. Greenhut, not Jacob.

At last someone in the north is hammering out details of what Venezuelan bloggers have been saying for a long time — that under Hugo Chávez, what was once one of the best-managed oil industries in the world is heading for disaster. What Tina Rosenberg (Nov. 4) doesn’t address is the fact that Chávez probably knows this. Which may be why his forceful governance and love song to the poor are being rushed into place. There is little reliable data on the extent of his misiones for the poor (financed by oil revenue). But while filming for two weeks in October, for HDNet World Report in Maracaibo, Caracas and at a massive cult gathering of 10,000 spiritualists outside Barquisimeto (celebrating Chávez’s Day of Indigenous Resistance, formerly Columbus Day), I talked to people from all over Venezuela. All reported that misiones are visibly active in their town, city, state.

I occasionally read that I was involved in Flew’s “conversion,” through the 2004 New York discussions Oppenheimer describes. Hitherto I have not discussed this matter, but I now wish to counter any impression that I am part of a group that has been in ongoing contact with Flew, pressing him to embrace theism on the strength of claims about contemporary science.

So John Bolton thinks that “serious people” don’t believe we can reduce carbon emissions enough to have an impact on global climate change (Deborah Solomon, Nov. 4). It’s a good thing there are plenty of less serious people working to mitigate the climate crisis and trying to elect leaders who don’t invade countries on faulty intelligence!.
What do the uninsured in America do when they need health care? Some turn to a volunteer medical group that was set up to provide free services in third world countries.

Those who feel safer with Hillary Clinton’s old-school “big stick” diplomacy than with the kind of intelligent use of “soft power” that Barack Obama endorses are living in the past. Our experiences in Vietnam and Iraq have established that use of force does not necessarily lead to beneficial results. What a President Obama would offer is a new avenue to power and respect, not through military might, but through cooperation and understanding. There is no strength more powerful than countries and peoples working together for the common good; and in the face of the dire threats we all share — from global warming to desperate acts born of social inequity — such cooperation can occur none too soon.

Is my co-author Tony Flew “all there” mentally? The only reason that people ask questions about his mental faculties is that he dared to change his mind. He believes in God and therefore he has dementia, or he has dementia and therefore he believes in God. But let’s not forget that his new view of the world is one embraced by many of today’s leading philosophers in the Anglo-American world as well as by pioneers of modern science. This is the dirty little secret that the “new atheists” and their drum-beaters never talk about. It’s so much easier to shoot the messenger!.

trophy / (tro fe) / adj. / prized for prestige-enhancing qualities. In the world of travel, applied to places, experiences and things that are sought after because they are little known or inaccessible to hoi polloi, as in, “Everyone who’s anyone will be in Miami for Art Basel — the art-show circuit is the new trophy trip,” or, “Southern Cambodia is so great, I’m sure it’s going to be the next trophy beach destination.”.
It’s no longer business as usual in Xalapa, where the university has nurtured a cultural scene so robust that some residential blocks have more than half a dozen artists living on them.
Pied-à-terre are the new hotels. Houseboats are the new Airstreams. Ice fishing is the new snowshoeing. Toronto is the new L.A. Australia is the new South Africa.
David Linley wouldn’t dream of cocktails without his vintage aluminium siphon.

Salvador's musicians are creating a Bahian music explosion. Singers like these three play every night in clubs, halls and parks all over town. Carlinhos Brown: One of Brazil's top percussionists and the founder of the band Timbalada.

TAYLOR--Richard J. A member of the New York Bar and former counsel at Colgate-Palmolive, Dick Taylor was an adventurer and world traveler. After graduating from the University of Wisconsin and the University of Michigan Law School, he spent his early career in France as an assistant professor at the Law School of the University of Paris (Pantheon-Sorbonne). He coauthored two books, Doing Business in France and Worldwide Trademark Transfers. Richard Taylor represented the American Bar Association in various capacities: as a delegate to a World Trademark Forum, as a past chairman of the ABA's International Committee in the International Trademark Association, and as a delegate to the Committee of Experts and the Standing Committee of the International Trademark Law Treaty. He was also a consultant to the World Intellectual Property Organization. Richard Taylor founded (and wrote the course book for) American Law & Language Worldwide Seminars. He was pro bono counsel to the music industry's Hearts & Voices, which benefits AIDS victims, and was a volunteer counsel for Lawyers without Borders. Born in Merrill, WI on January 19, 1939, Dick Taylor died on October 17 in Manhattan, where he lived with his wife of more than 40 years, Nancy Hildebrand Taylor. He was preceded in death by his parents, Billie Mead Taylor and Melvin N. ''Mully'' Taylor, who founded the pioneering environmental education center Trees for Tomorrow. Richard J.Taylor also leaves two older brothers, Robert M. Taylor of Washington state and Dennis M. Taylor of Ohio, along with numerous nephews, nieces, cousins and friends across the country and around the world. Memorial donations can be made to Trees for Tomorrow, P.O. Box 609 Eagle River, WI 54521.
Baby Steps to Prevent a Child's Death

To the Editor: The article ''Too Much Information? Ignore It,'' by Alex Williams (Nov. 11), reminded me of the Breatharian Wiley Brooks, who claimed to live on air alone. He was featured on a number of late-night TV shows. Then one day he was discovered coming out of a fast-food restaurant. When confronted, he said, ''This isn't food, this is poison.'' Methinks that Tim Ferriss, proponent of the four-hour workweek, is another Wiley Brooks.
Soaking Stony Brook Parkers

BUCHWALD--Beulah, 81, on November 16th, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Julius Buchwald, M.D. Cherished mother of Janet, Lynne, Deborah, Gail and Emily. Adored by grandchildren Julia, Saul, Isaac, Esti, Cecilia, Sandra and Sophia. She was a community activist, avid traveler, theater goer and folk dancer. She was a dedicated docent at the Eldridge Street Synagogue. After the death of her husband, she earned a Masters degree and pursued a career in Special Education. She was a cherished friend, advisor and confidant to many. Her vibrance and adventurous nature will inspire us always. She instilled in us a life-long passion for nature, animals, the arts and philanthropy. We love her and we will miss her each and every day. Funeral at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. Burial at New Montefiore Cemetery.

IF TOO MUCH EATING, drinking and merrymaking leave you feeling a bit tighter than you had intended, take cover in Iisli's forgiving blue-black wool-gabardine blazer. A clever alternative to the season's favorite boyfriend sweater, this jacket looks as if you filched your favorite guy's navy suit coat and magically shrunk the shoulders for a perfect fit. With crisp tailoring, a two-button closure and a cut that elongates arms while flattering the torso, this lean-looking number can accompany skinny jeans and leggings but also provide a witty counterpoint to a frothy cocktail dress, super-mini tunic or a panoply of sequins. $438 at Saks Fifth Avenue stores.

For Suphala, home is where the rhythm is. ''Once I'm onstage, I feel complete,'' says this New York-based tabla player, who was the first female musician to perform in post-Taliban Kabul. A Minneapolis native, she studied tabla -- a traditional North Indian drum -- with the master Alla Rakha and has collaborated with the hip-hop producer Timbaland. She takes her blend of electronic and classical Indian music everywhere, from Brooklyn (where she recorded her most recent album, ''Blueprint'') to a royal palace in Jodhpur, India (''the acoustics are amazing''), but Suphala finds some of her most attentive audiences at the airport. ''It's a given that my tabla gets lots of looks at security,'' she says. ''The case does look like something out of 'Star Wars.'''
Port Chester, Nov. 11.

FINK--Sheila. Darling cousin, best friend and (sister) I will miss you, your spirit, intellect, warmth, courage and bravery. You cannot be replaced in my heart and in the hearts of my family. You will be with us forever. Heaven will be an even better place because you are there. Barbara Nelkin & Family FINK--Sheila/d, died November 15, 2007, resident of Palm Beach, Florida and Chicago, Illinois. Beloved daughter of Albert and Lillian Gold, devoted wife of Dr. Victor Fink, precious mother of Doctors Nancy Levine and Jeffrey Levine and Dr. Robert Fink. Sister of the late Richard Gold. Sheila died after a long courageous battle with cancer. She leaves a rich legacy of love and devotion to her family, friends, and everyone who had the good fortune to know her. Her memory will be cherished, and love for her will never diminish. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

Stone, Executive Vice President Jewish Federation of Central New Jersey

The young British composer THOMAS ADÈS has won renown for a growing list of audacious works that teem with brash energy and wondrous colorings. An accomplished all-around musician, Mr. Adès is also an excellent conductor and fine pianist. His pianistic skills will be tested in an intriguing program he plays at Zankel Hall on Monday night, with works by Janacek, Nancarrow, Stravinsky, Castiglioni and, naturally, Adès. 7:30 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $28 to $42.
TRACT--Harold M. Passed away November 18, 1991. Beloved husband and father. He was a truly noble man. The Tract Family

THE MOTHER-TO-BE The indie-movie actress Lili Taylor has a new production under way: she is expecting her first baby, a girl, in January. Dressing for her growing girth has required resourcefulness and creativity, said Ms. Taylor, 40, who stars with Frank Langella and Lauren Ambrose in the film ''Starting Out in the Evening,'' in limited release starting Friday. ''Maternity is still a market that needs to be tapped,'' she said. ''I thought there'd be more out there. Instead, I've been wearing drawstring pants in larger sizes, going up into the 30s. Lucky Brand has turned out to be really good. They make a great jean called the Lil' Maggie.'' Ms. Taylor has discovered a few gems designed for pregnancy, too. Here, she wears a Cadeau maternity jacket with Habitual maternity jeans. Her shoes are by Christian Louboutin. ''What's nice about the jacket is that it's casual but it also pops, so you can go somewhere in the evening,'' she said. ''I've also been wearing short skirts and some little dresses. Anything bigger, and I feel like I'm being swallowed.''
East 102nd Street, Nov. 15.

To the Editor: Re '' 'Rite of Spring' as Rite of Passage'' by Christopher Atamian [Nov. 11]:

HOWES--Alfred Spencer, 90, of Scarsdale, NY, died on November 8, 2007. He was born in Troy, NY, September 10, 1917 to Alfred George and Frances Youngs Howes. Orphaned in his early teens, he came under the auspices of his Aunt Betty Howes, a nurse at Putnam Memorial Hospital in Bennington, Vermont, who guided him to his superior work ethic, and introduced him to his future wife. He attended Brown University, the University of Alabama and Syracuse University. On October 10, 1942 he married Elizabeth (Betty) Hoffner. At the time of her death last year, they had been married for 63 glorious years. He served in the US Army in World War II in the European Theater of Operation from 1943-1946. He was the Purchasing Agent for Neutral Nations. As a business and insurance consultant, he began his first business, Employee Incentive Plans of America in 1946. Over the course of his career he worked with Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Co., and contributed to the Active New York State Temporary Commission on Banking, Insurance, and Financial Services. He was an active member of the National Association of Life Insurance Underwriters, serving as past President of the New York Chapter. He was also past President for the New York State Association Life Underwriters, NYC Association Life Underwriters, and Association for Advanced Life Underwriting and qualified to be a member of the Million Dollar Roundtable every year since 1950 until his retirement in 2003. His career helped him become an influential member of many estate planning councils and state committees relating to taxes and other financial areas. During his career, he was on the Boards of Directors of 26 companies. He belonged to: Collectors in New York City; Brown Club in New York City and the Princeton Club in New York City; University Club in Albany and The Fort Orange Club in Albany; the Fort Schuyler Club in Utica. Other than his work, his passion was stamp collecting, a hobby he pursued for more than 75 years. He also enjoyed gardening, nature walks, playing Bridge, and being with his family. He was preceded in death by his wife, his brother Edward, and close cousin Jesse. He is survived by his daughters Wendy of Mechanicsburg, PA, Mary of Port Orchard, WA, and Constance Atwood of Port Townsend, WA; his grandchildren Robert Decker, Jr. of Everett, WA, James Decker of Winter Park, FL, and Haley Fraser of NYC; and numerous nieces and nephews. Funeral services are incomplete at this time. Memorials may be made to the Alzheimier's Association.

ESCAPE Ilha do Goió (1), a tiny island in the Baía de Camamú just north of Itacaré (itself an hour and a half from either Salvador or Trancoso), is little more than deserted white sand lapped by turquoise water. Get there by boat -- the tour company Órbita can take you (www.orbitaexpedicoes.com.br) -- and play castaway for a day. On the next-door Ilha do Sapinho is Bom Jesus da Lapa's restaurant (011-55-73-9996-1388), where you can eat crawfish caught to order from the end of the pier.

SCHEINFELD--David, 76, of New York City, died November 16, 2007. Beloved husband of Ellen (Rothstein) for 46 years. Loving father of Noah (Jackie), Moshe (Rivka) and Josh (Lizzy). Cherished grandfather of Max, Tamar, Batsheva, Charles, Samantha, Natalia, Louis and Farin. He was a scholar who loved ideas and knowledge. His generosity of heart and Tzdakah were only matched by his love and devotion to family and friends. Services will be held on Sunday, November 18, at 12 noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st Street), New York. Donations in his memory may be made to Amit Women or any Jewish charity of your choice.

WITH the real estate and mortgage industries slumping, housing analysts say that home-improvement projects are become more austere than in recent years -- if, indeed, such projects are happening at all. According to a report last month from the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University, remodeling activity this year is on pace to drop 2.3 percent when compared with 2006, with a further decline likely next year.

Getting downhill is the easy part of a ski vacation, whether you shred 40,000 vertical feet in a day or just barely hold your snowplow. It's nailing the rest of the scene that gets tricky. Are you turned on by ski bums or starlets, Picabo Street or Prada Sport? Here, T's guide to the season's most swinging slopeside resorts Aspen/Snowmass, Colo.: Aspen is Southampton on the slopes -- with kid-friendly Snowmass a few miles down the road. Kate Moss! Jack Nicholson! A $17 million indoor Kids Adventure Center just opened in Snowmass. The Tavern for alfresco truffle fries; Nobu's local outpost for sushi and a scene. Spring 2008 Prada Sport (it goes with the Chanel skis). Yoyo the Yorkie -- the Little Nell hotel has canine beds and cuisine.

To the Editor: A photograph accompanying ''Werner Kleeman's Private War'' (Nov. 11) shows a German travel document with the name ''Kleeman, Werner Israel.'' What isn't mentioned is that in the late 1930s, the Nazis required Jewish boys and men to add the name ''Israel'' on their documents. Jewish women and girls had to add the name ''Sarah.''

MALL ISN'T DEAD To the Editor: I was pleased to see Gregory Dicum's Day Out column ''Despite Malls, a Vital Culture'' (Nov. 4) about Japantown, San Francisco, one of the city's most distinctive treasures. My experience of the malls, however, has always been vastly different from Mr. Dicum's. Rather than ''never hopping ... dead interior spaces,'' the Post Street malls are a vibrant gathering place for the city's Japanese-American community and local and out-of-town visitors as well. In the evenings, especially on weekends, the malls are alive with families, teens, tourists and indoor street entertainers, and the authentic Japanese restaurants and ice cream parlors have long lines outside.

New York State elections officials have been so embarrassingly slow in figuring out how to buy new voting machines that the federal government has stepped in to clean up the mess. The trouble is that Washington could make things a whole lot worse. In 2002, responding to the disastrous elections in Florida two years before, Congress passed the Help America Vote Act, which provided federal money to help states modernize their voting machines. New York's Legislature, never known for acting quickly, finally passed a law enabling the changes in 2005.

With late-night comedy writers on strike and the talk shows in reruns, Laugh Lines readers step in to fill the void: France, the country of the 35-hour work week and six-week vacations, is plagued with a series of transportation strikes this week. So French workers are on strike? How do you tell?

An article on Nov. 4 in the Holiday Movies section about the film adaptation of ''Sweeney Todd'' misstated the number of Tony Awards that musical won for its original Broadway run in 1979. It was eight, not seven.

STREIT--Carl, on November 15, 2007. Beloved husband of Mona. Extremely loving father of Michael and Clifford. Absolutely adoring grandfather of Jack. Also survived by Blanche Brand and Martin Streit. Service Sunday 11:45am at the ''Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

NEWMAN--Anita (nee Eagle), died in White Plains, New York on November 14, 2007. Beloved wife of William, they would have celebrated their 59th anniversary on December 12th. She is survived by her daughter, Debbie, her son-in-law Dean Bernstein and her grandchildren Samantha, Matthew and Lauren. Two other children, Steven and Sharon predeceased her. She is also survived by her brothers Robert (Marilyn) Eagle and Sidney (Anita) Eagle. Anita was a beautiful woman who filled her life with beauty. She was an avid collector of all kinds of antiques and art-from Fiestaware to oil paintings. She was a life-long fan of Frank Sinatra from the time she was a teenager waiting outside the Paramount Theatre in order to catch a glimpse of him. Anita was an enthusiastic golfer and enjoyed her days with her friends at Boca Rio Golf Club in Florida and Brae Burn in Purchase, New York, playing mah-jong and canasta and going out to wonderful dinners. She loved to travel, and together with Bill, they visited Europe, The Far East, Africa and Russia. They were among the first American tourists to visit China in 1978. Anita participated with her husband in major philanthropic endeavors. Foremost among them were the United Jewish Appeal and Baruch College, whose main campus building and library bear their names. Anita will be sorely missed by her family and friends. Funeral services will be held at 10am on Friday, November 16, at Temple B'nai Israel in Armonk, NY. The family will be sitting Shiva at the home of Debra and Dean Bernstein following services on Friday and Saturday 12-8pm.

MILLMAN--Walter S., 75, of New Windsor, NY, died Saturday, November 10, 2007, at home surrounded by his loving family. Born October 23, 1932, in Boston; son of Dr. Beatrice Magid and Morris Millman. A retired associate superintendent of the Newburgh City School District, he spent a lifetime championing national and local efforts to promote diversity and innovation in the public schools, from Project Head Start in the 1960s to the Magnet School Program in the 1980s. He was an avid sailor, passionate outdoorsman, and noted civic leader, serving on the boards of the Black Rock Forest Consortium, the Newburgh Board of Education, the Association of Gifted and Talented Educators, the National Magnet Schools of America, the Newburgh Community Action Committee, and the Newburgh YMCA. A man of great wisdom and compassion, he will be deeply missed by his family and the scores of children, teachers and colleagues he challenged and inspired. He is survived by his devoted wife Jeanne; his children David, Michael, and Rebecca; and grandchildren Sophia and Henry. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, 1311 Mamaroneck Ave., Suite 130, White Plains, NY 10605 or the Black Rock Forest Consortium, 129 Continental Road, Cornwall, NY 12518.

THE news media have a penchant for reliving major events on significant anniversaries. So it came as no surprise this year that we were bombarded with 30-year-old memories of the summer of 1977, when the Bronx was burning, the Son of Sam was on the loose and a blackout led to days of widespread looting. Before the 1977 nostalgia passes, we should recall another series of frightening events from that year that hold lessons for today. In the space of a month, four New York State prisoners assigned to temporary release programs escaped. Three committed horrific crimes. In the uproar that followed, New York clamped down on these programs, leaving a policy legacy that still hamstrings our ability to reduce crime.

SAMPLING A PIZZA BIANCA AT ANTICO FORNO ROSCIOLI, NOV. 3, 2007 Romualdas Sabaliauskas, 55, a civil servant from Vilnius, Lithuania, on a five-day trip with his daughter (not pictured). ''I was there for work to study at the health ministry, but for my daughter it was a vacation. She really enjoyed it. Rome is wonderful, of course -- especially old Rome, imperial Rome. It was my daughter's first time there, but it was my third, so I explained to her things about the history, the people, the habits and so on. We like Italian food -- it's not fatty, but very tasty. Pizzas in Italy are good, but this pizza was so-so. It was not like a soft dough. It was very dry. It was the first time I had eaten one, and my opinion was can be better!'' As told to Austin Considine

FIRESTONE--Nathaniel, 81, of Fort Lee, NJ, on November 16, 2007. He is survived by his wife of fifty-six years, Marina, daughter Louise, son John, their spouses Joseph Pizzurro and Sandra Miller, and grandchildren Katie, Claire, Andrew and Gregory. Known as ''Nat'' to colleagues, ''Nuti'' to friends and family, ''Nonno'' to his grandchildren, he was born in Czernowitz, Romania, escaped to Italy in 1945 and graduated from the University of Torino and Yale School of Architecture. He worked as an architect in New York and Houston and supervised Peace Corps volunteers in Tunisia from 1964-1966. He was proud of his professional and volunteer work for the University of Texas Health Science Center and his 35year-long loving restoration of the family cottage, ''The Ark.'' A memorial service is being planned. In lieu of flowers, please consider a gift to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center, Holy Name Hospice, Teaneck, NJ, or the charity of your choice.

BATISTA--Fulgencio Ruben, who would have turned 74 today, passed away at home in Miami on November 7, 2007 after an inspirational battle with leukemia. He was born in Havana, Cuba, on November 19, 1933 to Elisa Godinez and ex Cuban President, Fulgencio Batista. Ruben graduated from Princeton (1956) and was a business owner, but his passion lay in the study of history and religion and his wife of 50 years. He was keenly intelligent, witty, bighearted, loyal and a pillar of strength to his friends and family. Despite his high profile, Ruben lived privately and unassumingly.

IN 2003, when Kiehl's introduced its Abyssine anti-aging face cream, the product became one of the company's all-time top three sellers (along with Creme de Corps body lotion and Creme With Silk Groom). Now, nearly five years later, Kiehl's has released an upgraded version, and zealous fans have grown, if possible, more zealous. Earlier this month, 500 jars sold out in a day, leaving a long waiting list; a second delivery has arrived at the Kiehl's store at 109 Third Avenue in New York, (212) 677-3171 and www.kiehls.com. While the new version has been bolstered with a 23 SPF and coral extracts -- purported to fend off effects of aging -- a jar of the luxury unguent remains an accessible $45. Therein, perhaps, lies the magic.

At last someone in the north is hammering out details of what Venezuelan bloggers have been saying for a long time -- that under Hugo Chávez, what was once one of the best-managed oil industries in the world is heading for disaster. What Tina Rosenberg (Nov. 4) doesn't address is the fact that Chávez probably knows this. Which may be why his forceful governance and love song to the poor are being rushed into place. There is little reliable data on the extent of his misiones for the poor (financed by oil revenue). But while filming for two weeks in October, for HDNet World Report in Maracaibo, Caracas and at a massive cult gathering of 10,000 spiritualists outside Barquisimeto (celebrating Chávez's Day of Indigenous Resistance, formerly Columbus Day), I talked to people from all over Venezuela. All reported that misiones are visibly active in their town, city, state. HARRIET GORDON GETZELS

Clara Fox was truly a great leader of the settlement house movement and has made a lasting contribution to the quality of life of low income New Yorkers. BRODY--Leo Michael, very peacefully passed away on the afternoon of November 14th, his family beside him. He was 89 and resided close to his family in Scottsdale, AZ in his final years. Leo worked for many years in the theatrical and then television entertainment business. In his early days he was a press agent for Paramount Pictures and later worked in sales and marketing for such companies as Trans Lux and Allied Artists. He is survived by his son Robert, daughter-in-law Roz, grandson and granddaughter Michael and Rebecca, his sister Selma and her children, Mollie our Westie who loved him dearly, as well as the many people he has befriended and brought smiles to thoroughout his life. We will miss him dearly. Leo was a very special soul whose spirit will never leave us or this world.

JULIA CHO's appealing family drama ''Durango,'' seen last fall at the Public Theater, was among the stronger offerings from Oskar Eustis's new regime. Ms. Cho returns to New York with a new play, ''THE PIANO TEACHER,'' at the Vineyard Theater. First seen at South Coast Repertory in Southern California, a well-regarded incubator of good new work, the play is about a widowed and retired music instructor with a few secrets in her past. Mrs. K, played by the invaluable Elizabeth Franz, never quite understood why her teaching career came to such an abrupt end, but when she decides to look up a couple of former students and probe their memories, she is forced to confront horrors buried in her own. Opens on Sunday, 108 East 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 353-0303, vineyardtheatre.org; $55.

The shows opening in New York this week reinforce the impression that the city's main museums are having something of a banner year where contemporary art is concerned. On Tuesday the METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART, which has already brought us Damien Hirst's shark, will dip its toes in the murky waters of installation art in the galleries, not on the roof garden. The work will be by TARA DONOVAN, an artist known for orchestrating quantities of common substances (tape, toothpicks, drinking straws) into immersive experiences of light and space. This time she will cover three walls of a large gallery with tiny loops of silver Mylar. Tuesday through April 27, (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org.

THE NEWS Most of Broadway was dark last week as stagehands continued their strike over new work rules producers are pushing. BEHIND THE NEWS The strike, which began Nov. 10, crippled Broadway and hurt the Midtown economy as the holiday season approached. Twenty-seven shows were shuttered, including ''Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas! The Musical.'' Eight shows and all Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway productions remained open, however. The last strike, a four-day walkout by musicians in 2003, cost the city about $7 million a day, tourism officials said at the time. Both sides planned to meet on Saturday to negotiate.

Beloved and mourned by his wife Barbara Urban, sisters Mary Lee and Nancy Mercante, stepson David Urban, nieces, nephews and many dear friends. Born in New York City in 1938, eldest child of Mary Louise Lee and James J. O'Shea, brother of Mary, Nancy and John (deceased). Graduated from Iona College in 1960. In the US Army from 1962 to 1964. Lifetime career with Metropolitan Life Ins. as IT Manager and Auditor; retired in 2000 after 40 years. To honor Jim's life and memory, donations may be sent to Iona College Scholarship Fund re: ''James J. O'Shea '60'' to Dan Konopka, Advancement Office, Iona College, 715 North Avenue, New Rochelle, NY 10810 (914633-2069). He will always live on in the hearts of the many who loved him.

COLE--Rosalie G., died peacefully at her caregiver's home on November 11th, 2007. Born Rosalie Grubb Haynes in Cape May, NJ in 1915, she graduated from Agnes Irwin School in Philadelphia, studied at La Sorbonne in Paris, France and at the French Fashion School of Design in New York City. She spent a great deal of her youth in Lancaster, Pennsylvania where her ancestors had developed the Cornwall Ore Mines, one of the largest deposits of iron in the eastern United States. As an adult, she served as a docent at many museums, including the Metropolitan Museum in New York City, The Denver Art Museum and The Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme, CT. She was married to Harrison Wells Cole, in 1953 and is survived by her daughter, Beverly Cole Costello, son-in law, Ned Bolton Costello and her grandchildren Blair Bolton Costello and Owen Cole Costello. A memorial service will be held at St. Ann's Church in Old Lyme, CT on November 29, 2007 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be given to St. Ann's Episcopal Church Outreach Program, 82 Shore Rd., Old Lyme, CT 06371. (860) 434-1621.

The Officers, Governors, members and staff of The General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen of NYC extend our deepest condolences to the family of our beloved Past President and Brother, John M. Petrula. Brother Petrula was an active member of the Society and served with distinction as President of the GSMT in 1990. LEVINE--John Morton, 78, of New York, NY, peacefully in his sleep on November 16. He is survived by his sister, Zita Loewe, by his loving daughters Julia Stokien, Jocelyn Hayes and Jessica Levine, by his sons-in-law James Stokien and Christopher Hayes, by his beloved granddaughters Katie and Emma Stokien and Adrienne and Chloe Hayes, by his former wife Janet Stein and her husband Howard Stein -his lifelong friends -by their daughters Joanna Stein and Jennifer Seay, and their granddaughters Antonia Sullivan and Rachel and Ava Grace Seay. He was godfather and friend to Nicholas Kabcenell and a devoted friend to Peter Kabcenell. A designer with a wonderful eye, he was a passionate follower of architecture, art, dance, music, opera and theater -a true citizen of New York. He will be missed by his many friends and colleagues. A memorial service is being planned. In lieu of flowers, you may consider a gift to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts or to the Dominican Sisters Family Health Service of Hampton Bays, NY.

Talk Show: Norman Mailer's entrance was the tip-off. He came on from stage left doing that pugilist walk: his hands were fists and carried high, and he had the tousled look of having visited a favorite bar or two en route. His suit was disheveled, his bow to Janet Flanner courtly, and his refusal to shake Gore Vidal's extended hand caused a murmuring in the audience. When I said I couldn't help noticing what had just happened, I was told by Mailer that he did not approve of Vidal and found him intellectually shameless. Mailer's mission, it became rapidly clear, was to eviscerate Vidal for what Vidal had written about him in The New York Review of Books. This was tossed about a bit and Mailer told Vidal that if Vidal could teach him something about writing, he would look up to him. When Vidal denied being the Famous Writers School, he got a laugh, displeasing Mailer thereby.

Known at least in some part for its sting attacks on high-profile devotees of fur, PETA allows its undercover operations to be followed here as both advocates and detractors of the group are interviewed.

AILEEN GURAL MAKES recycling beautiful, with her handcrafted Gratitude necklaces. Using cooled casting sprues (accidental splashes of gold or silver that occur when pouring hot metal), Ms. Gural reuses each penny-size amulet by threading it onto a cord or chain and engraving the smooth side with a diminutive sunburst and the tiny words ''Thank You.'' Give the necklaces as gifts or wear one yourself as a reminder to appreciate life's unexpected moments of loveliness. It's $60 for a silver Gratitude pendant on a cord, $125 for vermeil, $450 for 14-karat yellow or $470 for pink gold; all at Aileen Gural Jewelry in New York, (212) 349-0430 or at aileenguraljewelry.com.

TANZ--Alfred, M.D. The Board of Trustees, The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, and the entire Lenox Hill Hospital family express their profound sorrow on the death of Alfred Tanz, M.D., a prominent member of our staff for 38 years. Dr. Tanz, a skillful and respected Obstetrician-Gynecologis and surgeon, was beloved by his patients for his compassion and respected by his colleagues for his prodigious skill. He was also a dedicated teacher who inspired an entire generation of physicians. We offer our deepest sympathies to his family. William O. Hiltz, Chairman, Board of Trustees Gladys George, President and CEO Chitranjan Ranawat, M.D., President of Medical Board Michael Y. Divon, M.D., Chairman, Obstetrics and Gynecology

YOUNG--Felice, on Saturday, November 10, 2007, Felice Young, (nee Bernstein and marriee Neuhoff), died peacefully in Encino, California. After several months of valiant struggle and impassioned resistance to what became inevitable, she allowed herself to move quietly into her next world, joining Sam (her children's father), Sadie (her mother) and Doris (her sister). Felice built and managed a successful career in home design and still raised two children, Michael and Jo Ann, and then enjoyed watching her grandchildren -Melissa and Lindsey Neuhoff, and Sara Douglas grow into wonderful young ladies. Felice will be missed by her sisters, Beula Dember and Rhoda Dember, her adopted son Mike Stanley and son-in-law, Bob Wagoner, her friends Joan Menna and Richy Menna, her nieces and nephews and all her friends and fellow volunteers at the Mizell Center in Palm Springs, as well as the Betty Ford Center (where she did intake and said not a word about the registrants). A memorial gathering will take place in the near future, please contact K9Kastle@aol.com for information. No flowers or even donations, please, just make the most of life and have one on Felice.

SHAINBERG--Toby Sturman, of Memphis, TN, passed away peacefully at home the morning of Tuesday, November 6th. She was born on December 7th, 1933 in Liberty, New York. She was the daughter of the late Louis and Dora Sturman. She leaves Raymond M. Shainberg, her husband of 55 years. Toby Shainberg was the proud mother of five children she leaves behind; Nancy Kline, and Kathy Shainberg of Memphis, TN, Paul Shainberg, of Rye, NY, Andrew Shainberg of Short Hills, NJ and Robin Shainberg of New York, NY. She leaves a sonin-law Alan Kline and daughters-in-law Robin L. Shainberg and Robin S. Shainberg. Toby also leaves a brother Herbert and sister-in-law Beverly Sturman who reside in Los Angeles, CA. Toby's six grandchildren were her precious jewels; Brendan, Brooke, Jonah, Matthew, Jake, and Scott. She enjoyed spending time in New York and Vermont with her friends and family which she considered her second homes. She enjoyed traveling and experiencing new adventures. Toby proudly served as President of Memphis Ballet Society to which she enjoyed giving her time and efforts. She currently served as a board member of the Wings Cancer Foundation and was a member of Temple Israel and a life member of Hadassah. Toby was faced with lymphoma for the last fourteen years of her life, but she lived each day to its fullest and was an inspiration to all who knew her. She developed vasculitis that was debilitating, but she continued to fight valiantly to the end. In lieu of flowers contributions to your favorite charity will be appreciated.

As the former C.E.O. of Disney and the founder of a privately held company that invests in the digital future, you were recently speaking at a conference when you used the words ''stupid'' and ''insanity'' to describe the Writers Guild strike. Can you explain? What I was driving at was that it was a foolish time to have a strike issue over a business and a marketplace that is not evolved enough to even know if there is a business or a marketplace there. But aren't television networks already making money from programs that appear on the Internet, which is what the striking writers want a piece of? No. The areas in which they are making money, which let's call the reuse areas -- the movies to be downloaded, or television series to be downloaded -- are areas in which I believe the producers have agreed to make a deal. The area where they cannot make a deal is original production for the Internet, which is neither profitable nor is it clear in exactly what direction it's going to go.

Until the early '90s, Hayes Valley was a seedy neighborhood, best known for prostitutes, drug deals and the elevated freeway that once bisected its main drag. The freeway has since been replaced by a Parisian-style boulevard and village green, and the neighborhood is thriving, its tree-lined streets and alleys peppered with restaurants, bars and -- thanks to a 2003 local ban on chain stores -- some of the city's most original shops. 1. Honey Ryder: Like its namesake Bond girl, this new boutique knows what's sexy -- you'll find draped silk jersey dresses by Jessup, reversible wool jackets and psychedelic-print tunics by Smoke and Mirrors, and rock-star-worthy gold-plated cuffs and lariats by the celebrity favorite Kimberly Faith. 564 Hayes Street; (415) 255-6858.

DEVERIN--Daniele, died in New York on Friday, November 9, 2007, of congestive heart failure, aged 84 years. A longtime resident of New York and avid weekend gardener in Brookfield, CT, she was born in Saint Romain de Colbosc, France, and studied medicine at the University of Paris. Following her emigration to the U.S. after WWII, she worked for many years in Manhattan, primarily as an agent for commercial illustrators. She is survived by her son, Christopher Smeall, her daughter-in-law, Ann Fabian, and her two grandchildren, Andrew Smeall and Isabelle Smeall, of New York and Salisbury, CT; her sisters Michele Pellot of Paris, Claude Goodrich of Pacific Palisades, CA, and Magdeleine Flach of Chambery, France; her brother-in-law Daniel Flach of Chambery; numerous nieces, nephews and cousins; and many friends. She will be remembered by them all for her intelligence, independent spirit and love of life.
The Charmin public toilets are back. Charmin said the 20 temporary potties — part toilet paper promotion and part public service — were used more than 500,000 times last year.

Over the last five years, the holiday market at Bryant Park has been transformed from being a static and tepid street fair to a bustling showcase of plexiglass booths with $5 million to $6 million in total retail sales for its vendors. But in the early days, the market struggled to fill up the slots with mass mailings, recruiting at street fairs, and persuading skeptical retailers to open a second location in Bryant Park for the holidays.This year, the market, which opened on Saturday and will run for six weeks, had 300 applications for the 100 or so booths, which cost from $9,000 to $40,000 to rent. Vendors — which generally sell high-end crafts, jewelry and clothing — now do an average of $60,000 to $70,000 in sales, with a handful breaking $100,000. The top vendor clears $300,000 in merchandise during the period.

The town where I grew up was small and less than an hour's drive from Dallas. Miles of farming land surrounded this small pocket of humanity. The population consisted of mostly white residents with a minority of African- and Latino-American residents and me. It was the 1970s -- the Age of Aquarius, disco and human rights awareness -- but the population was still split into black and white. The war in Vietnam had come to an end and America was still counting its losses. It was in this setting that I grew up loved and protected.

A woman returning home from church yesterday afternoon was wounded by a stray gunshot, the police said. The woman, whose name was not released, was a passenger in a car that had parked in front of a home on Montrose Terrace. As she got out of the car, a bullet crashed through the rear window and struck her on the left side of the face. She was taken to University Hospital in Newark, where her injuries were described as not life-threatening. The police said that the bullet appeared to be a stray shot from several that were fired from a nearby white car at a black car. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Miguel Ángel Jiménez won the Hong Kong Open title by a stroke after the third-round leader, Robert Karlsson, double-bogeyed the final hole. Jiménez had an eagle and five birdies in a three-under-par 67 at Hong Kong Golf Club for a total of 15-under 265.

Oakland traded the utility infielder Marco Scutaro to Toronto for the minor league right-handers Kristian Bell and Graham Godfrey. The A’s, who missed the playoffs, want to give Donnie Murphy a chance in Scutaro’s role.
Matt Foy scored for the first time in more than two years, and Aaron Voros and Brent Burns added goals for the second time in two games as the host Wild beat the Colorado Avalanche, 4-1.

Thiago Pereira of Brazil and Stefan Nystrand of Sweden set world records at the short-course Arena World Cup in Berlin. Pereira swam the men’s 200-meter medley in 1 minute 53.14 seconds, beating the 1:53.31 set by Ryan Lochte of the United States in 2006. Nystrand finished the 100 freestyle in 20.93, 0.05 faster than the mark Roland Schoeman of South Africa set in 2006.
The Olympic champion Mizuki Noguchi won the Tokyo International Women’s Marathon. In her first marathon in two years, she finished in 2 hours 21 minutes 37 seconds.

American pitchers scattered seven hits and Jayson Nix and Jason Jaramillo each had two runs batted in as the United States defeated Cuba, 6-3, to win the Baseball World Cup in Taipei, Taiwan. The United States took command in the second inning when Jaramillo singled in a run, and Yadel Carrillo walked two consecutive batters with the bases loaded. Jaramillo singled in his second run in the third, and in the next inning Nix homered to make it 5-0.

St. Anthony’s of South Huntington, Long Island, won its seventh consecutive Catholic High School Football League AAA title yesterday, beating Mount St. Michael of the Bronx, 26-20, at Hofstra’s Shuart Stadium. Mount St. Michael also lost in last year’s final.The Rutgers-bound defensive tackle Scott Vallone had nine tackles, two sacks and a fumble recovery. He also made a potential game-saving tackle, taking down quarterback Jayson Holt short of a first down at the St. Anthony’s 15 with 59 seconds remaining. William Ruggiero scored two rushing touchdowns for St. Anthony’s (10-1).

New U.S. military data showed that attacks had declined to the lowest level since January 2006. It is the third week in a row that attacks have been at this reduced level.

Thirty-two people from the United States have been selected as Rhodes scholars for 2008, the scholarship trust announced yesterday. Nine either come from the region or go to college in it, including students at Columbia, the United States Military Academy, Princeton and Yale. The scholars were selected from 764 applicants endorsed by 294 colleges and universities. A list of the winners and their biographies is available online at www.rhodesscholar.org. The scholarships, the oldest of the international study awards available to American students, provide two or three years of study at Oxford University in England.
More teachers resigned during the last school year than at any time in recent history, according to figures released by the United Federation of Teachers.

A man was seriously injured early yesterday after fleeing the scene of a car crash in Flatbush, the police said. Shortly after midnight, a police officer spotted a car that had jumped a curb and hit a light pole near the intersection of Avenue H and East 16th Street, the police said. The driver ran down an alley and jumped over a fence. He was seriously injured because the ground dropped about 20 feet on the other side of the fence, the police said. The driver, whose name was not released, was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was in serious but stable condition yesterday evening, the police said. The crash was under investigation.

All train service between Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan and Penn Station in Newark was disrupted for nearly six hours yesterday after an eastbound New Jersey Transit train became entangled in overhead wires in a tunnel under the Hudson River. The break in service, which began about 8:30 a.m., affected dozens of Amtrak and New Jersey Transit trains and more than 30,000 riders, according to representatives of the railroads. The disabled train, traveling from Long Branch, N.J., was carrying about 300 passengers, who were transferred in the tunnel to a Long Island Rail Road train, a New Jersey Transit spokeswoman said. Both railroads said that normal service resumed in the afternoon and that the disruption was not expected to affect this morning’s commute.

Police officers responding to a report of an unconscious person in Hamilton Heights yesterday found a dead man who had been shot, the police said. The officers were summoned to the third-floor hall at 201 West 146th Street about 8:45 a.m. and found a man, 39, lying there with a single gunshot wound to his chest, according to the police. His name had not been released yesterday evening because his family had not yet been notified, the police said.

A firefighter was hurt yesterday afternoon when he fell from an aerial bucket while battling a blaze in an apartment in Highbridge, the Fire Department said. The firefighter, Brian Smith, 43, was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, where he was listed in serious but stable condition. One apartment resident was also injured in the fire, neighbors said. The fire was on the second floor of a six-story building on Shakespeare Avenue. Melissa Gonzales, who lives above the apartment that was on fire, said she believed that Firefighter Smith was trying to break a window on her floor to gain access. A bystander’s video of the accident shows two firefighters in the bucket, and one falling.

Titans quarterback Vince Young threw for a career-high 257 yards last Sunday, but given his shaky passing this season (4 touchdowns, 10 interceptions) it may be safer for Tennessee to keep the ball on the ground. Fortunately for the Titans, the Broncos rank 31st against the run, giving up 151 yards a game. LenDale White will have some help attacking that defense with the expected return of Chris Brown from an injury. Travis Henry’s sore knee may keep him out of the Broncos’ lineup, leaving Selvin Young to stare down the Titans’ second-ranked defense. If he cannot move the ball on the ground, Jay Cutler (nine touchdowns, nine interceptions) will have to pass it. The good news for Cutler is that he may not have to worry about Albert Haynesworth, who is nursing a hamstring injury. ANDREW DAS.

LEVINE--Sadie, 96. Devoted wife of the late Moe. Dedicated mother to beloved children Alan and Gail, Michael and Susan. Loyal sister to Pauline Cohen and the late Louis Soss. Loving grandma to Sheryl, Laura, Adam and Michelle and great-grandmother. Aunt Sadie played a huge role in the lives of her forever grateful nieces and nephews. We all feel so privileged to have known her. We will not see the likes of her for a long, long time. Graveside service to be held November 21, 2007 at New Montefiore Cemetery at 11:30am. Memorial contributions may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York at www.vnsy.org.

MARTINEZ--Juan Radames. It is with sorrow that we announce the passing of Juan Radames Martinez, former resident of Jackson Heights, Queens, NY on November 15, 2007. Dr. Martinez was born on September 19, 1928 in Paso Real de San Diego, Los Palacios, Pinar del Rio, Cuba. He attended ''La Escuela Normal Para Maestros de la Habana'' where he graduated at 21 with a Bachelor of Arts in Education. Thereafter, he was admitted to the University of Habana where he received Masters and Doctorate degrees in Education. Upon his graduation from the University he was employed as a teacher first, then as a Director of ''El Centro Escolar Fortuna Medel.'' An ardent believer and defender of Democracy he escaped Castro's regime in the early 1960's. He fled to Mexico where he began a crusade against communism modeled after Jose Marti's revolution. When he finally arrived to the United States of America, he became an active member of the anti-Castro organization El CID (Cuba Independence Democratica). He traveled to the Dominican Republic where once again he spoke out against communism. He created ''Escuelitas de la Patria'' with the objective for Cuban children to preserve their first language and culture on the radio broadcast ''Radio Marti.'' Dr. Martinez received a Bachelor of Arts degree at Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, NY. He then received Masters of Arts degrees in Education from St. John's University and L.I. University. He also obtained a Masters degree in Guidance at Montclair State College. A pillar in the Education Community, Juan R. Martinez taught 5th grade at the Epiphany Catholic School in Brooklyn. He was a Community Relations Teacher and Attendance Teacher for District 61 at P.S. 145K. He was the coordinator for State Monitors in District 32. He was the first Cuban exile to become a principal of the largest elementary school (student population 2000) of its time, P.S. 274 in Brooklyn. He implemented the Spanish Bilingual Dual Language Program which was originally used in Dade County, FL in the early 1960's when the first Cuban exiles arrived. He introduced District 14 to Spanish reading series ''A CADA PASO'', to teach children how to read in Spanish phonetically. He was the Co-founder of the Spanish Bilingual Program at Mercy College where he taught undergraduate and graduate courses. He was also a Professor at L.I.U and St. John's University. He was a frequent guest lecturer at various colleges including Eugenio Maria de Hostos, Hunter College, and Brooklyn College. He was a proud member of the UFT, CDSA, ETNA, TRS, Latinos for a Better Brooklyn, Master of Mason, Latino Gerontological Centro, and The Lion's Club. Juan Radames Martinez was the greatest source of pride to his parents Juancito and Saritia. He is survived by his beloved and devoted wife Fredesvinda. He is cherished and adored by his daughters Sarilyn and Aurora Elena. He was the respected eldest brother of the late Miguel A., Aramis O., and Marco A. and surviving brothers Rene L. and Augusto C. He will be remembered by a large extended family and the many other lives he touched and influenced throughout his lifetime. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Inc. 98-07 Ascan Ave, Forest Hills, NY, Monday and Tuesday 2-9pm. Funeral Mass to be celebrated at Our Lady of Mercy Church, 70-01 Kessel St., Forest Hills, NY Wednesday November 21 at 10:15am. Entombment St. Michael's Cemetery, East Elmhurst, NY. Please, in lieu of flowers donations to New York Medical Center, attention Heart Division, 530 1st Ave., NY, NY 10016 will be appreciated.

EPSTEIN--Eleanor (Amendola), on November 17, 2007. Beloved wife of Arthur. She is survived by her sister Carol Newman and sister-in-law Irma Amendola. Eleanor was an adored aunt, grandaunt and great-grandaunt. Friends may call on Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81st St. Funeral Mass on Wednesday, 10am at St. John the Martyr. Contributions can be made to St. Michael's Church, PO Box 699, Amsterdam, NY 12010.

DELBANCO--Kurt, 98, died at home in NYC on November 16. Born in Hamburg, Germany, Kurt fled to England in 1936 and settled in America after World War II. He was a businessman, art dealer, painter and sculptor, working as a creative artist till the last days of his life. His portraits have been collected by, among others, the National Portrait Gallery and the Museum of the City of New York. Committed above all to family, he is survived by his wife Mary, three sons; Thomas, Nicholas and Andrew, by his first marriage to Barbara Bernstein, their wives, Jill, Elena and Dawn, two stepdaughters, Judith and Janet (Andrew Lemer), nine grandchildren and nine greatgrandchildren. We will always miss his decency and optimism, his great grace. Contributions to Selfhelp Community Services, Nazi Victims Program, 520 Eighth Avenue, NY 10018.

KOSTYRA--Martha. CELINE DION ''Taking Chances'' (Columbia) It has now been a decade since Celine Dion first shared the musical electrocardiogram that has come to define her career. And in retrospect ''My Heart Will Go On'' seems like the end of an era. Since then she has managed only one more Top 10 hit in the United States: ''That's the Way It Is,'' from 1999. Her hugely successful residency in Las Vegas is testament to the size and devotion of her fan base, but it may also have fostered the impression that Ms. Dion has become an oldies act.

Consumers planning their shopping strategies for Black Friday, the day after Thanksgiving that marks the start of the holiday retail season, can turn to several Web sites to find store circulars showing sales and discounts. The downstream traffic from these sites, such as bfads.net, blackfriday.info and blackfriday.gottadeal.com, mostly flows to brick-and-mortar giants like Wal-Mart, above, Best Buy and Target. The Black Friday sites go beyond scans of advertising circulars to provide e-mail notifications, forums, searchable databases and discounts available before Friday. SHELLY FREIERMAN
Colleges Rebuff Movie Group

STREIT--Carl, To our beloved friend and mentor, you will be deeply missed. Our deepest thoughts and sympathies go out to his sons Michael and Clifford and his soul-mate Mona. Billlly, Susan, Jade and Mia Abramson STREIT--Carl, for my father, my best friend and the greatest ''Papa'' in the world. What do you say when, in an instant, you lose the most important person in the world to you? There are no words to express how much I loved and respected you both as a father, confidant, advisor and the greatest ''Papa'' to my son Jack. You lived for your family, friends and most recently your grandson. I hope that in the future both Jack and I become even half the man you were. A day will never go by as long as I live that you will be out of my thoughts. I will live the rest of my life as if you are still here guiding me daily. The love you showed for your grandson was nothing short of remarkable. Calling every day to see how he was, what new things he had to say, and the most endearing was the way you just stared at him every time he was with you, never taking your hand away from him for a minute. He knew when we were going to ''Papa's'', you would be out in front of the house waiting for us to arrive, and again watching the car when we left. Your love for him was an inspiration to me and a lesson on not just loving, but how to show that love. You will be missed more than you could ever know. All our love, Michael and Jack STREIT--Carl, we deeply mourn the loss of Carl Streit, November 15th, 2007. Beloved husband of Mona, devoted father of Clifford and Michael, loving grandfather of Jack, and great friend to us and all that had the pleasure to know him. We will miss you, Carl. With our love, always. The Podell and Crown Families

CLUTHE--Frederic S., of Short Hills, NJ and Norwich, VT, died on November 13, 2007 at age 87, at home in Vermont. He was born in New York, NY. Graduate from Dartmouth College (class of 1941) and attended Harvard Business School. He owned a food-importing business, Strohmeyer and Arpe, formerly of NY, NY, now located in New Jersey. An only child of Herman and Louise Cluthe, both deceased, he leaves his devoted wife, Ela Cluthe, daughters, Leigh Tilden of Stockton, NJ, and Sarah Rodgers and partner Sandy Abrams of Albuquerque, NM; granddaughters, Rebecca Tilden and husband David Laemmle of Wiscasset, Maine, and Ani Pierson and husband Trip of Pittsford, New York, and four greatgrandchildren, Kate and Sam Laemmle of Maine, and Hap and Tate Pierson of New York. His passion was traveling with his wife, Ela. There will be a private gathering among family. Contributions may be sent to: Visiting Nurse Association and Hospice of Vermont and New Hampshire, 66 Bennington St., Suite 6, West Lebanon, NH 03784.

LEVINE--John Morton, 78, of New York, NY, peacefully in his sleep on November 16. He is survived by his sister, Zita Loewe, by his loving daughters Julia Stokien, Jocelyn Hayes and Jessica Levine, by his sons-in-law James Stokien and Christopher Hayes, by his beloved granddaughters Katie and Emma Stokien and Adrienne and Chloe Hayes, by his former wife Janet Stein and her husband Howard Stein -his lifelong friends -by their daughters Joanna Stein and Jennifer Seay, and their granddaughters Antonia Sullivan and Rachel and Ava Grace Seay. He was godfather and friend to Nicholas Kabcenell and a devoted friend to Peter Kabcenell. A designer with a wonderful eye, he was a passionate follower of architecture, art, dance, music, opera and theater -a true citizen of New York. He will be missed by his many friends and colleagues. A memorial service is being planned. In lieu of flowers, you may consider a gift to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts or to the Dominican Sisters Family Health Service of Hampton Bays, NY.

HANDLER--Phyllis, on November 16, 2007. Loved wife of the late Max. Loving mother of David and Joanne. Greatly loved mother-in-law of Robin and John. Adoring grandmother of Michael, Carly, Morgan and Samantha. She will be deeply missed. Service private.

8 P.M. (HBO) I AM AN ANIMAL: THE STORY OF INGRID NEWKIRK AND PETA In 1980 Ingrid Newkirk, above, who lives alone in a one-bedroom apartment with few possessions, founded People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals with Alex Pacheco. Today the group has 300 employees, an annual operating budget of $25 million and more than a million members, including celebrity supporters like Pamela Anderson, Alec Baldwin and Bill Maher. Still, most people have never heard of Ms. Newkirk. This documentary from Matthew Galkin delves into her private life and follows some of her campaigns against research facilities, meat-processing factories and fashion establishments. Ms. Newkirk says, ''When it comes to feelings like hunger, pain and thirst, a rat is a pig is a dog is a boy.'' 8 P.M.
