The iPhone? Microsoft Shrugs A cynic would describe Microsoft's approach to the music player market as simple Apple envy. The iPod has the dominant market share and is helping Apple to increase its small share of the PC market. Are many in the inner sanctums of Redmond, Wash., hot to introduce a slick phone from Microsoft?

CAHN--Milton, 86, A life-long resident of New York City, died peacefully on November 16th, 2007. He is survived by his wife, Jeannie Litz, and his devoted sons, Brian Cahn and Stephen Litz. Milton, during his professional career, worked in the ladies apparel business, participating in the growth and success of the legendary firm, Jonathan Logan, spanning three decades from the 1950s thru the 1970s. In 1979, he co-founded Maggy London International, a ladies dress manufacturing company, with Larry Lefkowitz. He served as its chairman, and together they built a flourishing organization which today has operations throughout the world and employs approximately 500 people. Milton was an avid fisherman and loved to discuss his adventures. He was a powerful presence to all who had the good fortune to know and love him, an Icon in the apparel industry and the ultimate perfectionist. A mentor to many, he taught the virtues of fair business and that the commitment to fine quality can never go out of style. His inspiration and leadership will continue to inspire us all, he will never be forgotten. He leaves a rich legacy of love and devotion to his family, partners, friends and business associates. A memorial service will be held on Monday November 19th, at Riverside Memorial, 180 West 76th Street, at 9.30am. The family has requested that, in lieu of flowers, memorial donations can be made to The American Heart Association. CAHN--Milton. Mentor, role model, inspiration for so many, he had an indelible influence on my life. I will forever miss his spirit, intellect and the twinkle in his eyes. My heart goes out to his loving, devoted wife, Jeanne and his sons, Stephen and Brian. Liz Goldsmith
The Court of Appeals, New York State’s highest court, threw out the conviction today of a man who was arrested for standing and not moving on a Times Square corner in June 2004.
This is a week for turkey lotteries for the city’s food pantries. Though with declining federal support, some pantries are finding they have no turkeys to ration.
A City Hall news release today states that Rockefeller Center has installed its “first-ever ‘green’ Christmas tree.”

Charles Kernaghan stood in the rain before St. Patrick’s Cathedral this morning, brandishing a crucifix from the cathedral’s gift shop that he claimed had been made under terrible conditions at a factory in China. “It is immoral, it is unjust and it has to change,” he said.Mr. Kernaghan, the head of the National Labor Committee, an advocacy group that has unearthed past examples of abusive work conditions, and a veteran of battles with industries over the treatment of foreign workers, said the six-inch wooden crucifix and other religious articles are frequently made by women who toil for pennies an hour in an unrelenting grind of assembly work. (The Archdiocese of New York said today that it would investigate the charges.)

Pumpkins are out. Cranberries are in. This is a peak week for the Hunts Point Cooperative Market, which is the source for approximately 60 percent of New York City’s produce. On Sunday night, the market opened at 6 p.m. instead of a normal 9 p.m. to handle the nighttime rush — about twice the volume of any other day. That day some 500,000 pounds of fresh cranberries — mostly from the bogs of Massachusetts and New Jersey — passed through the market.“Cranberries are a unique item in that more than half of the fresh cranberries are consumed at one meal, Thanksgiving Day,” said Matthew D’Arrigo, whose family has been distributing cranberries for 25 years. “Most of the rest of the year, we limp along and sell 20 to 40 boxes a day. And then I put 12,000 into storage and starting about 10 days before Thanksgiving they start flying out,” he said. “It’s a very encapsulated market.”

Updated, 4:13 p.m. | Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced this morning that he was directing the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to scale back its plan to increase subway and bus fares, holding the base fare at $2 per ride. His plan would still allow the authority to increase some fares, including the cost of the 7-day and 30-day unlimited-ride MetroCards and fares on the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Railroad.

The stagehands’ strike is costing the city’s economy millions of dollars each day and is especially painful this week, one of the busiest of the year. Campbell Robertson, who covers Broadway for The Times, reports that the big shock came on Sunday night, when the league of theater producers and owners and the union suddenly broke off talks, after spending the weekend trying to end the strike. The sticking point in the talks has been the league’s desire for looser work rules for members of the union.

Updated, Nov. 21 | A study by the private nonprofit Rand Corporation found that blacks and Hispanics were more likely than whites to be searched when stopped by police officers, but the report does not accuse the department of racial profiling, according to Warren Robak, a spokesman for Rand.

Freddie Mac, the No. 2 guarantor of home mortgages in the United States, reported a much bigger-than-expected $2 billion loss for the third quarter and said Tuesday it had hired Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers to help it consider "very near-term capital raising alternatives."

There's been a lot of talk about personal branding lately. A few weeks ago, I heard Catherine Kaputa, author of U R a Brand, speak at a conference. She told a story about a book with a great idea that achieved only modest sales. But then it was repackaged with some attention paid to branding and went on to captivate dieters around the country. The book's original title was The Moderate Carbohydrate Diet. The book's modified title? The South Beach Diet. Ms. Kaputa's book is about how to apply this kind of thinking to ourselves.

A London buyout shop Candover, announced an agreement Monday to buy the Alma Consulting Group, a French tax recovery and cost reduction services company, from a private equity firm in Paris, Apax Partners, an independently managed member of the Apax Group, and Chequers Capital, a private equity firm also in Paris.

The legal fight between United Rentals, the rental equipment provider, and Cerberus Capital Management, the private equity firm that is trying to cancel its $4 billion buyout of the company, has Breakingviews wondering if these "reverse" break-up fees, which allow buyers to walk away from a deal freely for a nominal sum, might become a thing of the past.
Genesco, the shoe retailer seeking to be bought by Finish Line, fell the most in five years after UBS asked a judge to let it out of an agreement to finance the $1.5 billion acquisition.

Is demand for buyout-related debt drying up again? That question was raised late Monday by reports that the planned sale of $4 billion in loans tied to Cerberus Capital Management's acquisition of Chrysler will likely be postponed amid weak demand.
On Wall Street, the first quarter of 2007 may wind up as one of those periods, like the height of the dot-com bubble in early 2000, that is remembered wistfully for years.

Sanctions imposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission fell this year to the lowest level since 2002, after Republican commissioners complained that heavy penalties hurt investors and the agency brought fewer billion-dollar accounting fraud cases.
A Los Angeles investment firm, Hudson Capital, has a preliminary agreement to buy a former Warner Brothers studio that is now home to station KTLA-TV Channel 5, according to The Los Angeles Times.

The China Railway Group, a construction contractor, plans to raise up to $5.5 billion from its Hong Kong and Shanghai initial public offerings amid booming railway investment in China, Reuters reported.

It has been a rough few months for America's vaunted financial institutions, which are under siege. Shares of many Wall Street bank and Wall Street investment houses have taken a beating amid losses related to the mortgage market meltdown and the abrupt exits of several chief executives.

Portus Alternative Asset Management's co-founder, Michael Mendelson, was sentenced Monday to two years in prison after pleading guilty to fraud related to the collapse of the company, a Canadian hedge-fund firm, in 2005.

An affiliate of Sibir Energy is seeking what could be billions of dollars in damages in a lawsuit in London against the billionaire Roman Abramovich and his investment company, Millhouse Capital, saying that it was cheated out of its Russian assets.

Three former executives of Countrywide Financial who pleaded guilty to criminal insider trading charges were sentenced Monday to serve three years' probation, the United States attorney's office said.

A semiconductor equipment maker, Applied Materials, said Monday it was purchasing Baccini, a supplier of automated metalization and test systems for making solar systems, for about 225 million euros ($330 million).

The physician Oliver Sacks's latest book focuses on people afflicted with strange musical disorders or powers — “musical misalignments” that affect their professional and daily lives.
The polygamous leader of a fundamentalist Mormon sect was sentenced to 10 years to life in prison for forcing a 14-year-old girl to submit to sexual relations against her will.
Ian Douglas Smith rose to power and then slipped from it again, committed all the while to an unshakable belief that Africa without whites would not work.
Policy makers expect the economy to keep expanding over the next year, but they have lowered their forecasts.
When it comes to starting or running a business, there are many options for advice.
Justices will rule on the District of Columbia’s handgun ban, a case that bears directly on the Second Amendment right to “keep and bear arms.”
Two leading lawmakers accused the administration of trying to scare the public for political gain.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer today called on the transit authority to throw out a plan to raise subway and bus fares.
Turmoil in housing continued to reverberate today, with the homebuilder D.R. Horton also reporting a loss.

La Salle University dropped its football program for the second time, citing a shrinking number of conference opponents for shutting down a program it revived in 1997. La Salle reinstituted football in 1997 after a 56-year absence. Two years later, the Explorers joined the 10-school Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference.
A U.N. agency will lower to 33.2 million the number of people it believes are infected worldwide.

Agriculture officials said they changed their mind when they realized that the company’s feeding plan lists animal medications called ionophores, which the department has long considered to be antibiotics.

An article in the special Giving section on Nov. 12 about young philanthropists misstated the name of an organization that Jonathan Holmes, a 27-year-old who was asked to run his family’s foundation, went to for support. It is the Association of Small Foundations, not the Association for Small Foundations.
The Islanders beat the Rangers Monday night for the third time in three games this season, scoring twice in a span of 5 minutes 43 seconds in the second period, then holding on to their lead.

A front-page article on Sunday about Jeff Novitzky, a special agent for the I.R.S. who is the government’s leading investigator of doping in sports, misstated the name of a performance-enhancing drug and referred imprecisely to one of Mr. Novitzky’s high school athletic accomplishments. The drug is erythropoietin, a blood-boosting hormone; there is no steroid known as eritropotin. Although Mr. Novitzky indeed cleared 7 feet in the high jump, he did not set a state record.
Dany Heatley had a goal and two assists and Jason Spezza had three assists last night in the Ottawa Senators’ 4-2 win against the Canadiens in Montreal.
Deron Williams rebounded from two subpar games to score 20 points last night and lead the Utah Jazz to a 102-75 victory against the reeling Nets.

Liberty’s Josh McDougal outdueled Oregon’s Galen Rupp in the final straightaway to win the men’s N.C.A.A. cross-country title in Terre Haute, Ind. Rupp and the top-ranked Ducks won their first championship since 1977. The Texas Tech junior Sally Kipyego secured a second consecutive women’s title and Stanford won its third women’s team title in a row.

A group of Texas Tech alumni has set up a fund to pay the $10,000 fine levied against Coach Mike Leach by the Big 12 last week. The conference assessed Leach its largest fine after he condemned the officiating crew in the Red Raiders’ 59-43 loss at Texas on Nov. 10.

Lil’ Romeo, an actor and rapper whose full name is Percy Romeo Miller, signed a national letter of intent to attend Southern California yesterday. Miller is a senior guard at Beverly Hills (Calif.) High. His father, the hip-hop mogul Master P, had tryouts with two N.B.A. teams during the 1990s.

Mike Tyson was sentenced in Mesa, Ariz., to 24 hours in jail and three years’ probation for drug possession and driving under the influence. Tyson pleaded guilty in September to a single felony count of cocaine possession and a misdemeanor D.U.I. count. Tyson, 41, had faced a possible maximum sentence of four years and three months in prison.

The off-campus bonfire organized by Texas A&M students is on again after the Robertson County Commissioners Court lifted a burn ban, according to the student Web site for the event. Last week, commissioners voted to impose the ban because of dry conditions and strong winds. They lifted the ban yesterday in most precincts, including the one where the bonfire is held, and the traditional event was rescheduled for tonight.

The sprinters Tyson Gay and Allyson Felix were named the winners of the Jesse Owens Award as the outstanding United States track and field athletes of 2007. It was the first time Gay has received the award and the second time for the 21-year-old Felix.
Pope Benedict XVI accused international agencies of promoting abortion in Africa and blamed “disordered notions” of marriage and the family for the spread of sexually transmitted diseases there.
European Union foreign ministers warned Kosovo against unilaterally declaring its independence, cautioning that such a move could spur further conflict in the reason.
Rescue teams battled smoke and high temperatures as they pressed on with the task of tracking down 20 missing miners in a coal mine after a methane explosion killed at least 80 others.

About 2,000 people, including more than 30 members of the royal family, attended a service at Westminster Abbey observing the 60th wedding anniversary of Queen Elizabeth II and her husband, Prince Philip.
A nationwide trend for universities to use adjunct professors instead of a tenured faculty has become so extreme that some schools are pulling back.
Buoyed by its presence abroad, Hewlett-Packard appears to have sidestepped the softening demand from corporations inside the United States for new technology.
The success of American firms overseas may help prevent the economy from slipping into a recession.
Jeff Bezos, the chief executive of Amazon.com, is hoping that Kindle, an ambitious $399 electronic book device, will avoid the fate of other e-books.
The rush to criminalize children has set the country on a dangerous path.
The development of bacterial strains that are resistant to many antibiotics is a problem that needs to be tackled broadly.
Assurances that the Second Avenue Subway will be finished is heartening for a transit system in dire need of expansion.
The world’s scientists have done their job on global warming. Now it’s time for world leaders, starting with President Bush, to do theirs.
In one of the clearest signs yet of Hurricane Katrina’s lasting demographic impact, the City Council will have a white majority for the first time in over two decades.
Oxford, Miss.; St. Louis; Nashville; and Hempstead, N.Y., were selected as the sites of the presidential and vice-presidential debates in the general election campaign next year.
In each of Kellen Clemens’s three turns at starting quarterback, the Jets fell behind, but in each of those games, Clemens positioned the offense to win or tie.
Like vultures, the mortgage lenders began circling the single-family house with the tiny front lawn on Merrill Avenue.
At some of Giants Stadium’s pedestrian ramps, obscenity-laced chants and demands that women expose their breasts have become a staple during halftime at Jets home games.
THE happy couples announced their unions with the blare of car horns, bursting from freshly washed sedans draped with garlands of sunshine-yellow flowers. A wedding!.

Fran Townsend, the leading White House-based terrorism adviser who gave public updates on the extent of the threat to American security, is stepping down after four and a half years. Ms. Townsend, 45, said she would take a break from government work and look for work in the private sector.

A union-financed advocacy group that played a major role in the 2004 elections has agreed to pay a $580,000 fine after the Federal Election Commission concluded it illegally ran advertising against President Bush and in favor of Senator John Kerry, his Democratic opponent. The commission said the group, the Media Fund, which is now inactive, violated the law because it accepted unlimited donations from unions and expressly advocated the defeat or victory of a political candidate.

Two small private planes veered dangerously close to each other because of air traffic control errors, the second near miss in the area in less than a week. The planes traveling over central Wisconsin came within 2.8 lateral miles and 500 vertical feet from each other on Saturday. Federal regulations require at least five miles of lateral separation and at least 1,000 feet of vertical separation. “We were not talking to either airplane,” said Jeffrey Richards, president of the controllers’ union at the Federal Aviation Administration’s Chicago center in suburban Aurora. “This was really a bad situation.”.

A high school freshman will be tried as an adult in the shootings of two other teenagers and a couple near a middle school football game, a judge in Saginaw ruled. The student, Anthony Green Jr., 15, is charged with four counts of intent to commit murder. He also faces weapons charges in the Oct. 24 shootings outside South Middle School during halftime of the game. The authorities said the attack apparently stemmed from an altercation earlier in the day.
Officials said that they had found another case of hepatitis among the patients of an anesthesiologist on Long Island whose faulty infection-control practices put hundreds of people at risk.

Jim Gilmore, a former Republican governor, announced that he would seek the Senate seat held by John W. Warner, a Republican who is retiring. The announcement sets up a campaign against another former governor, Mark R. Warner, a Democrat. Mr. Gilmore, 58, made the announcement in a video e-mailed to 5,000 supporters and reporters and posted on YouTube and other Web sites. Mr. Warner, 52, announced his intent to run for the seat in mid-September, two weeks after Senator Warner announced his plan to retire after five terms.

Three boys, one 8-year-old and two 9-year-olds, were charged with kidnapping, rape, false imprisonment and sexual assault after an 11-year-old girl accused them of attacking her in the woods behind the apartment complex where the children live. Capt. Wayne Dennard of the Acworth Police Department north of Atlanta said the girl told officers she was playing with the boys on Thursday when they lured her into the woods and raped her. “The investigators who are working the case are confident that they have evidence to support the charges,” Captain Dennard said. But the father of one of the accused third-grade boys told The Associated Press that what happened was consensual.
Tom Glavine, whose family continued to live in suburban Atlanta even after he signed with the Mets five years ago, agreed to a one-year, $8 million contract with the Braves, his former team.

A late-night fire spread quickly through parts of a large apartment complex in Baton Rouge, killing three people and prompting residents to leap from second- and third-story windows, officials said. The blaze began in one building and spread to another in the Mirage Villa complex of multiple three-story brick and wood structures, said a Fire Department spokesman, Howard Ward. Eleven people were injured, including some with serious burns and broken bones.
After months of negotiation, the City Department of Education capitulated to state officials and agreed to shift more money to reduce class sizes and to spend more on low-performing schools.
Mr. Rabinowitz’s causes and clients ranged from labor unions to Black Panthers to Cuba to Dashiell Hammett to Dr. Benjamin Spock to his own daughter.
The Smithsonian Institution’s Board of Regents voted Monday to undertake the first large-scale private fund-raising effort in the organization’s history.
The student loan corporation in Pennsylvania improperly exploited a subsidy program to collect $34 million from the government, according to a new federal report.
An analyst’s downgrading of Citigroup to “sell” hit a raw nerve among investors and sent the Dow tumbling more than 218 points.
The University of Michigan on Monday proposed offering more wheelchair-accessible seating at its football stadium after a federal report said the facility violated the law.
Iraqis are beginning to reclaim their lost lives five months after extra U.S. troops arrived, but the depth of the changes remains open to question.
In an episode that has embarrassed the Department of Education, thousands of flawed testing booklets forced the invalidation of United States reading scores on an international exam.
Gloomy economic news formed a backdrop for the party’s candidates Monday as they intensified their fight over which one had the best experience to lead the nation.
Scientists are working feverishly to develop new technologies to test cosmetics before a European Union ban on animal testing begins in March 2009.
Mike Lowell, who was named the most valuable player in the World Series, will apparently be staying with the Boston Red Sox, if the issue of a no-trade clause can be resolved.

A public-interest law firm in Washington filed a class-action lawsuit against the New York City Education Department yesterday, charging that a program created to increase the number of black and Hispanic students in the city’s elite specialized high schools violates the Constitution by excluding whites and Asians. The law firm, the Center for Individual Rights, filed the suit in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on behalf of three Chinese-American parents whose children were denied admission to the Specialized High School Institute, which prepares students for the test determining admission to schools like Stuyvesant and the Bronx High School of Science. Andrew Jacob, a spokesman for the Education Department, said it was “reviewing the program’s eligibility criteria” in light of a June decision by the Supreme Court that struck down two race-based school integration programs. Since the institute’s creation more than a decade ago, the proportion of black and Hispanic students at the city’s most elite high schools has actually decreased; last year, 2.2 percent of Stuyvesant students were black.
Debbie Almontaser has filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court against the city’s Education Department, Chancellor Joel I. Klein and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

A South Carolina judge has ruled that a lawsuit against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and New York City over tactics used against out-of-state gun dealers can go ahead. Roger M. Young, a State Circuit Court judge in Berkeley County, found against the city’s motion to dismiss the 2006 lawsuit, brought by the Mickalis Pawn Shop of Summerville, S.C., according to papers filed yesterday. The suit was filed in response to city lawsuits against gun dealers in Georgia, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina and Virginia alleging that improper sales practices had led to a large number of guns ending up in criminals’ hands in New York. Some of the dealers settled the suits and agreed to work with a court-appointed monitor, but the owner of the Summerville shop, Larry Mickalis, countersued, accusing Mr. Bloomberg and the city of conspiracy, fraud and libel, among other charges.

The police are seeking a man who has robbed six drugstores in Manhattan in the past two months. The man, described as slightly over 6 feet tall and wearing a hooded sweatshirt, seeks out the store’s manager and starts a conversation before pulling a revolver and forcing the manager into an office, the police said. So far, the man has robbed three Duane Reade stores, a CVS, a Rite Aid and a Walgreens, the police said. The last holdup was on Nov. 15, at the Walgreens at 350 Fifth Avenue, the police said.

The New Haven police chief, Francisco Ortiz, announced yesterday that he would resign in January to take a security post at Yale University. Chief Ortiz, left, 48, a member of the force for nearly three decades and chief since 2003, had faced calls for his resignation this year after an F.B.I. sting exposed corruption in the Police Department’s narcotics division and gun violence spiked in the spring. The former chief of narcotics and two detectives pleaded guilty last month to federal charges, and an independent report released last week said the department needed an overhaul “in order to regain the public trust.” But the mayor, John DeStefano Jr., praised Chief Ortiz for helping to reduce crime by more than 40 percent over the last decade. “The city has been made a much better place,” Mr. DeStefano said.

A Queens man pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to the 2004 strangulation of his wife, whose body was found five days later in a car along with her 2-year-old daughter, prosecutors said. The man, Leonardo Almonte, 40, of 115th Avenue in Jamaica, is scheduled to be sentenced to 20 years in prison for manslaughter, Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said in a statement. Prosecutors said Mr. Almonte, a bodega owner, strangled his wife, Cesarina Colon, 32, on Oct. 23, 2004, at the family home. He left her body, along with her daughter, in a vehicle he parked about a mile away, prosecutors said. A pedestrian who spotted the body called 911, and firefighters rescued the child, who was strapped into her car seat, prosecutors said.
A skein of look-alike, sound-alike, seem-alike advertising campaigns is raising eyebrows along Madison Avenue.
A judge in Rhode Island has ruled that some of the 400 or so 17-year-olds treated as adults in the criminal justice system should have their cases moved to Family Court.
Stephon Marbury disappeared again Monday afternoon, not because of an aversion to his coach, but because of a much stronger impulse: to avoid television cameras, microphones and notepads.
The average weekly pretax pay for people who worked at investment banks and brokerage houses in Manhattan was $16,918 in the first three months of this year.

Separatist rebels fighting in the Ogaden region of Ethiopia accused the government on Monday of strafing nomads in recent days at a watering hole with helicopter gunships, killing up to a dozen civilians.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 (Reuters) — The hedge fund company Eton Park Capital Management said Monday that it would take over R6 Capital Management in January, in one of the first prominent acquisitions in the $2 trillion hedge fund industry.
On Nov. 11, members of the United States women’s national soccer team found themselves facedown on the floor of their bus as irate fans pelted it with rocks.

Federal prosecutors have issued grand jury subpoenas to some of the Blackwater employees present at a Sept. 16 shooting in Baghdad, Iraq, in which the company’s security personnel killed 17 Iraqi civilians.
Rachel K. Paulose, the United States attorney in Minnesota, said that she would step down to go to work at the Justice Department in Washington on legal policies.
Carl C. Icahn holds 13.2 million shares of Blockbuster Class A shares, according to a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
United Rentals, the rental equipment provider, sued the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management Monday over its cancellation of a $4 billion buyout of the company.
Even though murders in New York have declined to relatively low levels, the city still has more than its share of dopes with guns who shoot and don’t care where the bullets land.

Jay Cutler threw touchdown passes of 41 and 48 yards and the little-known Glenn Martinez and Andre Hall added to Denver’s slew of big scoring plays last night in a 34-20 victory over the visiting Tennessee Titans that left the Broncos tied for first place in the American Football Conference’s West Division.
The vote enables the guild to call a strike at any time, although a walkout is not imminent. A strike could affect CBS television and radio newscasts, both nationally and in four local markets.
Miss Phillips took the utilitarian craft of knitting and gave it bold new life as a modern art form to be displayed on the walls of museums around the world.
New drivers, a potential power shift to Toyota and perhaps a return to form by Dale Earnhardt Jr. will be some of the story lines in an ever-changing Nascar in 2008.
Norway’s decision to shut its career consulate in Minneapolis has upset residents of the Upper Midwest, which is home to more Norwegian-Americans than any other region of the country.
Linebacker Mathias Kiwanuka has a broken left leg and is out for the season, and the fleet of running backs is no longer deep as Brandon Jacobs has a sore left hamstring.
BORN: Jan. 24, 1964, in New York.
Mr. Wilson, a British-born character actor, won American television fame as Mr. Whipple, the comically fussy star of two decades of Charmin toilet paper commercials.

SEATTLE, Nov. 19 (AP) — The luxury retailer Nordstrom said on Monday that third-quarter earnings rose 22 percent, helped by an extra week of sales the company counted in the quarter compared with a year ago.
Amway, the door-to-door peddler of vitamins and soap, is pouring millions of dollars into a new online store called Fanista, which will initially sell DVDs and CDs.
The Philadelphia Eagles got some good news: quarterback Donovan McNabb does not have a high ankle sprain, just a regular one that may not even keep him out of Sunday’s game.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 19 (AP) — Xerox announced its first quarterly cash dividend in six years on Monday and predicted double-digit earnings growth in the coming years, citing new products and a stronger balance sheet.

The Thanksgiving speech was intended to show the more contemplative side of the president, who, his aides say, has been struck by the goodness of the many ordinary Americans he meets during his travels.
Representative Mike Ferguson’s unexpected decision to retire rather than face the prospect of a tough race in 2008 sent Republican officials scrambling to find a candidate to replace him.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 19 (AP) — The Lowe’s Companies, the nation’s second-largest home improvement chain, said Monday that its third-quarter profit fell 10.2 percent, citing a weak sales environment amid a continuing slump in the housing sector.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,861 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
NEW YORK.

The U.C.L.A. freshman Kevin Love adjusted after being frustrated by Maryland’s early physical play, scoring 18 points and grabbing 16 rebounds last night to help second-ranked Bruins overcome a sloppy first half in a 71-59 victory over Maryland in the semifinals of the CBE Classic in Kansas City, Mo.

Northern Rock said on Monday that it had received a number of disappointing takeover proposals, increasing the pressure on the British government to either find a solution or consider nationalizing the bank.
The company said second-quarter earnings fell 2 percent from a year ago as the recall of a component used with its implantable devices to treat abnormal heart rhythms hurt revenue.
The Campbell Soup Company posted a 7 percent decline in first-quarter profit yesterday, hurt by higher costs and lower soup sales in the United States, but stood by its full-year earnings forecast.
Apple won dismissal of a lawsuit claiming that company directors and managers, including the chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, lied to shareholders about the backdating of option awards.
The announcement by the prosecutor, Rachel K. Paulose, came after reports of new staff turmoil in her office.
President Nicolas Sarkozy’s stealth strategy may reflect the fact that public opinion is not overwhelmingly on the side of the strikers.
Hotels and airports are gradually catching on to the fact that mobile workers need more help getting their jobs done on the road.
New York City is acquiring South Brother Island, the last East River island of any significant size to remain in private hands.
When I travel, I have learned to cope with airline security, check-ins and some inevitable questions. The first: “Is that your real name?”
The overall number of Americans traveling during the Thanksgiving holiday season will rise by a slight 1.5 percent this year.
Michael Mukasey should release the Justice Department’s long-secret legal opinions that have warped our fight against terrorism.
How long must creative people wait for the Web’s new wealth to find a path to their doors?
As many of the country’s finest physicians have taken posts abroad, doctors and nurses in Cuba are left overworked, resulting in a decline in the quality of care for Cubans.

The Tribeca Film Institute and Gucci have joined to create the Gucci Tribeca Documentary Fund, which will offer financing and production guidance to help independent filmmakers complete documentaries that promote social change, focusing on issues neglected by the mainstream news media.

Fox’s animated comedy lineup ranked No. 1 on Sunday among adults 18 to 49, as “The Simpsons” and “Family Guy” (with the guest star Wallace Shawn providing the voice of Stewie’s archrival, Bertram, below) earned the night’s top ratings in that age group.

The Tribeca Film Institute and Gucci have joined to create the Gucci Tribeca Documentary Fund, which will offer financing and production guidance to help independent filmmakers complete documentaries that promote social change, focusing on issues neglected by the mainstream news media. The fund will provide grants totaling $80,000 to a minimum of three filmmakers in 2008 and will be administered by the Tribeca Film Institute. Recipients will be selected by the Tribeca Film Institute, along with Gucci and a selection committee of documentary filmmakers. All documentary filmmakers who have projects in production or postproduction may apply. Applications can be sent from Feb. 5 to April 11, 2008. Recipients will be announced next summer. Information: tribecafilmfestival.org.
Nicole Kidman told a jury in Sydney, Australia, that she had been reduced to tears and feared a car accident as she was chased by a celebrity photographer two years ago.
“Dirty Sexy Money,” the freshman drama on ABC, has been picked up for a second season.
The siblings Vanessa, Lynn and Corin Redgrave have joined the journalists, military officials, entertainers and academics participating in “A Question of Impeachment.”
Brian May, the guitarist in the band Queen, has been appointed chancellor of Liverpool John Moores University, The Associated Press reported.
Ex-Getty curator is now on trial in Greece, the family Redgrave, together onstage, from queen to academe and more culture news.

A former antiquities curator for the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles went on trial yesterday in Athens on charges of conspiring to acquire an ancient gold funerary wreath that Greek officials say was illegally removed from Greek soil about 15 years ago.
Natalie Merchant, who came to fame with 10,000 Maniacs in 1981, will play five or six shows — her first live appearances in four years — at Club Hiro in New York.
Former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi is forming a new political party to propel him back to power, vowing Monday to go forward without his allies on the center-right.
When Nergal, the leader of the long-running Polish metal band Behemoth, starts a concert by growling, “Get ready for chaos,” he’s not kidding.

A security guard along with 20 other people who had been riding in a truck were arrested Monday after the guard shot a teenage girl in central Baghdad.

Samsung sustained another blow to its image on Monday when a former legal adviser to South Korean President Roh Moo Hyun said the company had once offered him a cash bribe.
There is an East-West divide over stem-cell research and genetic engineering.
The new building delivers on Modernism’s promise to drag us — in this case, The Times — out of the Dark Ages.
The Philippine president suggested that her country might not ratify a new regional charter unless Myanmar committed to democratic reforms and released Aung San Suu Kyi.
In an apparent attempt to speed his return to football, Michael Vick began serving his prison sentence today.
Works & Process at the Guggenheim, the museum’s stimulating performing arts series, selected five compositions by Jo Kondo, then had Robert  Wilson stage them.

If the “The Rite of Spring” fairy tale had a happily-ever-after, Yvonne Rainer’s “RoS Indexical,” which had its New York premiere on Sunday at the Hudson Theater as part of Performa 07, would be the last attempt.
As Americans carve up their Thanksgiving turkeys this year, an age-old question will come into play: dark meat or white?
If you are an Army doctor caring for patients, you do your duty, complete your mission.
Bob Clyman’s play is a taut, twist-filled and appealingly cynical drama about the culture of high-stakes science.
Ehud Olmert and Mahmoud Abbas met to try to salvage efforts to agree on a short written text before an international peace gathering planned for next week, but some issues have yet to be resolved.

The company’s stock dropped the most since March 2003 after the announcement, which came two weeks after the company said its exposure to U.S. subprime mortgage woes would be limited.
Scientists are using a controversial genetic engineering process to change the composition of the wood in the hopes of  turning  trees into new energy sources.

To celebrate his 50th birthday — and also to benefit a scholarship fund at Ben Gurion University of the Negev, in Israel — the violinist Shlomo Mintz played Paganini’s caprices, all 24, at Carnegie Hall on Sunday.
The elegant reduction of physics and psychology to a single symmetry still has artistic influence long after science abandoned it, as the American Symphony Orchestra’s reminded us.
With a quarter of its annual budget slashed, the Arecibo radio telescope will be listening to the universe less often in the coming years.
New this week are two films starring Susan Hayward and a deluxe edition of “I Am Cuba.”
In evolution, host and parasite can engage in a kind of arms race. One side adapts and evolves; the other side adapts and evolves to keep up.
The ability to look the other way, while potentially destructive, is also critically important to forming and nourishing close relationships.
Alex Rodriguez won his third M.V.P. award Monday and is close to completing a 10-year contract with the Yankees, who have all but completed their three-year, $45 million deal for Mariano Rivera.
After one sister was diagnosed with diabetes, the other enrolled in a study aimed at delaying or preventing the disease in some patients.
Patient transporters help keep hospitals running smoothly while acting as a kind of bellhop and parking attendant, rolled into one.
A provincial governor in southwestern Afghanistan narrowly escaped a suicide attack Monday, but his 25-year-old son and five of his bodyguards were killed in the blast.

The study could not determine, however, whether hearing-impaired children were at higher risk of injury.
Researchers who followed the health of older people for almost a decade found that those who walked more quickly were less likely to die.
Smokers who were given nicotine-reduced cigarettes for five weeks and then allowed to return to their regular brands ended up smoking less, according to a small study.
Urban residents are more likely to see a doctor later than those in the country are, a new study suggests.
More often than not, chronic pain is untreated or undertreated, but it does not have to be this way.
Lloyd Carr announced Monday that he is retiring as  the University of Michigan football coach, putting L.S.U.’s Les Miles, a possible successor to Carr, in a difficult spot.
The former Khmer Rouge head of state Khieu Samphan is the last of five top leaders targeted by prosecutors.
Pakistan’s Supreme Court, which was appointed after emergency rule was imposed, dismissed the main  challenges to Gen. Pervez Musharraf’s election on Monday.
Where does that famous ant that can lift something like 20 times its weight get its power?
Researchers have studied jade ornaments from Southeast Asia to determine the extent of the trading of the prized substance.
The storm uprooted or severely damaged roughly 320 million trees, making an impact on the carbon balance in the region.
Somalia has higher malnutrition rates, more current bloodshed and many fewer aid workers than Darfur.
The New York city comptroller estimated that the city is losing about $2 million a day because of the strike.
In recent years, Holiday Inn, now owned by InterContinental Hotels Group of London, has recovered from its decline and is expanding aggressively.
Aurea Casellas, a mother of two, is slowly piecing together a brighter future with the help of a nonprofit organization.
We salute the great Alex Rodriguez for his powerbroker’s enlistment of a virtual league of American business savants in pursuit of the capitalist dream with a self-serving spin.
Alex Rodriguez won the American League Most Valuable Player award, and in so doing gained a $1.5 million bonus under the contract he opted out of three weeks ago.
Lines at the airport’s security checkpoints moved briskly, which had travelers and airport officials smiling.
To alleviate the anticipated pre-Thanksgiving jam in the New York area, traffic was rerouted  and  airspace was borrowed  from Canada.
To Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the Broadway labor dispute does not look all that bad.
“I don’t want this to be about me being a celebrity, about me getting my name in the paper,” said James J. Claffey Jr., the man who represents striking Broadway stagehands.
If it’s live performance you want during the Broadway strike, hope springs eternal. But how to spend your ticket money?
What’s missing from the eight Broadway shows still running is the very thing that promised to make this season distinct: a strong new drama.

Congo has announced the establishment of a rain forest preserve intended to protect the bonobo, one of human beings’ two closest ape relations.

MEYER--Richard M., 73, on November 18th, 2007 of New York City and formerly of New Rochelle, New York. Husband of June, father of David and Pamela, stepfather of Sylvine and grandfather of eight. Member of the New York Bar. A Graduate of Yale University and Yale Law School. Service will be held on November 20th at 12:45pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, Donation may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research or the UJA's Lawyer Division in Richard's name.

An article in some editions on Nov. 7 about Almaz Kelib, a Manhattan woman whose son has muscular dystrophy and who received money for furnishings and back rent from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, misidentified the agency that gave them the money. It is the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, not UJA-Federation of New York. (UJA-Federation, one of the beneficiary agencies of the Neediest Cases Fund, distributes money raised by the fund to the Jewish Board and other agencies.)

RUSKIN--Herbert B., attorney, a longtime White Plains resident died Saturday at his home from complications of Parkinson's Disease, he was 80 years old. Born in Detroit on April 23, 1927, he graduated from the University of Michigan in 1949 and from Harvard Law School in 1952. He married Barbara Joan Kreis on July 13, 1952. He practiced law briefly in Detroit and practiced with his father-in-law Maurice M. Kreis in Manhattan. He specialized in Maritime Law. He retired from the practice of law in 2002. He is survived by wife Barbara of 55 years, a brother Robert of West Bloomfield, MI, four children, Judith, James (Anne), Maureen (Jon), Steven (Joan) and nine grandchildren. Family is requesting charitable donations in lieu of flowers.

WEINTRAUB--Billie. Temple Sinai of Bergen County deeply mourns the passing of our member, Billie Weintraub, wife of Emanuel Weintraub. Condolences are extended to the entire family. Dr. Bruce S. Block, Rabbi Janene Edlin, President

Most years, it might appear unseemly to mix presidential politics with Thanksgiving. But rules of political etiquette may not apply this year, considering the holiday falls six weeks before voting begins. So don't look for Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware to be heading home. His campaign announced that he intends to spend Thanksgiving volunteering to help serve meals at the Machine Shed Restaurant outside Des Moines.

Some voters outside the early voting states have been grumbling lately about all the attention being paid to the people of Iowa and New Hampshire. But voters in those two states seem to be taking their civic duty seriously. A New York Times/CBS News poll conducted Nov. 2 to 11 in Iowa found that 56 percent of caucusgoers said they had gone to a campaign event or seen a candidate in person. The exposure was even higher among Democrats, with more than 6 in 10 saying they had been to a campaign event, while fewer than half of Republicans had attended an event.

GLASGOW--Vicki (Estelle). Friends and family mourn the loss of this amazing woman who died on November 3rd, nine days shy of her 89th birthday. A model for Gimbel's in her youth, she was the devoted wife of Robert for over 40 years. Vicki owned an antique store in New York and was a collector of and expert on antique music boxes. She will be sorely missed.

At a regional meeting meant to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, the Philippine president, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, suggested that her country might not ratify a new, European Union-like regional charter unless Myanmar committed to democratic reforms. Meanwhile, Reuters reported that Burmese state television showed Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the opposition leader held under house arrest for much of the last 18 years, meeting with a junta official for the third time since popular protests were crushed in September.

ELLIS--Moish. We deeply regret the passing of Moish Ellis, ''A Proud Turk,'' our esteemed Board Member and Co-Chairman of the House Committee, generous benefactor, and friend of the Sephardic Nursing and Rehabilitation Center. He was dedicated in his commitment to the home and our residents. We extend our deepest sympathy and condolences to his children, Keith and Ellen and granddaughter Justine. Sephardic Nursing and Rehabilitation Center Michael R. Lopez, President Clifton Russo, Chm. of the Bd. Michael New, Exec. Dir. --Moish, 86, of Brooklyn, NY died on November 17, 2007. Loving father of I. Keith (Ellen), adoring grandfather of Justine, husband of the late Lee Ergas, brother of Vivian Schwartz and ''Uncle Moish'' to the world. Member of the Board of the Sephardic Nursing and Rehabilitation Center, President of the Friendship, Truth & Benevolent Society of Kastoryalis and the Gabai of its Synagogue, Leader of the Broome and Allen Boys Association, Founding partner of Maylis Associates. Served in the U.S. Navy, Pacific theater, for the duration of WWII. He had a passion for the Sephardic Jewish community and dedicated his life to the preservation of the Spanish and Portuguese Jewish heritage. Donations in his memory may be made to any charity of your choice.

Mike Huckabee, the Republican presidential candidate and former Southern Baptist minister, is getting help from Tim LaHaye, the Christian conservative organizer and co-author of the apocalyptic ''Left Behind'' novels. ''America and our Judeo-Christian heritage are under attack by a force that is more destructive than any America has faced'' since Hitler,Dr. LaHaye and his wife, Beverly, wrote in letters sent to lists of conservative Christians in Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina. ''Defeating the radical jihadists will require renewed resolve and spiritual rearmament by the evangelical pastors in America.''

BRU--Dorothea Thelma Georgina, passed away Sunday, November 11, 2007 in NH following complications of a stroke suffered in July. She was 83. Formerly of Long Island, NY, she and her husband, Malcolm, retired to Vermont in 1995. She will be deeply missed by her daughter Elizabeth; son Ronald; and many family and friends. Predeceased by husband and daughter, Georgina Ann Bru. Contributions in her memory can be made to: CHAD C/O Child Life Program. Children's Hospital of Dartmouth, One Medical Center Drive, Hanover, NH 03756.

The former Khmer Rouge head of state Khieu Samphan, who was taken from a hospital in Phnom Penh and arrested, will join three other members of the regime's central committee and the commandant of its most notorious torture house in a detention center at the headquarters of the international tribunal set up to bring Khmer Rouge leaders to justice. Mr. Khieu Samphan, 76, is the last of the top leaders sought by prosecutors in advance of trials expected to begin next year. In a book published last week, Mr. Khieu Samphan calls Khmer Rouge a popular uprising, and he says its atrocities were carried out by brutal and uneducated lower-ranking cadres.

HUBNER--Robert W., died on November 15, 2007, in Vero Beach, Florida, after a protracted illness. He was 89 years old. Bob was born in Tacoma, Washington, and graduated from West Seattle High School in 1936. After graduating from the University of Washington with a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1941 and service in the U.S. Army, he joined the International Business Machines Corporation. Bob was made IBM vicepresident of marketing in 1965. He retired from IBM as a senior vice-president and member of the Corporate Management Committee in 1978. He was a director of the IBM World Trade Corporation and the IBM World Trade Europe/Middle East/Africa Corporation. He served on the boards of the FMC Corporation, the Marine Midland Banks, the Hong Kong Shanghai Bank, Baldwin Technology Corporation, International Income Properties, Inc. and the F. M. Schaefer Corporation. Bob was a member of the Advisory Board to the Graduate School of Business, University of Washington and a member of the New York Urban Coalition. Bob Hubner was a lifelong sailor. He began racing on Lake Washington in a 6-meter named ''Fun,'' and later competed successfully for many years in ocean races in a series of yachts named ''Kate.'' He chaired the ''Clipper'' syndicate in the 1980 America's Cup defense. He was a trustee of the New York Yacht Club and the Cruising Club of America and was a trustee and commodore of the Edgartown Yacht Club. Bob was a founder of Operation Sail, Inc., the organization that has brought tall ships from around the world to five Parades of Sail in New York Harbor. He served on the boards of the South Street Seaport Museum, the Norwalk Maritime Aquarium and the National Trust for Historic Preservation. He was an avid cook, skier, golfer and musician who excelled in piano, accordion, trumpet, coronet, saxophone and clarinet. He helped put himself through college by playing jazz on cruise ships to the Orient during the summers. His other club memberships included the Weeburn Country Club, the Edgartown Reading Room, the Brooke, the Pilgrims of the U.S., the Metropolitan Club (Washington, D.C.) and the Riomar Country Club. He was predeceased in 1996 by his first wife Kay, the former Katherine Lorraine Huick, to whom he was married in 1942. He is survived by his wife Patricia, the former Patricia Gillespie Stolar, his daughter Melissa B. Hubner, his son, Robert W. Hubner, Jr. and his two grandchildren, Tennessy Kay Hubner and Paris Toby Hubner. He was a wonderful husband, father and friend whose wisdom, strength, humor, gentleness, elegance and love will be in the hearts of his family forever. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be gratefully received at the Visiting Nurse Association & Hospice Foundation, 1110 36th Street, Vero Beach, FL 32960. A memorial service will be held 11am, Monday, November 26, 2007 at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, CT.

LOEB--Mady (Charlotte E. Loeb, nee Schlomann), was born in Munich, Germany in 1913. She immigrated to the USA in 1938 and started soon afterward The Handicraft Art Studio in Manhattan, handcrafted lamp shades and book bindings, a trade she learned in pre-World War Germany. She joined her late husband's firm, Marcel Loeb and Co. importers and exporters of steel, as financial officer until her retirement in 1982. She was a resident of Woodstock, New York and Manhattan. Devoted widow of the late Marcel Loeb, she is survived by the loving children, their spouses and children, of her late brother, Ernst A. Schlomann. Surviving nieces and nephews are Elizabeth Lowe McCoy, Margaret E. Jaret, Frederick Schlomann, Robert H. Schlomann and Alfred K. Schlomann. Services Tuesday 11:30am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

11 P.M. (TBS) FRANK TV You could call it a multiple-personality disorder. The impersonator Frank Caliendo has made his name mimicking celebrities from John Madden and Dr. Phil to Jack Nicholson, Al Pacino and President Bush. In this new comedy series Mr. Caliendo, above left as Mr. Madden, riffs on modern society in stand-up routines and sketches, and introduces a few new characters to his roster, including Jay-vid Lenoman, a combination of Jay Leno and David Letterman. 8 P.M. (CBS) NCIS The team goes into the woods searching for the survivalist father of a 9-year-old boy.

A front-page article on Sunday about Jeff Novitzky, a special agent for the I.R.S. who is the government's leading investigator of doping in sports, misstated the name of a performance-enhancing drug and referred imprecisely to one of Mr. Novitzky's high school athletic accomplishments. The drug is erythropoietin, a blood-boosting hormone; there is no steroid known as eritropotin. Although Mr. Novitzky indeed cleared 7 feet in the high jump, he did not set a state record.

LEVINE--Sadie, 96. Devoted wife of the late Moe. Dedicated mother to beloved children Alan and Gail, Michael and Susan. Loyal sister to Pauline Cohen and the late Louis Soss. Loving grandma to Sheryl, Laura, Adam and Michelle and great-grandmother. Aunt Sadie played a huge role in the lives of her forever grateful nieces and nephews. We all feel so privileged to have known her. We will not see the likes of her for a long, long time. Graveside service to be held November 21, 2007 at New Montefiore Cemetery at 11:30am. Memorial contributions may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York at www.vnsy.org.

There was a particularly striking number in The New York Times/CBS News poll of Iowa caucusgoers last week. It told the story of the complicated -- and cool-- relationship that Senator John McCain has always had with Republicans in Iowa. The number was 4, the percentage of Iowa Republicans who said they would support him.

WHERE THE PROFITS ARE American companies are enjoying hefty profits overseas. Sales at the heavy-equipment maker Caterpillar, for example, have risen by a third in Europe and by 20 percent in Latin America while demand for its products wanes in the United States. STRONG EARNINGS FOR H.P.Hewlett-Packard, the world's largest technology company, reported fourth-quarter sales and earnings that exceeded its performance of a year ago and that also beat Wall Street's projections. Helped by its international presence, Hewlett-Packard seems to have escaped some of the softening demand for new technology from corporations inside the United States. Mark Hurd, above, the chief executive of H.P., said that overall, ''We're seeing fairly steady demand.'' [C1.].
DePINNA--Marcia. Mommy, Happy 85th Birthday. Not a day goes by that I don't think of you. Miss you so very much. All my love, Janie

EAKINS--Jean P., of Locust Valley, Long Island on November 17, 2007. Beloved wife of the late William S. Mother of Pamela Wharton (Frank), Penelope McMillan and William. Grandmother of Holly Marshall (Tucker), Amy Nelson and Amelia Eakins. Great-grandmother of Tucker Marshall Jr. Service St. John's of Lattingtown Wednesday, November 21 at 2pm. Interment private. Donations may be made to: Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Blvd., Woodbury, NY 11797 or St. John's of Lattingtown, P.O. Box 448, Locust Valley, NY 11560.
STEINBERGER--Erno Jona, 84, Holocaust survivor. Beloved Husband of Rachel, Loving father of Michael (Ronnie) and Harry (Janie), grandfather and great-grandfather. Funeral Services held in Israel.

ROSADO--Roberto. Your wisdom, spirit, humor, tenacity, joy, courage, and warmth will sorely be missed but will live on in our hearts and of all those who were blessed to have known you. With all our love, The Cats & Dogs, Mad Dogs, Adam Weprin

The Advertising column in Business Day on Friday, about the integration of advertising into online video programs called Webisodes, misstated the title of one such series. It is ''Hollywood Fast Track,'' not ''Hollywood Fast Lane.''

KLUGMAN--Shirley (nee Rich), 90, a graduate of Brooklyn College, died peacefully on November 19th, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Guiding and generous spirit of a large and loving family who absolutely adored her. She sang rather than talked and skipped rather than walked. She always said ''maybe'' instead of ''no''. Devoted mother of Peter Klugman (Sandra (Marthanne deceased)), Nancy Rubin (Ronald), Jane Ockers (Thomas). Grandmother of Deborah Wittig, Rebekah Munyan (Matthew), David Miller-Klugman (Amy), Michael Rubin (Bernadette), Jennifer Rubin, Matthew Ockers, Daniel Ockers, and enriching her later years, great-grandmother to Sarah, Benjamin, Joelle Wittig, Morgan, Amanda, Hannah Munyan, Timothy, Brennan, Andrew, Kelsey Miller-Klugman. Known for her wit, wisdom, and insight, her courage and unconditional love brightened the lives of all who knew her. She will be dearly missed. In lieu flowers, donations may be made to Brookhaven Memorial Hospital, 101 Hospital Road, Patchogue, NY 11772. Interment Tuesday 1pm, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

ARNOFF--Arthur E., 87, died on November 18. He was a graduate of the Horace Mann School and the Wharton School of Business. During WWII, he served in the Navy on the aircraft carrier USS Ranger in the Pacific and on the USS Pasadena in the Atlantic. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Peggy House Arnoff, his four children: Linda Mackay of Hanover, NH, Ellen Sonis of Sherborn, MA, Arthur (Peter) Arnoff, Jr. of Katonah, NY and Polly Arnoff of Bath, ME, his sisters Shirley A. Baerwald and Betty A. Prashker of New York City, and six grandchildren. Donations in his name can be made to the Nantucket Conservation Foundation, P.O. Box 13, Nantucket, MA 02554.

A picture caption with an article on Saturday about anxiety in a divided Lebanon as the deadline for selecting a new president nears mistranslated an Arabic phrase on a billboard for the Lebanese news channel Future TV. It says, ''Before you are dragged back'' -- a reference to the possibility of the country's being forced back into civil war; it does not say, ''Before it is repeated.''
The healthiest food on the holiday menu may soon be in short supply.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s announcement that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had identified $220 million in unanticipated revenue and would use the money to keep the base subway and bus fare at $2 dominated local news coverage this morning.
All week, major New York City department stores have been unveiling their decorated holiday windows, which by some estimates draw more than 6,000 viewers per hour at the peak of the season.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is anticipating a record number of travelers — nearly 1.7 million — at its four major airports over the five-day holiday travel period that starts today and ends on Sunday.

He has one of the best-known family names in Queens politics. And, after years in the City Council, Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr. says he is seriously considering running for borough president — though he is unlikely to have the field to himself.

Once the basketball arena at Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn gets built — assuming it does get built — it should be fairly obvious where it is. But until now, the precise location of where the arena is going to be has proved strangely elusive.The location matters, somewhat, because elected officials and opponents of the $4 billion Atlantic Yards project have raised questions about security at the site based on the arena setback. In Newark, where a new arena recently opened, that city decided at the last minute that at 20 feet from the curb, the arena was too close to the street for comfort, so now Newark closes streets around its arena during events.

By now, it’s become part of the conventional wisdom that Rudolph W. Giuliani is both predicating much of his presidential candidacy on his two terms as mayor here and also running against New York City, as a symbol of American liberalism.In a new advertisement (as political blogs, including The New York Observer’s, have pointed out), Mr. Giuliani promotes his record on cutting crime, slashing welfare rolls and holding the line on taxes in New York City. The ad describes New York as “America’s most liberal city.”

Earlier this week, City Room noted that Charmin, the toilet paper manufacturer, had installed 20 temporary restrooms on a mezzanine in a Broadway office building, providing a public convenience that is often hard to find. Surprisingly, the toilets are attracting international attention.
The parade weather is expected to be nice for Thanksgiving Day, but watch out for the balloon menace. [The Mayor of Television]

Word comes from Pakistan that Mukhtar Mai is up against tough times in the wake of the political crisis. Nick first wrote about her three years ago after she had been gang-raped on order of a local tribal council. Tradition in rural Pakistan would have had her commit suicide, but instead she prosecuted her attackers. She won her case and used the compensation money to start schools for girls. We visited her earlier this year in her village, Meerwalla.

The average price for U.K. farmland is rising at the fastest rate in 30 years, according to Knight Frank, the property company. Values jumped 33.2 percent in 2007, hitting £4,178 per acre in the third quarter (€5,798), compared to £3,137 a year earlier (€4,353).

One thing I have been meaning to do as a regular feature since this blog started, but never got around to doing even once (I think), is to do a little roundup of news and views that appeal to me at other sites. So here's a glance at the latest talk on a few blogs and other sites:

Charlie Brown and the semifinal results on "Dancing With the Stars" delivered solid ratings for ABC on Tuesday, but the shows were no match for the eccentric doctor on Fox. The daily transcripts from Bill Belichick's news conference that the New England Patriots send out are typically some of the most interesting things that pop up in my in-box every day. Belichick is often portrayed as dry and confrontational by those who cover the N.F.L. Since I don't, the transcripts are often some of the most insightful things I read about football. Belichick may not talk much about injuries or running up the score or whatever the P.T.I. topic da jour is, but he has an astonishing grasp of football and its history. That's why I particularly enjoyed his take when the use of the spread offense in college football came up at his new conference today.

There are few people in the fashion world I like as much as Giancarlo Giammetti, Valentino's business partner and alter ego, even though we occasional disagree and he doesn't mince his words. Maybe that's the source of warmth. I remember his portrayal in Michael Specter's 2005 profile of Valentino, which captured, I think, the dynamic between these glamorous figures and their extended family, as well as Giammetti's frank personality. Some might call him politically incorrect. I don't think so. Anyway, what would you prefer? Giammetti and I met last week in his new apartment in New York. In January, of course, Valentino will retire.
Reports that residents of Baghdad are seeing commerce and movement finally increase as violence has declined in the city provided the leading edge of an altogether sunny week for news out of Iraq.
