If Sears Holdings, the parent of the retailers Sears and Kmart, decides to challenge Catteron Partners $366 million buyout of Restoration Hardware, it has a pretty good chance of winning, according to Breakingviews.
DP World, the Dubai-owned port operator with terminals from Britain to China, raised $4.96 billion in the Middle East's biggest initial public offering ever.
Delta Air Lines' pilots union on Tuesday reiterated its deep hostility to a hedge fund's recent proposal for a merger between Delta and the parent of United Airlines, UAL.
Copper Arch Capital, a New York-based hedge fund founded by Scott Sipprelle, a former banker at Morgan Stanley, is winding down operations, according to press reports.

Medingo, an Israeli medical device start-up, closed a first round of outside financing, raising as much as $27 million to support continued development and regulatory advancement of a patch pump to deliver insulin to patients with diabetes.

The private equity arms of the Quadrangle Group and Goldman Sachs have agreed to acquire a Norwegian cable group, GET, for 5.8 billion Norwegian kroner ($1.1 billion) in a secondary buyout from Candover Investments of London.
The Bank of America has reshuffled its investment management arm, as it continues to sort out senior staff changes at its investment bank.
After absorbing webMethods and seeing immediate returns from the deal, Software AG of Germany is shopping again.

Bear Stearns, which expects a fourth-quarter loss after writing down $1.2 billion linked to mortgages, got hit with a shareholder lawsuit that claims it should have known it was overexposed to subprime lending.

Shares of SuccessFactors, a human-resources software provider, climbed nearly 36 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday after the company's initial public offering of 10.8 million shares priced at the high end of the expected range.
the Dutch supermarket group Ahold is on the lookout for acquisitions in the regions where it has operations, its chief executive said on Wednesday.

The struggling British bank Northern Rock said it has received more rescue proposals, but warned that one of them contemplated an offer well below Tuesday's closing price, sparking a new slide in its shares on Wednesday.
Scottish & Newcastle 's chief executive, John Dunsmore, has signaled he would consider a partial break-up of the company, the biggest brewer in Britain, to guard its independence.

The Canadian government has approved the takeover of the PrimeWest Energy Trust by Abu Dhabi National Energy, but National Energy, which is owned by the Abu Dhabi government, will face new federal hurdles in its Canadian acquisition spree.

The biggest stock introduction on the Toronto Stock Exchange so far this year was given the green light Tuesday, setting the stage for the billion-dollar rebirth of Franco-Nevada, the Canadian gold and energy royalty company sold to Newmont Mining in 2002.
SolFocus has now raised a total of $63.6 million in series B funding to move into production of its solar power plants.

BlackRock, the big investment firm, is expected to be the main asset manager for a $75 billion fund being created by three large banks to help shore up the market for asset-backed securities, The New York Times reported.
Merrill Lynch ousted the co-head of its Asian fixed-income business Tuesday amid a management shake-up after $8.4 billion of losses on subprime mortgage-related securities and bad loans.

Meet "Bottom-Biting Bug" -- a Japanese cartoon insect who bites rear ends and social consciences. The critter's gone from an afternoon children's television program to karaoke favorite to live stage show. He's seen as a catalyst to end the everyday social isolation of Japanese:
Images from the exhibition at the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna.

They are the new Evil Empire, these Patriots. Stealing a moniker hard-earned by the Yankees, perhaps even coveted by the Red Sox. New England runs up scores, it breaks records. Through it all, though, SI.com's Peter King reminds us that Patriots Coach Bill Belichick is only human. On the other hand, ESPN.com's Liz Merrill goes to great lengths trying to come to the same conclusion. ...I don't mean to condone gambling but it seems noteworthy to point out that the early line has the Patriots a 23.5-point favorite over the Eagles this week, the largest point spread for an N.F.L. game not involving an expansion team. And it could get larger if Donovan McNabb doesn't play. ...While we're at it, Jackie MacMullan at the Boston Globe thinks there is something about the Patriots you've been overlooking. ...And, finally, here's this week's Tom Brady Watch.
The Fifth Down's contributors are Andrew Das, Benjamin Hoffman, Naila-Jean Meyers, John Woods and Toni Monkovic.
Villagers try to pick up the pieces following the devastation of Cyclone Sidr.

Screenwriters, represented by the Writers Guild of America East and the Writers Guild of America West, took to the streets of Hollywood with supporters from other unions on Tuesday afternoon in a demonstration that was meant to telegraph resolve. The show was complete with a performance by Alicia Keys and the presence of eight aging actors who played Munchkins in "The Wizard of Oz."

A streamlined technique
leads to a crusty loaf.
Filmed in real time during the freezing winter of 2000, “Yiddish Theater: A Love Story” tracks eight days in the failing life of the Yiddish Public Theater.
Among its many achievements, Todd Haynes’s “I’m Not There” hurls a Molotov cocktail through the facade of the Hollywood biopic factory.
Until the director Frank Darabont decides that he’s saying something important instead of making a nifty horror movie, “The Mist” isn’t half bad.
Based on the video game franchise of the same title, “Hitman” exploits every action-flick cliché imaginable and still manages to be dull.
Crispin Hellion Glover’s planned trilogy of blatant weirdness continues with a second installment, “It Is Fine! Everything Is Fine.”
“Enchanted” works its magic largely by sending up some of the very stereotypes that have long been Walt Disney Pictures’ profitable stock in trade.
“This Christmas” includes more family melodrama than all the holiday-homecoming flicks from the past decade combined.
To describe “August Rush” as a piece of shameless hokum doesn’t quite do justice to the potentially shock-inducing sugar content of this contemporary fairy tale.

In California, a longtime
promoter of French
wines holds his ground.
The Dow fell to its lowest level since April on a day when oil prices moved near the symbolic $100 level.
The Consumer Product Safety Commission is recalling more than 500,000 pieces of children’s jewelry from stores like Michael’s and Big Lots because they contained hazardous levels of lead.
A two-day hearing for the first Khmer Rouge defendant ended today with a clash by the lawyers over whether Kaing Guek Eav, known as Duch, would pose a threat if released on bail.

An ambulette driver was charged with vehicular assault and driving under the influence after his ambulette struck and critically injured a 12-year-old boy yesterday, the police said. The driver was identified as Juan Ortiz, 57. The boy, who was hit while trying to cross East 20th Street near First Avenue, was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, the police said.
An undercover operative’s attempt to buy a hand grenade in the Bronx last night ended with the suspected seller being fatally shot in the head as he tried to drive away.
Demand at New York City food pantries and soup kitchens jumped 20 percent this year, according to a survey released Tuesday.

Argentina lost its unbeaten record in World Cup qualifiers last night as Colombia took advantage of a first-half red card on Argentina’s Carlos Tevez to win their match by 2-1. Giancarlo Maldonado scored twice to lift host Venezuela to a 5-3 victory over Bolivia in another qualifying match. Argentina is in first place in the South American group with 9 points after four games. Colombia is second with 8.
Chuck Kobasew scored twice in the final minutes Tuesday night to help the Boston Bruins to a 4-2 comeback victory over the Maple Leafs in Toronto.
Mortgage lenders Countrywide, G.M.A.C., Litton and HomeEq have agreed to let many potentially distressed borrowers in California keep the initial low rates of their home loans.
Tony Parker scored 31 points and Manu Ginóbili scored 19 points to lead the San Antonio Spurs to a 95-83 win over the host Atlanta Hawks last night.
Marquette defended and hustled its way into the championship game of the Maui Invitational in Lahaina, Hawaii.

A group of investors led by the buyout firm J. C. Flowers & Company of the United States will bid about $1.8 billion for up to 32.6 percent of Shinsei Bank, putting more money into the Japanese bank it helped resurrect in one of the most lucrative private equity deals ever.
The budget airline EasyJet said full-year profit was up 62 percent as passenger numbers grew 13 percent.
Synthes, the world’s largest maker of devices to mend broken and malformed bones, won approval in the United States for a new spinal fusion strip.

Charges against a teenage driver involved in a fatal crash were dropped yesterday. The driver, Justin Martinez, 19, of Bronxville, had been charged with driving while impaired by drugs after the Nov. 7 crash on the Bronx River Parkway, which killed Bernard Cecere, 84, of Yonkers and his wife, Phyllis, 82. But in Yonkers City Court, it was revealed that blood test results showed that Mr. Martinez had not been using drugs or alcohol when his car collided with the couple’s vehicle.

New York City’s population has passed another milestone, officially topping 8.25 million. The Census Bureau originally reported that from mid-2005 to mid-2006, the population grew by a statistically insignificant 587 people, with gains in Manhattan and Staten Island. But the Department of City Planning challenged the census count, drawing on construction permits and other documents. Yesterday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced that the bureau had concurred that the city’s official count was 8,250,567, up more than 36,000 since the adjusted 2005 total. The mayor said the revisions would mean an additional $77 million in federal aid to the state by the end of the decade.

The Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union announced yesterday that it had organized more than 1,000 employees at nine H & M stores in Manhattan. Stuart Appelbaum, the union’s president, said the sales clerks, cashiers and other workers unionized through an expedited process.

Nearly five years to the day that a Stamford woman was found slain in her waterfront condo here, the authorities obtained a warrant on Nov. 6 to arrest a New York inmate serving a 25-year sentence for the attempted murder of her own husband. The Stamford police were seeking to extradite the woman, Sheila Davalloo, above, to stand trial in the killing of Anna Lisa Raymundo, 32, on Nov. 8, 2002. Ms. Davalloo was sentenced in April 2004 for stabbing her husband, Paul Christos, in 2003. The police said Ms. Davalloo tried to rid herself of both her husband and Ms. Raymundo, whose boyfriend, they said, she wanted to date. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A fire at a New Jersey hog farm Monday night killed nearly 1,000 pigs that were to be auctioned or slaughtered, fire officials said yesterday. Veterinarians were evaluating the health of the surviving swine as fire inspectors investigated the cause of the fire at Pig Farm Recycling. The fire was reported about 8 p.m. Monday and was not extinguished until around 3 a.m. yesterday, said Bob Rose, a Burlington County fire marshal. The state police said there had been about 1,700 hogs on the farm.

Three people died and two others were sickened by fumes at a North Babylon home, the Suffolk County Police said. The police said the deaths may have been caused by carbon monoxide poisoning. The bodies of Ricardo Pearce, 27, Tanisha Armstrong, 25, and Talani Johnson, 4, were discovered at 437 Route 27 when officers responded to a 911 call. The police said they removed a generator and kerosene heater from the home.

Tri-Built Construction, a New York drywall contractor, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to conspiring to defraud the carpenters’ union.. Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, said the two owners, Patrick N. McCaul and James D. McGonnell, had diverted at least $6.5 million from the union’s benefit funds. They face up to five years in prison and agreed to forfeit $1.5 million.

German producer-price inflation, an early indicator of price pressures in the economy, accelerated more than economists expected in October after the price of oil rose to a record and the cost of food surged.

A 2-year-old boy died yesterday after falling six stories from a window in his family’s apartment in Rego Park, the police said. The police did not release the child’s name. His mother, Sandra Perez, said he had crawled out the window while she was taking a shower, a law enforcement official said. The boy fell shortly after 8 a.m., the police said, and he was pronounced dead at Elmhurst Hospital Center at 8:45.

A front-page article in some editions yesterday about lower estimates of the number of H.I.V. infections worldwide misstated a researcher’s explanation for a drop in infection rates in some African countries. The researcher, Daniel Halperin of the Harvard School of Public Health, said surveys indicated that people in Kenya and Zimbabwe chose to have fewer sexual partners rather than to use condoms more often. He did not mention circumcision to prevent AIDS as a consideration in those countries.

A pop entry in the Week Ahead report in Arts & Leisure on Sunday misstated the dates for two concerts this week at Nokia Theater. Caetano Veloso ended its performance last night; it does not perform tonight and tomorrow. As noted, Youssou N’Dour performs tonight and tomorrow, but not on Friday.

Visiting Japan, the Dalai Lama floated the idea of breaking centuries of Tibetan Buddhist tradition by appointing his successor or letting high-ranking monks elect the next spiritual leader, the newspaper Sankei Shimbun reported.
A judge granted a reprieve to the chestnut tree that comforted Anne Frank as she hid from the Nazis, ruling in favor of conservationists who want to stop its being felled.

Cuba will hold elections on Jan. 20 to choose delegates for provincial assemblies and the National Assembly, the official newspaper Granma reported, in what could be the next step toward formally ending President Fidel Castro’s 48-year rule.

Manfo Kwaku Asiedu, a 34-year-old immigrant from Ghana who had admitted taking part in the botched July 21, 2005, suicide attacks on London’s transit system, was sentenced in London to 33 years in prison.
The government plans to convert 25.5 million acres of northern woodland into a new national park and wildlife protection area that will be one of North America’s largest conservation areas.

A parliamentary vote set for today to elect Lebanon’s next president has been put off until Friday as the country’s deeply divided political factions remain at loggerheads over who should replace Émile Lahoud, whose term expires that day.
A vice chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, who was expected to pour his own money into a bid for Congress, abruptly dropped out of the running Tuesday.
Floyd Landis filed his appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, setting in motion his last chance to regain the 2006 Tour de France title that was stripped because of a positive doping test.

The salaries of Penn State Coach Joe Paterno and the university’s top administrators must be disclosed by the state retirement system, the state Supreme Court ruled yesterday. The 4-to-2 decision said the Commonwealth Court, which had ordered the disclosure, balanced the public’s interest in knowing about retirement system finances against the effects disclosure might have on reputations and personal security. There has been speculation for years that Paterno is among the highest-paid coaches, but the numbers have never been made public.

Donato Hanover was named the 7-5 favorite in the $610,000 Breeders Crown 3-year-old Colt Trot at the Meadowlands Racetrack on Saturday night despite drawing post No. 10, the worst possible slot for his final start before he retires to stud.

A van driven by the former Alabama star running back Siran Stacy was struck by a pickup truck at an intersection in Dothan, Ala., late Monday. Six people were killed, including Stacy’s wife and four of his children, the police said. The driver of the second vehicle was also killed. The police said the pickup was on the wrong side of the four-lane road when it struck Stacy’s van on the passenger side.Stacy, 39, the first pick of the Philadelphia Eagles in the 1992 draft, was listed in stable condition in surgical intensive care in Dothan. His 3-year-old daughter, Shelly, was taken to Children’s Hospital in Birmingham, which did not release her condition.The victims were identified as Stacy’s wife, Ellen Stacy, 36; their children, Lequisa, 18; Bronson, 10; Sidney, 8; and Ellie, 2; and the other driver, Adam W. Wayman, 29.
Housing officials have identified 200 of New York City’s most poorly maintained apartment buildings and are renewing efforts to force their owners to repair hazards.
The Bush administration sought to ratchet up pressure on Congressional Democrats on Tuesday over a military spending bill for operations in Iraq and Afghanistan.
Sixteen days into a work stoppage, screenwriters and their employers are scheduled to talk on Monday for the first time since Nov. 4.
On a day of scattered violence across Iraq, American and Iranian officials said they would meet for a fourth round of talks aimed at stabilizing the country’s security.
After being fired as an Air Force reserve officer, Mr. Radulovich became a searing symbol of the excesses of anti-Communism in the 1950s.
The Federal Reserve expects economic growth to slow sharply next year, and policy makers there are worried that even this forecast may prove too optimistic.
Richard J. Codey, the president of the New Jersey Senate, emerged as the public official most determined to crack down on the harassment of women at Jets games.
Ian Smith, the former prime minister of Britain’s rebellious colony of Rhodesia, once promised that white rule in Africa would endure for 1,000 years.
John Kerry and John Edwards, running mates but never really friends, ended 2004 in recrimination and regrets.
The back and forth between Mitt Romney’s and Rudolph W. Giuliani’s presidential campaigns over illegal immigration continued Tuesday.
Three men were sentenced to prison Tuesday for their roles in chasing a gay man to his death in highway traffic in Brooklyn last year.

Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has decided to freeze plans for further reducing Army forces in Europe and will maintain about 40,000 soldiers in Germany and Italy, according to senior Pentagon and military officials.
What binds Thomas and Julius Jones, brothers and starting N.F.L. running backs, is their big, close family in a Virginia mining town.
Losses at the big mortgage finance company on Tuesday underscored the continuing turmoil in the housing industry.
NEW YORK.
The leading social conservative in the New Jersey State Senate accused Democrats of trying to rush a bill repealing the death penalty through the Legislature without sufficient deliberation.
Fingerprints provided a crucial clue in the murder of Dr. Daniel Malakov, and led to an arrest that linked the killing to an extended family feud.
Democrats convened the Senate for the first of four microsessions to be held during the holiday break, fearing that President Bush would again use a Congressional recess to install appointees.
Mike Lowell agreed to a three-year, $37.5 million contract with the Boston Red Socks Tuesday.
The Mets traded Guillermo Mota for starting catcher Johnny Estrada, and in doing so, got rid of a player who embarrassed them in 2007.
We hope that the Supreme Court will render a decision respectful of the Constitution and the consequences of denying government broad room to regulate guns.
Lawmakers in Congress will have to stand firm to enact more needed fixes to President Bush’s deeply flawed measure that encroaches on civil liberties.

An unlikely alliance between stores and Web sites that prematurely leak copies of discount-filled advertisements indicates how worried retailers are about the holiday shopping season.

But it turns out that a big source of the leaks are the retailers themselves.
The formula for financing mass transportation in New York City should be changed before any fares are raised by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
While the talent level has dipped with the loss of three first-round picks and two senior starters, there are still some very good players at Ohio State.
Officers are more likely to frisk, search, arrest or to use force against black or Hispanic people, a study found.
Logjams at Kennedy International Airport have become so bad in the past year that they have strained relations between the airlines and federal regulators.
The big investment firm is expected to be the main asset manager for a $75 billion fund being created by three large banks to help shore up the market for asset-backed securities.
The Republican presidential candidate Fred D. Thompson said the top federal tax rate for corporations should be cut, to 28 percent from 35 percent.

Lawmakers have given final approval to a law making San Francisco the nation’s largest city to issue identification cards to illegal immigrants. The Board of Supervisors voted 10 to 1 to create a municipal ID program to help residents without driver’s licenses obtain access to services and feel secure dealing with local law enforcement. The measure is modeled after a program that started last summer in New Haven, Conn. Supporters say that along with immigrants, elderly people who no longer drive and transgender individuals whose driver’s licenses no longer reflect their appearances also would benefit from having the cards. The measure goes into effect in August.

A graduate student charged in the car crash that killed the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist David Halberstam, left, pleaded no contest to a charge of misdemeanor vehicular manslaughter. Prosecutors and witnesses to the April 23 crash have said that the student, Kevin Jones, ran a red light while making an illegal left turn. Mr. Jones, a journalism student at the University of California, Berkeley, was driving Mr. Halberstam to an interview with the Hall of Fame quarterback Y. A. Tittle when the crash happened in Menlo Park. Mr. Jones, 27, will receive a maximum sentence of 30 days in the sheriff’s work program, Judge Mark Forcum said before convicting him. Sentencing is scheduled for Feb. 14. Mr. Jones had volunteered to drive Mr. Halberstam, 73, to the interview in response to an e-mail message from the journalism school’s alumni association saying that the author was looking for a driver who would get $20 an hour and a one-on-one journalism lesson.

Doctors reading the results of a blood test widely used to screen for prostate cancer can be fooled into thinking obese men are disease free, researchers reported in The Journal of the American Medical Association. The test may yield falsely reassuring results because obese people have more blood in their bodies because of their girth, diluting the concentration of the protein doctors use to detect the presence of tumors, researchers said. The prostate gland produces a protein called prostate-specific antigen, or P.S.A. If levels are higher, that suggests the cells are growing, which can be a sign of cancer, although an enlarged prostate can also send the levels up. Researchers examined records for nearly 14,000 men who had surgery for prostate cancer from 1988 to 2006. “It’s not that P.S.A. is a bad test in obese men.” Dr. Stephen Freedland, a researcher, said. “Rather, we just need to learn how to use it better.”.
The Bush administration finally acknowledged publicly on Tuesday that it had issued formal invitations for a heavily anticipated Middle East peace conference scheduled for next week.
The private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has hired as general counsel the lawyer who worked on several of its biggest deals, an indication that it may be moving ahead with plans to go public.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton tweaked Senator Barack Obama for saying on Monday that living overseas as a child had increased his experience in foreign relations.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer said Tuesday that an unexpected increase in ridership and other revenues have made a plan to raise the base subway fare unnecessary.
Tracking is an ancient art, if not a very happy one; the conscientious hunter prides himself on his ability to make a clean and swift kill.
A former ally of President Hugo Chávez , General Raúl Isaías Baduel has begun to speak out against the president’s plan to abolish term limits.
Warren S. Jeffs was sentenced Tuesday to 10 years to life in prison for forcing a 14-year-old girl to “spiritually” marry her 19-year-old cousin and submit to sexual relations against her will.
Unions, businesses and interest groups may run television and radio “issue ads” that name candidates in the days before elections, federal regulators said Tuesday, easing previous restrictions.
What is more humiliating for a player in the second half of a blowout defeat?.

The Indiana Utility Regulatory Commission approved Duke Energy’s application yesterday to build a new coal-fired power plant, and ordered the company to submit a plan within six months on how to capture some of the carbon dioxide it would produce.
Merrill Lynch ousted the co-head of its Asian fixed-income business amid a management shake-up after $8.4 billion of losses on subprime mortgage-related securities and bad loans.
The California secretary of state filed a lawsuit against a voting machine manufacturer for the alleged sale of uncertified machines to five counties.
In a rare miss for a company that more often surprises shareholders with positive news, the retailer Target reported a 4 percent drop in third-quarter profits yesterday.

Barnes & Noble raised its earnings outlook yesterday, after swinging to a third-quarter profit on sales of new releases. Losses widened in the same period at its rival, the Borders Group, which was hurt by charges related to the sale of its subsidiaries in Britain and Ireland.
A $3.7 million race discrimination judgment that had threatened to shut down the district attorney’s office will be paid largely by the state and the city, officials announced.
Pepperidge Farm is creating a Web site devoted to social networking and targeted at women who are looking to improve their social lives.
John D. Rock was a blunt-talking General Motors executive who tried unsuccessfully to save the Oldsmobile division.
The Supreme Court is plunging into a debate over how to interpret the Second Amendment’s guarantee of the “right of the people to keep and bear arms.”
In two communities west of St. Louis, the annual Thanksgiving Day high school football game between Webster Groves and Kirkwood is a quintessentially Norman Rockwell event.
Steelers strong safety Troy Polamalu and wide receiver Santonio Holmes seem certain to miss at least one game and possibly more with injuries sustained in a loss to the Jets.
An improving school in Beach Channel, Queens, was rattled this year by the violent or criminal behavior of several dozen students.
An alternative method of developing embryonic stem cells will allow people on both sides to say they have fruitful research to pursue.
Ringo, an undersized center who played 15 seasons in the National Football League, was elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1981.

A federal judge warned Tuesday that if the government did not allow lawyers to review classified material on possible wiretapping of an Islamic scholar convicted of inciting terrorism, she might order a new trial for him.
A look at the items delivered recently to mailrooms at universities across the country reflects students’ tastes and online shopping habits.
The Yankees are not used to much off-season activity from their manager, but Joe Girardi is different, and they like it.
A delay in publishing the results of trials on cholesterol  drugs is raising questions for the drug industry.
The president of the United Automobile Workers union said Tuesday he was concerned by General Motors’ exposure to the mortgage lending arm of its former finance.
Jittery investors decided to interpret comments from the Federal Reserve as suggesting another interest rate cut.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,864 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
On the back of record profit so far this year, Goldman Sachs is starting a donor-driven philanthropy fund that aims to reach $1 billion over the next few years.
The Republican-supported initiative would replace California’s winner-take-all system of allocating its 55 electoral college votes with one that allots the votes by Congressional district.
The Swedish telecommunications equipment maker  offered a downbeat outlook Tuesday for fourth-quarter sales, sending its shares tumbling.
The Hormel Foods Corporation said yesterday that quarterly profit rose a better-than-expected 12 percent, helped by higher sales across all product lines.
At the funeral for Khiel Coppin, who died last week in a hail of police gunfire, congregants struggled to draw something constructive or instructive from his death.
The court ruled that T-Mobile must offer the iPhone to everyone, even without the 24-month contract that it had required for buyers.
After releasing new figures showing that the global AIDS epidemic is smaller than it previously reported, the United Nations’ AIDS-fighting agency denied that it had priorly  inflated estimates.
In a setback for American producers, a federal trade panel ruled Tuesday against the American glossy paper industry’s request for tariffs on imported Chinese paper.
A new television advertisement for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton began running Tuesday in New Hampshire.
London’s cab drivers are by and large not happy about the city’s plan to help underrepresented groups pay the financial costs involved in joining their ranks.
Government scientists are investigating whether a drug from Pfizer used to help smokers quit cigarettes also increases suicidal thoughts and violent behavior.
A workers’ rights group accused St. Patrick’s Cathedral of selling religious items made under terrible conditions in sweatshop factories in China.
To optimists, huge investments by major developers provide proof that New Rochelle, New York’s renaissance has begun. Yet there remain few signs of renewed economic vitality downtown.
New York State’s highest court threw out the conviction of a man who was arrested for standing and not moving on a Times Square corner in 2004.
Mr. Bluestone was chief negotiator for more than 400,000 workers at General Motors in the 1970s and an advocate of worker participation in management.
The season of overeating is upon us. If you’re concerned about weight, you should eat early in the day.
The Costa book awards, formerly the Whitbread Awards, released this year’s short list in the fiction, first novel, biography, poetry and children’s book categories.
Monday’s semifinal installment of “Dancing With the Stars” lifted ABC to an easy victory in the night’s ratings.
The Peppers claim “Californication” for themselves, new cable head named, Picasso suit rejected and more culture news.
The Red Hot Chili Peppers are suing Showtime Networks over the new television series “Californication.”

A New York judge has ruled that the Andrew Lloyd Webber Art Foundation, owner of a Picasso painting, cannot be sued by a German collector who contended that the Nazis had forced his relative to sell the work.
Jimmy Page, the Led Zeppelin guitarist, said that a broken finger on his left hand was healing well and that he was confident of performing in a reunion concert on Dec. 10, rescheduled from November.
Greek police arrested a culture ministry employee after discovering dozens of ancient Greek and Byzantine antiquities in his home.
Louis Vuitton, the luxury goods maker, has won a French lawsuit that contended that a music video by Britney Spears violated counterfeiting laws.
NBC Universal completed its acquisition of the Oxygen cable channel yesterday and named Lauren Zalaznick as the executive in charge.
The Metropolitan Opera said yesterday that 100 recorded performances from its archives from as far back as 1937 were now available on the Rhapsody digital music service.
The hunt for a 20-year-old man suspected in the slaying of a British student in Italy ended after he was picked up Tuesday by German police for riding a train without a ticket.

The Super Bowl is the National Football League’s yearly orgy of capitalism, but the role that the league plays in our Thanksgivings is perhaps even more vital: It allows us, mercifully, a few precious minutes away from our extended family. (Or at least something else to talk about besides than Aunt Carla’s drinking.) We tend to remember the great Thanksgiving game moments — the famous coin flip fiasco of 1998, Leon Lett’s brain-dead blocked field goal kick in the snow in 1993 — even better than we remember playoff games.
I hope that my modest list of potential Thanksgiving weekend activities might serve to supplement the entertainment options that the news media have been supplying in the past week or two.
To the Editor:.
The episode, “Razor,” marks yet another step in the complex, fast-changing relationship between DVD sales and cable broadcast.
The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission decided on Tuesday that the Guggenheim should maintain the same light-gray paint shade it has had since 1992.
The concert found this Broadway lyric soprano not only alive and kicking but in great voice.
A newly revealed letter sheds light on what exactly happens at the end of “The House of Mirth.”
An eminent intellectual historian leads the reader on a pleasant ramble through Modernist art and literature.
To one degree or another, the tensions between body and spirit have always flickered somewhere in Caetano Veloso’s songs.
The United States Bridge Federation has dropped its effort to punish six members of the women’s championship bridge team.

To the Editor:.
The Collegiate Chorale, a few hundred strong, crowded the stage of Carnegie Hall on Monday night for its own “Elijah.”
The mild tension between the eager, can-do spirit of a four-person show and William Finn’s slightly acerbic songs creates a diverting light entertainment.
A radically untraditional step makes carving a turkey easier, if less spectacular.
Italy has released the first images of a deep cavern where some archaeologists believe ancient Romans honored Romulus and Remus — the legendary founders of Rome.

As with the work of any living composer, people are bound to have varied reactions to Thomas Adès’s music. But no one can fairly question that this 36-year-old Englishman is among the most accomplished all-around musicians of his generation.
Jimmy Rollins, the spry shortstop who helped the Phillies rumble past the Mets and reach the playoffs for the first time in 14 years, edged Matt Holliday for M.V.P.
In claiming relatively few lives, the cyclone that tore across Bangladesh left many more people in utter ruin.
The Culture Project’s staged reading of monologues from the disenfranchised is so flat and earnest that it seems detached from the moment even when it should speak eerily to the present.
Cooper’s Tavern opens this week, Zen Palate in Union Square becomes Fatty Crab, Orwasher’s Bakery changes hands and more.
Food on the Edge.
Portable credit card scanners are slowly making their way into restaurants in the United States.

If you’re hunting for Golden Bear tracks — that is, a sampling of Jack Nicklaus’s course designs—you will surely bag your limit along Florida’s Gold Coast, where Nicklaus has resided since the early 1970s. Among his best are two layouts of recent vintage in Palm Beach County, the Bear’s Club and its next-door neighbor, the Ritz-Carlton Golf Club, Jupiter. The latter course in particular illuminates Nicklaus’ evolution as a designer. Gone are the gigantic, unnatural conical mounds, vast waste bunkers and fiercely protected elevated greens that graced many of his early works. In their stead is a set of low-key holes that flow through dense stands of pine, palmetto and native scrub, with greens that are receptive to a variety of approaches. Artful contouring, deep, if smallish bunkers and just the right number of strategically deployed hazards keep the scratch golfer at bay, but fairways are amply wide, thus allowing Mr. Once-a-Week a pleasurable day. If your connections can’t land you on one of these private Nicklaus nooks, check out PGA National Resort & Spa’s Champion Course, which Nicklaus redesigned in 1990. A former Ryder Cup and PGA Championship site, it is current home to the PGA Tour’s Honda Classic. For those on a budget, North Palm Beach Country Club is your ticket. Jack’s gift to his adopted hometown was to reconfigure its tired muni into a local treasure—and he did it for the princely design fee of $1. Reopened in November 2006, the rolling, 7,100-yard layout boasts two holes along the Intracoastal Waterway and a high season green fee that’s well south of $100. For bargain hunters, that’s a Bear worth stalking. www.ritzcarltonrealestate.com, 561-691-8700; www.pgaresort.com, 561-627-1800; www.village-npb.org, 561-691-3420.

An article in The Arts on Oct. 31 about a new work by the choreographer John Jasperse, ''Misuse liable to prosecution,'' misstated the daily cost of the war in Iraq, using a figure given by Mr. Jasperse when he recites a list of numbers in the work. The cost of the war is about $330 million, according to an estimate by the Congressional Research Service, not $720 million. (The higher figure is the estimate by the American Friends Service Committee and includes long-term health care for veterans and debt interest, among other costs.)

RABINOWITZ--Victor . The members and staff of Rabinowitz, Boudin, Standard, Krinsky & Lieberman mourn the death of the firm's founding partner, Victor Rabinowitz, at age 96. For decades, Victor courageously was in the forefront of the fight for civil liberties when only a few were willing to stand up to the onslaught of the McCarthy era. He believed that his task was not only to expose the law's inequities but ''to carry on the necessary legal activities in a professionally competent and politically principled fashion.'' For more than six decades, Victor did precisely that--representing with extraordinary skill and commitment the militant labor movement, the targets of McCarthy-era repression, the civil rights movement, Vietnam-era protesters, Cuba and Allende's Chile. He served as an inspiration, teacher, mentor and friend to several generations of young lawyers, in our office and in the National Lawyer's Guild, who hope to use their talents and careers in the service of something more important than the pursuit of money and status. We will miss Victor, and we will try to carry on as he would have wished. Victor's family will be holding a memorial sometime in January. The family has asked that anyone wishing to remember Victor with a contribution, to consider the L. M. Rabinowitz Foundation, 18 Fountain Street, Clinton, NY 13323. Michael Krinsky Eric Lieberman Rabinowitz, Boudin, Standard, Krinsky & Lieberman, P.C.

STEMMERMANN--Dr . Grant N. A noteworthy pathologist and epidemiologist died on Saturday in Cincinnati. He was 89. The cause was cardiac arrhythmia. A native of New York City, Dr. Stemmermann attended Trinity College and Cornell University, and received his M.D. from McGill University in 1943. During WWII, he served as Battalion Surgeon with the 37th Engineer Combat Battalion in Okinawa, then returned to New York to complete his residency at Sea View and Richmond Memorial Hospitals on Staten Island. After 2 years as Assistant Pathologist at Halloran VA Hospital on Staten Island, he moved to Hilo, Hawaii, to be Head Pathologist at Hilo Memorial Hospital. In 1950, as Director of Laboratories at Kuakini Hospital in Honolulu, he initiated his groundbreaking studies of heart disease and cancer. As Principal Investigator of the Honolulu Heart Program, he contacted men who had fought in WWII in the famed 442nd Battalion, and gathered background information from each man. He then continued to follow this group in an ongoing study. In 1971, with the collaboration of colleagues in Japan, Dr. Stemmermann expanded these studies of second-generation Japanese - Ameri cans to include data from similar populations in Japan to assess the impact of western lifestyles upon their disease experience. After retirement, he continued to refine this research, and in 1993 took a position with the University of Cincinnati Medical School, where he worked until his death. In recognition of his work, Dr. Stemmermann participated in meetings in Japan organized by the Crown Princess Takamatsu, honoring those who have made significant contributions to cancer research. He was also recognized in 2000 by the Hawaii State Legislature for his exceptional service and outstanding contributions to the betterment of the community. He is survived by his wife Nell, daughters Maile, Mele, and Rachel. Donations in his memory can be sent to McGill University (Bursary Fund, Faculty of Medicine class of 1943), and the Cincinnati Chapter of the American Cancer Society.

Bins at the Greenmarkets are full of locally grown tubers right now, with some farms offering as many as six or seven kinds of colorful potatoes, plus Jerusalem artichokes, sweet potatoes and crosnes, small French delicacies. Edible tubers grow all over the world. An encyclopedic little handbook, ''Buried Treasures: Tasty Tubers of the World,'' describes more than 30 of them, their habitats, cultivation and culinary uses. The book, edited by Beth Hanson and published by the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, has a dozen recipes, including a creamy gratin that can be made with any of six or seven kinds of tubers.

The former 100-meter world-record holder Calvin Smith and the 1936 Olympic decathlon champion Glenn Morris were among five inductees to the United States Track and Field Hall of Fame announced yesterday. Honorees also included the nine-time United States heptathlon champion Jane Frederick, the two-time Olympic shot put runner-up George Woods and Coach Elmer (Ducky) Drake, whose pupils included the Olympic decathlon champion Rafer Johnson. Smith was a two-time world outdoor 200-meter champion and took the bronze medal at the 1988 Seoul Olympics. Morris, who died in 1974, took part in only three decathlon competitions in his life, winning the 1936 Kansas Relays and United States Olympic trials before taking gold in Berlin.

A sports article on Sunday about the swimmer Dara Torres, a four-time Olympian who is thriving at age 40 with the help of a rigorous training program, misidentified one of her sponsors. It is Bloomberg L.P., not the company's Bloomberg News division. Because of an editing error, the text with an accompanying chart referred incorrectly to the time frame in which Torres had her personal-best performance in the 100-meter freestyle. As the statistics in the chart noted, it was in 2000 -- not ''recently.''

Holiday entertaining means lots of leftovers, so stocking up on sturdy plastic wrap is a good idea. Stretch-tite, which is not sold in supermarkets, is heavier and stretchier than most brands, and 12 inches wide. It comes in a 500-square-foot roll with an efficient dispenser and cutter on the box. At $7.50 it is cheaper than some supermarket brands, which can cost more than $4 for 200 square feet. The company, Polyvinyl Films, in Sutton, Mass., also makes Freeze-tite, 15 inches wide and sold in 250-square-foot rolls, which is heavier still and self-sealing, also $7.50. Shipping is extra from stretchtite.com.

An obituary on Saturday about Jack Kuney, a producer and director of notable early television programs, referred incorrectly to WNTA, the New York-area television station where he did much of his work in the 1950s and 1960s and which was a forerunner of WNET. Initially, it was an independent commercial station owned by National Telefilm Associates; it was not a public television station. (It became an educational television station, WNDT, in 1962 and a public television station in 1967.)

ROSEN--Albert P. , 90, of Fair Lawn, NJ, died peacefully at home on November 18. He is survived by his son, Jonathan M. Rosen M.D. (Anna), his daughter, Nancy Rosen Blackwood (Michael), and four grandchildren. His wife of 58 years, Shirley (nee Tanenbaum), predeceased him. He attended Newton High School in Queens, earned his Bachelor's degree at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill in 1939, and his M.D. at Long Island College of Medicine (Downstate) in 1943. Serving in the U.S. Army Medical Corps until 1946, he was posted in France, England and Germany. Upon his discharge, his medical training continued at the Chapin Hospital in Providence, RI, the Bradley Home in Riverside, RI, and the Yale Clinic of Child Development. He was a Fellow of the American Academy of Pediatrics. In 1949 Rosen joined the faculty of Babies Hospital at Columbia Presbyterian, and began a practice in pediatrics in Fair Lawn. He continued to see patients until his retirement in 2002. A founding member of the medical staff of the Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, he served for 18 years as the Director of Pediatrics and was the first recipient of the Distinguished Physician Service Award. Rosen's avocational passions included gardening, hiking and mountain climbing. He cultivated a prolific garden of vegetables and herbs, kept bees, and maintained a menagerie of farm animals. As a mountaineer, Rosen, accompanied by his wife, climbed on all seven continents. He led weekend hikes in the Hudson Highland and Catskills and climbed all the peaks above 3500-feet in the northeast, joining the ranks of the Northeast 111 Club. An active member of the Appalachian Mountain Club, the American Alpine Club and Woodland Trail Walkers, in 1994 he authored Health Hints for Hikers published by the NY-NJ Trail Conference. Interment will be private. A memorial Service is planned for the spring. Donations may be made to: The Maurice M. Pine Public Library, Fair Lawn; The New YorkNew Jersey Trail Conference, Mahwah, NJ; and The Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, NJ.

BERMAN--Susan . The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Susan Berman, associated with The Times from June 24, 1965 until November 16, 2007. BERMAN--Susan. 65, of Springfield, NJ, on November 17, of cancer. Daughter of Dorothy Bernstein and the late Hy Berman, sister of the late Richie Berman. She died peacefully in her home surrounded by loving friends and family. She is survived by her mother, her devoted cousin Steven Saltzman and her adoring foster family, including son Thong Nguyen, daughter Ly Lam and grandsons Billy and Kevin and their cousin Anthony. Her warm spirit, keen sense of reason and boundless, often irreverent, humor will be sorely missed by her colleagues at the New York Times Index, where she worked for 34 years. Her favorite ballet was Symphony in C, she knew all the dialogue to On the Waterfront, and was never shy about voicing her political views. She loved, and was loved, and will be remembered always. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

CAMERON--Alexander Abbott, Jr. , ''Sandy'', of Southampton, NY, on November 18, 2007 at age 87. He was the son of Joanna and Alexander Cameron of Concord, MA. He graduated from the Fountain Valley School in Colorado Springs, the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, and attended Harvard Business School. He was a member of the Zeta Psi fraternity. Southeast Asian leaders signed a charter here on Tuesday that was drafted as a watershed document to bind the region together in a European-style economic community, but the pact has instead exposed the sharp divisions over one of its members, Myanmar. The Asean charter establishes the group as a legal entity, creating permanent representation for members at its secretariat in Jakarta, Indonesia, and committing heads of state to meetings twice a year. It includes a blueprint for economic reforms intended to create a European-style trading bloc by 2015, with free movement of goods, services, investment and skilled labor. The document also sets timelines for the elimination of nontariff barriers and other trade restrictions.

It has been quite a year for the Indiana football team. In June, Hoosiers Coach Terry Hoeppner died after an 18-month fight with brain tumors. Earlier this month, the Hoosiers (7-5), now coached by Hoeppner's former assistant Bill Lynch, became bowl eligible for the first time since 1994 with a victory over Ball State. Indiana running back Bryan Payton has written for The Quad before, reflecting on the impact Hoeppner had on his players and the legacy he left. Today, Payton takes a look at the Hoosiers' season, from early practices in 100-degree heat to Austin Starr's winning kick in last Saturday's 27-24 victory over Purdue in the annual Bucket Game. The German pole vaulter Yvonne Buschbaum is quitting athletics to have hormone therapy after deciding she was “emotionally in the wrong body.” Buschbaum, 27, won two bronze medals at the European Championships in her career.In a statement on her Web site (www.pole-it-buschbaum.de), she said that a recent injury had contributed to her decision. She also said she did not use performance-enhancing drugs. “I feel I’m a man in the body of a woman,” she said.

The drug Revlimid, made by the Celgene Corporation, can shrink tumors and slow down the spread of multiple myeloma, a deadly cancer of the bone marrow, according to two studies conducted in the United States and Europe. Revlimid, a derivative of thalidomide, helped shrink tumors for about 60 percent of patients in combination with dexamethasone, a corticosteroid, and stopped the cancer from spreading for six months, according to two studies published in this week’s New England Journal of Medicine. The drug, known chemically as lenalidomide, won American approval for multiple myeloma in July 2006 based on the studies.

San Francisco supervisors have rejected a proposal, spurred by Mayor Gavin Newsom’s affair with a staff member, that would have banned City Hall managers from having “romantic or sexual relationships” with subordinates. Supervisor Chris Daly proposed the measure in response to Mr. Newsom’s admission that he had an affair with his commission appointments secretary, the wife of his campaign manager. The vote on Tuesday was 10 to 1. The city’s current sexual harassment policy warns that consensual relationships between bosses and people they supervise are potentially problematic, but does not prohibit them.

A Honduran mother who was separated for 11 days from her nursing baby after being arrested in an immigration search was deported to Honduras, along with her three children and her husband. The woman, Saída Umanzor, 26, was separated from her American-born baby, Brittney Bejarano, when she was detained by the authorities with a deportation order on Oct. 26 in Conneaut, Ohio. After 11 days, Julie L. Myers, the head of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, ordered Ms. Umanzor’s release and issued instructions for illegal immigrants who are nursing mothers to be released after arrest in most cases. The agency paid the airfare to Honduras for all three children: Brittney and another daughter, who are United States citizens, and a son born in Honduras.

The coal mine where six workers were entombed after a collapse has been sealed, federal regulators said Tuesday. Richard Gates, the lead investigator for the federal Mine Safety and Health Administration, made the disclosure in a briefing for a state commission that is looking into whether Utah should return to regulating coal mines after a 20-year hiatus. Kevin Stricklin, the agency’s administrator for coal-mine safety, said the Murray Energy Corporation, based in Cleveland, sealed the Crandall Canyon mine’s three main passageways with walls of concrete block in early October. The decision did not represent any loss of hope for recovering the men’s bodies, he said. The walls can be removed, he said. The miners were trapped on Aug. 6. Ten days later, another collapse killed three people and injured six others.

A woman who was fired from a job working for Macomb County after less than 10 days was kept on the government-paid health insurance plan for eight years, billing $230,000 for treatment of cancer and other ailments, a prosecutor says. The prosecutor, Eric Smith, of Macomb County filed four counts of health care fraud against the woman, Jackie Youhanian, 38, who now lives at Prattville, Ala. She was removed from the county payroll at the Martha T. Berry Medical Facility in Mount Clemens, but apparently not the health care rolls, a mistake officials say may have been a record-keeping error. “This was not a one-time error, or a goof-up, or a mistake in judgment,” Mr. Smith said in a news release. “This was a continuing criminal scheme.” Ms. Youhanian did not immediately return calls to her home seeking comment.

Legal proceedings against a black teenager from Jena, who was among a group whose prosecution in the beating of a white classmate led to a huge civil rights protest, must be open to the public, a judge ruled. Because the charges involve violence, all proceedings against the teenager, Mychal Bell, will be public even though Mr. Bell is being tried as a juvenile, the judge, Thomas Yeager of District Court, decided. Mr. Bell, 17, faces trial on Dec. 6 on charges of aggravated second-degree battery and conspiracy in an attack last December on the white student, Justin Barker. The New York Times was among 25 news organizations that went to court for permission to attend hearings in Mr. Bell’s case.

The former Olympic canoeing silver medalist Nathan Baggaley faces more drug charges after being arrested with his brother for the manufacturing and trafficking of ecstasy in Australia. Baggaley, who won two silver medals at the 2004 Athens Olympics, has been told that he could not return to competition because of other pending drug charges after serving a two-year ban for taking steroids.

Months before he manages his first game with the Los Angeles Dodgers, Joe Torre is going for a victory at Hollywood Park. Night Chapter, owned by Torre’s Diamond Pride stable and trained by the Hall of Famer Bobby Frankel, drew the No. 6 post in the field of 10 for Saturday’s $150,000 Hollywood Turf Express, a Grade 3 race.

Defender Ryan Cochrane was selected first in the M.L.S. expansion draft yesterday, three days after helping the Houston Dynamo win a second straight M.L.S. Cup. Cochrane will return to San Jose for the inaugural season of the reborn Earthquakes. He played for the Earthquakes in 2004 and 2005 before the team disbanded and then essentially became the Dynamo. He was one of three Houston starters left unprotected by Coach Dominic Kinnear.

North Carolina and Coach Butch Davis agreed to a one-year contract extension through the 2014 season, university officials said. Davis will receive a raise of $291,000 that will push his annual income to about $2.1 million. Davis is 3-8 in his first season in Chapel Hill but had been rumored as a possible candidate at Arkansas — his home-state university — if the Razorbacks make a coaching change.

Looking for an alternative to a traditional Christmas tree? Next week, the A & G Merch design shop in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, will unveil a do-it-yourself holiday tree from Tord Boontje, the Dutch designer. The tree is actually an assembly of five of Mr. Boontje's Xmas Light kits, which were introduced in 2005, and which each include a strand of white lights, two sheets of lace made from Tyvek and a hook to hang your creation from the ceiling. The set of five kits ($419) results in a 26-inch-diameter tree that is 84 inches tall, above; the idea is to stack three of the fixtures and use the other two to round out the shape. Before hanging your tree, make sure there is an outlet nearby. A & G Merch, 111 N. 6th Street, Brooklyn, (718) 388-1779. JULIE SCELFO

McDEVITT--John Burke, M.D., 90, passed away November 19, 2007 at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City. He was the son of the late Justin and Elma McDevitt of Charlotte, North Carolina. He was born in Chattanooga, Tennessee in 1917. His father, Justin McDevitt, was the founder of JJ McDevitt Construction Company, a leading construction firm of the South, which is now part of Bovis Lendlease. John graduated from the University of North Carolina Chapel Hill in 1938 and then received his medical degree from the University of Pennsylvania in 1943. He served two years as a Captain in the US Army Medical Corps. He completed his residency at the Menninger School of Psychiatry in Topeka, Kansas from 1946 to 1948 and then became board certified in psychiatry by the American Board of Psychiatry and Neurology in 1949. His psychoanalytic training was at the Psychoanalytic Institute in New York with a specialty in Child Psychoanalysis. In addition to his private practice, he published numerous ground-breaking studies in child development, was a lecturer, Director of Research and a key co-investigator with Margaret Mahler of the Margaret S. Mahler Psychiatric Research Foundation. John had a love of the outdoors which included riding his bicycle at lunchtime in Central Park in NYC (while listening to the selected works of Sigmund Freud) or sailing his catamaran on Lake Waramaug in Connecticut. He is survived by his wife of 37 years, Dr. Valery Lanyi; daughters Dana McDevitt of Charlotte, North Carolina and Lindsay Wood and son-in-law Richard Wood of North Yorkshire, England; stepson Paul Lanyi and wife Kristi Harris of El Segundo, California; niece Tadge Pennington of Greensboro, North Carolina; four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by his sister, Mary McDevitt Penningon and stepson George Lanyi. In lieu of flowers or gifts, please send contributions to the Margaret S. Mahler Foundation at 254 Kent Road, Wynnewood, PA 19096. Memorial plans will be forthcoming.

GUTTERMAN--Peter, born October 18, 1943 in NYC, died at home in Washington, DC, November 20, 2007 of ALS. Peter had a 28 year career at the World Bank. Survived by wife, Debbie (nee Claman), daughter, Amanda, and sister, Gail Abrams. Services at Temple Micah in Washington at 11:00am on November 23.
RABINOWITZ--Victor. The Board and staff at CCR deeply mourn Victor Rabinowitz, our close friend and ally, and a fearless fighter for justice and human rights. We extend our sympathies to his family.

BURGER--Mae Sokol, M.D., 56, Academic child psychiatrist, died Saturday, November 17 in Omaha, NE, from complications of lymphoma. Mae Sokol Burger, M.D. was Associate Professor at the Creighton University School of Medicine. She was the Director of the Eating Disorders Program at Children's Hospital in Omaha. She was a published author, an accomplished researcher and teacher, and nationally known for her treatment of pediatric eating disorders. Dr. Sokol was the first to describe infection - triggered Anorexia Nervosa (PANDAS). Dr. Sokol trained in psychiatry and child and adolescent psychiatry at Bellevue Hospital, NY. She was an Examiner at the American Board of Psychiatry & Neurology, Child & Adolescent Psychiatry. She was an editorial board member of Eating Disorders: The Journal of Treatment and Prevention, and Open Psychiatry Journal. She was a reviewer for Depression and Anxiety, and Bulletin of the Menninger Clinic. Her Brooklyn High School experience volunteering to help blind children inspired her to change her career choice from an initial interest in writing to the helping field of medicine. Her professional accomplishments were driven by a sincere desire to help those in need. She was a loving wife and mother, and a caring professional. She is survived by her husband, Scott Burger, son, Levi Sokol, and stepson, Steven Burger.

Catherine Ledner lives with 2 dogs, 2 cats, 11 rabbits and 1 husband in Altadena, Calif. A portraitist and commercial photographer, Ms. Ledner became fascinated by the idea of using wallpaper patterns in animal portraiture, and her new book, ''Animal House,'' is the result. During her research, she pored over wallpaper books from the 1930s and '40s, and pulled new samples from the Pacific Design Center. The 47 animals were cast from the pool the local trainers had available.

Oops. You just sent out the dinner invitations, and suddenly noticed that several of your caned chairs have holes in them. Not to worry: any caned seat can be repaired, by machine or by hand, at Veterans Chair Caning and Repair in Manhattan. Sean Bausert and his father, John, run the family business, which opened in 1899 (named for the ''vets from the Spanish-American War working here at the time,'' the younger Mr. Bausert said). Veterans can fix Danish cord and fiber rush, above, and midcentury pieces by designers like Marcel Breuer. Hand-caned seats start at $185; machine-caned Breuer seats are $45. Delivery starts at $10 a chair. Veterans Chair, 442 10th Avenue (34th Street), (212) 564-4560. MARIANNE ROHRLICH Good deals and secret sources may be reported to rohrlich@nytimes.com.

This is the fifth in a series of articles examining global migration and its consequences. Previous articles dealt with the stakes of global immigration as they play out in the tiny West African nation of Cape Verde, the rise of skilled and salaried migrant workers, efforts in Dubai to improve conditions for migrant workers and the development of the Indian state of Kerala with money earned by workers who go abroad.

Ciara presented one to Patti LaBelle and called her ''the high priestess of good vibrations.'' Other honorees included Rihanna, Justin Timberlake, Mika, Avril Lavigne, David Guetta, Akon, 50 Cent and Maná. A music review on Monday about Stevie Wonder, at Madison Square Garden, misidentified the first song he performed. It was ''Love's in Need of Love Today'' -- not ''Too High,'' which was his second song.

Because of an editing error, the Brezovica Journal article on Monday, about surprisingly friendly relations between Serb and Albanian skiers on the slopes of Brezovica, in the Serbian enclave of Strpce in Serbia's ethnic Albanian province of Kosovo, misidentified the city used as a reference point for Strpce's location. Strpce is about 40 miles from Pristina, the provincial capital of Kosovo -- not from Belgrade, the capital of Serbia. (Belgrade is about 180 miles from Strpce.)

SPRITZ--Norton, M.D. The Department of Medicine of New York University School of Medicine is saddened by the passing of our longtime colleague, Norton Spritz. A member of our faculty for nearly 40 years, Dr. Spritz served as Professor of Medicine and as Chief of the Medical Service at the VA. He influenced two generations of students and house staff, and inspired his colleagues with his kindness and his skills as a doctor; he will be missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Martin J. Blaser, M.D., Chair, Department of Medicine NYU School of Medicine SPRITZ--Norton, on November 21, 2007. Beloved to family, colleagues and friends. When Christine Meier built a new home in Arkansas three years ago, she went looking for a room planning tool that would allow her to experiment with various furniture arrangements, but ''there was nothing out there on the market except expensive magnets,'' she said. ''I was ripping out pictures from magazines, but I couldn't get a feel of how it would all come together.'' So Ms. Meier and her husband, Randy, created the Room Spacing Kit ($7.99), for the bedroom, living room, children's room and office-studio. Each kit has 250 stickers, above right, depicting everything from sofas and armoires to treadmills and cat beds, as well as graph paper, cardboard, a ruler and labels like ''plasma TV'' and ''bean bag,'' so aspiring decorators can create professional-style design boards, above left. Information: www.homespacing.com. ELAINE LOUIE

The Media Equation column in Business Day on Monday, about the strike by the Writers Guild of America, referred incorrectly to the business interests of the Sony Corporation. The company is indeed in the television industry as the producer of several shows.

Lisa Krivacka's paintings nibble at the corners of the sort of Americana familiar to those who, like Ms. Krivacka, grew up in the 1960s: motel-room interiors, postcards from back-road attractions, chairs in a hunting lodge, all expressed in a naïve, folksy vernacular. Lately she's been sifting through photographs at flea markets and yard sales, looking for snapshots with a Christmas theme and making paintings from them. ''The photographs had a sort of sincerity to them,'' Ms. Krivacka said, ''and they gave me a window into how others had lived and celebrated.'' Ten of her Christmas paintings, in which she honors the piquant weirdness of those snapshots -- like the amateur composition, left, and the instant intimacy of a stranger's family group, right -- have been reproduced on holiday cards that are ambivalently celebratory. These holiday paintings are $1,800 through the Frederieke Taylor Gallery, 535 West 22nd Street, (646) 230-0992; 10 cards are $24 (including shipping) from lisakrivacka.com. PENELOPE GREEN
BOBLEY--Gloria. Our sympathy to Peter and his wife Sue. Gloria will be missed. Bobbi, Sue and Paul

A front-page article on Sunday about the effect of the mortgage loan crisis on tenants misstated the estimated number of renters evicted because of foreclosures. A survey taken this year by the Mortgage Bankers Association found that one in seven foreclosures was non-owner-occupied, not one in eight.

An article by The Associated Press in Business Day on Nov. 13 about the stock markets' performance misstated the Apple Inc. product that had its European debut the previous weekend. It was the iPhone, not the iPod.

An obituary on Friday about Clara Fox, a leading advocate of subsidized housing, misstated the location of Manhattan Plaza, the housing development where she lived. It is between 9th and 10th Avenues, not 8th and 9th.

An article in The Arts on Tuesday about Internet episodes of ''Lost: Missing Pieces,'' based on the ABC television show ''Lost,'' referred incompletely to the writers. Although Carlton Cuse, an executive producer, wrote the first in the Internet series of 13, others episodes were written by members of the group of writers who regularly work on the television show, including Mr. Cuse and Damon Lindelof, also an executive producer.

COSTA--Joseph A., 92, passed away on November 21, 2007 in Manhattan. Joe was a WWII veteran, successful business owner, well-known writer of advertisements, and a devoted family man. He is survived by his wife, Bea, of 43 years, his children Joe, Linda Britt and Pat Gilleaudeau, five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Visitation will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., on Friday, November 23, 2007 from 2-5 and 7-9pm. Services will be held at Saint Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church, 184 E. 76th St., on Saturday, November 24, 2007 at 10:30am.

MANN--Walter Preston II, passed away Saturday, November 17, 2007 in Poway, CA following complications of a stroke. Born in Dubois, Wyoming to Walter P. and Tonetta on February 25, 1917, he was 90. Beloved husband of Edna May (McDermand) Mann, loving father of Linda Lee (Mann) Urmacher, Dale B. Mann, and Walter P. Mann III, and adored father-in-law of Carlos D. Urmacher, M.D., he is also survived by his six grandchildren, Anders, Adam, Ammon, Heather, Jane and Walter IV, and five great-grandchildren. Formerly of Chadron, Nebraska, Walter moved to La Jolla, CA in 1945 with his wife and son after serving in the Army Air Force in WWII, stationed in North Africa and Italy for more than 18 months. After the War, Walter was Federal civil employee, serving as a fire fighter at Miramar Naval Air Base in San Diego for over 30 years. A rancher, fisherman, horseman and avid bird watcher, Walter retired to Poway with his loving wife Edna of 69 years where he cared for his home, his family and the many birds, quail and hawks who visited his garden. He will be missed and remembered by his family and friends. Services will be held privately in California.

Boo Weekley and Heath Slocum of the United States combined for an 11-under-par 61 in best-ball play to take a one-stroke lead over Alex Cejka and Martin Kaymer of Germany at the World Cup of Golf in Shenzhen, China. Finland, Wales, Scotland, South Africa, Thailand and England were two shots back.Weekley, No. 43 in the world, had six birdies and an eagle. He was picked to represent the United States after 13 other higher-ranked Americans turned down the invitation. He picked the 70th-ranked Slocum, his friend from high school in Florida.“I think I was up in a tree deer hunting when I got the call,” Weekley said.The teams will play an alternate-shot round today, another best-ball round tomorrow and then close with alternate shot Sunday.

Roger Federer overcame Pete Sampras’s stubborn resistance en route to a 7-6 (6), 7-6 (5) victory in their second Asian exhibition match, in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.Federer won their last encounter, by 6-4, 6-3 in South Korea on Tuesday, but the clash in Malaysia took nearly 90 minutes and proved a bit more difficult.Their age difference might have been the decisive factor — at 26, Federer was never in danger of losing against an opponent a decade older who retired from competitive tennis five years ago.Sampras, who has won a record 14 Grand Slams, showcased his big serves and hit ferocious forehand returns. “He played some unbelievable shots, but then again, he is capable of doing that,” Federer said.“He had an incredible serve which was so difficult to read tonight.”.

The International Ski Federation yesterday barred three Austrian cross-country skiers for two years for their roles in the doping scandal at the 2006 Olympics.Martin Tauber, Johannes Eder and Roland Diethart were suspended and deprived of all their results since Feb. 16, 2006. The Italian police raided the Austrian team lodgings during the Turin Games, seizing a large amount of doping products and equipment.

Rory McIlroy, a teenager from Northern Ireland playing only his sixth professional tournament, was among the Australian Masters leaders.McIlroy, who finished as low amateur at this year’s British Open, shot a two-under-par 70 on the Huntingdale course in Melbourne. He made birdies on Nos. 5, 6 and 7 and was three strokes behind the leader, Robert Allenby.

The International Association of Athletics Federations will meet today to discuss Marion Jones’s doping case, including whether to erase her Olympic and world championship results.Jones retired in October after acknowledging that she took a designer steroid from September 2000 to July 2001. She won gold medals in the 100- and 200-meter dashes and in 1,600 relay in the 2000 Sydney Olympics, as well as bronzes in the 400 relay and the long jump.Jones has returned her Olympic medals and agreed to forfeit all results dating to Sept. 1, 2000, but the I.A.A.F. and International Olympic Committee must still change the record books. The I.A.A.F. president, Lamine Diack, has called Jones “one of the biggest frauds in sporting history.”.

An assault charge against a Rutgers football assistant will be dropped if he completes anger management counseling, lawyers said.Prosecutor Steven Rubin said the July 14 altercation between the assistant head coach Chris Demarest and his girlfriend in a bar was more an argument than an assault.In court Saturday, Demarest’s lawyer, John Azzarello, said Demarest became angry when he had to pay a $2,000 tab for a birthday party thrown at the bar for his girlfriend. He was seen grabbing and pushing the woman, whom the police described as having cuts and bruises on her arms.Azzarello said Demarest had attended four sessions with a private counselor and would be required to attend more sessions.

To the Editor: Re “In the Valley of the Literate” (Nov. 16): If the Pioneer Valley of Massachusetts is the most “author-saturated, book-cherishing, literature-celebrating place in the nation,” it’s in no small part because of the University of Massachusetts Amherst. Though the university was unnoted in your article and unmarked on the accompanying map, it is not only the Valley’s largest employer but also its chief attractor and generator of creative talent in the arts and humanities. Distinguished poets and novelists on its faculty or among its alumni include James Tate, Sabina Murray, Martín Espada, Natasha Trethewey, Susan Straight and many other prestigious award winners. Recent public readings on campus involved Suzan-Lori Parks, Tony Kushner, Salman Rushdie and the late Grace Paley. By the way, the “local professor read[ing] from his new book on Chinese history” was Stephen Platt, just one of the many UMass authors who help make the Valley special for bibliophiles and everyone else.Joel Martin.

HOLIDAY TRAIN SHOW They look like scale models, those miniature city landmarks in bark, seed and other natural materials that make this annual event at the New York Botanical Garden much more than a trainspotter's affair. But the eye is easily fooled. No, these re-creations are ''replicas of how the building feels,'' said the show's designer, Paul Busse. The Brooklyn Bridge model, for instance, is much taller in proportion to its length than in reality, while Yankee Stadium, above, is much smaller or it would take up too much space. The George Washington Bridge, on the other hand, could only be 25 feet long because the biggest truck Mr. Busse and his staff at Applied Imagination in Alexandria, Ky., could find was 26 feet.

'PIPPI' Pippi Longstocking is famous for living her life with no strings attached. Although only a child, she has her own house (with a monkey and a horse); she is independently wealthy (thanks to the gold left by her absent father, a pirate king); and she doesn't attend school. But in her latest incarnation she has many strings; she never goes anywhere without them. Yet Pippi is still Pippi. Her new circumstances derive from her stardom at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theater, where the musical ''Pippi'' honors the centennial of Astrid Lindgren, the Swedish author of the Pippi books and a woman ahead of her time. Her diminutive heroine, with her red pigtails and disarming honesty, is fiercely independent. Pippi, above right, with her monkey, has no need for a prince or a magical godmother; if necessary, she can rescue herself.

THE ART OF FIELD RECORDING, VOL. 1 Every day the past of American music has a better future. Four years ago the Dust to Digital label put out ''Goodbye, Babylon,'' which some called the greatest anthology of American gospel music ever assembled. Now the label, based in Atlanta, has produced ''The Art of Field Recording, Vol. 1,'' four extraordinary discs culled from tapes recorded by Art Rosenbaum, a professor of art at the University of Georgia who has pursued musicology as a 50-year sideline.

(TLC) FASHIONABLY LATE WITH STACY LONDON Everyone's favorite style dominatrix, who disciplines fashion failures each Friday at 9 p.m. on TLC's ''What Not to Wear,'' gets a makeover herself in the form of her own talk show. Ms. London, left, calls it a ''girls' night out worth staying in for''; the TLC people describe it as a delicious cocktail of celebrity style, real-life tests of runway trends and tips for everyday life. Ms. London also offers experts and trendsetters armed with relationship advice, entertaining ideas and even ways to spruce up the man in your life. The festivities begin with a surprise makeover for a woman in the Coast Guard, a look at ''convertible fashion'' that can be worn 14 ways, some chitchat with Rebecca Romijn and a game of Chic or Shred, in which Ms. London teaches the audience how to eviscerate a wardrobe. 2 P.M. Five Hollywood studios -- Twentieth Century Fox, Walt Disney, Paramount Pictures, Columbia Pictures and Universal Studios -- have joined to sue Jeboo.com, a Chinese online service and Internet cafe, accusing it of offering pirated downloads of films including ''Night at the Museum'' and ''X-Men 2,'' Reuters reported. The companies are seeking damages of 3.2 million yuan ($432,000) in the case. This is not the first time American studios have gone after a business in China, where piracy is notoriously rampant. In August a Beijing court ruled in favor of six Hollywood studios in a case against a video store accused of selling illegal copies of ''Lord of the Rings'' and ''The Day After Tomorrow.''

When the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's 49th season opens at New York City Center on Nov. 28, it will start with a tribute to the French choreographer Maurice Béjart, who died yesterday at the age of 80. The company's artistic director, Judith Jamison, left, will lead the tribute, which will precede the company premiere of ''Firebird'' (1970), the first complete Béjart ballet to be staged by an American dance company. The company's five-week New York season will also include world premieres of ''The Groove to Nobody's Business,'' with choreography by Camille A. Brown,and ''Saddle Up!'' choreographed by Frederick Earl Mosley. More information is at alvinailey.org.

The curator of the Radya Pustaka Museum on Java Island in Indonesia was arrested along with three others this week after a routine inspection discovered that five ancient stone statues had been stolen, Agence France-Presse reported. The statues, above, which had been replaced with fakes, were found by police in the Jakarta home of Hashim Djojohadikusumo, a wealthy businessman. An aide to Mr. Djojohadikusumo said the statues had been purchased through a dealer. The police have closed the museum while the investigation continues.

Alfred Brendel, below, a master of the classical piano repertory, will retire from the concert stage at the end of next year, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Brendel, who turns 77 in January, will give his final concert on Dec. 18, 2008. ''He is playing at the peak of his form,'' said Josephine Hemsing, his New York publicist, confirming a report of his retirement that appeared in The Chicago Tribune. ''He's in perfect health, and he would like to go out at the top of his playing form.'' She said Mr. Brendel was touring in Europe and not available for comment. His final North American engagements will be in February and March, with performances in New York, Boston, Montreal, Cleveland, Minneapolis, Chicago and Pittsburgh. His final concert will be with the Vienna Philharmonic, a few weeks before he turns 78. He will perform Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 9, known as the ''Jeunehomme'' (''Young Man'').

A graduate of Virginia Polytechnic Institute, he had a long and happy career in the Gift and Glass Industries as owner of Knobler International, a gift importing firm, and The Pilgrim Glass Company.
