THE BRIT BOX Not so long ago, boxed sets seemed big, sometimes intimidatingly so: hours and hours of music, all in one place! Nowadays the problem is that they seem laughably skimpy; bulky, too. You get a doorstop the size of a shoe box containing a few hours of music -- that's a fraction of the capacity of an iPod nano, which is the size of a few business cards. Increasingly, it seems, the main draw is the booklet or sometimes the physical box itself.

Leftovers? For the holidays? That's one way to look at this year's crop of boxed sets. Now that most pop careers have already been distilled to a handful of discs, culling has given way to expansion. Musicians and labels are combing archives for outtakes, alternate versions, videos and other curios, rewriting pop's past and revealing how good -- or how misguided -- the original selection process was. And many of the leftovers deserve their second chance. JON PARELES Here are CD boxed sets, of three or more discs, recommended by the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times. A selection of smaller greatest-hits collections and reissues will appear on Dec. 7.

TANGO MEETS JAZZ FESTIVAL The dialogue between Argentine tango and American jazz has a history stretching back at least half a century, to the worldly innovations of Astor Piazzolla. An inspired composer and a master of the bandoneón (a type of button accordion), Piazzolla essentially created ''nuevo tango,'' which absorbs both classical counterpoint and jazz improvisation without losing the dramatic and mournful character of tango. To most outside observers, Piazzolla's high-flying brand of tango has come to represent the mainstream; some leading practitioners of tango today, like the pianist Pablo Ziegler, above, come to their authority partly as his former sidemen. Yet exploration in this realm hardly stopped after Piazzolla's death in 1992. Anyone now in search of tango-infused modern jazz (or, at times, the inverse) can seek out strong recent albums by the trumpeter Diego Urcola, the bassists Pedro Giraudo and Pablo Aslan, or the pianists Emilio Solla and Fernando Otero. All are Argentines based in New York, though each has his own style. At times their efforts have proved that hybridization can still confound: Mr. Aslan's recent album ''Buenos Aires Tango Standards'' (Zoho) was deemed ineligible for the tango category in this year's Latin Grammy Awards, even though it strictly features tango-savvy Argentine musicians like the drummer Daniel Piazzolla, whose grandfather was You Know Who.

DEVINE DANCE COMPANY ''Riverdance'' took the world by storm in 1994, when that Irish dancing spectacle was first seen at the Eurovision Song Contest. It has since spawned numerous offspring and imitators, and while it shows no sign of losing its appeal, for some the thrill is long gone. ''It seems a lot of the subsequent Irish dance shows have used that formula to present their productions,'' said the Irish dancer James Devine, whose dance company is wrapping up a critically lauded show at the family-friendly New Victory Theater. Mr. Devine, who holds the Guinness world record for fastest dancer, was invited to perform in Michael Flatley's ''Lord of the Dance'' in 1996, but the format wasn't for him. ''I thought, wouldn't it be interesting to present something that isn't about 34 dancers in a row,'' he said, ''and the bigger spectacle taking over the art form itself? I wanted to reduce it to something that was more stripped back, and had more edginess.'' That show is ''Tapeire,'' above, which ends this weekend and is, indeed, stripped back: Mr. Devine is the lone dancer. Working with an electric harpist, a percussionist and a fiddler, he presents his particular brand of 21st-century Irish dance, which folds American rhythm tap into sean-nos. A Gaelic term meaning ''old-school,'' sean-nos refers to dancing that is lower to the ground, with a relaxed upper body, like tap. ''That style of Irish dance is what would have emigrated with the people, when there was that mixing of cultures,'' Mr. Devine explained. ''That's really what was brought over, not the high kicks of modern Irish dance schools today. That's what I've eliminated from the show, to be quite honest, that leaping around the stage -- that's just spectacle dance, it's not really communicating anything.'' (Today and tomorrow at 2 and 7 p.m., Sunday at noon and 5 p.m., with a talk today after the 2 p.m. show. New Victory Theater, 209 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, 646-223-3010, newvictory.org; $12.50 to $35.) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

Brad Pitthas backed out of ''State of Play,'' the political thriller adapted by Matthew Michael Carnahan (''Lions for Lambs'') from the British television series of the same name, Variety reported. Mr. Pitt cited concerns over the script and a writers' strike that is preventing problems from being solved quickly. Mr. Pitt and the film's director, Kevin Macdonald (''The Last King of Scotland''), met several times recently to try to work out the problems but were unable to do so. Mr. Pitt was to play a reporter investigating the death of a political researcher. Shooting was to begin Nov. 15. Helen Mirren and Ed Norton are also featured in the cast, for the moment at least: Universal Pictures will need to replace Mr. Pitt quickly or risk losing other actors to scheduling conflicts if the delay goes on too long.

The Romantics, the Detroit pop group, have filed a lawsuit against Activision, saying that the company's video game ''Guitar Hero Encore: Rock the '80s'' features a recording that sounds too much like the band's 1980 song ''What I Like About You,'' The Associated Press reported. Activision has permission to use the song, but the band claims that a new version is indistinguishable from the original and could lead listeners to buy the cover track. The suit seeks unspecified damages. The band is also seeking an injunction that would remove the game from stores.

Boy George, below, the former lead singer of Culture Club, appeared in a London court yesterday to face a charge of false imprisonment, stemming from an episode this year in which he was accused of holding a male escort against his will, Agence France-Presse reported. The singer was indicted last week, and yesterday the Thames Magistrate Court set a trial date of Feb. 25. Boy George, the 46-year-old singer, spoke only to confirm his real name, George O'Dowd, and was released. Last summer he was sentenced to community service in New York after pleading guilty to falsely reporting a burglary.

KLEYNKUNST! After the First World War, Poland became an independent nation after more than a hundred years of foreign rule. In Warsaw, where a quarter of the population was Jewish, the city's rising class of secular Jews included lots of artistic types who were riding the new wave of Polish nationhood and looking toward a bright future. Kleynkunst teaters (little art houses) thrived during this vibrant period, offering irreverent, politically charged Yiddish cabaret that drew from a variety of sources, including Weimar cabaret, Russian folk music, jazz, tango and traditional cantorial music. Sadly, it's a type of performance that has largely been lost to time, but Rebecca Joy Fletcher, the writer and creator of ''Kleynkunst! Warsaw's Brave and Brilliant Yiddish Cabaret,'' is bringing it back. ''It's almost unimaginable for most American Jews how vital, hip and avant-garde Yiddish-speaking Warsaw was between the wars,'' she said. Ms. Fletcher, who is also a cantor, started working on her theatrical cabaret about a year ago. With the help of research assistants in Israel and Poland, as well as several professors and ethnomusicologists, she has tried to recreate an authentic Yiddish cabaret while simultaneously telling the story of the art form itself. The show, performed in both English and Yiddish, includes songs from the period in new arrangements by Bob Goldstone. And if you don't speak Yiddish, no need to fear -- the majority of the text is in English, and the Yiddish parts are translated on supertitles in both English and Russian.

SPRITZ--Norton, a brilliant doctor/lawyer, a beloved and loving friend. We will miss him. Our hearts are with Suzon and Nina and her family. Dorothy and Seth Dubin SPRITZ--Norton, M.D. The Administration and Staff of VA New York Harbor Healthcare System (NYHHS) mourn the loss of Norton Spritz, M.D. He died at Tisch Hospital on November 21, 2007. Dr. Spritz served as Chief of the Medical Service at the New York VAMC and Professor of Medicine, NYU School of Medicine, from 1968 to 1998. He was an expert in Lipid metabolism and a superb Clinician and Teacher who was dedicated to excellence in the care of Veterans and Medical Education. He taught and inspired countless numbers of students, residents, fellows and staff that he recruited to the facility. Dr. Spritz earned a law degree while serving as Chief of Medicine and he became an expert in Medical -Legal issues. After he retired, Dr. Spritz served as a special consultant to Vaco on Medical -Legal issues, and as chairman of the VA NYHHS IRB. He will be missed by us all. SPRITZ--Norton. Boundless intellect, compassion, kindness and wit. Proof that greatness can walk quietly among us. His friendship honored our lives. Our saddened hearts go out to Suzon and to Nina and her family. Shirley and Martin

FOR CHILDREN CIRCO COMEDIA AND 'MOOSELTOE, A HOLIDAY MOOSICAL' (Tomorrow and Sunday) A circus doesn't have to be a three-ring extravaganza. In Circo Comedia from Montreal two guys do it all: Jean Saucier is an acrobat, trick cyclist, juggler and magician; Patrick Côté is his (not quite) down-to-earth assistant and clown. And if you're in the mood for Christmas cuteness, you can try ''Mooseltoe,'' about a moose (not a reindeer) with big dreams. Circo, tomorrow at 11 a.m. and 2 p.m.; ''Mooseltoe,'' Sunday at 1 and 4 p.m.; Queens Theater in the Park, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718) 760-0064, queenstheatre.org; $12 each.

'DO HO SUH: PART ONE' With the New Museum of Contemporary Art reopening in a gleaming building on the Bowery next week, a handful of Chelsea galleries have heard the call of the Lower East Side. Among them is Lehmann Maupin, which has opened a satellite space on Chrystie Street, where, beginning on Thursday, it will show the work of the Korean artist Do Ho Suh. At the same time he has mounted a big companion exhibition in the gallery's Chelsea premises, the centerpiece of which is ''Cause & Effect,'' left, an enormous theatrical installation in the shape of a twirling tornado made out of thousands of plastic interlocking figurines stacked on top of one another and densely hung from the ceiling. It is like a Dale Chihuly sculpture crossed with the chandelier in the Palais Garnier, crossed with the Weather Channel. It is quite different from most of the art in Chelsea now. Even though the piece looks good, it is hard to comprehend its meaning. It allows us to get up close to and see the wonder of nature, but why is it made of cheap figurines turned out by workers in a studio factory operated by Mr. Suh in South Korea? Maybe it's a metaphor for late-capitalist decadence, in which the art world can feel at times like a vortex of glistening banality. My sense is that it is decorative, a sweetly pretty focal point for a room where it need not give off any meaning. (Through Dec. 22, Lehmann Maupin, 540 West 26th Street, Chelsea; Thursday through Feb. 2, ''Do Ho Suh: Part Two,'' 201 Chrystie Street, Lower East Side; 212-255-2923, lehmannmaupin.com.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

The clash between Japan and many Western nations over killing whales clicked up another notch last week. MORGANTOWN, W.Va. -- Here at the foot of the Allegheny Mountains, they are starting to party like it's 1988.That's the last time the Mountaineers had such a clear shot at the national title. That Major Harris-led team lost to Notre Dame in the Fiesta Bowl.If West Virginia defeats Connecticut today and Pittsburgh next week, it will most likely play for the national title on Jan. 7 in New Orleans. That notion hasn't been lost on the locals.Zippy Shearer, a member of that 1988 team, said in the parking lot before the game that folks at a local Buffalo Wild Wings last night celebrated Arkansas's upset of top-ranked Louisiana State by hoisting chairs in the air. The Arkansas victory put West Virginia, which entered the week No. 3 in the Bowl Championship Series, into the top two."Our run came a little more out of nowhere," Shearer said in comparing his team with the current team. "They were ranked to start the season."The feeling that the Mountaineers are on the cusp of something special could be felt throughout the parking lots surrounding Milan Puskar Stadium.Bill Henderson had just finished deep-frying a turkey at his tailgate, which was marked by the pirate flag hanging over the trailer. He said the main talk of the morning was about making flight and hotel reservations for New Orleans."There's a lot more anxiety," he said when asked the difference between today's tailgate and most others.A few yards away, Greg Stevens was sipping Crown Royal from a plastic cup and savoring the moment. He has been a season-ticket holder for 20 years, and before that he patrolled the sidelines while working for the West Virginia State Police. He said he thought that the Mountaineers would beat Connecticut by 14 points. When Pittsburgh comes here next weekend, it could be a different story, however."The backyard brawl is never easy," Stevens said.He took another sip of Crown Royal and continued soaking in the rarefied air in Morgantown, the improbable center of the college football universe.

The two-time world champion Stephane Lambiel of Switzerland edged the American Johnny Weir in the short program of the Cup of Russia yesterday in Moscow.Lambiel’s clean quadruple jump opened a combination and helped him move 0.34 points ahead of Weir. Lambiel led despite reducing his opening triple axel to a double.Andrei Griazev of Russia was third and showed no sign of injury in his precise jumps after tearing a ligament earlier this year.Earlier, Kim Yu-na of South Korea got off to a good start toward her second Grand Prix gold of the year by leading Yukari Nakano of Japan by 3 points after the women’s short program. Kim was one of three women to try a triple-triple, and the only one to succeed. In pairs, Zhang Dan and Zhang Hao of China took the lead over the Skate Canada winners Aliona Savchenko and Robin Szolkowy of Germany.

Robert Allenby shot a four-under-par 68 yesterday to maintain a one-stroke lead at the Australian Masters in Melbourne. He had a nine-under 135 total. His fellow Australian Aaron Baddeley shot a 66 to reach eight under, and five players were four shots back, including 18-year-old Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland. McIlroy followed his 70 with a 69.Allenby took a two-stroke lead with a birdie on the 17th, but gave the shot back on the 18th after an errant tee shot. Baddeley had eight birdies and two bogeys. He capped his round with a wedge on his final hole, the par-4 ninth, within inches for a birdie. Michael Campbell of New Zealand, the 2005 United States Open champion, failed to make the cut.

The United States improved to 3-2 at the Men’s World Cup with a three-set victory yesterday against winless Egypt in Toyama, Japan.Sean Rooney had 18 points and William Priddy added 12 in the Americans’ 25-22, 25-18, 25-19 victory. The top three teams at the tournament will qualify for the Beijing Olympics.

The Real Madrid sporting director assistant Carlos Bucero traveled to New York amid reports that the team was interested in signing the 18-year-old Red Bulls striker Jozy Altidore.Altidore’s agent, Richard Motzkin, would not say if he had met with Bucero, but he confirmed Altidore’s interest in Madrid.“We’ve heard of the interest, and for any soccer player it is a thrill to be linked with Real Madrid, and Jozy’s really happy about the news,” Motzkin said.Altidore made his United States national team debut in a 1-0 friendly victory against South Africa on Nov. 17.He scored four goals as the United States reached the quarterfinals at the under-20 World Cup earlier this year, and had nine goals in 22 games in Major League Soccer this season.

FALKENSTEIN--Arthur. Beloved and devoted husband of Marianne for 58 years; loving father of Peter and Jane and son - in - law Andrew Schachter, and proud grandfather of Joshua and Daniel, passed away on November 22nd, 2007, after a full and happy life. Those who met him were drawn to him by his amazingly warm and caring personality. Born April 30, 1924 in Plauen, Germany, he came to the United States at the age of 15. Arthur enjoyed a long and successful career as a CPA, and he devoted himself in every way to Congregation Habonim, founded by Holocaust survivors. His twinkling eyes, joyous smile, and loving spirit will always be with us. The funeral will take place on Monday, November 26, at 12:45pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Shiva will be held at the family home on November 26, 27, and 28 from 6-9pm. The family will also receive visitors on November 27 and 28 from 2-4pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Congregation Habonim, 44 W. 66th St, NY, NY or The Leo Baeck Institute, 15 W. 16th St., NY, NY 10011.

KNOBLER--Alfred, November 21, 2007, age 92. A graduate of Virginia Polytechnic Institute, he had a long and happy career in the Gift and Glass Industries as owner of Knobler International, a gift importing firm, and The Pilgrim Glass Company. He had a lifelong interest in issues of social and racial justice, and endowed scholarships for minority students at Virginia Tech as well as the Alfred Knobler Journalism Fellowship at The Nation magazine. He was a devoted benefactor of and volunteer at PS 42, the Bronx elementary school that he attended as a child. He is survived by his son Peter, daughter Joanna (Posy), daughter-in-law Jane (Dissin) Knobler, son-in-law Ira Kawaller, and grandchildren Daniel Knobler and Ben and Zoe Kawaller. Funeral arrangements are private. Donations in his name may be given to the Center for Constitutional Rights and/or organizations opposing Bush Administration policies.

The keyboardist Danny Federici, an original member of Bruce Springsteen's E Street Band, is taking a leave of absence from the group, which is on tour, while undergoing treatment for melanoma, Billboard reported. Mr. Federici will be replaced by Charles Giordano, who previously played in Mr. Springsteen's Seeger Sessions Band. On Monday in Boston, the E Street Band's set list was tilted toward material with which Mr. Federici is closely associated, including ''Kitty's Back,'' ''Tenth Avenue Freeze-Out'' and ''4th of July, Asbury Park (Sandy).'' ''Danny is one of the pillars of our sound and has played beside me as a great friend for more than 40 years,'' Mr. Springsteen said in a statement. ''We all eagerly await his healthy and speedy return.''

Günter Grass, the Nobel Prize-winning author, has sued Random House over a claim in a new biography that he volunteered to serve in the Nazis' Waffen SS unit, Agence France-Presse reported yesterday, citing the online edition of the German magazine Der Spiegel. Mr. Grass, right, is seeking an injunction against the publishing house over a phrase in a biography by Michael Jürgs, which reads: ''Günter Grass admitted ... that as a 17-year-old he willingly joined the Waffen SS.'' Mr. Grass wrote last year in his autobiography ''Peeling the Onion'' that he was drafted into the Waffen SS in the final months of World War II, an admission for which he was widely condemned because he had kept his Nazi service a secret for more than 60 years while urging other Germans to confront their painful histories. Mr. Grass told a Berlin district court that Mr. Jürgs had knowingly erred in writing that he had joined the Waffen SS willingly, his lawyer told Der Spiegel. He said Mr. Grass has handed the court a statement asserting, ''The conscription into the Waffen SS happened without my active participation.'' Mr. Jürg's book, ''Günter Grass,'' is published in Germany by Goldmann, which is owned by Random House, itself a subsidiary of Bertlesmann, a German company. A legal representative for Goldmann said the book would remain on sale pending a court ruling.

CASH INFUSION FOR H&R BLOCK H&R Block, the tax preparer, said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it had received $350 million of extra financing for its mortgage unit from Greenwich Capital Financial Products. The agreement increases the funds available to H&R Block's Option One unit to $750 million. H&R Block replaced its chairman and chief executive, Mark Ernst, on Tuesday after $1 billion of losses tied to subprime mortgages. The company said in August that an agreement to sell Option One to the hedge fund Cerberus Capital Management was collapsing. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

The earliest known full-length portrait of Queen Elizabeth I was sold at Sotheby's in London for £2.6 million (about $5.4 million), Bloomberg News reported yesterday. The price was a record for any British royal portrait, the auction house said, and more than double the pre-auction estimate. The winning bidder was Philip Mould, a London art dealer, who bought the portrait, above, along with another dealer. The painting was originally given by the queen to Griffith Hampden, the sheriff of Buckinghamshire, on a visit to Hampden House, Sotheby's said. The image dates from the 1560s and may have been painted by the Antwerp artist Steven van der Meulen. The work may have been intended to attract potential suitors, but Queen Elizabeth, known as the Virgin Queen, never married.

An article last Saturday about an address by Rudolph W. Giuliani to the Federalist Society described the society incorrectly. It is a conservative legal group with divisions of lawyers, law students and law professors; it is not a group of conservative judges.

A federal appeals court ruled that Sony Music must pay the founder of a small record company $5 million for failing to put his company's logo on reissues of Meat Loaf's album ''Bat Out of Hell,'' The Associated Press reported yesterday. Steve Popovich, the founder of Cleveland International Records, signed Meat Loaf, then known as Marvin Lee Aday, and in 1977 persuaded Epic Records, a unit of CBS Records, to release his album. Sony later bought CBS Records and paid $6.7 million to Mr. Popovich and his former partners to settle a lawsuit over royalties from ''Bat Out of Hell.'' The settlement required Sony to place the Cleveland International logo on future Meat Loaf albums, but Sony did not add the logo to ''Bat Out of Hell'' for more than a year. In a 2-to-1 decision reached Wednesday, a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in Cincinnati upheld a federal jury's 2005 decision awarding Mr. Popovich $5 million in damages. ''I worked too hard for them and made them too much money to get robbed now, in the autumn of my life,'' Mr. Popovich said. ''Bat Out of Hell'' has sold more than 30 million copies worldwide.

An article on Nov. 11 about the Carmona family of the Bronx, who struggle with illnesses and who received money to pay bills through The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, omitted the name of the agency that helped them, and referred imprecisely to the professional affiliation of their social worker, Margarita Colon. The agency is the Mosholu-Montefiore Jewish Community Center, and Ms. Colon volunteers for that agency; she does not work for Montefiore Medical Center, which provides services to the Carmonas. The article also referred imprecisely to the hospital where the Carmonas' 1-year-old twins spent three months in intensive care. It is the Jack D. Weiler Hospital of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, a division of Montefiore Medical Center -- not Montefiore itself.

SPRITZ--Norton, M.D. The Faculty and Administration of The NYU School of Medicine mourns the loss of our dear colleague, Norton Spritz, M.D., Chief, Medical Service, VA New York Harbor Healthcare System and Professor of Medicine, NYU School of Medicine from 1968-1998. Dr. Spritz was a beloved teacher, an outstanding clinician and a warm friend and colleague. As Chief of the Medical Service, he served as a mentor and inspiration to generations of students, residents and fellows. Dr. Spritz was a renowned expert in lipid metabolism as well as being a great physician. Dr. Spritz's kindness and his brilliance in various roles as teacher, mentor and ethicist will be deeply missed. Robert I. Grossman, M.D., Dean and CEO Steven Abramson, M.D., Vice Dean

Taslima Nasreen has been the target of death threats from extremist Muslims since 1994, when she published ''Shame,'' a novel that depicts violence against minority Hindus by Muslim fundamentalists in her native Bangladesh. Agence France-Presse reported that last week Ms. Nasreen, right, a self-proclaimed feminist and atheist, was being moved repeatedly, disguised in a black burqa, as authorities in India sought to assure her safety following violent Islamist protests calling for her expulsion from the country. ''I am mentally distressed; I am not well at all,'' Ms. Nasreen told the Press Trust of India on Friday by telephone from an undisclosed location. She has lived in the Indian state of West Bengal since 2004, in an apartment guarded by Indian security forces, while seeking permanent residence in India, which is officially a secular country. So far, however, the government, fearful of upsetting the country's large Muslim minority, has granted her only six-month visa extensions. The All India Milli Council, a Muslim group, said in New Dehli on Friday that all Muslim organizations would ''vehemently protest'' her continued stay. In March, an offshoot group of the influential All India Muslim Personal Law Board declared a reward for anyone who ''beheaded ... the notorious woman'' who has ''has put Muslims to shame.'' In August, Ms. Nasreen was assaulted in the Indian city of Hyderabad by Muslim activists, led by three state legislators, who hurled copies of her latest book at her and shouted for her death.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton had some tough words Saturday afternoon for the college student loan industry, saying banks and other lenders had ''ripped off'' students with high interest rates and repayment plans that were onerous on recent graduates and their families. ''I want to get rid of the student loan companies,'' Mrs. Clinton said at an event in Sioux City, as she laid out her college affordability plan in response to a parent's concern about high tuition prices. ''I kept working and I got a little scholarship, and I borrowed money from the government at 2% interest.'' ''I'm asking myself, why are we making it so expensive and costly for families today?'' she continued. ''I also want to eliminate the complicated form that families have to fill out. I don't know how many of you have had to fill out those forms, it takes dozens and dozens of pages.'' Mrs. Clinton's husband, former President Bill Clinton, battled the student loan industry in the 1990s as he championed the Federal Direct Loan Program, which eliminated for-profit lenders as the middlemen for students in that program. And an ally of Mrs. Clinton's, New York Attorney General Andrew Cuomo, has been waging legal fights against several lenders, accusing them of unscrupulous tactics to bilk students. Mrs. Clinton also supports the direct loan program, and she has also called for a ''student borrower's bill of rights.'' According to her campaign website, this proposal would ''make it easier for students to repay loans and give them a basic set of enforceable rights. ''It would give student borrowers the right to fair monthly payments that do not exceed a percentage of their incomes, as well as access to fair interest rates and fees. The bill would also give students the right to shop in a free marketplace for their lender and to borrow without exploitation. Finally, the bill will give students access to better information about their loans to provide students with better options during repayment.'' Mrs. Clinton's campaign event in Sioux City was chiefly devoted to fighting autism; she pledged to spend $700 million a year to expand research on the causes of autism and monitor its impact nationwide, and to create a task force to investigate treatments and services for those with autism. Her remarks about getting ''rid'' of student loan companies came as part of a length answer during the Q&A portion of the event with the audience, and was not part of a pre-planned attack on the industry, aides said. Mrs. Clinton has been critical of student lenders before, casting herself as an ally of middle-class families struggling with the rising cost of attending college. But taking on for-profit lenders, if she choose to, would come with risks: It is a multi-billion-dollar industry with powerful allies in Congress, many of them Republicans, thanks in part of campaign contributions over the years.

It's Sunday afternoon and I am manning (womaning?) the sports fort at the shiny new New York Times building on Eighth Avenue in New York City. No one else will be here for another four hours, so I thought, it's time to spend some quality time on The Fifth Down. I've got the AP wire at my disposal, and the Giants-Vikings game on one screen, and ... nothing on the other (thanks, CBS). I'll try to keep you posted on today's big headlines and happenings. If you're out there, please feel free to join the discussion and tell me what you see (just no profanity, no matter how badly your team -- real or fantasy -- is playing). Just don't get used to thiskind of attention. It's a holiday weekend after all. It's my gift to you (you may not consider it such a gift when this is over).

Jan Hudec of Canada won the first downhill of the World Cup season before a home crowd in Lake Louise, Alberta. Hudec, coming back from three knee operations, finished ahead of Marco Sullivan of the United States.At Panorama, British Columbia, Denise Karbon of Italy won her second straight World Cup giant slalom.

After bouncing a drive off a spectator’s bag and into the fairway, then hitting his second shot into a bunker behind the green, Fred Couples knocked a 35-yard shot out of the sand and into the hole to win $75,000 at the Skins Game in Indian Wells, Calif. Couples, 48, had not played competitively for almost eight months because of back trouble.

The Smith Center Redmen defeated Pittsburg/St. Mary’s-Colgan yesterday, 40-14, in the title game of the Kansas 2-1A high school division. It was their 54th consecutive victory and their 4th straight state championship. The Redmen need one more perfect season to break a state record for most consecutive victories, 66. “It’s been a top-of-the-mountain kind of season,” said Smith Center’s athletic director, Gregg Hobelmann.

Boo Weekley and Heath Slocum held their lead at the World Cup of Golf in Shenzhen, China, shooting a six-under-par 66 to give their United States team a one-stroke lead over France and Scotland. The Americans are at 20-under 196 and have led by one stroke after all three rounds.

The Eagles said quarterback Donovan McNabb would not play tonight against the Patriots. A. J. Feeley will try to stop unbeaten New England. The Panthers downgraded the status of quarterback Vinny Testaverde to questionable after he had back stiffness.
Denise Karbon of Italy won her second consecutive World Cup giant slalom to open the season. She had a two-run time of 2 minutes 42.71 seconds in Panorama, British Columbia.

Johnny Weir of the United States won the men’s figure skating title at the Cup of Russia in Moscow over the two-time world champion Stephane Lambiel of Switzerland. Kim Yu-na of South Korea won the women’s gold medal for her second victory in a Grand Prix event this season.

Kim Yu-na of South Korea won her second Grand Prix gold medal of the season yesterday with a precise and passionate free skate in the Cup of Russia in Moscow.Skating to the soundtrack of “Miss Saigon,” Kim opened with a triple-flip, triple-toe combination and did not falter until the middle of her program, when she wobbled in landing a triple lutz. She was slightly off form in her subsequent triple salchow, but she recovered to knock off a late-program double axel. The gold in Moscow and her victory at the Cup of China qualifies Kim for the Grand Prix final, which she won last year.Yukari Nakano of Japan won silver and also qualified for the Grand Prix final.Joannie Rochette of Canada climbed from fifth place after the short program to win bronze.Beatrisa Liang was the top American, finishing eighth.In ice dancing, Oksana Domnina and Maxim Shabalin of Russia were in first place after the original dance segment with a lead of more than 10 points on Nathalie Pechalat and Fabian Bourzat of France. Ekaterina Bobrova and Dmitri Soloviev of Russia were in third place.

The former T-Mobile rider Patrik Sinkewitz said the German cycling federation knew he used the blood booster EPO early in his career. Sinkewitz, 27, is serving a one-year suspension after testing positive for elevated testosterone levels before the Tour de France in June.

Natalie Coughlin of the United States won the 100-meter butterfly and Randall Bal won the 100 backstroke at the FINA short-course World Cup super final in Belo Horizonte, Brazil. Coughlin won in 56.39 seconds, nearly matching her tournament record of 56.34 set in 2002.

Axel Teichmann of Germany and Marit Bjorgen won the season-opening distance races at a World Cup cross-country ski meet yesterday in Beitostolen, Norway.Teichmann covered the men’s 15-kilometer freestyle event in 36 minutes 31.1 seconds, beating Lukas Bauer of the Czech Republic by 6.3 seconds. Anders Sodergren of Sweden was third, 31.3 seconds back.Bjorgen, of Norway, won the women’s race, beating Vibeke Skofterud by 20.3 seconds.Bjorgen, a former two-time overall champion, finished in 26:16.3 for her 29th World Cup victoryh.

SULZBERGER--Maye and Edward. This coming week we remember our darling Maye on the second anniversary of her passing, and we ''celebrate'' our dearest Eddie on his hundredth birthday. We loved them very very much, and are so grateful for the many years worth of our cherished memories. Daughter Susan, Grandchildren Jody, Mickey and Penny and our families

FALKENSTEIN--Arthur. Beloved and devoted husband of Marianne for 58 years; loving father of Peter and Jane and son - in - law Andrew Schachter, and proud grandfather of Joshua and Daniel, passed away on November 22nd, 2007, after a full and happy life. Those who met him were drawn to him by his amazingly warm and caring personality. Born April 30, 1924 in Plauen, Germany, he came to the United States at the age of 15. Arthur enjoyed a long and successful career as a CPA, and he devoted himself in every way to Congregation Habonim, founded by Holocaust survivors. His twinkling eyes, joyous smile, and loving spirit will always be with us. The funeral will take place on Monday, November 26, at 12:45pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Shiva will be held at the family home on November 26, 27, and 28 from 6-9pm. The family will also receive visitors on November 27 and 28 from 2-4pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Congregation Habonim, 44 W. 66th St, NY, NY or The Leo Baeck Institute, 15 W. 16th St., NY, NY 10011.

ADAMENKO--Elaine, 79, died peacefully on November 22, 2007. KALLETTA--Edward Sr., 89, passed away on November 22, 2007 in New Jersey. He was FDNY Assistant Chief Brooklyn Borough Commander and retired in 1977. WWII Veteran served as Lt. Army Air Corp Navigator on B29 Bombers in the Pacific. Born in the Adirondacks, NY, he raised his family in Brooklyn, NY. He retired with his wife, Claire to Ormond Beach, Florida in 1980. Beloved husband of the late Claire (nee Anderson). Loving father of Richard and Sheridan, Daniel and Anne, Marie and Dr. Philip Friscia, Edward Jr. and Joyce, William and Rita and Nancy and Jean. Adored grandfather of Alexis, Nicole, Danielle, Jennifer, Stephen, Juliette, Arielle, Edward III, Christina, Sean, Claire, and George. Great-grandfather of Emily. Also survived by his brother William and Marion of Ormond Beach, Florida. He was a member of Oceanside Country Club, Halifax River Yacht Club and the Moose Lodge in Ormond Beach, Florida. He was a member of St. Brendan's R.C. Church in Ormond Beach, Florida where he served as a Eucharistic Minister. Friend are invited to visit Monday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 at the Shore Point Funeral Home and Cremation Services, Inc., 3269 Highway 35, Hazlet, NJ. Mass of Christian burial St. Catharine's R.C. Church Holmdel, NJ, Tuesday 9am, 732842-3963. He will be laid to rest at Arlington National Cemetery in Arlington, Virginia. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to New York FireFighters Burn Center Foundation, 21 Asch Loop, Bronx, NY 10475.

To the Editor: In ''The System Flunked, We Didn't,'' (Op-Ed, Nov. 11), Tovah Klein, Marcia Sells, Peter Rubie and Amy Monegro mention that part of the reason their elementary school in East Harlem, Central Park East I, got a D was its 92 percent attendance.

DAY--Jerome Corbin, 71, of West Orange, NJ, died on Thanksgiving Day. A greatly loved husband, father, and grandfather, he is survived by his wife, Julie Sage Day, six children, and eight grandchildren. He was a tremendous support to his family and loved flying, sailing, music, history, and all things electronic. In lieu of flowers, send donations to the Zauber Fund at the St. Barnabus Medical Center Foundation or to the Adirondack Council.

McCREADY--Lauren S. RADM USMC (Ret.) died at his Redding, CT home November 15 from heart failure at age 92. Regarded as one of the founders of Kings Points Merchant Marine Academy in February 1942, he developed the wartime and peacetime engineering curriculum until 1971. During his career at the academy he brought the engineering program to full accreditation, founded the nuclear engineering curriculum and led officer training for the U.S.S. Savannah, he received the US Dept of Commerce Gold Medal in 1968 and a year later assisted in organizing the National Maritime Research Center. He held masters degrees from NYU and Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute and an honorary Doctorate of Science from the Academy. He is survived by Joan Arnold, his wife of 21 years. A memorial service will be held at 2pm, December 12 in the Mariner's Chapel at the Academy. Memorial donations maybe made to Seafarer's Friend, 77 Broadway, Chelsea, MA 02159.

HAZZAH--Dr. Ahmed, died Wednesday, November 21, 2007. He settled in Bronxville, NY in 1967 with his family. Ahmed worked at Mobil Oil, Chase Manhattan Bank, taught at New York University, and at Concordia college. Ahmed is survived by his wife Mary, and sons Ali and Adel. He was predeceased by son Karim in 1990. Funeral services private.

Without warning or consultation, our new neighbor cut down the trees that separated our properties, destroying our privacy and views. He had the legal right to do this -- I checked with the county -- but does he have an ethical obligation to mitigate or repair the damage or compensate us in some way? -- J.T., GREENBRAE, CALIF. Ethics concern the effect of our actions on others, and property rights notwithstanding, your neighbor's Mr. T act (Sly Stallone act? Bette Midler act? All three have been implicated in messy arboreal incidents) had a truly baleful effect. The law may have permitted it, but your neighbor should set a higher standard than mere legality.

FRANK--Conrad G., of New York City, died November 6, 2007. Son of Elisabeth (deceased) and Gerard Frank (deceased); brother of Henry (Rosalyn) Frank of Cleveland, OH, and uncle of Wayne (LuAnn) Frank of Denver, CO, and Nancy (Jay) Abramson of Barnet, VT; one greatniece and three great-nephews. Mr. Frank was born in Germany. After immigrating to the U.S. in 1939, he fought with the U.S. infantry in Italy during WWII.

THE NEWS British officials disclosed that the government lost two computer disks containing detailed personal information on 25 million Britons. BEHIND THE NEWS Privacy advocates described the loss of the disks as potentially the most significant privacy breach of the digital era. They disappeared in October after being sent out by a government agency via a private delivery service. Though protected by a password, the disks were not encrypted, and contain detailed personal information on 40 percent of the British population, including bank account numbers and the British equivalent of Social Security numbers.
The Count column last Sunday, about insurance losses from catastrophes, misstated the year of Hurricane Katrina, which was responsible for $41.1 billion in losses. It was 2005, not 2002.

SMITHERS--Charles Francis, 77, died peacefully at home on Thursday, November 22nd. A fourth generation partner of F.S. Smithers & Co., founded by his greatgrandfather, which was purchased by PaineWebber Inc. in 1973. The firm as Unger & Smithers became a member of the New York Stock Exchange in 1869 and subsequently was renamed F.S. Smithers & Co. He was a past president and board member of East Side Settlement House founded by his greatgrandfather along with J.P. Morgan and other prominent New York financiers. He also was a longtime director and treasurer of the Christopher D. Smithers Foundation, which has been a major supporter of treatment of alcoholism. He served as Vice Chairman of the Congressional Award Foundation and as an international trustee of The Duke of Edinburgh's Award-World Fellowship. He is survived by his devoted wife Anne. His children Chuck, Claire, Bonnie and his stepchildren Amelie de Richemont and First Lieutenant Philippe de Richemont. Also by his grandchildren Nicholas and Oliver Falla and his half sister Mary Vey Smithers. Services will be at St. James Church, 865 Madison Ave., on Thursday, December 6th at 4:00pm. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to East Side Settlement House, 337 Alexander Ave., Bronx, NY 10454.

SWARTZ--Marilyn, beloved wife, mother, grandmother, great - grandmother and friend passed away on Monday from complications from heart surgery. She was 79. Marilyn, or Nina to her grandchildren, was a passionate animal activist. She was an active volunteer at the Humane Society of Naples and Friends of Gummi, dedicated to helping rescue cats and dogs. In addition to her volunteer work, Marilyn was an expert knitter, often teaching knitting and designing sweater patterns for her family and friends. Her skill and love of knitting allowed her to establish and run a successful knitting and yarn business. Marilyn was born in Providence, RI as Marilyn Botvin, daughter of Max and Hatti Botvin. She lived in Pawtucket with her beloved husband and best friend, Philip Swartz who passed away 11 years ago. Together, they raised their two twin daughters, Ina Gulin and Janice Lightman. Marilyn's largest joy in life was her family. She will be forever missed by her daughters, her son-in-law Stanley, her beloved grandchildren, Rachael, Stacey, Mark, Joshua and John and her great-grandchild, Asher Philip. Her love and strength will be missed.

LANG--Dr. Theodore H., on November 23, 2007. Dr. Lang leaves three children, Dr. Dale Roskos (Dr. Richard Roskos), Stephanie Lang Goldsmith and Dr. Hewitt Lang (Pamela). He has six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. He is also survived by his partner Alberta and predeceased by his loving wife Kate. Dr. Lang devoted his life to serving the people of New York City and numerous additional capacities as well as being the author of numerous articles in the field of personnel administration.

FOLDI--Andrew, 81, opera singer, November 21, 2007 following a stroke. Renowned as Schigolch in Alban Berg's ''Lulu'', he sang the bassobuffo repertoire at opera houses including The Metropolitan Opera, La Scala, Chicago Lyric Opera. Foldi chaired the Opera Department at The Cleveland Institute of Music and directed Chicago Lyric's Opera Center. He leaves behind wife Marta Justus Foldi, children David and Nancy Foldi; first wife Leona Foldi; stepsons Christopher and Gregory Hancock, and five grandchildren. Donations in his honor may be made to the Franciscan Foundation www.fhshealth.org/founda tion

Relative Choices: In the late 1960s, when I was 16 years old and pregnant, the United States's adoption process was secret and punitive. In the religious maternity home where I spent six sodden months, a dose of guilt was dispensed with the daily vitamins: I was bad and should be punished ... I was meant to swiftly sail through ''delivery,'' as if it were the tonsillectomy I'd had as a girl. It was only during labor -- under lights and woefully ignorant -- that the real drama being enacted inside me was finally revealed. This was no impersonal mound of flesh I'd been carrying but a kicking life, fighting to emerge. And it had come from me, barely finished myself. ... I was strongly discouraged from seeing the daughter I bore on that July day. This was common policy.

ALPERT--Hollis, Author and Film Critic, died November 18, 2007 in Naples, FL. In 19501956, he was fiction editor at The New Yorker, a film critic for Saturday Review and Woman's Day, a book reviewer for The New York Times, and contributor of short stories and essays of famous film personalities to Playboy, Esquire and Cosmopolitan. He then became managing editor of World Magazine, and editor-in-chief of American Film Magazine. In 1966, he founded the National Society of Film Critics with Pauline Kael. He wrote nine novels and several biographies of Hollywood personalities. A compilation of his life's work resides at Lawrence and Lee Theater Research Institute at Ohio State University. For further details contact Lacey King at (239) 591-8470.

First Lt. Aaron W. Childers stood before a doorway inside a mud-walled compound while an Afghan and American patrol searched behind him. Paratroopers swept metal detectors over the dusty ground, looking for buried weapons and ammunition. A middle-aged woman, one of the compound's residents, faced the lieutenant, speaking emphatically and waving her arms. A young woman beside her hid her face beneath a shawl. The lieutenant's Afghan interpreter also hid his face, concealing his identity. ''She says there is no Talibs,'' the interpreter told the lieutenant. ''They have no Talibs here.''

BARCLAY--Robert G. Sr., age 85, of Brick, NJ died on November 22, 2007. He was a graduate of Princeton University Class of 1944 and Harvard University Law School Class of 1950. He retired in 1979 as a Vice President of The Chase Manhattan Bank, Trust Department. He was a member of the New York State Bar Association and the Phi Betta Kappa Society. He was a decorated World War II Veteran earning two Bronze Stars and a member of the 94th Infantry Division Association and the Presbyterian Church of Toms River. He was predeceased by his first wife Marie. He is survived by his wife Helen, two sons Paul and Robert Jr. and his wife Theresa, and three grandchildren Kelsey, Laura and Grant. Viewing hours are Sunday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Colonial Funeral Home, 2170 Highway 88, Brick, NJ. No services will be held on Monday. Funeral Service will be Tuesday 9:30am at the funeral home followed by interment at the Brig. Gen. Wm. C. Doyle Veterans Memorial Cemetery, Wrightstown, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations in Mr. Barclay's name can be made to either Helping Hands at Epiphany Church, Thiele Road, Brick, NJ 08724 or the Salvation Army, 1738 Highway 37, Toms River, NJ 08753.

DESCENDING INTO A CEREMONIAL KIVA AT BANDELIER NATIONAL MONUMENT, JULY 11, 2007 Julia Tannenbaum, 7, from West Hartford, Conn. ''I'd never been to New Mexico, and I'd always wanted to visit my cousins there. This was on the last day, at Bandelier. I got to climb up to some caves. And the very last ladder was a 140-vertical-foot ascent. It was a big cave, it was so high. Four families could fit in there. There was a kiva, a little hole that Indians have a meeting in. Three people went down -- my brother, my cousin Michael and me. Bandelier also has many bears. And you have to throw sticks and rocks and yell as loud as you can if you see one. There are also these little squirrels that have really long ears. They look really cute, but they eat your fingers for breakfast.'' As told to Seth Kugel

CAMPOREALE--Marc Lawrence, 1961-2007. A memorial service dedicated to the life of Marc Camporeale, deceased on October 28th, 2007, will be held on Saturday, December 8th at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Ave. at 53rd St., NYC, at 1:30pm. MULSHINE--Robert A., 66, passed away on November 20, 2007 at his home in Wainscott, NY after a long, brave fight with pancreatic cancer. Bob was born in the Bronx and graduated from Notre Dame University and received a law degree from Fordham University. He served as an officer in the United States Navy from 1963-1967. He spent 33 years at Price Waterhouse serving as a senior managing partner until his retirement in 2000. Bob was an avid golfer, loved the ponies, completed the New York Times crossword everyday and wrote a book while retired. He is survived by his wife Jane and four children; Mary Kathleen Ross of Laguna Beach, CA, Brendan of Indiana, Christopher and Tobin, both of Greenwich, CT and eleven grandchildren. He will be missed by all. Donations in his name may be made to the East End's Hospice, Post Office Box 1048, West Hampton Beach, NY 11978.

ECKMAN--Irving, 91. Beloved husband of Fern Marja Eckman, brother-in-law of Wilbur Friedman Sr. and Frances Friedman, uncle of Judith Eckman-Jadow, Julian Jadow, Mark Eckman, Alan Eckman, Ronald Weiss, Leslie Freeman, Roger Freeman, Bruce Freeman, Wilbur Friedman, Fred Friedman, grand uncle of Anna Jadow Bloom and Lindsay Jadow, and great-grand uncle of Caroline Bloom, died peacefully in his sleep on the morning of November 23, 2007 after a long illness. Irving was born and educated in New York City and was a Physiologist. During World War II, while serving as an officer in the US Navy, he conducted pulmonary-function research, and later taught at Hunter College, CUNY. Irving will be mourned by countless friends and relatives who loved him deeply and will be forever in our hearts. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the American Diabetes Association.

GAGARIN--Frances Moore, ''Patty'', died peacefully on November 18, 2007 at age 90. She was married for 65 years to Prince Serge Gagarin. She was the daughter of Charles W. Moore and Frances Wickham Moore of St. Louis. She was a resident of Greenfield Hill and Southport, Connecticut. Patty is survived by her husband, her two sons, Andrew of Watch Hill, RI and Charles of Carmel Valley, CA and two grandchildren Sasha and Serge Gagarin of Watch Hill, RI. Patty attended the Mary Institute of St. Louis and the Ethel Walker School. She was a member of The Fairfield Garden Club, The Country Club of Fairfield, The Pequot Yacht Club and The Aubichwi Gun Club. She was an expert in the early American antiques and head of Patty Gagarin Antiques for over two decades. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be sent to the Patty Gagarin Memorial Fund, Southport Congregational Church, P.O. Box 366, Southport, Connecticut 06890.

GREENBERG--Harriet, (indoor woman). Beloved wife of the late Carl. Devoted mother of Glen, Stuart, and the late Gary. Adored grandmother of Lauren, Jason, Sara, Caroline, Marybeth, and Kevin.

A loophole in New York State’s rent regulations that would have led to sharp rent increases for thousands of tenants was closed last Wednesday by housing officials. The rule allowed landlords withdrawing from government subsidy programs to immediately bring the rent in their apartments up to market rate by claiming that exiting the programs created a “unique and peculiar” circumstance.

New York City has agreed to turn over 1,300 pages of records that could shed light on the identities of some 50,000 people who have been buried over the past several decades at Hart Island, the city’s public burial ground in Long Island Sound.The records are a missing piece of a puzzle that has obsessed Melinda Hunt, a sculptor, writer and filmmaker who lives in the East Village, for more than 16 years.

After a tumultuous and bitter meeting replete with persistent heckling, the New York City Planning Commission voted this afternoon to approve Columbia University’s much-debated plan for a 17-acre campus expansion in Harlem. The plan now goes to the City Council, which is expected to modify it before giving final approval.The commission’s decision marks an important step — though not the final one — in the often difficult process known as the Uniform Land Use Review Procedure, or Ulurp.

Old Chinatown and New Chinatown are united at 21 Mott Street, where a rusty 50-year-old coffee shop sign was uncovered, refurbished and placed on the front wall of a hip new noodle shop — the sort of lost New York tale that draws people who yearn for tangible echoes of their memories.For more than 20 years, starting in 1956, Lonnie’s Coffee Shoppe sat alone among dozens of Chinese restaurants as the solitary Happy Days-style burger joint on Chinatown’s narrow streets. “Lonnie” was Lon Ying Lee, whose family originally hailed — like 80 percent of Chinese American immigrants before 1950 — from the Taishan region of the Guangdong Province, also known as Toisan.

In 2005, the State Legislature found that “certain forms of mold pose an unacceptable risk to New York State’s health and environment” and that “indoor toxins, specifically toxic mold, have been an under-recognized health and environmental problem.” The Legislature passed a law, effective Aug. 2, 2005, that called for the creation of a 14-member Toxic Mold Task Force to “assess, based on scientific evidence, the nature, scope and magnitude of the adverse environmental and health impacts caused by toxic mold in the state.”

David Justice, Robb Nen, Rod Beck, Chuck Knoblauch and many others were also included. But Raines, who had his best years with the Montreal Expos and had three productive seasons with the Yankees (1996-1998), appears to be the only player worthy of any consideration.

"Emeril Live!," the cooking show hosted by Emeril Lagasse that helped put Food Network on the map ten years ago, will cease production in two weeks, the cable channel confirmed on Monday.

The Times has reported that ABC News and the social-networking site Facebook "have formally established a partnership ­ the site's first with a news organization ­ that allows Facebook members to electronically follow ABC reporters, view reports and video and participate in polls and debates, all within a new 'U.S. Politics' category."

Teddy Bears were dragged into a scandal at a school in northern Sudan, as a British teacher was put in jail for allowing a student to name her stuffed animal "Muhammad." "How can you call a bear Muhammad?" a government spokesman told The New York Times. "Muhammad is the holy prophet of Islam." The article notes that Muhammad is also "one of the most common names in the Muslim world."
On December 15th one of London's oldest and most famous hotels, The Savoy, will be closing its doors for a 16 month, 100 million pound restoration.

NBC's "Sunday Night Football" broadcast of the game between the Philadelphia Eagles and the New England Patriots lifted the network to a first place win on Sunday night. The game scored the highest metered-market ratings for a prime time football game since November 2005, according to early data.
In what Sky News heralded as his first interview in four years, Matt Drudge served notice to "corporations that don't want to report real news" about the presidential election.
Doing it later is the name of the game.

When Mike Darnell, the president of alternative entertainment for Fox, says "the last time I felt like this was before 'Joe Millionaire,'" it seems like a sure sign that another scandalous reality show is on the way.

Garry Kasparov stopped by The Times recently to talk about his campaign in opposition to Russian President Vladimir Putin. Mr. Kasparov, the former world chess champion, was realistic about the steep odds against his fledgling movement succeeding at the ballot box. The point is not to win elections, he said, but to have elections.

What the Giammetti post reveals to me is that a candid discussion leads to all kinds of other thoughts and information: the real tool of our lives. We cannot have enough sharp tools in our box. I did not see a recent discussion about George Orwell on one of the TV book-chat programs, but I heard the participants discussed how language (and, inevitably, our understanding of events) is increasingly corrupted by feel-good phrases, like "support our troops" - mainly offered by political conservatives and spread by the media to help avoid scrutiny. I mention this because the fashion industry is under extreme pressure from marketing. One of the biggest marketing/PR hoaxes is that grand old Paris fashion houses should be revived. Why on earth do we need Schiaparelli? Ah, because Diego Della Valle can make some money. It's not complicated. There is no altruistic motive (let's save a great name!). The fashion world, like the literary and art worlds, is full of great names that only a few people take the time and interest to investigate. But it's limited, and should be limited. So they are reviving Ossie Clark-to capitalize on the fact that dozens of designers have already dipped into the Ossie well? Too late. Anyway, I'm not interested. I am intrigued by the latest Halston revival, mainly because of the players involved and because I like the challenge of seeing Halston done in a contemporary way. A journalist can examine the details of the current strategy without shoveling the nostalgia.
Florida quarterback Tim Tebow: His broken right hand won't stop him from hoisting the Heisman.

Emma Clarke, London's "voice of the Tube," has been heard by tens of millions of people since 1999, when she began relaying "stand clear of the closing doors" and other canned messages to commuters in her calm yet compelling way.
It's the latest fashion in venture capital: investing in technologies -- known as "cleantech" -- that aim to reduce fossil fuel emissions or provide alternative energy sources.

To consumers who pay dearly for cable television -- sometimes more than $100 a month -- a la carte pricing sounds like common sense, not to mention a welcome innovation. Why not pay just for the particular channels you watch and not for the ones you don't?

It is hard to define what makes a great quarterback, but when Brett Favre, quarterback of the 10-1 Packers, comes out and says that he's concerned about the team's complacency and rather than celebrate their success is worried about their future, it seems as if that might just be a blueprint. Favre tells Chris Jenkins of The Capital Times "I never thought we'd be 10-1 and be as loose as we are. I worry each week that this complacency and stuff will creep up on us, and it may. I don't know."
NBC's traditional Thursday morning telecast of the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade delivered a cumulative audience of 41.4 million viewers -- its smallest audience in at least five years.

The decision by Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi to resign sets off a shuffling of the Republican leadership that will likely keep Capitol Hill insiders scrambling throughout the remainder of the Thanksgiving recess.

JPMorgan Chase announced on Monday that it has appointed Barry Zubrow as its chief risk officer, a position that had been vacant since Don Wilson retired last year. In some ways, though, the bank seems to have done better than its rivals even without an official top risk manager -- for now, at least.

BOW, N.H. - As a politician, Senator John Edwards has always leaned heavily on his modest background as the son of a mill worker, but today he used it to argue that he is the most trustworthy candidate in the presidential race.

Wall Street is tightening its belt these days, as highlighted by Citigroup's carefully worded announcement Monday about becoming more "cost-effective." As layoffs and cutbacks pile up, it seems increasingly likely that the pain will spread beyond the financial industry.

Some Republican presidential candidates are breathing easier because of the news on stem-cell research, and some religious leaders are proclaiming a truce in their conflict with scientists. But I wouldn't bet on any longterm peace, for a couple of reasons.

"Here are facts," The Associated Press wrote in the introduction to a 178-word sidebar to its coverage of the the Middle East peace meeting beginning tonight in Annapolis, Md. But in the Middle East, the facts are rarely so easily summed up, as evidenced by an 886-word rebuttal to the sidebar, posted at Just World News, a blog by Helena Cobban.
Kazutaka Yamada, known as Kossan, is a rollerblading Buddhist monk who offers prayers to passersby in front of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

With private equity's buying bonanza over, at least for now, it may be time for buyout firms to think about selling their portfolio companies back to the public. By some estimates, two-fifths of the new shares offered in initial public offerings this year will come from private-equity-backed companies.

I came across a blog that thinks I simply do not understand what is going on in the housing market, as shown by the Off-The-Charts column on Saturday. That column argued that we've never had a severe decline in housing starts -- such as we have now -- without a recession.
Josh Ruxin is a Columbia University expert on public health who has spent the last couple of years living in Rwanda. He's an unusual mix of academic expert and mud-between-the-toes aid worker.
It's list-making season in the book world - you can find the Book Review's roster of 100 Notable Books of the Year here - and that's as true in the U.K. as it is on this side of the Atlantic.
The latest list of best-selling political books offers up quite an eclectic mix, from the humorous to the historical views of a wide range of authors.
The Writers Guild of America and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers return to the negotiating table today at 10 a.m. Pacific time.

Hedge funds can inspire terror in boardrooms these days. Whereas directors might once have trashed an angry letter from a hedge-fund manager holding a few million shares of their companies, in this age of investor activism, they are far more apt to listen -- and, in many cases, go along with the fund manager's demands.

With the regular season over for many teams, there will be plenty of hiring and firing in the next few weeks. Mike Sherman is expected to be named Texas A&M's new football coach at a news conference today, according to a report by Brian Davis of the Dallas Morning News. Georgia Tech has scheduled a news conference for later today and ESPN.com's Mark Schlabach is reporting that the university will announce the firing of Coach Chan Gailey. As for Nebraska, it has interviewed Bo Pelini and Turner Gill is expected to be next, according to Brian Christopherson and Steven M. Sipple of the Lincoln Journal Star.

All news reports about deaths that follow Taser shocks seem to come with two accompaniments: outrage over police brutality on the one hand, and a lack of definitive proof that the weapon was to blame on the other. A man's death in Vancouver, B.C., on Saturday was no different. But it happened to come a day after a United Nations panel appeared to take a stand against Tasers.

Take a good long look at that new logo hanging over the proceedings above us. The Bagger has gone all jaunty. During the off-season, corporate did extensive consumer research and discovered that the rumpled, over-the-hill version of the Bagger was in need of updating. The focus groups have spoken and the hoary use of metaphor in the blog will now be a thing of the past, as will cute asides about stuff that has nothing to do with movies.

Thankfully, the one thing the Bagger has been allowed to do is see movies, although he has been forced to wear a disguise that involves a fake nose and a rather unfortunate beret. And so far, this season has been like a trip to the magic multi-plex, where the Goobers are free, the popcorn is bottomless and all the clinkers are at some other theater.

G.O.P. candidate Rudolph W. Giuliani criss-crossed New Hampshire on a bus this weekend, shifting his strategy a bit away from his concentration on the states that vote Feb. 5 and focusing more on his rivals who have long courted the Granite State's vote.
Starting today, the Bagger returns for another year of Oscars analysis and more.
DES MOINES -- Oprah Winfrey is coming to town for Senator Barack Obama, his campaign announced today, scheduling a three-state tour beginning here on Dec. 8.

Dubai International Capital, a private equity company owned by the ruler of Dubai, said it had made a "substantial investment" in Sony, boosting the shares of the Japanese electronics and entertainment firm.

HSBC Holdings said Monday it would consolidate two structured investment vehicles, or SIVs, bringing $45 billion of assets onto the British lender's balance sheet. The move, which is expected to reduce the worldwide assets in SIVs, comes as United States banks are trying to organize an $80 billion fund to stabilize these kinds of vehicles.

Despite market volatility, the Citadel Investment Group, a hedge fund based in Chicago, has gained 27 percent year to date in what's shaping up to be its second straight showing of double-digit returns, The Chicago Tribune reported.

Losses in the distressed mortgage sector of the United States could reach $300 billion, only a portion of which has so far been accounted for by write-offs at major banks, according to a study released on Thursday by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

The perks for lawyers have burgeoned in recent years as firms pull out the stops to attract top-notch talent. While extras for the partners have always been common, many are now finding their way to associates - young lawyers who have not yet made partner, The New York Times reports.

The amount of money raised through initial public offerings in New York is set to surpass London for the first time in three years as companies fuel a surge in I.P.O. volume in spite of the turmoil in capital markets, The Financial Times reported.

The exit package for Warren Spector, the former president of Bear Stearns, insures that the man charged with the oversight of two internal hedge funds that spectacularly blew up this summer won't want for money, The New York Post reported.
Ford Motor's British union Wednesday endorsed India-based Tata Group's bid to buy the Jaguar and Land Rover units.

Genius Products, whose main business is the home video distribution of The Weinstein Company, is stirring considerable commotion with plans to list on the Nasdaq exchange as soon as next month, Fortune reports.

Since last week ended on a Wednesday, I never got around to my Friday links. So now that I'm completely off schedule, I'm treating Monday like Friday and sharing a couple of inspiring reads I consumed these past few days between turkey and television.

The mining giant Rio Tinto promoted its assets and growth prospects Monday as it moved to justify its earlier rejection of a takeover proposal from a rival, BHP Billiton, a multibillion dollar deal that would be among the world's largest buyouts.

When Doubledown Media published the first issue of Corporate Leader magazine this month, it included a list of the "100 Best C.E.O.'s." But if there is a second annual listing, at least four of those chief executives will be missing.

The British government has chosen a consortium led by Richard Branson's Virgin Group as the preferred bidder to rescue the troubled lender Northern Rock. The Virgin group has said it plans to repay 11 billion pounds ($22.6 billion) quickly to the Bank of England.

Goldman Sachs is aiming to raise between $4 billion and $6 billion for a new hedge fund as the investment bank tries to rebuild its reputation in the hedge fund business, The Financial Times reported.

23andMe, an online company backed by funds from Google that is selling a personal DNA test for $999, has made its start as a kind of genetics-focused MySpace or Facebook, but with the more serious aim of allowing medicine someday to target Americans' ills more precisely.

Does Rupert Murdoch have his eye on LinkedIn, the networking site for professionals? TechCrunch reported that it had heard an "unconfirmed rumor" from "a reliable source" that LinkedIn is in talks with the media giant News Corporation over a possible buyout in January.

The buyout shop, TPG Capital, is teaming up with Goldman Sachs's private equity arm to help finance its acquisition of a Russian supermarket chain, Seventh Continent, as TPG seeks to expand its European network.

Cerberus Capital Management, in its latest attempt to scuttle its $4 billion purchase of United Rentals, said it had filed a request on Wednesday for declaratory judgment in New York State Supreme Court.

The British House of Commons Treasury Select Committee plans another inquiry into Britain's private equity industry, which continues to fend off criticism over its secretive nature and swelling profits.

Lawyers who recovered about $7.2 billion in settlements for investors who were damaged by the collapse of the energy trader Enron in late 2001 are seeking $700 million for their efforts, the largest fee in history in a securities fraud case.
Rising oil wealth is lifting Islamic banking, which adheres to the laws of the Koran and its prohibition against charging interest, into the financial mainstream.
Holiday shoppers weren't the only ones seeking bargains on Black Friday.

An unlisted savings bank Caja Madrid has built a stake of more than 23 percent in the Spanish flagship airline Iberia in a move that could disrupt a potential bidding war for the airline, Europe's fourth-largest carrier.
Bain Capital has appointed the former chief operating officer of Arcor, a German fixed-line telecommunications provider to run one of its portfolio companies.

Philips Electronics has agreed to buy the Genlyte Group, a lighting maker based in Louisville, Ky., for $2.7 billion (1.8 billion euros), making it the top lighting company in North America and sending its shares up to a week-high.
Dutch electrical wholesaler Hagemeyer threw its full support behind a 3.13 billion euro ($4.6 billion) break-up bid from a French rival, Rexel on Friday.
Barry Diller, the chief executive of the Internet conglomerate IAC/InterActiveCorp, said Friday that the company would invest $100 million to expand in China by creating services for local users.

The China Railway Group, a construction contractor, said it had raised 22.44 billion yuan ($3 billion) in its initial public offering in Shanghai on Friday after generating record interest in its $5.5 billion offer on the Hong Kong and Shanghai markets.

Gottex Fund Management, the Lausanne- and London-based fund of hedge funds group, this month made its opening on the Swiss Exchange, the latest in a line of alternative asset managers cashing in on a perceived appetite among investors for publicly quoted hedge funds.

At least four of Canada's biggest financial institutions have signed confidentiality agreements to explore a takeover of DundeeWealth, and potential bidders are expected to decide within days whether to submit offers, The Globe and Mail reported.
Gail Simone has become the first woman to serve as “ongoing writer”  in Wonder Woman's 66-year history.
Another crack in the subprime mortgage market appeared to have been patched Thursday as two French banks bought out a bond-insurance company that has exposure to the mortgage crisis.

The Kelda Group, a British water utility, said Monday that it had accepted a 3 billion pound ($6.2 billion) takeover approach from a consortium of infrastructure investment firms. Its announcement of the bid on Friday sent its shares almost 15 percent higher.
As bidders continued to circle Northern Rock, SRM Capital, a Monaco-based hedge fund firm, has bumped up its stake in the troubled British lender.
