The S.&P. 500 and Dow Jones indexes are officially in correction territory, down more than 10 percent from their peak on Oct. 9.
The S.&P. 500, Dow Jones industrials and Nasdaq composite all ended the session officially in correction territory, down more than 10 percent from their peaks.
President Bush seemed to be more optimistic about this week’s Mideast talks than the Israeli and Palestinian leaders whom he welcomed to the White House today.
Europe’s largest bank, HSBC Holdings, said today that it would bail out its two structured investment vehicles by taking $45 billion in assets onto its balance sheet.
In the face of angry protests, a debate on Monday includes David Irving, jailed in Austria in 2005 for denying the Holocaust, and Nick Griffin, leader of a far-right party.
Sean Taylor, a safety, was fighting for his life today after being shot by an intruder at his home south of Miami.

Decades ago, tea makers took out ads that urged coffee-mad consumers to “Take tea and see.” Today, a leader in the booming tea market is asking tea drinkers to take another look at their favorite beverage.
Almost three weeks after rejecting a takeover proposal from BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto laid out its case today for why it thinks its shareholders should hold out for a better offer.
The Virgin Group appeared as the front-runner today to buy Northern Rock, the troubled British mortgage lender, after winning the backing of the Treasury and Bank of England.
Yesterday was the first time the two sides had held formal negotiations since talks broke down the night of Nov. 18.
Jason Kidd had 15 points and 14 assists to help the Nets overcome Kobe Bryant’s 31 points and beat the Lakers on Sunday.
The win came hard, but New England stopped a late Philadelphia drive to keep its perfect record intact on Sunday.

A New York City police officer was hit by a vehicle as he was crossing Queens Boulevard in Elmhurst, the police said. The police located the vehicle nearby, but it had been abandoned, said the police, who were searching for its driver. The officer, whose name was not released, was in stable condition in Elmhurst Hospital Center and was expected to recover, the police said.
Immigrants contribute nearly one-fourth of the economic output of New York State, according to a study to be released Monday.

Connor Sweeney threw for two touchdowns and Daquan Grobsmith ran for 116 yards and a score to lead Bishop Ludden to a 21-16 victory over No. 1-ranked Dobbs Ferry in the New York State Public High School Athletic Association Class C final in Syracuse.Bishop Ludden (12-1) snapped the Eagles’ 23-game winning streak and their quest for a fourth title in six years. Bishop Ludden, from Syracuse, has won 12 straight.

Aksel Lund Svindal of Norway, the defending overall champion, won the season-opening super-G yesterday in Lake Louise, Alberta, his second victory of the World Cup season.Svindal, the winner of the season-opening giant slalom in Solden, Austria, finished in 1 minute 29.19 seconds. Benjamin Raich of Austria was second in 1:29.63, followed by Didier Cuche of Switzerland in 1:29.79.

Aaron Baddeley of Australia won the Australian Masters, defeating Daniel Chopra of Sweden on the fourth playoff hole in Melbourne.Baddeley and Chopra were tied at 13-under-par 275 after 72 holes. They each parred the 18th hole three more times before Baddeley holed a par putt from 10 feet and Chopra missed a 6-footer.

Colin Montgomerie and Marc Warren gave Scotland its first victory in the World Cup of Golf, beating Boo Weekley and Heath Slocum of the United States in Shenzhen, China, with a par on the third hole of a playoff. Weekley missed a 15-foot putt for par on the third playoff hole after Montgomerie tapped in. Scotland shot a six-under-par 66, and the United States had a 67 to finish regulation at 25-under 263. The Americans forced the playoff on the last hole of regulation in alternate-shot play when Slocum made a 5-foot birdie putt. On the first playoff hole, Slocum missed a 7-foot birdie attempt that would have won it.

Marlies Schild of Austria raced to her second straight slalom victory, beating the world champion Sarka Zahrobska of the Czech Republic by 0.68 seconds in Panorama, British Columbia.Schild had a two-run time of 1:39.95 seconds. Zahrobska finished in 1:40.63, and Ana Jelusic was third by one-hundredth of a second. Schild, who won the season-opening slalom Nov. 10 in Reiteralm, Austria, has won six of seven slaloms dating to last season.

James Johnson set a Grey Cup record with three interceptions to help the Saskatchewan Roughriders beat the Winnipeg Blue Bombers, 23-19, in Toronto. It was Saskatchewan’s first Canadian Football League title in 18 years.

The police have charged a man with murder in the shooting of a man whose body was found on a street corner in Harlem last week. The suspect, Mohamed Musaid, 30, who the police said had no known address, was charged in the fatal shooting of Rafik Alsamet, 39, of Melville Street in the Bronx. The police said the killing was part of a continuing dispute. Mr. Alsamet’s body was found at West 133rd Street and Lenox Avenue on Wednesday.

Dealers at the Foxwoods Resort Casino have voted to unionize. The dealers voted 1,289 to 852 on Saturday in favor of joining the United Auto Workers, which represents about 6,000 workers in the gambling industry in Detroit, Atlantic City and Newport, R.I. The vote was held after the National Labor Relations Board rejected a motion by the casino’s owners, the Mashantucket Pequot Indians, to delay the process while the board reviews the ruling by regional labor board officials that found the dealers had the right to unionize. The Pequots had argued that tribal employment law has jurisdiction in the matter.

A woman crossing the street was struck yesterday by a charter bus leaving Chinatown for Atlantic City, the police said. The woman, 78, whom the police did not identify, was reportedly in critical condition at Bellevue Hospital Center, the police said. The accident occurred shortly after 11:30 a.m. on the Bowery at Broome Street. The woman was crossing Broome, walking south, when the bus, also southbound, turned left on Broome and struck her. A witness, Greg Horowitz, 23, an employee at a Bowery lighting store, said the woman was thrown several feet. No charges were filed against the driver yesterday. A man answering the phone at the bus company, Skyline Travel and Tour Bus, declined to comment.

Standing in front of the World War I memorial in Madison Square Park yesterday, Senator Charles E. Schumer called on the Defense Department to investigate reports that veterans disabled by wounds suffered in combat had been asked to return part of their enlistment bonuses because they were unable to finish their terms of service. “It’s just a disgrace,” said Mr. Schumer, a Democrat. The number of affected veterans was not known, but Senator Schumer said his office had received several complaints. He cited the case of Jordan Fox, an Army sniper from Mount Lebanon, Pa., wounded by a roadside bomb in Iraq. According to Mr. Schumer, the Pentagon acknowledged that the return of $2,800 of the wounded veteran’s bonus had been demanded, but said that it was a clerical error and that the debt had been canceled.

Three 28-year-old men were stabbed in a parking garage in Midtown early yesterday after an argument, the police said. The stabbing occurred shortly after 4 a.m. in the garage at 810 Seventh Avenue, near a restaurant and bar, Mars 2112, the police said. One man was stabbed eight times in the torso; he was taken to NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital, where his condition was upgraded during the day to stable from critical. The other two victims were in stable condition at St. Vincent’s Midtown Hospital, the police said. One of them had been stabbed six times, the other, once. There were no arrests yesterday.

MULSHINE--Robert A., 66, passed away on November 20, 2007 at his home in Wainscott, NY after a long, brave fight with pancreatic cancer. Bob was born in the Bronx and graduated from Notre Dame University and received a law degree from Fordham University. He served as an officer in the United States Navy from 1963-1967. He spent 33 years at Price Waterhouse serving as a senior managing partner until his retirement in 2000. Bob was an avid golfer, loved the ponies, completed the New York Times crossword everyday and wrote a book while retired. He is survived by his wife Jane and four children; Mary Kathleen Ross of Laguna Beach, CA, Brendan of Indiana, Christopher and Tobin, both of Greenwich, CT and eleven grandchildren. He will be missed by all. Donations in his name may be made to the East End's Hospice, Post Office Box 1048, West Hampton Beach, NY 11978.

E-commerce purchases are expected to grow a healthy but unspectacular 17 percent to 20 percent this holiday season over last year. But the Web's influence over what people buy could be growing even faster. ShopLocal, a company based in Chicago that helps retailers use their sites to drive in-store sales, says that the purchase of goods researched online but bought in stores is booming.

GAUGING HOLIDAY SALES According to two reports, retail sales surged on the day after Thanksgiving but the amount spent by each shopper fell, with stores dangling steep discounts and consumers worried about the economy. ''Enchanted,'' the new film from Disney, had a strong opening weekend, almost double that of its closest competitor (box at right). Thanksgiving weekend has been good to Disney, which has had nine of the top 25 holiday films. A big opening, like that for the fourth Rocky film or ''Toy Story,'' above, often translates into a strong run. But some relatively slow starters finish well, too. These include ''Three Men and a Little Lady,'' which opened in 1990 with $22 million and had receipts of $115 million, and ''The Bodyguard'' (1992), which went to $182 million after a $25 million start. SHELLY FREIERMAN

BOIARDI--Mario J., (81) child of the famous Italian-born chef whose line of food products -Chef Boyardee -which became a household name, died Saturday, November 24, 2007 at his home on Bennett Point Road after a long battle with cancer. Son of the late Ettore (Hector) Boiardi and Helen Wroblewski; beloved husband on Maureen E. Boiardi; father of five and grandfather of eight. Interment will be held at Arlington National Cemetery in Arlington, VA, at a later date. For more info see: www.fhnfuneralhome.com.

9:30 P.M. (ABC) NOTES FROM THE UNDERBELLY Those navel gazers in their 30s have returned to grapple with parenthood for a second season. Tonight Andrew (Peter Cambor) tries to be more assertive and turns Lauren (Jennifer Westfeldt) on in the process. Meanwhile Julie (Melanie Paxson) and Eric (Sunkrish Bala) hire a nanny who refuses to divulge her baby-soothing swaddling technique. And Danny (Michael Weaver) and Cooper (Rachael Harris) find themselves dating, sort of, when he starts cooking her dinner in exchange for legal advice. 9 P.M. (ABC) SAMANTHA WHO? Regina (Jean Smart) sets up Sam (Christina Applegate) on a blind date with her flooring contractor (Eddie Cibrian). Now Sam needs advice from her old boyfriend, Todd (Barry Watson), who has a new girlfriend (Kiele Sanchez).

CHASE--Gertrude Horowitz, November 18, in Boca Raton, FL. Formally of Bronxville and Mt. Vernon, NY, after a wonderful 99 years. Beloved wife of the late Marvin Chase and Leon Horowitz. Mother of Robert and Myra. Grandmother of Holly, Lee and Devin. Great-grandmother of Casey, Evan and Jonah. Forever in our hearts.

LUDWIG--Michael. Michael, you were like a brother to me. You will always live in my heart. Noah LUDWIG--Michael. Michael Ludwig was one of my dear friends. We both did many things together. I very much wish he had never left this world. Lawrence Silver LUDWIG--Michael. Taken from us suddenly on November 24, 2007. Beloved son of Lisa and Ed, adored brother of Josh, cherished grandson of Paula and Mel Nelson, Elizabeth Serkin, and Edmund Ludwig. He was a shining light to his countless friends, family, and all who knew him. His dazzling smile and loving spirit will always be with us. His short life was a gift to us all. Funeral services on Tuesday, November 27, 12:30pm, at Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, NY. Interment private.

ROSEN--Herbert, November 23, 2007, age 81. Herb was a family man first and last: loving husband to Barbara for 43 years; doting father to Jody and Jennifer; adoring grandfather to Lille and Haley; proud father-in-law to Zachary and Nick; faithful brother to Irwin and Mel; loyal brother-in-law; cherished uncle; caring cousin; devoted son. He felt privileged to serve his country in World War II as a Radioman 3rd Class aboard the U.S.S. William J. Pattison. Herb was a co-founder and past president of Marlboro Jewish Center, Marlboro, NJ, and a stalwart of the paper industry for four decades. Throughout his life, he was an honorable businessman, a dedicated mentor, and above all, a steadfast friend. Those who knew him will remember and celebrate his warmth, optimism, perseverance, and generous heart. A memorial service will be held Sunday, December 2, at 2:30pm, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. Donations in his name may be made to the 92nd Street Y, his home away from home.

SCLATER-BOOTH--Neil Lutley, of New York City, Fifth Lord Basing, Baron of Basing Byflete and of Hoddington, died after a long battle with esophageal cancer on November 24. He will be remembered for his generosity of spirit, integrity, wit, and great charm. Educated in England at St. Peter's court and Eton College, Neil graduated with a degree in economics from Harvard University. He held positions in the securities business as Executive Vice President of Akroyd & Smithers Inc, the US subsidiary of the London firm and as President of Standard New York, Inc. He was instrumental in its development into a securities, metals, investment advisory and international finance trading firm. Above all he was devoted to his family and leaves his wife, Patricia, and sons, Stuart and Andrew and his grandchildren, Eliza, Luke and Charles. A Memorial Mass will be held at the church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street. Contributions may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York/Hospice Care.

Nowhere is the relentless reduction in prices for technology products more visible than in the cellphone market. It seems that only months pass from the time a phone is offered for sale at $300 to the point that it is ready to be given away free in cereal boxes. (O.K., not quite, but that's not a bad marketing idea.) What's odd is that people are actually spending more on cellphones than they did a year ago, according to new data from the NPD Group. Americans bought 38 million phones in the third quarter, up only 4 percent from the third quarter of 2006. But they spent a total of $3.2 billion on those phones, up from $2.2 billion a year earlier.

The Kindle, Amazon's electronic book reader and online service, represents a major commitment by its chief executive, Jeff Bezos, above, to help shape the future of books. So it stands to reason that there will be both software upgrades and new versions of the device. That makes it fun to speculate about what's coming next. Here are some guesses: LARGER SCREENS, WITH COLOR When the Kindle's electronic ink technology improves, the screen may also, opening the device to books with lavish illustrations and color photos. Since one of Kindle's selling points is its ability to display magazines and newspapers, color would seem to be a must-have feature.

Memorial service to be announced. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. EISENSTADT--Abraham S. Our beloved brother and uncle whose love, wit and keen intelligence enriched our lives. Murray, Kappie, Ellen and Elliot

BERK--Harold I., Jack Lichstein, Joel Stoltz and the employees of Aberdeen Sportswear Inc. mourn the loss of our dear friend and leader, Harold Berk. Mr. Berk was the co-founder of Aberdeen Sportswear Inc. and helped build it into one of the industry's leading companies. We all had the privilege of celebrating with him the 50th anniversary of the company in 2006. His leadership, humility an warmth will be deeply missed. BERK--Harold I., died peacefully at home on November 23, 2007, at age 93, widower of Elaine Alkus Berk, his beloved wife of 67 years. He is survived by his brother, Mortimer Berk; nieces, Wendy Berk and Leslie Johnston; nephew, Richard Berk; grandnieces, Emily Ross, Meredith Dunlap, Stephanie Johnston and Rachel Berk; grandnephew, Michael Berk; greatgrandniece, Sonja Rose Dunlap; great-grandnephew, Seth Dunlap; loving caregiver and friend, Debbie Haynes. Mr. Berk was an abiding congregant of Temple Emanu-El and the devoted friend and partner for a half century of Jack Lichstein and Joel Stoltz in Aberdeen Sportswear Inc. The funeral will be at Noon on Wednesday, November 28 at ''The Riverside,'' on Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street. Burial will follow at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I. The family requests, in lieu of flowers, donations be made to Temple Emanu-El, 1 E. 65th Street, NYC 10065. BERK--Harold. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Harold Berk, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of his passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May all who loved him be comforted. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, President Roberta A. Calinoff, Secretary

For a long time, there was only one destination for your old electronics: the dump. In the last few years, environmentally conscious recyclers like Green Citizen have sprung up in some major cities. They ask you to pay a few dollars and promise to dispose of your old gear in a responsible manner. If you wanted to forgo that expense and even recoup some of your original investment, your best choice was to sell the device on a site like eBay. Brett Mosley, 25, of Denver, has an even more appealing idea. About a year ago, Mr. Mosley started BuyMyBrokeniPod.com and began buying, refurbishing and reselling used or broken iPods. Mr. Mosley, who is apparently comfortable around a soldering iron, started the company by posting an ad on Craigslist seeking damaged iPods. He has since hired two employees and fixed about 1,000 iPods. He renamed his company BuyMyTronics.com and expanded into iPhones and game consoles.

FLOM--Claire, The partners and employees of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the loss of Claire Flom, beloved wife of our partner, Joseph H. Flom. She is also survived by her children, Nancy Liang, Peter and Jason Flom. Six grandchildren and one great-grandchild also survive her. Celebrated for her keen intelligence, philanthropy, energy and wit, she was always an original. She participated in every stage of our growth. We all depended upon her wisdom and insight. Claire Flom will be deeply missed.

GUARRERA--Frank, The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Frank Guarrera, an admired and beloved member of our company who sang leading baritone roles from 1948 to 1976. His extraordinary total of 680 performances included 35 roles, two of which he sang more than anyone in the company's history: Escamillo in ''Carmen'' and Guglielmo in ''Cosi fan tutte.'' He was also featured in numerous new production premiers, broadcasts, and in many Metropolitan Opera recodrings including four complete operas. We extend our sincere condolences to his daughter Valerie, his son Dennis, and all his family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Dir.

FELDBIN--Beatrice ''Betty'' Beloved wife of Rabbi Abraham. Devoted mother of Rena Perelmuter, Judith Brown, Rachelle Urist and Aliza Avital. Loving grandmother and doting greatgrandmother -''Super Bubbie.'' Dear sister of Esther Katz. Services at Weinstein Garlick Kirschenbaum Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Avenue (at Ave H), Brooklyn, Tuesday at 11:00 am.

SMITHERS--Charles Francis, 77, died peacefully at home on Thursday, November 22nd. A fourth generation partner of F.S. Smithers & Co., founded by his greatgrandfather, which was purchased by PaineWebber Inc. in 1973. The firm as Unger & Smithers became a member of the New York Stock Exchange in 1869 and subsequently was renamed F.S. Smithers & Co. He was a past president and board member of East Side Settlement House founded by his greatgrandfather along with J.P. Morgan and other prominent New York financiers. He also was a longtime director and treasurer of the Christopher D. Smithers Foundation, which has been a major supporter of treatment of alcoholism. He served as Vice Chairman of the Congressional Award Foundation and as an international trustee of The Duke of Edinburgh's Award-World Fellowship. He is survived by his devoted wife Anne. His children Chuck, Claire, Bonnie and his stepchildren Amelie de Richemont and First Lieutenant Philippe de Richemont. Also by his grandchildren Nicholas and Oliver Falla and his half sister Mary Vey Smithers. Services will be at St. James Church, 865 Madison Ave., on Thursday, December 6th at 4:00pm. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to East Side Settlement House, 337 Alexander Ave., Bronx, NY 10454.

Big 12 Trophies First While Missouri Coach Gary Pinkel spoke to the news media after Saturday night's 36-28 victory against No. 2 Kansas, he sat in front of a crystal trophy given to the Big 12 North division champion.

COHEN--Morris. The West Side Jewish Center/Congregation Beth Israel expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of Rabbi Morris Cohen, son of the late Rabbi Ben Zion and Nechama Cohen, of blessed memory, and brother of Rabbi Harry Cohen, past president of The West Side Jewish Center/Congregation Beth Israel, Rabbi Sol Cohen, and the late Rabbi Simon Cohen, of blessed memory. May His Soul be Bound in the Bond of Eternal Life. Jason Herman, Rabbi Eliyahu Ellman, President

After years of delay and political squabbling, state officials have selected Danforth Development Partners to redevelop the long-vacant Victoria Theater on 125th Street, once Harlem’s largest and most elegant theater. Danforth plans to transform the Victoria, which sits a couple of doors east of its more well-known sister, the Apollo Theater, into a cultural center, with two live theaters and space for the Jazz Museum of Harlem, along with a hotel and 91 condominium apartments.
The Empire State Development Corporation named an ombudsman today to serve as a public liaison for the contentious Atlantic Yards development near Downtown Brooklyn.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other city officials announced this morning that 38 percent of the 21,183 applicants who passed the city’s firefighters examination on Jan. 20 are minorities, calling the result “a significant improvement” since the last time the exam was administered, in 2002, when 21 percent of those who passed were minorities. The Fire Department has historically been criticized for having relatively few women, blacks and Hispanics, compared with the far more diverse Police Department.The city also noted a 50 percent increase in the number of women test-takers who passed: 770 this year, compared with 512 in 2002.

Nearly one-quarter of New York City voters have an unfavorable opinion of Pope Benedict XVI and a similar proportion do not approve of the way he is doing his job, but an overwhelming majority of New Yorkers — 70 percent — believe his planned visit in April will be good for the city, according to Quinnipiac University poll results released this morning.

Robert M. Corrigan, a well-known urban rodentologist and Brooklyn native who works as a research scientist for the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, took questions on the City Room blog from Nov. 26-30.

In preparation for a $15 million expansion into a 14,000-square foot space designed by Maya Lin, the Museum of Chinese in America — renamed this month from the Museum of Chinese in the Americas as part of a rebranding campaign — is starting an archaeological project around five Lower Manhattan sites to document the shifting patterns of immigration and assimilation in New York City.

What we are reading elsewhere…

A new book challenges the widely held notion that the destruction of the original Pennsylvania Station in 1963-64 — a watershed event in New York’s postwar history — gave birth to the movement to preserve landmarks and save the city’s architectural heritage.

Does Eliot Spitzer have the judgment to succeed as governor? For a front-page article that looks at Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s tumultuous first year as governor, Nicholas Confessore and other reporters interviewed a dozen top aides and advisers to the governor, and more than two dozen lawmakers, former elected officials, labor leaders and political experts. Many seemed almost bewildered by how swiftly his fortunes have declined. Nearly all of the advisers now concede that they deeply misjudged how the driver’s license proposal would fare, though few believed that it would permanently hobble Mr. Spitzer and fewer still blamed the governor himself.
The early stages of the 2000 Senate race in New York offered a lesson on the politics of psychological warfare.

Well, it's officially official. "Into the Wild" blew in out of nowhere and won best feature. Ellen Page, cute as bug's ears and a lot more articulate, picked up the breakthrough actor award for her preggy teen in "Juno." And there were some kissing cousins in the ensemble award, with "Before the Devil Knows You're Dead" and "Talk to Me" tying.

The NBC talk show "Last Call With Carson Daly" will resume production Wednesday, making it the first late-night program to produce original episodes since the Writers Guild of America went on strike three weeks ago.

I was 24 when I first returned to my birth country. Stepping onto the plane that would carry me back to a country I had left 21 years before, I felt dizzy at the convergence of my past and present. Once again I was the 3-year-old girl, traveling halfway around the world to an unknown future in a foreign land - now a woman returning, a foreigner again.
The new United Nations Human Development Report is the first of these annual surveys to focus on the intersection of climate change and efforts to improve the human condition.

Barbra Streisand is endorsing Hillary Clinton. It's no great surprise, given her longstanding ties to the Clintons, but she had also given contributions to Barack Obama and John Edwards.

Throughout the day, reports have been circulating that Mitt Romney said during a fund raiser that he would not appoint a Muslim to a Cabinet post. Today, after a campaign stop in Florida, Mr. Romney confronted the issue, saying those reports were not accurate.

A Christian Science Monitor opinion piece claims that, when asked the rather odd question of whether he "would consider including qualified Americans of the Islamic faith in his cabinet as advisers on national security matters," Mitt Romney reportedly gave an even odder answer: "Based on the numbers of American Muslims [as a percentage] in our population, I cannot see that a cabinet position would be justified. The nominations for the Spirit Awards, which are handed out the day before the Oscars and often are a good measure of heat in the indie world, were announced this morning. Best feature nominations include "The Diving Bell and the Butterfly," "I'm Not There," "Juno," "A Mighty Heart" and "Paranoid Park." Later tonight after the Gotham Awards, which are an Eastern version of the same award ethos, the Bagger will do vector analysis to figure out what it all means.

Vulture at New York magazine points out that efforts to soft-peddle the darker implications of "The Golden Compass" are bumping up against the author of the book, who refuses to shut up long enough for New Line to tamp down the debate about whether or not God is killed in the movie. Among other golden bits of spin, Phillip Pullman has suggested, "I'm trying to undermine the basis of Christian belief," and "My books are about killing God."

One of my favorite blogs, in a Debbie Downer kind of way - I tend to poke around in it on days when I've read 7 bad novels in a row and feel like I may never read a good one again - is "101 Reasons to Stop Writing," written by Sean Lindsay. It's a daily blast of unfiltered comic bile, aimed at writers who aren't smart enough (in Lindsay's opinion) to know they're terrible.

The Monday night game was a truly terrible one, though the presence of the Dolphins can hardly be blamed. Heinz Field was a bog after pouring rain water-logged the new sod that had been put in because of wear and tear from five football games over the weekend. The red zone was reached only once, by the Steelers on their final drive, when Jeff Reed kicked the winning field goal with 17 seconds left for a 3-0 victory. (I've been saying this a lot about the Monday night game this season: Watch the highlights at your own risk.)

The good news for Citigroup is that it just found $7.5 billion to freshen up its wilting balance sheet. The bad news is that it sacrificed a lot to get it -- and it may still need more.

Could this be the dawn of a new business model for the music industry? Following Radiohead's decision last month to let fans pay whatever they wanted to download their latest album "In Rainbows", other artists, staid and crazy, are trying the same tactic.
On Friday, after TV Decoder noted that NBC was pre-empting the detective drama "Life" on Dec. 12, dozens of fans immediately wrote in to come to the show's defense.

Every year, the United Nations ranks its 175 members plus Hong Kong and the Palestinian territories using an index of human development -- mainly life expectancy, literacy rates and income. The usual suspects occupying the top spots on the list all have affluent, well-developed market economies, and politely switch places from year to year over small statistical shifts.

I got a kick out of reading Jill P. Capuzzo's story on the introduction of roundabouts in New Jersey. Growing up outside of Boston, I was raised on roundabouts and rotaries. There was a roundabout between my house and the high school. There was another one on the way to a local farmer's market. I never thought twice about them.

The women of "The View" expressed support for the striking television writers on Monday, following the decisions by Michelle Obama and John and Elizabeth Edwards to cancel their appearances on the show as a gesture of solidarity with the writers.

Shortly after Merrill Lynch ousted its chairman and chief executive several weeks ago, a report in The Wall Street Journal added to the firm's troubles by saying it had committed to off-balance-sheet deals with hedge funds to delay the reporting of potential losses. The Journal article even mentioned the dreaded "E" word: Enron (a Merrill client for whom the bank allegedly tried to help hide losses via sham transactions involving Nigerian barges).

And now for something completely different. I'm putting out a call to any creative souls willing to break the Hollywood writer's strike and post how they imagine the conversation went yesterday when President Bush and former Vice President Al Gore met privately for 30 minutes at the White House. (The meeting happened after a photo op in which Mr. Bush congratulated the American winners of Nobel Prizes, including Mr. Gore, of course). Mr. Gore told Sheryl Gay Stolberg of The Times that the entire chat was on global warming. Half an hour of conversation between Al Gore and George Bush on climate?

My book was featured on the "Today" show yesterday. A one-minute appearance on national television may not sound like a big deal for someone who writes for The New York Times regularly. But it did feel like a big deal. Television is very different from print. And even though I've appeared on television several times to talk about my book, it's still new enough to me that each time I do it, I learn something. The experience reminded me of a few truths about careers -- and a few truths about publicity.

The activist hedge fund manager William Ackman has raised his stake in the Borders Group, the country's second-largest book seller, to 17.1 percent, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing late Friday.
A Swedish bank, SEB, acquired Key Asset Management, a manager of funds of hedge funds based in London.
The shoe and hat retailer Genesco said on that it had received a subpoena from federal prosecutors in New York for documents related to buyout negotiations with Finish Line.
Two-time winner Barcelona reached the round of 16 in European soccer’s Champions League after a 2- 2 draw at Lyon, while Inter Milan, Roma and Sevilla advanced with victories.
Citigroup announced Monday night that it was selling a $7.5 billion stake to a Middle Eastern sovereign fund in the latest bid to shore up its balance sheet.

Guy Hands, the chief executive of the buy-out group Terra Firma, is in "a wild panic" about his $4.7 billion acquisition of EMI and how he'll manage to make a return on the record company, according to The Financial Times' Alphaville blog.

HSBC's announcement Monday that it would bail out its two structured investment vehicles, or SIVs, by taking $45 billion in assets onto its balance sheet, was an attempt to repair investor confidence and create a long-term solution for assets that have become difficult to value or sell since the meltdown of subprime mortgage market.

While Rio Tinto continued Monday to outline why a $153 billion takeover proposal from rival mining company BHP Billiton was not in its best interests, the company nevertheless seemed to signal that it was receptive to suitors.
Seeking to reassure banks amid the continuing credit crisis, the Federal Reserve said Monday that it would provide $8 billion in funds to ease concerns about lending during the holiday season.

British Airways and TPG, the American private equity firm, on Monday withdrew their 3.4 billion euro ($5 billion) offer to buy Iberia, setting the stage for a prolonged contest for control of Spain's flag carrier and increasing the prospect it could remain in Spanish hands.

Prosecutors argued Monday that a former Brocade Communications Systems executive was a key enforcer in an illegal accounting scheme, while her attorney said she was just following instructions when she backdated stock options.

Classmates.com on Friday set the terms of its initial public offering at 12 million shares, with an estimated price range of $10 to $12 per share in a bid to raise as much as $144 million, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.
Carbylan BioSurgery, a medical device company focused on medical products for osteoarthritis and chronic rhinosinusitis, said Monday it had closed a second round of funding with $20 million.

Yodle, which aims to solve the knotty problem of using the Web to connect potential customers with the local plumber, pizzeria, or podiatrist, has landed $12 million in a second round led by Draper Fisher Jurvetson, the company announced Monday.

The health insurer Cigna said Monday that it had reached an agreement to buy the health care unit of Great-West Life & Annuity Insurance for about $1.5 billion in a move to expand its business in the western United States.

Computer Sciences, a provider of computer services to government agencies and businesses, said federal regulators have concluded an investigation of stock option grants and do not plan any further action.

A Wachovia Securities broker must pay a fine of more than $346,000 after a judge found that he illegally traded on insider information concerning the acquisition of the propane gas distributor Blue Rhino.

The safety with the Washington Redskins, who was shot yesterday by an intruder at his home, died today from his injury, one of his lawyers said.

The wife of Steve Fossett, the adventurer whose plane disappeared in September, asked a court to declare him legally dead, saying she believed he was killed in a plane crash in rugged terrain. Michael A. LoVallo, a lawyer for Peggy V. Fossett who filed the petition in Cook County Circuit Court, said the request was a step toward resolving the legal status of Mr. Fossett’s estate, which according to court papers surpasses “eight figures in liquid assets, various entities and real estate.” Mr. Fossett, 63, disappeared Sept. 3 after taking off in a single-engine plane from an airstrip near Yerington, Nev., heading toward Bishop, Calif.
A 24-year-old man was arrested for the brutal killing of his mother and younger brother.
The investment underscores Citigroup’s depleted capital position, and also highlights the growing petrodollar wealth of Mideast countries.

Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland have agreed in principle to play each other in a tournament every other year starting in 2009, the Football Association of Ireland said. It would be similar to the defunct Home International Championship, which featured England instead of the Republic of Ireland.
The move is the latest action taken by the company to bolster its capital base, which has dwindled to unusually low levels after a spate of acquisitions and recent credit market turmoil.
For the second straight game, Stephon Marbury produced the defense and the leadership that Coach Isiah Thomas had asked or demanded, and for the second straight game, the Knicks won.

Mike Modano scored his second goal of the game 35 seconds into overtime last night and Marty Turco made 23 saves for the Dallas Stars, who collected their sixth consecutive victory with a 3-2 win over the host Islanders.
Candace Parker scored 13 points, leading four Lady Vols in double figures, to help top-ranked Tennessee defeat visiting Louisiana Tech, 81-60, Monday night.
Hundreds of residents were evacuated yesterday from a 23-story building in Lower Manhattan after rainwater flooded the basement garage and forced emergency crews to shut off power.

Striking teachers marched through Athens streets, part of a planned wave of strikes against what unions describe as government plans to raise retirement ages and cut benefits to millions of future retirees. The journalists union was set for a 24-hour nationwide strike today, with a general strike scheduled for Dec. 12.

Doctors across Italy walked off their jobs, forcing the cancellation of 5 million visits and tests, and 45,000 operations. Unions representing 135,000 medical workers called the walkout to protest stalled negotiations over contracts. Other unions have planned a series of strikes on Friday that are expected to idle many trains, ferries and planes, as well as buses and subway trains.

India, Pakistan and Afghanistan, along with the African nation of Nigeria, are the only countries where polio remains stubbornly endemic. The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation announced that it was giving $100 million to the Rotary Foundation of Rotary International to try to stamp out the crippling disease, and Rotary, which has already contributed $633 million to the fight, pledged to match the Gateses’ grant. Most of the money will be used for immunization.

Prime Minister Wen Jiabao said the transmission of the first photograph of the moon’s surface by a Chinese satellite showed that China had thrust itself into the front ranks of global technological powers. He unveiled the image in a televised speech at the Beijing Aerospace Control Center. The probe, launched Oct. 24, is expected to orbit the moon for a year as it scans its entire surface.
Chad’s army said its soldiers had killed 200 rebels in a four-hour battle at Abougouleigne, in the country’s east.

Shiga Prefecture’s government is calling on the public to eat enough bluegill fish to eradicate it. The “catch-and-eat” drive for Lake Biwa in the prefecture follows a rare expression of contrition from Emperor Akihito, who has admitted bringing the fish home in 1960 as a gift from Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago. The bluegill is Illinois’s state fish. It has turned into a nuisance in Japan’s rivers and lakes, steadily destroying native species. Shiga’s Web site is offering recipes for deep-fried, marinated and chili-sauce bluegill.

Emma Clarke, a 36-year-old voice-over specialist whose recorded warning to “mind the gap” is familiar to millions of London Underground riders, was fired after telling the newspaper The Mail on Sunday that she does not use the Tube anymore because it is “dreadful.” Miss Clarke, who has recorded hundreds of announcements for the Tube since 1999, “had done a good job until she started criticizing our service,” Dan Hodges, a London transit spokesman, said, adding, “London Underground is sorry to have to announce that further contracts for Miss Clarke are experiencing severe delays.”.
Concerns that problems in the credit market could push the economy into a recession drove investors to the safety of Treasuries and led to a sell-off of stocks on Monday.
A suspected gunman agreed reluctantly to testify for the defense after being assured that he was immune from prosecution but could not invoke the Fifth Amendment.

Volkswagen labor leaders sued Porsche in an effort to gain more influence on the board of a holding company that will oversee Porsche’s stake in Volkswagen. The Volkswagen works council filed the complaint Friday, said a spokesman for the German labor court in Stuttgart that is handling the case. Volkswagen labor leaders are unhappy that Porsche workers will get half of the six seats reserved for employees on the new board. Volkswagen workers want the seats distributed based on each carmaker’s size.

British Airways said it would not increase its stake in Iberia Líneas Aéreas de España, dimming prospects that British Airways would be part of a takeover bid for Iberia and increasing the likelihood that it would remain in Spanish hands. By not exercising its right to buy shares being sold by two of Iberia’s Spanish investors, British Airways and the American private equity firm TPG are unlikely to mount a full takeover bid of 3.4 billion euros ($5 billion), as was expected, analysts said. The decision opens the door for Caja Madrid, a large Spanish savings bank, to raise its interests in Iberia. Caja Madrid said last week that it wanted to exercise its own option to buy the Iberia shares held by Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria and Logista, the logistics arm of Altadis, raising its stake in the Spanish carrier to about 24 percent.

The Kelda Group, a water supplier to British cities including Leeds and Sheffield, agreed to be bought by a group including Citigroup and HSBC Holdings for £3.04 billion ($6.26 billion). Kelda’s shareholders will receive 1,100.65 pence a share, including a dividend of 10.65 pence, a premium of 17.5 percent over the closing price on Wednesday, the day before Kelda said it had been approached. Kelda, based in Bradford, also reported a 58 percent increase in first-half profit after raising prices at its Yorkshire Water unit, which supplies about 4.7 million people and 140,000 businesses.

The Murphy Oil Corporation bought a stake in an offshore oil project in Australia from the closely held Finder Exploration, its first venture in the country. Murphy, based in El Dorado, Ark., said it had agreed to acquire a 40 percent stake in an exploration permit for an area northwest of Australia and operate the project. Terms were not disclosed. “This acreage acquisition is important as it not only marks our entry into Australia where we see further growth opportunities but complements our existing Southeast Asia position, which is already yielding strong results in Malaysia,” Murphy’s chief executive, Claiborne P. Deming, above, said in a statement.
Caron Butler scored 35 points and Antawn Jamison added 27 last night to help the Washington Wizards defeat the host Dallas Mavericks, 110-98.
One month, Kellen Clemens is the team’s quarterback in waiting. The next month, he finds himself the starting quarterback on a losing team under heavy scrutiny.

George J. Zahringer III of Deepdale Golf Club in Manhasset, N.Y., a fixture of amateur golf in the New York area for more than 30 years, won the 2007 Jerry Courville Sr. Metropolitan Golf Association Player of the Year award. It was the 10th time Zahringer won player of the year, extending his own record. Zahringer had 844 points, 209 more than Brian Komline of High Bridge Hills and 264 more than the third-place finisher, Joe Saladino of Huntington.

A federal appeals court denied a petition to rehear an attempt by the Major League Baseball Players Association and Major League Baseball Advanced Media to get a ruling reversed that allows a fantasy baseball company to use players’ names and statistics without paying a licensing fee. A three-judge panel of the Eighth United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last month that the company, CBC Distribution and Marketing Inc., did not have to pay players, even though it profits by using their names and statistics. The motion was denied without explanation.

Jeff Gordon lost his car chief when Jeff Meendering joined Petty Enterprises as crew chief for Bobby Labonte. Meendering began his career at Hendrick Motorsports 13 years ago sweeping floors. He was the interim crew chief during a six-race stretch this season when Steve Letarte was suspended. His new job with Petty will start immediately.

Lawyers for four people convicted two years ago in the Balco steroids case filed a motion yesterday to oppose a government order that they return or destroy all grand jury transcripts and other sealed materials in the case, according to Victor Conte Jr., founder of the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative. The defendants were given materials to prepare their defense; they later pleaded guilty. The 18-page motion says the government request — which was made under seal and signed by a judge Sept. 11 — is “futile” and “unenforceable” because the sealed materials have already been widely shared, leaked and published outside of the criminal defense team. It also argues that the order would pose “an open-ended danger” of further leak investigations against the defendants, Conte, James Valente (Balco’s former vice president), Barry Bonds’s former trainer Greg Anderson and the track coach Remi Korchemny. It argues they may need the materials to prepare for testimony in future cases. Troy Ellerman Jr., a former defense lawyer, was sentenced earlier this year to two and a half years in prison for obstruction of justice after admitting he had leaked grand jury transcripts to a reporter for The San Francisco Chronicle. Natalya LaBauve, spokeswoman for the United States attorney, declined to comment.

Richard Paez resigned as Venezuela’s coach yesterday, saying he did not want to be an obstacle in his country’s attempt to qualify for its first World Cup. His resignation came less than a week after Venezuela beat Bolivia, 5-3, and moved in fifth place in South American World Cup qualifying. Four, and possibly five, teams will advance.

A stadium collapse Sunday night that killed seven people highlighted the crumbling state of Brazil’s soccer arenas less than a month after the country was chosen to play host to the 2014 World Cup, architects said. The victims in the collapse fell 49 feet when a 10-foot wide hole opened in the concrete stands at Fonte Nova stadium in Salvador, a coastal city of Bahia state. At least 40 people were injured.“Unhappily, a lot of stadiums have problems — some are in better conditions than others — but I think we could see another collapse like this if something isn’t done,” said Eduardo de Castro Mello, an architect who helped conduct a survey of Brazil’s soccer stadiums. The survey, which was released Nov. 1, found that Fonte Nova, built in 1951, was the worst of 29 major soccer stadiums around the country.
After a tumultuous and bitter meeting replete with heckling, the New York City Planning Commission voted  Monday to approve Columbia University’s much-debated plan for a 17-acre campus expansion.
The board of Grady Memorial Hospital effectively voted itself out of business Monday, the first step in at least a short-term escape from insolvency.
President Bush may be repeating Bill Clinton’s role in the peace process, yet he rejects what he sees as the meddlesome quality of it.
Areva, the French nuclear power giant, signed the largest deal in the industry’s history Monday, with China’s leading nuclear power company.
With patients living longer, the government is making hospices repay hundreds of millions of dollars to Medicare.
The electorate is upset, anxious and hungry for change. But “weak tea” is as good a term as any to describe what the Democrats are offering.
The controversial process of turning sewage into drinking water is getting a close look in several American cities.
Reflecting on his first year, the governor said that he knew he needed to temper his bluntness but also that the problems overshadowed real accomplishments.
Israeli and Palestinian negotiators made progress toward completing a joint statement for the planned Middle East peace conference in Annapolis, Md.
Demonstrators disrupted a forum featuring a British author who denies the Holocaust occurred and a far-right British politician.
Britain has opened a formal investigation after Danish television reported on Sunday that two Danish soldiers were killed by missiles fired by British forces who mistook them for Taliban fighters.

An article on Wednesday about the decision by Norwegian officials to close their consulate in Minneapolis misstated the annual cost, supplied by the Norwegian Embassy, of operating the facility. It is about $1 million a year, not $2 million.
Cable companies are media titans, and they should be regulated. The Federal Communications Commission can take an important step toward that goal.
The health insurer said it had reached an agreement to buy the health care unit of Great-West Life & Annuity Insurance for about $1.5 billion.
The carpenters’ union local for the East Side was placed under emergency supervision Friday as an independent investigator looked into allegations of no-show jobs
A Swiss man arrested on 20-year-old charges of taking part in the vast heroin smuggling case was released after federal officials acknowledged that they had destroyed evidence.
The New Jersey attorney general said Friday that a city police official acted improperly by asking about the immigration status of two journalists who witnessed a crime scene in September.

Lawmakers said Friday that they would pass a law to force health insurers that rank doctors to evaluate the doctor’s patient care first and stop using the doctor’s cost to the insurer as the sole measure.

Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein sent a letter to all teachers in the city’s school system yesterday, praising their efforts and saying that a new push to remove unsatisfactory teachers had been “badly misunderstood and mischaracterized.”
The mother of a 26-year-old drug user who died shortly after the police stunned him at least four times with a Taser has sued the town of Hamden and the sergeant who used the Taser.
A 30-year-old Brooklyn man died from stab wounds early Friday, and officers arrested a 30-year-old woman who the police said had a history of mental disturbances.
The development of Dane Reynolds, an explosive and intuitive surfer from Ventura, Calif., has been anticipated like that of few others in the sport in recent years.
Europe’s largest bank, HSBC Holdings, said Monday that it would bail out its two structured investment vehicles by taking $45 billion in assets onto its balance sheet.
Sean Taylor, a Pro Bowl safety with the Washington Redskins, was fighting for his life Monday after being shot by an intruder at his home in a suburb south of Miami.
For a leader who has everything, President Vladimir Putin of Russia looks increasingly desperate and threatened ahead of parliamentary elections.

Air traffic delays were worse on the three main travel days of this Thanksgiving holiday period compared with a year ago, according to preliminary Federal Aviation Administration statistics. Delays on the Tuesday before Thanksgiving affected 3,124 flights, an increase of 65.9 percent; on Wednesday, 2,678 flights, up 21 percent; and on Sunday, 2,442 flights, up 14.1 percent. Delays were down slightly on Thursday, Friday and Saturday. Weather was the major cause of delays, and the figures do not include mechanical breakdowns. Though President Bush ordered military air space opened to relieve flight congestion, its use appears to have been light. About 60 planes used the military space from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Sunday, the F.A.A. said. The agency did not have figures for later in the day.

A small plane being flown by a descendant of one of the brothers who built the Mayo Clinic crashed at a southern Minnesota airport, killing all four people aboard. Dr. Chester W. P. Mayo, 51, an orthopedic surgeon, was taking his oldest son, Chester Jr., 17, back to boarding school when the plane crashed on Sunday night at the Faribault airport. The names of the other two victims were not immediately released. The four-seat Cirrus SR22 plane burst into flames on its second landing attempt, said Elizabeth Isham Cory, a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration.

Representative Bob Filner, Democrat of California, has entered a plea days before he was scheduled to stand trial on assault and battery charges over accusations that he pushed a United Airlines baggage employee at Dulles International Airport in northern Virginia. At a hearing in General District Court in Loudoun County, Va., Mr. Filner entered what is known as an Alford plea to trespassing, according to a statement issued through his lawyer. The plea means that he did not admit guilt in the Aug. 19 episode, but acknowledged that sufficient evidence existed for a conviction. Mr. Filner, whose trial was to have begun on Dec. 4, was fined $100, the court clerk said.

A convicted murderer sentenced to life was on the loose after escaping from a medium-security prison in Albion, about 20 miles southwest of Erie. Guards conducting a routine inmate count on Sunday afternoon discovered that the prisoner, Malcolm Kysor, 53, was missing. The prison was locked down yesterday while the state police and correction officials investigated how Mr. Kysor was able to get free, the authorities said. Mr. Kysor was convicted in January 1987 of first-degree murder in the beating death of Barney Fenton, 40.

An Ivy League professor pleaded guilty to voluntary manslaughter for killing his wife last year as she wrapped Christmas presents, telling a judge that he “just lost it” during an argument. The man, Rafael Robb, 57, a tenured economics professor at the University of Pennsylvania, faces 4 ½ to 7 years in prison for bludgeoning his wife, Ellen, 49, last Dec. 22. She was reportedly planning to move out the next month and seek a divorce after a rocky 16-year marriage. Detectives theorized that the scene had been staged to look like a burglary.
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates called Monday for the United States government to commit more money and effort to “soft power” tools, including diplomacy, economic assistance and communications.
A bus crossed an Interstate highway median in Arkansas on Sunday and collided with a pickup and a tractor-trailer, killing three people and injuring at least 19.

Representative Julia Carson, an Indiana Democrat who announced over the weekend that she had terminal lung cancer, said she would not seek re-election to a seventh term next year. Ms. Carson, 69, has been away from Washington since September, when she was hospitalized for an infection in her leg. While she was recuperating, her doctor discovered the recurrence of lung cancer that had been in remission for several years, she said. Ms. Carson wants to complete her two-year term, which runs through 2008, said Len Sistek, her chief of staff.
Young and trendy Muscovites are in the throes of nostalgia for the staples of Soviet childhoods.
The federal government’s feeble citizenship agency has been unable to deal with a flood of applications that arose this summer.
Nearly five months after the mortgage mess spilled into Europe, the head of Commerzbank said the full extent of the damage was still unclear.
Arbitron delayed a wider rollout of a new system for measuring radio audiences, prompting sighs of relief from some radio stations but driving the company’s stock price sharply lower.
Sunday’s loss might have been the worst game of Eli Manning’s career. But when it ended, he dissected it the way he always does — little emotion, flat voice and no display of remorse.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s proposal is similar to those of Senator Barack Obama and John Edwards in terms of spending, goals and differences with President Bush’s AIDS policy.
New Yorkers have been known to swoon over manhole covers. The photographs by J. Adam Huggins in Monday’s Times offer a much uglier reality.
Georgia Tech fired Chan Gailey while Texas A&M hired Mike Sherman. Arkansas’ Houston Nutt and Washington State’s Bill Doba also departed days after emotional victories.
With the city looking to reward gains among the lowest-achieving students, principals at specialized high schools disagree over how their schools should be judged.
Almost three weeks after rejecting a takeover proposal from BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto laid out its case Monday for why it thinks its shareholders should hold out for a better offer.
Doctors administered an electrical shock Monday to Vice President Dick Cheney’s heart and restored it to a normal rhythm after an irregular heartbeat was discovered.
Mike Huckabee is clearly using his faith to differentiate himself from his Republican rivals in a new television advertisement running in Iowa.
The move by the Federal Reserve Bank was intended to reassure banks amid the concerns about lending problems and the continuing credit crisis.
The Computer Sciences Corporation said that the Securities and Exchange Commission had notified it that an investigation into its option-granting practices was over.
Royal Philips Electronics said Monday that it would buy the Genlyte Group for $2.7 billion in a move the company said would strengthen its position in energy-efficient lighting.
Mr. Tolkin, the long-suffering head of Sid Caesar’s celebrated television writing team, was present from the cramped, sweaty, malodorous beginning.
The “Declaration of Principles” signed Monday does not specify the eventual number of American troops nor the length of their deployment.

The Registered Traveler program was supposed to offer regular air travelers the technology that would speed them through airport security. Now it can be best described as a “go to the head of the line” pass.
Mr. DuBrow was the gravelly voiced singer for heavy-metal band Quiet Riot, captivated fans with high-intensity musicality, quirky theatricality and a hint of menace.
Mark Michel must pay more than $346,000 after a judge found that he illegally traded on insider information concerning the acquisition of a propane gas distributor.
Hank Steinbrenner, the senior vice president for the Yankees, stressed that the discussions with Minnesota about trying to obtain pitcher Johan Santana were at an early stage.

Warner Brothers named Jeff Robinov to be the president of a newly created Warner Brothers Pictures Group, which will manage the company’s filmmaking operation along with worldwide theatrical marketing and distribution.
Mr. Guarrera, a lyric baritone who sang at the Metropolitan Opera for nearly 30 years, was known for his slender but firm voice and winning stage presence.

Investigators said that they were “fairly confident” that a toddler whose body washed ashore last month in a plastic storage bin was a girl whose Ohio grandmother called the authorities after seeing a sketch of “Baby Grace.”
People involved in the talks said that while progress was being made, it was slow and incremental.
GlaxoSmithKline signed a deal on Monday to sell a nonprescription version of Merck’s cholesterol-lowering drug Mevacor.

For the tens of millions of Americans the question before the Supreme Court on Monday was pertinent: If an employer, or its agent, mishandles an individual 401(k) account, can the employee sue to recover the losses?
As the subway fare holds at $2, commuter rail tickets and New York City’s bridge and tunnel tolls will jump an average of 3.85 percent.
The European agriculture commissioner warned farm ministers on Monday that Europe’s resistance to importing genetically modified products could pose a threat to the meat industry.
Twelve, an imprint of Grand Central Publishing, bought world rights to Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s autobiography, in a deal pending approval by the Senate Ethics Committee.
Coach Andy Reid reaffirmed that Donovan McNabb — not A.J. Feeley — would start Sunday against Seattle if McNabb was fully recovered from his thumb and ankle injuries.
A dispute between the children of Lee V. Eastman, best known as Paul McCartney’s lawyer during the breakup of the Beatles, is simmering in a Suffolk County court.
The influx of Brazilian-born soccer players in domestic leagues around the world could endanger the geographic integrity of future international tournaments.
Scotts Miracle-Gro agreed Monday to pay $500,000 to resolve allegations that it violated testing rules for genetically engineered creeping bentgrass.
Two women are accused of stealing jewelry, designer luggage and other valuables while visiting open houses on Manhattan’s Upper East Side.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign is courting voters who may have been born before suffrage, hoping they might feel an emotional bond with the candidate.
I’m not the type to get embarrassed by people staring at me; I go to the airport dressed in a gigantic belt buckle, a cowboy hat and Western boots.
Another domestic carrier, US Airways, plans to start serving Heathrow Airport in London in late March, with flights from its hub in Philadelphia.
Shares of Restoration Hardware fell 6 cents, to $7.00, while Sears declined 4 percent, to $107.77 on Monday.
Dubai International Capital said Monday that it had made a “substantial investment” in the Sony Corporation, its first investment in a Japanese company.
A police officer breathed the dust at ground zero but started doing it on September 13, 2001, two days too late to be considered a victim of the attacks.
An evening paying tribute to a single song: “Brother, Can You Spare a Dime?”

Trudging through the rain-soaked quagmire of Heinz Field, the Pittsburgh Steelers defeated the visiting Miami Dolphins by 3-0 last night when Jeff Reed kicked a 24-yard field goal with 17 seconds left. It was the lowest scoring N.F.L. game in 14 years.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,867 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:.
AnchorFree, a company in Sunnyvale, Calif., has introduced a service that lets merchants offer free advertising-supported Wi-Fi to customers on store premises.
The disease is being transmitted to infants, older adults, women and heterosexual men at an epidemic pace, according to city health officials.
As aged farmers and gardeners in Europe die, there is a chance that the fruits, grains and vegetables they have tended to will be lost within a generation.
The Urban Divers Estuary Conservancy works at transforming New York City waterways from environments that are shunned to those that are protected and perhaps even loved.

David Prieto, in federal prison, is providing testimony that could free a man he says was convicted of a crime he did not commit - and he’s doing it without the promise of federal protection or a shorter sentence.
The N.H.L. still has goal judges, but they do not all still sit in Plexiglas boxes behind the end boards in back of the goals. In many arenas, the judges sit in the lower stands or in press boxes.
Hackers obtained access last month to the e-mail addresses and passwords of thousands of donors to 92 charities that use online database software and services from Convio Inc.
Al Gore, who was honored at the White House for winning the Nobel Peace Prize for his work on the environment, was granted a private tete-a-tete with the president.
For the “Balanchine Preservation Initiative” and other reasons, the Suzanne Farrell Ballet is one of the most courageous projects in ballet today.

The Bank of America Corporation is selling four paintings, including one each by N. C. Wyeth and his son Andrew Wyeth, in hopes of raising more than $1 million for three New York City nonprofit groups.

The Italian culture minister, Francesco Rutelli, announced yesterday that Giorgio Ferrara, a film and stage director, had been asked to “guide the rebirth of the Spoleto Festival,” which takes place in the small Umbrian city of Spoleto each summer.
The German government invited architects yesterday to submit proposals for the task of reconstructing Berlin’s Stadtschloss, right, a Baroque royal palace torn down in 1950.
Our house, not Bauhaus, a plan to reunite The Jackson Five, changes at Spoleto and more culture news.
The Jackson Five, Michael included, may reunite next year for a tour.

This series of meditations upon the triumphs and failures of the Revolutionary generation reminds us of the role that circumstance and luck played in shaping the nation’s fortune.
With the publication of issue No. 14 of Wonder Woman, Gail Simone  is the first woman to serve as “ongoing writer”  in the character’s 66-year history.
“Crossroads” seeks to mine musical gold from tension, not least from the anxieties of stars shown laboring outside their comfort zones.
Scientists are hoping to create more forests in California and other parts of the world.
The “Futurama” creators said they were thrilled to find that the studio believed it made more economic sense to commit to four DVD movies.
A chemical used as an antidepressant in humans can extend the life of C. elegans by 30 percent.
Learn from science as well as the wisdom of our ancestors, and wash your hands.
Are video games really bad for children? Yes, no and maybe.
What is the evolutionary value of art and why do we humans spend so much time at it?

A new source for cells now leads to the question of  how to make them useful to the body.
‘Drunken Angel’ by Akira Kurosawa is his first film to feel solidly like a Kurosawa movie.
In 1969, Dr. Denton A. Cooley took an artificial heart from the lab of Dr. Michael E. DeBakey and started a feud that ended up on the cover of Life magazine. Now they’ve made up.
Sometimes the will to help is what matters, even if the remedy isn’t perfect.
Piping plovers are fighting their way off the endangered species list, thanks to a difficult, and sometimes contentious, program to restore them.
A plant widely used in traditional Chinese medicine contains compounds that slow the growth of the germ that causes most peptic ulcers, a new study suggests.
Women in the sunniest countries seem to get endometrial cancer less often than those who live far from the equator.
The harsh tone reflected the increasing isolation of the Hamas rulers of Gaza, with the Arab states, including Syria, a patron of Hamas, having chosen to participate in the Annapolis meeting.
A new study has found a link between asthma and post-traumatic stress disorder, though the reasons remain unknown.
The Sudanese police arrested a British schoolteacher and accused her of insulting Islam after she allowed her pupils to name a class teddy bear Muhammad.
The antioxidant beta carotene may help prevent mental decline in men, a new study reports, but only with long-term use.
Jessica Snyder Sachs’s capable overview of the global war on germs could hardly be more timely even if it did not call to mind a variety of other recent headlines.
Dozens of youths clashed with the police for the second night in a row in a working- and lower-class suburb north of Paris on Monday.
President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday accused the United States of trying to taint the legitimacy of next week’s Russian parliamentary elections.
Why will the newest particle collider operate at lower energy levels than older ones?
When someone says life isn’t worth living, pay attention.
For decades, doctors have dismissed growing pains as normal signs of growing in small children.
A man with a deep voice may have a survival advantage, a better chance of passing on his genes, a new study suggests.
Ralph Holloway is widely regarded as a leading expert on the evolution of the human brain, even by many who have disagreed with his more controversial conclusions.
The California sea lion is a robust species, but in the past decade marine biologists have recognized domoic acid poisoning as a growing threat to its health.
Using odor and visual cues elephants are able to classify subgroups of humans.

Nearly a year after the New York City Opera gave up on the idea of leaving Lincoln Center to build its own home, the opera and the New York City Ballet have agreed on making changes to the New York State Theater.
Nawaz Sharif, the religiously conservative former prime minister, demanded an end to emergency rule.

Welcome to the tail end of the Thanksgiving travel period: All it took was a little bad weather to choke up the flight travel system nationwide.
Alexander Imich lost all his money in the stock market and remains in debt. His life is full, however, with his continuing studies in parapsychology.
The Giants probably need to win two games to make the playoffs. Even one might get them in. But is this all there is? For Tom Coughlin’s sake, the answer had better be no.
The Angels will pay Torii Hunter $90 million for the next five years while they pay Gary Matthews Jr. the rest of his $50 million contract for four more years.
A lawsuit by Tiffany & Company, which claims that eBay enables the trading of counterfeit items, could threaten the online marketplace’s business model.
Sensing that concerns over genetically engineered foods are subsiding, beet producers have cleared their growers to start planting biotech beets next spring.
Brooke Astor’s son and one of her former lawyers have been indicted on charges related to her financial affairs.

GUTTMAN--Miriam. The community of West End Synagogue, A Reconstructionist Congregation, mourns the loss of this dynamic, vivacious, activist and longtime reconstructionist member. Our sympathies go out to her beloved ''Natie'' and their children and grandchildren.

FOLDI--Andrew, 81, opera singer, November 21, 2007 following a stroke. Renowned as Schigolch in Alban Berg's ''Lulu'', he sang the bassobuffo repertoire at opera houses including The Metropolitan Opera, La Scala, Chicago Lyric Opera. Foldi chaired the Opera Department at The Cleveland Institute of Music and directed Chicago Lyric's Opera Center. He leaves behind wife Marta Justus Foldi, children David and Nancy Foldi; first wife Leona Foldi; stepsons Christopher and Gregory Hancock, and five grandchildren. Donations in his honor may be made to the Franciscan Foundation, P.O. Box 1502, Tacoma, Wa 98401.

Even before he released his humorous advertisement featuring a Chuck Norris endorsement, Mike Huckabee was gaining support in Iowa. The latest ABC News/Washington Post Poll shows Mr. Huckabee, a former Arkansas governor, and Mitt Romney, a former governor of Massachusetts, running neck and neck when accounting for the poll's five-percentage-point margin of sampling error. Mr. Huckabee was trailing by 18 percentage points in a similar poll of likely Republican caucusgoers taken in July.

10 P.M. (Discovery) EVEREST 2: BEYOND THE LIMIT With the summit in sight, the expedition leader, Russell Brice, gives his team a tough-love talk before they try to conquer Mount Everest, above. That includes a warning about how dangerous the climb will be -- and how he will not tolerate anyone disobeying his orders. At 11, in ''After the Climb,'' a new four-part series, Phil Keoghan (''The Amazing Race'') talks with amateur climbers from the 2007 trek, as well as with a roster of Everest mountaineers about their treacherous ascents of the world's highest mountain. 8 P.M. (ABC) A CHARLIE BROWN CHRISTMAS Charlie Brown, fed up with the materialism of the season, searches for the true meaning of the holiday with his friend Linus.

FLOM--Claire. The Gateway School community mourns the loss of its founder and long standing past board member and chair. Claire's founding of Gateway more than 40 years ago, with three students and a lot of guts and determination, was an extraordinary accomplishment, and well ahead of its time in the educational field. We honor her vision and achievements by continuing her work to serve children with learning disabilities. Everyone in the Gateway community and in the field of special education have benefited from her initiatives. Claire's vision has served so many children; her legacy lives on. Our condolences to her family including present Trustee Peter Flom. Warren H. Feder, Chair, Board of Trustees Robert B. Cunningham, Head of School FLOM--Claire. Fordham University and the Board of Trustees mourn the loss of our colleague and friend, Claire Flom. A Fordham Trustee for over a decade, she served as Vice Chair and as a member of the Executive, Capital Campaign and Academic Affairs Com mittees. She was a remarkable woman who will be remembered for her extraordinary contributions to education. Our thoughts and prayers are with her husband, Joseph, her children and grandchildren. John N. Tognino, Chair, Board of Trustees Joseph M. McShane, S.J., President FLOM--Claire. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Claire Flom, beloved wife of Joseph Flom and mother of Jason Flom, cherished leaders and esteemed philanthropists. The Flom family's historic commitment to the Jewish people and other humanitarian causes in New York, in Israel, and around the world is unparalleled. Such leadership, including Joseph's involvement in our Lawyers Division and Jason's dedicated service to our Entertainment Division, strengthens our ability to serve those in need. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Joseph; to Claire's children, Jason and Wendy Flom, Peter and Leslie Flom, and Nancy Laing; to her grandchildren; to her great-grandchild; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. FLOM--Claire. With profound sadness, we record the passing of Claire Flom, late wife of our esteemed Board Member, Joseph Flom, and late mother of our Executive Director, Nancy Laing. Our thoughts go out to Joe, Nancy, Peter and Jason. The Carroll and Milton Petrie Foundation, Inc. FLOM--Claire, The partners and employees of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the loss of Claire Flom, beloved wife of our partner, Joseph H. Flom. She is also survived by her children, Nancy Laing, Peter and Jason Flom. Six grandchildren and one great-grandchild also survive her. Celebrated for her keen intelligence, philanthropy, energy and wit, she was always an original. She participated in every stage of our growth. We all depended upon her wisdom and insight. Claire Flom will be deeply missed. FLOM--Claire. President Gregory H. Williams and The City College of New York mourn the loss and celebrate the life of Claire Flom, a woman of keen intelligence, elegance and grace. An adopted daughter of CCNY, the College was pleased to honor her with the 2007 Distinguished Service Award for her abiding interest in education, and in the great democratic promise of a good education for everyone. In the mid-sixties, when she determined that there was no decent school in New York for children with learning disabilities, she founded the Gateway School, where she served as administrator and secretary of the Board of Trustees for the next 13 years. She founded and served for 10 years as the chairman of the New York Alliance for Public Schools, and served four terms as a trustee of Fordham University. With her husband, she was a source of generous support and wise counsel to City College because she believed in our mission. Our hearts go out to her husband, Joseph Flom, her children and grandchildren, and countless others whose lives she touched. She will be greatly missed. FLOM--Claire. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the family of Claire Flom, the beloved wife of our dear friend Joseph H. Flom. A devoted wife, mother and grandmother and tireless education advocate, Claire will be deeply missed. Kekst and Company Gershon Kekst, President FLOM--Claire. SMITHERS--Charles Francis, 77, died peacefully at home on Thursday, November 22nd. A fourth generation partner of F.S. Smithers & Co., founded by his greatgrandfather, which was purchased by PaineWebber Inc. in 1973. The firm as Unger & Smithers became a member of the New York Stock Exchange in 1869 and subsequently was renamed F.S. Smithers & Co. He was a past president and board member of East Side Settlement House founded by his greatgrandfather along with J.P. Morgan and other prominent New York financiers. He also was a longtime director and treasurer of the Christopher D. Smithers Foundation, which has been a major supporter of treatment of alcoholism. He served as Vice Chairman of the Congressional Award Foundation and as an international trustee of The Duke of Edinburgh's Award-World Fellowship. He is survived by his devoted wife Anne. His children Chuck, Claire, Bonnie and his stepchildren Amelie de Richemont and First Lieutenant Philippe de Richemont. Also by his grandchildren Nicholas and Oliver Falla and his half sister Mary Vey Smithers. Services will be at St. James Church, 865 Madison Ave., on Thursday, December 6th at 4:00pm. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to East Side Settlement House, 337 Alexander Ave., Bronx, NY 10454. SMITHERS--Charles Francis. The Board of Managers and staff of East Side House Settlement express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our good friend and benefactor, Charles Francis Smithers. A member ofthe Board since 1962, former President and Chairman of the Board and longtime Chairman of the Investment Committee, he exemplified his family's 115 year dedication to East Side House. He will be long remembered. Peter D. Standish, President East Side House Board of Managers John A. Sanchez, Executive Director East Side House Settlement

A theater column on Nov. 13 suggesting that the striking movie and television writers turn their attention to the theater referred imprecisely to the time Tennessee Williams spent in Hollywood, in citing examples of playwrights who wrote for movies. He spent six months there in 1943 working on projects, including a Lana Turner film, but he was not ''cranking out screenplays.''
