DONOHUE--Edward Francis, 78, of Spring Lake, New Jersey, died Tuesday, November 20 at Jersey Shore University Medical Center. Mr. Donohue was born October 3, 1929 in Jackson Heights, NY, and grew up in Parkchester, NY. Edward attended St. Helena grade school and Cardinal Hayes High School, Class of 1947. Mr. Donohue graduated from Fordham University in 1953 and received his master of business administration from New York University. He served in the U.S. Army during the Korean War. Mr. Donohue was employed by Mobil Oil Company starting in 1949, in the purchasing department, and was promoted to national manager of distribution and rose throughout the company to become general manager of International trade and operations. Edward was president of Anschutz Energy Corp. from 1978 to 1981 and a senior consultant with International Crude and Products Trading Co. and Poten and PVM until 1983. Mr. Donohue was a member of Blessed Sacrament Parish, Staten Island, where he served as an usher and commentator. He was the commissioner of the Titan league basketball and baseball programs. He was recently a member of St. Catherines Parish, Spring Lake, NJ, where he was a volunteer in the finance committee and the meal on wheels program. He was also a member of the American Oil Traders Association, the National Republican Committee, Richmond County Country Club and the Spring Lake Country Club. Edward is survived by his wife of 53 years, Geraldine Taylor, his five children, Edward III and his wife Caroline, Geraldine Lacombe and her husband Mark, Mark and his wife Dawn, Jennifer Sommer and her husband Gordon and Gayle Skau and her husband Jeffery, his 14 grandchildren, Meredyth, Juliette and Isabelle Lacombe, Madelyne, Grant and Reagan Donohue, Gordon, Margureite and Paige Sommer, Madison and Lindsey Skau and Edward IV, Claire and Robert Donohue. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that monetary donations be made to the New Jersey Committee for Life, 490 Somerset St, Plainfield, NJ 07060.

SEIDMAN--Benedict S. of New Rochelle, NY passed away Monday, November 26th, 2007, he was 86 years old. A 3pm memorial gathering will be held Wednesday at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 LeCount Place, New Rochelle, NY, 914-6320324. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to The Bard College. SEIDMAN--Benedict S. (Dick), was a man of extraordinary passions, which included his family, Bard College, tennis, The New York Times, Gilbert & Sullivan and social justice. Dick passed away on November 26, 2007 at the age of 86. Dick was a journalist and businessman, who was president of The Metro Group of Long Island City for more than 30 years. He served in World War II and received a Purple Heart. Dick is survived by his loving family including his brother Lloyd, his three sons and their wives: Michael (Judy), Robert (Maureen), Peter (Julie), eight grandchildren and his companion, Sally Barnett. He was predeceased by his wife of over 60 years, Irene. A memorial will be held at George T. Davis Funeral Home in New Rochelle. Contributions in his memory can be made to Bard College.

CRESHKOFF--Nancy Freeman, 91, former editor, died at her home in Manhattan on November 19. Nancy graduated from Vassar in 1938. Her marriage to Frederick Harper ended in divorce. With two small children, she started a daycare center at home, then took a degree in early childhood education at Boston University. In 1951 she launched a daily program for pre-school children on Boston's new public radio station, WGBH. In 1953 she married Lawrence Creshkoff, the station's program manager. After moving to New Jersey in 1957, she worked as an editor at McGraw-Hill, then at Macmillan until retiring. In 1982, she went to the American Museum of Natural History, advancing from volunteer to associate editor of Curator, a quarterly journal for museum professionals. From 1999 to 2002 she volunteered as an editor in the museum library. She is survived by her husband of 54 years; four children: Mary and Fred Harper; Maggie and Rebekah Creshkoff; two granddaughters; and two great-grandchildren. Memorial gifts may be made to the Germantown Friends School in Philadelphia.

Video submissions from the public for Wednesday's Republican CNN/YouTube debate picked up sharply over the weekend, with 750 new videos pouring in on Sunday alone, right on deadline. That brings the total to about 5,000 (2,000 more than were sent in for the Democratic YouTube debate in July). CNN plans to show about 40 for the broadcast, which is to start at 8 p.m., with the candidates again jogging on stage one by one. The actual debate will start 10 minutes later and will run for two hours.

ROSEN--Herbert, November 23, 2007, age 81. Herb was a family man first and last: loving husband to Barbara for 43 years; doting father to Jody and Jennifer; adoring grandfather to Lille and Haley; proud father-in-law to Zachary and Nick; faithful brother to Irwin and Mel; loyal brother-in-law; cherished uncle; caring cousin; devoted son. Herb was a co-founder and past president of Marlboro Jewish Center, Marlboro, NJ, and a stalwart of the paper industry for four decades. A memorial service will be held Sunday, December 2, at 2:30pm, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. Donations in his name may be made to the 92nd Street Y, his home away from home.

An Indian film will be released officially on Friday in Pakistan, having been cleared by the censor board, a first for two countries that have banned each other's films for more than three decades, Reuters reported yesterday. The film, ''Dhan Dhana Dhan Goal,'' produced for 160 million rupees ($4 million), is set among London's Asian residents and includes some Bollywood stars, who are popular in Pakistan despite the official ban on their work. The film, a football drama, is to open in seven cities in Pakistan, including Karachi and Lahore. The arrangement is anything but straightforward, however. ''We got the permission because 'Goal' is technically a U.K. production, which was funded via a specially set up London-based banner, Aim Films,'' said Siddharth Roy Kapur, the chief operating officer of UTV Motion Pictures, based in Mumbai, which made the film. ''The Pakistan distribution deal with Lahore-based Eveready Pictures was worked out via Dubai-based distributor, Al Mansoor Films.''

HENLE--Mary. It is with great sadness that we announce the death of Mary Henle on November 17, 2007 at the age of 94 in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania. Ms. Henle joined the Graduate Faculty of The New School for Social Research in 1946, where she served as Professor of Psychology until her retirement in 1983. Ms. Henle was a renowned experimental psychologist, historian of psychology, incisive critic of psychological theory, and champion of the Berlin school of Gestalt psychology. Philip Scaturro, Chair, Board of Trustees Bob Kerrey, President Michael Schober, Dean, The New School for Social Research

STRAUSS--Herb. The Officers, Governors and members of the New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Friar Herb Strauss. Herb was a member for the past five decades. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Jerry Lewis, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Michael Gyure, Executive Director STRAUSS--Herbert H. Award-winning advertising executive and foundation president, died on November 25, at age 78, of complications from cancer. Herb Strauss' early career was centered on singing. A graduate of Princeton University, he performed in Triangle Club productions, and went on to leading roles in summer theaters. He then moved into television and advertising production, with positions at NBC, National Educational Television, Kenyon & Eckhardt, and Doyle Dane Bernbach (now DDB Worldwide). His creative work at DDB earned him a Grand Prix at the Cannes Film Festival, two ''Clio'' awards and two Emmy nominations. Subsequently he formed his own company, Herb Strauss Productions, where he created, produced and directed commercials, TV programs and corporate videos. Herb continued to sing. He produced and starred on two recordings, ''Folk Music for People Who Hate Folk Music'' and ''Songs and Stories for the Jewish Holidays.'' In addition, for more than 50 years, he has been cantor at the Port Washington Jewish Center, in Port Washington, New York. At his death, Herb was president of the Lauri Strauss Leukemia Foundation, which he and his wife Evelyn, with family and friends, created after the death of their eldest daughter, Lauri, from leukemia at age 26. To date, the foundation has raised and awarded research grants totaling more than $3 million; these grants, in turn, have generated more than $130 million in additional research funding. Herb is survived by his wife Evelyn; their daughter, Julie and her husband, David Safran; two grandchildren, Gregory and Emily Safran; Herb's sister, Ruth Berger; and Ruth's family. Services are being held on Tuesday, November 27, at 11:30am at United Methodist Church, 1515 Middleneck Road, Port Washington. In lieu of flowers, contributions will be gratefully accepted by the Lauri Strauss Leukemia Foundation, 30 Park Avenue, Suite 11F, New York, NY 10016. STRAUSS--Herbert. More than a friend -we mourn the loss of a spirited, pro-active and giving man, whose grace and good heart touched so many people, and whose initiatives through the Laurie Strauss Leukemia Foundation gave hope and renewed life to many others. Roberta & Willard Block and Family

SLAUSON--Sidney. Died peacefully on November 23, in his 98th year, at his home in Palm Beach, FL. Mr. Slauson was a graduate of Lehigh University and Rutgers Law School. Mr. Slauson combined a career in social service and the practice of law. During WWII and the Korean War, Mr. Slauson was national director of the USO. He was director in Paris, France, for HIAS, assisting displaced persons. Mr. Slauson was admitted to the New Jersey bar in 1938 and practiced in Bergen County, NJ, for over 40 years. He was general counsel for Russ Berrie & Co. and was a member of its board of directors from 1984-2005. In Palm Beach, Mr. Slauson was president of the Palm Beach Chapter of American Technion. Mr. Slauson was married for 68 years to his beloved wife Blanche and is survived by his daughter Gail Flatto, his grandson Adam Flatto and Adam's wife Olivia, the parents of his greatgrandchildren Julia and Alexandre. A private service was held in Palm Beach on Tuesday, November 27.

When Oprah Winfrey offered her endorsement of Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, a few months back, no one in Mr. Obama's campaign was entirely certain what it would mean. Would she be a quiet supporter, a fund-raiser? Would she actively campaign? Fiercely protective of her brand, Ms. Winfrey has previously eschewed politics. But she is scheduled to make her debut on the campaign trail next week with a two-day swing through Iowa, South Carolina and New Hampshire.

Mitt Romney might take after President Bush in one regard: He is reading up a storm -- and likes to talk about it. Mr. Romney stands out among the presidential candidates for how often he cites books, from across the ideological spectrum, in his speeches and forums. When talking about globalization, he often mentions ''The World is Flat,'' by the New York Times columnist Thomas L. Friedman; he likes to contrast the perspectives of David S. Landes in ''The Wealth and Poverty of Nations,'' and Jared Diamond in ''Guns, Germs, and Steel,'' on what explains the rise and fall of countries; he cites Doris Kearns Goodwin's political study of Abraham Lincoln, ''Team of Rivals,'' to describe the kind of cabinet he would want.

The Roundabout Theater Company will mount a new Broadway production of ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses,'' based on Pierre Choderlos de Laclos's 18th-century French epistolary novel, as adapted and translated by Christopher Hampton. The adaptation, first performed in New York in 1987, will be directed by Rufus Norris at the American Airlines Theatre. Laura Linney, above, will play the Marquise de Merteuil; Ben Daniels, in his Broadway debut, will play the Vicomte de Valmont. The limited engagement is scheduled to run from April 11 to June 29. ... Kathleen Turner will direct another Roundabout production, a revival of Beth Henley's ''Crimes of the Heart,'' to open Feb. 7 at the Laura Pels Theater. Previews are to begin Jan. 18. ... Algonquin Theater Productions, dedicated to grooming productions for runs on Broadway, Off Broadway and regional theaters, has taken over the lease of the Blue Heron Theater at 123 East 24th Street and renamed it the Algonquin Theater. Algonquin will renovate the space's two performing venues: the Kaufman, with 99 seats, and the Parker, with 45 seats, which will be used primarily as a rental space. ... On Dec. 3 the 92nd Street Y Unterberg Poetry Center will play host to ''William Blake at 250,'' the American premiere of a one-woman show by Ruth Rosen in honor of Blake, who was born in London on Nov. 28, 1757. Information: 92Y.org/poetry.

Suicide is more common among older Americans than any other age group. The statistics are daunting. While people 65 and older account for 12 percent of the population, they represent 16 percent to 25 percent of the suicides. Four out of five suicides in older adults are men. And among white men over 85, the suicide rate -- 50 per 100,000 men -- is six times that of the general population. Yet, says Dr. Gary J. Kennedy, director of geriatric psychiatry at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, ''If you consider only major depression as the antecedent of elder suicide, you'll miss 20 to 40 percent of cases in which there is no sign of mental illness.''

JONES--Jeffrey Owen, 63, formerly of Westport, CT, died Sunday, November 11, 2007 in Rochester, NY. Jones was a writer/producer and a teacher of film and animation at the Rochester Institute of Technology. He graduated from Staples High School in 1962; he was captain of the football team and president of the senior class. He was a 1966 graduate of Williams College (where he received the Grovesnor Cup as the outstanding Senior), a graduate of the Middlebury Foreign Language School and a Fulbright Scholar. In 1997, he won an EMMY in New York for Outstanding Fine Arts Programming. He is survived by wife Ellen Hyman Jones, son Eli Owen Jones, brothers Robert Haydon Jones of Westport, Christopher Jones of Manhattan, and sisters Jeremy Jones of Philadelphia, Jude Anne Jones and Pamela Cathlyn Jones of Westport. A memorial service will be held Friday, November 30, 2007, at 3pm at the Church of the Assumption, 98 Riverside Avenue, Westport.

Senator Trent Lott's announcement on Monday that he would resign in a few weeks added to the growing Republican exodus from Congress, but may have strengthened Mr. Lott's post-Senate job prospects. By retiring before the end of the year, Mr. Lott, the 66-year-old minority whip and Mississippi dealmaker who fell from power with a remark touching on segregation but then bounced back, avoids new rules forcing senators to wait two years before lobbying former colleagues.

LICHT--Marvin, beloved husband of Sybil. Loving father of Elayne and Jordan Lipkin, Sherry and Paul Carbery, Alyssa and Jonathan Held. Adored grandfather of Sage, Blaine, Jeffrey, Charlie, Ben, Jacob, Ilana and Louise. Dear brother of Stuart and Barbara Licht and Roberta and Fred Geller. His generosity, warmth, tenacity and courage will be sorely missed, but will live on in the hearts of all who knew him.

KENNEDY--Elizabeth Higgins, formerly of Bronxville, NY, died on November 19, 2007. She was the daughter of the late John R. Rafter and Elizabeth C. Rafter of Bronxville. Mrs. Kennedy was a graduate of Convent of the Sacred Heart in Noroton, Connecticut, and Manhattanville College. She was predeceased by her first husband, John V. Higgins, and later predeceased by her second husband, Joseph Kennedy. She is survived by her daughter, son-in-law, grandson and granddaughter, Justine H. (Jill) Pearis, Stuart M. Pearis, John P. Pearis and Meghan M. Pearis, all of Vestal, NY; and by her son and daughterin-law, Christopher P. Higgins and Kathleen M. Higgins of Saugerties, NY. A funeral mass was held at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY, prior to interment on November 23. She will be sadly missed and fondly remembered as mother and grandmother. Memorial contributions may be made to The New York Foundling, 590 Avenue of the Americas, 13th floor, New York, NY 10011.

WOLFF--Rita S. (nee Smith), of NYC on November 22, 2007. Beloved wife of Dr. William I. Wolff. Devoted mother of Richard, Deborah Dumovic, David, Alan, Lisa, Mitchell, George, Rebecca and Barbara Redmond. Dear sister of Francis (Tiny) and the late Vincent, Carl and Paul. Also survived by 16 grandchildren and a great many nieces and nephews. Visitation, Tuesday 10am, at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Dr, Tenafly, NJ. Funeral service, 11am, at the funeral home. Interment Brookside Cemetery, Englewood, NJ. Donations may be made to The National Endowment for the Arts, 1100 Pennsylvania Ave. NW, Washington, D.C. 20506. For directions visit: www.barrettfuneralhome.net

LUDWIG--Michael. Michael, you were like a brother to me. You will always live in my heart. Noah LUDWIG--Michael, The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of the young son and grandson of its devoted members and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Ellen Sunness, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Jonathan Blake, Assoc. Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor LUDWIG--Michael. Dear Michael, you've graced our holiday table for so many years. We will always think of you, especially at Thanksgiving. The Chatzky Families, The Linde Family, The Nelson Family LUDWIG--Michael, Our hearts our broken. Michael was a beautiful boy and we will never forget his beautiful smile. He will be in our hearts always. John, Jane, Carly, Adam, Lindsay and Annie LUDWIG--Michael. Taken from us suddenly on November 24, 2007. Beloved son of Lisa and Ed, adored brother of Josh, cherished grandson of Paula and Mel Nelson, Elizabeth Serkin, and Edmund Ludwig. He was a shining light to his countless friends, family, and all who knew him. His dazzling smile and loving spirit will always be with us. His short life was a gift to us all. Funeral services on Tuesday, November 27, 12:30pm, at Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, NY. Interment private.

A report in the Observatory column in Science Times last Tuesday about a study of co-evolution between a water flea and a bacterial parasite misidentified the journal in which the study appeared. It was Nature, not Science.

An article on Wednesday about the decision by Norwegian officials to close their consulate in Minneapolis misstated the annual cost, supplied by the Norwegian Embassy, of operating the facility. It is about $1 million a year, not $2 million.

SPERBER--Reuben, died on November 25th, shortly after his 100th birthday. He is survived by Doris, his beloved wife of 75 years, and by his sons Stephen, Joel, Frederick, David, their wives and eight grandchildren. He graduated from CCNY and practiced as a CPA with competence and integrity. Those who knew and loved him will be comforted by memories of a life filled with loving-kindness and good deeds. Services to be held 3pm, November 28 at Hills of Eternity Cemetery, Colma, CA. Donations in his memory may be made to Congregation Sherith Israel or The Jewish Home for the Aged, San Francisco.

The top local story in today’s newspapers is the court appearance of Anthony D. Marshall, who pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to charges of stealing millions of dollars and valuable property from his mother, Brooke Astor, the philanthropist and socialite, after she was found to have Alzheimer’s disease. Among the charges against Mr. Marshall, who had been his mother’s salaried financial adviser: scheme to defraud, grand larceny, criminal possession of stolen property and falsifying business records.

Has New York City’s remarkable economic expansion of the past decade been too much of a good thing? A panel of developers took up this question on Tuesday night in a panel discussion organized by the Municipal Art Society, with the title “The Oversuccessful City, Part 1: Developers’ Realities.”Not surprisingly, no one really argued that the city could be too successful. Instead, the often spirited discussion — which at times seemed dominated by angry members of the audience — focused on the dilemmas of affordable housing and out-of-scale development. Projects like Atlantic Yards and the redevelopment of the Far West Side came up. Charles V. Bagli, who covers economic development for The Times, moderated the discussion.

The Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, has named a local community board chairwoman to the City Planning Commission, following the political downfall of his previous appointee, Dolly Williams, a self-inflicted casualty of the Atlantic Yards battle. Ms. Williams agreed last month to a $4,000 fine from the city Conflicts of Interest Board, the board announced Tuesday, settling a complaint over a crucial zoning vote that paved the way for the Brooklyn mega-project in 2004. The planning commission is a 13-member body whose part-time commissioners are paid $48,000 per year to oversee zoning and urban renewal, subject to approval of the City Council.

A survey of post-9/11 effects on children released today found that children exposed to the dust cloud following the collapse of the twin towers were twice as likely to be diagnosed with asthma as those not caught in the dust cloud.In general, children under 5 years old had an elevated likelihood of being diagnosed with asthma in the two to three years after the event, though not as sharp an increase as the rescue workers (who were 12 times as likely to be diagnosed as the general population). The survey did not reveal evidence of elevated levels of post-traumatic stress in children.

Mr. Giuliani is put on the spot about how on earth, as a Yankees fan, he could support the Red Sox after they beat the Yankees in the playoffs. He says he's an American League fan and notes that when he was mayor, the Yankees won the World Series four times; since he left office, the Yankees have won none.

By land, by air and by sea, the disciples of Ron Paul converged on the debate hall here in St. Petersburg, Fla., in the hours before the debate here tonight. There were two planes circling overhead, one flying a Ron Paul banner, another with lights spelling out his name Goodyear Blimb-style. A ship circling in the bay just outside the hall was festooned with Ron Paul paraphernalia, blaring martial music. In the park, just beyond the security fences erected around The Mahaffey Theater, the Paulites outfitted a group that was decidedly young and decidedly loyal with shirts and stickers and other assorted Paul gear.

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, or C.O.P.D., includes both chronic bronchitis and emphysema - progressive, incurable lung diseases usually caused by smoking. Twelve million Americans are living with C.O.P.D., but researchers think at least that many have the disease but do not know it. In its early stages, C.O.P.D. may go unnoticed; doctors do not test for lung disease as aggressively as they do for high blood pressure or cholesterol. Yet, as The Times reports today, there are treatments that can ease symptoms and help patients live longer.

Open primaries ­ in which voters don't have to be a member of a party to vote for its candidates ­ have long been a thorn in the sides of national Democrats and Republicans. Now, according to the Associated Press, Virginia's G.O.P. is going to do something about it: "If you're planning to vote in Virginia's February Republican presidential primary, be prepared to sign an oath swearing your Republican loyalty. The State Board of Elections on Monday approved a state Republican Party request to require all who apply for a G.O.P. primary ballot first vow in writing that they'll vote for the party's presidential nominee next fall."

While you were sleeping on Tuesday night, Todd Bertuzzi came back to Vancouver for the first time since 2006, when he was traded to Florida for Roberto Luongo. And while reports indicate that he said all the right things, he left town as a minus player in Anaheim's 4-0 loss to the Canucks.

The Politico's Ben Smith takes a look at previously undisclosed records that indicate Rudolph W. Giuliani billed "obscure city agencies" -- including agencies responsible for regulating loft apartments, aiding the disabled and providing lawyers for indigent defendants -- "for tens of thousands of dollars in security expenses amassed during the time when he was beginning an extramarital relationship with future wife Judith Nathan in the Hamptons."

Nearly five months after the Blackstone Group went public, Stephen A. Schwarzman finally spoke out in defense of his firm and the private equity industry. But at least a few observers thought that the speech was a little too defensive and more than a little too late.

Nearly 25 million viewers tuned in for final results of ABC's "Dancing With the Stars" on Tuesday, according to Nielsen's estimates, the largest audience for the series this season but less than the fall finale a year ago. On Tuesday night, former Attorney General John D. Ashcroft became the latest backer of waterboarding to face a stirring moral appeal that came from the Bible, and may be written into our genes: "Do unto others as you would have them do unto you."

Bear Stearns, the investment bank, is eliminating 650 jobs, or 4 percent of its workforce, as it seeks to lower costs after losing bets on risky subprime mortgages. Bloomberg News said a majority of the cuts would be in the firm's fixed-income business; the Associated Press said cuts would likely come from the operations side, which includes information technology and legal departments.

An upstate New York judge who detained 46 people in his courtroom when a cell phone call interrupted proceedings was removed from the bench Tuesday. The phone rang while Niagara Falls City Court Judge Robert Restaino was hearing domestic violence cases. ''Everyone is going to jail,'' Restaino said. ''Every single person is going to jail in this courtroom unless I get that instrument now." Read more.

After live-blogging the Gothams last night to mixed effect -- he got the name of the winning movie, "Into the Wild" wrong for a few minutes -- the Bagger was sort of played out. Perhaps it was the final stop of the evening, at the Tick Tock diner on Route 3 in New Jersey, where he flyspecked the copy he had put up and finally ate something. If there is a place psychically more distant from the glamour of the Gothams than the Tick Tock, the Bagger has never been there. It is the kind of joint where third-string mafiosi go to profile, being careful not to park in that one spot where Uncle Vinny was probably buried under the asphalt some time ago. The food, though, is wonderful and if its good enough for the real-life Sopranos, it is good enough for the Bagger.

The National Weather Service's red flags are flying again in Southern California, and they are being whipped by the Santa Ana winds that were merciless during late October's blazes. A severe warning of fire risk is in effect until 10 p.m. Eastern time for much of the region.

A British hedge fund has hired a former litigator to invest $100 million in European legal disputes, in what The Times of London says is believed to be the first formal arrangement of its kind.

Absolute Capital, an Australian hedge fund that suspended withdrawals because of the turmoil in credit markets, has appointed an outside administrator to review the business, the company said Tuesday.

Shares in UBS powered higher on Wednesday on speculation that Asian or Gulf-based investors might target European banks whose stock has weakened in the wake of the subprime crisis. The speculation was prompted by Citigroup's $7.5 billion stake sale to Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund.

Norman Mailer won The Literary Review's Bad Sex in Fiction Award, becoming the first posthumously honored author. The judges paid tribute to a notable coupling (discretion advised) in "The Castle in the Forest," Mailer's novel about Hitler. "We are sure that he would have taken the prize in good humor," the judges said of Mailer, who died this month at 84. Read more on the awards (fifth item).

A federal grand jury indicted one of the nation’s most successful trial lawyers, Richard F. Scruggs, on criminal charges that he engaged in a scheme to bribe a judge.
The newly released documents provide insights into America’s relationship with Israel.
The charges include kidnapping and armed robbery, stemming from a confrontation in a Las Vegas hotel room.
James L. Jones will report to Condoleezza Rice as part of what the White House hopes will be an intensified negotiating track following the Annapolis conference.
The Dow closed more than 330 points higher today after unusually candid remarks by a top Federal Reserve official, who appeared to open the door to further interest rate cuts.
Pervez Musharraf remains president and will be sworn in to a new five-year term on Thursday, but as a civilian leader his power will be diminished.
LeBron James scored 38 points, including a crucial 3-pointer and six free throws in overtime, for the Cleveland Cavaliers Tuesday night in a 109-104 victory over the visiting Boston Celtics.
The unfriendly confines of the Izod Center tripped the Nets up again Tuesday night as they lost their fifth straight game at home, falling to the Memphis Grizzlies.

Oral Roberts University’s regents said that they would separate the university from the ministry headed by Richard Roberts, the television evangelist accused in a lawsuit of tapping university and ministry money to finance a lavish lifestyle.
Up to 50 residents of a Brooklyn building were displaced from their homes after stairs in an apartment building collapsed Tuesday night.
Scientists are updating the National Cancer Institute’s online risk calculator to reflect newer data on black women and cancer.
American consumers jammed online shopping sites on Monday, the official start of the holiday season for e-tailers, resulting in robust sales, according to an Internet research company.
A Portuguese oil company, Galp Energia, plans to announce that it is building a 6,500-barrel-a-day plant to make diesel fuel from vegetable oils using a method akin to refining oil.
New data showed that Abbott Laboratories’ new drug-coated heart stent, Xience V, ouperformed the market leader in preventing coronary arteries from clogging again.
After he fatally shot his mother and younger brother two Sundays ago, Lamar J.  Platt maintained his composure around unsuspecting coworkers and neighbors.
In the past week, George J. Mitchell has informed the players union and baseball officials that the report would be issued in December.

The French drink company Rémy Cointreau said its first-half profit fell from a year earlier, when it booked gains from asset sales. Net income at Rémy Cointreau, the maker of Rémy Martin cognac and Piper-Heidsieck Champagne, dropped to $56.5 million (38.1 million euros) for the six months through Sept. 30, from 75.7 million euros, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 5.6 percent, to 374.4 million euros ($555.7 million).

Business confidence in Germany rose in November for the first time since April, a closely watched survey showed, defying analysts’ expectations for Europe’s largest economy. Another report, this one from the government, estimated that Germany’s annual inflation rose to 3 percent this month, its highest level in more than 13 years, as a result of high prices for oil products, food and beverages. The Ifo Institute for Economic Research said its business climate index rose slightly, to 104.2, from 103.9 in October, after slipping for six straight months. Companies assessed their current situation more positively than in October, but were “somewhat more cautious” regarding the six-month business outlook, said Hans-Werner Sinn, above, Ifo’s president. The 3 percent annual inflation estimate by the Federal Statistics Office was up from 2.4 percent in October.

Bank of Montreal reported a 35 percent decline in quarterly earnings, reduced by previously announced charges, but profits excluding the charges rose 8 percent. Analysts said the bank’s 2008 outlook, including a target for 10 to 15 percent growth in earnings per share, was an encouraging sign; the company’s stock rose 5 percent. Bank of Montreal, which is based in Toronto, said earnings for its fourth quarter, which ended Oct. 31, were 452 million Canadian dollars ($457 million), or 87 Canadian cents a share. That compares with net income of 696 million Canadian dollars, or 1.35 Canadian dollars per share, a year earlier. The bank said significant items included charges in its capital markets unit and restructuring expenses.

Qantas Airways admitted to fixing prices on international air cargo shipments and agreed to pay a $61 million fine, the Justice Department said. Qantas sought to eliminate competition by fixing the rates for shipments of cargo to and from the United States and elsewhere from at least January 2000 through February 2006, according to the charges filed in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. During the time covered by the felony charge, Qantas was the largest carrier of cargo between the United States and Australia, earning more than $600 million from its cargo flights between the nations, according to the Justice Department. Representatives from the airline, which is based in Australia, were not immediately available for comment.

A report on Thursday in the Men’s College Basketball Preview about the outlook for Georgetown misstated the stage of last season’s N.C.A.A. tournament at which the Hoyas lost. It was the national semifinals, a Final Four matchup against Ohio State, not the title game. (Florida defeated Ohio State for the championship.).

An article in Science Times on Nov. 20 about the role of denial in nourishing close relationships misstated the title of a book. It is “Predictably Irrational: The Hidden Forces That Shape Our Decisions,” not “Hidden Forced.”.

A report on Thursday in the Men’s College Basketball Preview about the outlook for Georgetown misstated the stage of last season’s N.C.A.A. tournament at which the Hoyas lost. It was the national semifinals, a Final Four matchup against Ohio State, not the title game. (Florida defeated Ohio State for the championship.).
Alex Kovalev had two power-play goals, then scored again in the shootout Tuesday night as the Montreal Canadiens beat the host Toronto Maple Leafs, 4-3.
Greg Paulus scored 13 of his 18 points during the decisive first half, and No. 7 Duke ran No. 20 Wisconsin right out of Cameron Indoor Stadium in an 82-58 rout Tuesday night.

The Fire Department’s pool of black and Hispanic job candidates has more than doubled since 2002, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday, raising hopes that efforts to hire more minority firefighters might be yielding results.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 27 (AP) — The Nascar driver Aaron Fike understands where he was headed when he was arrested while shooting heroin in an amusement park parking lot this summer.
Natavia S. Lowery told a story in court markedly different than the one in which she confessed to the killing of her employer, real estate broker Linda Stein.
At first, Gov. Eliot Spitzer told a packed room of Assembly Democrats on Tuesday, his wife didn’t like him much either.

With the latest talks on the future of Kosovo between Serbian authorities and leaders of the province’s ethnic Albanian majority set to end in Austria today, there were no signs of a compromise. “I am afraid nothing spectacular will happen,” said Skender Hyseni, a spokesman for Kosovo’s Albanian leadership, which insists on full independence.

The Simon Wiesenthal Center is extending a campaign to search for aged Nazis to South America, where investigators say they believe Aribert Heim, left, in an undated photo, one of the most wanted suspected war criminals, is hiding. The center is offering a $460,000 reward for information leading to the capture of Dr. Heim, known as “Dr. Death” for allegedly performing gruesome medical experiments on concentration camp inmates. If alive, he would be 93. His daughter lives in Chile, and he continues to maintain a bank account in Germany containing more than $1 million, said Efraim Zuroff, the center’s chief Nazi hunter. Mr. Zuroff said “dozens, if not hundreds” of Nazi war criminals were hiding in South America. The countries involved in what the center calls Operation Last Chance are Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Uruguay.

A warship from China dropped anchor off Tokyo today for the first port call in Japan by a Chinese military vessel since World War II, a highly symbolic display of improving ties. The missile destroyer Shenzhen will stay for four days and be opened for tours. As part of a mutual exchange, a Japanese ship will visit China later.

Thirteen civilians, including 11 children, were killed by a remote-control government military mine in rebel-held Killinochchi, the Tamil Tigers said. The military denied the attack, but said the air force had hit the radio station there. The Tigers said the air raid killed nine people, including a 14-year-old girl.

The defense minister, Mostafa Mohammad Najjar, said Iran had built a new long-range missile. In comments reported by the Fars news agency, he said the missile had range of 1,200 miles. He did not say how the missile, called Ashoura, differed from the Shahab-3, also with a range of 1,200 miles, or if it had been test fired.

Prime Minister Abdullah Badawi threatened to use a tough colonial-era security law that allows for years of detention without trial to stop a wave of street protests that have rocked Malaysia in recent weeks. More than 10,000 ethnic Indians staged a protest in Kuala Lumpur, the capital, over the weekend to complain of discrimination. Two weeks earlier, another crowd of about 10,000 people rallied there to demand election reforms. The Internal Security Act “will be there,” the official Bernama News Agency quoted Mr. Abdullah as saying. “When it is appropriate to use it, it will be used.”.

Opposition leaders in six of Bolivia’s nine provinces, including Santa Cruz, the country’s economic powerhouse, called a 48-hour general strike to begin today to protest the rushed approval of a draft constitution that would give more power to President Evo Morales. Protests in the city of Sucre, where Congress is based, over the weekend led to at least three deaths and hundreds of injuries after clashes with the police.
Venezuela called home its ambassador to Colombia for consultations after an exchange of insults over the weekend between President Hugo Chávez and the Colombian president, Álvaro Uribe.

A male South China tiger was born at the Laohu Valley wildlife reserve. Conservationists said it was the first birth on a reserve outside China. Only about 60 of the tigers exist in captivity, and fewer than 30 are believed to survive in the wild.

A judge sentenced a Somali immigrant to 10 years in prison for plotting to blow up an Ohio shopping mall with a man who was later convicted of being a terrorist with Al Qaeda. The immigrant, Nuradin M. Abdi, left, will be deported to Somalia after serving the sentence. Judge Algenon L. Marbley of Federal District Court imposed the sentence as part of a plea deal with Mr. Abdi in July, in which he pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring to provide material support for terrorists. The other man, Iyman Faris, a Pakistani immigrant, is serving 20 years for a plot to destroy the Brooklyn Bridge.

Despite alarming predictions, the United States came through a second straight hurricane season virtually unscathed, raising fears among emergency planners that they will be fighting public apathy and overconfidence when they warn people to prepare for next year. Friday marks the official close of the Atlantic season; unless a storm forms in the next few days, only one hurricane will have hit the United States during the June-to-November season. The preliminary total for the season: 14 named storms, 6 of them hurricanes, 2 of them major. That was less activity than the government predicted before the season started. Hurricane Humberto, a Category 1 storm that hit Texas and Louisiana in September, was the first hurricane to strike the United States in two years. It was blamed for one death and $30 million in damage.

Lawyers want a court to determine whether members of the Bluffton University baseball team in a deadly bus crash in Atlanta this year are entitled to insurance money. A charter bus carrying the team to spring training plunged off an overpass, killing five students, the driver and his wife. Twenty-eight others were injured. The filing in Federal District Court said that the driver and the company were insured under three policies issued to the university. According to the suit, the insurance companies, Hartford Fire Insurance, American Alternative Insurance and Federal Insurance, have refused to acknowledge that the driver and the bus company were covered under the policies, which total $21 million. Representatives of all three insurers said they could not comment on the suit.
The Fish and Wildlife Service reversed seven rulings that denied increased protection for endangered species, after an inquiry found that the actions had been tainted by political pressure.
Some Muslim communities are forming Girl Scout troops to help girls escape the perception that they are different.
A falling dollar, a growing pile of oil revenue and an interest in not being overshadowed by Dubai spurred Abu Dhabi to purchase a big $7.5 billion stake in Citigroup.
The agreement to negotiate a peace treaty by the end of 2008 revived a peace process that the United States had left dormant for seven years.
The families of two Jersey City police officers who died when they drove off an open drawbridge in the fog have settled lawsuits against the state for a total of $2.3 million.
Initial tests at 53 apartments and in the common areas of nine buildings within 1,500 feet of ground zero found dust samples contaminated with lead and asbestos.
A federal judge upheld a city regulation Tuesday that bans new parades on Fifth Avenue, ruling against an antiwar group that had sought to challenge it as a violation of the First Amendment.
A former assistant district attorney in Brooklyn was charged Tuesday with providing information about prosecution witnesses to a defense lawyer who is now her husband.
After years of delay and political squabbling, state officials have selected Danforth Development Partners to redevelop the long-vacant Victoria Theater on 125th Stree.
Two men were shot, one fatally, early Tuesday behind an apartment complex in West Orange.
At the winter meetings, Mets General Manager Omar Minaya figures to explore the possibility of prying loose Dan Haren from the Oakland A’s.
Anxieties among Sunni Arab countries over Iran’s growing influence in the region hover over the Annapolis peace talks.

Christine Ohuruogu, the world 400-meter champion, won her appeal against a lifetime Olympic ban for missing doping tests. Ohuruogu, a 23-year-old British runner, was cleared to compete in next year’s Beijing Olympics after the ruling by a sports arbitration panel. The British Olympic Association said the panel approved Ohuruogu’s appeal because of “significant mitigating circumstances.” Ohuruogu was the first British track athlete punished for missing three tests. She said she missed the tests when her training schedules were changed with late notice.

The World Cup overall champion Aksel Lund Svindal of Norway crashed during downhill training in Beaver Creek, Colo., and was hospitalized with a cut and bruised face and lacerated leg. Svindal apparently lost control on the lower section of the run. He was removed from the course on a sled. The laceration on the back of his left leg was six inches long, but no ligament damage or broken bones were suspected.

The Brazilian stadium where seven people died after the stands collapsed will be destroyed and a new one will be built in its place. At least 40 others were injured Sunday night in Salvador, a coastal city of Bahia state. The accident was the worst in Brazilian soccer history and raised questions about the country’s readiness to stage the 2014 World Cup. Gov. Jacques Wagner said yesterday the Fonte Nova stadium will be imploded. He did not give a timetable for the demolition, but the new stadium is expected to be completed by 2014.

Internazionale of Milan, AS Roma and Sevilla advanced to the second round of the European Champions League with victories yesterday, and Barcelona gained a berth with a tie.Inter (4-1) beat visiting Fenerbahce, 3-0, on goals by Julio Ricardo Cruz, Zlatan Ibrahimovic and Luis Jiménez to clinch first place in Group G. PSV Eindhoven (2-2-1), which is third, won, 1-0, at CSKA Moscow (0-4-1) on a 39th-minute goal by Jefferson Farfan. Roma (3-1-1) won, 4-1, at Dynamo Kiev (0-5) and earned second place in Group F as Mirko Vucinic scored twice following goals by Christian Panucci and Ludovic Giuly. Ismael Bangoura scored for Dynamo.Barcelona reached the Round of 16 with a 2-2 tie at Lyon. Manchester United (5-0), the only team with a perfect record, already had clinched advancement and assured itself of first place in Group F with a 2-1 victory over visiting Sporting Lisbon (1-3-1). Carlos Tevez scored off a pass from Cristiano Ronaldo in the 62nd minute and Ronaldo got a goal on a free kick in injury time. Fernando Abel had put Sporting ahead in the 22nd minute.
Accused of killing a white youth in a predominantly white suburb, a black man evokes Jim Crow lynch mobs in his defense.
Freddie Mac cut its quarterly dividend Tuesday and announced plans to sell $6 billion in preferred stock to bolster its finances in anticipation of more losses.
A seasoned and concise John Edwards has changed not the substance of his campaign, but the style.

The American syndicate BMW Oracle Racing won a court case against America’s Cup champion Alinghi on Tuesday, giving it the right to race the Swiss team in a head-to-head series for the title next July.
The Democratic and Republican presidential candidates offer profoundly different approaches to energy policy.
When the government is allowed to show up unannounced without a warrant and search people’s homes, it’s bad news for all of us.
Investigators searched the Miami home of Washington Redskins safety Sean Taylor, who died after he was shot by an intruder.
The man whose wife and two daughters were killed in a home invasion appealed to Connecticut legislators on Tuesday to address “glaring defects” in the criminal justice system.
As the Twins negotiate with teams about Johan Santana, they are seeking premium prospects and the Yankees have offered a package that does not include pitcher Joba Chamberlain.
Congressional negotiators are working on a measure to set significantly higher fuel economy standards for cars and light trucks.
Dr. Cade  mixed water, sugar, salt and cunning dashes of whatever to invent Gatorade, which is now guzzled daily by electrolyte-depleted athletes, post-operative patients and the simply thirsty.

The United Nations’ top peacekeeping official said Tuesday that obstacles created by the Sudanese government were jeopardizing the deployment of the joint African Union-United Nations force in Darfur.
The nation’s second-largest mortgage lender said Tuesday that it would take a $1.4 billion fourth-quarter charge for losses it anticipated in connection with home loans.
When Stephon Marbury and Kevin Garnett meet Wednesday in Boston, it will serve as a stinging reminder of all that has gone wrong in the last decade of Marbury’s basketball life.
T-Mobile, the professional cycling team that began this year with an ambitious plan to reform the sport’s drug problem, lost its sponsor Tuesday because of continuing doping controversies.
Young Jews around the country are challenging traditional Jewish notions of prayer and identity by organizing independent prayer groups.
Mr. Clinton’s statement while campaigning for his wife was more absolute than his comments before the invasion of Iraq in 2003.
The latest chapter in a battle between Delaware and New Jersey over control of the river that separates the states.
The New England Patriots, whose undefeated start has been largely free of serious injuries, absorbed their first big jolt Tuesday, losing outside linebacker Rosevelt Colvin.

Negotiations are scheduled to resume this morning between the stagehands’ union and the league representing Broadway theater owners and producers after a one-day hiatus that was described by a union spokesman as a “rain delay.”
The suicide of a 13-year-old girl after an Internet hoax that was hatched by an adult has brought outrage.
Stock markets snapped back yesterday as promising news on credit and oil emerged from the Middle East, offering investors some reassurance about two recent trouble spots.
Whether it is because of suspension or injury, Dolphins running back Ricky Williams has shown quite a knack for not being on the field in recent seasons.
NBC Universal has agreed to become the first major broadcaster to use ratings data and other advertising products from the digital video recorder company.
Mrs. Lorillard with her husband, Louis, started the Newport Jazz Festival and created the model for what became a worldwide circuit of outdoor jazz festivals.
Porsche will not move to take over Volkswagen before Dec. 25, but its chief executive refused to say whether Volkswagen would remain an independent carmaker in 2008.
The religious divide over Mitt Romney’s Mormon faith that his supporters had long feared would occur is emerging as he is being challenged in polls by Mike Huckabee, a former Baptist minister.
The numbers on job churning compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics are based on a quarterly canvass of work sites across the country.
Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said Tuesday that it was considering the sale of the rest of the Ottaway community newspaper group.
Verizon Wireless plans to give customers more choice in what phones they can use on its network.
With New Hampshire’s primary a mere five days after Iowa’s caucuses, restaurants and hotels are anticipating less business, and some people fear getting less attention from the candidates.
Daly’s NBC talk show will be the first late-night program to produce original episodes since the Writers Guild of America went on strike three weeks ago.
Two senior American admirals expressed concern over China’s refusal to allow access to the port of Hong Kong for three American warships.
Do college applicants need slick packaging to make strong impressions on top-flight colleges?
Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender and loan servicer, has been subpoenaed to determine whether it abused the federal bankruptcy system.
Housing prices fell the most in almost 20 years this summer, and consumers remain deeply skeptical about the economy, according to reports released Tuesday.
The great majority of American journalists in Iraq say that most parts of Baghdad are too dangerous for them to visit, according to a newly released survey.
A five-year, $1.876 billion renovation of the iconic United Nations complex is set to be approved soon by the General Assembly.
Ryan Lochte has enough talent and whimsy to pierce Michael Phelps’s Beijing dream of equaling or eclipsing Mark Spitz’s seven-gold medal haul from the 1972 Olympics.
Robert Mugabe’s decision to attend a summit meeting next week is guaranteed to provoke divisions over human rights and a boycott by the British prime minister.
President Thabo Mbeki’s control of South Africa’s ruling party has shifted to his former vice president and bitter rival, the populist politician Jacob Zuma.
When I was 14, I was caught fishing illegally in a drinking-water reservoir by a game warden named Joe Haines. Instead of giving me a ticket, he took me under his wing.
A Niagra Falls City Court judge was recommended for removal after his tyranical reaction to a ringing cell phone in his courtroom.
The final five designs in the State Quarters series of the United States Mint will honor Oklahoma, New Mexico, Arizona, Alaska and Hawaii.

The Advertising Council, which coordinates public-service initiatives for Madison Avenue, is changing its approach to better reflect changing media-consumption patterns of the audience it is trying to reach.
Bill Hartack was a Hall of Fame jockey who was a five-time winner of the Kentucky Derby.
A truck leaked poultry fat along 20 miles of a road in Virginia on Tuesday, causing at least four crashes and making a stinky mess.
After 47 years of operating the Downtown Manhattan Heliport, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is getting out of the helicopter business.
A medal created for George Washington, and given to Marquis de Lafayette, is for sale at Sotheby’s.
New York City schools could begin reducing class sizes immediately in more than 150 of the cities lowest performing schools, according to a report released Tuesday.
The four-time Olympian Dara Torres will miss the United States short course national championships beginning Thursday in Atlanta while recovering from surgery on her right shoulder.
Houston Nutt agreed to a contract late Monday night and replaced Ed Orgeron, who was fired Saturday after the Rebels lost to rival Mississippi State to finish 3-9.

The area stretching north from Canal Street to about 34th Street is attracting a growing number of media, communications and entertainment companies with low rents and large spaces.
The most widely used influenza drug in the world should carry a stronger warning label about psychiatric problems seen in a handful of patients, government advisers said Tuesday.
President Roh Moo-hyun of South Korea agreed to an independent investigation into a scandal that includes accusations that he may have accepted bribes from the Samsung Group.
The first round of college applications have been submitted since top schools cut early admission. It’s hard to see any obvious new strategies yet among college applicants.
China signaled Tuesday that it would resist demands for rapid appreciation of the yuan and would instead continue gradual progress toward a more flexible exchange rate.
America’s expensive investment in President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan has yielded little in the way of tangible results.
Google said it would spend hundreds of millions of dollars on renewable energy, part of that to hire engineers and experts to investigate alternative energies like solar and wind power.
Developers are scrambling to turn the once-downtrodden avenue into the latest trendy corridor for luxury goods and entertainment.
The four-day multimedia event, which will take place at the Eyebeam Gallery in Chelsea, encompasses music, video and informational workshops.
Shakespeare was a big winner at the annual Evening Standard Theater Awards.
The Bollywood star Sanjay Dutt  was granted bail yesterday and is expected to be released.
“In Bruges,” a first-time feature written and directed by the playwright Martin McDonagh will open next year’s Sundance Film Festival.

Norman Mailer won The Literary Review’s Bad Sex in Fiction Award, becoming the first posthumously honored author.
ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” drew its largest audience of the season on Monday as 24.7 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m. for the show’s final round.

Will promoting “Ratatouille” as the year’s best picture lead to ballot-splitting that would diminish its chances of getting the Oscar for best animated film?
Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., the self-made Texas oilman who pleaded guilty in October to violating the rules of the United Nations oil-for-food program, was sentenced yesterday to a year and a day in prison.

Promising news from the Middle East sent the Dow up 215 points, a long way toward making up for yesterday’s steep sell-off.
