WILLIS--Prof. John Ralph, 69, of Hightstown, NJ, passed away suddenly at home. Born in Lorain, OH, Prof. Willis received his BA from University of Arizona, his MA from Boston University on a Woodrow Wilson Scholarship, and his Ph.D. from University of London on a Marshall Scholarship. He was a professor at the University of Birmingham (UK), University of Wisconsin, and University of California at Berkeley. Prof. Willis retired from Princeton University after 35 years, as an expert in West African History and Islamic Law. He was a Fellow of the Morgan Library and enjoyed landscape architecture. Son of the late John R., Sr. and Lena Mae Tinch Willis, he is survived by his loving wife of 35 years, Anne Jones Willis, and their children, Avery, Kingsley, and Goreleigh; and numerous cousins. Funeral gathering will be held 8:30am Saturday at Glackin/Saul Funeral Home, 136 Morrison Avenue, Hightstown, NJ. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated 9:30am Saturday at St. Anthony of Padua R.C. Church, 251 Franklin Street, Hightstown. Visitation will be 7-9pm, Friday at the funeral home.

LICHTENSTEIN--Chaim. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the father of our member, Deborah Marcus. May his entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Steve Graber, President

HARDAWAY--Desiree. The board and staff of United Way of New York City mourn the sudden passing of Desiree Hardaway, our colleague since 1997. We will miss Desiree's sunny disposition and the can do spirit she brought to her work everyday as Vice President of our organization. Her passion for serving the community inspired us all.

NICKEL - FARA--Leslie A. Washington Square Partners mourns the death of Leslie Nickel-Fara, a Senior Vice President who joined the firm in 1994. Her work for Cooper Union, Downtown Brooklyn, Jamaica, Queens and many other projects will be remembered. Leslie was a consummate professional. We will miss her warmth and intelligence and will always remember her extraordinary courage. She inspired all who worked with her these past years. Paul Travis Washington Square Partners NICKEL - FARA--Leslie A. Nickel, an urban planner and commercial real estate developer, died Thanksgiving Thursday at Sloan Kettering Hospital in New York after a long fight with breast cancer. She was 66. Ms. Nickel-Fara was a founding principal of Washington Square Partners and a Board Member of WX, NY Women Executives in Real Estate. Prior to her years in real estate, Ms. Nickel worked in New York, London and Barcelona as a photo stylist. Ms. Nickel-Fara was a devoted Upper West Side resident for 30 years and served for 10 years as President and Secretary of the Board of Directors of her co-op. She was also active in Riverside Park, the local block association, an enthusiastic supporter of the arts of New York and a longstanding member of her book club. She is survived by her husband Michael Fara, son Christopher, and sister Sally Garvin. A memorial service will be held Thursday, November 29th, from 6:30 to 8:30 pm at the New York Athletic Club, 180 Central Park South. The family requests that contributions in her memory be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering.

TIETZ--Herman, longtime resident of Port Washington, passed away on November 26, 2007 in his 87th year. Devoted husband of Vera. Beloved father of Larry (Janet) and Gladys (David) Mercier. Cherished grandfather of Lauren, Geoff, and Meredith. Dear brother of Rosalie Jasen. Also survived by several nieces, nephews and a greatgranddaughter. Herman emigrated from Germany in 1933 and served in the U.S. Army. He was the grandson of Oscar Tietz, the founder of Hermann Tietz Department Stores which, prior to its Aryanization in 1934, was the largest privately-held retailer in Europe. In his younger days Herman enjoyed skiing, tennis and traveling and in his later years became an avid bridge player. A funeral service will be held on Thursday, November 29 at 10:30am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 Station Plaza North, Great Neck. The family will observe shiva on Thursday, Saturday and Sunday at 7:30pm and visitation will be on Sunday 2-4pm at the residence of Vera and Herman. For those wishing to make a donation in Herman's memory, the family suggests the Anti-Defamation League or a charity of your choice.

MONTGOMERY--Margaret and James M., of Amityville, L.I., suddenly on November 22, 2007. Beloved mother and father of Alexander Montgomery and Katherine M. Porter and her husband Frederick. Cherished grandparents of James J. and William N. Porter. Mrs. Montgomery is also survived by her brother Donald O'Rourke, her sister Mimi Spagnoli, and predeceased by her brothers Gerald and John O'Rourke, and her sister Honor Williams. Mr. Montgomery is survived by his sister Nina Dana. The family will receive friends Thursday 2-4:30 and 79:30pm at the Powell Funeral Home, Inc., 67 Broadway (Rt. 110), Amityville. Amityville Fire Dept. service 7:30pm. Prayers 8:00pm. Funeral Mass Friday, 9:30am,. St. Martin of Tours R.C. Church, Amityville. Interment Saturday, Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn. The family has requested, in lieu of flowers, memorials in Mrs. Montgomery's name be directed to the Kennebec Land Trust, 134 Main St., Suite 2B, Winthrop, ME 04364, and memorials in Mr. Montgomery's name be directed to the Amityville Fire Department, 55 West Oak St., Amityville, NY 11701. Envelopes available at the funeral home.

RICHMAN--Michael, 61, died November 26, 2007 after a courageous battle with lung cancer. Michael is survived by his wife, Sheila (Carey) Richman, two loving children, Joshua Adam Richman and Allison Jane Packer (Steven) and three grandchildren, Lauren Richman, Alexis and Drew Packer. He is also survived by a sister, Ronnie Richman Leib and many friends and relatives, who will miss sharing the fun times which were so abundant when Michael was around. Services will be held on Wednesday, November 28, 2007 at 1:30 PM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapels. 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st St.) NYC.

BUCKLEY--Mortimer J., M.D., of Osterville, MA, formerly of Winchester, MA, died November 24, 2007. Beloved husband of Marilyn (Scully) Buckley. Devoted father of Dr. Kathleen Buckley and her husband Dr. Thomas J. Gill, Deirdre Buckley Clark and her husband Robert L. (Rufus) Clark, Kara Buckley and her husband Karl Zachar, Mortimer J. Buckley III and his wife Elizabeth Norris. Loving grandfather of Ty, Olivia and Rebecca Gill; Brett and Charlotte Clark; Cormac and Conor Zachar; Mortimer Declan, Evan and Finn Buckley. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:00am on Saturday, December 1, 2007 at Christ The King Parish -3 Job's Fishing Rd., Mashpee, MA. In lieu of flowers, his family requests that you remember Mort with memorial contributions to The Multiple Myeloma Research at DanaFarber Cancer Institute, 44 Binney St, Boston, MA 02115. Services by the Lane Funeral Home of Winchester, MA.

KERR--William ''Bill'' K., died on November 21, 2007 in Litchfield Park, Arizona. He was born in Wilkinsburg, PA, on August 31, 1916. He was preceded in death by his father Andy Kerr, his mother Mary Keister, his brother Dr. Andrew Kerr, Jr., his wife Charlotte Read Kerr, and his son William K. Kerr, Jr. He graduated Colgate University in 1939 and Harvard Law School in 1943. His wartime service included working as an agent for the FBI and a Naval Intelligence officer in the Pacific on the USS Princeton. Bill joined the New York law office of Fish, Richardson & Neave (later Fish & Neave) in 1947 where he was managing partner from 1977 to 1980. He was a highly regarded trial lawyer, specializing in intellectual properties and antitrust cases. He was a Fellow in The American College of Trial Lawyers and a member of The Links Club in New York, The Links Golf Club, Sankety Head Golf Club in Nantucket, MA, and the Bermuda Seniors. His stepdaughters survive Bill: Anne Phillips Clark, Ruth Phillips Gulick, Virginia Phillips, and Phebe Phillips Byrne. He also leaves seven grandchildren: Phebe Gulick, Robin Pino, Peter Gulick Jr., Andrew Clark, Miles J. Kerr, Read Van der Wal, and William K. Kerr III, and greatgrandchildren Kate and Salvatore Pino. No services are planned at this time. In lieu of flowers, the family asks donations be made to Colgate University, Harvard Law School, American Cancer Society, or a charity of your choice. KERR--William K. The partners and staff of the former law firm Fish & Neave, now part of Ropes & Gray LLP, mourn the passing of William K. Kerr on November 21. Bill was the Managing Partner of Fish & Neave for a number of years in the 1970s, and nationally recognized as one of the leading patent trial lawyers of his era. At Fish, Richardson and Neave--later Fish & Neave--Bill represented leading technology firms of the day, such as Ford, IBM, and Polaroid, and participated in many of the most important patent infringement cases of the time. He was widely respected and enjoyed high honors in the profession including, notably, Fellowship in the American College of Trial Lawyers. He was a gifted mentor to a generation of lawyers who succeeded him. He was a leader and colleague who will be missed.
To the Editor: ''The High Cost of Health Care'' (editorial, Nov. 25) captures the true complexities facing the challenges of the American health care system.

BIRNBACH--Maks, of New York, NY and Greenwich, CT. Adoring and adored husband (of Naomi Salit), fantastic father, devoted ''Papa'', loving brother, passionate Zionist and beloved friend. Chairman of Fullcut Manufacturers, member of the International Board of Governors, Weizmann Institute of Science, board member Tel Aviv Foundation, and Emeritus board member, Carnival Cruise Lines. The family of Maks Birnbach will be receiving visitors Wednesday, November 28 and Thursday, November 29, 2:30-5 pm and 6:30-9 pm, Friday, November 30, 2:30-5:00 pm and Sunday December 2nd, 2:30-5:00 pm at his home in New York. BIRNBACH--Maks, November 25, passed away at the age of 87 years in New York City. Nathan and Elizabeth Leight extend their deepest sympathies to their dear friend Jonathan and his entire family. Maks is survived by his loving family. Our hearts go out to Naomi, his wife of almost 53 years, their three children, Jonathan and his wife Joan, Lisa, and Norman and his wife Deborah, and his brother Otto, who lives in Israel. Maks was instrumental in Israel gaining its independence. Maks was most passionate about his family. We know his legacy and many wonderful memories will live on with his children and grandchildren; Jenna, Julia, Sam, Boco, Maisie, Ben, Fischer and Rebecca, who brought him tremendous pleasure. May you be comforted by the many loving memories and by the good times we shared with each other. His good name lives on.

Leaves were confetti at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens for the followers of La Barra, a largely Argentine local soccer team, as it won its league championship on Saturday. ''This is my family,'' Manuel Galian, upper left, said of the people he joins for games near the Willets Point station of the No. 7 train.

FLOM--Claire. Fordham Law School records with profound sorrow the passing of Claire Flom, with her husband Joseph H. Flom, a devoted friend of the Law School. Her sage counsel, wit, and wonderful spirit were of invaluable assistance to Fordham University, which she served as a Trustee, and to the Law School, where she was a founding member and guiding force of the Advisory Board of the Feerick Center for Social Justice. She will be greatly missed, and we extend our deepest sympathy to her family. William Michael Treanor, Dean FLOM--Claire. The Gateway School community mourns the loss of its founder and long standing past board member and chair. Claire's founding of Gateway more than 40 years ago, with three students and a lot of guts and determination, was an extraordinary accomplishment, and well ahead of its time in the educational field. We honor her vision and achievements by continuing her work to serve children with learning disabilities. Everyone in the Gateway community and in the field of special education have benefited from her initiatives. Claire's vision has served so many children; her legacy lives on. Our condolences to her family including present Trustee Peter Flom. Warren H. Feder, Chair, Board of Trustees Robert B. Cunningham, Head of School FLOM--Claire. The American Jewish Committee is deeply saddened by the death of Claire Flom, beloved wife of our dear friend Joseph Flom. Claire and Joe were partners in life and in philanthropy, together crafting a legacy of kindness and compassion that continues to benefit our society and enrich our lives. We send heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Richard J. Sideman, Pres. David A. Harris, Exec. Dir. FLOM--Claire. Harvard Law School mourns the loss of our dear friend, Claire Flom. With her husband, Joseph, Claire was a source of great support to our institution, helping to establish the Petrie-Flom Center for Health Law Policy, Biotechnology, and Bioethics. We will miss her wise counsel and kindness. Dean Elena Kagan. FLOM--Claire. The board of directors, staff, and members of the Food Allergy Initiative mourn the loss of Claire Flom, our dear friend and dedicated volunteer. She was determined to build a healthier future for millions of children affected by life-threatening food allergies. We offer our heartfelt condolences to her husband, Joseph; her children, Nancy, Peter, and Jason; and her six grandchildren and one great-grandchild. She was a remarkable woman and will be deeply missed by all who knew her. Todd J. Slotkin, Chairman and President Sharyn T. Mann, Vice Chairman The Food Allergy Initiative FLOM--Claire. The trustees, directors, officers and members of the Federal Bar Council and Federal Bar Foundation mourn the passing of our friend Claire Flom, a longtime supporter of our Winter Bench and Bar Meetings. We will miss her. We extend our sympathy to the entire Flom family. Mark C. Zauderer, President Federal Bar Council FLOM--Claire. The trustees, faculty and staff of NYU Medical Center mourns the passing of Claire Flom, dear friend to so many in need and generous supporter of cancer research; and wife of our former trustee Joe Flom. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Flom family. Kenneth G. Langone, Chairman, Board of Trustees Robert I. Grossman, M.D., Dean and CEO

8 P.M. (NBC) CHRISTMAS IN ROCKEFELLER CENTER Nick Lachey, Al Roker and Ashley Tisdale help flip the switch at this 75th tree-lighting ceremony, whose real star is an 84-foot-tall Norway spruce from Connecticut (above, the scene last year). But if you thought New York's Christmas tree was already green, think again. This year its brilliance will come from 30,000 solar-powered light-emitting diodes strung along five miles of wire, which will reduce energy consumption to 1,297 kilowatt hours a day from 3,510 kilowatt hours -- saving about the same amount of energy that a family in a 2,000-square-foot house might use in a month. According to City Hall, the tree was also cut with a hand-held saw to save energy. After Christmas it will be turned into lumber for Habitat for Humanity. Tonight Natasha Bedingfield, Tony Bennett, Celine Dion, Sean Kingston, Carrie Underwood and others sing in the holiday season. 8 P.M. (ABC) SHREK THE HALLS Mike Myers, Eddie Murphy, Cameron Diaz and Antonio Banderas lend their voices to this half-hour special spun off from the ''Shrek'' movies. Everyone's favorite ogre tries to muster a little holiday spirit for the sake of his princess bride, Fiona, and their children, but Donkey, Puss in Boots and Gingy, for all their good intentions, just end up spoiling his plans.
LUDWIG--Michael, Our hearts are broken. Michael was a beautiful boy and we will never forget his beautiful smile. He will be in our hearts always. John, Jane, Carly, Adam, Lindsay and Annie
$5.9 MILLION PER FLOOR 666 Broadway (at Bond Street)

MILLER--Claude Henry, Jr, M.D., dies at 85. A longtime resident of New Rochelle, Dr. Miller ran an active psychoanalytical practice in Manhattan for over 50 years. He was preceded in death by his wife Catherine Mary Miller, and is survived by three siblings, three children, six grandchildren and many friends and colleagues. Visitation and a Memorial Service will be held starting at 9am Saturday, December 1, at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home in White Plains, followed by a noon burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

COWEN--Leon, 87, died of pneumonia in NYC on October 29, 2007. Father of Elaine and Ron Cowen, brother of Estelle Mark, beloved husband of late wife, artist Maria Szeni, attentive grandfather to Julie Cowen, uncle to Alan and Michael. Leon graduated from City College in 1941 and served in the Pacific during WWII. He was an administrator in the New York State Division of Human Rights until his retirement in the early 1980s. Leon then volunteered for many years at the MCR Dispute Resolution Center, helping settle cases out of court. A longtime member of the New York Society of Ethical Culture, Leon also contributed generously to the United Jewish Appeal. Scrappy and keenly alive, Leon in his eighties took computer classes and exercised at the local YMCA, saw several offBroadway and art shows each week, attended demonstrations against the war and injustices around the world, and campaigned actively against President Bush. Memorial service on December 16, 2pm, Ceremonial Room of the NY Society of Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64 St., 4th floor.

OKIN--Stan, a young 80, passed away suddenly on November 27, 2007. Beloved husband of Rita for 57 years, devoted father of Ellen; Robert and Susan; Peter and Jamie; loving Grandpa to Rae, Alex, Emily, Ben, Jonathan, David and Ben. The most loving, generous, dependable, thoughtful sweetheart of a man. I had the best. Funeral service will be held at 12 noon at Gutterman's at 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Center. Family will be sitting shiva Thursday through Friday and Saturday night at their home in Oceanside as well as Sunday from 12-6pm in Armonk.

PETRILLO--Harold Vincent, of Orange City, Florida, died peacefully after a short illness on October 29, shortly after celebrating his 100th birthday with his whole family around him. Known as ''Pete'' in the business world and ''Hap'' to his family and friends, he was an avid reader and loved to golf. He was born in New York City, New York, graduated from Pace University, and worked for Haskins & Sells as a young man. He retired as a senior partner from that firm which later became Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu. At his retirement he was known as ''The Legend of Wall Street'' because of his lifelong financial acumen, brokerage and accounting knowledge, and selfless leadership. Always generous with his immense financial expertise, he was President of the Board of Education of his children's school and Honorary Treasurer of the Board of Hackensack Hospital in New Jersey. Not only did Hap support three Lutheran Churches with his financial ability but also gave very generously of his personal money to the Church. On retirement he was proud of being a member of the Rotary. Hap is predeceased by his first wife Helen and survived by their five children and four grandchildren, also predeceased by his second wife Shirley and survived by her three children and five grandchildren, and survived by his present wife Martha Eugenia, her two sons; and several greatgrandchildren. Services were under the care and trust of: Volusia Memorial Funeral Home, 548 N. Nova Rd., Ormond Beach, FL 32174.

HILL--Ann Marie (nee Lynch), age 75, died peacefully on Monday, November 26, 2007 at her home in Waldwick. Ann Marie was born in Philadelphia, PA, on August 17, 1932. She was a 45 year resident of New Milford before moving to Waldwick two years ago. Ann Marie was employed at Fairleigh Dickinson University in Teaneck for more than 20 years, retiring in 2001. She was a long time parishioner of Church of the Ascension in New Milford. Surviving are her children, Jean Marie and her husband Thomas Albano of Livingston, NJ; Elizabeth Ann Hill of Mahwah; Dorothy Ann and her husband Steven Kariofiles of Waldwick; L. Stephen Hill and his wife Suzanne of Ramsey; Deborah Jean and her husband Rick Massimi of Pacific, MO. Ann Marie also leaves five grandchildren, Jason, Thomas Lee, Christie, Emily Elizabeth, and Troy. In addition, she leaves her loving sister Jean Lawrence of Lafayette Hill, PA. The family will receive friends Friday, 2:00 to 4:00 and 7:00 to 9:00pm, at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home (www.vpfh.com), 257 Godwin Avenue, Wyckoff, NJ. Funeral Mass will be Saturday, 10:30am, at the Church of the Nativity, 315 Prospect Street, Midland Park, NJ. Cremation will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Parkinson's Disease Association, 1250 Hylan Boulevard, Suite 4B, Staten Island, NY 10305.

The Personal Health column in Science Times on Nov. 20, about treatments for chronic pain, misstated the purpose of one type of medication. When fentanyl is administered as a lozenge, it is designed for acute, breakthrough pain, not for chronic, continuous pain.

Just when you need a warmer for wintry days, the makers of Macallan, a single-malt Scotch aged in sherry casks, have introduced their first liqueur. Called Amber, it comes in a sleek bottle shaped a bit like a kidney bean. The liqueur has the richness of whiskey overlaid with a maple syrup aroma and flavor, with a sweet hint of pecan from the syrups used to blend it. It is 50 proof. A splash will mellow a Scotch on the rocks, bolster a cup of black tea or add a new dimension to a highball made with dark rum and pineapple juice.

Ginger babies and candy canes of crystallized ginger could adorn a gingerbread house, of course, or garnish holiday pastries and all sorts of desserts. But these intensely flavored bites are not just for children. They can accompany cheese, or, on a toothpick, decorate a cocktail. A candy cane might hang from the rim of a litchi martini. Made by Ginger People of Marina, Calif., they are $6.50 to $7 for 6.7 ounces at Whole Foods at Columbus Circle, and $7 plus shipping from gingerpeople.com.

EISENMAN--Della, on November 21st, 2007 in Florida. Beloved wife of Bernard, loving mother of Roberta Bogash, Dr. Richard Eisenman and Ronald Eisenman and mother-in-law of Rodney Bogash and Lauren Eisenman. Cherished grandmother of Robyn and Ross Bogash; Jonathan, Debra, Gregory, Heather and Robert Eisenman. She will be lovingly remembered and greatly missed by her family and friends.

SEIDMAN--Benedict S. (Dick), was a man of extraordinary passions, which included his family, Bard College, tennis, The New York Times, Gilbert & Sullivan and social justice. Dick passed away on November 26, 2007 at the age of 86. Dick was a journalist and businessman, who was president of The Metro Group of Long Island City for more than 30 years. He served in World War II and received a Purple Heart. Dick is survived by his loving family including his brother Lloyd, his three sons and their wives: Michael (Judy), Robert (Maureen), Peter (Julie), eight grandchildren and his companion, Sally Barnett. He was predeceased by his wife of over 60 years, Irene. A memorial will be held at George T. Davis Funeral Home in New Rochelle. Contributions in his memory can be made to Bard College. SEIDMAN--Benedict S. The Bard College community mourns the passing of Benedict S. Seidman, Class of 1940. An enthusiast of the arts, a committed citizen, and connoisseur who believed in the power of learning, he was deeply devoted to Bard throughout his life, and served the college as an alumni/ae trustee, overseer of Simon's Rock, and trustee associate. We send our deepest condolences to his family. He will be sorely missed. Leon Botstein, President Charles P. Stevenson Jr, Chair David E. Schwab II, Chair Emeritus

BURGER--Walter. New York City SCORE mourns the loss of their colleague who served unselfishly for the past 17 years. BURGER--Walter Maurice, age 85, died on November 26, 2007, following a severe stroke. Born in Dusseldorf, Germany. His career included international trading and volunteering at SCORE. He is survived by his wife, Ruth, sister Suzanne Steinberg, three daughters Michele, Jackie, Suzanne and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, send donations to the Parent Project Muscular Dystrophy or New York Presbyterian Hospital. Services today at 11:45am at The ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Kelli Bernard, a former Web site designer with a love for Japan, has opened a shop and tearoom, Amai Tea and Bake House. A brick-walled oasis, it serves high-quality teas and drinks like frothy green-tea latte and green tea cupcakes, both at near left. Ms. Bernard's pastries, which she bakes downstairs, include, far left, puff pastry with sweet potato filling, along with quince brownies, Champagne brownies with a glaze, pear muffins and cookies (75 cents to $4.95). Amai is at 171 Third Avenue (17th Street), (212) 863-9630.

BORELLA--Sheila Rae (nee Bouch) of New York City and Cedar Grove, NJ, on November 18th, 2007 at age 66 of pancreatic cancer. She died peacefully surrounded by her loving family and friends. Until her retirement in 2001, Mrs. Borella worked in advertising as a Vice President of Media Buying Services for agencies such as: BBD&O, Ally & Gargano and Hill Holiday in NYC. She is survived by her loving husband, Edward, her devoted son and daughter-in-law, Jon Paul and Penny, her adoring granddaughter Casey Rae, and her cherished sister, Roberta Jennings. Her devotion to her family and friends, her boundless and often irreverent sense of humor and her great enthusiasm for life will be sadly missed and always remembered. A memorial gathering to celebrate her life will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC on Wednesday December 5th, 2007 from 4pm to 8pm.

GREENSTADT--Inez. The Mount Sinai Alumni mourns the loss of Inez Greenstadt. Mrs. Greenstadt came to Mount Sinai in 1958 and retired in 2001. She created the Recreation Office at Mount Sinai and helped thousands of students, faculty and staff members find just the right ticket, show, or deal. She brought culture into our lives and will be dearly missed.

OTTENSOSER--Ruth, sud denly on November 23, 2007. She was born in Karlsruhe, Germany, on June 9, 1920 and escaped Nazi tyranny in 1939. She was predeceased 25 years ago by her husband Max, of blessed memory. She is survived by her children Sam (Brenda), Milton (Susan) and Aviva (Bob); grandchildren David (Jennifer), Gilad (Deena), Yaakov (Sarrah), Esty, Uri (Wendy), Daniel (Judith), Rebecca (Eric), Sara and Abigail (Seth); and seventeen great-grandchildren. She lived her entire life as a woman imbued with a love of G-d, her family and Israel. OTTENSOSER -- RUTH. Deepest sympathy to Sam and Brenda Ottensoser, Silver Founders, and their extended family, on the loss of his beloved mother. Ruth Ottensoser's courage saved her family from the Holocaust, which began a legacy of Chesed, Torah and Mitzvot. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem

WILLIAMS--Leslie R. Teachers College, Columbia University mourns the passing of Professor Leslie R. Williams, a stellar and much-loved member of our Curriculum and Teaching faculty for the past three decades. In her work in multicultural and early childhood education, Leslie was a powerful advocate for inclusion, which she defined as ''a dialogue between self and other'' in which both adults and children move ''from initial identification of others like oneself, to acknowledgement and acceptance of differences, and finally to a deeper recognition of fundamental human similarities without denial of differences.'' It was a view she formed in part through her work with native American children, and it was a gospel that she spread worldwide through her scholarship, publication, teaching, mentorship and work to promote educational exchange. Leslie Williams exemplified all that is best about Teachers College, and she will be sorely missed. President Susan H. Fuhrman and the Community of Teachers College, Columbia University WILLIAMS--Leslie Rowell, 63, died November 22, 2007. Dr. Williams taught in the Department of Curriculum and Teaching at Teachers College, Columbia University for 33 years. A memorial service will be held in January at Teachers College. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the scholarship fund for children of the Rita Gold Center, Teachers College. Please contact Isabel Belinkie, Teachers College, Box 98, 525 West 120th Street, New York, NY 10027, Phone (212) 678-3013.

IFP, the organization of independent filmmakers, announced the winners of the 17th annual Gotham Awards last night, which took place in Brooklyn at Steiner Studios. The main winners were: ''Into the Wild'' (starring Emile Hirsch, right), for best feature; ''Sicko,'' for best documentary; Craig Zobel, of ''Great World of Sound,'' for breakthrough director; Ellen Page, of ''Juno,'' for breakthrough actor; ''Before the Devil Knows You're Dead'' and ''Talk to Me,'' for best ensemble cast; ''Frownland,'' for best film not playing at a theater near you.

PIGGOTT--Robert W., died on November 19, 2007. Born in Quincy, Illinois, on June 26, 1933, Bob moved to New York City in 1967 to work in the 42nd Street branch of the New York Public Library as a music librarian and cataloger. His association with the library was a long and happy one, and he retired in 1996. His encyclopedic knowledge of music, particularly vocal music, served him well in his ten years as facilitator of the Monday Morning at the Opera group at SAGE. Such a scholar, friend and gentleman will be greatly missed by all who knew him. A memorial is being planned.

UNGAR--Joseph. Beloved husband of Harriett of 63 years. Loving father of Eugene and Heidi Ungar and Jill and Robert Feinman. Cherished grandfather of Kerri, Jennifer, Seth, Peter and Ross. WWII veteran. 1943 graduate of Queens College. Founder of Smirlock and Ungar Insurance Brokerage. Founding member and past president of North Country Reform Temple, Glen Cove, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to either B'nai B'rith or The American Heart Association.
RAINE--Sydonia, and now it is 8 years. We miss you dearly. Your ever loving Murray, Caren, Bonnie, Alan, Joshua and Colin

CLARKE--Eugene. Prom inent Irish-American Book Publisher dies in Savannah. Eugene (Owen) Clarke of Sun City, Bluffton, died Monday, November 26, 2007 after a six week battle with lung disease. Seventy-four years of age, Eugene was born in Lenanavra, Mullagh, County Cavan, Republic of Ireland. A graduate of St. Patricks College, Cavan, Eugene boarded the boat to New York at the age of eighteen, accompanied by a younger sister. It was 1952. Gene soon made his mark in the New York book publishing community, first landing assignments with Barnes & Noble. In later years, he oversaw the publication of many well-known works at Harper & Row, aka Harper Collins. In his later years in Bluffton, South Carolina, Gene became known as a retirement community activist, earning the respect of his neighbours and friends. Gene was an avid follower of politics and business, and enjoyed debating the issues of the day. He was President of the Cavan Men's Association in the early 1960s. Gene is survived by his wife Bonita, loving sisters, Ann and Theresa (New York), Evelyn (Dublin), and brother, James Clarke (Lenanavra, Mullagh, County Cavan, Ireland). He is also survived by his three sons, Brendan, Ciaran, and Eoin, and grandchildren Sean, Mel and Nora. Visitation: 5-9pm, Wednesday at Fox and Weeks Funeral Directors, Hodgson Chapel. A Mass of Christian Burial will take place at 10am, Thursday at the Cathedral of St. John the Baptist. Burial to follow at St. Killians Church, Mullagh, Kells, Ireland.

Making latkes for Hanukkah, which starts Tuesday evening, is fairly simple. Grated potato, onion, flour or matzo meal, salt and pepper and beaten egg -- plus oil and a frying pan -- are all that's needed. But when there's a crowd to feed after lighting the menorah, a shortcut may be called for. About the best frozen heat-and-serve latkes that have come our way are Linda's Gourmet Latkes. Large ones come 10 to a package, and bite-size 24 to a package. The smaller ones make perfect hors d'oeuvres begging for sour cream and a spoonful of caviar or a ribbon of smoked salmon.
WOOD--David. David and ''Lena''. A true love story. We will miss his spirit and love of life. Gwen and Michael

A sports article on Nov. 20 about Lloyd Carr's decision to retire as Michigan's football coach referred imprecisely to the contract status of his assistant coaches. They have two-year contracts with one year remaining, not one-year contracts.

RABINOWITZ--Victor. The National Lawyers Guild and the NYC Chapter mourn the passing of Victor Rabinowitz, a founding member of the Guild and a consummate progressive lawyer. For over five decades Victor championed the rights of political movements, activists, trade unionists and targets of McCarthyism and represented the revolutionary Cuban government. The Guild salutes our beloved founder and role model for scores of lawyers, young and old.

STEIN--Matilda N., died on November 22, 2007, age 94. Adored mother of Paul and Amy Stein, cherished grandmother of Gregory, Danielle and Mary and loving greatgrandmother of Azalea Rosales, dear sister of Abe and Ben Newmark. Loving wife of Irving Berger. ''Your beauty and goodness will live in our hearts forever.''

MICHELS--Barbara, beloved wife, mother, and grandmother, died peacefully at home in Columbia, Maryland, on November 26, 2007 at age 74. She is survived by Harold Michels, her husband of nearly 52 years, and by their children and children-in-law: Alan Michels and Laureen Kim of San Francisco, Lisa and Robert Ott of Columbia, MD, and Heidi and Rob Silverstone of New York. She is also survived by four grandsons: Alapai, Brian, Michael and Max. Born and raised in Brooklyn, and in Fort Dix, NJ, during the war, Barbara (along with her family) spent 35 years in Parsippany, NJ, before moving to Columbia, MD, in 2001. Barbara was an inspiration to her family and friends, and no one ever left her home hungry. She touched the lives of countless people everywhere she went. She will be greatly missed. The funeral service will be at 9:30am on Wednesday, November 28, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, at 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, in Manhattan. Burial will follow at Old Montefiore Cemetery, 121-83 Springfield Blvd, St. Albans, Queens. The family requests, in lieu of flowers, that donations be made to one of the following organizations: Claudia Mayer Cancer Resource Center, 5900 Cedar Lane, Columbia, MD 21044. 410-740-5858; Center for Women's Health and Medicine at Mercy Hospital, 301 St. Paul Place, Baltimore, MD 21202. 410-332-9000; There will also be a memorial service on Sunday, December 2, 2007, from 2:30-4:30pm, at the Columbia Jewish Congregation, 5885 Robert Oliver Place, Columbia, MD.

OIL PRODUCERS' DEEP POCKETS Oil-producing countries flush with petrodollars have embarked on a global shopping spree, with the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority's investment of $7.5 billion in Citigroup the latest example. Abu Dhabi is typically a low-key investor. But a falling dollar, a growing pile of oil revenue and an interest in not being overshadowed by Dubai spurred an investment in Citigroup. [C1.]

BELLER--Jeanne, 95, a resident of Boca Raton, Florida, passed away peacefully on November 21, 2007. Loving wife of Charles W. Beller. She is survived by her son, Gary, of New York City, and his wife Carole, a son, Dr. Leonard Beller of Los Angeles, CA, and his wife Sheila, and a daughter, Enid Zimbler, of Cambridge, MA, and her husband Dr. Seymour Zimbler. She leaves six grandchildren, Brian, Andrew, Maria, Mark, Lani, and Jessie, and 11 great-grandchildren. She was a loving mother whose family and their accomplishments were very important to her. She will be sadly missed, and always remembered. Services will be private; and in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hadassah of Boca Raton, Florida.

LIPTON--Peter. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Peter Lipton, beloved son of Lini Lipton, whose commitment and generosity to the Jewish community is deeply felt, strengthening our ability to help those in need. We extend our deepest sympathies to Lini; Peter's wife, Diana; his children, Jonah and Jacob; and the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

Many readers have written to The City section and the City Room blog, asking how they can help support the work of Jorge Muñoz, the “chicken and rice man” profiled on the cover of the weekly Sunday print section and in this video.Mr. Muñoz, a 43-year-old former illegal immigrant from Colombia, is called an angel by the dozens of day laborers — many hungry, homeless and without work — who congregate at the corner of Roosevelt Avenue and 73rd Street in Jackson Heights, Queens, looking for odd jobs. He shows up at 9:30 every night driving a white pickup truck laden with enough home-cooked fare to feed them all at no charge.

At year’s end, Raymond W. Kelly will have logged the longest continuous period as police commissioner of anyone who has held that post since 1945. That’s not including his first of term of service in the Dinkins administration.

Broadway performances are to resume this evening, following a settlement reached late Wednesday by the theaters producers’ league and the union of stagehands, which had engaged in a costly 19-day strike.
Following is the script of the weekly “Only in New York” audio podcast. Listen at left or download the mp3 to a portable player. Browse a list of other Times podcasts here.
These days, the best place to find someone who is bent on running for a city office in the 2009 election is at a fund-raising event –- generally their own.
And then there was one. Or rather, the brick facade of one.

In between the remarks about crime-fighting, terrorism and any future role he has in city government, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly dispensed with some funny business at a breakfast meeting this morning in Borough Park, Brooklyn. It involved a plastic, life-size model of a pigeon. The commissioner, who is approaching a modern-day record of sorts for continuous service in his post, presented the figurine, along with a certificate of appreciation from the police commissioner’s office, to City Councilman Simcha Felder for “taking on a real serious quality-of-life issue.”

Following is a second set of answers from Robert M. Corrigan, a well-known urban rodentologist and research scientist for the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene who is took questions on the City Room blog from Nov. 26-30. A first set of answers was posted on Wednesday.

One of the inherent joys of college sports is the surreal feeling of discovery when a team or programs reaches the peak for the first time. This obviously happens more in basketball than football, as small schools often ambush their major-conference brethren in the N.C.A.A. tournament, which is almost tailor-made for such moments.

Postgame: The Cowboys improve to 11-1 and cement their reputation as the N.F.C.'s favorite to be the Patriots' whipping 'boys in the Super Bowl. (New England has already beaten Dallas, 48-27, this season).

Jed Drenning was the first quarterback in Rich Rodriguez's spread offense. Drenning started for Glenville State in 1991, when Rodriguez was the coach. Now that the coach has West Virginia in the hunt for a national title, Drenning has fond memories of the spread's early days and he was nice enough to share them with us here at The Quad.
Iraqi officials handed out cash to returning refugees during an event at a Baghdad hotel.

Favre received treatment and had an X-ray at halftime. No word yet on the extent of the injury to his right elbow. He came out a few minutes into the third quarter and put a Packers cap on his head. Going by his body language, he's not coming back in, and now the Cowboys are teeing off on Aaron Rodgers. Just sacked him.
First aired on Nov. 29, 2007.

Megan Meier, a 13-year-old from Dardenne Prairie, Missouri, killed herself last year after an online relationship she believed she was having with a cute 16-year-old boy named Josh went very sour. What she didn't know - what her parents would learn six weeks after her death - was that "Josh" was the fictitious creation of Lori Drew, a then-47-year-old neighbor and the mother of one of Megan's friends.

Brett Favre has been knocked out of the game for at least one series with a right elbow injury. His return has been announced as questionable. Aaron Rodgers replaced him, and the Packers promptly went three-and-out.
Somebody has to give in on this NFL Network issue, because 74 million or so of you are missing a shootout that the Cowboys are threatening to turn into a rout.

Morgan Stanley said Thursday that Zoe Cruz, a co-president and one of the highest-ranking women on Wall Street, would leave the investment bank in the latest management shakeup since the summer's credit turmoil.

Sovereign wealth funds based in Asia and the Middle East are on the move. In recent months, these huge government-backed investment firms have taken stakes in Bear Stearns, the Carlyle Group, Advanced Micro Devices, and perhaps most notably, Citigroup.

Whew. CNN had barely been confronted by the disclosure last night that one of the video questioners -- (the gay retired general) -- served on two of Hillary Clinton's committees before computer keyboards from one coast to another began sounding off heatedly.

Pirates operating off the coast of Somalia haven't caused so much havoc by simply being ruthless. Their innovative tactics have enabled them to launch attacks farther out on the high seas than small skiffs should be able to go, and then they evade pursuers by floating closer to the shore, where international patrols can't follow without permission from Somalia's embattled government.

The dynamic CSTV.com duo of Matt Meyers and Mike Ogle are nearing their end of the season-long odyssey known as Going Big. Along the way they've seen a little bit of everything, but nothing as jaw-dropping as Missouri assuming the No. 1 ranking. They also managed to solve the season-long mystery of why a flag from Washington State has been in the background for 61 consecutive broadcasts of ESPN's "College Gameday." So make sure the gas tank is full. It's time to hit the road.
Promises, promises. Soccer fans in the New York metropolitan area have heard them before.

It pains me that several of you feel that I dissed the farmers in Iowa and South Dakota in my Nov. 29 column. After spending years working with Verlyn Klinkenborg on the editorial board here, I've become a fan of all things farm related, give or take a few subsidies.
Sears fell to its lowest level since the KMart-Sears merger today, although it did somehow eek out a profit of a penny per share.

The 2008 presidential election is fast approaching and some states are still using unreliable paperless computerized voting machines.
Peter H. Bresnan, the man who led the Securities and Exchange Commission's landmark accounting fraud lawsuit against WorldCom, is trading his enforcement duties for private practice.

A group of eight senators sent a letter of protest today to Ryozo Kato, the Japanese ambassador to the United States, over Japan's impending whale-hunting operation near Antarctica. The operation is billed as scientific research but has been widely criticized by other countries, many environmental groups and marine biologists as a slaughter conducted for relatively unpopular meat and national pride.
The Chicago Blackhawks are making progress, and moving out of obscurity.

CNN's Republican YouTube debate last night attracted 4.4 million viewers, making it the most-watched debate of this presidential primary season and breaking all records for any primary debate on cable television in cable history.

Robert F. Kennedy Jr. endorsed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton for president today, and headed out to campaign for her in Iowa - a state where he once told residents, "large-scale hog producers are a greater threat to the United States and U.S. democracy than Osama bin Laden and his terrorist network."

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York is the clear favorite among gay and lesbian voters, who see her as a champion of gay rights, according to new nationwide poll released today by Hunter College in New York. Almost 63 percent of respondents said they supported Senator Clinton, with Senator Barack Obama of Illinois a distant second with just over 22 percent.
One moment that got some attention at Wednesday's CNN-YouTube Republican debate was when the candidates were asked whether they believed every word of the Bible.

Private equity firms have been asleep at the public relations switch, more interested in reaping profits than cultivating a positive public image, Carlyle Group co-founder David Rubenstein said Wednesday, according to TheDeal.com.

The Oilers played the Avs at the Pepsi Center on Wednesday night and managed only 13 shots. They were 0 for 4 on the power play. Still, they lost by only 4-2 with Peter Budaj manning the net for Colorado. Edmonton's Dustin Penner, the behemoth with the five-year, $21.25 million contract, had one shot and no points. Somewhere I hear Brian Burke chuckling.
The Atlanta metropolitan area has been hit by a drought so severe that Georgia's governor has resorted to praying for rain.

On the final night of the November sweeps period, ABC's new holiday special "Shrek the Halls" lifted the network to a first place finish among adults 18 to 49 on Wednesday. Attracting an impressive 21.1 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates, "Shrek" delivered ratings in the 18-to-49 set higher than any other program on network television last week with the exception of "Sunday Night Football."

It was a week of some wonderfully satisfying wines, and I'm not just thinking of Thanksgiving, which in my case was fairly simple: a case of white, a case of red, and 35 people (not all of them wine drinkers). It was not a day for reflective drinking, except for a lull in the cooking when my cousins and I opened a dry, delicate '98 blanc de blancs from Duval-Leroy, which, as Garrison Keillor says, gave us the strength to do what needs to be done.

Over a decade ago, I remember seeing a "Saturday Night Live" skit that still stays with me. It was a talk show where all of the guests had one thing in common: they were all jerks or psychopaths whose one-time actions had created lifelong inconvenience for the rest of society. There was that guy who put poison into a bottle of Tylenol, initiating the era of the childproof (and adult-proof) package. There was the hijacker, whose actions led to the nationwide construction of airport X-ray machines. There was the creep who put razor blades into Halloween candy. And so on.
A rough patch just got rougher for Edward Lampert, the famed value investor who runs ESL Investments.

The Writers Guild of America and ABC have reached an agreement on a new contract for 250 ABC News writers, editors, artists, assistants, and researchers, the guild said Thursday morning.

Anne Thompson, writing in Variety, said that the refusal of the Coen Brothers to let good triumph over evil in "No Country for Old Men" is a subject of discussion that is showing up everywhere, including her book club. The ending hews closely to the book and the Bagger found it in keeping with a film that constructed its own moral universe. Others, though, aren't so sure. Nora Ephron gets a laugh out of the debate in the New Yorker, while Alec Baldwin uses it as a soapbox for a short speech. "Go see No Country for Old Men. It's a metaphor for Iraq and the post 9/11 world,"he concludes.
Backstage at the Gothams, two Oscar vets -- Tom O'Neil of the Envelope and Dave Karger of EW -- talk smack about this year's race.

One of the games we play out here in the land of much portent and little impact is The Big One That is Still Coming. So far, with "Charlie Wilson's War" getting a wan initial reception, that would be "Sweeney Todd."

It is a little early in the season for the Bagger to mount his hobby horse, but how come "Lars and the Real Girl" and "Once" are getting so little love? "Lars," a touching story of romance between Ryan Gosling's character and a blow-up doll, got bubkes at the Gothams and ditto from the Spirit nominations. "Once" got a foreign film nod from the Spirits, but that's it. Both films would seem to embody indie excellence and ambition, but don't seem to be gaining the kind of traction they deserve.

Johan Santana, the star pitcher of the Minnesota Twins, is at the center of trade talks between the Twins and a number of clubs. He won't come cheaply. The team that lands him would likely have to give up multiple top prospects and sign Santana to a long-term contract. How far should a team go to get Santana?

When football players sustain traumatic blows to the head, some television commentators see a great play while others take a more sober tone. Anne-Marie Slaughter, an international lawyer and the dean of the Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton University. She is the author "The Idea that is America," and she is spending this academic year in Shanghai.

Hockey is a red-blooded, manly endeavor, and with that in mind have a look at Agence France Presse's report on the bench-clearing brawl between two teams of 8-year-olds that took place in Guelph on Friday. Ontario hockey authorities are tut-tutting the sordid episode -- clearly players shouldn't fight until they're 15. To start earlier would be, why, obscene.

Over the last several years, several big-city mayors, led by Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and Richard M. Daley of Chicago, have made pronouncements that amount to a race to see which metropolis is the "greenest" in the country. They're retrofitting old city buildings to cut energy waste and greenhouse gases, trying to curtail traffic, putting up solar panels. (For two independent analyses of green cities, go to the Green Guide and Yahoo.)

John Ford, a successful programmer for TLC, Discovery Health and National Geographic Channel, is taking the reigns at Discovery Communications' signature channel, the company said today.
NBC is dropping hints about what its spring programming schedule will look like if the writers' strike continues.

Axcan Pharma, a Canadian pharmaceutical company specializing in treatments of gastrointestinal disorders, said Thursday that it will be acquired by TPG Capital for about $1.3 billion in cash. It is the latest in a string of smaller buyouts, since the summer's credit market squeeze halted the mega-deals from earlier this year.
So CNN chose which questions would be asked in the Republican debate last night. And guess what: not one question about health care, the central domestic issue for this election.

When Amaranth Advisors was collapsing last summer because of energy trades gone bad, the firm's chief operating officer, Charles Winkler, got a call from Kenneth Griffin. Mr. Griffin came right to the point: "Charlie," he said, according to documents Amaranth filed in a recent lawsuit, "what can we do, and how can we help?"

(Their videos and takes on the Granite State primary race can be found at CampusVoices.org)

"Well, at least the candidates were probably all Republicans. As for the questioners, that's a different story," writes Rick Moran at Rightwing Nuthouse, pretty much summing up the outrage among conservatives that "at least 4 of the questioners from last night's CNN/YouTube Debate were Democratic party supporters and activists including one gay general who worked for John Kerry's campaign and is on Hillary Clinton's LGBT Steering Committee."
New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick has again found time in his busy media schedule avoiding talk of a possible perfect season to grace us with some college thoughts.

In the wake of the news that Michigan has sought permission to talk to Louisiana State Coach Les Miles, Michael Rosenberg of the Detroit Free Press writes that it's time to take a step back and examine whether Miles would really be the best fit for the Wolverines. Rosenberg doesn't think so. He prefers Jeff Tedford of Cal instead.

A new frontier in the worlds of luxury (and luxury trappings) is the receipt package-a precious little envelope to carry your carefully folded proof of purchase. Borrowed from those connoisseurs of all things shopping and packaging, the Japanese, the conspicuously tiny envelope is in circulation at stores including J. Crew, Phillip Lim, Diesel, Louis Vuitton, Marni and Calvin Klein. "It's these little things that make a difference," says Millard Drexler, the mastermind behind J. Crew's turnaround and its amped-up luxe quotient. "It says, 'I really care about your shopping experience.'" (What these high-design disposables say about waste management, however, is another issue.) Prada's embossed, stiff card stock is Milanese navy; Diane von Furstenberg's open-top version has a sexy, low-cut back to expose its fuchsia interior; Jil Sander's has a bold-lettered, starkly minimal style; R by 45rpm's envelope is slightly rough, unbleached paper. Of course, the amenity has its practical purposes. As Diesel's envelope puts it: "A token of our time spent together And a keepsake for a change of heart."

Right out of the gate, last night's Republican debate took on a weighty topic - immigration - and had two leading candidates playing defense. It was a night for sharp jabs among several of the contenders, who also offered up some veiled charges underlining recent controversies.
The Bagger hits the streets once again! In this clip, he heads to the 2007 Gotham Awards with Mira Nair.

PopCandy at USA Today tips its hat to a feature about the best movie moustaches. There are the predictable nods to Erroll Flynn and Charlie Chaplin, but the Bagger thinks putting Ben Stiller's "Dodgeball" 'stash at number 12 was a grave injustice.

At a time when hedge fund investors will be glad if they end the year with 12 percent to 14 percent positive returns, multi-strategy hedge funds like Citadel Investment Group are increasingly finding themselves in the sweet spot, Breakingviews says.

Awards Daily pointed us to a scabrous video take on the cravenness and calculation of some in the movie business at this time of the year. It was produced by "The Soup" over at E! Apparently -- the Bagger is shocked -- some movie producers are so infected by gold lust that they may even allow it to affect their choices of themes, talent, and story.

Democratic presidential candidate Dennis Kucinich had a stage all to himself last night as he broadcast a Manchester, N.H., town hall meeting live at the same time the G.O.P. candidates were competing for the spotlight in Florida.
