A report that an ambitious banker recently pitched a Citigroup-Bank of America merger has got the folks at Breakingviews thinking: Wouldn't a combination of Citi and J.P. Morgan Chase make more sense? (At least one commenter on DealBook has been thinking the same thing.)

As a consumer, the Bagger has never been a big Roger Ebert fan. His tendency to go so deep into the tank for a film that he risks getting the bends when he returns to the surface always seemed excessive. But sitting near the stage the other night at the Gothams, the Bagger watched him take what could have been a forlorn turn during a tribute and turn it into yet another triumph.

The chairman of Sallie Mae, the big student lender locked in a dispute with an investor group over a buyout deal, is assuming the additional role of executive chairman with an approved $3 million annual pay package, the company said Wednesday.

Singapore state investment company Temasek Holdings is selling up to $277 million worth of shipping company China Cosco shares in a placement, marking its third divestment of holdings in Chinese firms this week.
BHP Billiton, the world's largest mining company, should increase its $132 billion proposal to win over shareholders of rival Rio Tinto Group or drop the takeover bid, RBC Capital Markets said.

A few months ago, I wrote a column, Blurring by Choice or Passion, about people who choose a life with few boundaries between their work and the rest of their life. The article featured the story of Anthony Sandberg, an entrepreneur who turned his interest in sailing into a thriving business. When he told me about how he accomplished that, much of the story had to do with finding the right partner, Richard Jepsen, who could bring complementary skills to the business.
Swiss private bank Julius Baer Holding is eyeing an initial public offering or a management-led buyout of its U.S. asset management unit after talks to sell it stalled, according to Reuters.

National Australia Bank, the nation's largest bank, agreed to buy U.S.-based Great Western Bancorporation for $798 million, its biggest acquisition since the 1998 purchase of HomeSide Lending led to billions of dollars in losses.
E*Trade Financial, the troubled Internet bank and brokerage, said Thursday it secured a $2.55 billion cash infusion from a group led by hedge-fund firm Citadel Investment Group.
Group4Securicor, a British security firm, is in talks to buy Global Solutions, a company it used to own, for around 350 million pounds ($774 million), The Telegraph reported.

The European Commission is exploring plans for an EU-wide law to regulate sovereign wealth funds, a move that could vastly complicate the City of London's ability to serve as hub for the investment flows from Asia, the Middle East, and Russia.

KfW Group, which organized the bailout of IKB Deutsche Industriebank over subprime losses, said an agreement was reached with German banking associations to cover the lender's remaining risks of about $520 million.
After more than two years awaiting trial in the United States on Enron-related charges, three British bankers pleaded guilty Wednesday in federal court here to one count each of wire fraud.

The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled Wednesday that public companies could block investors from putting director candidates on corporate ballots, a major setback for shareholders seeking a greater say in boardroom affairs.

Chinese insurer Ping An said it has paid $2.7 billion to take a 4.2 percent stake in the Belgian-Dutch financial-services group Fortis, continuing a trend of Asian and Middle Eastern interest in Western financials.
Tesla Motors, the Silicon Valley electric-car start-up, has put a fast driver behind the wheel.

Coming off a setback at the hands of the cable television industry, the head of the Federal Communications Commission moved to reassert himself on Wednesday by proposing that the commission quickly adopt a rule that would prevent Comcast, the nation's biggest cable company, from becoming larger, commission officials said.
In another win for activist investors, the parent company of American Airlines, AMR, said Wednesday that it planned to shed its American Eagle regional airline unit.

A federal judge Wednesday ordered Conrad Black's Canadian holding company to pay $13 million in fines and restitution as punishment for taking part in a scheme to defraud shareholders of the parent company of the Chicago Sun-Times.
Mobile phone group Vodafone Group and Spanish carrier Telefonica are taking stakes in a mobile advertising company in a move to battle the threat of online giants Google and Yahoo.

As governments in the Middle East take big stakes in American companies, China's state-run investment fund has quietly shifted its focus from overseas deals to bolstering the country's troubled banking system.
Frazier Healthcare Ventures said it's closed its sixth institutional fund, having raised $600 million and bringing its total capital under management to $1.8 billion.

School districts and local governments in Florida have pulled $8 billion out of a state-run investment pool, or 30 percent of its assets, after learning that the money market fund contained more than $700 million of defaulted debt.

The banking giant Wachovia will pay $300,000 to settle claims that it failed to disclose conflicts of interest in research reports by analysts, the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said Wednesday.

Prudential Financial, the nation's second-largest life insurer, said Wednesday that its vice chairman, John R. Strangfeld, would take over as chief executive on Jan. 1 and become board chairman in May.
A decade ago, only a handful of women could claim the kind of style clout that comes with a presence in the D.J. booth. That has changed.

"Striking screenwriters and Hollywood producers agreed to extend their renewed contract talks to a fourth day this evening, signaling at least some progress toward ending a work stoppage that began three and a half weeks ago," Michael Cieply reports in Thursday's New York Times.
For young friends in Queens, bikes souped up with stereo systems function as rolling D.J. booths.
A seriously deranged dramedy about finding yourself through terrorism, “Be My Oswald” attempts high-wire artiness on a bargain-basement budget.
In the dark days and weeks after the suicide of the artist Jeremy Blake in July, his friends and colleagues were left to pick up the pieces, literally.
The screenwriters called the proposals from producers a “a massive rollback,” and called on their members to continue their walkout.
The decision reopens an issue that was settled in 2005 after years of negotiations over claims by freelance writers that their contracts did not allow for electronic publication of their work.
Dell reported today that third-quarter net income increased 26 percent to $766 million, or 34 cents a share, on sales of $15.6 billion.
The owner of Sears and Kmart said profit for the third quarter plunged an eye-popping 99 percent as customers flocked to rival stores during the back-to-school  season.
Sanofi-Aventis said that it would make significant payments to collaborate with Regeneron and use its genetically engineered mouse to develop new drugs.
The White House began a new offensive against Congressional Democrats today over money for the Iraq war.
Bowing to U.S. pressure on the eve of economic talks, China agreed today to end a dozen trade subsidies.
The administration’s forecast calls for “solid growth” through next year, a prediction that is more optimistic than those of the Federal Reserve and many Wall Street analysts.
The theater district buzzed today as Broadway prepared to revive a season interrupted by a 19-day strike by stagehands.
A group of soldiers demanding the ouster of the Philippine president agreed to end the standoff with police begun when the took over the five-star hotel earlier in the day.
Fans and merchants in the Theater District welcomed the news of a tentative settlement of the Broadway strike.
The settlement brought to an end a strike that had shuttered most of Broadway for 19 days and disrupted the plans of thousands of theatergoers.
Michigan athletics officials asked for and received permission from Louisiana State to meet with Les Miles about the Wolverines’ head football coaching vacancy.
The Devils are not only starting to win under Brent Sutter, they are finding ways to come from behind and get the job done.
A white man convicted of killing a Hmong hunter as they both stalked squirrels in the woods last January was sentenced to 69 years in prison.
A Muslim convert pleaded guilty to charges of plotting to use hand grenades to attack holiday shoppers at a mall in Rockford.

O. J. Simpson and his two co-defendants pleaded not guilty to a dozen charges stemming from a confrontation in a hotel room here on Sept. 13. Judge Jackie Glass of Clark County District Court set a trial date for April 7.

Local intelligence-sharing centers set up after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks have had their antiterrorism mission diluted by a focus on run-of-the-mill street crime and natural disasters, a government report concluded.
The winner of a $1 million lottery scratch ticket may have a problem: He is a convicted robber who is not supposed to gamble.
President Bush appointed a special panel to investigate sticking points in negotiations between Amtrak and eight of its unions.

Alitalia, the unprofitable airline that the Italian government is trying to sell, may have no value because labor costs remain too high compared with its peers, Deutsche Bank’s European airline analysts said. The airline, the largest carrier in Italy, will struggle to cut personnel expenses further without clashing with unions, the analysts said. Cutting labor costs will be hard for Alitalia without a bankruptcy filing, they said.

The Guardian Industries Corporation and three other companies were fined $724 million by European regulators who said they fixed the price in Europe of flat glass used to make windows, fire-resistant glass and mirrors. The four companies were Guardian, based in Auburn Hills, Mich.; Compagnie de Saint-Gobain of France; the Pilkington Group of Britain; the Asahi Glass Company of Japan.

Telkom South Africa abandoned talks to sell its mobile and fixed-line phone assets to the Vodafone Group and the MTN Group, ending the possibility of South Africa’s biggest takeover. Vodafone, which owns 50 percent of Vodacom Group, South Africa’s largest cellphone company, was in talks to buy the other half from Telkom. The MTN Group was negotiating to buy Telkom’s fixed-line business.

Wolseley, the world’s largest distributor of plumbing products, said yesterday that it was cutting 1,300 more jobs in the United States as it sought to cut costs amid the struggling housing market. Wolseley has already eliminated 1,700 jobs in the United States and said it would cut 1,300 more in its second quarter. The cuts represent about 5 percent of its total work force.

Bombardier, the global airplane and train maker, said it had named Pierre Beaudoin as its chief executive, taking over from his father, Laurent Beaudoin, who will remain chairman. The move comes as Bombardier reported an almost 23 percent increase in third-quarter profit amid strong orders for trains and planes. Earnings rose to $91 million, or 5 cents a share, despite bad publicity in the quarter over several crash landings of one of its turboprop aircraft as a result of landing gear failure. Pierre Beaudoin, above, currently president and chief operating officer of the aerospace unit, will become chief executive effective with the next annual meeting on June 4.
More than 100 people Wednesday debated how well WWOR-TV, Channel 9, is fulfilling its mandate to provide coverage of issues important to the residents of northern New Jersey.
Kia Vaughn had 12 points and 11 rebounds and No. 5 Rutgers survived a scare from host Saint Joseph’s to hold on for a 56-50 victory Wednesday night.

An article on Sunday about Dr. Charles S. Hirsch, the New York City medical examiner, whose review of an autopsy on a city police detective has generated controversy, referred incorrectly in some copies to the size of a state medical review panel that in 1989 contradicted Dr. Hirsch’s findings in the case of Richard Luke, a 25-year-old man who died while in police custody. (The same error appeared in an article on Dec. 29, 1989, about the panel’s decision.) At the time, the panel had three members, not two. (It was authorized to have seven members, but four seats were vacant.).

An article in some editions yesterday about a feud in a Long Island surrogate’s court over the estate of Monique de T. Eastman — the widow of Lee V. Eastman, a lawyer who represented Paul McCartney and who is the father of Linda Eastman, Mr. McCartney’s first wife — misstated in one reference in some copies the surname of one of Monique Eastman’s sons from her first marriage. He is Peter Sprayregen, not Eastman.

An article in some editions yesterday about a feud in a Long Island surrogate’s court over the estate of Monique de T. Eastman — the widow of Lee V. Eastman, a lawyer who represented Paul McCartney and who is the father of Linda Eastman, Mr. McCartney’s first wife — misstated in one reference in some copies the surname of one of Monique Eastman’s sons from her first marriage. He is Peter Sprayregen, not Eastman.
LeBron James sprained his left index finger in the second quarter Wednesday night and did not return in the visiting Cleveland Cavaliers’ 109-74 loss to the Detroit Pistons.
Despite the records, when the Jets (2-9) play the Dolphins (0-11), the game will have big implications — historic implications as the Dolphins plod toward a possible 0-16 season.

An obituary on Tuesday about Kevin DuBrow, lead singer for the rock group Quiet Riot, misstated the circumstances of an accident in 1982 involving Randy Rhoads, who formed the band. Mr. Rhoads was a passenger in a plane that clipped a tour bus of Ozzy Osbourne, for whom he played guitar. The plane then crashed, killing all three people aboard; he did not die in a traffic accident.
The main faction in the Lebanese Parliament agreed to amend the Constitution to allow the head of the military to assume the vacant presidency.
Prime Minister Almazbek Atambayev stepped down and was presented with a service award by President Kurmanbek Bakiev.

Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore and six other players from the United States team that reached the under-20 World Cup quarterfinals are on the squad that will travel to China in preparation for Olympic qualifiers. This will be the first time the United States under-23 team has gathered since Peter Nowak took over as the coach in August. Games will begin Dec. 16.Altidore will be joined by 17 fellow players from Major League Soccer clubs, including his Red Bulls teammate Hunter Freeman as well as his former U-20 teammates Robbie Rogers and Tim Ward of Columbus, Nathin Sturgis and Chris Seitz of Real Salt Lake, Dax McCarty of FC Dallas and Sal Zizzo of Hannover 96 in Germany. Freddy Adu, Michael Bradley and Danny Szetela were not placed on the roster because of scheduling conflicts.
Dodge said it would use its Charger model next season in Nascar, scrapping plans to field the Avenger it used in Car of Tomorrow races this year. Dodge used both models this past season.
Prosecutors arrested the former vice minister of the Defense Ministry on suspicion that he accepted cash and lavish entertainment from military contractors in exchange for business, officials said.
Canada’s Parliament formally called on Japan to apologize for coercing women to work as sex slaves for its soldiers in World War II.

The defending champion AC Milan moved into the second round of the European Champion League with a 1-1 tie at Benfica, and Chelsea advanced with a 4-0 victory at Rosenborg. Two other qualifying groups were wide open, and half the 16-team field for the second round will not be decided until the final games. Liverpool eased some of the pressure on Coach Rafael Benítez with a 4-1 victory over Porto, and Real Madrid hurt its chances with a 3-2 loss at Werder Bremen.

Greg Robinson will have another season to turn Syracuse around. Athletic Director Daryl Gross said Robinson would remain as the coach in 2008 despite leading the Orange through the worst three-year stretch in the history of the program, including the first two 10-loss seasons in its history. Robinson’s teams have gone 1-10, 4-8 and 2-10; in those 28 losses, Syracuse has been outscored by 514 points.
A vast archive of German war records opened to the public, giving historians and Holocaust survivors who have waited more than 60 years access to concentration camp papers detailing Nazi horrors.

Don Miller, the longtime president of Roger Penske’s Nascar operation, has announced his retirement. Miller has been with Penske since it began racing stock cars in 1990. He has been at the top for 75 victories and more than $90 million in winnings.

An inquest into the death of the Pakistan cricket coach Bob Woolmer ended when a Jamaican jury was unable to determine the cause of death after hearing testimony from more than 50 people over five weeks. The 11-member panel deliberated for about four hours before returning an open verdict, which means jurors decided they had not heard sufficient evidence to declare Bob Woolmer’s death an accident, a homicide or the result of natural causes.
The World Health Organization and Unicef reported a stunning 91 percent reduction in measles mortality across Africa.
A last round of negotiations on the future status of Kosovo  broke up in Austria without an agreement.

Aksel Lund Svindal, the defending overall World Cup champion, could be sidelined for up to six weeks after surgery following a serious training accident. A team of three doctors operated simultaneously on Svindal for nearly five hours at the Vail Valley Medical Center in Beaver Creek, Colo., to repair a deep gash in his left buttock and broken bones to his face and nose.

The new W.N.B.A. franchise in Atlanta does not have a team name, colors or players, but it named Marynell Meadors, 64, one of the league’s eight original coaches, as its first coach and general manager.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 28 — A former American sailor accused of helping support terrorism by leaking classified information about the whereabouts of Navy vessels in early 2001 told jihadist supporters that if they were not going to do anything with his information to “just destroy it,” a government witness told a federal judge here on Wednesday.
If the Boston Celtics could go from an also-ran last season to a title contender this season, then why shouldn’t the Knicks keep dreaming of big changes in small time frames?
Rutgers is in fifth place in the eight-team Big East Conference and will probably receive a berth in the International Bowl on Jan. 5 in Toronto.
Richard F. Scruggs, a prominent trial lawyer who has been fighting insurance companies over payments for damage from Hurricane Katrina, was indicted Wednesday on federal bribery charges.
The head of the F.C.C. has proposed quick adoption of a rule that would prevent Comcast, the nation’s largest cable company, from growing larger.
Sean Avery, one of the most energetic Rangers and their chief agitator, will have arthroscopic surgery on his left wrist Thursday and will be out indefinitely, the team announced Wednesday.
In contrast to other sovereign wealth funds, China’s state-run investment fund has no immediate plans to take a large stake in any foreign company.
While the N.F.L. has adopted guidelines for concussions, no rules govern how they are treated in college football.

Five people, including a police official and airport workers, were charged in Colombia yesterday as part of an investigation into heroin smuggling, federal prosecutors in Manhattan said. The five will be extradited to the United States to face federal drug charges in Manhattan, the prosecutors said. The arrests are part of an investigation into heroin smuggling from Medellín, Colombia, to the New York City area, Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan, said in a statement. Prosecutors have already charged three other people, including two Colombia police officials, in connection with the case. They charge that the suspects carried the drugs hidden in suitcases, clothing and computers.

A former investment banking analyst has been sentenced to 1 ½ to 4 ½ years in state prison for stealing more than $572,000 from state tax authorities and attempting to steal an additional $4.6 million, prosecutors said yesterday. The analyst, We Jin Shon, 25, a Canadian citizen who worked for Morgan Stanley in London, pleaded guilty to grand larceny and attempted grand larceny in State Supreme Court on Tuesday, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, said in a statement. He was sentenced the same day. Prosecutors said Mr. Shon filed 30 fraudulent tax returns using fake names and sought more than $5 million in refunds. Not all the returns were processed, but some money was wired to bank accounts in Mr. Shon’s name, prosecutors said. He was arrested after a bank manager questioned Mr. Shon after noticing that he was withdrawing $189,681 and that the original source of the money was a tax refund in another person’s name, prosecutors said.

The City Council passed a greenhouse gas reduction bill yesterday that puts into law the ambitious carbon dioxide emissions goals that were laid out in Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s sweeping sustainability plan last April. The bill, which Mr. Bloomberg supports, requires that heat-trapping gases from city government buildings and vehicles be cut 30 percent from current levels by 2017. Moreover, it requires that carbon emissions from the entire city, including privately owned buildings, be reduced by 30 percent by the year 2030. Transforming the emissions controls from goals into law will ensure that they will be enforced in future administrations, said Councilman James F. Gennaro, chairman of the Environmental Protection Committee.

Larry Starr, who was the head trainer for the Cincinnati Reds and Florida Marlins, said Wednesday that he shared with investigators his perspective and knowledge on the use of performance-enhancing drugs.

Late in his tenure as mayor of New York, Rudolph W. Giuliani billed tens of thousands of dollars in travel expenses to little-known city agencies as he was beginning an extramarital affair, a report said.

New Jersey’s vehicle titles and temporary license plate tags are getting makeovers. State motor vehicle officials said on Tuesday that both documents will have new security features to combat fraud and to make them harder to duplicate. The new titles will be issued in January on purple paper and feature watermarks, security threads and special colors and ink. The temporary tags will be issued next month and will feature special paper and blue ink.Compiled by John Sullivan.

A doctor who was convicted of conspiring to treat injured Qaeda fighters was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 25 years in prison by a judge who said a sentence that would deter others was needed because terrorists cannot carry out their deadly aims without help. Judge Loretta A. Preska said that the doctor, Rafiq Sabir, 53, of Boca Raton, Fla., showed no remorse after his conviction in May for conspiring to provide material support to terrorists by agreeing to treat injured Qaeda members so they could return to Iraq to battle Americans. Before the sentencing, Dr. Sabir insisted that he was “completely innocent” and said a co-defendant, Tarik Shah, had duped him into taking an oath to Al Qaeda with an F.B.I. agent who was posing as a Qaeda recruiter. “I’m an extremely gullible man,” he said.

Children who inhaled dust from the collapsed World Trade Center may be twice as likely to develop asthma as children who were not exposed, according to preliminary findings released yesterday by the City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. The department based the observation on self-reported symptoms from the World Trade Center Health Registry’s initial survey, which was conducted in 2003 and 2004. Health officials said about 6 percent of the 3,100 children under 18 who are enrolled in the study received a new asthma diagnosis after 9/11. The asthma rate for children under 5 who were directly exposed to the dust cloud was even higher — possibly three times the rate for the same age group across the Northeast, officials said. But they cautioned that it was too early to tell whether the increase is due to exposure, better detection or the tendency of parents of children with asthma symptoms to join the registry. A follow-up survey is under way.
The agency planned to close all the trailer camps it runs for victims of the 2005 hurricanes by the end of May, including its biggest camp outside of Baton Rouge, La.

A former city police officer who helped his brother distribute vast quantities of cocaine and marijuana throughout the New York area from 2002 to 2005 was sentenced in Federal District Court to 10 years in prison yesterday. The former officer, Jose Torrado, 32, of the Bronx, pleaded guilty earlier this year to drug trafficking charges. Mr. Torrado joined the Police Department in 2001 and resigned in 2006 amid an investigation into his crimes. While serving with the department, Mr. Torrado worked with a criminal group that smuggled drugs from Mexico to New York in trucks, prosecutors have said.
This week, the Condoleezza Rice way toward reaching a peace deal between Israelis and Palestinians got off the ground.
The Twins are close to dealing pitcher Matt Garza to the Tampa Bay Rays in a multiplayer trade for outfielder Delmon Young.
Laptops, digital cameras and MP3 music players are among the hottest gift items this year. For preschoolers.
The states filed the suit for weakening regulations that for two decades have required businesses and industries to report the toxic chemicals they use, store and release.
The Dow soared to its biggest one-day gain in more than four years on Wednesday after a top Federal Reserve official hinted at another interest rate cut.

A 40 percent contingency fee negotiated by a Manhattan law firm retained by the widow of a real estate developer involved in a multimillion-dollar estate dispute was not “unconscionable on its face,” an appeals court ruled yesterday.
The latest battleground in the federalism wars at the Supreme Court is an unlikely one: the state of Maine, which is trying to prevent under-age consumers from buying cigarettes over the Internet.
After more than two years awaiting trial in the United States on Enron-related charges, three British bankers pleaded guilty Wednesday in federal court to one count each of wire fraud.
For once, it is tempting to take Shamil Tarpishchev at his word when he claims that his Russian Davis Cup team has only a “35 percent chance” of winning this weekend against the United States.
A declassified 1969 memorandum shows that the Nixon administration was worried that Israel’s acquisition of a nuclear arsenal could touch off an arms race in the Middle East.
R. J. Reynolds said that starting next year it would stop running cigarette ads in consumer magazines and newspapers for brands like Camel, Winston and Pall Mall.
Keith B. Hennessey will succeed Allan B. Hubbard as chairman of the National Economic Council.
The investment bank will cut 650 jobs in all departments from its work force of about 15,500.

The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled yesterday that public companies could block investors from putting director candidates on corporate ballots, a major setback for shareholders seeking a greater say in boardroom affairs.
ComAlert represents an impressive start toward the goal of helping newly released inmates forge viable lives on the outside.
China will allow market forces to exert more influence over the value of the yuan as the country moves toward a fully convertible currency.
Former Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, a centrist Democrat, announced that he was leaving the law firm Patton Boggs to form his own firm with a son.
Lynn DeJac on Wednesday became the first woman in the United States to have her conviction for killing someone overturned based on DNA evidence but she faces another legal hurdle.
Unless something is done quickly to address the foreclosure crisis, whole communities, not just people who lose their homes, will suffer.

The banking giant Wachovia will pay $300,000 to settle claims that it failed to disclose conflicts of interest in research reports by analysts, the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said yesterday.
It’s not too late for former Pakistani prime ministers Benazir Bhutto to repair her democratic credentials and for Nawaz Sharif to establish his.

A large group of paintings discovered several years ago and thought by some to be by Jackson Pollock included many containing paints and materials that were not available until after the artist’s death in 1956.
The move is an escalation of a dispute after Álvaro Uribe’s withdrawal of support last week for Hugo Chávez’s mediating role with Colombian guerrillas.
Genentech’s plan to restrict the availability of Avastin so doctors cannot use it instead of a more expensive medicine for eye disease will cost taxpayers $1 billion to $3 billion a year.

School districts and local governments in Florida have pulled $8 billion out of a state-run investment pool after learning that the money market fund contained more than $700 million of defaulted debt.

The settlement, which applies to Explorers in model years 1991 through 2001, will allow vehicle owners to apply for $500 vouchers to buy Explorers or $300 vouchers to buy other Ford or Lincoln Mercury products.
The number of operations has fallen sharply, from thousands a year to under 200 in 2006. Some researchers praise this as a triumph of data over wishful thinking.
The Cowboys’ defense, once maligned as a weak link, has improved since the beginning of the season ans is hoping to put pressure on Packers quarterback Brett Favre.
The Arizona Pro Bowl safety Adrian Wilson will have season-ending surgery on his ailing right heel, the team said Wednesday.
The chief executive of Qualcomm gave the iPhone credit for making consumers more eager for third-generation cellphone networks.
Southwest Airlines could soon be standing head and shoulders above the competition because it loaded up years ago on hedges against higher fuel prices.
A United Nations tribunal on Wednesday reduced the jail terms of three Rwandan journalists convicted of fanning the 1994 genocide by inciting Hutu extremists to slaughter Tutsi.
A European court has awarded damages to an investigative journalist whose home was raided and computers confiscated after he published articles alleging fraud within the E.U.
Banks, shops, schools and public transportation were closed in cities across Bolivia on Wednesday as demonstrators protested a proposed constitutional overhaul.
Other than the hellish heat, a crushing carbon dioxide atmosphere and corrosive clouds of sulfuric acid, Venus is a lot like Earth, scientists said.
As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York again prepares to trot around the world, a question is emerging: Is he traveling so much for the city? Or for much-denied presidential aspirations?
The rejection of New Orleans as a site for one of next year’s presidential debates strikes us as far more plainly stupid than political.

Two City Department of Transportation employees, including a high-ranking official earning $106,000 a year, were charged yesterday with soliciting hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes from a company handling bridge repairs.
Officials burned one of the largest shipments of narcotics ever seized, sending about 23 tons of cocaine into the tropical sky in a black plume.
Ethnic Tamil separatists were suspected in the attack, the Sri Lankan military said.

The state health commissioner has proposed a series of changes to help prevent delays in notifying patients who may be exposed to various infections in case a doctor’s infection-control practices are faulty.
A day after the firing of its chief executive, the American Red Cross discussed all its problems including governance, failures in disaster relief efforts and in its blood business.
A developer wants to build a 16-mile tunnel beneath Long Island Sound that would link Long Island and Westchester.
A top police official in Miami said Wednesday that the evidence collected so far in the investigation of Sean Taylor’s death suggested he was not a premeditated target of his killer.
A settlement was reached in a court battle between a Cuban farmer and a wealthy Florida couple over his 5-year-old daughter. It gave the farmer sole custody.
Two youthful computer whizzes are quietly trying to change how campaigns raise money, netting millions of dollars for Democrats in the process.
The teenager, Eric Walker, was charged as an adult with the murder of a student from Senegal, who was shot to death on Nov. 19 as he walked to his apartment.
With the holiday travel season upon us, timely updates on traffic conditions, weather, flight times and gas prices can save time and frustration.
I get a white screen and no picture when I try to play an .AVI movie with the QuickTime Player on my Mac. What kind of software do I need?
How does Flickr.com know what kind of digital camera I use when I post photos on the site? Is there a way to keep this information from being displayed?
Three of the N.F.L.’s best defensive ends, the Giants’ Osi Umenyiora and the Bears’ Mark Anderson and Adewale Ogunleye, are bachelors and best friends who will share a house this off-season.
After a dispute that turned into a public relations problem, Starbucks said that it would open a center to help Ethiopian coffee farmers improve the profitability of their crops.
Investigators in Rahway, N.J., are trying to determine whether a woman died because of a procedure performed by an unlicensed cosmetic surgeon.
Bill Willis was the Cleveland Browns’ Hall of Fame guard who played a major role in breaking pro football’s color barrier in the decade after World War II.
Gudrun Wagner, who as the wife of Wolfgang Wagner, the director of the Bayreuth Festival, played a major behind-the-scenes role in guiding the event, the world’s pre-eminent Wagner opera festival.
Amid labor disputes between television writers and CBS, the Democratic National Committee announced that it was canceling the debate among Democratic candidates scheduled for Dec. 10.

The decision to shed the American Eagle regional airline unit came after an investor group called on the parent company of American Airlines to bolster its stock price by getting rid of some operations.
In Richmond Hill, Queens, teens are turning bicycles into rolling outdoor sound systems.
Obesity rates in women have leveled off and stayed steady since 1999, long enough for researchers to say the plateau appears to be real.
Juba, the capital of South Sudan and one of the fastest-growing towns on the continent, is a land of big dreams and broken — or at least neglected — promises.
Twenty children died in shelters during the three-year period from 2004 to 2006, with by far the most — 12 — dying in 2006, the report said.
Packers at Cowboys.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 28 — A 9-year-old boy who took a loaded semiautomatic handgun to school has been suspended, police and school officials said Wednesday, adding that they were trying to determine how the boy had obtained the weapon and what he had planned to do with it.
Federal regulatory advisers have recommended strengthening safety warnings on GlaxoSmithKline’s asthma drug Serevent amid reports of deaths in children taking the treatment.
Poland is facing a rare war-crimes prosecution at a crucial juncture for the newly elected government’s commitment to overseas military engagements.
In a few decades, as many as 2 percent of all cancers in the United States may be due to radiation from CT scans given now.
The vice chairman of Prudential Financial, John R. Strangfeld, will succeed Arthur F. Ryan by taking over as  chief executive and will later become the board chairman.
Two sheriff’s deputies in Palm Beach County in Florida were killed Wednesday when another sheriff’s office vehicle ran into them during the pursuit of a stolen car.
The D.N.C. had found itself in the middle of labor disputes between television writers and CBS.
Telling Burger King to pay an extra penny for tomatoes and provide a decent wage to migrant workers would hardly bankrupt the company.
The SanDisk Sansa View claims 35 hours of audio and 7 hours of video playback on a single charge.

The Nokia N82 smartphone has 2 gigabytes of storage space for photos and can display pictures and video on a television using an optional TV-out dock.

India promises to protect threatened writer, an “Early Show” exit, back in ascendance and more culture news.
Evel Knievel said that he and Kanye West had settled a lawsuit concerning Mr. West’s use of the motorcycle daredevil’s image.

C3 Presents, the producers of Lollapalooza in Chicago, and Festival Republic (formerly Mean Fiddler), the producer of the enormous Reading and Glastonbury festivals in England, have announced a new event: The Vineland Music Festival.
The Metropolitan Opera and In Demand Networks have signed an agreement to offer the eight operas from the Met’s second season of “Metropolitan Opera: Live in High Definition.”
Hannah Storm, the former NBC sportscaster who has been a co-anchor of “The Early Show” on CBS since 2002, is being reassigned.
Almost 25 million viewers tuned in for final results of ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” on Tuesday, according to Nielsen’s estimates.
Last week the classical crossover star Josh Groban performed on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” and, predictably, sales of his latest CD, “Noël” (Reprise), jumped.
Eighteen months after being fired for threatening a radio rival, D.J. Star, is returning to the airwaves.
Doris Lessing, 87, will be unable to travel to Stockholm to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature on Dec. 10 because of back problems.
India has pledged to protect a Bangladeshi writer who is in hiding after receiving threats from Islamic groups.
For those in need of book recommendations, the National Book Critics Circle has created a monthly Best Recommended List.
In the isolated farmland counties of eastern Nebraska, polka helps tie people together.
It took 90 years, but Gluck’s “Iphigénie en Tauride” has finally returned to the Metropolitan Opera.
Obesity rates in American women have stayed steady since 1999, and there are hints that obesity rates may be leveling off for men, too.
The ThinkStation D10 from Lenovo is a PC that is primarily intended for game designers, videographers and other high-end users.
Widgets will not turn your vintage Motorola StarTAC into an iPhone, but they will add features and functions that you didn’t think were capable on your phone.
The VholdR camcorder from Twenty20 lets you skip the hand-holding by clipping it right onto handlebars, helmets or goggles to record action video as you see it.
Michael Thalheimer’s concept and direction reveal why Frank Wedekind’s 19th-century works can leap so fluidly to the present.
Making a green decorative statement on a grand scale is a challenge.
Palestinian Authority security forces opened fire in Hebron to disperse a funeral procession that had turned into a pro-Islamic rally, marking a second day of violence in this West Bank city.

Parents of young children often squeeze in a workout by joining a gym with childcare. But as The Times reports today, many parents don’t like leaving a toddler in a room where the main attraction is often a blaring television set or -- almost as bad, a simple puzzle.

Perhaps no winter sport is immune to the X-Games factor, the adrenaline-juiced force that can turn a sport into an amped-up version of itelf. The latest sport to get a jolt is sledding, thanks to a new breed of equipment that allows downhill riders to jump, spin, flip and glide on the snow.

Extreme winter sports became part of Wayne Johnson’s life during childhood, when he realized that mainstream pursuits wouldn’t satisfy him. “Just skiing, unless it is racing, isn’t enough anymore,” he writes in his new book, “White Heat: The Extreme Skiing Life” (Atria Books, $26). So for more than 40 years, Johnson, now 51, pursued breakneck speeds and daring jumps on skis, and now satisfies his appetite by volunteering as a rescue worker at Park City, Utah. Along the way, he built a stable of friends who pursue extreme skiing or any other thrillingquest they can find.
Danny Ainge has the Celtics headed in one direction whereas the Knicks’ Isiah Thomas is moving in the opposite direction.

Johan Santana, the star pitcher of the Minnesota Twins, is at the center of trade talks between the New York Yankees and the Twins. He won’t come cheaply. The Yankees would likely have to give up multiple top prospects and sign Santana to a long-term contract. How far should the Yankees, or any other team, go to get Santana?.
Beneath the festive trappings of Michael Feinstein’s annual holiday extravaganza (this year’s edition is titled “Winter Dreams”) is one of his most personal shows.
President Vladimir V. Putin has transformed Sunday’s election into a vote of confidence on his leadership and on the nation’s economic recovery
The winners of the Victor Mitchell Open Board-a-Match Teams at the Fall North American Championships were Aubrey Strul, Michael Becker, David Berkowitz, Larry Cohen, Chip Martel and Lew Stansby.
The Hammond B-3 organist Sam Yahel began his second set at the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night with a row of intervals arranged to avoid any hint of resolution.

Ballet Hispanico’s “Palladium Nights” has many more musicians onstage than dancers.

How can I freshen up my sofa without reupholstering it or resorting to slipcovers?
Fueled by an oil boom, the Russian capital seems as awash in cash as Dallas was in its heyday and all the millionaires have to shop somewhere.
A decade ago, only a handful of women could claim the kind of style clout that comes with a presence in the D.J. booth-that has since changed.
The brokerage firm Terra Securities said it would file for bankruptcy protection because of accusations it made four remote towns victims of subprime problems in the United States.
A British teacher faces 6 months in jail and 40 lashes after letting her students name a teddy bear Muhammad.
A young man gives a year over to the job hunt, sampling one at a time.
For some business partners, help for a struggling relationship can come from a variation on the couples counselor: the business therapist.

FLOM--Claire. Fordham Law School records with profound sorrow the passing of Claire Flom, with her husband Joseph H. Flom, a devoted friend of the Law School. Her sage counsel, wit, and wonderful spirit were of invaluable assistance to Fordham University, which she served as a Trustee, and to the Law School, where she was a founding member and guiding force of the Advisory Board of the Feerick Center for Social Justice. She will be greatly missed, and we extend our deepest sympathy to her family. William Michael Treanor, Dean FLOM--Claire. The Directors, Staff and 70,000 youngsters associated with the Police Athletic League express their profound sorrow on the death of one of their good friends, Claire Flom. We extend our deepest sympathy to her entire family including her husband Joe and daughter Nancy Laing. Robert M. Morgenthau, PAL Chairman FLOM--Claire. In loving memory of our dear friend, Claire Flom. We mourn her loss and send our affection to Joe, Nancy, Peter and Jason. Lino, Amelia and Sara Caiola FLOM--Claire. Dear Claire, 10 years ago you wanted to provide stimulation and diversion for a cancer-ridden friend. You then handpicked women for a book group. There are now fifteen of us meeting monthly to talk about books we chose together. The discussions were wonderful, and you, Claire, so witty and perceptive, never grabbed the spotlight and made us all feel special. We are privileged to have had you in our lives as we bid a loving farewell. Your Book Group
REBITSKY--Eric, 47, died on November 26, 2007. Graveside service Friday, November 30, 2007, 11am at New Montefiore Cemetery.

GABER--George, died on November 21, 2007, at 91 in Bloomington, IN. His remarkable career as a timpanist, percussionist and teacher will resonate forever. ''When I play, I try to play like him. When I teach, I say what he said to me.'' -Luther Rix ''I'm going to miss my favorite pen pal. Each of George's typewritten missives was ripe with his boundless knowledge, wisdom and humor. I will cherish these always. Thanks GG.'' -Gordon Gottlieb ''I watched my dearest friend, Mr. Timpani receive group adulation from New York's top percussionists. George is my life.'' -Howard Hirsch ''GG taught his students well. Professionalism, musicality, compassion and laughter: his calling, ethos and way of life.'' -Peter Erskine.

McDONOUGH--Robert Emmett, 85, of Capistrano Beach, CA, passed away on November 21, 2007, surrounded by loving family. Born in Chicago, IL, he is survived by his beloved wife, Simone; children, Susan and Emmett; sister, Kathleen Ecklund; five grandchildren, Meaghan, Jenna, David, Stephen and John; and two great-grandchildren, Jackson and RyanCarlson. He was preceded in death by his first wife of 47 years, Elsa. Bob served in the Merchant Marines during World War II and earned his BA in 1949 at Georgetown University, School of Foreign Service. The founder of Remedy Temporary Services, in 1998, Bob made the largest gift of its kind to Georgetown University and the McDonough School of Business. Bob served on the Board of Directors of Georgetown University for a decade and was a Hoya through and through. Bob also served for many years on the Board of Directors of the Historic Mission Preservation Society in San Juan Capistrano and was a strong supporter of educational causes, including the San Juan Capistrano Mission School and the America Ireland Fund. A lifelong Democrat, Bob was active in local and national politics, making his last contributions to candidates in September. A vigil will be held on Thursday, November 29, 2007 at 6:30pm at the Mission Basilica San Juan Capistrano, 31522 Camino Capistrano, San Juan Capistrano, CA 92675. Funeral services will be held on Friday, November 30, at 10:30am at the Mission Basilica. A reception will follow. O'Connor Mortuary, Directors. (949) 581-4300.

FRIED--Ben, 82, of Sunny Isles Beach, FL. Died November 25, 2007. Survived by wife Tamara Fried, daughters Eda Sorokoff and Barica Fried. Grandchildren Caroline Stearn, Laura Gelman and Peter Sorokoff and five great-granchildren. Graveside service 11:30, November 29, 2007 at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

KAUSMAN--William E. Died peacefully November 27th, beloved husband of Edna and Eleanor (deceased). Adored father of Douglas, Jill, and Kenneth; Special step-father to Deborah, Richard, Laura and Robert; Awesome grandpa to 12. Brother, Robert of Scarsdale also survives. Bill graduated from Horace Mann in 1943 and Columbia College in 1949. He enlisted in the Navy at age 17 and served his country well during World War II. He was a fabulous athlete, a man of great courage and integrity. A celebration of his life will be at Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, Saturday, December 1st at 1:00pm. He will be very much missed and remembered by those who loved him dearly. Contributions in Bill's memory to American Cancer Society or American Heart Association.

Martha Stewart is introducing her first line of fine china this month, the Martha Stewart Collection With Wedgwood. Many of the patterns, some of them shown below, were inspired by pieces in her personal collection. How big is Martha Stewart's collection of china, you wonder? Because of an editing error, a caption in Science Times on Tuesday with photos for a profile of Ralph Holloway, an anthropologist who studies brain evolution, reversed the position of two brain endocasts, or latex molds. The endocast of the chimpanzee brain was on the left; an endocast of the so-called Taung child, a fossilized human ancestor, was on the right.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28 -- Hollywood producers and striking screenwriters agreed to extend their renewed contract talks to a fourth day on Thursday, signaling at least some progress toward ending a work stoppage that began three and a half weeks ago. In negotiating sessions over the last three days, the sides managed to clarify positions and make small steps toward each other, according to people who were connected with the talks who spoke on condition of anonymity because of the official press blackout.

BELLER--Jeanne, 95, a resident of Boca Raton, Florida, passed away peacefully on November 21, 2007. Loving wife of Charles W. Beller. She is survived by her son, Gary, of New York City, and his wife Carole, a son, Dr. Leonard Beller of Los Angeles, CA, and his wife Sheila, and a daughter, Enid Zimbler, of Cambridge, MA, and her husband Dr. Seymour Zimbler. She leaves six grandchildren, Brian, Andrew, Marla, Mark, Lani, and Jessie, and 11 great-grandchildren. She was a loving mother whose family and their accomplishments were very important to her. She will be sadly missed, and always remembered. Services will be private; and in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hadassah of Boca Raton, Florida.

David Stark made the topiaries and chandeliers, below, for the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum's recent awards party from 6,000 pounds of shredded paper harvested from his and the museum's offices, as well as 12 years' worth of his own tax returns. He hired American Security Shredding (800-882-1979; americanshredding1.com) to shred the paper, and then take it away and recycle it after the event. Onsite shredding of about 500 pounds of paper is $99; offsite shredding costs $59.

Simon Doonan, creative director of Barneys New York, used bottles, cans and bottle tops like mosaic tiles, below, in his 12 Green Days of Christmas windows at the Madison Avenue flagship store. Where did he get them all? ''We scrounged the cans from hither and thither -- we even bought some from homeless dudes on the Bowery,'' Mr. Doonan said. ''What will happen to them afterward? Good question. We will definitely recycle them. Maybe we will take them back to our pals on the Bowery.''

Herb McKenley, the world's fastest 400-meter runner more than half a century ago and later the driving force in Jamaica's climb to track and field prominence, died Monday in Kingston, Jamaica, where he lived. He was 85. The cause was complications of pneumonia, his wife, Beverley, said. She said his health had been unsteady since he had triple-bypass surgery in 1998.

10 P.M. (Sundance) ICONOCLASTS Madeleine K. Albright, the former secretary of state, and Ashley Judd, the actress, meet in Washington to discuss their devotion to international causes and to do a little work. Ms. Albright invites Ms. Judd to the National Democratic Institute, of which Ms. Albright (above left with Ms. Judd) is chairwoman, for a teleconference with AIDS workers based in Africa. Ms. Judd, in turn, takes Ms. Albright to the headquarters of Population Services International, for which Ms. Judd serves as global ambassador, to discuss its mission to combat malaria and infant mortality in developing countries. And then they tour the National Museum of Women in the Arts, where they chat about the feminist movement. 8 P.M. (TCM) INHERIT THE WIND (1960) Mark Mothersbaugh, a composer and artist and the lead singer of Devo, was the guest programmer for Turner Classic Movies tonight. First up: Stanley Kramer's ''Inherit the Wind,'' the blustery drama starring Spencer Tracy and Fredric March as lawyers on opposing sides of the 1925 Scopes case, the ''monkey trial.'' In ''A Face in the Crowd'' (1957), at 10:15, Andy Griffith plays Lonesome Rhodes, an Ozark guitar picker with Machiavellian tendencies who is discovered in jail by a talent coordinator (Patricia Neal) and her assistant (Walter Matthau). At 12:30 a.m., in ''Juliet of the Spirits'' (1965), Federico Fellini enters the troubled psyche of a daydreaming housewife (Giulietta Masina) in his first color film. And at 3, a family is terrorized by thrill-seeking hoodlums in the 1967 cult classic ''Hot Rods to Hell.''

An art review in Weekend on Friday about the Detroit Institute of Arts, which has been reorganized and has expanded its gallery space, misidentified the country of birth for Nii O. Quarcoopome, the curator who oversees the reinstalled African galleries. It is Ghana, not Nigeria. A picture caption with the review misidentified the region of Africa where a nail-figure sculpture was made. It was Central Africa, not West Africa.

The Economic Scene column in Business Day yesterday, about the slowing rate of job creation in the United States, referred imprecisely to the work by Honeywell, whose work force history was used as an example, on the Louisiana Superdome in New Orleans. The company made a material that helps insulate the roof; it did not make the roof itself.

A report in the Inside Art column in Weekend on Nov. 16 about the 2008 Whitney Biennial, using information provided by the Whitney Museum of American Art, misstated the dates of Biennial events at an adjunct site, the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 67th Street in Manhattan. The events are to run from March 6 to 23, not March 4 to 22.

MERCER--Norman J., of Manhattan and East Hampton, who was an international business man and renowned sculptor, died in his East Hampton home on Tuesday, November 20th, from cancer at the age of 91. He was born on July 17, 1916 in New York City. Mr. Mercer's artistic calling appeared after his retirement at the age of 62. He is known for his cast acrylic sculptures of color and geometric shapes using the reflection and refraction of light. He is survived by Carol, his loving wife of 37 years, and his beloved children David Mercer (CA) and Howard Mercer (OR) and Mari Stadler (NY). Mr. Mercer also leaves three grandchildren: Helen Walsh, Valerie Stadler, and Steven Mercer; and five great - grandchildren: Clair, Julia, Meghan, Niaema and Joshua. A memorial celebration of his life will be held on December 16th, at 2pm at Guild Hall in East Hampton.

The Books of The Times review yesterday, about two books on the Constitution, misstated the title of one. As shown in the bibliographical capsule with the review, it is ''A More Perfect Constitution,'' by Larry J. Sabato, not ''A More Perfect Union.''

GREENLEAF - JAYNES-Madeline. 1943 to 2002. Our radical Quaker librarian friend missed so much: a war of aggression, the death of the news, the legitimization of torture, the shredding of the Constitution and the loss of rights guaranteed since Magna Carta. How outraged you'd be. We miss you, mad. If you're reading this call me.

Developers in the Miami area used Modernist styles to attract tourists and home buyers in the mid-20th century. ''The hotels were swank, escapist, over-the-top fantasies, and other building types had clean Bauhaus-inspired lines or tropical features like courtyards and louvered mahogany doors,'' said Ruth Grim, acting chief curator at the Bass Museum of Art in Miami Beach, where ''Promises of Paradise: Staging Midcentury Miami'' opens on Wednesday. It includes photos, furniture and accessories (like a 1947 lamp, above left, by George Farkas) and brochures for attractions like the 1956 Americana hotel in Bal Harbour, right. Ms. Grim said she hoped the show would draw attention to the region's endangered Modernist buildings: on Nov. 18, the Americana was felled to make way for condos. Through April 13; (305) 673-7530 or bassmuseum.org. EVE M. KAHN

SAYRES--Michael, a brilliant, charming and honorable man. Loving husband to Avivah, adored father of Julie and Amy, cherished grandpa of Noah, beloved brother of Joe and Teddy, dear brotherin-law of Mickey, caring uncle to Laurie and Mindy. NEUMAN--Stephen H. Loving husband of Glee, beloved father of Brad, and dear brother of Kenneth, Priscilla, Rodger, and the late Bruce. His life was characterized by an absolute appreciation of all things and a fiercely independent spirit. We will miss him terribly and try to honor his memory by looking for the goodness he saw in everything and being utterly content with all that life does or does not bestow upon us. To see sun in cloudy skies and be warm and frigid winds is to see things through his eyeshis outlook, his philosophy, our cherished memories. Services Friday 11:30am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

A report in the Metro Briefing column in some editions on Monday about an accident in which a woman was struck by a charter bus while crossing a street in Manhattan misstated the direction in which the bus was traveling. It was moving northbound on Bowery, not southbound, before turning left on Broome Street.

Growing up in South Korea, the artist Do Ho Suh, 45, lived in a traditional ''scholar's house'' built by an elderly carpenter who had worked for the Korean royal family. It was a copy of a house called Yeon Kyung Dang, built in 1828 by King Sunjo, Mr. Suh said, ''because the king wanted to experience what it would be like to live a civilian life.'' ''It was, ironically, considered the most beautiful civilian style from the period,'' he said.

Chairman of Fullcut Manufacturers, member of the International Board of Governors, Weizmann Institute of Science, board member Tel Aviv Foundation, and Emeritus board member, Carnival Cruise Lines. The family of Maks Birnbach will be receiving visitors Wednesday, November 28 and Thursday, November 29, 2:30-5 pm and 6:30-9 pm, Friday, November 30, 2:30-5:00 pm and Sunday December 2nd, 2:30-5:00 pm at his home in New York. Our hearts go out to Naomi, his wife of almost 53 years, their three children, Jonathan and his wife Joan, Lisa, and Norman and his wife Deborah, and his brother Otto, who lives in Israel. May you be comforted by the many loving memories and by the good times we shared with each other. His good name lives on. BIRNBACH--Maks. The Officers, Trustees and Staff of Jewish Child Care Association express their deep sympathy at the passing of Maks, the husband of Naomi Birnbach, a longtime, dedicated trustee. We send our heartfelt condolences to the Birnbach family. The JCCA Board of Trustees BIRNBACH--Maks L. He personified the word: charm. He said the right thing always, whether in person or behind a microphone. He was adored by those he worked with and those who worked for him. His resilience and renewed spirit following so many serious illnesses were an inspiration. He was always there for me. He was humorous in three languages. I am so proud of him. Naomi

SOCCER players have a rapt devotion to their footwear. So as the game moves indoors during short winter days, players have stowed their cleats and are lacing up a new generation of indoor soccer shoes that resemble the timeless sneaker. They come in a rainbow of colors and styles, with lighter construction and nifty additions like asymmetrical laces and instep designs that manufacturers claim enhance the swerve of the ball.

The Museum of Arts & Design is moving, so for a recent party David Stark decorated with packing materials that the museum could later use. Mr. Stark made a wall of boxes that looked ready to tumble, and centerpieces of twine and wire flowers. Mr. Stark recommends Materials for the Arts (718-729-3001; mfta.org), a Brooklyn-based organization that will take castoffs, from filing cabinets to dressmaker's dummies, and donate them to nonprofit groups that need materials.

An article in some editions on Tuesday about closed-courtroom testimony from a witness to the 1990 killing of a nightclub bouncer in Manhattan gave an erroneous spelling in some copies for the given name of a law professor who commented on the judge's decision to seal the courtroom. He is Stephen Gillers, not Steven.

NOLTE--Richard H., November 22, 2007. The American Geographical Society notes with sorrow the death of Hon. Richard H. Nolte, a member of its governing Council since 1969, Chairman from 1988, and Chairman Emeritus since 1996. His invaluable leadership during a critical time of transition led to the rescue and transfer of the AGS library to the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, the sale of the society's building at Audubon Terrace, AGS's movement to midtown, and the vigorous launching of new programs. A Rhodes Scholar; authority on Islamic law, Arabic and Arab history; U.S. Ambassador to Egypt (1967); Executive Director of the Institute for Current World Affairs; President of the Near East Foundation; and Executive Director of the Alicia Patterson Foundation, he brought intellectual depth and astounding energy to those roles and many others. He joked about his approaching demise with his customary wit and good humor. We will miss him deeply. John E. Gould, Chairman Jerome E. Dobson, President Mary Lynne Bird, Executive Director

Q. I get a white screen and no picture when I try to play an .AVI movie with the QuickTime Player on my Mac. What kind of software do I need? A. If you see a white or gray screen when trying to play a movie file with QuickTime Player software from Apple, it's usually because QuickTime doesn't have the software component it needs to display the video. Different digital video formats have differing codec (compressor/decompressor) software. Since .AVI is a container format that can use several video codecs, you need to add the right one to QuickTime to see the video.

Monkeybiz, a nonprofit group in Cape Town, South Africa, supports women's health care by distributing beaded animals made by more than 450 women in communities outside the city. The organization gives supplies and training to the women, who work at home and sell the finished pieces back to Monkeybiz. The one-of-a-kind animals are then sold at stores like Carrol Boyes, 118 Prince Street (Greene Street), (212) 334-3556, for $78 to $312, and ABC Carpet & Home, 888 Broadway (19th Street), (212) 473-3000, for $30 to $200. WOLFE--Ralph J. The East End Hospice Board of Directors, staff, and volunteers mourn the loss of Ralph J. Wolfe, member of the Board of Directors, Hospice patron, and treasured friend. In addition to his many contributions as a board member and volunteer, Ralph was the driving force behind our speaker's bureau and was devoted to our Children's Bereavement Program, Camp Good Grief. Ralph's spirit and dedication to our cause was unmatched. We are grateful to have had the benefit of many years of his good counsel. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Sherry, his children, family, and his many friends. We shall miss him greatly. Priscilla Ruffin, CEO Michael Pitcher, Chairman Board of Directors East End Hospice Westhampton Beach, NY

An interior design and decoration sale to benefit the Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club will be held today and tomorrow from noon to 7 p.m. Furniture, china, silver and carpets donated by designers and friends of the club will be displayed in vignettes by designers like Larry Laslo, Albert Hadley and Amy Lau, whose display is above. Welcome back to the Reading Room. Last month, an all-star group of commentators made their way through Tolstoy's "War and Peace." This month, another distinguished crew (see their bios on the right) will spend two weeks tackling "The Education of Henry Adams," an American classic published 100 years ago this year. Well, sort of: The memoir, which covers the years from Adams's birth in 1838 to the death of Adams's great friend the statesman John Hay in 1905, was printed in a luxurious private edition in 1907 and circulated to 100 or so friends - including then-president Theodore Roosevelt - who were invited to return it with comments and corrections in the extra-wide margins. (Only three complied.) The book was republished for a general audience in 1918, the year of Adams's death. An unsigned review in the New York Times Book Review called it "a book every American should read." It won the Pulitzer Prize.

I first met David Downton maybe five years ago at a showing of his drawings in Paris. His subject was Erin O'Connor. You might say David, who is English, has an obsession with Erin's long neck and lines. Well, she was meant for charcoal. Shortly after that meeting, I asked him to sketch a Dior couture dress in the studio, for a story about the making of a collection. Our link then and now was our admiration for the work of Joe Eula, and a fascination with the man. I got to know Joe well and in the last years of his life we worked together on a number of illustrated articles for the Times, including one about the denizens of the back track at Belmont. This past January, at the Dior show, David told me he was planning to bring out a magazine of fashion illustration and asked if I'd write something about Joe. Issue #1 of Pourquoi Pas? has drawings by Rene Gruau, Eula, Richard Gray, Jason Brooks, with illustrations by David of Amanda Harlech, Jade Parfitt, and Carmen Dell' Orefice. Among the writers contributing are Sarah Mower, Tony Glenville and Tim Blanks. The 72-page magazine is on heavy stock, costs about $40, and is available at pqpmagazine.com. David and I chatted by phone a few days ago.

Tim Burton was jittery when the Baguette interviewed him recently but who could blame him? He's got both a movie -- "Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street," and a baby -- with Helena Bonham Carter -- making an appearance in the world about the same time. "I'm a bit nervous about both I guess," Mr. Burton said.Ms. Carter co-stars in "Sweeney" as Mrs. Lovett, and Sacha Baron Cohen plays looney rival barber Signor Adolfo Pirelli. The Baguette asked Mr. Burton about casting non-singers in the title roles of the film."It gives the film, I think an extra layer of something that you don't necessarily get from the stage," which led the Baguette to ask about the casting of Mr. Cohen, who inhabited a similarly over-the-top persona as Borat."Sacha, he's great! I'll never forget it, he came in to audition and he had the book for 'Fiddler on the Roof' and basically did pretty much the whole song book," Mr. Burton said. "I knew he could do it. He has no fear."Mr. Burton's most palpable fears involved Stephen Sondheim's reaction to his film. "I was so nervous. I think I was more nervous showing it to him than anybody."Before they showed the movie to Mr. Sondheim he told the producers, "You show him the movie. I'll be down at the pub down the street." Mr. Burton said he was relieved that Mr. Sondheim liked the film. "He was extremely positive."As the Bagger mentioned, the movie has a rather crimson palette."We tried to use a bright color red, you know, because it's Christmas."
