After a strong opening that sent the Dow up more than 150 points, shares gave up their gains amid weaker-than-expected data on personal income and spending.
Mr. Beard propelled the University of Kentucky to two consecutive N.C.A.A. basketball championships before his career was shattered by involvement in a widespread collegiate point-shaving scandal.
Terrell Owens, Tony Romo and the Cowboys stamped their claim to N.F.C. supremacy after Green Bay lost Brett Favre, who injured his right arm in the second quarter.
In a setback for journalistic freedom in Mexico, the judges ruled 6 to 4 against the journalist, Lydia Cacho, despite claims that public officials conspired to harass her.
The Warner Music Group said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit slipped 58 percent amid a softer international market and a decline in compact disc sales.

The H. J. Heinz Company posted an 18 percent increase in quarterly profit yesterday as the weak dollar improved results in Europe and in emerging markets, and price increases helped offset rising ingredient costs.
Abbott Laboratories moved closer to joining the American market for drug-coated heart stents on Thursday as an advisory panel backed the company’s experimental device.
Millbrook Capital, the activist hedge fund seeking a breakup or sale of the Brink’s Company, is expected to announce its four nominees for directors of the security company.
A California appeals court has ruled that enforcement of federal drug laws did not supersede the state’s allowance of marijuana for medicinal purposes.

Programs designed to reduce performance-enhancing drug use among teenage athletes are effective in the short term, but their impact over longer periods of time is unclear, a report by the Government Accountability Office concluded. The report included evaluations of two programs that have received federal funding: ATLAS, which targets male athletes, and Athena , for female athletes. The study did not measure the impact beyond a year’s time.
Barack Obama’s fund-raiser was his first in the historic seat of black cultural and political power since he announced his presidential candidacy.
The Rangers (14-9-2) used the victory to grab a piece of the Atlantic Division lead with Philadelphia with 30 points.

The On Education column on Nov. 28, about private firms that use branding techniques to coach high school students who apply to college, misstated the educational credentials of Chioma Isiadinso, founder of a small New York coaching firm, Expartus. She has a master’s in education from the University of Pittsburgh, not an M.B.A. from Harvard.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Nov. 20 about performances by the singer and songwriter Natalie Merchant at Club Hiro in New York starting on Jan. 4 misstated her recent performing history. The Club Hiro dates will be her first full concerts in four years, not her first live appearances in four years.

picture caption with an article yesterday about high-technology toys misidentified one item shown. It was the ClickStart, My First Computer, by LeapFrog, not the Easy Link Internet Launch Pad by Fisher-Price.

An article in Business Day last Friday about a deal between Gazprom, the Russian energy giant, and Eni, the Italian energy group, referred imprecisely to its scope. It was a contract to conduct a feasibility study on a pipeline linking Russia to Europe via the Black Sea; it was not a contract to build the pipeline. (A memorandum of agreement between Gazprom and Eni signed in June detailed the companies’ plans to design, finance and manage the construction of the pipeline.).

A picture caption with an article yesterday about the Bush administration’s effort to provide impetus for peace efforts on the day after Israeli and Palestinian leaders committed themselves to negotiating a peace treaty reversed the position of the leaders shown walking with President Bush. Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel was on the left and Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, was on the right.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Wednesday about Ryan Lochte, an elite American swimmer, misstated the distance of a long-course race in which he has posted three of the 10 fastest times. It is the 200-meter individual medley, not the 400. As the article noted, Lochte also swims in the short-course 200-yard individual medley. (Long-course events take place in a 50-meter pool, and short-course races are in a 25-yard pool.).

A sports article yesterday about John Tavares, a promising 17-year-old hockey player for the Oshawa Generals in Ontario, misspelled the surname of the former National Hockey League defenseman who coaches the team. He is Brad Selwood, not Sellwood.

A picture caption with the Shifting Careers column in Business Day yesterday reversed the identifications of two of the three men shown. Richard Jepsen, a partner in OSCS Sailing School in San Francisco, was in the middle, not Larry Ledgerwood, a consultant, who was at the left.

The Advertising column on Wednesday, about efforts by the Advertising Council to devote more attention to online media, included a foundation erroneously in a coming campaign to discourage violence among teenagers. The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation is not involved in the campaign.

A headline and picture caption with an article in some editions on Wednesday about a search for a new operator of the heliport in downtown New York misidentified the agency that is conducting the search. It is the city’s Economic Development Corporation, not the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. (The Port Authority, the current operator, did not renew its lease.).

Because of an editing error, a front-page article in some editions yesterday about the Republican presidential debate misstated the response of former Senator Fred D. Thompson in a passage about high points for many candidates. During the debate, he offered a spirited defense of gun rights, not gun control.

A picture caption with an article yesterday about the Bush administration’s effort to provide impetus for peace efforts on the day after Israeli and Palestinian leaders committed themselves to negotiating a peace treaty reversed the position of the leaders shown walking with President Bush. Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel was on the left and Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, was on the right.

An article on Nov. 21 about a RAND Corporation study on street stops by the New York Police Department referred incorrectly at some points to an overall figure and misstated the number of individual officers who were found to be disproportionately more likely to stop whites. There were 508,540 street stops in 2006 — not 508,540 people stopped — and 13 officers, not 9, tended to stop whites more often. The article also misstated the finding of a racial disparity in the handing out of summonses. Whites are more likely — not less — to receive them.
The N.H.L.’s Board of Governors approved the sale of the Nashville Predators and changed the scheduling format so every team can face one another at least once every season.
Maya Moore scored 17 points to become the first Connecticut player ever to reach double figures in each of her first six starts, s the second-ranked Huskies routed Brigham Young, 80-34.

A judge should consider removing the defense lawyer representing Bernard B. Kerik, the city’s former police commissioner, because the lawyer might be called as a witness, federal prosecutors said yesterday in a request they sent to a court.
The European Parliament overwhelmingly backed a set of stricter gun-control rules that would limit gun ownership across the 27-member European Union.
The Supreme Court ruled that Gov. Mario Marin of Puebla State did not violate the rights of a journalist, Lydia Cacho, when he had her briefly jailed on slander charges that were later dropped.

The Foreign Ministry said China withdrew permission for the United States aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk to visit Hong Kong last week because of the Bush administration’s proposal to sell antimissile upgrades to Taiwan, and not as a result of a “misunderstanding,” as the White House characterized it earlier.
A Moscow court convicted the Russian oligarch Boris Berezovsky in absentia of embezzling millions of dollars from the national airline, Aeroflot.

Pope Benedict XVI has thanked 138 Muslim scholars for an October letter to Christian leaders in which they urged better relations between the faiths and he has invited them for meetings in Vatican City, the Vatican said.

David Beckham and the Los Angeles Galaxy practiced in front of more than 15,000 fans at Westpac Stadium in Wellington, New Zealand, today. The 35,000-seat stadium is the site for tomorrow’s exhibition match between the Galaxy and Wellington Phoenix. It is also the Wellington home of the All Blacks rugby team. The All Blacks might draw a few thousand to a training session before a major match. To draw 15,000 to a soccer practice, in a country in which soccer is a minor sport, was unprecedented.

A Scottish council rejected a plan by Donald Trump to build a golf course on a stretch of remote coastline that is home to some of the country’s rarest birds. After a debate lasting two and a half hours, Aberdeenshire Council’s Infrastructure Committee rejected plans for the Trump International Golf Links after a tie-breaking vote. A spokesman for Trump said he was looking at alternative sites in other European countries.

Mike Piazza hit one 290 yards — straight into the cup. Piazza, a free-agent catcher, made a hole-in-one on the par-4 opening hole of The Fairmont Turnberry Isle Resort & Club Soffer Course in Aventura, Fla., on Nov. 19. The drive was right on line, landing in the cup for a double-eagle.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey will propose to give money to poor children outside inner-city school districts.

A jury awarded $5 million yesterday to a former Alabama football booster who claimed the N.C.A.A. defamed him when it imposed penalties on the Crimson Tide in 2002. The state court jury awarded the booster, Ray Keller, $3 million in punitive damages, $1 million for mental anguish, $500,000 for economic loss and $500,000 for damage to reputation.Keller, a timber dealer and fan whom the university severed ties with because of the investigation of the program, argued that the N.C.A.A. slandered and libeled him during the announcement of penalties by referring to him and others as “rogue boosters,” “parasites” and “pariahs.”Keller, who denied he did anything wrong, maintained that he was wrongly lumped in with other boosters who were accused of making improper contacts and payments to recruits in the 1990s.The N.C.A.A. did not use the name of Keller or other boosters in announcing penalties against Alabama, but their names appeared in news accounts and the university sent Keller a letter barring him from its athletics program.

Frank Lickliter II shot his second consecutive 10-under 62 at Orange County National to take a nine-stroke lead after the second of six rounds in the PGA Tour National Qualifying Tournament in Winter Garden, Fla. The top 25 finishers and ties will earn 2008 PGA Tour cards, and the next number of players nearest 50 will receive full Nationwide Tour exemptions. The remaining players in the 166-man field will have conditional Nationwide Tour status.
President Bush said the American people do not want the government to create needless uncertainty for troops in Iraq and urged lawmakers to pass the bill.
Morgan Stanley said Zoe Cruz, a co-president who oversaw all the firm’s trading and risk operations, would retire, effective immediately.
The Knicks and the Boston Celtics were once great rivals. But today’s Knicks are 4-9, and in no shape to stoke a new rivalry with a new Celtics powerhouse.
Injuries have placed a larger burden on Chris Baker, the sixth-year tight end, for Sunday’s game in Miami between the Jets (2-9) and the Dolphins (0-11).
The house of the prominent Sunni, Adnan al-Dulaimi, a leader of the Iraqi Consensus Front, is in Adel, an affluent Sunni-majority neighborhood in Baghdad.
The Giants have not scored more than 20 points in any of their last four games, a trend that may be tied to Plaxico Burress’s declining production.
Kansas City Chiefs lineman Kyle Turley has risked the ire of the N.F.L. players union to raise awareness for retired N.F.L. players who have been financially and physically devastated by injuries.
Art Carmody kicked a 33-yard field goal with 20 seconds remaining to lift the Cardinals over the Scarlet Knights on Thursday.

An F.B.I. official from Philadelphia has been chosen as the next police superintendent in Chicago. Mayor Richard M. Daley has picked J. P. Weis to succeed Police Superintendent Philip J. Cline. Mr. Weis, left, is currently special agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s Philadelphia field office. Mr. Cline resigned in April amid controversy surrounding accusations of misconduct by Chicago officers. Mr. Weis’s nomination requires approval by the City Council.

The Santa Monica City Council has challenged the Federal Aviation Administration by voting unanimously to ban the fastest jets now flying into the city’s single-runway airport. The new challenge comes in response to concerns among residents and local officials about the potential for aircraft to overrun Santa Monica’s runway. Homes sit as close as 250 feet to landing and departing aircraft. The F.A.A., which signed an agreement with the city in 1984 to prevent Santa Monica from regulating jet traffic, has vowed to fight the ordinance.

A body found about 50 miles east of El Dorado appears to be that of a missing college student who led a secret life as an Internet sex star, the police said. The authorities said the preliminary physical description of the body found matches that of the student, Emily Sander, 18, above. Investigators refused to give details about the state of the body or how it was found. Police Chief Tom Boren of El Dorado said the cause of death was not yet known.

A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit filed against the government by two North Dakota farmers seeking to grow industrial hemp, which can be used to make a variety of products from rope to lotion. The judge, Daniel L. Hovland of United States District Court in Bismarck, said in his ruling on Wednesday that the best remedy might be to change the definition of industrial hemp under the Federal Controlled Substances Act, which does not distinguish the plant from the illegal drug marijuana.

The authorities charged a married man with slipping his girlfriend an abortion drug that caused her to miscarry twice. The man, Manishkumar M. Patel, 34, of Appleton, was charged with seven felonies and two misdemeanors, including attempted first-degree murder of an unborn child, stalking, burglary and two counts of violating a restraining order. Mr. Patel and his girlfriend, Darshana Patel, a 39-year-old family physician, have a 3-year-old child together, the authorities said. They are not related, and he is married to someone else.

The Army’s top procurement official, Gen. Claude M. Bolton Jr., is resigning, Army officials said. General Bolton’s resignation comes one month after an independent panel criticized how the Army oversees $4 billion a year in contracts for food, water, shelter and other supplies to sustain American forces in Iraq, Kuwait and Afghanistan. General Bolton, a retired two-star Air Force general, plans to leave on Jan. 2, after exactly six years in his current job. He is scheduled to testify before a Senate subcommittee next week on the review panel’s conclusion that the Army failed to train enough experienced contracting officers to operate in combat zones.

State lawmakers, stepping into a vacuum left by the defeat of immigration legislation in Washington, have considered more than 1,560 bills related to immigration this year and enacted 244 of them in 46 states, according to a report by the National Conference of State Legislatures. The number of measures enacted nearly tripled from the 84 in 2006, creating a legal patchwork for immigrants across the country. A large number of measures determined whether states would give drivers’ and other licenses to illegal immigrants, and established penalties for employers hiring those immigrants.

More than 300 dogs and cats may have died this year as a result of eating contaminated pet food, a survey shows. Estimates had run from a few dozen to several thousand. The survey, by Michigan State University, was based on data collected from veterinarians, veterinary technicians and pathologists from April 5 to June 6. It showed the cause of death may have been related to melamine and cyanuric acid, two contaminants that turned deadly when pet food makers combined them. The contaminated pet food was imported from China and sold in North America. After pets began dying, companies recalled thousands of kinds of pet food and treats.

Rodney King, whose videotaped beating by Los Angeles police officers in 1991 led to riots after the officers involved were acquitted, suffered minor injuries after being hit by a shotgun blast, the authorities in California said. Mr. King, 42, summoned officers to his home in Rialto, about 60 miles east of Los Angeles, on Wednesday night to report he had been shot, said Sgt. Don Lewis of the Rialto Police Department. Sergeant Lewis said Mr. King told the police the shooting took place while he was riding his bicycle in neighboring San Bernardino.

A former personal assistant who sued an investment firm chief for sexual harassment has been arrested on charges of using the executive’s credit card to charge tens of thousands of dollars in personal expenses. The assistant, Fatima Monahan, 36, of North Arlington, N.J., is charged with grand larceny. She was accused of stealing more than $43,000 from Frederick Iseman, founder and managing partner of Caxton-Iseman Capital, a private equity investment firm. Ms. Monahan’s lawyer, Charles Ross, said “when the evidence is heard, it’ll be absolutely clear she did nothing wrong.” Mr. Iseman said yesterday that Ms. Monahan’s claims were “baseless and dishonest, and were fabricated to distract attention from her own outrageous behavior.” Ms. Monahan pleaded not guilty at her arraignment yesterday in State Supreme Court.

The Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, said yesterday that county officials would stop taking part in drills of the Indian Point nuclear plant’s evacuation plan until the plant’s owner takes them more seriously. In a letter to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, Mr. Spano criticized the owner, Entergy Nuclear, saying that employees were unprepared. A spokesman for Entergy said that one purpose of the drill was to train new employees in executing the plan. A spokesman for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said the commission would review Mr. Spano’s concerns.

A man accused of luring people he met on the Internet to engage in secretly videotaped sex, later used for blackmail, pleaded guilty yesterday in exchange for a sentence of up to eight years in prison. The man, Michael Largue, 46, of Franklin Square, pleaded guilty to grand larceny and conspiracy in Nassau County Court. His co-defendant, Shawn Payne, pleaded guilty in June and was expected to receive up to seven years in prison when she is sentenced next month.

New York City has replaced nearly all of the jobs lost since employment in the city peaked before the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, according to federal data released yesterday. The number of jobs in the city, adjusted for seasonal hiring trends, rose to 3.742 million in October, from 3.738 million in September, figures from the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics showed. That was the highest level of employment in the city since January 2001, when there were 3.748 million jobs. Employment in the city has risen steadily all year, outpacing the rate of job growth in the nation, the Labor Department said, but some economists expect that trend to be disrupted soon by various labor strikes and layoffs at big financial firms.

A Cortlandt Manor man was arrested yesterday in connection with a burning cross found in the front yard of a black family on the night of Nov. 21. The man, Christopher Hudak, 21, was charged with aggravated harassment, the police said. Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney, said the case would be prosecuted as a hate crime. The police said that Mr. Hudak’s sister had been involved in a school fight with a boy from the family hours before the burning cross was found.
New York has its share of strikes, but few can match the killjoy effect of shutting down Broadway, especially during the holiday season.

A 33-year-old man was arrested yesterday after he fired at police officers who were trying to arrest him after they saw him toss aside a different gun. The officers, none of whom were hurt, arrested the man without returning fire, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said. “It showed tremendous restraint on the part of the officers,” Mr. Kelly said. He said that a police sergeant and two officers saw the man, identified as Nnamdi Clarke, toss the gun shortly before 1 a.m. near 97th Place and 57th Avenue. They chased him, and Mr. Clarke, of Horace Harding Expressway, fired one shot before his weapon jammed, the police said. They said that Mr. Clarke had not yet been charged yesterday evening. The police commissioner said that the suspect had two guns, a .25-caliber automatic and a .32-caliber automatic, as well as several bags of marijuana.

Three fishermen died early yesterday when their boat capsized, the Coast Guard said. Coast Guard crews found the bodies of two of the fisherman, Mark Stroud, 45, and Danny Pavic, both of Galloway, shortly after 1 a.m. after their 25-foot boat was reported missing by a friend. A salvage crew found the body of a third man inside the cabin of the boat, about five miles offshore. He had not been positively identified yesterday evening, but the Coast Guard had previously said the third fisherman was Jerry Berwick of Philadelphia. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A man whose death sentence in the fatal shooting of five people at a Wendy’s restaurant in Flushing was set aside last month by the state’s highest court was resentenced yesterday to life in prison without parole, prosecutors said. The man, John B. Taylor, had been convicted of shooting seven employees at the restaurant on May 24, 2000, after forcing them to kneel at gunpoint inside a basement refrigerator. Prosecutors said Mr. Taylor shot the people to eliminate witnesses of a robbery; two survived. The Court of Appeals had vacated his death sentence in a divided opinion that found the state death penalty statute to be unconstitutional. Yesterday, Mr. Taylor was resentenced in State Supreme Court. His co-defendant, Craig Godineaux, had already been sentenced to life without parole. “Neither will ever again see the light of day,” Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said in a statement.
Seeking to stem a multibillion-dollar run on an investment pool for local governments, top Florida officials voted to suspend withdrawals from the fund.
In trying to remedy his team’s pitching situation Omar Minaya, the Mets’ general manager, said he would not part with shortstop José Reyes.
China agreed Thursday to terminate a dozen different subsidies and tax rebates that promote its own exports and discourage imports of steel, wood products, information technology and other goods.
The message for patients and their doctors is clear: restrict the use of CT scans to cases where they can truly aid in diagnosis and consider other options.
A prosecutor said the men took oaths to Al Qaeda in a ceremony caught on a hidden camera, and that they sought $50,000, weapons and other equipment to conduct their jihad.
The ever-feckless Bush administration, rather than looking for ways to compel Iraq’s leaders to perform, is lessening the pressure.
For almost three years, Syria has been in the diplomatic doghouse. But after the Annapolis peace summit the door may have cracked open to allow Syria back in the house.
Corporate and special-interest lobbying is where the big money is growing Capitol Hill’s quasi-aristocracy of ex-incumbents.

Twenty-eight retired generals and admirals plan to release a letter on Friday urging Congress to repeal a law that allows gay men and lesbians to serve in the military but only if they keep their orientation secret.
A federal appeals court threw out a hard-fought agreement between publishers and freelance writers to pay the writers for electronic reproduction of their work.
Sprint Nextel has rejected an offer from Providence Equity Partners and SK Telecom of South Korea to replace management and invest $5 billion in the company.
Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Donovan McNabb did not practice Thursday, and his availability for Sunday’s game against the Seattle Seahawks is still in doubt.
Dell, undergoing a transformation to reach consumers worldwide and a broader base of business customers, reported improved financial results that nevertheless disappointed Wall Street.

The husband of a city police sergeant was arrested on a child pornography charge on Thursday, and federal investigators said police officers had apparently withheld and destroyed evidence in the case.
Straphangers could be forgiven if they see something Grinch-like about the Metropolitan Transportation Authority this holiday season.
For anyone not intimately familiar with the business of Broadway, the ratio of spoils gained to losses incurred in the recently settled labor dispute seems almost Verdun-like.
Mr. Van for nearly two decades presided over the Bridgehampton saloon that bore his name, an upscale oasis frequented by literary royalty like Truman Capote, Kurt Vonnegut and Joseph Heller.
Penn State Coach Joe Paterno’s salary, long a secret, was released by the Pennsylvania State Employees’ Retirement System after The Patriot-News of Harrisburg won a five-year court case.
Kate Whitman, the daughter of former Gov. Christie Whitman, said on Thursday that she would seek the Congressional seat being vacated by Rep. Mike Ferguson, a Republican.
The Tennessee governor is under fire for plans to add a $4.8 million entertainment complex to the governor’s mansion.
Weight problems among high school football players have far outpaced those of other male children and adolescents, according to two recent medical studies.
This is the year when “sanctuary” became a dirty word in the presidential campaign.
Liquor commercials began appearing on WNBC-TV in New York, Channel 4, last Friday, without fanfare.
Mr. Hyde won battles to prohibit federal financing of abortions and to impeach President Clinton but failed to persuade the Senate to convict and remove him from office.
Western officials are concerned that Venezuela, under the leadership of President Hugo Chávez, is becoming increasingly opaque in its finances.
When skiers on the men’s World Cup circuit approach the Golden Eagle jump in Friday’s downhill race in Beaver Creek, Colo., they will be traveling more than 80 miles an hour.
The chief of the neurosurgery department at Rhode Island Hospital has stepped aside while officials investigate three incidents in which surgeons operated on the wrong side of a patient’s head.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,869 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
After a young reader complained, Turkish prosecutors questioned the Turkish publisher of the book “The God Delusion,” by a British author, Richard Dawkins.
Sears Holding, the owner of the Sears and Kmart chains, said profit for the third quarter plunged a startling 99 percent, from $196 million last year to just $2 million.
The new agreement over the candidacy of Gen. Michel Suleiman is the first major turning point in two years of political clashes.
HBO Films is planning to turn a best-selling book about Barry Bonds’s alleged steroid use and the government’s probe into the use of performance-enhancing drugs in sports, into a film.
The curious case of Congo, a German shepherd sentenced to die for attacking a Honduran landscaper, is making its way through New Jersey’s courts.
A Senate panel inched forward Thursday in its struggle with the White House over subpoenas demanding information about the firing of several United States attorneys last year.
Two Hungarians and a Ukrainian were arrested Wednesday after trying to sell highly enriched uranium. The quantity was far too small to make a crude warhead.
Conan O’Brien has agreed to pay nonwriting staff members on his show their regular salaries if the strike by scriptwriters against networks and studios is not resolved.
Johnson & Johnson said last night that it would record a $440 million write-down to account for declining revenue from its heart-failure infusion treatment, Natrecor.
The Texas director of science curriculum said she resigned this month under pressure from officials who said she had given the appearance of criticizing the teaching of intelligent design.
A federal list of mentally ill people barred from buying guns has doubled in size since the Virginia Tech shootings this spring.
U.S. military officials said the Iraqi government had yet to develop a plan to absorb returning refugees and keep them from setting off a new round of violence.
Wall Street extended its rally with modest gains in the major indexes after two days of sharp advances, despite economic readings that painted a mixed picture of the economy.
Nine months after new sanctions were imposed on Iran, it has steadily increased its enrichment of uranium, which can be used to produce electricity or fuel bombs.
On the road for business or commuting from the suburbs, games, gadgets and high-tech devices have caught the attention of businesspeople.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has revived plans to build an office tower over the north wing of the West Side bus terminal at the suddenly hot intersection of Eighth Avenue and 42nd Street.
Elizabeth H. Berger, an urban lobbyist, foresees a unique convergence of business, commerce and culture despite the continuing construction chaos.
The economy’s performance was the strongest in four years but is not expected to last through the current quarter amid the housing slump and credit squeeze.
In his campaign’s fourth advertisement in New Hampshire, Rudolph W. Giuliani criticizes the leading Democrats by name.
Ben S. Bernanke said a “fresh wave of investor concern” led to tougher credit conditions, reinforcing views that the Fed will cut interest rates at its next meeting.
Faced with its second mass protest by members in its short life span, Facebook is reining in some aspects of a controversial new advertising program.
In a nation where a third of the population is now made up of people of color, Barack Obama is in the vanguard of a new brand of multiracial politics.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
Gustavo Dudamel, classical music’s hottest young podium property, takes on the New York Philharmonic.
The new museum will overlook Biscayne Bay and feature a wide canopy designed to connect with the tropical surroundings of a park.
The critics of The New York Times offer a guide to the some of this year’s most notable classical music CDs.
Charles Ray at Matthew Marks, Georg Baselitz at Gagosian, Adrian Paci at Peter Blum Chelsea and more.
The economic effect of the writers’ strike, catching Canadian movie pirates, actors in Argentina strike and more culture news.
Some theatrical pieces inspire a vague boredom as they are performed, yet feel worthwhile by the time it ends. Such was “Ship in a View,” as seen at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday.
The Illinois Republican was an opponent of abortion and a leader of the impeachment effort against Bill Clinton.
The Manhattan School of Music’s exemplary young contemporary-classical ensemble performed works by Schoenberg and Berg with passion on Wednesday.
Stacey Kent’s bright, sharp-edged voice with Jim Tomlinson’s seductive Getz-style saxophone was a heady combination as seen on Wednesday at Birdland.
Even with the ever-vivid  Zooey Deschanel as the lead, the  Sci Fi Channel’s splashy, high-tech refashioning of “The Wizard of Oz,” is an artifact of its time.
Gillian Gibbons was sentenced to 15 days in jail and deportation after her class called a teddy bear Muhammad.
JAZZ.
POP.
AROUND TOWN.
Selective listings from dance critics of The New York Times.
Selective listings from theater critics of The New York Times.
CLASSICAL.
FOR CHILDREN.
Selective listings from art critics of The New York Times.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
There were bits of recurrent magic in “Distance Between Us,” but then the piece became a choreographic and somewhat repetitious exercise.
To the Editor:.
For those of us who attend too many galas, Wednesday’s opening night at City Center was a happy model of how these things should be done.
Will Eno’s unmistakable voice rings out with arresting originality in this hourlong evening of playfully profound theater.
The nuance and force of personality that are her trademarks were still in short supply in her performance of Schoenberg, Satie and William Bolcom at Zankel Hall on Wednesday.
Gifts for snow nostalgists, retro hipsters, trivia buffs and art lovers.
After serving a five-day sentence for leading an opposition march, Garry Kasparov, the former chess champion, warned that Russia was heading toward chaos.
The first thing everyone mentions is the helicopters and the probing searchlights that have kept the residents of a heavily immigrant suburb of Paris awake over the last four nights.
Moderate British Muslim leaders on Thursday proposed guidelines that aim to root out extremism, promote a culture of “civic responsibility” and foster women’s rights.
Rome’s taxi drivers clotted all of Rome’s main roadways on Wednesday, and the disruption resumed on Thursday.
Here is information about the books included in this article:.
December promises to be a big month for 20th-century furniture and decorative arts at fairs, auctions, exhibitions and events around the country.
Israeli police who are investigating whether Prime Minister Ehud Olmert had acted criminally in the 2005 sale of a bank recommended today that the case be closed, citing a lack of evidence.
Nancy Goliger and Bruce Berman, the Hollywood couple knwon for their photography collection, are divorcing, thus about 500 works are heading to auction at Christie’s.
The chairman of the Hong Kong company that manufactured millions of the toy beads said the firm had not considered the possibility that the chemicals in the beads might be poisonous.
After Nazis murdered his parents, the author's father became a propaganda tool — the Reich’s youngest Nazi.
Philippine SWAT teams stormed a five-star hotel commandeered by dissident army officers Thursday.
The move was in retaliation against the Bush administration’s proposed upgrading of Taiwan’s Patriot anti-missile batteries, Chinese state media said today.
Pervez Musharraf was sworn in as a civilian president Thursday, a day after giving up his post as army chief.
Pervez Musharraf made the announcement after being sworn into a second term as president of Pakistan today.
MOVIES.
Food banks around the country are reporting critical shortages that have forced them to ration supplies.
A new report says the country is brimming with opportunities to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, while saving money at the same time.
Both Mitt Romney and Democrats have accused Rudolph W. Giuliani of a pattern of misleading figures.
The curtains are up, the marquees are glowing, the Playbills are once again stacked in their neat little piles. Now what?
The most important question for the markets now is this: With the theory of riskless risky lending thoroughly discredited, where will new financing come from?
Paranoid schizophrenia has plagued Rodney Smith for more than two decades.
Senator Trent Lott’s decision to leave the Senate to “do something else” truly is “something else.”
Fifty-two points separated the Celtics from the Knicks at one point Thursday, and it was hard to say whether the biggest gap was on the scoreboard, or between Coach Isiah Thomas and his players.
After a strike that shut down Broadway theaters for 19 days, some shows raced the clock to get the curtain up.
Nikolay Davydenko, who has been the subject of a match-fixing inquiry, was not chosen by the Russian captain Shamil Tarpishchev to play singles in the Davis Cup finals.
Rudolph W. Giuliani called an account of his spending a “political hit job” as his campaign struggled to explain the billing practices.

EVERYTHING’S POPPING UP SHOWBIZ Like a Disney show itself, “How Does the Show Go On?,” a whiz-bang introduction to the inner workings of the commercial theater from Disney Editions, is gorgeously produced and cunningly designed to appeal to the largest possible audience. Kindergarten concepts (what is a ticket?) are explained alongside complicated issues that longtime theatergoers will have wondered about. In easily digestible, winking prose, Thomas Schumacher, who runs Disney’s theatrical unit, and Jeff Kurtti, a Disney historian, define dummy lyrics, fight calls and house heads, and parse which union member is in charge of a candle.

The On Education column on Nov. 28, about private firms that use branding techniques to coach high school students who apply to college, misstated the educational credentials of Chioma Isiadinso, founder of a small New York coaching firm, Expartus. She has a master's in education from the University of Pittsburgh, not an M.B.A. from Harvard.

NATIVE THEATER FESTIVAL A dedicated New York theatergoer might be justified in thinking that this town has played host to every kind of theater festival possible, including not only those dedicated to genre (musical, fringe, clown) but also those devoted to artistic identity (Latino, Asian, gay). But the Public Theater, which doggedly tends to uncover the new, is offering a festival next week featuring the work of American Indian artists from the United States and Canada. Oskar Eustis, the Public's artistic director, created a similar event when he was the artistic director of Trinity Repertory Company in Rhode Island, but this Native Theater Festival is his first time doing it in New York. ''There is clearly a significant number of Native theater artists in this country who are talented and original,'' Mr. Eustis said in a telephone interview. ''The stories of the Native experience are extraordinary, and yet we have no Native theater movement here.''

Four short films made by Indian directors to spread awareness about H.I.V. and AIDS will go on YouTube in February after making their debut in Indian theaters and television, Reuters reported yesterday. The 18-minute creations of Mira Nair, Santosh Sivan, Farhan Akhtar and Vishal Bhardwaj, with financing by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, will also be shown at a screening planned for lawmakers on World AIDS Day, tomorrow. The shorts will be screened at Indian theaters before full-length Bollywood films. Collectively named ''AIDS Jaago'' (''AIDS Awake''), the films were screened for the first time at the 38th International Film Festival of India in Goa this week.

Released from jail after serving a five-day sentence for leading an opposition march, Garry Kasparov, the former chess champion, warned that Russia was heading toward chaos under President Vladimir V. Putin. Mr. Kasparov said his coalition, Other Russia, would continue its protests to spotlight what he described as a government that has grown increasingly repressive. He was arrested Saturday when he tried to deliver a letter to election officials contending that the parliamentary election this Sunday is biased toward Mr. Putin's party, United Russia. His release came as Mr. Putin made a direct televised appeal to the nation to support United Russia.

According to a new report from the Anderson School of Management at the University of California, Los Angeles, the economic impact of even a long strike by screenwriters would not be much. If the strike, now about four weeks old, were to last for five months, the report said, the Los Angeles area would see economic activity drop by about $380 million, or roughly one-tenth of 1 percent of the region's $380 billion in annual activity, and personal income growth for area residents would fall by just a quarter of 1 percent in 2008. Written by the economist Jerry Nickelsburg, the report, released yesterday, described the strike's likely effect as ''modest and transitory.'' It said widely published higher estimates of the strike's impact had failed to account for the entertainment industry's stockpiling of programs and movies; spending by consumers on other entertainment; and the large number of reality television shows, which are unaffected by the walkout.

CRESHKOFF--Nancy Freeman, 91, former editor, died at her home in Manhattan on November 19. Nancy graduated from Vassar in 1938. Her marriage to Frederick Harper ended in divorce. With two small children, she started a daycare center at home, then took a degree in early childhood education at Boston University. In 1951 she launched a daily program for pre-school children on Boston's new public radio station, WGBH. In 1953 she married Lawrence Creshkoff, the station's program manager. After moving to New Jersey in 1957, she worked as an editor at McGraw-Hill, then at Macmillan until retiring. In 1982, she went to the American Museum of Natural History, advancing from volunteer to associate editor of Curator, a quarterly journal for museum professionals. From 1999 to 2002 she volunteered as an editor in the museum library. She is survived by her husband of 54 years; four children: Mary and Fred Harper; Maggie and Rebekah Creshkoff; two granddaughters; and two great-grandchildren. Memorial gifts may be made to the Germantown Friends School in Philadelphia.

He will be very much missed and remembered by those who loved him dearly. Contributions in Bill's memory to American Cancer Society or American Heart Association.

The first criminal charges under new cinema antipiracy laws have been filed in Canada, Reuters reported yesterday. ''It's a step forward,'' Douglas Frith, president of the Canadian Motion Pictures Distributors Association, said after Louis-Rene Hache of Montreal was charged Wednesday with recording in a movie theater for commercial distribution. Mr. Hache was arrested on Oct. 26 and charged with recording the Touchstone Pictures comedy ''Dan in Real Life'' at a movie theater in Montreal. He pleaded not guilty to both charges and was released ahead of his next scheduled court appearance on Jan. 21. His arrest was made possible in part after a $5,000 night-vision system to detect digital-camera lenses was installed in the Guzzo Lacordaire multiplex cinema, described as a target of illegal videotapers. Mr. Hache faces a fine or up to two years in prison if found guilty of recording a movie without a theater's permission and a fine or up to five years in prison if convicted of recording for commercial gain.

McDONOUGH--Robert Emmett, 85, of Capistrano Beach, CA, passed away on November 21, 2007, surrounded by loving family. Born in Chicago, IL, he is survived by his beloved wife, Simone; children, Susan and Emmett; sister, Kathleen Ecklund; five grandchildren, Meaghan, Jenna, David, Stephen and John; and two great-grandchildren, Jackson and RyanCarlson. He was preceded in death by his first wife of 47 years, Elsa. Bob served in the Merchant Marines during World War II and earned his BA in 1949 at Georgetown University, School of Foreign Service. The founder of Remedy Temporary Services, in 1998, Bob made the largest gift of its kind to Georgetown University and the McDonough School of Business. Bob served on the Board of Directors of Georgetown University for a decade and was a Hoya through and through. Bob also served for many years on the Board of Directors of the Historic Mission Preservation Society in San Juan Capistrano and was a strong supporter of educational causes, including the San Juan Capistrano Mission School and the America Ireland Fund. A lifelong Democrat, Bob was active in local and national politics, making his last contributions to candidates in September. A vigil will be held on Thursday, November 29, 2007 at 6:30pm at the Mission Basilica San Juan Capistrano, 31522 Camino Capistrano, San Juan Capistrano, CA 92675. Funeral services will be held on Friday, November 30, at 10:30am at the Mission Basilica. A reception will follow. O'Connor Mortuary, Directors. (949) 581-4300.

THE BARNARD PROJECT University dance departments have budgets, studios, and students eager to work with real-life choreographers. And choreographers have budget constraints, time constraints, space constraints. Putting the two together could help both parties, Mary Cochran, chairwoman of the Barnard College dance department, realized. And so was born the Barnard Project, a collaboration between Dance Theater Workshop and Barnard, now in its third year. ''The choreographers get to use far more bodies than they could normally afford to pay, which is fun for them,'' Ms. Cochran said, ''and the students are so energized by the different creative processes that they experience.'' The strength of the project is in its choice -- made by Ms. Cochran and Carla Peterson, the artistic director of Dance Theater Workshop -- of experienced choreographers with strong, distinctive voices. This year Gerald Casel, Amanda Loulaki, RoseAnne Spradlin and Keith A. Thompson have created works for 44 students in the dance departments of both Barnard and Columbia University, and the fruits of that collaboration will be offered at Dance Theater Workshop next week. (Above, Reggie Wilson's piece ''Arrested Development of Violent Femmes'' from last year's Barnard Project.)

ABC's new holiday special ''Shrek the Halls,'' right, attracted 21.1 million viewers on Wednesday night at 8, Nielsen estimated, lifting the network to first place among adults 18 to 49. ''How the Grinch Stole Christmas'' at 8:30 (18.7 million), also on ABC, outpaced NBC's broadcast of ''Christmas at Rockefeller Center'' (9 million). CBS ranked second in the 18-to-49 set, and edged ABC in total viewers. CBS dominated at both 9 and 10, with ''Criminal Minds'' (16.3 million) followed by ''CSI: NY'' (14 million). ABC's ''Pushing Daisies'' earned a second place finish over all at 9 (10.2 million); NBC's ''Bionic Woman'' came in fourth over all (6 million). NBC ranked fourth over all among adults 18 to 49.

THE JAZZ PASSENGERS Music making and storytelling have long been inextricable for Roy Nathanson, the saxophonist and composer best known for his work with the Jazz Passengers. When he formed that group 20 years ago -- with the trombonist Curtis Fowlkes, whom he had met in a Big Apple Circus band -- Mr. Nathanson brought some idiosyncratic ideas about jazz and narrative. The typical Jazz Passengers album includes a bolt of polyphonic bluster, a dash of sly grace and a bit of archly hard-boiled language, either spoken or sung. The Jazz Passengers haven't worked much as a full band in recent years, notwithstanding the odd performance with Deborah Harry, formerly of Blondie. But Mr. Nathanson has kept sharpening his style through projects like ''Fire at Keaton's Bar and Grill,'' a song cycle featuring, among others, Ms. Harry and Elvis Costello. In ''Sotto Voce'' (AUM Fidelity), released last year, Mr. Nathanson works alongside Mr. Fowlkes, the violinist (and fellow Passenger) Sam Bardfeld, the bassist Tim Kiah and the vocal percussionist Napoleon Maddox. At times they all sing together, in barbershop-style harmony.

A strike of actors in Argentina has halted production of all telenovelas, the popular soap-opera-style series, Reuters reported yesterday. Local networks have been broadcasting news, reality and talk shows in their place. Argentina's actors union is demanding a shorter daily work shift. Shows affected by the strike, like ''Patito Feo,'' ''Mujeres de Nadie'' and ''Son de Fierro,'' are extremely popular in Argentina and overseas. Argentine telenovelas and children's programming are exported around the world, particularly to the Middle East, Eastern Europe and Asia.

INDEPENDENT AND SMALL PRESS BOOK FAIR It's hard to get more indie than Ian MacKaye. For more than two decades, Mr. MacKaye, the founder of Dischord Records and the frontman of the seminal Washington punk band Fugazi, has stood firm against corporate enticements and megadeals, eschewing major labels and high ticket prices. Though he's never written a book, tomorrow he brings his D.I.Y. ethos to the 20th annual Independent and Small Press Book Fair. ''There's parallels in all these worlds,'' said Mr. MacKaye, above, an avid reader who will take part in a Q. & A. introduced by Ian Sevonius, another D.C. rocker. ''This notion that there's a farm team, that you work within the independent sphere as you wait to get kicked up to the majors, I just don't believe in that at all. Within my sphere, I have maintained a steady kind of exterior path, outside of the mainstream. I'm on a service road, not the interstate, but I'm going somewhere.''

The American Academy of Arts and Letters named the writers Madison Smartt Bell and William T. Vollmann recipients of its Strauss Livings awards of $250,000, the largest literary award in America. The Livings provide $50,000 annually for two writers over five years, and recipients agree to forgo positions of paid employment during that period. Mr. Bell, who wrote ''All Souls' Rising'' and other books, and Mr. Vollmann, a prolific writer whose works include ''Europe Central,'' were selected by a committee of writers who are academy members. (Members are ineligible for the awards.) The Livings were established in 1983 by a bequest from Harold and Mildred Strauss. Winners have included Cynthia Ozick, Raymond Carver and Marilynne Robinson.

MURRAY--Sir James, KCMG, 88, on November 28, 2007, survived by his wife Jill, his stepdaughters Sophie Chapuisat Smith and Tanya Soler Chapuisat, his stepgrandchildren Lucas, Natacha, and Kai, his nieces Catherine Perry and Sheila Taplin, and nephew Philip Murray of the United Kingdom. Born on the Isle of Arran (Scotland), Sir James served in the Royal Regiment of Artillery in Burma and India during World War II. Joining HM Foreign Service in 1947, his distinguished career included significant responsibilities in Egypt, Canada, France, Indonesia, and the European Community. Sir James was Consul General in San Francisco; he served as Ambassador to Rwanda and Burundi, and to the United Nations both in Geneva and New York, as well as Special Envoy of five western governments for negotiations regarding the independence of Namibia. In retirement, he was the Withrow Professor of Government at Deep Springs College in California, and actively involved with the Congressional Award Foundation, the Center for Migration Studies, and Auburn University. A Memorial Reception for family and friends will be held on December 11th at 5pm at The Brook.

Joel Shapiro's latest show is exquisite: a focused, perfect arrangement of just under a dozen sculptures filling Pace Wildenstein in Chelsea. This may well be the artist's best effort in years. The work may look old-fashioned to some, with its attention to relationships between abstraction and representation, its choice of weighty materials (wood and bronze) and its heroic scale. The pieces may even be reminiscent of David Smith's, specifically his final ''Cubi'' series of monumental geometric sculptures made of stainless-steel cubes and prisms. Certainly Mr. Smith opened up a space for abstract sculpture in which Mr. Shapiro works. But Mr. Shapiro is very much his own artist, with his own style and set of aesthetic concerns, chief among them the striving for a sense of compositional balance between opposites. His sculptures are compact yet fluidly elegant; rapturously open yet contained; full of life yet inert; majestic yet humble. Several seem to defy gravity, with the arrangements of the cubes, prisms and rectangles surging into the air (left, ''Untitled,'' 2005-7). The works can also be brightly colored or lovingly hand-finished, the surface of the bronze sculptures made to resemble wood. They are like scaffolding crossed with a bouquet of flowers. (Through Jan. 19, Pace Wildenstein, 545 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, 212-989-4258, pacewildenstein.com.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

Warner Music Group and the family of Frank Sinatra, above right, have established a partnership to handle his body of work. Frank Sinatra Enterprises will manage Sinatra's musical, film and stage legacy and will own some of Sinatra's commercial recordings, as well as a trove of films, television specials and unreleased footage, photos and audio recordings. It will also administer all licenses for the use of his name and likeness. Representatives from the Sinatra family and Warner Music Group will manage the partnership, with day-to-day operations under the Rhino Records executives Jimmy Edwards and Gregg Goldman.

The echo of gunfire that accompanied two nights of rioting in the Paris suburb Villiers-le-Bel this week has subsided, and now it is the relentless throbbing of police helicopters and the probing searchlights that keep residents awake. ''I feel safer for having all those cops on the streets and the helicopter at night making sure the kids are not planning more riots, but it sure is hard to live like this,'' said Nadège Tanier, a 40-year-old mother of two. She is among many locals trying to make do with an undeclared state of emergency. There is no curfew, but few people go out after dark when police officers move in. In interviews with residents, it became plain that there was little sympathy for the rioters. ''I don't like the way the police are treating the kids sometimes, and I know they do not have many economic opportunities, but there is no excuse for the violence and the destruction,'' said Nora Hemmal, a Moroccan immigrant who had hoped to enroll her daughter in a nursery that the rioters destroyed. ''Most of us are just caught in the middle.''

SCHEETZ--Dr. Jane Overmeyer passed away peacefully and in comfort at the home of her son and his family in Greenwich on November 27, at the age of 75. She had battled lung and brain cancer for the better part of the year. She successfully struggled to survive and spend a final Thanksgiving with her entire family. She enjoyed Thanksgiving with her daughter, Mary Zehnle, and her husband, Tom, their two children Madeleine (11) and Nicky (6) and with her son, Ed, his wife Marianne and their two children Alexander (14) and Victoria (12). Jane was born in 1932 in Columbia, PA to Mary and Henry Overmeyer. She grew up in this small town in Amish Country. From there, she went to Penn State University and was one of the few women in the pre-med program there. She met her future husband, Walter, there. Walt and Jane were married in 1955. Both graduated from Temple Medical School in Philadelphia. Jane was a general practitioner but specialized in Bacteriology and Pathology. Walter entered the Army as a surgeon. While living in Honolulu, they had two children: Walter Edward (Ed) born January 11, 1965 and Mary Alice born April 5, 1966. After having the children, Jane devoted herself to raising them and became a homemaker. She maintained her license to practice medicine her entire life up to her death. The family settled in Potomac, Maryland, outside of Washington, DC. Jane's devotion to her family and her children were her proudest accomplishment. Her brilliance and wit was transferred to her children. Ed graduated from Princeton and became a successful real estate investor and now lives in Greenwich and New York. Mary graduated from Dickinson College and Catholic University Law School. Mary and Jane remained best friends and visited virtually everyday. Jane enjoyed watching her four grandchildren grow older. They adored her and enjoyed spending every moment they could with her. Jane was a movie buff with an incredible grasp of trivia. She kept her mind sharp reading, maintaining her medical degree, and mastering crossword puzzles. She often visited her family and enjoyed traveling with them to Hawaii, the Bahamas and other warm places. She faced a very difficult illness with courage and strength. Living with Ed's family in Greenwich she got to know Alex and Victoria even better prior to her death. Jane had a special fondness for Marianne, her daughterin-law, and Marianne was her primary companion and caregiver during her final six months. Jane will be missed enormously by her children Ed and Mary, their spouses, Marianne and Tom, and by her grandchildren, Alex, Victoria, Madeleine and Nicky. Mom, we love you very much and are happy you are in heaven with your parents and other close relatives. A memorial service will be held Saturday December 1st at Saint Peter's Roman Catholic Church, 121 South Second Street, Columbia, PA 17512 (717) 684-7070. Gifts in lieu of flowers can be sent to: Greenwich Hospital Oncology, Oncology Unit, 5 Perryridge Rd. Greenwich, CT 06830. 'JOEL SHAPIRO: NEW SCULPTURE' Joel Shapiro's latest show is exquisite: a focused, perfect arrangement of just under a dozen sculptures filling Pace Wildenstein in Chelsea. This may well be the artist's best effort in years. The work may look old-fashioned to some, with its attention to relationships between abstraction and representation, its choice of weighty materials (wood and bronze) and its heroic scale. The pieces may even be reminiscent of David Smith's, specifically his final ''Cubi'' series of monumental geometric sculptures made of stainless-steel cubes and prisms. Certainly Mr. Smith opened up a space for abstract sculpture in which Mr. Shapiro works. But Mr. Shapiro is very much his own artist, with his own style and set of aesthetic concerns, chief among them the striving for a sense of compositional balance between opposites. His sculptures are compact yet fluidly elegant; rapturously open yet contained; full of life yet inert; majestic yet humble. Several seem to defy gravity, with the arrangements of the cubes, prisms and rectangles surging into the air (left, ''Untitled,'' 2005-7). The works can also be brightly colored or lovingly hand-finished, the surface of the bronze sculptures made to resemble wood. They are like scaffolding crossed with a bouquet of flowers. (Through Jan. 19, Pace Wildenstein, 545 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, 212-989-4258, pacewildenstein.com.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

FINK--Daniel J., M.D. NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Columbia University Medical Center mourn the sudden passing of our dear friend and colleague Dr. Daniel J. Fink. A uniquely talented pathologist, Dr. Fink gave 28 years of devoted service to the Medical Center, the entirety of his professional career. He was founding director of the Hospital's Core Laboratory and the University's Center for Advanced Laboratory Medicine, and he led development of our first laboratory information system. An early and enthusiastic advocate for the use of information technology to improve quality and safety for patients, he also helped lead an influential NIH-funded study of the effects of the Chernobyl accident on thyroid cancer and other thyroid diseases. Dr. Fink received degrees from two of our schools--an M.D. degree from The College of Physicians & Surgeons and a master of public health degree from the Mailman School of Public Health. Our deepest condolences are extended to his wife, Yvonne, and daughter, Leslie. A beloved member of the New York-Presbyterian and Columbia University family, he will be greatly missed. Herbert Pardes, M.D., President & CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Lee Goldman, M.D., Dean Columbia University Medical Center

Bo Pelini, the defensive coordinator at Louisiana State, is expected to be named the head coach at Nebraska, two sources with direct knowledge of the situation said last night. Pelini served as the defensive coordinator at Nebraska in 2003 and was the interim coach in the Cornhuskers’ Alamo Bowl victory against Michigan State that season after Frank Solich was fired. After leaving Nebraska, Pelini was co-defensive coordinator at Oklahoma. The hiring is expected to become official after L.S.U. plays Tennessee in the Southeastern Conference title game today.

Democratic leaders in Congress said that they would formally send a bill expanding a popular children’s health care program to the White House despite the threat of a veto. The bill would provide health insurance to about 10 million children in low-income families that are unable to afford private insurance but earn too much to qualify for the federal Medicaid program for the poor. To pay for the aid, the bill would raise tobacco taxes. President Bush vetoed a version in October.

A federal bankruptcy judge has approved the sale of the headquarters of Your Black Muslim Bakery in Oakland for use as a nonprofit center serving people with AIDS and other serious illnesses. Judge Edward D. Jellen on Thursday approved selling the property for about $1 million to a partnership buying the property for Vital Life Services. The bakery had been a well-known community business before falling apart amid gang activity, violence and bankruptcy. Devaughndre Broussard, 20, a handyman at the bakery, has been charged with killing Chauncey Bailey, editor of The Oakland Post.

A 45-year-old woman was charged with arson and felony murder in the June 7 fire in the Riverdale Budget Inn that killed five people, four from the same family. John Oxendine, the state insurance and safety fire commissioner, identified the woman as Sherce Dionne Murphy, who went by the street name Queen. Commissioner Oxendine said officers were searching for Ms. Murphy in Atlanta, where she has family. “It took us a long time to do this,” Commissioner Oxendine said, “and we have suspected Queen for some time. We wanted to make sure we had a strong case.”.

A prominent bird-watcher who was tried for shooting a cat to death said he left the state after someone shot at him. The bird-watcher, James M. Stevenson, founder of the Galveston Ornithological Society, said he had received death threats since his trial on animal cruelty charges. A judge declared a mistrial last month when the jury failed to reach a verdict. Mr. Stevenson told the police that he was standing on his porch Wednesday when someone shot at him. In his trial, Mr. Stevenson admitted shooting the cat but defended the action because he believed it was threatening endangered birds.

The State Supreme Court threw out a district attorney’s lawsuit against the judge overseeing the murder trial of a man accused in a rampage that began in an Atlanta courtroom. The lawsuit — which sought to force jury selection to resume in the trial of Brian Nichols and questioned whether the presiding judge, Hilton Fuller of Superior Court, should be removed from the case — should have been filed first in Superior Court, the high court ruled. Chief Justice Leah Ward Sears wrote that despite the ruling, she was disappointed with the progress of the Nichols case. Judge Fuller has suspended the trial because the state public defender’s office has cut off financing to Mr. Nichols’s lawyers.
Israel’s Supreme Court ruled that the government could continue cutting fuel supplies to the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip, which it has done since Oct. 28.

The weather in Southern California turned from dangerously dry to extremely wet as storms brought the threat of mudslides and flash floods in areas burned by recent wildfires and prompted evacuation orders. Residents were ordered to leave 200 homes in two Orange County canyons, while voluntary evacuations were urged in a third and the authorities were keeping an eye on a fourth, said Capt. Chris Concepcion of the Orange County Fire Authority. Flood warnings and watches were issued throughout Southern California.

Even cable cars shut down. The unions want more government investment in transportation. “Nightmare,” said Emma Everitt, who arrived in Rome in the morning from Britain for a weekend visit.

A jury awarded $9.5 million yesterday to the family of the former Chicago Blackhawks star Keith Magnuson in a wrongful-death lawsuit against the former N.H.L. player Rob Ramage, whose drunken-driving accident killed Magnuson. Magnuson’s wife and two children filed the suit against Ramage and National Car Rentals of Canada.Magnuson was a passenger in the rental car driven by Ramage that was involved in a head-on collision in suburban Toronto as the men were returning from a funeral Dec. 15, 2003. Magnuson died at the scene. He was 56.Ramage was convicted in October in Ontario of impaired driving causing death and four other charges. Bobby Bowden and Florida State are completing a contract that will keep him on the Seminoles’ sideline next season, and maybe longer. Bowden’s lawyer, Russ Campbell of Birmingham, Ala., confirmed that the university and his client had a deal. “We’ve come to a handshake agreement,” Campbell said in a statement. “It hasn’t been finalized yet.”The agreement allows Bowden, 78, to coach as long as he wants, according to the statement.Bowden has 373 career victories, the most among major college coaches, and two more than Penn State’s Joe Paterno, who turns 81 on Dec. 21.

The European Champions League will be opened to more clubs from smaller countries and its final each May will be moved to Saturday. Six of 32 places in the first round will be reserved for champions from less competitive leagues, European soccer’s governing body decided in announcing changes effective for the 2009-10 season.In addition, three teams each from the powerful leagues in England, Italy and Spain will qualify automatically for the first round. Currently, two teams from each nation receive automatic berths and two more go into the third round of qualifying. Under the new format, the fourth-place teams from those countries will have to qualify against second-place teams from relatively strong nations like the Netherlands or Portugal.The final has traditionally been held on a Wednesday night. Michel Platini, the new president of the Union of European Football Associations, wanted it moved to a weekend to encourage more family viewing and attendance.

The six young actors and actresses who helped make ''High School Musical'' and ''High School Musical 2'' the most popular movies on the Disney Channel reached an agreement with Walt Disney Studios to star in a feature film based on the franchise, a Disney executive said yesterday. The executive, who would speak only on condition of anonymity because the company is not yet ready to make a formal announcement, said that five cast members -- Vanessa Hudgens,Ashley Tisdale, Corbin Bleu, Lucas Grabeel and Monique Coleman -- have signed contracts to appear in the film, which has the working title ''High School Musical 3'' and is scheduled to have its premiere next fall. The sixth, Zac Efron, who had a major role in the film ''Hairspray'' earlier this year, has committed to return but still has to sign a contract, the executive said. Mr. Efron's salary, the highest of the six, would be in excess of $3 million, the executive said. The movie will be directed and choreographed by Kenny Ortega, who was in charge of the first two productions, and will be set during the characters' senior year. Disney will also use the movie to introduce a secondary cast, who will star in future ''High School Musical'' television movies. The question of whether to include Ms. Hudgens had been extensively debated within Disney because she acknowledged in September that she was the nude woman in a photograph circulating widely on the Internet. She has since apologized to her fans.

A BID TO EASE CREDIT IN EUROPE The European Central Bank said that it would extend a lending deadline in December to help the banking system through a period of unusually tight credit at the end of the year. The action represents a renewed effort by the bank to calm a lending system that had showed signs of returning to normal recently but now appears nearly as nervous as during the summer days when the global credit turmoil began. The bank's normal midmonth lending, which typically has a maturity of a single week, will be extended in December so that loans are not due until Jan. 4. ''In this operation, the E.C.B. will aim to satisfy the banking sector's liquidity needs for the entire two-week period,'' the bank said in a statement.

He was born in New Haven, CT, grew up in Brownsville, Brooklyn, moved to Bayside, Queens, then lived in Plainview, NY, and retired to Tamarac, FL. As a younger man, he worked in the millinery industry, then the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and was a decorated war veteran wounded three times in WWII. After the war he went into the florescent lighting fixture business where he was a partner in Lamar Lighting for over 30 years and then retired. We will miss you and love you forever. You will always be in our hearts.

(HBO) ALPHA DOG (2006) In 2000, a 20-year-old Los Angeles marijuana dealer named Jesse James Hollywood kidnapped, partied with and then ordered the murder of the 15-year-old half-brother of a client who owed him $1,200, prosecutors say. After that he was on the F.B.I.'s most-wanted list for five years until his arrest in Brazil in 2005. In this retelling by Nick Cassavetes, Emile Hirsch plays Johnny Truelove, the dim-bulb mastermind; Bruce Willis is his dad; and Justin Timberlake is Johnny's best friend. Mr. Cassavetes's ''sexed-up, alternately funny and horrifying, heavy-panting exploitation of the crime, despite some name and geography changes, tracks close to the recorded facts,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, adding, ''Do you know where your children are?''

PRUDENT--Dr. Jacques H ., expired at Huntington Hospital on November 26, 2007 after a prolonged illness. Dr. Prudent was born on August 7, 1952 in Haiti, graduated from State University of Haiti College of Medicine and completed residency training at Interfaith Medical Center. He joined the Medical Staff at Coler-Goldwater Hospital in 1984 and provided distinguished service throughout his tenure. Dr. Prudent chaired many Medical Staff Committees and was the President of Medical Staff during 2002 and 2003, as well as President of Roosevelt Island Medical Associates, P.C. from 1997 to 1999. His friendly personality, unflappable calm and willingness to extend himself to help other colleagues will be greatly missed. Kind words were the only words Jacques would speak and in doing so, has touched many lives. He is survived by his wife, Gladys, and children, Jacques Jr., Ronald and Christina. Funeral services will be held on December 1, 2007, at 9:30am at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, Garden City, NY. With heartfelt condolences to the Prudent family from friends and colleagues. Coler-Goldwater Medical Staff and RIMA, P.C.

The Rugby World Cup will keep its 20-team format for the 2011 tournament in New Zealand, the International Rugby Board said. The board said before this year's World Cup in France that it would review the number of participants to ensure that smaller nations would be able to be competitive in the tournament.South Africa won its second title in Paris on Oct. 20 with a 15-6 victory against England, the defending champion. Among the strong performances turned in by smaller countries was Fiji's upset of Wales to reach a quarterfinal and Georgia's 4-point loss to Ireland.

Thousands of participants have taken over a sprawling convention center and galaxy of hotels once or twice a year for talks aimed, in theory, at achieving a goal agreed to by all the world's nations in Rio de Janeiro in 1992 -- avoiding "dangerous" human interference with the climate system. It's not news that Grayson Perry loves to wear a frock. ''I'm a transvestite,'' says Perry, who won the Turner Prize in 2003. ''It comes with the territory.'' But don't expect this self-described ''art tranny'' to be impressed by designer labels. He prefers to have his wardrobe custom-made. (For a summer course he taught at Central St. Martins, the students had five weeks to make him an outfit; he bought the ones he liked the best.) Perry, whose work ranges from ceramics to graphic novels, is currently designing a fabric for the English company Liberty; curating a show for the Arts Council England, ''Unpopular Culture''; and crafting a medal for the British Museum that he promises will be anything but noble. Despite his own penchant for baby-doll dresses and ruffled socks, he says: ''I am terribly sick of the infantilization of everyday life. Whatever happened to things being subversive, slow and complex?''

As a child growing up in San Francisco, the multimedia artist Slater Bradley was obsessed with whom he wanted to be. ''I think it's something we all do when we're really young,'' he says. This search for identity still lingers in his work. ''Doppelgänger Trilogy,'' his 2004 lo-fi video series, showed his ''veritable double,'' Benjamin Brock, dressed as cultural icons from Bradley's youth like Kurt Cobain and Michael Jackson. ''I think the 'Doppelgänger' piece was practically begging for YouTube to exist,'' Bradley says. He is now interested in moving toward sculpture but is aware that his alter ego won't stop haunting him anytime soon: ''I have had about 29 solo shows, but people mostly know me by that piece.''

Their his-and-his bespoke suits have made them two of the most recognizable peacocks in the art world. But unlike their perfectly tailored demeanor, the work of the London artists Gilbert and George is a messier affair. Often the stars of their own pieces, the pair have explored taboo subject matter like bodily fluids and skinhead subcultures in their photography and performance art. (An image from their 2005 series ''Ginkgo Pictures'' shows them morphing into a sort of two-headed monster.) A retrospective of their work was shown this year at the Tate Modern and is making its way to the Brooklyn Museum in October 2008. Much like their sartorial habits, their work appears timeless.

I have a confession to make. I've run out of adjectives, descriptives and hyperbole to describe this college football season. I'm done. Spent. For the past six weeks, I've stared at my computer screen and tried to come up with new words to describe this season. I've used surreal, topsy turvy, volatile, dizzying, inexplicable, unpredictable, engaging and maddening. And those are just off the top of my head. I'm sick of going to the thesaurus, convinced that a new word will magically appear -- just as a new improbable scenario seemed to appear every week.

An article last week about the future of the AIDS epidemic misidentified the antibiotics that kill Yersinia pestis, the microbe that was one of the causes of the Black Death. Streptomycin, doxycycline and chloramphenicol are generally used against the bacterium, not penicillin. The article also misstated the percentage of AIDS sufferers in low- and middle-income countries who receive antiretroviral drugs. It is estimated that close to a third or more of those who need the drugs get them; not one-tenth.

An article last week about the decline in the teaching of psychoanalysis in college psychology departments misidentified the journal where a study of the trend will appear in June 2008. It is The Journal of the American Psychoanalytic Association (JAPA), not The American Journal of Psychiatry.

In their excellent article about bariatric surgery, Stephen J. Dubner and Steven D. Levitt (Freakonomics, Nov. 18) mention that the procedure “often produces complications — physiological ones, to be sure, but also perhaps psychological ones.” As a psychiatrist, I have no doubt that a morbidly obese patient without other medical cause for obesity (i.e., thyroid disease) already has a severe psychiatric problem. Without treating the compulsion that underlies such behavior, it is no wonder that patients who have surgery but no psychiatric treatment may develop “new” psychiatric symptoms, like gambling, compulsive shopping and alcoholism.

Because of an editing error, a review last Sunday about “The Pleasures of the Damned,” a poetry collection by Charles Bukowski, misspelled the second word of a Latin phrase meaning “we were smoke.” It is fuimus fumus, not flumus. An article on Oct. 21 about the artist Lawrence Weiner misstated the duration that manhole covers he created with the assistance of the Public Art Fund were to remain in 19 locations below Union Square. The manhole covers are to remain there indefinitely; they were not removed several months after their installation in 2000. The article also gave an erroneous description of Mr. Weiner’s personal copy of the Public Art Fund manhole cover in front of the Whitney Museum. That manhole cover is nonfunctional; it did not replace a working manhole cover. This correction was delayed because a reader’s query went astray at The Times.

The framer Richard Ziello has a knack for complementing a canvas, from Motherwell to Matisse. (One collector calls him a “rogue aesthetician.”) Ziello will measure your art at home and then return to his Long Island studio to fabricate welded aluminum, wood and gold-leaf frames with molding of his own design. “We can adjust the style and molding to fit the proportions of the picture, and the art never leaves the owner’s hands,” he says. His couture approach stems from his trade as a sculptor (see his work at the Tribes Gallery through Dec. 7). Too busy with commissions from Ameringer Yohe Fine Art, the estate of Hans Hofmann and others, Ziello neglects his own art. “I’m like the shoemaker who couldn’t afford his own shoes.” E-mail rickybonzai@aol.com.

TRENTLER--Theodore R., Sr., passed away on November 29, 2007. Served in the United States Marine Corps from 1954 through 1956. Ted worked for Pan American World Airways for 30 years, until 1991. IF you are a fan of the indie version of the human drama, it would be tough to top the one about the plucky Midwestern girl who used a stripper pole to shimmy her way up and out of a drab office cubicle and grab her piece of the Hollywood dream. A few years ago, Brook Busey-Hunt was typing copy at a Minneapolis advertising agency and walked by the Skyway Lounge, a skeevy strip bar where desiccated women grind out a living a dollar at a time. Good Catholic girl that she was, Ms. Busey-Hunt saw an ad for amateur night and had a naughty epiphany. And the rest is, well, a stage name, a blog, a book and a screenwriting career.
