TEN YEARS AGO, Shu Uemura came out with Pleasure of Japanese Bath, a quartet of bath oils designed to soften and sweetly scent the skin without leaving it slick or greasy. When the company phased out the oils in 2000, public response was neither soft nor sweet; Karl Lagerfeld himself protested. This fall, Pleasure of Japanese Bath has finally effected a return, and the Pleasure-hungry throng is rejoicing. Available in four traditional Japanese fragrances, the sellout scent is yuzu, a subtle citrus oil that hydrates and warms the body ($40 each at ShuUemura-USA.com).

ON THE CW SHOW ''Gossip Girl,'' the charismatic and glamorous Serena van der Woodsen is the glossy visual planet around which all other characters orbit. Blake Lively, the actress who plays Serena, finds that in terms of fashion, life and art imitate each other. ''She does have a strong sense of style, and I like to think mine is a little bit like hers,'' said Ms. Lively, 20, who often orders pieces directly from the designers she wears on the show. ''I like the urban, chic Kate Moss look and the ladylike Audrey Hepburn look as well.''

The minister wore all black: jogging pants, basketball sneakers and a T-shirt.

To the editor: The iPod is no more responsible for ''thinning the ranks of audiophiles'' over the last decade than cheap fast food is responsible for depleting the ranks of gourmets, or cheap wine is for thinning the ranks of oenophiles.

To the Editor: Audiophile gear has always been a niche market -- as has classical music in general. But the ascendance of portable, downloadable music is not necessarily at odds with the audiophile ethos, which is a devotion to sonic authenticity with the goal of maximizing the enjoyment of recordings. IPods and similar devices are not limited to the sound quality inherent to the lowly MP3 file. If the user chooses, a higher-resolution format can be opted for when, for example, someone copies a CD he owns onto his iPod. And some classical music organizations that sell their material online know that sound quality matters. For example, the Philadelphia Orchestra Web site has downloads available as MP3 files or in the CD-quality FLAC format. It's no harder ''to be an audiophile in an iPod world'' than it is to be a Angela Gheorghiu fan in a Christina Aguilera world.
Setauket, Nov. 19.

Spinning the Spin ATLANTA -- Louisiana State football fans do not know whom to believe. Is Les Miles leaving or staying? ESPN reported yesterday that Miles had accepted the Michigan job. In response to the report, Miles held a brief news conference before the Southeastern Conference championship game and angrily declared he would remain the L.S.U. coach. Not everyone believed him.

KUGEL--Morton died November 21, 2007 at the age of 85. You were loved and will be missed terribly by your loving wife Thelma, sons Richard (Shelley), Barry (Shelley), your grandchildren Allison, David (Robin), Danielle, Jared, and Lauren. You will be missed by all your relatives and friends. He was born in New Haven, CT, grew up in Brownsville, Brooklyn, moved to Bayside, Queens, then lived in Plainview, NY, and retired to Tamarac, FL. KERR--William ''Bill'' K., died on November 21, 2007 in Litchfield Park, Arizona. He was born in Wilkinsburg, PA, on August 31, 1916. He was preceded in death by his father Andy Kerr, his mother Mary Keister, his brother Dr. Andrew Kerr, Jr., his wife Charlotte Read Kerr, and his son William K. Kerr, Jr. He graduated Colgate University in 1939 and Harvard Law School in 1943. His wartime service included working as an agent for the FBI and a Naval Intelligence officer in the Pacific on the USS Princeton. Bill joined the New York law office of Fish, Richardson & Neave (later Fish & Neave) in 1947 where he was managing partner from 1977 to 1980. He was a highly regarded trial lawyer, specializing in intellectual properties and antitrust cases. He was a Fellow in The American College of Trial Lawyers and a member of The Links Club in New York, The Links Golf Club, Sankety Head Golf Club in Nantucket, MA, and the Bermuda Seniors. His stepdaughters survive Bill: Anne Phillips Clark, Ruth Phillips Gulick, Virginia Phillips, and Phebe Phillips Byrne. He also leaves seven grandchildren: Phebe Gulick, Robin Pino, Peter Gulick Jr., Andrew Clark, Miles J. Kerr, Read Van der Wal, and William K. Kerr III, and greatgrandchildren Kate and Salvatore Pino. No services are planned at this time. In lieu of flowers, the family asks donations be made to Colgate University, Harvard Law School, American Cancer Society, or a charity of your choice.

Domestic Disturbances The Meier case got massive play in the national media this past week, coming as it did on the heels of a major new survey showing that up to one in three children in the United States has been harassed or bullied online. But for me the tragedy highlighted another troubling issue that threatens our homes just as steadily as poisonous online communications. That is the disturbing degree to which today's parents -- and mothers in particular -- frequently lose themselves when they get caught up in trying to smooth out, or steamroll over, the social challenges faced by their children.

Hiroshi Sugimoto The Japanese photographer and documentarian Hiroshi Sugimoto's continuing series like ''Dioramas'' (1976-) and ''Seascapes'' (1980-) serve as a visual record of the 20th century. Now he is shifting his focus to fashion (previous work is above and at far left). For T, he captured the season's best pieces for ''Isn't It Iconic?'' on Page 216. ''I am certainly not a fashion photographer,'' he says. ''But fashion is integral to my larger project in understanding the history of modernism.'' He is in awe of the revolutionary techniques of haute-couture pioneers like Paul Poiret and Madeleine Vionnet (her work is at center) and likes to wear Comme des Garçons to his openings. But Sugimoto also appreciates American design: ''I wear Gap underwear.'' His exhibition ''Stylized Sculpture: Contemporary Japanese Fashion From the Kyoto Costume Institute'' is at the Asian Art Museum in San Francisco through Jan. 6, 2008.

I have been in love with magazines all my life: the feeling of the paper on my fingers, the weight of it in my hands, the sound of flipping through the pages. After more than 20 years of working in magazines, I still find it exciting scanning the newsstand for a good cover or a new title. Sharing T with readers of The New York Times has been an incredible pleasure, like inviting you to my house for dinner and a great bottle of wine. In these past three years, we have tried to be good hosts, serving up memorable images and great stories that whet your appetite for the culture: these days a fusion of fashion, art, design, film and music -- or as Jean Baudrillard might have said, a total entertainment world. We have also defied the prevailing wisdom that a magazine cannot address a large audience without sacrificing quality and elegance. With this issue, T goes global, as part of The International Herald Tribune, and also goes online. Just by logging on to nytimes.com/tmagazine, an even larger audience can enjoy our pages. But pages are not part of the virtual world, and that's a challenge. Much of what you see on the Web is visually unpleasant, busy and clunky. How could we make the virtual experience as sensual as the written one? We've worked on that task for months, and now you can judge the results. What we've attempted to create is a total immersive experience. Not just a place to go for information, though surely there's plenty of that, but also a place where you can be seduced by an image, a story and those special qualities that the Web can deliver: sound and movement. On our Web site, you will find everything that appears in our magazine, and much more: videos by artists and filmmakers, original interactive features and The Moment, a blog full of style discoveries, news and T's trademark wit, updated at least five times a day. Just as T has been editing the best in contemporary culture -- in fashion, art, design and travel -- T online will be your way to experience the best of the Web, put together by the same people we hope you already trust.
Dance Jack Anderson

REED--Dr. Charles E., 94, passed away on November 16, 2007 at his home in Bridgeport, CT. He was a retired General Electric Research and Development Center scientist. He joined GE in 1942 and contributed to the company's work in engineered materials. He was appointed Senior Vice President of Corporate Technology in 1971 and retired from GE in 1978 after 36 years of service in various capacities. Dr. Reed was born and raised in Findlay, Ohio. He attended Case Institute of Technology where he received his B.S. in chemical engineering in 1934. He received his Sc.D. degree from Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1937, in the same discipline. During his career at GE, he worked in various disciplines; silicone development, artificial diamonds, and engineering plastics. He was awarded the nation's highest technology honor, The National Medal of Technology, presented by President George Herbert Walker Bush in 1991. He holds many patents in silicone manufacturing and is the recipient of other numerous professional awards. He was a member of the U.S. National Academy of Engineering. He is also the coauthor of Applied Mathematics in Chemical Engineering. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the Biological Energy Corp. He has created numerous endowment funds with his philanthropic gifts to institutions of higher learning, as well as to many of his favorite charities and organizations. A memorial service will be held in Westport, CT. on December 2, 2007, 2:00pm at the Westport Unitarian Church. In lieu of flowers please submit any donations to the Westport Unitarian Church at 10 Lyons Plain Road, Westport, CT 06880. His inspiration and words of encouragement will be missed by his family and friends.

The wind was picking up, and Dick went out to check on his boat. Tipsy ran ahead, standing on his hind legs snapping at raindrops. Dick was relieved to find that the cover was fastened, tight as a drum. He watched the rain bounce off the taut canvas. The boat danced on the choppy waves. He tied and retied the line that stretched from the bow to the cleat on the dock. He listened to the groans and squeaks as the boat nudged the rubber bumpers along the wood. He stood for a long time, staring out at the craggy, gray sea while the dog whined, tired of the wet and the wind. Rain ran down Dick's face, and he wiped his eyes with the back of his hand. The boat tossed wildly, a glistening lipstick red in the indeterminate cloud of sea and rainy, overcast sky. '' 'Alone, alone, all, all alone, alone on a wide wide sea!' '' a voice behind him recited.
Hartsdale, Nov. 23.

MANY homeowners are surviving the subprime mortgage crisis with little anxiety, but this could change as collateral damage spreads. According to a recent report by the Center for Responsible Lending, a credit advocacy group in Durham, N.C., more than 44 million homeowners could experience a decline in the value of their properties of about $5,000 on average over the next two years because of foreclosures in their neighborhoods.

MILLNER--Murray, 82, of heart failure on November 16th, 2007. His wife Ida, daughter Jan, a broadcast news reporter, son-in-law, Mike Zimet, grandsons Darren and Bradley Hecht, brothers Hy, Joe and sister Shirley survive him. A longtime resident of Jericho, NY, and Pembroke Pines, FL, he was co-founder of the Jericho Jewish Center. He and his wife moved to Lake Worth, FL, in 2004. Murray Millner, son of Esther and David Millner came to this country in 1925 from Warsaw, Poland. He was a self-made family man of integrity, honor, and old-fashioned values, with a great sense of humor, and a lifetime interest in history and politics. A WWII veteran of the 71st Infantry, he helped liberate the concentration camps of Strubing and Gunskirken Lager. In 1945, he was awarded the Bronze Star.

9 P.M. (Sci Fi) TIN MAN They're off to see the wizard -- make that the Mystic Man (Richard Dreyfuss) -- in this darkly reimagined version of ''The Wizard of Oz.'' This time around it's the O.Z., as in Outer Zone, where DG (Zooey Deschanel, second from left above, as a motorcycle-mama Dorothy) winds up after riding the tail of a tornado from Kansas to an alternate universe. Her sidekicks in this three-part series include the zipped-up Glitch (Alan Cumming, left above, as a sort of scarecrow); the half-human, half-wolverine psychic Raw (Raoul Trujillo, right above, channeling the cowardly lion); and, in the title role, Neal McDonough, second from right above, as an ex-cop who spent years imprisoned in a metal suit. Kathleen Robertson is Azkadellia, the evil sorceress who holds the O.Z. hostage. 8 P.M. (HBO) MR. WARMTH: THE DON RICKLES PROJECTJohn Landis directed this 90-minute documentary, which celebrates the life and times of one of America's most acerbic -- and enduring -- funny men. Among the highlights: Mr. Rickles's appearances on ''The Tonight Show,'' on Dean Martin's celebrity roasts and, more recently, at the Stardust Hotel in Las Vegas. Dave Attell, Roseanne Barr, Roger Corman, Billy Crystal, Robert De Niro, Clint Eastwood, Whoopi Goldberg, Jay Leno, Richard Lewis, Bob Newhart, Carl Reiner, Joan Rivers, the Smothers Brothers and Robin Williams testify to Mr. Rickles's inspiration.

PRUDENT--Dr. Jacques H., expired at Huntington Hospital on November 26, 2007 after a prolonged illness. Dr. Prudent was born on August 7, 1952 in Haiti, graduated from State University of Haiti College of Medicine and completed residency training at Interfaith Medical Center. He joined the Medical Staff at Coler-Goldwater Hospital in 1984 and provided distinguished service throughout his tenure. Dr. Prudent chaired many Medical Staff Committees and was the President of Medical Staff during 2002 and 2003, as well as President of Roosevelt Island Medical Associates, P.C. from 1997 to 1999. His friendly personality, unflappable calm and willingness to extend himself to help other colleagues will be greatly missed. Kind words were the only words Jacques would speak and in doing so, has touched many lives. He is survived by his wife, Gladys, and children, Jacques Jr., Ronald and Christina. Funeral services will be held on December 1, 2007, at 9:30am at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, Garden City, NY. With heartfelt condolences to the Prudent family from friends and colleagues. Coler-Goldwater Medical Staff and RIMA, P.C.

THE NEWS Young people armed with rocks, firebombs and shotguns clashed with police over two nights in a northern suburb of Paris, injuring more than 80 officers. BEHIND THE NEWS The riots erupted in Villiers-le-Bel, about 12 miles from Paris, after two teenagers on a motorbike died in a collision with a police car. The clashes echoed on a smaller scale the uprisings that swept Paris's lower-class suburbs for three weeks in 2005. Some 1,000 riot police restored order by midweek but tensions remained. ''The suburbs are like tinderboxes,'' said one mayor. ''You have people in terrible social circumstances ... and all you need is one spark to set them on fire.''

BLOOM--Bernard S., beloved husband of the late Pansy Modell Bloom, died peacefully at home on November 29, 2007. He was the adored father of Peggy and David Gershon, Robin and David Gelles, Heidi and Kenneth Glass. He was the proud grandfather of Jessica and Michael Kay, Rachel and Daniel Mishkin, Alisha and Ronald Cipriano, Stefanie and Matthew Gelles, Jared and Brandon Glass and the great-grandfather of Evan Kay. He was predeceased by two brothers, Joseph and Aaron and two sisters, Frieda and Roslyn. He was the loving brother-in-law of Arthur and Pat Modell and Selma Rosen. Bernie will always be remembered for his deep commitment to his Jewish faith having served as past president of Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn, NY, as well as a board member for over 50 years. He was extremely principled and honorable and was a phenomenal support for his loved ones, sharing his profound wisdom and ethics. His memory will live as a blessing for all who knew him. A mourning period will be observed at his home, 38 Pinewood Road, Roslyn, starting Sunday afternoon, December 2, through Friday, December 7, at 1pm.

MALONEY--Elizabeth M., 85, died peacefully on November 21, 2007 with family in Wilmington, NC. Survived by sister and brother-in-law Theresa and William Rideout of Cheyenne, WY, nieces Jeanne, Mary, Martha, Barbara and Nancy and nephews Richard and William. Also survived by devoted friends Mary and Nancy. Born in Upstate New York on September 5, 1922, she received a diploma in nursing from St. Elizabeth Hospital in 1943 and served in the Army Nurse Corps in France during World War II. On leave she fell in love with Paris, returning many times including in May of this year. After discharge, she began a more than 40 year association with Teachers College, Columbia University, NYC. She earned a B.S., M.A. and Ed.D and served as faculty, director of the psychiatric nursing program and Chair of the Department of Nursing Education until her retirement in 1993. She was a leader in the field of graduate nursing education and influential in psychiatric nursing on a national level as consultant, lecturer, author and editor of Perspectives in Psychiatric Care. Her friends, students and colleagues will miss her wry humor and wisdom. She was cherished and will be remembered by loved ones for a life lived extraordinarily well.

SOME musicians spend years working on their studios, trying to make a homey space they'll want to keep forever. But the Grammy-nominated producer Brian Burton, right, who is also known as Danger Mouse and half of the alt-pop duo Gnarls Barkley, thinks a temporary setup keeps him most creative. ''I change spaces all the time,'' he said. ''Every four or five months.'' He said that he has always moved around a lot, so the idea of being unsettled ''kind of creeps into relaxing me when I work.'' But his current studio in Los Angeles still bears some personal touches, like a boxing-themed bathroom and a wall plastered with quirky images and cryptic notes to himself. ''Sometimes I stare at things on the wall when I'm getting tired, in the hopes that they'll make more sense to me when I wake up,'' he said. ''Some people think it's weird, but that's the way I work.''

You don't have to be a megacollector to commission a portrait, but it helps. ''I wouldn't do one unless the person really interests me,'' says Marilyn Minter, who recently painted Stephanie Seymour. Francesco Clemente

Q: Your novel ''Atonement'' -- the story of Briony Tallis, a novelist who tells a lie in her girlhood and hurts her older sister in a way for which she can never atone -- hasbeen made into a film, and I was surprised to see that you are the executiveproducer. Most novelists run from film, afraid that the care they lavished ontheir prose will be squandered. I know. Well, it will be squandered whether they run or not. So why are you the executive producer? So I could stay involved but not write the screenplay. I refused to write the screenplay. I didn't want people sitting around a table -- a producer, a director -- telling me that I hadn't fully understood these characters.

CAVALLARO--Rosina Rosina Cavallaro passed away on October 29, 2007 at the age of 96. She was a New York City school teacher for nearly 40 years and a devoted sister and aunt. As many first generation immigrants Rosina acheived the American dream. Rosina was born in an East Harlem tenement in 1911 shortly after her parents arrived from Italy. Before WWI, her parents brought Rosina to Italy for a visit. After the outbreak of the War, her father was drafted into the Italian Army. The family was unable to return to the U.S. until 1921. At age 10, unable to speak English, Rosina entered the NYC Public Schools. She progressed rapidly to graduate with honors. After High School graduation, rosina entered Hunter College and again graduated with honors. She began her long teaching career as a substitute teacher and, in 1939, obtained a permanent teaching position in the New York City School System as a High School teacher of Italian, French and Spanish. Early in her career, Rosina attended Columbia University Teacher's College at night and received a Masters Degree in Romance languages. Rosina taught in a number of NYC High Schools but spent most of her career at the Evander Childs High School in the Bronx. She was beloved and endeared by many colleagues and students. After her retirement in 1973, many who knew her maintained contact until the last years of her life. Rosina was a life long resident of the Bronx, living in the family home on Morrison Avenue, in Parkchester and, in later years, Fort Schuyler House in Throgs Neck. Rosina had many scholarly and cultural interests. She was a generous donor to religious and social organizations during her life. Rosina was an active member of the Casa Italiana and The American Association of Italian Teachers. She was an avid opera fan and held subscription seats to the New York City Metropolitan Opera for more than two decades. She toured Europe and the U.S. frequently. Rosina is survived by her brother Salvatore and his wife Claire Cavallaro of Glen Head, NY; nieces Sahli Cavallaro of Albany, NY, Claire Cavallaro of Fullerton, CA, Mary Waddle of New Rochelle, NY, Angela Merindino of Sommers, NY, nephew Michael Cavallaro of Sleepy Hollow, NY; greatnephews Paul Waddle of Katonah, NY, Anthony Waddle of Lake Worth, FL, William Caplenor of Northridge, CA; and great-greatnieces and nephews Joseph, Enrico and Marisa.

MURRAY--Sir James, KCMG, 88, on November 28, 2007, survived by his wife Jill, his stepdaughters Sophie Chapuisat Smith and Tanya Soler Chapuisat, his stepgrandchildren Lucas, Natacha, and Kai, his nieces Catherine Perry and Sheila Taplin, and nephew Philip Murray of the United Kingdom. Born on the Isle of Arran (Scotland), Sir James served in the Royal Regiment of Artillery in Burma and India during World War II. Joining HM Foreign Service in 1947, his distinguished career included significant responsibilities in Egypt, Canada, France, Indonesia, and the European Community. Sir James was Consul General in San Francisco; he served as Ambassador to Rwanda and Burundi, and to the United Nations both in Geneva and New York, as well as Special Envoy of five western governments for negotiations regarding the independence of Namibia. In retirement, he was the Withrow Professor of Government at Deep Springs College in California, and actively involved with the Congressional Award Foundation, the Center for Migration Studies, and Auburn University. A Memorial Reception for family and friends will be held on December 11th at 5pm at The Brook.

GORDON--Richard, M.D., died November 29, 2007 from complications of A.L.S. Richard graduated C.C.N.Y. in 1957 and the N.Y.U. School of Medicine in 1961 where he was later a member of the Radiology faculty for 36 years. He was also a staff radiologist at the NY V.A. hospital for 38 years. He concluded his career at Harlem and Lincoln hospitals. From 1952 to 1959 he traveled widely as a member of the National Maritime Union, working prior to college and then subsequent summers, as an Ordinary Seaman on freighters and passenger ships which also helped finance his education. Richard was an avid bicyclist and together with his wife enjoyed multiple trips through Europe and Costa Rica. He is survived by his devoted and caring wife, Becca, and son, Reed, and his wife, Meredith, whose attention to him during his illness was monumental. Also surviving are a brother Harold, and his wife, Carole, stepsons Matthew and Paul and his wife Julie, stepdaughters Suzan and her husband Chris, Amey and her husband Tsaka, grandchildren and very close friends Bob and Lorriane, Wade and Rosemarie and Larry and Lucy. Donations in his name may be made to the Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Association, 116 John St., Suite 1304, New York, NY 10038.

SLAUSON--Sidney. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Sidney Slauson of Palm Beach, Florida. Mr. Slauson provided exemplary leadership and support during his many years of involvement with the ATS. He was a past member of the national Board of Directors, a Life Trustee of the Board of Regents at the time of his death, and president of the Palm Beach Chapter, which he continued to serve for many years as a senior statesman. He was also an honorary life member of the Technion International Board of Governors. A successful attorney, Mr. Slauson was a high-ranking official with the USO during World War II and the Korean War. The Gail Slauson Flatto Scholarship Fund and the Emergency Fund for Technion Students -as well as many endeavors of the Palm Beach Chapter -were among the many Technion projects he supported. To his daughter Gail Flatto, grandson Adam and the entire Flatto family, we give our heartfelt condolences. American Technion Society Joan Seidel, President Stephen A. Laser, Chairman Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Louise Goldberg, Palm Beach Chapter President Ileane Rayman-Kaufman, Palm Beach Chapter Director

MILLER--Irene Ardleigh, of Rye, New York, passed away on November 28, 2007 after a long and courageous battle against cancer. Irene was a self - educated woman, schooling herself in the classics and opera. She was an active sports woman, accomplished equestrian and an outstanding swimmer. In her early years, she could be seen at the helm of her beloved sailboat, Indigo. She loved to take long walks in the countryside and work in her garden. She was a needlepoint and cross stitching expert. For many years she provided loving and tender home care for the Miller family. Irene particularly enjoyed her time on Little Saint Simon's Island in Georgia. She was predeceased by her beloved husband Edmund earlier this year. Succeeded by her sons Paul Ardleigh and his wife Linda of Larchmont, NY; Carl Ardleigh and his wife Ila of Boca Raton, FL; Christopher Ardleigh of Charlottesville, VA; grandchildren Kristen Chadwick, Erin Ardleigh, Kerry McCollough, Katherine Ardleigh, Meghan Ardleigh, and her greatgrandchildren Tyler and Avery Chadwick. Services will be held December 3rd, 11am at Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home, Mama roneck, NY. Burial at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery in Tarrytown. A reception will follow at Gus's Restaurant in Harrison. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Rosenthal Hospice Res idence, Stamford, CT, who made Irene's last days comfortable and dignified.

The New York State Toxic Mold Task Force will hold its first meeting on Tuesday, in Latham, N.Y. The panel represents an attempt by health officials and medical experts to address what they describe as a growing but little-recognized mold problem that has damaged property and affected the health of tenants, homeowners and their children.

The penetration of mandatory iPods in secondary and higher education has been growing. Duke University has issued the music players to incoming freshmen. The Brearley School, a private school for girls in Manhattan, has required iPods for homework and classroom assignments. And the school district in Union City, N.J., has issued 300 iPods to bilingual students with limited English skills to improve their English vocabulary and grammar.

The decision to add Walter F. O’Malley to the Baseball Hall of Fame is expected to draw predictable griping from ardent Brooklyn Dodgers fans who lament the team’s departure to Los Angeles in 1957 — even if they were not alive when it happened.

The New York City comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., warned today that the local economy is “at a turning point,” and predicted that the city could face a budget gap of more than $6 billion in the fiscal year that starts in July 2010 — the first year that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s successor will be in office.In a City Charter-mandated report on the city’s economy and finances, Mr. Thompson warned: “Turmoil in the nation’s housing and mortgage markets has reverberated through the financial sector, threatening to produce a marked slowdown in local economic activity. The principal threat to both the national and local economies is the unfolding subprime mortgage debacle and its collateral effects on credit markets. The resulting financial losses and layoffs are likely to fall disproportionately on New York firms and workers.”

Santa Claus has set up shop in the 10001 ZIP Code, though addressing an envelope to “Santa Claus New York,” “Santa’s Workshop, North Pole” or just plain “Santa” is enough to land a letter in the hands of Santa’s helpers.

Fighting decreased by 20 percent in New York City schools from 2003 to 2005, but dating-related violence is on the rise. The new report, “Teen Safety in New York City,” described trends in youth violence and showed an association between violence and other health risks — both for victims and for aggressors.

The State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, the state’s top Republican, was asked by City Room this afternoon about his other salaried position — his job at a Connecticut-based investment company, the Winthrop Corporation, which was the subject of a Times article on Saturday. The State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, is not on good terms with the other two state leaders. That’s putting it mildly. This afternoon, he held a news conference to chastise Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver for stalling on an agreement over who will run the state’s three thoroughbred tracks when the New York Racing Association’s contract expires at the end of the year. Mr. Bruno is at a disadvantage in the talks, because Saratoga Race Course is in the heart of his district and thus the issue is a far higher priority for him than the other two men who run the state.

The National Weather Service has issued a wind advisory for the late afternoon and evening, warning of west winds between 23 and 28 miles per hour, with gusts as high as 45 m.p.h. There were reports of pedestrians struck by objects falling off Midtown buildings, including the new headquarters of The Times.There have been sustained winds from 25 to 35 m.p.h. throughout the five boroughs, with Kennedy International Airport reporting winds of up to 46 m.p.h. around 1 p.m. “We do have a wind advisory out until 7 a.m. tomorrow,” said Matthew Tauber, a meteorologist with the weather service. “We are looking at these winds continuing throughout tonight.”

Even in an era of rampant brand extension, there is something incongruous about the sight of a Brooks Brothers store at Broadway and 65th Street, which was still “West Side Story” territory in the days when Brooks was outfitting John F. Kennedy in sack suits.You could say, cynically, that this is merely a sign that the venerable clothier is now no more than a Banana Republic chain for the next-higher income bracket. Or you could say that Brooks Brothers is really returning to its roots, since it conducted business on Broadway from 1858 to 1915, moving steadily uptown all the while.
Did Diane Sawyer really refer to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg as a “munchkin” this morning on national television? Indeed she did.

In Science Times this week, I have a story examining the limits of language. Can scientists or anyone else find new words sufficiently potent to inspire action on long-term challenges, like shifting from unfettered use of coal and oil to limit the odds of climate surprises?

The Rangers did not need Carolina center Matt Cullen to show them how good an offensive player he can be, but that is just what happened in Monday night's 4-0 loss to the Hurricanes. Cullen, whom the Rangers traded in the offseason for two players who may never play for them and a draft pick, had two assists, giving him 21 this season to go with six goals.

On Monday, two broadcast networks, CBS and NBC, gave the clearest indication to date of how their programming schedules were being affected by the four-week writers' strike. CBS said it would introduce several new reality shows and midseason replacements beginning in January, including the first winter season ever of the reality show "Big Brother."

"The Education of Henry Adams" is not really an autobiography. As the author himself confesses several dozen pages from the end, it is the modern omega to the medieval alpha (his book "Mont-Saint-Michel and Chartres") in his project to contrast long-ago cohesion with latter-day multiplicity. "The Education" is a treatise, an elegant, patrician apogee to the fine American tradition of cranks putting forth literary explanations for the whole universe, of which their own country is a strangely exceptional precinct. Adams's "Dynamic Theory of History," developed during a decade in which he was also playing with magnets and seeking revelation in the statistics of coal production, proceeds from a late-life awareness of himself a "a conscious ball of vibrating motions, traversed in every direction by infinite lines of rotation or vibration." His discovery that, as of 1900, the world would "not be a unity but a multiple" freed him to write a memoir whose own ever-increasing entropy could be rationalized as a shape to suit the times.

He has made Albany and his stewardship of the state such big news that Vanity Fair and The New Yorker both have huge profiles on him in their big holiday issues that have just come out.

U.C.L.A. fired Karl Dorrell today after the Bruins finished the regular season with a 6-6 record. The Bruins will face B.Y.U. in the Las Vegas Bowl on Dec. 22, though the university has not said who will be the coach of the team for that game. In the next few months, college football fans are going to be hearing a lot more about the "Plus One" system as an alternative for the college football postseason. In numerous conversations with college football power brokers over the past year, it's become very clear that the Bowl Championship Series meetings this April in Miami will be a critical time to see whether or not the Plus One will be implemented in 2011. Mike Slive, the coordinator of the B.C.S., has nudged the issue to the forefront lately by asking the question: "Is two enough?" He means is having two teams with a shot at the national title enough anymore. Certainly a legitimate question this season.

In the timeless category of, "If it's too good to be true, it probably isn't," a remarkably sophisticated, but fake, news release and Web link went out to the media this morning proclaiming that the Climate Action Partnership -- a who's who of big corporations, from Alcan to Xerox -- had pledged essentially to turn off their emissions in the next 50 years (a 90 percent cut by 2050). Retirement ceremonies for career American diplomats tend to be predictable, decorous affairs reflecting the skills of envoys who have spent years perfecting the fine art of defending often indefensible Washington policies abroad. But when Michael Guest, a former ambassador to Romania, closed out his quarter-century career recently he did what few people do - displayed uncommon courage and threw a rhetorical hand-grenade into his own party.

Now we're fixated on Loic Prigent's film, "Marc Jacobs & Louis Vuitton," which recently came out on DVD in Paris and will be shown Stateside on the Sundance Channel at the end of January. The film was made after a year's unfettered access to the designer and his work process (beaucoup de all-nighters, ponderous brain-storming sessions and Tiger's Milk energy bars). Admittedly, the translation is a bit choppy and the point-of-view sometimes verges on wide-eyed, but there are some brilliant moments. We nearly broke our DVD player's rewind button to get the following details on the ultimate fashion insider's bag-the so-called "emergency bag" all models receive before the Louis Vuitton show in Paris. The Vuitton baggies are a million miles removed from the little ones we're used to seeing backstage, and contain...

In his weekly DealBook column, Andrew Ross Sorkin takes a look at the somewhat strange tradition of top-tier law firms matching each other virtually dollar for dollar on new bonuses. The tradition, he says, is out of step with many other businesses such as investment banks -- lawyers' closest business cousins -- which typically pay their people based on merit and the health of their own businesses, while still being competitive in a down year.

John Thain, who begins his new job as Merrill Lynch's chief executive on Monday, told The Financial Times that he wants to remake Merrill's management culture to look more like that of Goldman Sachs, where he once worked.

Swiss Life surprised investors on Monday with plans to buy AWD, the dynamic German financial advisory group, hard on the heels of big disposals in recent weeks.

SK Telecom, South Korea's largest cellular carrier, said Monday it has agreed to buy a controlling 38.89 percent stake in broadband and telephone service provider Hanarotelecom for 1.09 trillion won ($1.2 billion), equipping itself to challenge the country's biggest fixed-line operator, KT, following deregulation next year that will allow telecom companies to offer bundled services.

When the Blackstone Group closed it $39 billion deal for Samuel Zell'sEquity Office Properties earlier this year, it was the largest leveraged buyout ever. But, says The Deal.com, that was only half the remarkable story.

If there is one issue that most of us will face, it is likely to be the need or desire to spend time with an aging relative or close friend. I have a 93-year-old grandmother who lives a remarkably independent life. She lives in and cares for her own home, prepares her own meals and does most of her own food shopping. Until two years ago, when she gracefully agreed not to use her car anymore, she also drove. What she wants and needs most is company, and she never fails to recognize how busy all of us "young people" around her are even as my mother, my two cousins and I do our best to visit each week. We are the lucky ones. My grandmother is relatively healthy and autonomous, and we are able to enjoy the time we spend with her. I also have a flexible working life, so if I visit her on a Tuesday, I can work on a Saturday to make up for it.

In 1982, John J. Mack, now the chief executive of Morgan Stanley, interviewed a fresh-faced Harvard Business School graduate named Zoe Cruz for an associate position in the firm's bond trading business. With his support, she flew higher in the investment bank, rising to the level of co-president and Mr. Mack's heir apparent.

Li Ka-shing may have agreed to write a $60 million check to help Facebook founder and chief executive Mark Zuckerberg build out his fast-growing social networking site, but a media company controlled by the Hong Kong billionaire denies that the money went through them.
The market value of mining giant Rio Tinto continues to outstrip the multibillion dollar bid put forward by rival BHP Billiton, Rio's Chief Executive Tom Albanese said Sunday.

Italy's Eni has agreed to buy oil explorer Burren Energy for 1.736 billion pounds ($3.58 billion), boosting the oil major's operations in the Republic of Congo and giving it a toehold in Turkmenistan, where a new leadership is warming to foreign investment.
FL Group, the Icelandic investment firm that had pressed American Airlines parent AMR to sell off assets, is now washing its hands of the company.

Consorte Media, a Hispanic online media company, said Monday that it received $7 million in a round of venture investment led by Sutter Hill Ventures. The Series B round also included the Mayfield Fund, a return investor.

U.S. intelligence agencies may scuttle Bain Capital's $2.2 billion cash buyout of 3Com, announced in September, because of concerns about the role of Chinese minority investor Huawei Technologies, The Washington Times reported.

The European Central Bank said that it would extend a lending deadline in December to help the banking system through a period of unusually tight credit at the end of the year, The New York Times reported. The action represents a renewed effort by the bank to calm a lending system that had showed signs of returning to normal recently but now appears nearly as nervous as during the summer days when the global credit turmoil began.

William Ackman may be incapable of giving short answers, if his hourlong presentation at an investment conference last Wednesday is any sign. But the activist hedge fund manager is nothing if not persistent.

Genentech’s drug Avastin did not help women with breast cancer live meaningfully longer, and it caused significant side effects, including a few deaths, the F.D.A. said today.

Here is the text of a statement issued today by Stephen Hadley, President Bush’s national security adviser, concerning the new National Intelligence Estimate on Iran’s nuclear weapons program. The intelligence estimate says that, contrary to previous assessments, Iran halted the program in 2003 in response to international pressure and has probably not restarted it since then, though it has the capacity to do so.

A new assessment by American intelligence agencies, which concludes that Iran’s weapons program is on hold, contradicts a report two years ago that Tehran was working inexorably toward building a bomb.

Frank Lickliter II shot a four-under 68 at Orange County National to take a five-stroke lead after the fifth of six rounds at the PGA Tour National Qualifying Tournament in Winter Garden, Fla. The top 25 finishers and ties in the 166-man field will earn 2008 PGA Tour cards.

The defending World Cup champion Italy was drawn with France, the Netherlands and Romania in what appears to be the most difficult first-round group for Euro 2008. The tournament opens June 7. The final is in Vienna on June 29.

Daisuke Takahashi won the NHK Trophy men’s figure skating event in Sendai, Japan, to close out the Grand Prix series. Takahashi, who also won Skate America this season, will join Evan Lysacek, Johnny Weir and 16-year-old Patrick Chan in the Grand Prix finals in two weeks in Turin, Italy.

Martina Schild battled biting cold and a slick track in Lake Louise, Alberta, in winning the season-opening women’s super-G in 1 minute 16.21 seconds for her first World Cup victory. Lindsey Vonn, formerly Lindsey Kildow, who won Saturday’s downhill, fell, hit a gate and slid into the fencing. Vonn said she was sore and bruised but not seriously injured.

Second baseman Kazuo Matsui completed a three-year, $16.5 million contract with the Houston Astros yesterday, a little more than a month after helping the Colorado Rockies to their first World Series appearance. Matsui, a 32-year-old switch-hitter, batted .288 and stole 32 bases last season. Houston stole only 65 bases, the third fewest in the National League.

Russia qualified for next year’s Beijing Olympics at the expense of the United States with a five-game victory against the Americans on the final day of the men’s World Cup in Tokyo. The United States can still reach the Olympics through other qualifiers, including a regional qualifier Jan. 5-13 in Puerto Rico.

Jane Park, the 2004 United States amateur champion, completed a wire-to-wire victory at the L.P.G.A. Final Qualifying Tournament in Daytona Beach, Fla. Seventeen players earned full 2008 playing status. Park had a 17-under-par 274 total.

Michael Rasmussen said he considered suicide after he was kicked out of the Tour de France this year for lying about his whereabouts to avoid doping tests.Rasmussen wore the leader’s yellow jersey and won the 16th stage before being removed from the race July 25. He told the Dutch daily De Telegraaf in weekend editions: “On the other side of the road, trucks kept passing us. It would have been easy to grab the steering wheel. Then this terrible nightmare would have been over.”.

Baltimore’s defense is ranked third against the run, but New England is most dangerous when Tom Brady is passing, and the Ravens have been much more pedestrian in that area. The Eagles were successful last week by being physical with Brady and his receivers; the Ravens have a reputation for playing the same way. It could be cold and windy at game time, so Willis McGahee could see extra carries. He has 910 yards this season, but he has never scored against the Patriots and has never played on a team that has defeated them. Losing Rosevelt Colvin for the season was the first serious injury for New England this year. Then again, the Ravens, who have lost five in a row and average 23.7 fewer points a game than the Patriots, may not be able to take advantage of his absence. ANDREW DAS.

FINE--Janet, 56, journalist and author, died peacefully and surrounded by love on November 24th, 2007 in Mumbai, India. Janet's generous spirit and giving heart touched hundreds of people throughout the world. She made us laugh; she made us care; she opened the door and invited us to join her on great adventures and unconventional journeys. Janet is survived by her sisters Carla, Ellen and Jill, and her nephews Ben and Jono. She was preceded in death by her beloved parents Lillian and Benjamin Fine. A memorial gathering to celebrate Janet's incredible and wondrous life will be held at 2pm on Sunday, December 9th, 2007 at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

THOMSON--Barbara it is with great sorrow that we mourn the passing of our dear friend Barbara Thomson. Barbara was a bright, vivacious lady. Her intellect, variety of interests, and charm made spending time with her a pure pleasure. Unfortunately all of this was suspended to early in her life. For Malcolm her dedicated husband our condolences and wishes that he be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and may her memories be a blessing and an inspiration. Ingeborg and Ira Leon Rennert THOMSON--Barbara Ellin Schiffman Parker Thomson, age 66, died on Saturday, December 1, 2007 at New York Presbyterian Hospital after a long battle with multiple sclerosis. Mrs. Thomson is survived by her husband, Malcolm Thomson, her children Jean Parker Hill, Steve Parker and Arthur Parker, her grandchildren Amanda Hill, Clara Hill, Eve Parker and Izzy Parker and her sisters Marilyn Oser and Joanne Kirschenbaum. Mrs. Thomson was formerly married to Robert Parker. Services will be held at 11:45am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel. Interment will be at Temple Sholom Cemetery, Greenwich, Connecticut. Shiva will be observed at her home and the home of her daughter at 750 West 232nd St., Bronx, NY all day and evening, and will also be observed from 6:30pm to 9:00pm each evening at the home of Malcolm Thomson, 880 Fifth Ave., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in honor of Barbara Thomson to the Multiple Sclerosis Society.

SISKIND--Teri. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Teri Siskind, whose long and exemplary life served as a model for her family and our community. Her son Alan served brilliantly as executive VP of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, one of the flagship beneficiary agencies of UJAFederation. And her son Arthur, who served as a chair of our Entertainment, Media & Communications Division, has been widely honored for his valued counsel and leadership. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Teri's family; her children, Alan and Marla, Arthur and Mary Ann, and Carol; her grandchildren; her great-grandchildren; her sister, Evelyn; and the entire family. GORDON--Richard, M.D., died November 29, 2007 from complications of A.L.S. Richard graduated C.C.N.Y. in 1957 and the N.Y.U. School of Medicine in 1961 where he was later a member of the Radiology faculty for 36 years. He was also a staff radiologist at the NY V.A. hospital for 38 years. He concluded his career at Harlem and Lincoln hospitals. From 1952 to 1959 he traveled widely as a member of the National Maritime Union, working prior to college and then subsequent summers, as an Ordinary Seaman on freighters and passenger ships which also helped finance his education. Richard was an avid bicyclist and together with his wife enjoyed multiple trips through Europe and Costa Rica. He is survived by his devoted and caring wife, Becca, and son, Reed, and his wife, Meredith, whose attention to him during his illness was monumental. Also surviving are a brother Harold, and his wife, Carole, stepsons Matthew and Paul and his wife Julie, stepdaughters Suzan and her husband Chris, Amey and her husband Tsaka, grandchildren and very close friends Bob and Lorriane, Wade and Rosemarie and Larry and Lucy. Donations in his name may be made to the Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Association, 116 John St., Suite 1304, New York, NY 10038.

LAINOFF--Irwin, died November 29, 2007, at the age of 77. He is survived by Carole, his beloved wife of 55 years. He is also survived by his two sons, Steven and Michael, their wives, Riea and Kathryn, by five adored grandchildren: Caitlin, Brian, Mark, Lillie, and Charles, and by his brother, Eliot. Mr. Lainoff was a retired general partner at the investment firm Neuberger & Berman, where he managed mutual funds, pension, and other accounts, and served on the firm's executive committee. Before that, among other things, he was a finance editor and reporter at Business Week and also wrote for other publications. Mr. Lainoff was active in many civic, community, and religious organizations. To name a few, he was Board Chair for The Brooklyn Academy of Music's Endowment Trust, and had been a President of Brooklyn's Congregation Beth Elohim. He also created scholarships for students at Columbia University's School of Journalism, and endowed a prize for students of literary fiction at Brooklyn College. In 2001, he and his wife were recognized for their contributions to the Borough of Brooklyn with an award from the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts. He was a wonderful husband, father, and friend, and he will be deeply missed and always remembered.

Verizon's Move To Openness Verizon Wireless got a lot of attention last Tuesday for its vague announcement about offering open access to its network. But a much more technical announcement today may well be more important.

The endorsement yesterday of Senator John McCain by New Hampshire's largest newspaper, The New Hampshire Union Leader of Manchester, is an undeniable boost for his campaign, which is counting on a victory in that state to propel them forward. But like so much with the Republican race this year, it is hard to gauge the impact. The newspaper and its publisher, Joseph W. McQuaid, are among the most respected conservative voices in the state. In the past, the paper's support has bolstered candidates, but the candidates whom it endorses have a mixed track record.

Mitt Romney's two-front war in Iowa and New Hampshire became more difficult on Sunday, as a Republican abortion-rights group began an advertising offensive against him, attacking him as a flip-flopper on the issue. The 30-second spot, started by Republican Majority for Choice, highlights some of Mr. Romney's statements on abortion, starting with a clip from his Senate campaign against Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts in which Mr. Romney, who now says he opposes abortion, pledged support for abortion rights. The group also ran full-page advertisements in The Des Moines Register, The Concord Monitor in New Hampshire and The New Hampshire Union Leader. Jennifer Stockman, one of the group's leaders, donated $2,300 to Rudolph W. Giuliani in May.

Al Gore is not running for president — not yet, anyway, his most ardent supporters would say –- but the campaign to draft him in New York lives, if only on life support, in an apartment on East 84th Street.Yes, the local “Draft Gore” campaign rests in several neat stacks of nomination petitions, on a campaign table next to “Gore for President” buttons, stickers and fliers. The table is in the modest, rent-stabilized apartment of Robert Plautz, 60, a tax lawyer and longtime Democratic activist. Mr. Plautz helped organize a last-ditch effort to put Mr. Gore on the Democratic primary ballot in New York State with a signature-gathering mission to persuade the former vice president to run again.

In the five years since sloppy work in the Police Departent’s crime laboratory, the nation’s busiest, was identified in 2002, some of the evidence has been destroyed, making any new tests very difficult, according to a new review by the state inspector general. From CNET:As if the burden of divorce weren't bad enough, people with failed marriages can be blamed for global warming, according to a study by Michigan State University. Divorced couples use up more space in their respective homes, which amounts to to 38 million more rooms worldwide to light, heat and cool, noted the report. And people who divorced used 73 billion kilowatt-hours more of electricity and 627 billion gallons of water than they would otherwise in 2005. Dissolving a marriage also means doubling possessions, from the lowly can opener to the SUV. The report, however, did not estimate how many more natural resources the children of shared-custody parents consume by getting birthday and holiday gifts twice. Nor did it count the greenhouse gases spent to shuttle kids between their pair of energy-hogging households. Read more here, here and here.

For the second week in a row, the Patriots found their perfect record in jeopardy late in the fourth quarter, but they pulled out a 27-24 victory against the Ravens. (Here are the highlights if you didn't stay up.) The Ravens certainly had the right personnel to follow up on the Eagles' defensive strategy from last week, but who knew their offense would be able to help out, too? Willis McGahee, who said he was playing for his fellow Miami Hurricane Sean Taylor, kept Tom Brady off the field by grinding out 138 yards on 30 carries. It was only the third game this season the Patriots did not lead in time of possession. AOL FanHouse writes that the Ravens' performance shows that the Steelers have a good chance against the Patriots next week because Pittsburgh can copy a lot of what Baltimore did.

After my post yesterday about the challenges of eldercare, I wanted to suggest Web sites that caregivers can use for information and support on a variety of issues. Not surprisingly, the people behind these resources have firsthand experience with eldercare -- just another one of the ways people are shaping their careers based on their own life experiences.AGIS is an online eldercare site founded by Kevin Sypniewski, who has spent a lot of time thinking about caring for those who need extra care. His developmentally disabled brother, who died at 31, needed care throughout his life. His sister is a special education teacher, and his mother worked as a nurse in a special education school district. Mr. Sypniewski helped care for his mother, his stepfather, and most recently for his father, who all died of cancer. "My family was exposed to these issues through a train of close relatives needing care in the late 1990s and early 2000s," he told me. "But it is something all baby boomers will be dealing with."
