Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is not holding takeover discussions with LinkedIn, a fast-growing online social network for professionals, according to Reuters.
After seven months of takeover warfare and the $99.1 billion it took to win ABN Amro, Royal Bank of Scotland may now have do battle with some of the Dutch lender's bankers over loyalty bonuses.

Transocean, the world's largest offshore oil and gas drilling contractor, on Monday said it plans to raise $8.5 billion by issuing debt in order to repay borrowings to pay shareholders in its recent purchase of GlobalSantaFe.

South Koreans have grown tired of the corrupt ways of their big businesses. But because the economy depends so heavily on a handful of them, Koreans fear striking too hard a blow against them. That appears to be the case with the bribery scandal that has rocked manufacturing giant Samsung.

In an effort to limit fallout from the subprime lending crisis in the United States, the German bank WestLB said on Monday that it would guarantee full liquidity to several of its investment vehicles that had put money into asset-backed securities.
Snatches of city street conversation posted at Overheard in New York:

The trial of five senior insurance executives accused of helping the American International Group manipulate its finances through $500 million in fraudulent transactions could put the spotlight not only on Warren E. Buffett, but also A.I.G.'s chairman, Maurice R. Greenberg, who was forced out after nearly four decades, as well as several prominent Wall Street equity analysts.

Those plump Lincoln Town Cars that provide a ride as soft as a pillow are clogging city streets and airport access roads these days - a sign that the $2.4 billion chauffeured transportation business in the United States is doing well, particularly with corporate customers.

BlackRock, the asset management firm hired to advise Florida on a state pool whose subprime-tainted holdings led to withdrawal of almost half its $27 billion assets, recommended Monday that the remaining holdings be split into two entities to ensure the fund's survival.
It's not the freshest video on YouTube, but youth isn't everything:
Photos from the Broadway play "The Farnsworth Invention."
Properties on the market in Vermont, Florida and Wyoming.
The Edmonton Oilers' Sam Gagner, who turned 18 in August, may be the N.H.L.'s youngest player, but he's old enough to school some of the league's best goaltenders in the shootout.
A week after Aberdeen officials rejected his plan for a $2 billion golf course and resort project, Donald Trump is threatening to take his project and go home.
Images from the show at the Howard Greenberg Gallery.

As far as late-game personal fouls go, Bart Scott's meltdown after the Patriots took the lead Monday night didn't have the lose-your-head stupidity of Dwayne Rudd's helmet toss in the Browns' opener in 2002, but answer this:
Matt Cullen returned to the Garden Monday night to play against the Rangers for the first time since leaving the team, and did it well, assisting on the Hurricanes’ first two goals.

In three works presented on Saturday night the choreographers largely espoused the ordinary movement and neutral presentation of odd activities first deployed by artists like Yvonne Rainer and Steve Paxton.
A military official said that there had been four to six incidents of detainees harming themselves in the last two months.
Elizabeth Hardwick was a critic, essayist, fiction writer and a co-founder of The New York Review of Books.
State officials moved to stabilize Florida’s $14 billion local investment pool by placing restrictions on withdrawals to keep the program from going broke.
Once again facing criticism over the handling of intelligence reports, President Bush warned today that Iran remained a threat.
The bank cut its key interest rate Tuesday by a quarter-point, to 4.25 percent, citing concerns about the global effect of the subprime loan crisis in the United States.
High winds and heavy rains caused floods that prompted the governors of Oregon and Washington to declare states of emergency.
The Patriots rallied in the final minutes to come from behind and defeat the sputtering Ravens and hold on to their hopes of a perfect season.

After a 10-year absence and two operations to remove a brain tumor, Todd Demsey finally made it back to the PGA Tour.Demsey, a former N.C.A.A. champion and amateur teammate of Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson, closed with an eight-under-par 64 in the sixth and final round of Q-school in Winter Garden, Fla., to earn one of 26 full-exempt cards next year in the big leagues.Frank Lickliter, who opened with consecutive 62s, completed a wire-to-wire week at Orange County National and finished as the medalist at 29-under 403. He won by four shots over Brett Rumford of Australia.
Despite the enormity of its recurring scandals, Samsung is unlikely to go the way of Enron, in part because of its economic importance to South Korea.

PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 3 — Rutgers was trailing an undefeated team by 5 points, and its leading rebounder and defensive stopper was on the bench with four fouls. It did not look good for the Scarlet Knights — that is, until Epiphanny Prince took over.
Dissecting the Jets’ defense requires dividing the past two seasons into segments: before bye and after bye.

Cristiano Ronaldo scored twice and Manchester United defeated Fulham, 2-0, to reclaim second place in the Premier League. Ronaldo, who finished second to A.C. Milan’s Kaka for the European Golden Ball award Sunday, scored in the 10th and 58th minutes. He has 13 goals in 11 games. Wayne Rooney returned after missing three games for United — as well as two for England — with an ankle injury and partnered with Carlos Tévez in attack.

New Jersey’s public and private high schools will not be split into separate sports leagues. In a close vote, members of the New Jersey Interscholastic Athletic Association rejected a plan to separate the schools for football only and a second plan that would have split up the schools for all sports. The proposal to separate all sports failed by eight votes. The vote to separate only football failed by a wider margin.Critics say private schools have an advantage because they are not limited by attendance boundaries. But smaller public schools say they would have been forced to travel farther if the system were changed.

Sam Vasquez, a 35-year-old fighter from Houston, was injured in a sanctioned bout in his hometown Oct. 20 and died Friday in a hospice. The Harris County Medical Examiner’s Office confirmed Vasquez’s death, but a spokeswoman said it could be several days before the official cause is determined.Vasquez was hospitalized after he was knocked out by Vince Libardi of San Antonio in the third round of a fight at the Renegades Extreme Fighting show. He lost consciousness and had a seizure.

Tim Thomas stopped 33 shots and Glen Murray and Chuck Kobasew scored power-play goals last night for the Boston Bruins, who ended a 10-game winless streak on Long Island with a 3-1 victory over the Islanders.

U.C.L.A. Coach Karl Dorrell was fired yesterday, a day after the Bruins accepted a bowl bid and two days after a loss to their crosstown rival, Southern California. Dorrell, 43, was let go despite leading the Bruins to a postseason game in each of his five seasons at U.C.L.A., which had an outside chance to reach the Rose Bowl before its loss to U.S.C. The firing of Dorrell, who is black, leaves five black head coaches at 119 major college programs.Dorrell had a 35-27 record. U.C.L.A. (6-6) will play Brigham Young (10-2) in the Las Vegas Bowl on Dec. 22. The defensive coordinator DeWayne Walker will be the interim coach.

Hannes Reichelt led an Austrian sweep at a World Cup super-G yesterday, his second straight victory in the discipline on the Birds of Prey course in Beaver Creek, Colo. Austrians captured five of the top six places, while the best United States skier was Ted Ligety in 23rd place. Bode Miller was 30th.

Kris Humphries and Carlos Delfino each scored 17 points and Joey Graham added 13 as the Toronto Raptors shrugged off injuries to three top players to beat the visiting Charlotte Bobcats, 98-79, Monday night.
EBay and Yahoo Japan said Tuesday that they would link up their auction sites to make cross-border bidding easier, in a deal that will give eBay another chance to woo Japanese consumers.
The police found the skeletal remains of a missing woman  in a home in Brooklyn on Monday. How long ago she died was unknown, but neighbors said they had not seen her for about two years.
Wind gusts knocked glass or debris from two skyscrapers in Midtown Monday afternoon, including the new building that houses The New York Times.
The chance of a recession lurks in the background as Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the Legislature prepare to negotiate over how to fill an estimated $4.3 billion budget gap.
Penny Lane, a million-dollar showcase scheduled to be unveiled on Monday, is a plan to pave a New York City street with copper to raise money for charity.

Rick Noriega, a five-term Democratic state lawmaker, formally began his bid to unseat Senator John Cornyn, making it clear that he would use his stature as a National Guard officer to criticize the Iraq war.

A jury began deliberations in the trial of seven Miami men accused of plotting to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago and wage a religiously motivated war against the United States government. Prosecutors, drawing on evidence collected in an eight-month investigation, have said the men were trying to get financial support from Al Qaeda to conduct an armed jihad. But defense lawyers have insisted their clients were entrapped by undercover F.B.I. agents and played along to raise money to build a construction business and a local religious mission..
A man accused of taking hostages at Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign office in Rochester was arraigned on six felony charges, including kidnapping and criminal threatening.

A man who killed the family of two young siblings and then sexually abused the children before killing one of them at a remote Montana campsite pleaded guilty to federal charges that could lead to his execution. The man, Joseph E. Duncan III, had earlier pleaded guilty to state charges and was sentenced to life in prison without parole. He told the judge that he wanted to take responsibility for his actions. Mr. Duncan admitted kidnapping Shasta Groene, then 8, and her 9-year-old brother, Dylan, sexually abusing them and killing the boy.

More than 40 million people in the United States say they cannot afford adequate heath care and go without drugs, eyeglasses or dental treatment, according to the annual report on the nation’s health by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The report also shows that death rates from cancer and heart disease have dropped in recent years, but that just as many Americans are dying in car crashes. Private insurance plans paid for 36 percent of total personal health care expenditures in 2005, while the federal government paid 34 percent, state and local governments paid 11 percent, and patients paid for 15 percent out of pocket.
President Bush could end his term with even his own intelligence apparatus unsure of Iran’s intentions.
What we know that Congress has learned in its investigation of the purge of nine top federal prosecutors is disturbing.

The Giants would like to think that their come-from-behind victory over the Bears in Chicago will come to represent a turning point, when the growing doubts about a teetering team were finally tucked away.
Is Texas about to become the next state to undermine the teaching of evolution?
A suicide threatens to plunge the Air Force into a quagmire as it struggles to emerge from a huge scandal.
Congress is within reach of a breakthrough energy bill that would reduce both America’s dependence on foreign oil and its emissions of the greenhouse gases that cause climate change.
Some House Democrats are concerned over the possibility that Hillary Rodham Clinton will be their party nominee.
Voters on Sunday gave a split decision to two of the world’s most prominent and problematic authoritarian leaders, Vladimir Putin of Russia and Hugo Chávez of Venezuela.
The Bush administration’s effort to help borrowers in danger of defaulting on their subprime mortgages could help only a small number of those who took out such loans.
The mayor of Phoenix withdrew support for a police department order barring officers from asking the immigration status of people it arrested.
Thieves who broke into a meat warehouse in suburban Sydney and stole 17.6 tons of ham and bacon left behind a message. “Thanks,” they daubed on a wall. “Merry Christmas.”
The Muslim Council of Britain, the biggest Muslim umbrella group in the country, has voted to end its boycott of Holocaust Memorial Day, The Guardian reported.
Kevin Rudd of the Labor Party was sworn in as prime minister, officially ending nearly 12 years of conservative government under John Howard.
India will be ready to test its first domestically built nuclear-powered submarine at sea by 2009, said its navy chief.
Mets General Manager Omar Minaya sounded like a man who did not expect to make a major trade for a pitcher at the winter meetings.
Assistant Secretary of State Christopher R. Hill, the chief American envoy to the six-nation talks intended to end North Korea’s nuclear capabilities, is on a three-day visit to that country.
King Edward VIII’s 1934 Buick, which he rode to Downing Street to announce his abdication from the British throne in 1936, sold at auction for $205,429.
One of Italy’s most wanted men, Daniele Emanuello, said to be the head of a Mafia family in Gela, in southern Sicily, was killed by the police during a raid in central Sicily, the police said.
A Moscow court sentenced the former director of a research institute associated with Russia’s space agency, to 11 ½ years in prison for passing classified technology to China.
The unfolding drama over Seth Tobias’s estate is providing a racy account of fast money and faster living in the volatile world of hedge funds.
More than 500 Iranian women calling themselves “mothers of peace” have signed a letter to senior officials expressing their fear that there will be a war over Iran’s nuclear program.

The Yankees’ pursuit of Johan Santana showed a flicker of life early Tuesday when the Twins backed off their demand for Ian Kennedy, but Hank Steinbrenner indicated that Minnesota is still asking too much.
The decisions came as both General Motors and Ford Motor Company are struggling to keep their respective turnaround plans on track.
About 3,000 people came to say goodbye to Washington Redskins star Sean Taylor, shot and killed last week during an attempted burglary of the player’s Miami home.
A federal appeals panel has ruled that a state-financed evangelical Christian program to help prisoners re-enter civilian life violated the constitutional separation of church and state.
If O.J. Mayo wants to create a legacy at Southern California,  he needs to do it fast. He’ll most likely be gone to the N.B.A. after one year.

An article in Business Day on Friday about favorite gadgets of executives referred incorrectly to the video game Gran Turismo 5. It has not yet been released, and thus is not a best-selling game. The article also referred imprecisely to the game Halo 3. It is the first game in the Halo series designed for the Xbox 360; the earlier games, though playable on the Xbox 360, were designed for the original Xbox. The chip in the Xbox 360 also was misidentified. It has a Xenon chip, not a Cell processor. And the article also misstated the price of the Sony PlayStation 3. The PlayStation 3 starts at $399, not $299.
State officials claim that the nuclear reactors in Westchester County are vulnerable to a terrorist attack and that the surrounding area could not be evacuated if an accident occurred.
President Nicolas Sarkozy of France denounced colonialism as “profoundly unjust” but stopped short of apologizing for the atrocities France was accused of committing there.
Neither President Bush nor the Congressional Democrats are softening their views on a range of contentious issues even though lawmakers have just a few weeks left to wrap up work for the year.
Auto policy experts were still struggling on Monday to determine exactly what the effects would be under the energy compromise reached by Congressional leaders last week.
Rival campaigns have said an independent group’s calls promoting Mike Huckabee are spreading negative information about their candidates.
Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, declined to describe what he does for a money management firm that has employed him for more than a decade.
Minutes after the final buzzer sounded on a Knicks defeat, Stephon Marbury learned that his father was dead. A season checkered with frustration and pain was now layered with sorrow.
The posthumous election of Walter O’Malley to the  National Baseball Hall of Fame is a twist of the knife to some Brooklynites who remember him for moving the Dodgers to Los Angeles.
Tim Tetrick has had a magical season in the sulky, setting records for the most money earned and the most victories in a single year by a driver.
The education of the American soccer player, Freddy Adu, continues in Portugal, where he is finding that everyone is a good player and that no one’s place is guaranteed.
The United States is flushing whole generations worth of cash into the bottomless pit of a failed and endless war.
As the writers’ strike halts much scripted television production, networks are increasingly relying on unscripted fare to fill the programming gaps.
City officials are looking to keep landlords from illegally turning units in apartment buildings into hotel rooms.
The N.Y.P.D. has begun to test thousands of drug samples after a review found the lab could have skewed evidence.
The chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee said the F.C.C. has suffered “an apparent breakdown in an open and transparent regulatory process.”
The Tampa Bay Rays traded another troubled outfielder yesterday, sending Elijah Dukes to the Washington Nationals for Glenn Gibson, a minor league pitcher.
A black teenager whose prosecution in the beating of a white classmate led to large civil rights protests pleaded guilty to a battery charge.
Many people were without electricity and at least two died as hurricane-force winds and heavy rain battered the Northwest for a second day.
The Baltimore Ravens put Steve McNair’s on injured reserve Monday, ending a season in which the 34-year-old struggled to stay healthy and hold onto the football.
For the third time Marvin Miller was rejected for the Baseball Hall of Fame.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,873 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
Although Rudolph W. Giuliani is campaigning as President Bush’s ally in the war on terror, his law firm has lobbied on behalf of legislation the administration calls a threat to antiterror efforts.

City officials said that yesterday’s decision by a justice in State Supreme Court in Manhattan has cleared the way for the renovation of Washington Square Park to begin. The work, including moving the park’s fountain and decreasing the size of the plaza, had been challenged by neighborhood and environmental groups. The city won two previous lawsuits, and yesterday’s decision, by Justice Joan A. Madden, found that the city had taken steps to ensure that the work would not significantly damage the environment, city officials said. The renovation is expected to begin by year’s end, city officials said. Daniel L. Alterman, a lawyer for the opponents of the renovation, said they were considering whether to appeal.

The United Federation of Teachers said yesterday that it would seek to withdraw from a $28 million effort to build 234 units of moderately priced housing for teachers because the city and the developer would not pledge to use union labor. Randi Weingarten, the union’s president, said she would ask the Teachers Retirement System to end its participation in the project. The city’s Housing Development Corporation and the developer, Atlantic Development Group, trying hold down costs, said they would not guarantee use of prevailing-wage workers.

The death of a 38-year-old city fire marshal who was discovered shot to death in his Staten Island home over the weekend was ruled a homicide yesterday, the authorities said. Detectives were investigating the killing last night, but had made no arrests, the police said. An autopsy showed that the victim, Douglas Mercereau, above, died of gunshot wounds to his head, said a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner’s office. Mr. Mercereau’s wife dialed 911 about 8:25 a.m. on Sunday, the police said, and emergency responders found Mr. Mercereau lying in bed in their home at 90 Tarrington Street. Mr. Mercereau, who joined the Fire Department more than 12 years ago, was promoted to supervising fire marshal last month, a Fire Department spokesman said.

A dancer with the American Ballet Theater died in a 10-car crash in New Jersey on Sunday night while returning from Pennsylvania. The ballet company, which is based in New York, said Jennifer Alexander, 35, died at the crash site on Route 3 in East Rutherford. A spokesman for the Bergen County prosecutor’s office said there was one other fatality in another car. Three other dancers were in the car with Ms. Alexander. One was her husband, who remained hospitalized. Ms. Alexander was returning from a guest appearance in the Williamsport Civic Ballet’s annual performance of “The Nutcracker.”.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. Eliot Spitzer spoke yesterday at a ceremony in the Times Square subway station to mark the start of work on a westward extension of the No. 7 subway line. The extension is intended to spur development on the west edge of Midtown, using what Mr. Bloomberg called “the galvanizing power of the subway.” The 7 train now runs from Flushing, Queens, to Times Square. The extension will take the line west to 11th Avenue, then south to 34th Street, where a station will be built at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. At the ceremony, Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff defended a decision not to build a station at 41st Street and 10th Avenue, saying that development had already been progressing in that area without the impetus of the new subway. The project is due to be completed in 2013.

A man and two women were arrested last Tuesday at a Bank of America on 97th Street and Broadway as they tried to withdraw money by using stolen identification, a police source close to the investigation said yesterday. The three, Charles Belim, 51, Crystal Velasquez, 30, and Kimberly Tucker, 30, all of Manhattan, have been charged with forgery and identity theft, the police said. The women were charged with wearing wigs, scarves and makeup to mimic the photographs on driver’s licenses, the source said. Officers from the Manhattan North Grand Larceny Unit seized 11 stolen credit cards, three driver’s licenses, wigs and sunglasses, the police source said.

A bill that would abolish the death penalty in New Jersey easily passed the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee yesterday by an 8-to-4 vote. The next stop for the bill is the floor of the Senate, where the Senate president, Richard J. Codey, has said he would like to see the bill voted on before the end of the year. In the State Assembly, an identical bill is scheduled for a committee hearing on Monday. That bill is expected to pass the committee easily, and then go before the full Assembly by the end of the week.

Two drivers who the police said were drag-racing when they had an accident that killed a 17-year-old passenger in one of their cars in July were indicted yesterday on manslaughter charges. The drivers, Anthony Reis, 18, and Joseph Donovan, 17, were both driving more than 80 miles an hour on Veterans Road West at the south end of Staten Island on July 25 when Mr. Donovan’s car struck Mr. Reis’s, the Staten Island district attorney’s office said. The crash killed one of Mr. Donovan’s passengers, Michelle Arout, 17, and injured several others. Both men were charged with second-degree manslaughter, which carries a sentence of up to 15 years in prison.
This season has been as disappointing for Reggie Bush and the Saints as last season was satisfying.
After accusations that reports in The New Republic about the cruelty of ordinary officers in Iraq were false, the magazine says that it can no longer stand by the articles.

BlackRock, the asset management firm hired to advise Florida on a state pool whose subprime-tainted holdings led to withdrawal of almost half its $27 billion assets, recommended yesterday that the remaining holdings be split into two entities to ensure the fund’s survival.
A bouncer on trial for three killings claimed that he was being framed by a squad of corrupt police assassins, and that he had a secret notebook of evidence to prove it.
The long legal fight between two members of Congress over an illegally taped telephone call ended Monday when the Supreme Court refused to review the case.
Despite the enormity of its recurring scandals, Samsung is unlikely to go the way of Enron, in part because of its economic importance to South Korea.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — Following are key judgments from a November 2007 National Intelligence Estimate, “Iran: Nuclear Intentions and Capabilities,” as declassified and released Monday by the office of the director of national intelligence. The judgments include the following footnote:.

Beneath the surface of a Supreme Court argument on Monday was the question of whether the court has drifted so far to the employer’s side in job discrimination cases that it is now to the right of the Bush administration.
The German bank WestLB said Monday it would guarantee full liquidity to several of its investment vehicles that had put money into asset-backed securities.
The maker of electronic-payment equipment  lost nearly half its market value in New York trading after accounting errors erased four-fifths of pretax profit for the first nine months of 2007.
The November results, the 10th consecutive monthly expansion, were slightly stronger than analysts expected.
Federal prosecutors intend to call the chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway to testify against five former insurance executives accused of helping A.I.G. manipulate its financial statements.
The social networking site started positioning itself on Tuesday as a top destination for buying exclusive musical performances.
King Albert II of Belgium has asked the country’s acting prime minister to take steps necessary to end a political deadlock that has prompted talk of a breakup of Belgium.

VimpelCom, Russia’s second-largest cellphone company, has offered to buy a rival, Golden Telecom, for about $4.2 billion to create Russia’s first integrated mobile and fixed-line provider. VimpelCom offered $105 a share for the Internet, voice and data provider, 3.5 percent higher than the closing price Friday, the companies said. They are “in discussions regarding the potential acquisition of all the outstanding common stock” of Golden Telecom, according to the statement. VimpelCom, which had more than 61 million subscribers at the end of October in Russia, Armenia, Kazakhstan, Ukraine, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Georgia, wants to branch out in more markets and into services like broadband. Golden Telecom said Nov. 8 it had 394,900 broadband subscribers in Russia.

The Dutch employment company Randstad Holding said that it would bid about $5.17 billion in cash and shares for a rival, Vedior, in a management-backed takeover. The two companies combined send out 700,000 temporary employees daily and have around 33,000 employees. If the deal is completed the merged company would be larger than Manpower, the temporary employment company based in Milwaukee. Randstad’s cash-and-share offer was worth 3.51 billion euros, or 20.19 euros ($29.76) a Vedior share at Friday’s closing price, a 64 percent premium. Randstad and Vedior each have various operations in more than 20 countries and some overlap.

China Pacific Insurance Group, which is part-owned by the Carlyle Group and Prudential Financial, has received approval to sell a billion new shares in a Shanghai offering to bolster its finances and compete with domestic rivals. The listing committee of China’s securities watchdog agency approved the share sale yesterday, the China Securities Regulatory Commission said on its Web site. China Pacific also plans to sell as many as 900 million shares in a Hong Kong public offering “as soon as possible” after the mainland initial public offering. The two offerings are expected to raise as much as $6 billion.

Shares of the state-owned power provider Électricitée de France went on sale as the government sought to raise about $7.4 billion to finance the university system. The finance minister, Christine Lagarde, said in a statement that the government was offering money managers 45 million shares, or 2.5 percent of EDF, worth about 5 billion euros. If there is sufficient demand, the government could sell as many as 67.3 million shares, she said, raising as much as 5.6 billion euros ($8.27 billion). The money is earmarked for the public university system.

The World Trade Organization’s highest court, backing a European Union complaint, upheld a ruling finding that Brazil illegally bans imports of retread tires for vehicles. Appellate judges agreed with a June 12 decision that the restriction was unjustified because Brazil imports used tires for making retreads, so it would be unfair to prevent imports of the finished retread product. Europe said Brazil’s September 2000 ban unfairly denied it a market expected to import three million used tires by 2003. Brazil had argued that Europe was trying to export its pollution problem of old tires, which cannot be used for making retreads more than once, and would therefore become a waste problem at the end of their second life.
AT&T said on Monday that it would exit the rapidly shrinking pay phone business by the end of next year, before it becomes unprofitable.
No criminal charges will be filed in the case of an Internet hoax that ended in a teenage girl’s suicide in a St. Louis suburb last year, the local prosecutor said.
Redemption was in the air as Don Imus returned to the radio after eight months in exile.
Many Brazilians who moved to the United States over the last two decades are now moving back.
Genentech’s drug Avastin did not help women with breast cancer live meaningfully longer, and it caused significant side effects, the Food and Drug Administration said Monday.
With overall costs for business travel expected to rise 6 to 8 percent next year, more companies appear to be saving on lodging by having employees share hotel rooms on business trips.
Girls won top honors for the first time in the Siemens Competition in Math, Science and Technology, one of the nation’s most coveted student science awards.
Investors balked after two Federal Reserve officials expressed concern about the subprime mortgage crisis and its impact on banks and brokerage firms.
The new chief executive of Merrill Lynch, John A. Thain, made his first big move at the brokerage firm by hiring his former finance chief at the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. Steffy cast his career as an electrical contractor aside when he was 48 to pursue his passion, studying shipwrecks, and became a leading expert in the field.
Mr. Wachtel was a stock market analyst whose humor and trademark Brooklyn accent kept radio listeners attuned to the ups and downs of the markets for more than three decades.
The continuing strength of ad spending online — as well as the stimulative effects of the elections and the Summer Olympics — should keep the ad industry from suffering a recession in 2008.
Across Britain, trucks are increasingly being directed by G.P.S. navigation devices that fail to appreciate that the shortest route is not always the best route.

The Roman Catholic Diocese of Davenport, Iowa, has reached a settlement to compensate victims of sexual abuse by clergy members and let the diocese emerge from bankruptcy, the two sides have announced.
A new strain of the Ebola virus has been detected in five districts in western Uganda, and the death toll has reached 19.

Mr. Brach was a New York painter and teacher who became the first dean of the School of Art at the California Institute of the Arts and a mentor to some of the brightest stars of the art world of the 1980s.
The $2.4 billion chauffeured transportation business is doing well both in the United States and overseas.
Toxic chemicals in the water in Punjab, India’s grain belt, could be causing genetic mutations in the population, a recent study suggests.
Cholera is a grave threat for the American project in Iraq, but also an opportunity to capture the hearts and minds of the population.
In my job, you have to look good. Fortunately, being stylish, or at least trying to look stylish, is something that I’ve managed to do, even at 30,000 feet.
To the Editor:.
Morning programs like “Today” on NBC and “The View” on ABC are the modern equivalents of the old Barbizon Hotel for Women.
Mr. Payne, 84, was one of the first baritone saxophonists to master the intricacies of modern jazz.
“Ratatouille,” the tale of a rodent chef, amassed 13 nominations, including best feature, when the Annie Awards, honoring animation, were announced.

Mark Wallinger was named the winner yesterday of the Turner Prize, given annually to a British artist younger than 50 for an outstanding exhibition or other presentation of work in the 12 months preceding May 8.

The adult actors and assistant stage managers who work at the theater in the American Girl Place store voted, for the second time, to take on Actors’ Equity Association as their bargaining representative.
To the Editor:.
Singing, strutting, hugging and even pole-dancing to the delight of a screaming audience of more than 15,000, all five of the Spice Girls reunited in Vancouver, British Columbia.
A song cycle inspired by love for a wife doomed to an early death has won Peter Lieberson the University of Louisville’s $200,000 Grawemeyer Award for outstanding works in music composition.
The world’s first self-tuning guitar was introduced yesterday in London.
Drawing 20.6 million viewers on Sunday, “Desperate Housewives” lifted ABC into first place for the night’s ratings, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

The platinum-selling hip-hop star Akon, 34, pleaded not guilty yesterday to criminal charges filed after he tossed a 15-year-old boy off the stage at a concert on June 3 at the minor league baseball stadium in Fishkill, N.Y.
To the Editor:.
Turner Prize winner, Peter Lieberson songs win an award, robot guitar calls the tune and more culture news.
Mr. Nolte was a Middle East expert whose tenure as American ambassador to Egypt lasted only three weeks in 1967 because of the turmoil of the Six-Day War.
Mr. Henderson, a psychologist and author, was an early practitioner of methods developed by Carl Jung to explore cultural influences on the unconscious mind
Mr. DeBlanc was awarded the Medal of Honor for shooting down five Japanese planes on a single day while running out of fuel.
The airline delay rate has averaged 23.95 percent of all domestic flights this year through October, the highest in 12 years.
Aaron Sorkin’s information-crammed, surface-skimming biodrama about the creators of television suggests nothing so much as a classroom presentation on a seven-figure budget.
Controversy has erupted from the sleepy third-floor hallway galleries at the New York Public Library, where a modest exhibition of contemporary prints called “Multiple Interpretations” is on view.
In recent seasons the American tenor Matthew Polenzani has come into his own at the Metropolitan Opera.
American military and intelligence officials are seeing early signs that Al Qaeda may be increasing its activities in Afghanistan.
Understanding physical infirmity can help assess the work of a handful of Impressionists.
Smart cars will never be infallible, but they just have to be better than the drivers who now cause more than 90 percent of traffic accidents.
“Ford at Fox” is a gargantuan boxed set that assembles 24 of the 50-some films John Ford made for the studio that was his most consistent home.

KALAT--Peter A. The partners and all employees of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle, LLP, bemoan the death on December 1, 2007 of Peter A. Kalat, a highly regarded corporate international partner in the firm's New York City office. Our thoughts and condolences go out to his wife Nie-Lih and to his surviving family. Peter was with the firm for over 40 years and had a wide-ranging practice in the corporate international field -including testifying as an expert witness on New York corporate law before the Iran-US Claims Tribunal at the Hague. Peter had numerous other interests and was an accomplished tournament bridge player, having won a national bridge championship. Peter will be deeply missed by his many friends and admirers.

An article in Business Day on Thursday about a Norwegian brokerage firm that lost its license misstated the location of one of four remote Norwegian towns that lost money on investment securities the firm sold them. Rana, the largest of the four towns, with about 25,000 residents, is about 50 miles south of the Arctic Circle, not north of it. (Another of the towns, Narvik, with 18,000 residents, is 100 miles north of the Arctic Circle.)

Now on Broadway, and Off: The Trufflettes No, the Trufflettes do not have a hit song, but they do have T-shirts. The group, all young women, have interesting part-time jobs: delivering truffles to restaurants, where demanding chefs can have their pick. And now they do the same for fussy home cooks who want comparable quality and like being able to select from a good assortment. Such clients pay slightly more than chefs who are regular customers, but considerably less than at fancy-food stores.

How will Mitt Romney handle the subject of his Mormon faith during a much-anticipated speech on Thursday? He gave some clues yesterday, dispelling notions that he would focus mainly on allaying any doubts about his Mormon faith. ''I am not going to be giving a J.F.K. speech,'' Mr. Romney said, referring to John F. Kennedy's speech in 1960 in which Kennedy, then the Democratic nominee for president, promised that the national interest -- not his Roman Catholicism -- would dictate his policies. ''I am going to be talking about the role of religion, faith in America and in a free society.''

Every year, an estimated 200,000 children around the world are born with crippling defects of the spinal column. Many are paralyzed or permanently impaired by spina bifida; some, with a condition called anencephaly (literally, ''no brain''), survive in a vegetative state. It is a stubborn and terrible problem, in the developed and developing worlds alike. But many experts believe it could be greatly eased by a simple government measure: requiring that flour be fortified with the dietary supplementfolic acid, which has been shown to prevent these neural tube defects if taken by expectant mothers from before conception through the first trimester.

An article in Business Day on Nov. 22 about benefits at law firms misstated the extent of one such perk at Fulbright & Jaworski. Employees are eligible for discounts on vehicles made by General Motors and Toyota, but not by Subaru. A benefit at Cravath, Swaine & Moore was also misstated. The firm reimburses meals (up to $30) for lawyers who work late if they order from the cafeteria or through a delivery service, SeamlessWeb.com. It does not reimburse meals from the Palm Restaurant. (While the Palm does not deliver, its meals can be ordered through Dial-a-Dinner.)

An article in Business Day on Friday about favorite gadgets of executives referred incorrectly to the video game Gran Turismo 5. It has not yet been released, and thus is not a best-selling game. The article also referred imprecisely to the game Halo 3. It is the first game in the Halo series designed for the Xbox 360; the earlier games, though playable on the Xbox 360, were designed for the original Xbox. The chip in the Xbox 360 also was misidentified. It has a Xenon chip, not a Cell processor. And the article also misstated the price of the Sony PlayStation 3. The PlayStation 3 starts at $399, not $299.

BLAND--Larry I. Historian, author, and teacher, died of a heart attack on November 27 in Lexington, Virginia. He was 67. Generally recognized as one of the world's foremost authorities on the life and career of George C. Marshall, Bland was working on the sixth volume of ''The Papers of George Catlett Marshall'', principal publications project of the George C. Marshall Foundation in Lexington, when he died. Bland also edited ''George C. Marshall Interviews and Reminiscences'' and ''George C. Marshall's Mediation Mission to China.'' He was managing editor of the ''Journal of Military History'' for 19 years.

GANTMAN--Julius, 97, Insurance Executive. Mr. Julius Gantman, who served as a senior executive and member of the Board of Directors of Public Service Mutual Insurance Company died at his home in Westchester on Sunday, December 2, 2007. He was 97. At the time of his death, Mr. Gantman was one of three senior members of the Executive Committee of the Board of Directors having been named to the Board in November 1977. Mr. Gantman joined Public Service Mutual Insurance Company's legal department in 1942 and served in various leadership positions until his retirement from active employment in May 1980. ''Julie will always remain an important and colorful part of our Magna Carta history and will be sorely missed by all,'' said Andrew L. Furgatch, Chairman of the Board of Public Service Mutual Insurance Company, an affiliate of Magna Carta Companies. Mr. Gantman earned both his undergraduate degree and bachelor of laws degree from St. John's University in New York. The Magna Carta Foundation established the Julius Gantman Scholarship Fund at St. John's University School of Risk Management, Insurance and Actuarial Science (formerly the College of Insurance) in 2003. On behalf of the entire Public Service Mutual and Magna Carta family, we extend our heartfelt sympathy to his many children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. The Board of Magna Carta Companies GANTMAN--Julius, 97, beloved husband of the late Edith Cohen Gantman, and loving brother of the late Ida Tischler, died peacefully in his sleep at home, December 2, 2007. He was the adored father of Lynn and Stevan Lieberman, Jane and Stephen Lewis, proud grandfather of Jonathan and Ellen Lewis, Robert and Deborah Lewis, Jennifer and Bernard Yamron, Deborah and Matthew Miller and Amy and Pantelis Klonaris, and devoted greatgrandfather of Deborah, Michael, Emily, Elizabeth, Jacob, Juliet, Benjamin, Brooke, and Nicholas. He was a practicing attorney in New York State for over 75 years and a director of Public Service Mutual Insurance Co. His humor and joy for living is an enduring gift to all who knew him, professionally and personally. Services Wednesday, 11:15 am, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

WOLMAN--Benson A. 1936-2007, The board of directors, members and staff of the ACLU of Ohio note with sorrow the passing of Benson A. Wolman, who died November 30 in Columbus. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and friends. A nationally recognized constitutional and civil rights lawyer, Benson served as the ACLU's executive director in Ohio from 1969-1986. His distinguished career in litigation and advocacy included presenting a winning argument before the U.S. Supreme Court in Capital Square Review and Advisory Board v. Pinette. Benson, acting as an ACLU volunteer attorney, successfully challenged the State's refusal to permit the Ku Klux Klan to erect a cross next to a menorah on the grounds of the Statehouse, thus infringing upon the Klan's right to freedom of expression. He was perhaps most proud of his work on the Kent State University shootings litigation. Under his leadership, the case, entitled Krause v. Rhodes, reached a settlement on behalf of the students who were killed or injured on May 4, 1970 at Kent State. During his seventeen years as ACLU executive director, Wolman became well known as an articulate advocate of individual rights. Under his tutelage, the ACLU received the Gold Medal Award of the Freedoms Foundation for developing the Ohio Mock Trial Program of law related education in the state's high schools. He served on the National Advisory Council of the ACLU and as a member of the ACLU's national, state and local boards of directors. After leaving the ACLU, Benson served as counsel to the law firm Moots, Cope & Stanton, and later formed his own firm, Wolman, Genshaft & Gellman, both in Columbus. Benson had been serving as executive director of the Equal Justice Foundation in Columbus at the time of his death. Benson was known for his wit, eloquence, and passion for civil liberties. He will be missed by the many ACLU members whom he recruited, mentored, supported and collaborated with over the years.

FRISCHER--Abraham David. On December 2, at age 94. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy Frischer. Devoted father of Judith (Steven) Shmueli and Barry (Ilene) Frischer. Adored grandfather of Joy and Jayson Shmueli; Lindsey and Adam Frischer and Adam's fiancee, Andrea Malloy. Devoted brother of Anita (Joseph) Goldfeder. A generous, giving person. A success in business and forging lasting friendships. He had an unquenchable thirst for knowledge. Abe was a decent, honorable, bright, stimulating man who will be truly missed. Services Tuesday, 10am, at Star of David Memorial Chapel, 1236 Wellwood Ave, West Babylon.

GILLIATT--Mary R., 86, peacefully on November 28 in Greenwich Hospital, attended by family and friends, after a brief final illness. During and after a vibrant career as a company wife and mother, Mary, a natural-born party girl, was known as a consummate organizer and hostess. She was widely sought-after to oversee charitable and eleemosynary fund raising events and served on several boards of directors. Mary remained active in that regard to the very end as, inter alia, Chairman of the Patron Committee of Friends of (channel) Thirteen, Founder and Member of the Fairfield County Alumnae Chapter of Kappa Alpha Theta, and Board Member of Norwalk Community college. Other credits include: Board of Directors, Chicago Foundlings Home; Deaconess, Second Congregational Church; Chairman, New York Philharmonic Luncheon 1986 and Opening Night 1988; Chairman, House Corporation, Yale University Chapter, Kappa Alpha Theta; Chairman Institutes of Religion and Health Christmas Benefit 1989-93; and Chairman, Historical Society of Greenwich Luncheon 1994. Mary was born and raised in LaPorte, Indiana, daughter of Helen and Ben Rees, an attorney. She graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Indiana University, married Neal Gilliatt in 1943, and lived most of her life in Greenwich. She is survived by her son David, and granddaughters Victoria and Olivia. Mary touched a great many lives with her spirit, drive and generosity, and she will be sorely missed. She asked that in lieu of flowers, donations be sent to the Mary Rees Gilliatt Scholarship Fund, c/o Kappa Alpha Theta Foundation, 8470 Founders Road, Indianapolis, IN 46268-1300 (317876-1870). Services will be held at second Congregational Church in Greenwich on December 8 at 12:00 noon, followed by a reception at the Greenwich Country Club.

FOX--G. William ''Bill,'' On December 1, 2007 at his home in Medford, surrounded by his loving family. Age 66. Beloved husband of Sandra (nee Williams). Loving father of Tacie Fox, G. William Fox, Jr., Liza Fox Lyons and Sara Fox. Devoted grandfather of eight grandchildren. Dear brother of Frederick S. Fox, III, Mary Fox Zwally and Jane Fox and brother-in-law of Erik Williams. Bill attended Haddonfield High School and graduated from The Peddie School in 1959. He was a 1963 graduate of Trinity College in Hartford, CT, and began his career with Fox and Lazo in 1963 under the guidance of his father. Bill helped grow the business from eight agents in 1963 to over 3,000 agents in 2003, when it was recognized as the dominant firm in the Philadelphia tri-state area, and the fourth-largest privately-owned residential financial services firm in the nation. Mr. Fox retired as Chairman of the Board of Prudential Fox and Roach in December 2003. Bill and his family devoted much energy to organizations dedicated to finding a cure for Huntington's Disease. Bill was tirelessly involved in his community and charitable, spiritual and family oriented activities. Relatives and friends are invited to the viewing 6-9pm Wednesday at the Bradley Funeral Home, Rt 73 and Evesham Rd., Marlton, NJ, and also to the Funeral Service 11am, Thursday, at the Haddonfield United Methodist Church, 29 Warwick Rd., Haddonfield, NJ. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Hereditary Disease Foundation (HDF), 3960 Broadway, 6th Floor, New York, NY 10032.

A front-page article yesterday about obstacles facing the presidential campaign of Mike Huckabee of Arkansas misspelled the surname of Mr. Huckabee's national campaign manager. He is Chip Saltsman, not Saltzman.

A mass of Christian Burial will be held on Monday, December 10, 2007, at 11am at Sacred Heart Catholic Church on High Street in Chestertown, MD. NEWMAN-Hannah. Deepest sympathy to Mrs. Rose Romerovski, Diamond Founder together with her late husband Martin, and to the extended family, on the loss of her cherished daughter. A sports article yesterday about the announcement that top-ranked Ohio State would play No. 2 Louisiana State for the college football national championship reversed the rankings for the Buckeyes and the Michigan Wolverines when they played for a berth in last season's title game. Ohio State was No. 1 and Michigan No. 2.

On Monday, the police found the skeletal remains of Christina Copeman in her home in East Flatbush, Brooklyn. She had been dead for a year to 18 months, and was dressed to go out, in a coat and beret. “It seems impossible for a person to fall through the cracks like that, to die in her own home and go undiscovered. New York is a big city, but it is impersonal only at a distance,” Andy Newman writes. “People have neighbors. They have relatives. But Christina Copeman, who would be 70 if she were alive today, managed to slip away almost by sheer force of will.”

Remember congestion pricing? The New York City Traffic Congestion Mitigation Commission continues to evaluate Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan for charging traffic fees in much of Manhattan, even as several opponents of the plan have put forward alternatives that would not involve charging regular passenger vehicles.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and leaders of the City Council announced this morning that New York City will invest $2.8 million to start a nonprofit organization that will be dedicated to helping homeowners avoid foreclosure — the city’s most tangible response so far to the crisis in subprime lending and the turmoil in the housing and mortgage markets.

Growing up in Queens, I remember visiting the Bowne House as a child. Along with institutions like the Queens County Farm Museum and the Louis Armstrong House & Archives, Bowne House is a reminder of Queens’s rich — and often underappreciated — contributions to American history.
What we are reading elsewhere…

The early December flurries on Sunday and today give rise to the question: Is it snowing earlier than usual this year? Well, not really, according to meteorologists at Pennsylvania State University. Todd Miner, a meteorologist at the university, which supplies the information for The Times’s daily weather reports, said the city is almost exactly on track for average snowfall this winter. So far in December, 1.4 inches have been recorded; November had 0.3 inch.

Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo today unveiled his long-awaited “Project Sunlight,” a new good-government tool that his office has been working on for the better part of the year.The project is a essentially a large database that knits together information on legislation, lobbyists, campaign donations, state contracts and charities in a single, very user-friendly Web site. Our first impression is that this will be an extraordinarily useful tool for examining the interplay between money, politics and power in New York.

The Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, announced on Tuesday the creation of an Immigrant Affairs Program to encourage immigrants who are crime victims or are aware of illegal activity to come forward without fear of arrest and deportation.
Perhaps you think of “The Nutcracker” as the perfect children’s entertainment? Irina Roizin, the founder of the Brighton Ballet Theater and School of Russian Ballet in Brooklyn, is not so sure.

We’ve heard of Christmas trees made of potatos, chocolate and even butter cookies. On the campaign trail in Iowa last week, John Edwards let his rivals do the sparring.
The Mets’ José Reyes is back home in the Dominican Republic, reflecting on last season and preparing for 2008.

The Christmas classic "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer" led CBS to a Tuesday night victory in the ratings as the special delivered 14.4 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates.

It has all the markings of tabloidian detail that can haunt a candidate, a lawmaker, an elected official, who walks and stalks the halls of criminal justice, who has, as he has said, weighed decisions on whether to impose capital punishment, and has ordered death.

William A. Ackman is not afraid to make big bets and stick by them. For years, he has been wagering that bond insurer MBIA would implode. This summer, his $6 billion hedge-fund firm, Pershing Square Capital Management, plunked down $2 billion to buy a stake in Target.

Injured Rangers forward Sean Avery will not play when the Toronto Maple Leafs come to Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, which means: A) No worries about a brawl in warmups, B) Avery's main agitation target, Darcy Tucker, should have a quieter night, C) earplugs will not be necessary for children sitting near the ice.

At the New York premiere of "No Country for Old Men" -- a big winner of the National Board of Review awards -- the Baguette mentioned to Javier Bardem that Anthony Lane, reviewing the film in the New Yorker, wrote that he had the "biggest, noblest and most sculpted head of anyone in movies."

A service inaugurated in Rome this week allows you to reserve tickets via phone or online to some of Rome's most popular monuments - including the Colosseum, the Borghese Museum, and the National Roman Museum. It also includes a number of theaters, although theater in any language other than Italian is a rarity here.

Mitt Romney of Massachusetts for the Republicans.

During my two decades as a Washington journalist, I often mused that the orgy of scandal and tainted money that made the capital such a feast for investigative reporters and spoofers (think "Thank You for Smoking") had to rival that of the Gilded Age, which provided Adams so much rich material. I think there is no better piece of writing about Washington than Adams's chapter on Grant. Like Adams, I found that some of the politicians and lobbyists I covered defied burlesque because "they were more grotesque than ridicule could make them," and that senators (the esteemed Mr. Hart a notable exception!) were often comical in their egotism. Still, like Adams, I couldn't help but love the place. As he writes, "one could not stay there a month without loving the shabby town."

Before the 2000 presidential election, just three candidates, all independently wealthy, had ever opted out of the public finance system for the primaries. Today, few presidential hopefuls opt in, instead preferring to amass their own financial war chests.

Actor Danny Glover has filmed a TV ad asserting that the Bush Administration is destroying the Constitution through the use of torture, rendition, and other war-on-terror tactics. Mr. Glover urges viewers to "rescue the Constitution."

The National Board of Review, which will be held on Jan. 15, is a lovely event, in part because everyone knows who already won. And that's because they were announced today. Although the results aren't terribly predictive in terms of the Oscars, it does get a witless monkey like the Bagger typing and speculating. So, without further ado, witless monkey speculation.

It seems that people, just like the deadlocked jury in the Texas case of Jim Stevenson, the cat-shooting bird lover, remain deeply divided over whether cats should be allowed to roam free outdoors. Scientists estimate that free-range cats, either pets or feral, kill tens of millions of birds each year (not to mention chipmunks, voles, the occasional rabbit and other critters).

We can all fancy ourselves masters of our own domains these days; cyberspace allows us to draw up our own preferences, to cater to our niche interests, to create a community of people who are just like us. We have the whole world in our hands (in our laptops), we can swivel between hundreds of channels on our TV sets, our cell phones allow us to contact Cindy in Tibet.
The Writers Guild of America, East marked Tuesday's one-month anniversary of their strike against the studios by returning to the Rockefeller Center plaza, the site of the first day of picketing.

According to the centuries-old rules of the Roman Catholic Church, sin-reduction is a two-step process. Guilt is absolved through confession and prayer, but punishment -- on earth or in purgatory -- can be avoided through indulgences, an ancient form of church-granted amnesty that critics deride as a shortcut to salvation.

I mistakenly lumped the United States and Liechtenstein as the last of the industrialized countries that have not ratified the Kyoto Protocol, now that Australia did so early this week under its new government.

I've been working in the newsroom for the last few months. On the surface, there's not much that distinguishes the modern journalist from the modern software developer. Gone are the days of grizzled hacks grousing into phones and banging out copy five minutes before deadline on dented Underwoods. Modern journalists work against increasingly continuous deadlines and are as likely to collaborate via e-mail and instant message as by phone. And they bang out their stories on computers just like mine in cubicles just like mine.
Title: Pasta With Chestnuts And Mushrooms

Michael Schumacher and Kimi Raikkonen appear together in this commercial for the Fiat Bravo T-Jet. We've seen this premise before. Stick two superstars together in a game of one-upmanship, add some trash talk, and watch the sparks fly. The classic example is Larry Bird and Michael Jordan playing horse for a Big Mac.
Dan Colen (Hannah Liden)

In November the total audience for the "CBS Evening News with Katie Couric" "was down over a million (or 13.5 percent) when compared with the same month a year ago," Jacques Steinberg notes in today's Times.

Red Sox Manager Terry Francona sat in front of a row of black curtains, doing his best not to mention Johan Santana. A half hour later, Ron Gardenhire, the manager of the Twins, sat in front of a different set of black curtains and spoke openly about Santana.

"Gratin" has come to mean a kind of macaroni-and-cheese affair, a gooey dish in which the main foodstuff -- whether potatoes, noodles or vegetables -- is dominated by a mass of white sauce, cheese and butter. But the word really refers to the crust that forms on the top and sides of a dish that has been browned under a fire. Although gooey, cheesy dishes can be enjoyable, you can make honest, simple, lean gratins with fewer ingredients to produce easy, interesting vegetable dishes.

United Rental's lawsuit against Cerberus Capital Management introduced a new phrase to legal neophytes watching the proceedings: "specific performance." In its lawsuit, the rental equipment operator is demanding that Delaware's court of chancery force Cerberus to complete the $4 billion buyout, arguing that the specific performance clause in the deal agreement mandates just that.

James Wolcott, in this week's New Republic, delivers a status report on the health of book reviews, and writes that, in the digital age, "book reviewing bears the social handicap of a dying trade, like typewriter repair or horseshoe mending." It's a piece worth reading - you can find it here.

Just two days after the release of a National Intelligence Report that has made Iran the flashpoint of debate in the presidential race, the Giuliani campaign is up with a new ad highlighting the Iran hostage crisis, and the need to "stand up" to "dictators" and "tyrants."

Who cares if Adams doesn't say more about his brothers or his Harvard roommates, or anything at all about his wife's suicide? It's ungrateful and "unfair," they suggest, to greet this "startlingly brilliant exercise of mind and style" with a cry for more color, more anecdotes, more tears, more dish.

On Thursday night HBO is going to begin airing a documentary about Darfur, "Sand and Sorrow." Most places would headline that it features narration from a big-time movie star, but here in "On the Ground," we're going to trumpet that Nick is in it. The folks behind the film are encouraging people to have house parties and to participate in a call-in after show. Nick will be on the call along with filmmaker Paul Freedman, Samantha Power and John Prendergast. The documentary premieres on Dec. 6 at 8 p.m. and will also show on Dec. 10 at 2:15 p.m. and 10:30 p.m.

In the World Cup in Khanty-Mansiysk, three matches went to tiebreaker games today to decide the final three quarterfinalists. Dmitry Jakovenko of Russia, No. 19 in the world, upset Levon Aronian of Armenia, No. 9; Gata Kamsky of the United States, No. 17, also pulled an upset by beating Peter Svidler of Russia, No. 12; and Evgeny Alekseev of Russia, No. 14, held to form by taking care of Evgeny Bareev of Russia, No. 57, who was the lowest remaining player in the tournament. The results and the games can be found on the tournament's Web site.

Investors have entered December, usually a winning month on Wall Street, cautiously. Fears of further weakness in the financial sector helped push the stock market down for a second day Tuesday.
A Senate committee unanimously approved bipartisan legislation that would halt for at least six months a proposal to let companies own a newspaper and broadcast station in the same city.

Cerberus Capital Management's recent decisions to walk away from a couple of traditional leveraged buyouts, namely its deal for H&R Block's mortgage arm Option One and United Rentals, has taken some of the shine off the distressed investors, Breakingviews says.
Pegasus Capital Advisors, the middle-market private equity firm, has closed its latest investment vehicle, capping the new fund at $750 million.

The Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil charges Tuesday against legendary Silicon Valley entrepreneur Jack Gifford and the former chief financial officer of Maxim Integrated Products, alleging they were responsible for routinely rigging stock options to make them more valuable for workers, new hires and directors.

NexTone Communications and Reef Point Systems, two well-funded, venture-backed telecommunications start-ups, have combined to form NextPoint Networks and have raised $20 million in new capital to advance converged opportunities in fixed-mobile and wireless interconnectivity products.
