Like her brother Freddie Mac, Fannie Mae, the mortgage finance company, said Tuesday that it would sell $7 billion of preferred stock and cut its dividend 30 percent to shore up its capital base through 2008 as the housing slump worsens.

In the latest case of pillow talk leading to a jail time, a former financial analyst at Morgan Stanley and her husband, a former hedge fund analyst at ING, were each sentenced yesterday to a year and half in prison for insider trading.
General Motors is bidding for a stake in Russia's largest carmaker as part of an effort to expand its presence in that rapidly growing market, a G.M. spokesman confirmed Tuesday.

In a big step forward for the Belize market, the Belize National Association of Realtors has signed a reciprocal agreement with the U.S.-based National Association of Realtors. The deal should help bring ethical guidelines and basic standards to agents in the Caribbean country.
David Pogue puts nine cameras to the test on a recent trip to Miami. The following slides highlight some of their hits and misses.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Before Henrik Lundqvist there was Dan Blackburn, the first-round pick (10th over all) of the Rangers in 2001 who made the N.H.L. at 18. He recorded his first victory in Montreal, beating Jose Theodore and the Canadiens, 2-1, with his mother cheering him on. The future was dazzling. But after two seasons, it was all over. A freakish injury while weight training caused nerve damage in his left shoulder. By way of James Mirtle's blog comes this story from Scott Cruickshank , of The Calgary Herald. Blackburn is managing just fine in his life after hockey.

Going to the theater in London can be an expensive business. Prices in the West End for good seats range from 45 - 60 pounds. And if musicals aren't your thing then choice is limited. However...if you are looking for good theater as well as good value, don't despair. A number of what are known as "Off West End" houses consistently offer exciting work for less.
Loss

The Associated Press reports: On Tuesday "bargaining resumed in Los Angeles after a four-day recess, with a relatively scant $21 million separating contract proposals by studios and striking Hollywood writers.
The tiny, tough, sneakily moving film “The Violin” wears its revolutionary romanticism on its sleeve, not far from its gun.
“Undoing,” by the writer and director Chris Chan Lee, buries a potentially haunting pulp thriller beneath flashy tics.
The documentary “Billy the Kid” presents the world according to a troubled teenager in Maine.
“Juno” respects the idiosyncrasies of its characters rather than exaggerating them or holding them up for ridicule.
The price of oil has shot up, and the dollar has plunged to new lows. For lovers of European wines in particular, it’s a recipe for skyrocketing prices.
The saga of the last two Yangtze giant soft-shells is symbolic of the threatened state of wildlife as a result of pollution, hunting and rampant development.
The gunman was said by some witnesses to have fired about 20 shots into a crowd at a Von Maur department store. The police said that five other people had been injured in the shootings.
The advisory committee voted that Genentech’s drug Avastin should not be approved as a treatment for breast cancer.  It is already on the market as a treatment for lung and colon cancer.
Lobbyists opened a push today to fuel ordinary cars to run on blends of 20 percent to 30 percent ethanol, compared with 10 percent now.
Lawyers argued before the Supreme Court today over whether detainees have adequate means to challenge their captivity.
A New York City Police officer pleaded not guilty to a charge of first degree manslaughter in the fatal shooting of an unarmed man when the officer was off duty.
The Pacific Northwest coped with flooding, while the Midwest experienced snarled highway traffic and air travel delays as snow moved into the region.
The cartel rejected calls from oil consumers to increase output to drive down prices, signaling it was more concerned with slowing economic growth than with high oil prices.
New York’s Attorney General Andrew Cuomo is reviewing the packaging and selling of subprime mortgages.
Stocks jumped sharply today on news that private payrolls had grown more than expected in November.

Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the Judiciary Committee, criticized delays in filling top Justice Department jobs by a White House that has long complained about stalled nominations. Last month, the White House announced that it would nominate officials for the No. 2 and No. 3 spots at the department and for three assistant attorneys general. Mr. Leahy called that announcement “mostly bluster.” President Bush has submitted nominations for two of the five jobs, a delay Mr. Leahy called “unfortunate and unnecessary.”.

Auburn Coach Tommy Tuberville reportedly agreed to a two-year contract extension yesterday that includes a $200,000 annual raise and ends speculation he might leave for another job.Tuberville told The Birmingham News and The Huntsville Times that he and Athletic Director Jay Jacobs reached an agreement that would run through the 2013 season. Tuberville, who had been mentioned as a candidate for the now-filled Texas A&M job and the Arkansas opening, will make $2.8 million next season, escalating to $3.8 million in the final year, the two newspapers reported.;Auburn Coach Tommy Tuberville reportedly agreed to a two-year contract extension yesterday that includes a $200,000 annual raise and ends speculation he might leave for another job.Tuberville told The Birmingham News and The Huntsville Times that he and Athletic Director Jay Jacobs reached an agreement that would run through the 2013 season. Tuberville, who had been mentioned as a candidate for the now-filled Texas A&M job and the Arkansas opening, will make $2.8 million next season, escalating to $3.8 million in the final year, the two newspapers reported.

A former detective has filed a lawsuit to get his job back after being fired from the New York Police Department, which rejected his assertion that he failed a random drug test because his wife had spiked his meatballs with marijuana.
Memphis remained undefeated by squeaking past No. 24 Southern California in overtime in last night’s Jimmy V Classic at Madison Square Garden.
The Cavaliers looked lost without LeBron James, and Richard Jefferson took advantage.
Tyler Hansbrough scored 29 points and Danny Green had 19 last night as No. 1 North Carolina easily held off Penn, 106-71, in their first game at the Palestra in 50 years.

The top aide to former Representative Curt Weldon, Republican of Pennsylvania, was accused in federal court documents of falsifying Congressional financial disclosure reports to cover up $19,000 that his wife received for doing limited work at a consulting firm tied to the lawmaker’s family. The aide, Russell J. Caso Jr., also argued in meetings with Bush administration officials that the projects his wife was working on should get federal financing, according to the documents. Mr. Caso’s lawyer did not respond to a message. A hearing is scheduled for Friday. The case comes amid a federal inquiry involving Mr. Weldon and his daughter’s consulting firm.

The Fish and Wildlife Service must reconsider whether sage grouse should be listed as an endangered species, a judge has ruled in a decision highly critical of the agency and its decision-making process. Judge B. Lynn Winmill of Federal District Court said the service ignored experts’ advice and failed to use the “best science” available when deciding not to give the species protection under the Endangered Species Act. Judge Winmill also found that a former official used intimidation and edited scientific conclusions to keep the birds from being listed as endangered.

San Diego took another step toward a pilot project that would purify treated sewage to increase the supply of drinking water in a reservoir. The City Council voted 5 to 3 to override a veto by Mayor Jerry Sanders, who had rejected the plan as costly, unnecessary and unpopular with the public. The city’s Water Department will now write a plan for the project, which would make San Diego, confronting possible water shortages next year, one of the few places in the country that augments drinking water reservoirs with purified sewage.

State health officials said that they were investigating neurological illnesses among 11 workers at a pork processing plant, but that there was no evidence the public was at risk. Dr. Sanne Magnan, the state health commissioner, also said Monday that there was no evidence the food coming out of the plant, Quality Pork Processing in Austin, had been contaminated. The workers had symptoms including numbness and tingling in their limbs. Two were hospitalized; some recovered completely, and others are still going through rehabilitation, Dr. Magnan said. All worked in the same part of the plant, removing hog brains with compressed air. Kelly Wadding, the owner and chief executive of Quality Pork, said the workers had been given more protective clothing and no longer used compressed air to remove the brains.

The sentencing hearing for the convicted terrorist Jose Padilla, left, which was scheduled to begin today, was postponed until next month by the judge presiding over the case, court officials said. Judge Marcia Cooke of Federal District Court in Miami had planned several days of hearings to determine what sentences to impose on Mr. Padilla, 37, and two foreign-born men, who were convicted Aug. 16 of terrorism conspiracy charges. But Judge Cooke had to reschedule the start of the hearing for Jan. 7 because her brother died unexpectedly yesterday, the officials said.

A former aide to Senator Maria Cantwell, Democrat of Washington, is in federal custody after being arrested on a charge of attempting to sexually exploit a minor. Hours after his arrest on Friday, the aide, James M. McHaney, 28, was dismissed from his job as a scheduler for Ms. Cantwell. The F.B.I. said in a charging document that Mr. McHaney tried to set up a meeting with an undercover witness posing online as a 13-year-old boy. Mr. McHaney was being held without bail pending a hearing today, said Channing Phillips, a spokesman for the United States attorney’s office for the District of Columbia.
Boston College announced a 10-year, $1.6 billion project to expand and renovate its campus and detailed its plans for a 65-acre tract it bought from the Archdiocese of Boston in 2004.

Julie Menin yesterday recalled the chaos in Lower Manhattan when the Deutsche Bank building began to burn on Aug. 18: Residents did not know whether to leave their apartments or stay inside, whether the air was safe to breathe or the fire was a result of another terror strike.
Vinny Prospal scored in the fourth round of a shootout last night for the Tampa Bay Lightning in a 4-3 victory over the visiting Ottawa Senators, who have now lost seven games in a row.
Having moved from shock to shared grief to quiet resolve, the Knicks will resume their season Wednesday evening with a point guard yet to be named.

;Tamir Fishman, an Israeli venture capital fund, and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development pulled out of a Russian investment project after a Russian partner boasted in a newspaper interview that he had backing from the F.S.B., the successor agency to the K.G.B., to force business owners in Russia to sell to him at below market rates. The Tamir Fishman Russian venture fund was intended for investment in high-tech start-ups, and would have received matching funds from the Russian government. In an interview with Kommersant newspaper, Oleg Shvartsman, a minority owner of the fund’s management company, described using ties to the F.S.B. to force private Russian business owners to sell out to companies with ties to Kremlin and F.S.B. insiders and “members of their families.” The European development bank said it was withdrawing from the project to protect its reputation.;Tamir Fishman, an Israeli venture capital fund, and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development pulled out of a Russian investment project after a Russian partner boasted in a newspaper interview that he had backing from the F.S.B., the successor agency to the K.G.B., to force business owners in Russia to sell to him at below market rates. The Tamir Fishman Russian venture fund was intended for investment in high-tech start-ups, and would have received matching funds from the Russian government. In an interview with Kommersant newspaper, Oleg Shvartsman, a minority owner of the fund’s management company, described using ties to the F.S.B. to force private Russian business owners to sell out to companies with ties to Kremlin and F.S.B. insiders and “members of their families.” The European development bank said it was withdrawing from the project to protect its reputation.

ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steel maker, will spend up to $1.75 billion to buy the rest of its Brazilian specialty steel unit. The company also agreed to buy the British steel distributor NSD. Separately, ArcelorMittal said its chairman, Joseph Kinsch, 74, would step down in May to be succeeded by Lakshmi Mittal, who led Mittal when it made a bid to acquire Arcelor.;ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steel maker, will spend up to $1.75 billion to buy the rest of its Brazilian specialty steel unit. The company also agreed to buy the British steel distributor NSD. Separately, ArcelorMittal said its chairman, Joseph Kinsch, 74, would step down in May to be succeeded by Lakshmi Mittal, who led Mittal when it made a bid to acquire Arcelor.

A suitor for the Nordic stock exchange operator OMX, the investment group Qatar Holding, has withdrawn its application to be considered a potential owner. The decision could clear the way for a joint $4.9 billion takeover bid for OMX by Borse Dubai and Nasdaq. The Qatar group owned under 10 percent of the shares in OMX and had applied for permission to buy up to 100 percent of the company, fueling speculation of a bidding contest.;A suitor for the Nordic stock exchange operator OMX, the investment group Qatar Holding, has withdrawn its application to be considered a potential owner. The decision could clear the way for a joint $4.9 billion takeover bid for OMX by Borse Dubai and Nasdaq. The Qatar group owned under 10 percent of the shares in OMX and had applied for permission to buy up to 100 percent of the company, fueling speculation of a bidding contest.

The Instinet unit of Nomura Holdings has delayed the start of its Canadian stock trading system until the middle of the first quarter to give investors time to adjust to new equity markets. Instinet said in June that it planned to bring its alternative trading system to Canada by the end of December. Instinet’s Chi-X Canada platform is one of at least three alternative trading systems being developed in Canada in the next year to compete with the TSX Group, owner of the Toronto Stock Exchange. Perimeter Financial plans to start its Omega ATS on Dec. 6 and Alpha Trading Systems, owned by a group led by six banks, plans to start its trading platform in late 2008.;The Instinet unit of Nomura Holdings has delayed the start of its Canadian stock trading system until the middle of the first quarter to give investors time to adjust to new equity markets. Instinet said in June that it planned to bring its alternative trading system to Canada by the end of December. Instinet’s Chi-X Canada platform is one of at least three alternative trading systems being developed in Canada in the next year to compete with the TSX Group, owner of the Toronto Stock Exchange. Perimeter Financial plans to start its Omega ATS on Dec. 6 and Alpha Trading Systems, owned by a group led by six banks, plans to start its trading platform in late 2008.

General Motors is pursuing a “significant” stake in Russia’s biggest automaker, OAO AvtoVAZ, as it seeks to expand outside North America, where sales and profit are stagnant. G.M. is “in the bidding process” for a portion of AvtoVAZ, a spokeswoman, Melisa Tezanos, said. She declined to say how much G.M. had offered or what percentage of the company G.M. was seeking. AvtoVAZ, based in Togliatti in central Russia, has said it wants a foreign partner to develop new vehicles.;General Motors is pursuing a “significant” stake in Russia’s biggest automaker, OAO AvtoVAZ, as it seeks to expand outside North America, where sales and profit are stagnant. G.M. is “in the bidding process” for a portion of AvtoVAZ, a spokeswoman, Melisa Tezanos, said. She declined to say how much G.M. had offered or what percentage of the company G.M. was seeking. AvtoVAZ, based in Togliatti in central Russia, has said it wants a foreign partner to develop new vehicles.

The Brazilian star Romario has attributed his failed drug test to a substance found in anti-balding medication. Romario, a 41-year-old striker who was FIFA’s player of the year in 1994, said yesterday that he tested positive for the banned substance finasteride in October. He said he had been using the drug, whose active ingredient is Propecia, to prevent hair loss.;The Brazilian star Romario has attributed his failed drug test to a substance found in anti-balding medication. Romario, a 41-year-old striker who was FIFA’s player of the year in 1994, said yesterday that he tested positive for the banned substance finasteride in October. He said he had been using the drug, whose active ingredient is Propecia, to prevent hair loss.

Madison Square Garden announced that it would stage a heavyweight title fight Feb. 23 between Wladimir Klitschko of Ukraine and Sultan Ibragimov of Russia. The 31-year-old Klitschko (49-3, 44 knockouts) is recognized as champion by the International Boxing Federation and the International Boxing Organization. Ibragimov (22-0-1, 17 knockouts), 32, is the 2000 Olympic silver medalist and the champion of the World Boxing Organization. Their fight will unify three of the five heavyweight titles.;Madison Square Garden announced that it would stage a heavyweight title fight Feb. 23 between Wladimir Klitschko of Ukraine and Sultan Ibragimov of Russia. The 31-year-old Klitschko (49-3, 44 knockouts) is recognized as champion by the International Boxing Federation and the International Boxing Organization. Ibragimov (22-0-1, 17 knockouts), 32, is the 2000 Olympic silver medalist and the champion of the World Boxing Organization. Their fight will unify three of the five heavyweight titles.
The Mets’ plan to speak with free agent Liván Hernández, the veteran right-handed starter who went 11-11 last season with the Diamondbacks.

Clemson University gave Coach Tommy Bowden a contract extension after ESPN reported that Arkansas was focusing on Bowden to lead its program. Terms of the extension were not available, the team said in a news release. Bowden made $1.2 million this season. Bowden led Clemson to a 9-3 record and an appearance in the Chick-fil-A Bowl against Auburn on Dec. 31.;Clemson University gave Coach Tommy Bowden a contract extension after ESPN reported that Arkansas was focusing on Bowden to lead its program. Terms of the extension were not available, the team said in a news release. Bowden made $1.2 million this season. Bowden led Clemson to a 9-3 record and an appearance in the Chick-fil-A Bowl against Auburn on Dec. 31.

Karl Dorrell, U.C.L.A.’s ousted coach, has decided not to coach the Bruins when they play Brigham Young in the Pioneer Las Vegas Bowl on Dec. 22. Dorrell said yesterday that he thought it was in the team’s best interest if he was not at the game. DeWayne Walker, the Bruins’ defensive coordinator, will serve as the interim coach.;Karl Dorrell, U.C.L.A.’s ousted coach, has decided not to coach the Bruins when they play Brigham Young in the Pioneer Las Vegas Bowl on Dec. 22. Dorrell said yesterday that he thought it was in the team’s best interest if he was not at the game. DeWayne Walker, the Bruins’ defensive coordinator, will serve as the interim coach.

Archie Manning succeeded Ron Johnson yesterday as chairman of the National Football Foundation and College Football Hall of Fame. Manning, an All-America quarterback at Mississippi, was inducted into the Hall in 1989. He played 14 seasons in the N.F.L., and his sons Peyton and Eli are N.F.L. quarterbacks. Johnson, a running back, was inducted into the Hall in 1992. He played for Michigan and then seven seasons in the N.F.L.;Archie Manning succeeded Ron Johnson yesterday as chairman of the National Football Foundation and College Football Hall of Fame. Manning, an All-America quarterback at Mississippi, was inducted into the Hall in 1989. He played 14 seasons in the N.F.L., and his sons Peyton and Eli are N.F.L. quarterbacks. Johnson, a running back, was inducted into the Hall in 1992. He played for Michigan and then seven seasons in the N.F.L.
Religious rifts have flooded courts nationwide with civil lawsuits over church property, an area of jurisprudence where courts are notoriously uncomfortable.
Hillary Rodham Clinton is right that Barack Obama’s health care plan would leave out millions, but her plan probably would as well.

As sure as the weather grows cold and the holidays approach, dancers from American Ballet Theater and other major companies fan out to regional theaters for performances of “The Nutcracker,” a fixture in the world of dance and the minds of young ballerinas.
A federal lawsuit filed in California seeks to help legal immigrants whose petitions for citizenship have been held up by delays in background checks performed by the F.B.I.
There is a lot of good news in the latest intelligence assessment about Iran. But there’s also a lot of worrisome news in there that must not be overlooked.

Federal immigration authorities arrested twice as many illegal immigrants in New Jersey in the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30 as they did during the previous one, according to figures released yesterday. Of the 2,079 people arrested on immigration charges during the last fiscal year, 270 had criminal histories in addition to being in the country illegally, the federal Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency said.

Illegal immigrants who live in Manhattan and have been victims of violence, fraud or other crimes, or who are aware of illegal activity, can now report the episodes without fearing arrest and deportation. The Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, announced yesterday that he had created a unit to address issues that confront immigrants, whether they are legal residents or not, and to prosecute people who prey on them. “Everyone who comes here is entitled to the full protection of the law,” Mr. Morgenthau said.

A governor’s task force yesterday recommended shrinking the size of drug-free school zones in New Jersey. The task force recommended shrinking the zones by 80 percent, to 200 feet around schools, but increasing mandatory prison time for people convicted of dealing drugs in them. Gov. Jon S. Corzine said the recommendation was reasonable. It is similar to a proposal made two years ago by a state commission. The State Senate president, Richard J. Codey, who has opposed attempts to weaken the school zone law, said he would not block the proposal from a vote in the Senate.

Two men have been arrested and charged with brandishing handguns during a bank robbery in Piscataway on Nov. 10 in which they took more than $93,000, according to complaints filed with the United States attorney’s office. One of the men, Ruben Rosado, pointed his pistol at bank employees and customers as they lay on the floor, while the other, Michael Green, vaulted over the tellers’ counter at Investors Savings Bank and dumped cash from the registers into a bag before the duo fled in a stolen car, the complaints charged. Mr. Green was arrested after a witness led the police to a barbershop in Perth Amboy, court papers said. Mr. Green identified his accomplice as Mr. Rosado, the papers said. He appeared in federal court on Monday and was being held without bail, said Michael Drewniak, a spokesman for the United States attorney in New Jersey. Mr. Green pleaded not guilty yesterday to one count of armed bank robbery and was being held pending a bail hearing, said his lawyer, Richard Verde.

A unanimous State Supreme Court upheld a death sentence for the convicted killer Ambrose Harris yesterday, ruling that the special circumstances that recently removed another inmate from death row did not apply to Mr. Harris, 55. He was sentenced to death in 1996 for murdering Kristin Huggins, 22, of Lower Makefield, Pa., after kidnapping and raping her in 1992. In a decision last year, the court overturned the death sentence of another inmate, Anthony DiFrisco, based on the type and timing of reviews in his case. The State Legislature is considering abolishing the death penalty in New Jersey, a move that Gov. Jon S. Corzine supports.

A federal appeals court yesterday upheld the corruption conviction of former Mayor Joseph P. Ganim, rejecting claims that his sentence was unreasonable and that prosecutors engaged in misconduct. The decision, from the Federal Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, found that Mr. Ganim, who was convicted in 2003 on 16 charges, did not merit a reduced sentence because of the severity of his offense. Mr. Ganim, who was first elected in 1991, was serving his fifth term as mayor when he was indicted in 2001. Compiled by John Sullivan.
A case before the Supreme Court offers a chance to redress an enormous wrong done by President Bush and Congress when they denied justice to a group of prisoners.
The Kansas City Royals and outfielder José Guillén have reached an agreement on a three-year, $36 million contract.

;An article in Business Day yesterday about a prosecution witness list for the coming fraud trial of five executives accused of helping the American International Group manipulate its finances misstated the nature of the fraud charges in one reference. As the article noted, prosecutors contend that A.I.G. used sham transactions to inflate its reserves, not its earnings.;An article in Business Day yesterday about a prosecution witness list for the coming fraud trial of five executives accused of helping the American International Group manipulate its finances misstated the nature of the fraud charges in one reference. In the first fallout from the Bloomberg administration’s controversial new school report cards, the city named six schools Tuesday that will be shut down after earning D’s and F’s.
Researchers believe the flu virus is more stable and stays in the air longer when air is cold and dry.
A federal judge has dismissed all but one charge in a lawsuit that challenged two Long Island Indian tribes over their practice of selling tax-free cigarettes from reservation smoke shops.

A lawsuit against New York City is the latest volley in a yearlong battle between a Christian Science church on Park Avenue and its well-to-do neighbors, who do not want the church building rented out for social events.
A couple who met at a Nazi transit camp in the Netherlands during World War II shared many moments together amid tortured times, then got married.
The sudden flight from a Florida investment pool points to a broader uncertainty among officials in other states over how far the credit and mortgage crisis might spread.
A prisoner cut his throat with his own fingernail last month, causing a substantial loss of blood, but was never at risk of death, military officials said Tuesday.
The University of Pittsburgh Medical Center will contribute up to $100 million to help pay college tuition for eligible high school seniors who graduate from the city’s public schools.

The Albany County district attorney has decided not to bring a perjury case against a former top press assistant to Gov. Eliot Spitzer at this point, though he has not ruled out revisiting the case next year.
The Nuclear Regulatory Commission should grant New York’s request to intervene in the relicensing process for the Indian Point nuclear power plant.
With early jockeying under way to win U.S. government approval for a new generation of nuclear reactors, ominous signs are emerging that the plans may not go smoothly.
Investors in junk mortgages helped create the subprime mess. Now they have to help clean it up.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 4 (AP) — One of two men accused of killing a Hudson Valley family of five in January was found guilty Tuesday after five hours of jury deliberations.
A former West German intelligence officer used a parliamentary committee hearing Tuesday to both insult and support his onetime ally, former Prime Minister Brian Mulroney.
The reduced violence in Iraq in recent months stems from three significant developments, all of which can be reversed, and on relatively short notice.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 4 — Telling him, “Not even the collar can protect you from prison,” Judge Janet Bond Arterton ordered a 37-month sentence Tuesday for the Rev. Michael Jude Fay, the Roman Catholic priest who admitted pilfering $1.3 million from the church he had led in Darien.
As Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama exchanged jabs this week, John Edwards found himself on the sidelines. And enjoying it.
Nearly five years after her husband died when the space shuttle Columbia broke apart over Texas, the astronaut’s widow has decided to put her grief in storage.
The leader of the Archdiocese of Los Angeles told fellow priests that he was assaulted last summer by a man who yelled angry statements about the sexual abuse of children by Roman Catholic priests.
Tempelhof Airport is known for one of the most important stories in aviation history, the Berlin Airlift of 1948 and 1949.
A set of accords puts Bosnia on the road to eventual membership in the European Union.
Afghanistan’s most senior government and military leaders appealed for more money, weapons and security trainers.
Sergio Gómez, the lead singer of the popular Norteña group K-Paz de La Sierra, was found dead along a highway on Monday.
China ordained Joseph Gan Junqiu, a priest who has publicly declared his fidelity to Pope Benedict XVI, as a bishop of Guangzhou.
A police raid over the weekend at a Jewish community center in Caracas by about two dozen armed security agents was ostensibly a search for weapons.
In Las Vegas, a lawsuit over who can use the Plaza name has been filed by the owner of a Plaza hotel in the city's decaying downtown core.
A new agreement sets out the details governing the operations of Blackwater and other private security contractors in Iraq.
Across the United States, the number of severe rainfalls and heavy snows has grown significantly in the last half-century.
A Louisiana murder case in which a black man was convicted by an all-white jury is back before the Supreme Court.
Neighbors recalled a woman whose skeletal remains were found this week, nearly two years after she began to ignore neighbors and dropped out of sight.
The force-out rule is where football meets figure skating. Cue the fuzzy criteria. Cut to the controversy.
After devastating wildfires swept through rural and suburban San Diego County, regional officials have taken a step toward establishment of a consolidated countywide fire service.

The decision by the Bank of Canada on Tuesday to cut its key interest rate by a quarter-point, to 4.25 percent, will probably do little to help exporters struggling to cope with a rising Canadian dollar.
The South Plaquemines High football team, which will be playing for the Louisiana state title, has provided a symbol of resilience for a vulnerable region.

Congress is poised to act on the first bill to increase vehicle fuel efficiency significantly since 1975 and on the first economywide bill to address global warming since scientists raised the alarm in the late 1980s.

As far as Eric Rabinowitz knew, there was no problem with the checks from an insurance company that he had been receiving since he was a teenager, for damage to his right eye. His limited vision prevented him from holding a regular job, and he depended on the insurance money to pay for his apartment and other expenses.
Norman Hsu was indicted on mail and wire fraud charges and violating federal election law.
The two companies are looking to promote cellphones as media devices and develop new revenue for a music industry struggling with piracy.

The Giants placed Derrick Ward, their leading rusher, on injured reserve yesterday, two days after Ward broke his left leg against the Bears.

Ms. Hardwick set her ambitions on becoming a member of New York’s glittering intellectual elite and then achieved them, as a critic, essayist, fiction writer and a co-founder of The New York Review of Books.
Federal regulators Tuesday denied a request by Verizon Communications to let it charge rival carriers higher rates to get access to lines in six East Coast markets.
The states sued the maker of Camel cigarettes , contending that a promotion in Rolling Stone magazine violated a 1998 agreement not to use cartoons in its marketing efforts.
Since the 1990s, a growing economic disparity has emerged between prosperous cities and depressed rural areas.
Billy King, team president and general manager, was fired on Tuesday and replaced with the Nets’ general manager, Ed Stefanski.
The space shuttle Atlantis is poised for a Thursday launching to the International Space Station on an 11-day mission that will make the orbital outpost more international.
Hundreds of Iraqi refugees have been caught in a dragnet of heightened security in Lebanon after a showdown between an international jihadist group and the Lebanese security forces over the summer.
Delta Air Lines and Southwest Airlines will scale back seating-capacity plans for next year on mounting concern over high oil prices and a weakening United States economy.
The tax preparer said on Tuesday that it was closing its mortgage-lending arm after the sale of the subprime unit fell through.
The Flushing Remonstrance, which has been called the religious Magna Carta of the New World, goes on display at the Queens Public Library in Flushing.
The company announced Tuesday that it was cutting 1,000 jobs, or about 2.3 percent of its work force, as part of a plan to rid itself of underperforming businesses and increase efficiency.
Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said Tuesday that it had hired Rodrigo de Rato as a top executive for its investment banking unit.
Retreating oil prices and signs of strength in industries outside the financial sector could not keep the stock market from declining for a second day Tuesday.
The Cordis Corporation, a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, has begun the first attempt by a medical device maker to market a heart stent directly to consumers.
The personal computer maker said it would resume its stock-buyback program with a $10 billion repurchase, the first since it restated four years of earnings.
Last week the Supreme Court heard arguments about whether the manufacturer of a medical device approved for sale by the F.D.A. can be sued for damages under state law if the device injures a patient.

Gillian Gibbons, the British teacher jailed in Sudan for more than a week for allowing her pupils to name a teddy bear Muhammad, arrived back in Britain and said she was ''very upset to think that I may have caused offense to people.'' She told reporters after landing at Heathrow Airport that she had gone to Sudan ''to have an adventure and got a lot more adventure than what I was looking for.'' She declined to be drawn into a discussion of the merits of the case against her, saying ''it's a very delicate area.''

DELGADO--Debra Y. The Atlantic Philanthropies mourns the passing of Debra Delgado, a wonderfully fun and compassionate woman known for her unflagging advocacy on behalf of children and youth and for her infectious laugh, her uncommon wisdom and her common sense. She has left an indelible mark on us and on all those who had the privilege and pleasure of knowing her. Through her work at Atlantic, The Annie E. Casey Foundation, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation's Program Office for School - Based Health Care, the Title X Family Planning Program for the District of Columbia, Planned Parenthood of Metropolitan Washington, the Los Angeles Free Clinic and the Watts Health Foundation, Debra used her instinctive leadership skills to give voice to the needs and aspirations of the most vulnerable among us. Our thoughts are with Debra's husband, Warren Simmons, her family and extended family, and the many people whose lives have been graced by her presence.

SEATTLE, Nov. 26 -- For all the fame of the rain in this soggy city, conversations about climate often lead to local defensiveness: Seattle, which averages about 38 inches of rain annually, is far from the country's wettest big city. Atlanta, Boston, Houston, Miami and New York are just some of the others that get more rain. The rain here has made its name mostly through persistence, not volume. It plays bass, not lead guitar. And not every complaint about precipitation involves wanting less.

Former President Bill Clinton is not happy with the way the news media are covering the presidential campaign, telling students at Keene State College in New Hampshire yesterday that too much focus is put on ''pure politics'' and not enough on the candidates' experience. ''One percent of the press coverage was devoted to their record in public life,'' Mr. Clinton said while campaigning for his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, in New Hampshire. ''No wonder people think experience is irrelevant. A lot of the people covering the race think it is.''

An article in Science Times on Nov. 27 about a study showing that some men with deeper voices have more children referred imprecisely to the language of the research subjects, the Hadza of Tanzania. Although the research was conducted in Swahili, it is neither the first nor the only language of the Hadza; most are bilingual and speak their native language, Hadza.

VITON--Albert, Ph.D., born Azriel Levitan, son of Shlomo Yehuda and Chana Siev Levitan. Born in Tver, Lithuania, on May 28, 1913, died November 28, 2007, in Washington D. C., of congestive heart failure at the age of 94. His family immigrated to the U.S. when he was in his teens. He received his BA, MA and Ph.D. from Northwestern University. Prior to completing his doctorate, he was a journalist reporting from Palestine, after which he joined the US Department of Agriculture. In the early 1940s, he was responsible for determining the fair allocation of wartime food and gas rationing coupons for U.S. citizens with the Office of Price Administration. After the war, he joined the Commodities Division of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations in Rome, Italy, where he rose to the rank of Senior Division Director. He became an expert in sugar, coffee, tea and cocoa, and played a significant part in the negotiation of international trade agreements in these commodities. He was a prolific writer, contributing to numerous journals and magazines, and authored many technical reports relating to commodity pricing and its economic impact. His last book, The International Sugar Agreements: Promise and Reality was published in 2004. Upon his retirement in 1976, he and his wife returned to McLean, Virginia, where he continued his work on commodities as a private consultant. His wife, Elaine Hofsteede, to whom he was married for 58 years, predeceased him in 1993. In November 2004 he moved to Washington, DC. where he resided until his death. He is survived by his three siblings David, Max, and Charlotte, and by his children Philip, Karen and Gail, and by three grandchildren.

GANTMAN--Julius. The Justices of the New York State Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department mark with sadness the passing of a great friend of the Court. As a valued member of the Character and Fitness Committee, he served the Court with distinction for many years. Jonathan Lippman Presiding Justice GANTMAN--Julius, 97, Insurance Executive. Mr. Julius Gantman, who served as a senior executive and member of the Board of Directors of Public Service Mutual Insurance Company died at his home in Westchester on Sunday, December 2, 2007. He was 97. At the time of his death, Mr. Gantman was one of three senior members of the Executive Committee of the Board of Directors having been named to the Board in November 1977. Mr. Gantman joined Public Service Mutual Insurance Company's legal department in 1942 and served in various leadership positions until his retirement from active employment in May 1980. ''Julie will always remain an important and colorful part of our Magna Carta history and will be sorely missed by all,'' said Andrew L. Furgatch, Chairman of the Board of Public Service Mutual Insurance Company, an affiliate of Magna Carta Companies. Mr. Gantman earned both his undergraduate degree and bachelor of laws degree from St. John's University in New York. The Magna Carta Foundation established the Julius Gantman Scholarship Fund at St. John's University School of Risk Management, Insurance and Actuarial Science (formerly the College of Insurance) in 2003. On behalf of the entire Public Service Mutual and Magna Carta family, we extend our heartfelt sympathy to his many children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. The Board of Magna Carta Companies

WOLMAN--Benson. The American Civil Liberties Union and its Board of Directors mourn the death of Benson Wolman, a longtime civil rights lawyer and a champion of the poor. Wolman was a former member of the ACLU National Board and past executive director of the Ohio affiliate. Wolman died on Friday. He was 71 years old. Wolman's heart was always with the ACLU and he remained a volunteer attorney even after he left the organization and went into private practice. It was in that role that he won Pinette v. Capitol Square Review Board, a major Supreme Court free speech decision in 1995. Wolman joined the ACLU in the 1950s to defend First Amendment rights and due process, and stayed on to help the organization as it fought on other fronts, including leading the Ohio affiliate from 1969 to 1986. His work during that period on behalf of the Kent State University shooting victims was a great source of pride for him. Under his leadership, the case, entitled Krause v. Rhodes, reached a settlement on behalf of the students who were killed or injured when the National Guard opened fire on them during a May 1970 college protest. Although his base was in Columbus, Wolman's influence extended far beyond Ohio. In 2005 he became chief executive and general counsel of the Equal Justice Foundation, a nonprofit agency that represents people disenfranchised by the legal system.

(TCM) THE MEN WHO MADE THE MOVIES: WILLIAM WELLMANTurner Classic Movies pays tribute to Wellman, one of Hollywood's most prolific filmmakers and toughest taskmasters, beginning with this documentary. The evening continues with the Wellman films ''Wild Boys of the Road'' (1933), in which an impoverished girl (Rochelle Hudson) masquerades as a boy to run with a gang of young hobos, at 9; ''The Ox-Bow Incident'' (1943), about a posse hunting suspected rustlers, starring Henry Fonda (above, with May Beth Hughes), Dana Andrews and Anthony Quinn, at 10:30; ''The Public Enemy'' (1931), with James Cagney as a punk trying to make it big in organized crime, at 1 a.m.; ''The Star Witness'' (1931), with Grant Mitchell as an old man threatened by gangsters, and Walter Huston as a district attorney, at 2:30; and Wellman's last film for Warner Brothers, ''Heroes for Sale'' (1933), with Richard Barthelmess as a veteran fighting drug addiction, at 3:45. 8 P.M. The signature dessert at Gotham Bar and Grill is a flourless cake with an almost souffléed lightness and a deep chocolate soul. And now you can make it the grand finale of your next dinner party at home, serving it warm, just as the restaurant does. The 10-inch cake is rich enough for at least 12 people. It is shipped frozen and must be removed from the freezer or refrigerator one hour before it is warmed. Put it, still wrapped in its heavy-duty plastic, in a 200-degree oven for at least 30 minutes and up to three hours. The plastic will not melt, but do not use a microwave oven. Let the cake stand about 15 minutes more before removing the wrap and cutting it.

At the end of a busy day, putting a home-cooked meal on the table without a lot of prep work is a real bonus. Get Fresh in Brooklyn is the latest shop in the city to offer all the ingredients for a meal -- sliced, seasoned and packaged together. Kelley Roy and Caroll Lee, the owners, sell mostly raw components; the customer does only the final cooking, like searing pork chops and then baking them with the apples and cider glaze they come with. I found it easy to boil pumpkin ravioli, brown the accompanying pine nuts and then add Swiss chard and its sauce mixture. Steak au poivre for two is $43.95, with lots of potatoes -- not cheap, but featuring excellent grass-fed boneless rib-eyes. Some dishes, including soups and macaroni and cheese, are fully cooked and need only be heated and served.

As recently as three years ago, if you told a top game industry executive that your favorite genre was online PC games, you would almost invariably provoke a reaction akin to telling a television mogul that your favorite shows explain the migration patterns of obscure African fauna. In other words, you would get the verbal equivalent of a condescending pat on the head -- ''Oh, that's nice'' -- while the executive looked around for someone with something more relevant to say. And if you had dared suggest that an online fantasy game made by some guys in Orange County, Calif., would become a worldwide phenomenon by attracting more players in China than in the United States, you would have been laughed out of the room.

The president of the Senate, Renan Calheiros, left, resigned the post to avoid being expelled from Congress by his fellow senators. An important ally of President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, he became the latest political casualty in a series of corruption investigations that have dogged the president this year. The accusations against Mr. Calheiros included using funds from a lobbyist to pay the child support of a daughter from an extramarital affair with a television journalist who leveraged the scandal into a spread in Brazilian Playboy. In September, the Senate voted by secret ballot against impeaching him, even after the Ethics Committee concluded that he had failed to show legitimate income to cover his expenses. Public outrage subsequently forced Congress to eliminate the secret ballot in cases of ethics violations.

GOLDHILL--Paul. Sadly we lost an old friend, he will be missed. Patti and Herb Frumkes GOLDHILL--Paul, M.D. My mentor, my healer and my best friend. To his dear wife Elaine, his children, and grandchildren. He will always be remembered for his great compassion for life. Joanie Vogel

Will Rudolph W. Giuliani's decision to pull back from the direct management of his consulting and law firms insulate him from questions about the firms' activities? His presidential campaign has repeatedly faced questions about the firms' work for its clients. John G. Geer, a professor of political science at Vanderbilt and the author of ''In Defense of Negativity: Attack Ads in Presidential Campaigns'' (University of Chicago Press, 2006), said the ties to the firms would probably remain a campaign issue.

STRAUSS--Anne. Service Guild Auxiliary of Long Island Jewish Medical Center extends sincere condolences to the family of our late beloved Anne Strauss. Longtime board member and Chairwoman of our Babies Alumni Communitee. Isabel Albom, President

An article in Business Day yesterday about a prosecution witness list for the coming fraud trial of five executives accused of helping the American International Group manipulate its finances misstated the nature of the fraud charges in one reference. As the article noted, prosecutors contend that A.I.G. used sham transactions to inflate its reserves, not its earnings.

KRASNOV--Vivian. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and former Executive Director and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Howard A. Stecker, Sr. Rabbi Hon. Richard Kestenbaum, Pres. KRASNOV--Vivian, of Great Neck, NY, died on December 4, 2007. Funeral will be at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, in Great Neck, on Thursday, December 6, 2007 at 11:30am.

GALLAGHER--William J., was special Counsel to the Inspector General in the NYS office of Court Administration. Died on December 3, 2007. Bill was with the Office of the Inspector General for the last 20 years. Prior to this he was Director of Administration for the Courts of New York. Bill has also held the position of Deputy Attorney and Chief, Legal Aid Society, Attorney in charge, Legal Aid Society, New York City, from 1974 to 1977. He was a graduate of Fordham University receiving a BS in 1959 . He received his law degree from Brooklyn Law School in 1963. Bill belonged to many outstanding organizations and clubs. He has been a recipient of many awards. One award that he was proud of having received is the Police Department Honor Legion Award for Heroism. Another award he was very proud of was The Man of the Year award presented by the Emerald Society, New York State Courts. Bill had many memorable moments in his life that he was proud of. One of them was the time he worked at the Vacation Camp for the Blind and learned to sign. He was the owner/manager of the famous St. George Hotel Pool for many years in Downtown Brooklyn. Bill is survived by his children Elizabeth, Dawn Marie, Sean, Matthew, his sister Maureen Gallagher and aunt Alice Walsh. Wake service will be held at F. G. Guido Funeral home at 440 Clinton St., Brooklyn, NY 11231 on the corner of Carroll, Wednesday 6-9pm, and Thursday 4-9pm. Mass of Christian burial Friday, 9:45am, at St. Charles Borromeo R. C. Church. Interment immediately following at Greenwood Cemetery.

Shaik Mohammed, center, immigrated from Afghanistan with his family 19 years ago. He sought warmth on Monday outside his business, Queens Muffler Shop, in an area sometimes called the Iron Triangle, near the Willets Point station of the No. 7 train. He says the business has helped put his wife through dental school.

LEIBOWITZ--Marian Louise (Mickey Fargotstein), July 26, 1920-December 1, 2007. Beautiful, sensitive, creative and artistic woman who was a loving wife, mother, and grandmother to Herb, David, Mark, Kass, Matt and Nick. From Pittsburgh, to Pismo Beach, to Los Angeles, New York City, Gallup, NM, Santa Fe, Bombay, India, to Berkeley, CA. An incisive and bright social worker, rehabilitation consultant and elementary school counselor, she made consistent contributions. A student at Carnegie-Mellon, the University of Pittsburgh, Columbia University and the University of California, Berkeley, she was always learning and growing. A lively and loving spirit, she will be greatly missed. Memorial contributions can be made to a local hospice.

It seems appropriate that the renovation of Washington Square Park would involve six years of planning, arguing and fighting. After all, a spot that has played host to marching suffragists, picketing workers and protesting beatniks should not ease into changes without a brickbat or two, even if they are only rhetorical. But after all the shouting, the city’s proposal to shift the park’s fountain into direct line with the Washington Square Arch, add more lawn and spruce up the statues and fixtures finally seems about to move forward. In a decision issued on Monday, a judge dismissed two remaining claims against the renovation plan. Filed on behalf of community activists, the lawsuits claimed that the city’s Department of Parks and Recreation plan would violate environmental rules and alter the nature of the park.

Murray Klein, who swept floors and stocked the shelves for Louis Zabar before becoming the managing partner of Zabar’s and transforming it from a modest deli into a venerable food emporium, died today at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 84. The cause was lung cancer, according to Roger Klein, his son.
What we are reading elsewhere…

X Dreams, an adult entertainment business in an industrial section of West Babylon, N.Y., has a lot of regular customers, who pay cash for lap dances, pornographic videos and admission to the erotic theater.

The decision to decentralize management of the subway system could significantly affect riders’ experiences of the New York City subways. As William Neuman reported, New York City Transit plans to appoint a general manager for each subway line. The new managers will be responsible for almost all day-to-day operations on the line — stations, tracks, train cars and announcements — in an effort to improve accountability and responsiveness to customer opinion.

For the 91st year, members of the St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox parish in Lower Manhattan gathered on the day in the liturgical calendar that honors the namesake of their church. For the seventh year, they had no church in which to gather.

Kristen Kane, one of the most trusted advisers to Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, stepped down today as the chief operating officer of the Department of Education. Ms. Kane’s departure represents a significant loss for the department; she was one of the officials hired by the chancellor and gained a reputation for being extremely hard working and an important behind-the-scenes organizer of the department.“Kristen’s contribution to our city and schools has been incalculable,” Mr. Klein said in a statement. “She helped to shape and manage virtually every significant initiative of recent years, and her skill and dedication made her a model of public service. I am deeply grateful to Kristen for her work and wish her the best.”

The neighborhood on Broadway south of Macy’s may already be getting a new nickname, SoMa, but will New York coffee lovers soon call it Stumptown?There has been speculation that Stumptown Coffee Roasters, the chain of cafes and “roasteries” based in Portland, Ore., might be planning an outpost in the lobby of the Ace Hotel, a Portland transplant that is scheduled to open on 29th Street and Broadway in 2009.

Updated, 4:10 p.m. | The more you think about it, the more unlikely the undetected death of Christina Copeman comes to seem. A colleague said to me, “If you purposely set out to die in your house in New York City and not be found for two years, you couldn’t do it.”

For the last 25 years, Assemblyman Dov Hikind has been a fixture in Albany and in state politics. And he has also been a fixture — really, something of a political don — in his district, which is anchored in Borough Park, Brooklyn. But Mr. Hikind recently indicated that he might be looking to reduce his commuting time, and he is giving consideration to running for the City Council seat currently held by Simcha Felder.

New York City Transit is to announce an overhaul today of how the subway system is managed. As William Neuman reports, the changes will give individual subway lines a greater degree of autonomy by putting each one under the direction of a manager who will be responsible for almost everything that happens on the tracks, in the trains and in the stations. The goal is to have each subway line operate, in many ways, as a self-contained railroad. The 24 lines will compete against one another and be rated on service, cleanliness, on-time performance and other measures.

There was plenty of hardware handed out tonight (most of it down in Florida) to honor college football's best. Florida's Tim Tebow won the Davey O'Brien Award as the nation's top quarterback and the Maxwell Award as the best player (according to the Maxwell Memorial Football Club). Arkansas's Darren McFadden won the Walter Camp Award honoring the best player (given out by the Walter Camp Foundation) and the Doak Walker Award, given to the top running back. McFadden also won the Doak Walker last year. These awards will only serve to fuel the Heisman talk heading into this weekend. Meanwhile, Dan Connor won the Chuck Bednarik Award as the best defensive player, making it three consecutive years that a Penn State linebacker has won it (Paul Posluszny won the previous two). "Broadcast at least one reality show every weeknight" appears to be NBC's New Year's resolution.

Jason Blake has found himself in the middle of all kinds of unwelcome stories this season, his first with the Toronto Maple Leafs after signing there as a free agent. It was supposed to be a triumphant move for Blake, who spent most of seven years playing for the Islanders, where he scored a career-high 40 goals last season.

Countrywide Financial is one of the downtrodden stocks that rallied today on the government's plan to push creditors to give some subprime homeowners a break in order to let them keep their homes. Why is it good for a lender to be forced to make concessions to borrowers? Beats me. Perhaps the theory is that this will make investors in mortgage securities more willing to accept modifications that will keep borrowers in their homes (and keep servicing fees flowing to Countrywide).

Richard Prince's mega-retrospective at the Guggenheim may be called "Spiritual America," but the artist does not necessarily have God on his side. I mean, could it really be coincidental that just as the exhibition was coming together this summer, his Guggenheim-owned installation in upstate New York, "Second House," was struck by lightning and burned to the ground? Meanwhile, here in Miami Beach, the intersection of Booth C-13 (White Cube Gallery) and Booth C-16 (Hauser & Wirth) at Art Basel marks an interesting nexus of un-American activity. On one corner, Christoph Buchel weighs in with "Training Ground for Training Ground for Democracy," a raucous two-story kindergarten cum internment camp that is simultaneously a prequel and a riposte to the Swiss artist's ill-fated Mass MoCA show. On the opposite corner, White Cube throws a double punch with Tracey Emin's tri-color neon wall sculpture "Red, White and [f-bomb deleted] Blue," and Liza Lou's bewitching "Black Flag," which gives new meaning to the words Star Spangled Banner.
Mitt Romney's speech drew inevitable comparisons to another speech from a half-century earlier by John F. Kennedy.
The galleries of 19th-century European painting and sculpture are a popular attraction at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

In his latest post, Altidore discusses training camp in California and the coming trip to China with the United States men's Olympic team for games on Dec. 13 in Changsha and Dec. 16 in Guangzhou. The squad leaves Friday from Los Angeles, the start of a trip that is expected to take 20 hours, or more.

Shareholder activists have been unusually vocal this year. But that doesn't mean they've been more successful, a new report by Thomson Financial finds.

Scoring a room at the writer Brian Antoni's house is possibly the ultimate stay in town. Just ask the German painter Anselm Kiefer, who described Antoni's hodgepodge of quirky objets trouvée mixed with pieces like a classical self-portrait bust by Antoni's sister, Janine, as "the best art in America." Not only is the house enlightening, but Antoni, whose book "South Beach: The Novel" is due out from Grove Atlantic in February, is just the kind of tour guide you want. His reserve of gossip from Miami days past is perfect breakfast fodder. Just ask regulars like Jeffrey Deitch, Ellen Barkin or Patrick McMullan (who, we hear, has been sporting a bed-head look at Antoni's all week). Take that, Andre Balazs!

The long and winding road has finally brought the duo of Matt Meyers and Mike Ogle back to New York. These two have been on the road for three months for CSTV.com (with weekly dispatches for The Quad), checking out the wacky happenings on the college football landscape. Their final stop was the Big 12 title game in San Antonio, where they encountered some excited Missouri alums and a singing Lee Roy Selmon. It's been quite a trek for these two and we're glad they shared their adventures with The Quad.

The King of Spain achieved momentary Internet stardom when his tirade at President Hugo Chávez hit YouTube. During the clip, Mr. Chavez seemed to hold his fire, but he did anything but that in another one is climbing the video site's charts today with 90,000 views so far.

Nature designed me for a big chair, one more than 31 inches from the chair in front of me. I'm pretty tall, perhaps more than adequately wide, and jumbo-footed. My feet, egads! The front-seat overhang of a taxi traps my foot every time. I thus prefer the bus or the subway. When I fly, I want my shoes parallel, north and south, not in an X shape. In addition, I dislike having to win an elbow rest through combat. Sounds like first class should suit me.
(John Loomis/Redux)

A few days ago, I was sent Al Gore's schedule for December. He (and his family and his aides) are flying first to Norway to pick up his Nobel Prize on the 10th, and then flying on to Bali for the climate conference there. OK, Al Gore is a real hero of the environmental movement, and has admirably helped galvanize the world to action.

I go way back with Jamie Langenbrunner, who was named Wednesday as the Devils' captain. I met him in October 1996, when he was in his first full season with the Dallas Stars and I was a reporter for the Dallas Morning News. He was 21, a skinny kid from Minnesota's Iron Range, and I remember talking to him one day about how he hated to sit around in the afternoons at his apartment waiting for games to start. He just seemed so young, as if he should still be playing at Cloquet High School.

"Imagine if other sports had such rampant disregard for their postseasons," Will Leitch writes about the B.C.S. system in this week's Play newsletter. "The Cubs would make the playoffs every year; the Packers would host a wild-card game even if they were 8-8; heck, the N.B.A. might even find a place for the Knicks. For all the talk of the B.C.S. being "impartial," the selection process for the non-title game bowls is steeped in the same cronyism and back-scratching we've been mired in for years."

To call Sisley a niche scent house is almost overstating it. A skincare brand, Sisley has only three perfumes, in limited distribution, and niche houses are usually associated with shock-the-bourgeoisie, Santiago-Calatrava-in-a-bottle olfactive modernity. Exhibit A: The "I'm so cool I can barely stand it" Hotel Costes scents.

Among Wall Street's big investment banks, one has remained an object of fascination and more than a little envy of late. We speak, of course, of Goldman Sachs, which has managed to avoid the subprime-related write-downs that its brethren have been forced to take. The firm was not even among those subpoenaed by Andrew Cuomo, New York's attorney general, for information related to its subprime-tied activities.

Pelikan Technologies, which makes a device for electronically extracting blood samples for glucose monitoring in diabetics, raised $69 million in venture funding. Clarus Ventures was the lead investor in the round, which also included new investors Bio*One Capital and Global Life Science Ventures.

Conflicts of interest are pervasive among executive compensation consultants, according to a Congressional investigation. Moreover, the inquiry found, consultants who do other work for companies while helping them devise executive pay recommended significantly higher pay packages than consultants who had no such additional relationships.

Canada Pension Plan Investment Board cut the debt portion of its NZ$1.8 billion ($1.4 billion) offer for 40 percent of Auckland International Airport to quell concern the deal would have tripled the airfield's borrowings.
Bells will be ringing, and carolers will be greeting the Upper East Side neighbors of Henry Kravis this morning.
Casual games maker WildTangent on Wednesday said it raised $20 million in debt funding from Hercules Technology Growth Capital.

The chairman of Baosteel Group, China's biggest steelmaker, has denied his company plans to lead a bid for mining giant Rio Tinto, saying the company lacks the resources to do so, reports said Thursday.

With the new National Intelligence Estimate this week coming to the surprising conclusion that Iran dropped its efforts to make a nuclear weapon in 2003, Hillary Rodham Clinton turned to an old friend on Wednesday to help boost her foreign policy credentials.

The effects of the mortgage market meltdown were in stark relief Thursday when Royal Bank of Scotland, announcing a 1.5 billion pound ($3 billion) writedown, saw its shares rise as investors expressed relief that the bank's situation wasn't worse.
It looks like Cerberus Capital Management, which bought a $7.4 bilion controlling stake in Chrysler in August, won't be able to able stop the the bleeding just yet at the ailing carmaker.
China Shipping Container Lines, the second-largest in Asia, attracted 2.6 trillion yuan ($351 billion) worth of orders for a stock sale, 170 times the amount available, according to Bloomberg News.
DundeeWealth surged 6.7 percent on speculation that Bank of Nova Scotia may buy the Canadian money manager to expand its mutual-fund business.
Most technology companies do not dare to go public in late December, when the market for initial public offerings is usually as chilly as the weather.
TPG, the U.S. buyout fund, may announce its biggest Japan acquisition as early as this week, investing 30 billion yen ($270 million) in lender NIS Group, Bloomberg News said.
Dana's hopes of an early 2008 emergence from bankruptcy were boosted Wednesday when a New York judge approved the auto parts maker's $2 billion exit financing package.
FilmBankers International of Beverly Hills, Calif., is raising a $200 million private equity fund to invest directly in U.S. independent films.

Wireless heart monitor developer CardioMEMS raised $33 million in a Series E financing to expand sales of an approved product for aneurysm patients and complete regulatory development and launch sales of a product for the larger heart failure market.
Air France-KLM Group, the world's biggest airline, said it will offer to buy Alitalia and revive the unprofitable carrier that the Italian government has been trying to sell for a year.
A federal jury on Wednesday convicted Stephanie Jensen, the former personnel director of Brocade Communications Systems, on charges of conspiracy and falsifying records.

When I finished law school in the recession of 1991, jobs were scarce. I didn't have a job upon graduation and that was fairly common. Young people entering the job market today face a far more welcoming workplace. And as increasing numbers of baby boomers retire, the newest members of the work force will have even more choices. This anticipated shortage of skilled labor has been called the "war for talent," and even if there is some dispute as to its grounding in fact, employers are behaving as if it's real. Last week one of the most e-mailed articles on The New York Times Web site was about a law firm employing a "happiness consultant" to make sure that everyone was feeling properly fulfilled. I expect to see more of this type of thing.
A lawyer has pleaded guilty to conspiracy to bribe a judge and is assisting federal prosecutors in a case involving one of the nation's wealthiest trial lawyers, according to court documents.

My third-floor study here in Washington looks out toward the old Naval Observatory a few blocks away. The Vice President currently lives inside the gates of the new Observatory - an 1890s improvement that took the astronomers to higher ground. This older one sprang from the vision of John Quincy Adams, who called for it in his 1825 State of the Union message. It wasn't his fault that the choice of a site - a malarial patch of land so often fogged over that the astronomers couldn't see anything - fell to one of his successors, John Tyler, more than fifteen years later.
Hmmm ... a post-prison business opportunity for Michael Vick?From K9 Magazine in Britain:
A former drug addict, Florent Mathurin scrambles to keep the life he built.
After years of banishment and disfavor, golf is rapidly taking root in Eastern Europe, according to the latest Golf Benchmark Study by KPMG, the consulting firm.

Marc Crawford's Los Angeles Kings are unwatchable, injuries are mounting and the goaltending situation remains lost in a black hole that was created back in the 1990s when Kelly Hrudey left Southern California after the 1995-96 season.
The next commercial you see for the March of Dimes may have been created by a viewer rather than an advertising agency.
Resort guides to help you navigate the slopes and their ski towns.
Pedro Ruiz’s “Club Havana” has become a signature work for Ballet Hispanico, and on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater it was easy to see why.
Practical presents for those who like to dig in the dirt.
Major League Baseball announced today that it has suspended two players linked to shipments of banned substances.

The C.I.A. destroyed videotapes in 2005 amid scrutiny about its secret detention program, according to government officials, raising questions about whether C.I.A. officials withheld information from the courts and the Sept. 11 commission.
It was Mr. Bush’s first direct communication with Kim Jong-il, the reclusive North Korean dictator.
Brushing aside a veto threat from the White House, the House today passed a package of energy measures that includes a 40 percent increase in fuel economy standards.
New Medicare rules for a small but promising class of cancer drugs may cause thousands of lymphoma patients to lose access to the treatment, which in some cases is the only therapy available to them.
The report lists proposals for how to unlock congestion at the airports and allow them to handle more traffic.
The European Central Bank, caught between fears of rising inflation and subsiding economic growth, left interest rates unchanged. But the Bank of England cut its key rate by a quarter-point.
NASA officials delayed the launch of the space shuttle Atlantis for at least 24 hours Thursday following problems with a pair of fuel sensors.
With some of the hosts paying the salaries of non-writing staff members, the strike has become a financial drain.
The move represented a bitter retreat for Senate Democrats who pledged to pay for any new tax cuts or programs rather than add to the federal deficit.
Muhtar Kent, Coke’s president and chief operating officer, will take over as chief executive on July 1, the company said today. He will succeed E. Neville Isdell, who will remain chairman.
After pressing China for a new effort to police the safety of its exports, the White House is meeting resistance.
Big chain stores this morning reported strong sales for November, led by department stores. But signs of trouble remain and shares of several major retailers fell sharply in early trading.
China said today that it had demolished the facilities of more than 2,800 rural food makers.
Officials today gave a more detailed chronology of what took place in an Omaha mall in the few minutes it took Robert Hawkins to kill eight people.

Louisiana State defensive tackle Glenn Dorsey won the Lombardi Award as the nation’s top college lineman or linebacker last night, his third individual honor in three days.The 6-foot-2, 303-pound Dorsey won the Bronko Nagurski Award on Monday, given to the nation’s top defensive player. He was named the Southeastern Conference defensive player of the year earlier yesterday. Despite playing the last five games of the season with a sore right knee, Dorsey finished with 64 tackles, 6 sacks and 11 ½ tackles behind the line.

Patrol officers shot a woman after a car chase in New Jersey last night, the police said. She collided with a police car, kept on driving, spun out of control and tried to hit another squad car, they said.

At least two of the men charged in the death of the  Redskins star Sean Taylor were involved in a burglary of his home days before his shooting death, a law enforcement official and a lawyer in the case said.

A Brooklyn man has been arrested in connection with the killing of a nightclub patron in Manhattan two weeks ago, the police said yesterday. The man, Anthony Taylor, 26, of 141 East 21st Street, in Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday in Atlanta and will be returned to New York, investigators said. The fatal attack, on Nov. 23, occurred about closing time at Duvet, a bar and club at 45 West 21st Street, in the Flatiron district. The victim, Shamel G. McKinney, 25, of Brooklyn, was stabbed once in the chest. A knife was recovered in a nearby trash bin, but investigators have not said whether it was the weapon used in the killing. They also have not commented on a motive.
Manu Ginóbili scored a season-high 37 points to help the host San Antonio Spurs overcome the absence of Tim Duncan to beat the Dallas Mavericks, 97-95, last night.

Patrik Elias scored his second goal of the game with 1 minute 44 seconds left in overtime last night, and the Devils extended their winning streak to eight with a 4-3 comeback victory over the Boston Bruins at the Prudential Center in Newark.
DaJuan Summers had 18 points and 9 rebounds last night as No. 5 Georgetown dominated the final few minutes to beat Alabama, 70-60, in Birmingham, Ala.

ALBANY, Dec. 5 — Senate Republicans charged on Wednesday that the Spitzer administration might have used a legal maneuver to make statements that top aides submitted to the attorney general’s office appear to be sworn affidavits when they were not.
A roadside explosion for which Tamil separatists were blamed tore through a passenger bus crowded with civilians, killing at least 15 people and wounding 23, the military said.

Natascha Kampusch, the teenager abducted on her way to school in 1998 and held prisoner for eight years, is to become the host of a television talk show, Austria’s national news agency, APA, reported.
The center-right government resigned after coming under intense criticism for trying to fire a popular anticorruption investigator.

A Santa Claus starting his fourth year at a store in Cairns said he had been fired for saying “Ho! Ho! Ho!” which, according to local reports, the recruitment agency Westaff, the country’s biggest Santa supplier, feels might frighten children and be seen as demeaning to women.
Thais celebrated the 80th birthday of their revered King Bhumibol, honoring the world’s longest-reigning monarch with festivities and prayers amid concerns about his declining health.
Policemen armed with riot shields and batons were called in to subdue angry tourists from the mainland who clashed with tour guides in the tiny gambling enclave of Macao, the police said.

Russia dispatched an 11-ship aircraft carrier group to the Mediterranean Sea, Defense Minister Anatoly E. Serdyukov said, as part of what he said was an effort to resume regular Russian naval patrols there and on the world’s oceans.
The government formally retired 37 judges who opposed President Pervez Musharraf’s imposition of emergency in the country last month and refused to take a new oath of allegiance to him.
President Evo Morales called for a nationwide referendum to decide whether he should stay in office as a way to resolve a deepening political crisis in the country.
Berlin officials broke ground this week for the construction of the Great Berlin Wheel, a 600-feet Ferris wheel that will top the London Eye by more than 160 feet to become the largest in Europe.
A gunman in camouflage and wielding a rifle opened fire in a mall crowded with holiday shoppers.

A judge ruled Wednesday against the claim of the founding principal of New York City’s first Arabic-themed school that her right to free speech was violated when she was forced out during a furor over comments she made in a newspaper interview.

Tyrone Willingham will return next season as Washington’s coach. The university confirmed the decision at Willingham’s end-of-season news conference. The briefing had been delayed amid speculation that Mark Emmert, the university’s president, was considering whether to fire Willingham, who is 11-25 in his three seasons.

Inter Milan and AS Roma posted comfortable victories to extend their lead atop the Italian league. Inter beat Lazio, 3-0, with a penalty kick from Zlatan Ibrahimovic and goals from Maicon and David Suazo. The Brazilian midfielder Rodrigo Taddei scored twice as Roma beat Cagliari, 2-0.

Everton, Atletico Madrid, Villarreal, Hamburger SV and FC Basel won yesterday to advance to the UEFA Cup’s Round of 32. Everton became the first English club to advance past the group stage when Tim Cahill scored in the 85th minute for a 1-0 victory over Zenit St. Petersburg.

Sean Sherk, the Ultimate Fighting Championship lightweight champion, had his suspension for steroids cut in half and can return to competition Jan. 6. The California State Athletic Commission reduced the one-year ban after a hearing in Los Angeles. Sherk was suspended for testing positive for nandrolone in July. The U.F.C. already had scheduled an interim lightweight title match between B. J. Penn and Joe Stevenson for Jan. 19 in Newcastle, England.

The University of Colorado has agreed to pay two women $2.85 million to settle a lawsuit alleging they were sexually assaulted by football players and recruits, university officials said yesterday. The allegations sparked a recruiting scandal, prompted university reforms and led to a shake-up of the university’s leadership. The agreement came two months after an appellate court revived the lawsuit.A Colorado spokesman said the university agreed to hire an adviser to monitor compliance with federal laws governing equal treatment of women and to add a position in the university’s Office of Victim Assistance.Hank Brown, the university’s president, called the decision “painful in some ways,” but he said the university faced years of litigation over the case.

Goalkeepers Hope Solo and Briana Scurry, who were at the center of a World Cup controversy, were invited to the United States women’s national team training camp by the new coach, Pia Sundhage. The camp will mark the beginning of the run to the 2008 Olympics in Beijing.
ALBANY, Dec. 5 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced on Wednesday that his top budget official would move to a key post overseeing New York’s myriad agencies and departments.
Seen by Democrats as too timid, the plan has limitations that are expected to exclude many subprime borrowers.
