The teenage birth rate in the United States rose 3 percent in 2006, the first increase since 1991, fueling a debate about whether the Bush administration’s abstinence-only sexual education efforts are working.
I realized that I had somehow long ago thrown out the notion of a “scenic drive,” a drive just for the pleasure of seeing what you can see.
New York City fire officials have prepared a proposed updated fire code that reflects a number of recent emergencies in the first major revision of the document in nearly a century.
After a one-day meeting in Abu Dhabi, OPEC cemented the impression that it wanted to keep oil prices at levels that would have been unthinkable a few years ago, leaving its output goal unchanged.
The data reflect deep racial disparities in the nation’s correctional institutions. In several states, incarceration rates for blacks were more than 10 times the rate of whites.
It was revealed Wednesday that the commissioner’s office and players union officials were discussing a penalty for José Guillén, who is believed to have received performance-enhancing substances.
The bill would be a major step toward passage of a measure that would for the first time slow and then reverse emissions of the gases that scientists blame for the warming of the planet.
Wall Street firms are coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.
The better approach for Kosovo, for all involved, would be an internationally supervised independence recognized by the United Nations.
With Project Sunlight, New Yorkers will start believing that somebody is telling them the truth about how their state really works.
President Bush isn’t interested in compromise even though the differences between the Democrats’ spending bills and his budget are not that large.
Pittsburgh defensive back Anthony Smith is so certain the Steelers will end the New England Patriots’ unbeaten season, he is guaranteeing a win Sunday in Foxborough, Mass.
Even as the beef industry spends hundreds of millions of dollars a year to keep harmful pathogens out of the meat it sells to the public, it appears to be losing ground.
Joanne P. McCallie, the 2005 Associated Press coach of the year at Michigan State, was hired to replace Gail Goestenkors after Duke was stunned in the N.C.A.A. tournament last season.
Ethanol advocates began a push Wednesday to allow ordinary cars to run on blends of 20 or 30 percent ethanol, compared with 10 percent currently.
A majority of the Supreme Court on Wednesday appeared ready to agree that detainees were entitled to invoke some measure of constitutional protection.
Baseball players would no longer receive bonuses for winning the Most Valuable Player, Cy Young or rookie awards under a rule passed Wednesday.
A federal appeals court blocked the rule under which the Bush administration allowed logging and burning projects in national forests without first analyzing their effects on the environment.

ALBANY, Dec. 5 — A state investigations commission on Wednesday subpoenaed the lawyer who used to oversee New York’s horse racing association, as part of an inquiry that comes amid strained negotiations between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the State Senate over whether the association will continue to run the state’s thoroughbred franchise.
Under an overhaul, subway lines would compete against one another and be rated on cleanliness, on-time performance and other measures.
Mr. Anderson’s accomplishments included discovering oil in Alaska, becoming America’s largest rancher and giving generously to environmental causes.
Advanced Micro Devices confirmed that a technical irregularity has delayed widespread availability of its Barcelona chip for servers until early next year.
A growing number of Sunni insurgents have relocated to Mosul and other places in northern Iraq.
The number of juvenile criminals in China has more than doubled over the past decade, as broken homes and a decline in social values have spurred youth delinquency.
Medical treatments are being delayed or deferred at hospitals worldwide because of the extended shutdown of a Canadian isotope reactor.
A federal advisory committee voted Wednesday that Genentech’s drug Avastin should not be approved as a treatment for breast cancer.
The financial health of the country’s biggest bond insurer, MBIA Inc., has been under greater threat from bad mortgage debt than it was thought to be weeks ago.
Conflicts of interest are pervasive among executive compensation consultants, according to a Congressional investigation.
Phil V. Donahue wants to be sent to Iraq and Afghanistan to help soldiers who want to vote in next year’s presidential primaries.

Five states, New York City and several groups filed petitions with the Environmental Protection Agency in an effort to force cuts in emissions of heat-trapping gases from airliners, a rapidly growing source.
A transported diner in the Catskills has reopened, and its backstory carries enough material for a reality show.
The Boy Scouts will be evicted from a Philadelphia municipal building for refusing to denounce the organization’s policy of prohibiting homosexuality.
Stephanie Jensen, the former personnel director of Brocade Communications Systems, was found guilty in a case stemming from options-backdating investigations.

Federal agents yesterday concluded a three-year drug investigation with six arrests, including that of a Newark police officer, the Drug Enforcement Administration said. D.E.A. officials said the group laundered about $7 million in proceeds from the sale of heroin. The officer, Michelle Davis, 35, was charged with money laundering, federal officials said. The authorities said the group operated in Essex and Union Counties. More than 100 officers seized sports cars, semiautomatic weapons and $50,000 in cash during raids, the D.E.A. said. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A state lawmaker proposed yesterday that New York create a $59 billion health insurance program that would cover everyone in the state and would probably be paid for through a tax increase. The plan, from Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, left, would generally replace the private health plans that now provide coverage to many people through their jobs. Assemblyman Gottfried, a Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the Health Committee, said the program would have to be paid for by new taxes, but he said that state residents would pay less than they now pay in premiums and deductibles. Critics said there was little evidence that the state could afford the program, or that it could do better than the current system.

A bicyclist riding northbound on the Avenue of the Americas yesterday morning died after he struck an open car door, fell off his bicycle and landed in the street, where he was hit by a truck, the police said. The cyclist, David Smith, 63, of West Ninth Street, was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead, the police said. The accident happened shortly before 8:30 a.m. in front of 989 Avenue of the Americas, near 36th Street, the police said. Mr. Smith, who was riding in a designated bicycle lane, hit the car’s door after someone on the passenger side opened it into his path, the police said. It was unclear if he was wearing a helmet. The police issued two summonses to the car’s driver, Benjamin Siano, 52, of Staten Island, for parking at a fire hydrant and for blocking a bicycle lane. They also issued a summons to his passenger, Augustus Browne, 31, of Staten Island, for opening a door unsafely into traffic, the police said.

The Spokane Police Department will remove crosses from its chaplain badges to settle a lawsuit filed by a Lutheran pastor-turned-atheist. “It’s a milestone,” said the plaintiff, Ray Ideus, 75, who volunteers eight hours a week for the department but not as a chaplain, and filed the lawsuit in 2006. “It’s very important that they’ll have to take that cross off. It’s not a Christian Police Department. The chaplains have to minister to all faiths and nonfaiths.” Chaplains’ badges included the city seal and a Christian-Latin cross. Chaplains may still wear lapel pins with crosses or other insignia.

Two teenagers died and three others were critically injured when their car struck a guard rail, became airborne for 100 feet and hit a concrete overpass pillar on a sharply curving exit ramp from the Van Wyck Expressway to the Nassau Expressway early yesterday, the police said. The car, a 2007 Dodge Charger, was being driven at a high rate of speed when the accident occurred at 12:45 a.m. near the northern border of Kennedy International Airport, investigators said. Two passengers, Devindra Harilall and Christopher Karan, both 18, were pronounced dead at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. Both lived in Ozone Park. A 17-year-old and two 19-year-olds, the other occupants of the car, were taken to the same hospital. The police declined to identify them, but said that they had life-threatening injuries.

The United States Supreme Court blocked the execution of a convicted murderer set for Thursday in Alabama. The reprieve was the latest granted since the court agreed on Sept. 25 to decide a challenge to the three-chemical mixture used in lethal injection procedures in Kentucky, procedures similar to those used in other states including Alabama. There was an execution in Texas on Sept. 25, but there have been none since then. The stay issued Wednesday in the case of Thomas Arthur will last until the court decides whether to take up Mr. Arthur’s request that it rule on his separate lethal-injection challenge. Mr. Arthur, 65, was sentenced to death for the killing in 1982 of Troy Wicker, 35, of Muscle Shoals.

The federal Department of Justice will not investigate Michael B. Nifong, the former Durham County district attorney, for his handling of the Duke University rape case, a spokesman for the agency said. The department decided the case was better resolved inside the state, said Peter Carr, the spokesman. Mr. Nifong pursued charges in the spring of 2006 against three Duke lacrosse players falsely accused of raping a stripper during an off-campus party. He was later disbarred.

The city will start implementing 132 energy-conservation projects in the next several months — the first in a series of steps aimed at reducing city energy consumption and greenhouse gas emission by 30 percent by 2017, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The projects, at a cost of $67 million, include installing energy-saving light bulbs and lamps in schools, police precincts and other municipal buildings and at landmarks including City Hall and the Brooklyn Bridge. The city will also upgrade the laundry system at Rikers Island to allow hot water to be filtered and reused, and will replace 200 of the most polluting vehicles in its 27,000-vehicle fleet with hybrid cars. Municipal government accounts for 6.5 percent of the city’s total energy usage and 10 percent of its peak electricity demand.

A Capitol Police officer was charged by a grand jury with setting a fire on Nov. 2 in a women’s bathroom in the Dirksen Senate Office Building. The federal indictment of the officer, Karen Emory, 36, of Waldorf, Md., did not mention at least six other fires in Senate office buildings since late September. Sgt. Kimberly Schneider, the Capitol Police spokeswoman, said investigations continue in the other fires, all but one in women’s restrooms. The Nov. 2 fire was quickly extinguished, and there were no evacuations or injuries.

The family of a white student, Justin Barker, who was beaten in December in Jena is filing a civil lawsuit against the LaSalle Parish School Board, the adult suspects in the beating, and the parents of the younger suspects. The suit accuses the school employees of failing to adequately supervise the students or maintain discipline. It also names all of the so-called Jena Six defendants, as well as a seventh student whose identity has not been released by law enforcement officials. This week, the lead defendant, Mychal Bell, pleaded guilty to a reduced charge of second-degree battery and was sentenced to 18 months in jail.
A study concluded that dyslexics were more likely than nondyslexics to excel in oral communication and problem solving and to own two or more businesses.

The Department of Education announced yesterday that it planned to close Far Rockaway High School in Queens and Public School 220 in the Bronx, weeks after both schools received poor marks under the city’s new school-grading system. P.S. 220, also known as the Mott Haven Village School, will shut its doors at the end of this school year, and Far Rockaway will stop accepting new students and be phased out over the next four years. The Mott Haven school has been plagued with problems for several years — in 2004, the city decided to restructure it by eliminating the middle school grades there. Both of the schools had already been on the state’s list of failing schools in danger of being shut down. Officials said they expect to announce within the next week up to 12 more schools to be closed.

The White House formally nominated a federal judge for the Justice Department’s No. 2 job yesterday, a day after the Senate Judiciary Committee chairman threatened to postpone confirmation hearings until next year. The chairman, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, had complained Tuesday that the White House had sent up formal nominations for only two of the people chosen to fill five top jobs at the Justice Department. Yesterday, he agreed to hold a hearing Dec. 19 for Judge Mark R. Filip of Federal District Court in Chicago, who has been nominated to serve as deputy attorney general.
Besides layoffs, the company said it would sell or close half its 27 manufacturing plants worldwide, farm out some manufacturing and winnow its portfolio of products.
A research note issued by Citigroup on Tuesday said 70 percent of Netflix’s return mailers must be sorted by hand.
Laveranues Coles’s ankle is still bad, but this Sunday, when the Jets play the Cleveland Browns at Giants Stadium, Coles seems sure to be there.
A free electrical outlet is manna for those in need of a charge, and many are finding that at the bus terminal in Manhattan.
The Bronx Symphony Orchestra is one of dozens of small arts organizations now competing for public money after a policy change by the city ended decades of automatic annual financing.
A lawyer has pleaded guilty to conspiracy to bribe a judge and is assisting federal prosecutors in a case involving one of the nation’s wealthiest trial lawyers.
Haunted by the memory of a violent accident in a race early last year, the 2006 Olympic men’s downhill champion, Antoine Dénériaz of France, announced his retirement Wednesday.
The British oil company BP and Husky Energy said they would form a joint venture linking a BP Ohio refinery with Husky’s Sunrise oil sands project in Alberta.
An international conference to ban cluster bombs was held in Vienna, Austria as part of the Oslo Process, which began in February when 46 countries agreed to consider a ban.
Manatees remain on Florida’s endangered species list, for now.
No freshman or sophomore has won the Heisman Trophy. But this year, Florida sophomore quarterback Tim Tebow is considered the favorite to win.

MINEOLA, N.Y., Dec. 5 (AP) — A man arrested with his neighbor’s decapitated head in the trunk of his car was sentenced to 30 years in prison on Wednesday over the objections of the victim’s family, who wanted him to face life without parole.
President Hugo Chávez’s political movement is being consumed by recrimination and soul-searching, with calls by some of his followers to embrace a more pluralistic path.
Mr. DeBlanc was a World War II fighter pilot who was awarded the Medal of Honor for shooting down five Japanese planes on a single day while running out of fuel.
The developers behind the plan to rebuild Pennsylvania Station are trying to lure Macy’s from Herald Square to a glass-enclosed mall that would sit inside the new train station.
A jury on Wednesday acquitted a man who spent more than 15 years on death row in Tennessee for the fatal shooting of a woman.
The United Nations and European Union must guide Kosovo on a path to independence as soon as failed negotiations with Serbia officially end on Monday.
Part of the Giants’ game planning in the coming weeks will include finding a balance between chasing regular-season victories and getting the team healthier for the playoffs.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,874 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:.
Mr. Payne was one of the first baritone saxophonists in the 1940s to master the intricacies of modern jazz and  for more than half a century was a leading exponent of his instrument.
Mr. Valdés, better known as Patato, was a giant of Latin jazz in Cuba and then for more than half a century in America.
After taking off their shoes, emptying their pockets and passing through the security checkpoint, travelers at some major American airports can now roll up a sleeve and get a flu shot.
Officials said that the smuggling scheme was one of the largest smuggling operations ever discovered.
Just 9 percent of chief financial officers said they were more optimistic about the economy in December than they had been three months earlier, a record low.
The agreement offered new momentum to stalled negotiations over what the former Yugoslav republic should call itself.
The LG Shine, available now from AT&T Wireless for $149 with a two-year contract and rebate, has a 2.2-inch screen with a reflective coating.
A promising employment report lifted stocks Wednesday, with the main indexes erasing two days of declines on renewed optimism about the outlook for the economy.
Congressional investigators pointed to faltering federal leadership, malfunctioning technology and overworked air traffic controllers.
Bears at Redskins.
Mark Zuckerberg, founder and chief executive of the social networking site Facebook, apologized to the site’s users about the way it introduced a controversial new advertising feature last month.
The janjaweed fighters are held responsible for attacks on black African villagers in a campaign that has caused at least 200,000 deaths.
We should be suspicious of any document that suddenly gives the Bush administration a pass on a big national security problem it won’t solve during its remaining year in office.
Motorola’s new Bluetooth headset, the Motopure H12, uses noise-canceling technology to filter out background noise so the user can hear the person on the other end.
The ear hears a surround system, but the eye sees only one device.
The iControl is a watch and receiver combination that connects to almost any iPod and the iPhone.
To the Editor:.
The Thirsty Light’s corrosion-resistant brass probe sits in the soil, and the tip reads the moisture level once a second.
